description: The Atlanta Braves took their flamboyant owner, Ted Turner, off the hook last night by beating the San Diego Padres, 9I, in Atlanta Stadium.

title: Finger Lakes Bad News for Bettors
description: They gotta be kidding, an offtrack bettor said yesterday when word spread that a horse named Robinski had won the first race at Finger Lakes.

title: ICELANDIC ACCORD SIGNED BY BRITAIN
description: OSLO, Norway, June I (AP) Britain and Iceland signed a temporary agreement today ending the sevenmonth dispute over fishing rights off Iceland.

title: 4YEAR U.S. NOTES COULD YIELD 7.65%
description: The fouryear notes that the Federal Government will self tomorrow will likely yield close to 7.65 percent, a rate somewhat lower than Wall Street auessed last week. The estimate Was lowered as the credit markets Credit moved toward Markets higher fixed  income prides and lower interest for the second trading day in a row.

title: Cuba Denies Exit Permits To Two Foreign Reporters
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June I (Reuters)Two foreign correspondents who entered Cuba to report on last week's United Nations seminar on apartheid were denied exit visas after the meeting closed at the weekend, officials said today.

title: The proposal to set up a national community service for girls leaving school at 16 and for others after graduating from high school appears properly revolutionary in France.
description: PARIS, June 1The French Government has given approval in principle to a fiveyear plan designed to move the status of women in this country closer to equality with men.

title: Television
description: 7:00 Tory Mexican Travel

title: ROMAN ROAD FOUND Pi OLD JERUSALEM
description: JERUSALEM, June 1 (UPI)Archeologists have uncovered a section of a 1,860yearold road in East Jerusalem in what Was termed the most important archeological find from the Roman period in Jerusalem.

title: 2 Motorcyclists Killed, 3 Hurt in Car Collision on L.I.
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., June 1 (UPI)Two Wantagh, Li., motorcyclists were killed and three of their companions seriously injured last night in a collision with two cars here, the Nassau County police reported.

title: Possible Takeover Of Maritime Fruit Is Cited in Londoni
description: LONDON, June 1The Maritime Fruit Carriers Company, the troubled IsraeliAmerican shipping company and a major customer of the British shipbuilding industry, may be taken over.

title: I.R.S. Studying Moon Sect's Tax Status
description: The Internal Revenue Service is conducting an investigation of the taxexempt status of the Rev. Sun Myong Moon's Unification Church and other Moonaffiliated organizations, according to Representative Peter A. Peyser, Republican of New York.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Merola Tells of Change In Court Procedures
description: Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola said yesterday that he had been assured by the Bronx Criminal Court that new procedures had been adopted to prevent incidents like the one last month in which a prisoner appeariffg under an alias was paroled by error even though he was held under his real name on more serious charges.

title: Potato Exchange Busy Deciding Default Penalties
description: Officials of the New York Mercantile Exchange, center of the Maine potato futures de1 bacle last week, convened after trading hours yesterday to set penalties against J. R. Simplot, the Idaho potato king; P. J. Taggares, another big factor in the industry, and their associates for defaulting on the delivery of 50 million pounds of Potatoes.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 1The $2.85 billion state budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1 was voted out of a joint legislative committee today and appeared to be headed for a bitter fight on the floor of the Legislature.

title: ConventionBound Democrats Taking Over the Garden
description: Managers of the Democratic National Convention took official control of Madison Square Garden yesterday, and New York City convention hosts gave the man who brought the smokepuffing cigarette sign and other such spectaculars to Times Square the task of draping midtown in red, white and blue.

title: JaiAlai Fronton Opens in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 1Jaialai opened in Bridgeport tonight, half a year late and full of promise that it was rid of the scandal on which this fast  moving Basque game had been stumbling in trying to get started in Connecticut.

title: ParsonsButera Win Golf Playoff
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 1 John O. Parsons and Aldo Butera of the Ridgewood (Conn.) Country Club der feated Greg Zorilla ad Jack Dalrymple of the Siwandy C.C. of Bronxville today in the onehole continuation of sudden death for the Wilson Memorial Cup at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

title: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities
Chile Loses Extradition Bid
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 1 (Agence FrancePresse)The Costa Rican Supreme Court ruled today that the Chilean leftist leader Andres Pascal Allende and his companion, Anne Marie Beaussire, should not be extradited to Chile. Chile sought extradition of the two on the ground that they were wanted on criminal charges relating to underground activities against the Chilean regime.

title: Stage: Livin Fat Opens
description: Judi Ann Mason is a senior at Gramhling State University. Presumably it was in a spirit of pedagogy that the Negro Ensemble Company presented her play Livin Fat at the St. Marks Playhouse last night.

title: Atom Power in Key Coast Vote Tuesday
description: LOS ANGELES  Atomic power, once assumed to be al simple answer to energy problems but now a matter of widespread controversy, will face a significant hurdle in California's primary next Tuesday.

title: Subway Strike in Paris
description: PARIS. June 1 (UPI)Workers in the Paris subway stations staged a 24hour strike today. Subway trains stopped for 15 minutes to dramatize employees charges that rising violence and vandalism were turning the system into Chicago of the 1930's.

title: A French Reporter Describes Rebels in Cambodia
description: PARIS. June 1 (Reuters)A French journalist says he accompanied a group of antiCommunist guerrillas in. Cambodia earlier this month and found growing armed resistance to Cambodia's Government.

title: Golf Cup Named for Architect Jones
description: A silver trophy named after Robert Trent Jones, the golfcourse architect, will be presented to the winner of the eighth annual Insurance Youth Classic tournament, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of the sponsors, the Independent Insurance Agents of America. Jones, who has designed more than 400 courses, was a scratch player in his teens before an ulcer forced him out competition.

title: EDWARD TRAUNER
description: Edward Trauner, a watch distributor, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital in Sarasota. Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Beame Signs Bill, Pinball Machines Are Legal Again
description: Mayor Beanie signed a bill into law yesterday legalizing pinball machines in New York City. But it will remain at tilt for.60 days while the Consumer Affairs Department develops licensing, regulations.

title: U.S. VIEW PREVAILS IN SKIRMISH AT LLO.
description: GENEVA, June 1The United States, which has threatened to pull out of the International Labor Organization, has prevailed in a skirmish preceding the opening here this week of two world labor conferences.

title: Soviet and Philippines Agree on Establishing Ties
description: MOSCOW, June 1 (AP)Leonid I. Brezhnev. the Soviet Communist party leader, and; President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines have agreed; to establish diplomatic relations between their countries. the Soviet press agency Tass, reported today.

title: TAIWAN TO EXPLOIT OFFSHORE GAS FIELD
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 1The Governmentowned Chinese Petroleum Corporation today announced plans to exploit an offshore natural gas field in the Taiwan Strait some 60 miles southwest of Taiwan.

title: One Gladiator on Two Wheels
description: Noonday crowds on Fifth Avenue ogled the black RollsRoyce with the British plates at the curb just south 59th Street and a few passersby recognized the man mounted on a bicycle alongside the car. One who did, black man with a tufted chin, reached across the hood shake the cyclist's hand. Then Joe Frazier pedaled south through the traffic with a news photographer panting ahead, shooting pictures as he ran. As the former heavyweight champion of the world started across 58th Street the lights turned against him but cars comSports of The Times ing across slowed to let him go on. At 57th of Street a cop strolled toward him, reaching for his summons book. Bill Kaplan, a public relations man on foot, spoke hastily: Is all right to ride a bike on Fifth Avenue, officer? I just wanted Joe's autograph, the cop said.

title: For South African National Unity
description: We in South Africa cannot deal with the dangers inherent in today's power vacuum in black Africa without a united country at home and good friends abroad. National unity in a crisis, if it is to mean anything, must mean a basic unity of the great bulk of all the peoples who live in South Africa. And foreign friendships cannot be limited to the holeandcorner diplomacy which so far has necessarily and inevitably characterized the policy of detente.

title: I.M,F. Sale of Gold, Planned for Today, Draws Many Bids
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reu ters)The International Monetary Fund will auction 780,000 ounces of gold tomorrow amid signs of heavy interest on the part of market professionals.

title: India Reports Bumper Crop Of 14 Million Tons of Grain
description: NEW DELHI, June 1 (Reu ters)India, which has had a bumper crop, now has food grain stocks of about 14 millions tons, Jagjivan Ram, Minister of Food and Agriculture said yesterday.

title: RENT STRIKE ON IN FORT GREENE
description: The 600 tenants of Willougnby Walk, an apartment complex in the Fort Greene district of Brooklyn, began a rent strike yesterday to protest the alleged failure of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to maintain the property adequately.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Westchester Bus Strike Ends

title: Giles Eliminates Bailly From British Amateur
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland. June 1 (AP)Vinny Giles conquered the Scottish winds today and moved another step toward winning the British Amateur for the second straight year.

title: Bill Allowing Direct Review by Court Of Education Rulings Vetoed by Carey
description: ALBANY, Jane 1Governor Carey today vetoed a bill widely viewed as an antibusing measure that would have subjected most decisions of the state's Commissioner of Education to direct review by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: 5,000 Children Find Book Fair Is Unfair
description: The crowd of 5,000 schoolchildren, their teachers and some parents were all set yesterday for a musical book fair in Central Park, but somehow the Broadway performers and most of the books never showed up.

title: Olympic Ticket Sales Story: Only Glamour Events Sought
description: Within a few days Philip Stein of Brooklyn will open envelopes bursting with 35,000 tickets for the Olympics in Montreal.

title: Merrill Lynch Agrees to Sell Lionel Edie to Employees
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell a portion of Lionel D. Edie & Company to Edie employees, effective July 1, for $8.4 million paid over 10 years.

title: Books of The Times
description: The story that Marge Piercy tells in her latest novel, Woman on the Edge of Time, is almost too easy to summarize. Consuela (Connie) Ramos, a oncebeautiful Chicana from Texas, now down and out on welfare in New York City, is first tossed into Bellevue and then committed to Rockover State Hospital for attacking her niece's pimp, Geraido, with a wine bottle when he tries to force the niece to undergo an abortion at the hands of an unlicensed hack.

title: Hugo E. Johnson, Was Head Of Iron Ore Group in Ohio
description: Hugo E. Johnson, president of the American Iron Ore Association of Cleveland from 1958 to 1975, died Monday in University Hospital, Cleveland, after a long illness. His age was 68.

title: William Marler, 88, Clothier For American Military Men
description: William A. Marler, a salesman for the Rogers Peet Company whose customers included American military men from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to Gen. William C. Westmoreland, died Sunday at his home. He was 88 years old and lived at 12011 Hillside Avenue in Richmond Hills, Queens.

title: Demands for Discipline of Hays Grow as Congressmen Return From Districts
description: WASHINGTON, June 1Demands for disciplinary action against Representative Wayne L. Hays mounted today, spurred by pressure from constitutents of House members who had spent the holiday weekend in their Congressional districts.

title: Frustrations Grip Faculty at City U.
description: Prof. Alfred Levine of Richmond College was so frustrated by the 11thhour shutdown of the Staten Island college, along with the rest of City University, that he told the 25 students in his physics class to meet on the 6:45 ferry out of St. George last night for their final examination.

title: Woman Who Reported Slaying Charged With the Crime on L.I.
description: The Suffolk County police arrested the woman friend and a business associate of a wealthy North Shore motorcycle dealer yesterday on charges of kidnapping and murdering the dealer.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: After opening lower than Friday's close, prices for wheat, soybeans and soybean meal rose sharply yesterday on the 1 Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Former Hughes. Aide May Drop Mormon Will
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1The possibility that Noah Dietrich will move to withdraw from probate a purported will of Howard R. Hughes was raised in Superior Court today.

title: Woman Has 2d Boy In Rare
description: PATERSON, N. J., June 1 (AP)A 29yearold Clifton woman who had a kidney transplant when she was 13 years old gave birth to a boy today in a birth her doctors called rare and potentially dangerous.

description: At the start of the year, the economic issues were expected: to be the dominant ones inl the election of 1976, but thus far they have not figured itn portantly in the campaign.

title: ACCORDIN ALBANY NEAR ON JUDGES
description: ALBANY, June 1Republican and Democrats in the Legislature are near agreement on an amendment to the State Constitution that would allow the Governor to appoint the judges on the state's highest court, legislators involved in the discussions said today.

title: U.S. Views Syria's Entry Into Lebanon as Helpful
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The United States gave its tacit approval today to the latest Syrian military incursions into Lebanon but again warned Damascus not to increase its forces beyond Israel's tolerance.

title: 11 PRISONERSLOSE RELEASE RIGHTS
description: TRENTON, June 1State prison officials said today they had canceled the workrelease programs of 11 prison inmates who had been allowed to work outside prisons as part of a rehabilitation program.

title: Rockets Red Glare; a Gift From BBC
description: As a Bicentennial gift to the United States on July 4, the British Broadcasting Corporation 11 is planning to transmit by satellite a 25minute program of fireworks on the Thames River, accompanied by a performance of Handel's Royal Fireworks music.

title: WEST POINT SUED OVER HONOR CODE
description: WEST POINT. June 1Cadet Timothy Ringgold, acting individually and on behalf of all other similarly situated cadets, filed suit against the United States Military Academy in Federal Court today to seek elimination of the honor code.

title: Arms Talks Resume Today
description: GENEVA, June 1 (Reauters) United States and Soviet nuclear arms negotiators resume talks here tomorrow after a fourweek recess, with no outward sign of progress toward bridging differences holding up a new agreement on limiting strategic arms.

title: Parimutuel Arms Talks
description: VIENNASoviet diplomacy, skillful, patient and relentless, achieved a political settlement of World War H by signature of the Helsinki agreement on European security. That accord. accepted by the United States acrd all of Europe (save Albania). legally ratified existing frontiers on this continent.

title: Textile Unions to Merge And Plan Drive in South
description: WASHINGTON. June 1Two major unions in the textile and men's apparel field voted today to merge. At the same time their leaders announced plans for a new drive to organize workers in those industries in the largely unorganized South and Southwest.

title: ARNOLD R. STREIT
description: Arnold R. Streit, a lawyer, died Monday at Methodist Hospital in Houston after a heart operation. He was 54 years old and lived at 425 East 79th Street.

title: Sept. 26 Good Neighbor Day
description: WASHINGTON. June 1 (AP) President Ford today proclaimed Sept. 26 as Good Neighbor Day, calling upon Americans to know and care about the people next door.:.

title: PakistaniEuropean Accord
description: BRUSSELS, June 1 (UPI)The European Common Market and Pakistan today signed a fiveyear agreement to develop trade and economic cooperation. India and Sri Lanka had already signed similar agree; ments with the Common Market.

title: Bruins and Trojans Share Tennis Title
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. June 1 (UPI)Peter Fleming and Ferdi Taygan defeated Southern California's Chris Lewis and Bruce Manson, 60, 62, 64, and won the National Collegiate Tennis Doubles Championship today.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS LOGAN'S VILLAGER; Conspiracy on Fraudulent Tax Statement Also Laid to 2 Officers of Parent RAINESS PARTNER NAMED Villager. (Afulkan and Keery) Plead Guilty on 2d Count, Causing a False Return
description: A Federal grand jury in New ark has indicted Villager Industries Inc., an apparel manufacturing subSidiary of Jonathan Logan Inc., two of Logan's officers and a partner in Clarence Rainess & Company, a major New York accounting firm, on Oiarges that they engaged in a conspiracy to file a fraudulent Federal income tax return.

title: U.S. Views Syria's Entry Into Lebanon as Helpful
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The United States gave its tacit approval today to the latest Syrian military incursions into Lebanon but again warned Damascus not to increase its forces beyond Israel's tolerance.

title: U.S. Agrees to a Study Of Soviet Radiation Effect
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The State Department has agreed to an independent medical study of about 600 past and present workers at t he United States Embassy in Moscow who might have been subjected to Soviet microwave emissions.

description: Following are the. latest sallies from yesterday's Presidential primaries:

title: WINE TALK
description: From time to time, this space is devoted to tips on traveling in the wine regions of France, Italy, Germany and the United States. Why have you never said anything about the vineyards of England? a reader asked. Why not indeed?

title: Stolen $100.000 Seized
description: MONTREAL, June 1 (AP)The police arrested six persons today seized more than 8100,000 and announced they had solved the $2.S million robbery of a Brinks armored car here in March. They said that the money was found in several different houses and that serial numbers traced it to the Brinks robbery.

title: FRANKLIN SHARES SEEM TOTAL LOSS
description: Shareholders of the Franklin New York Corporation, holding company for, the insolvent Franklin National Bank, are likely to recover nothing from their holdings, according to the company's court  appointed trustee.

title: Brief Storms Cause Damage in Suburbs; Commuters Delayed
description: A series of brief but powerful thunderstorms swept through the New York City metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, wreaking an irregular pattern of havoc from northern New Jersey to Long Island.

title: Various Companies Report Sales, Earnings and Loss Figures
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: NARCOTICS USED BY 61% OF FELONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Nearly twothirds of state prison inmates have used drugs regularly and onefourth were serving time for crimes comrflitted while under the influence of drugs, a Census Bureau survey reported today.

title: CARTER WINS ONE, LOSES 29, JOLTED BY BROWN IN 3D
description: Jimmy Carter won the South Dakota primary yesterday, lost in Montana and in a third race the hardfought Rhode Island contesttook more delegates than anyone else despite surprising victory by an uncommitted slate backed by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: A Southern Diary: In Spring, a Traveler Finds Eternal Hurts and Healin
description: LUMPKIN, Ga.The road disappears into pines draped with wisteria, whole groves and hillsides covered with heartrendering purple. Then the pines and vines fall away and there, just a few yards from the road, is a washedout gully that goes straight down 150 feet and fingers across the low slopes quarter of a mile.

title: GROUP BACKS USE OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: A group representing more more than 100 scientists and engineers, including five Nobel laureates, came out yesterday against regulations that would drastically curtail and ultimately ban the use of nuclear power. The group referred specifically to California's Proposition 15, which will be on the state's June 8 primary ballot.

title: Pell Tries to Oust Head Of U.S. Humanities Unit
description: WASHINGTON, May 31Senator Claiborne Pell is trying to end the term of Dr. Ronald Berman as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. The Senator is chairman of the twoman subcommittee that oversees arts and humanities matters.

title: Poll Shows Blacks Decisive for Carter In Lead Over Ford
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The major reason that Jimmy Carter appears to be leading President Ford as the choice of the electorate at this point is the former Georgia Governor's overwhelming support among blacks.

title: S.E. C. Suit Charges Fraud To Geo Resources on Tax
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) One of the nation's largest oildrilling tax shelters allegedly defrauded more than 2.000 wealthy investors by offering them $80 million in false income tax deductions, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today.

title: Signal to General Park
description: As a majority of the House International Relations Committee recognizes, this is no time for the United States to bestow a blessing on the repressive regime of President Park Chung Hee with a twothirds increase in military aid for South Korea. When it votes today on the military assistance bill, the House will strike a blow for decency without jeopardizing an ally's security if it sustains the committee recommendation that arms aid for Seoul be held at the existing level for the next two years.

description: BASEBALL

title: Porter Suit Names Missouri Portland
description: The H. K. Porter Company, owner of 52 percent of the Missouri Portland Cement Company, has filed suit in Federal Court in St. Louis to compel Missouri Portland to seat two

title: Leo L. White, Toy Company Founder and President, 83
description: Leo L. White, chairman of the Board and President of Knickerbocker Toy Company, died yesterday of a heart attack enroute to a meeting of his company. He was 83.

title: Rain Falls on Yanks in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 1Rain, not firecrackers, forced a postponement of tonight's game between the New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox.

title: TUITION IMPOSED AT CITY U., ENDING A129YEAR POLICY
description: The New York City Board of Higher Education voted 7 to 1 last night to impose tuition at the City University next fall, drawing the curtain on a unique era in American education.

title: COMMUNITY UNITS GETLANDUSEROLE
description: The New York City Planning Commission voted unanimously yesterday to adopt new procedures giving community boards a formal role for the first time in determining the use of land within their jurisdiction.

title: DAMASCUS SENDS TROOPS AND TANKS INTO MIDLEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1Syrian tanks advanced deep into Lebanon along the DamascusBeirut highway today and swung north to relieve Christian forces that have been surrounded by Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Moslems for several months.

title: About New York
description: At the final session of The Visible and the Invisible, subtitled A Conference About Energies and Consciousness, at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church on Monday night, Dr. Lyman Fretwell displayed some photographs he had made earlier in the day.

title: Newcombe Ousted in First Round
description: PARIS, June 1 (UPI)John Newcombe, hardly looking like the threetime Wimbledon champion, lost to Juan Gisbert of Spain, 2.6, 76, 75, 64, in a major upset in the first round of the $210,000 French open tennis championships.

title: Ramsay Blazer Coach
description: The pro basketball game of musical chairs contined yesterday with the dismissal of Lenny Wilkens and the hiring of Jack Ramsay. The game is not over yet, only the music has stopped.

title: AGENCY ON ENERGY WINS HOUSE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The House of Representatives voted today to extend the life of the Federal Energy Administration for 18 months, not the 39 months recommended by the House committee that watches over the agency.

title: A $500 Fun Night
description: Old Blue Eyes, Frank Sinatra, came to New York City last night to raise at least 500.000 greenbacks to help Governor Carey out of the red.

title: DOW DECLINES 2.10 IN A SLOW SESSION
description: Memorial Day seemed to linger an extra day on Wall Street this year, as trading on. the New York Stock Exchange slipped yesterday to the second lowest level of the year. The spring lethargy reached also to prices, which, after a promising beginning ultimately closed down.

title: Brown Claims Rhode Island Victory Despite Reported Rift in Uncommitted
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California claimed a victory in Rhode Island last night on the basis of the narrow plurality achieved by the uncommitted slate in that state's Democratic Prlisidential primary election yesterday, even though some of the uncommitted delegates reportedly support former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georeia.

title: Bournonville's Bounce and Precision Are Basking in an Upsurge of Interest
description: If you have wondered how the Royal Danish Ballet gets that extra bounce, lightness and precision in its footwork as it has performed the 19thcentury ballets by August Bournonville in its current engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, you are not alone. The Danish choreographer's works make up the company's special legacy, and there is an extraordinary upsurge of interest in American dance circles about the Bournonville technique needed to perform these

title: DEADLINE IS FRIDAY FOR T.W.A. DISPUTE
description: Contract talks between Trans World Airlines and representatives of its 5,000 cabin and flight attendants and service workers continued yesterday in the face of a midnight Friday strike deadline.

title: New Charges Filed Against Kodama In Lockheed Affair
description: TOKYO, June 1 (AP)The Tokyo police department filed new charges against Yoshio Kodama today, accusing him of failing to report the receipt of $460,000 from the Lockheed Aircraft Corp.

title: About Real Estate
description: Since the brewery moved, the brewhouse was worthless. Ditto the keg warehouse. And there was nothing to be done with the tank storage building.

title: H.E.W. Warned of Fund Curb in Medicaid Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 F. David Mathews, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was told today by the General Accounting Office that the Federal Treasury would no longer pay states for certain Medicaid programs whose standards on longterm hospitalization had not been enforced.

title: Jobs Up in New England
description: BOSTON, June 1 (AP)The number of nonfarm jobs in New England rose 44,900 from March: to April this year with the biggest increases posted in menufacturing industries, the United States Department of Labor reported today. It said that nonfarm employment reached 4,720,800 in April, a gain of 69,000 jobs over the same time last year.

title: Alabama Witness Of Alleged Slaying Admits an Error
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June (AP)  Attorney General Bill Baxley said today a witness had admitted he incorrectly identified one of the three white men he said had forced a black truck driver to leap to his death in a river 19 years ago.

title: Iranian Consulate Occupied By Students in Geneva
description: GENEVA. June 1 (AP)About 15 Iranian students occupied the Iranian Consulate General in Geneva today for about two hours to protest what they said was a new wave of repression of political dissidents in Iran.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Environmental groups, organizations representing the elderly and consumer groups have been rating legislators based on voting records on bills the groups deem important. but in March when a group called Environmental Action headed its list of the dirty dozen with the name of the House minority leader, John J. Rhodes, and said he should be defeated for his poor record on ecological issues, Mr. Rhodes began a counterattack with the supof 101 other members.

title: THAILAND AGAIN BIDS U.S. FORCES GET OUT
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June RAP)Thailand rejected today a request by the United States that it be allowed to keep an electronic eavesdropping station in operation, and again ordered the American military to leave the country by July 20.

title: MORE CUTS URGED IN BEAME BUDGET
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has called on the Beame administration to plan an additional $150 million worth of budget cuts in the coming year to be kept as standby protection against various soft spots in New York City's austerity plan.

title: GROWTH OF CITIES SEEN LEVELING OFF
description: VANCOUVER, British Columtia, June 1The basic premise of the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements herethat the world's cities will keep on growing into monstrosities that somehow must be made livablewas challenged today by a leading ,United States ecoloeist.

title: Trenton Water Loss Laid To Error and Poor Design
description: TRENTON, June 1Human error, equipment failure and design vulnerability were blamed today for an accident last Labor Day Weekend that knocked out the Trenton water  filtration plant on the Delaware River.

title: Helstoski Favored Despite Investigation
description: ENGLEWOOD. June 1Representative Henry Helstoski remained a heavy favorite today to win the Democratic renomination for the Ninth Congressional District seat in Tuesday's primary although he has been under investigation by United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein's office for the last two years.

title: Rabbi Martin Katz Weds Yaffa Simon
description: Yaffa Simon, daughter of Rabbi E. Yechiel Simon; spirirual leader of the Clearview Jewish Center in Whitestone, Queens, and Mrs. Simon of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday evening to Rabbi Martin Katz. a teacher at the Ramaz Academy. He is the son of David Katz of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Katz.

title: AUSTRALIAN ASKS SOVIET RESTRAINT
description: CANBERRA, Australia, June; 1 (Reuters)Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser declared today that the Soviet Union was engaged in a major worldwide political offensive backed by force and propaganda.

description: ALBANY. June 1Legislative leaders were hopeful here today of final action on a plan to reorganize the City University's management and financing by the end of this week after the Board of Higher Education voted to impose tuition on all students tonight.

title: Beanie Signs Bill, Pinball Machines Are Legal Again
description: Mayor Beame signed a bill into law yesterday legalizing pinball machines in New York City. But it will remain at tilt for 60 days while the Consumer Affairs. Department develops licensing regulations.

title: EXPERTS DEBATE NUCLEAR DANGERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1Atomic energy specialists from 11 countries that are major exporters of nuclear technology began assembling in London today to discuss new safeguard mechanisms for curbing the spread of atomic weapons.

title: FEDERAL JOBS BAN FOR ALIENS UPSET
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 1 Striking down a nearly 1001 yearold Government practice. the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Civil Service Commission may not bar residentaliens from Federal Civil Service Mobs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BOHEMIAN SUMMER Such a title does not refer to warm months ahead in contemporary Greenwich Village. This is a new playa romantic drama derived from Henri Murger's Scenes de la Vie de Boheme, which gives previews tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and opens officially on Friday. The place is the Central Arts Theater in the Central Presbyterian Church, 595 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. The company is the Public Players unit, which has previously performed Once in a Lifetime, La Ronde and, most recently, A Midsummer Night's Dream.

title: Flawless New Horizon Wins Jumping at Devon
description: DEVON, Pa., June 1New Horizon. the only mount in the field to clear 13 jumps, won the faultandout class in the intermediate jumper division today at the Devon Horse Show.

description: WASHINGTON. June 1The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Bricktop, at 80, Recalls and Is Recalled
description: Cole. Porter had a permanent table at Bricktop's in Paris. She taught the Prince of Wales. at private lessons, 10 do the Black Bottom. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, endless lists of longforgotten members of fashionable sets and royalty were habitus of her clubs.

title: Fire Forces Security Unit To Use Emergency Power
description: FORT MEADE, Md.. June 1 (UPI)Fire forced the topsecret National Security Agency to turn to emergency power equipment today.

title: 2 Bombs Injure 15 Americans And a German at U.S. Base
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 1 (AP)Two time bombs exploded here today in the headquarters of the United States Army's V Corps, injuring 15 Americans and a German civilian, two of them seriously, an Army spokesman said.

title: Bridge:
description: Two prominent East Coast experts won two titles during the Eastern Regional Championships which ended Monday at the New York Hilton Hotel. Mike Moss of New York and Ken Cohen of Philadelphia, who had captured the Men's Pair title Friday, scored a second success Monday by winning the Mixed Teams. Moss played with his wife, Gail, and Cohen with Helen Smith, another Philadelphian.

title: Ensign's Discharge Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, June I (AP) Federal District Judge Gerhard Gesell said today he would rule tomorrow on a re. quest from Ens. Vernon Berg 3d that the Navy be tempor. arily blocked from issuing him a less than honorable discharge after Ensign Berg described himself as a homosexual.

title: Market Place
description: When you're talking about I.B.M.. a Wall Street analyst commented yesterday. there's a hyperintensity of interest at all times in the investment community.

title: BanjoPicker Plays a Therapy Tune
description: NEWARK. June 1A banjopicking psychiatrist from Tennessee demonstrated today the therapeutic effects of music to 500 professionals and laymen attending the opening day of the 25th annual conference of the New Jersey Association for Mental Health at the Robert Treat Hotel here.

title: Changes in Grand Jury System Is Proposed by Panel in Albany
description: Citing alleged prosecutorial abuses by Maurice H. Nadjari, a special state prosecutor, the staff of a State Assembly committee has proposed major changes in the state's grand jury system.

description: MONDAY NIGHT'S MATCH Phoenix 28, San Diego 27.

title: Crisis in Mathematics
description: Mathematics, school children are taught, is the most exact of the sciences. An answer to a mathematical problem is either right or wrong; maybe is excluded. The proof of a mathematical theorem is either correct or incorrect, and a good enough mathematician can always come to a firm conclusion. But now, according to Science magazine, such ideas may be obsolete. Mathematics, too, is in a state of crisis in which the old verities are at least suspect, if not actually destroyed.

description: Tuesday, Juno 1, 1976

description: Outgoing

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rate for Tuesday.

title: Ford Says Sweep in Rhode Island Augurs Well For Convention,
description: WASHINGTON, June IPresident Ford telephoned gleeful supporters in Rhode Island tonight to tell them his sweep of the state's 19 convention delegates will look awfully good in that win column at the Republican National convention.

title: Schmitt, ExAstronaut, to Face Montoya in Contest for Senate
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 1Harrison Schmitt, the former astronaut who walked on the moon, won the Republican nomination tonight to oppose Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat, in his bid for third sixyear term.

title: F.B.I. TRIED TO BAR SPY BOOK FROM TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation took steps in the mid1960's to prevent the authors of a book about Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. the convicted atomic spies, from discussing their work on television interview programs, according to newly released bureau documents.

title: Woman Dies in Hotel Fall
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 1 (AP) Louise Hooper, 54 years old, of Jersey City, fell to her death from the 20th floor of the Sheraton Hotel, the police said today. They said Miss Hooper checked into the hotel Thursday.

title: Steel Service Centers Expanding Role as Middlemen
description: BOSTONThe telephone in Larry Bondy's car rang as he drove to lunch here recently. Daniel Y. Greiff picked it up, had his East Boston office route in a call from a customer and took a $50,000 order for 300,000 rounds of steel.

title: Securities Man Gets Termfor Attempt To Sell Stolen Stock
description: A 4Syearold investment counselor convicted of trying to fence a million dollars worth of stolen stock was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to 18 months imprisonment and fines totaling S20.000.

title: Torre Hits 2 Homers, But Pirates Top Mets
description: Outside of the fact that Joe Torre hit two home runs, the New York Mets spent, another cheerless evening at Shea Stadium last night as John Candelaria of the Pittsburgh Pirates stopped them, 32, on six hits and 12 strikeouts.

title: Frustrations Mount At the University
description: Prof. Alfred Levine of Richmond College on Staten Island was so frustrated by the 11thhour shutdown of the college, along with the rest of City University, that he told the 25 students in his physics class to meet on the. 6:45 ferry out of St. George, S.I., last night for their final examination.

title: Fight to Save Italian Factory Reflects Key Vote Issue: Has Capitalism Failed
description: TURIN, Italy, May 31For 29 years. Armando Garabello worked in the factory of the Emanuel Company here, making automobile washing equipment. Two years ago the comp went bankrupt and tried o close down, but Mr. Garabello and his fellow workers refused to let their jobs disap, pear.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON. AMEX AND OTC
description: Continued concern over increasing interest rates weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in sluggish trading.

title: Rights League Tells the U.N. India Tramples on Freedoms
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 1The International League for Human Rights asked the United Nations today to investigate its charges that the Indian Government has been trampling on the freedom of tens of thousands of its citizens, imprisoning political opponents and permitting extensive practice of torture.

title: SevenNation Economic Parley Due Soon
description: WASHINGTON. June 1 President Ford and leaders of six other nations will discuss the possibility of renewed inflation at an economic conference late this month in Puerto Rico, the White House said today.

title: Kissinger and Simon Irked By Rebuff at Trade Parley
description: WASHINGTON, June., 1The (Secretaries of State and the Treasury expressed annoyance, today at the lastminute rejection by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Nairobi, Kenya, of the United States proposal for a new international  resources bank.

title: No One Hurt as Blast Hits A London Subway Station
description: LONDON, June 1 (UPI)A bomb exploded at the Pimlico subway station on the Victoria line during the rush hour today, but no one was injured, the police said.

title: Now Grown Children of G. I.'s in Korea Are Bitter
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThey call themselves the haltpersons. The Koreans politely call them the mixedrace people. Pearl S. Buck, the author who wrote about the Orient. called them Amerasians.

title: BIAS SUIT POWERS WIDENED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that employees of the Federal Government have the same rights as privately employed workers to have full trials in a Federal district court when they file Title VII job discrimination complaints.

title: Report Lays Blame for 75 Trenton Water Cristie

title: Credentials For Lawyers Tightened in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June I (Reuters) In a move apparently intended to discourage political dissidents, the Yugoslav Republic of Serbia, which includes the capital. Belgrade, is tightening regulations on who may open a lawyer's office.

title: Levitt Cites Medicaid Payments To Ineligibles in New York City
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the city's Medicaid program paid out millions of dollars annually for ineligibles. He urged state requirements for field or other checkups in nonwelfare Medicaid canes.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A Nissan Motor Company's execrtive said in Tokyo yesterday that the auto maker must consider building a United States assembly plant although one won't be needed in the short term.

title: Notes on People
description: Described by his edit,ir as one of the more uniqua ohservers of Republican oulitics. John W. Dean 3d is going to join the boys on Cite bus for Rolling Stone mattazinc. covering the Repute ican National Convention and Presidential campaign as a special correspondent.

title: People in Sports
description: The Kansas City Chiefs traded Otis Taylor, the team's leading career receiver, to the Houston Oilers yesterday for en undisclosed draft choice. In his 11 years with the Chiefs, Taylor made 410 catches for 7,306 yards and 57 touchdowns. That ranks hint second behind Fred Biletnikoff of Oakland among active American Football Conference receivers, and 21st on the National Football League career list. However, he was active for only one game last seasonthe regularseason opener in Denver. Hampered by fluid on the knee, the played sparingly and was later placed on the injured reserve list and sidelined for the season.

title: Soviet Decrees More Emphasis On Specialized Modern Farms
description: MOSCOW, June 1The Communist Party announced plans today for the further development of specialized agricultural  industrial complexes designed to cut costs and increase food production.

title: Blyleven Goes to Texas
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 1 (AP)The Minnesota Twins sent Bert Blyleven, the pitcher, to the Texas Rangers tonight in a sixplayer trade.

title: Fiscal Equity in Divorce Dies in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 2Chances for sweeping changes in the state's law governing financiall settlements in divorce cases are dead in the Legislature for this year.

title: Gannett Buys Paper
description: RICHMOND, Ind., June 2 (AP)  The Richmond PalladiumItem, founded in 1831 by a relative of Daniel Boone, will be sold to the Gannett newspaper chain for a reported $4.72 million. The paper, which publishes both morning and afternoon editions, will become th? 54th in the Gannett group.

title: Devon Title To Coyote In Jumping
description: DEVON, Pa.. June 2Wile E Coyote, who started out his career as a mediocre field hunter but found more successful pursuits in later life, won the amateurowner juniper championship today at the Devon Horse Show.

title: Indictment Against Cleaning Concerns Dismissed by Court
description: A criminal indictment against 11 major building maintenance concerns and 10 executives acTcused of conspiring, to fix prices and avoid competiti in New York City was dismissed in Federal Court yesterday by Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt on the ground that the indictment shows nothing about any effect on interstate commerce.

title: Falstaff Opens the Glyndebourne Festival
description: GLYNDEBOURNE, England, June 2  The Glyndebourne Festival, now 42 years old, started its season last night with a new production of Verdi's Falstaff. The opera festival remains one of the relatively few oases of tradition in an England beset by difficulties on every side.

title: Albany Rushing New Plan to Save H. F.
description: ALBANY, June 2Faced with a policy shift in Washington, Governor Carers office has had to come up with a new proposal to rescue the state's Housing Finance Agency, but Republicans in the Legislature are balking at certain aspects of it.

title: COLOMBIA PRIESTS REBUKE CARDINAL
description: BOGOTA. Colombia, June 2 Two hundred leftwing priests and nuns shook the conservatiye Roman Catholic hierarchy of Colombia today with a public attack on the primate. Anibal Cardinal Mutioz Duque, as an accomplice of the system of injustice.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syrian troops stayed in the positions short of Beirut they took up Tuesday as Palestinian and Lebanese Moslems reiterated that their troops would resist any advance in that direction. For the first time in Lebanon's 14month civil war, a meeting of two leaders of the opposing factionsKamal Jumblat of the leftistMoslem alliance and Pierre Gemayel, son of the leader of the rightwing Christian military and political organization was publicly announced. It was arranged by a leader of Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group of the Palestine Liberation Organization. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Eastern Farmers View Prices as a Game of Chance
description: PRESQUE ISLE. Me.. May 28The first thing to understand about the Maine potatoes futures crisis on the New York Mercantile Exchange, according to the average person here, is that it does not have much to do with the price of real potatoes. Farmers and potato processors think otherwise.

title: ASSEMBLY REVIVES AN ABORTION BILL
description: ALBANY, June 2The Assembly today revived a bill that would impose criminal penalties on doctors who performed abortions on minors without obtaining parental consent.

title: Support Requested For Reorganization Planned at GEICO
description: The District of Columbia's Department of Insurance has asked 16 major insurers in the fire and casualty business to consider supporting a financial reorganization program for the troubled Government Employees Insurance Company and advise it by June 22 of their decisions.

title: Parnassus Group Plays New Music At Columbia Hall
description: The concert given at Columbia University's McMillin Theater Tuesday night by Parnassus, a newish newmusic ensemble directed by Anthony Korf, was relatively predictable in terms of the composers representedMario Davidovsky, Erik Lundborg, Milton Babbitt and Charles Wuorinen, plus a couple of more or less pleasant exhumations in VillaLobos and Cowell. What wasn't so predictable was the quality of the performances. New York is full of excellent individuals and groups that play the music of our time, but Parnassus is surely one of the best.

title: French Chief of Staff Backs NATO Tie in Case of War
description: PARIS, June 2The French Chief of Staff has given official blessing to French participation on NATO's front line in case; of war. The development was the latest in a growing change of defense strategy involving all political groups here.

description: Editorial employees last night struck Time magazine and its sister publicationsSports Illustrated, People, Money and Fortune magazinesand the TimeLife book division.

title: NEW YORK FACING HOSPITAL STRIKE
description: The city officially announced plans yesterday to.lay off 3,150 workers at municipal hospitals by the end of the month because of the continuing fiscal crisis. The workers, who hold nonmedical jobs, responded by threatening a citywide municipal hospital strike next Monday.

title: Jury Awards a Doctor $8,000 In Reversing Malpractice Suit
description: CHICAGO, June 2, (UPI)A Circuit Court jury reversed yesterday a medical malpractice suit, declaring the original plaintiff, her husband and her lawyers guilty of willful and wanton misconduct and awarding the defendant doctor $8,000 in damages.

description: LOS ANGELES, June 2The Republican side of the Caifornia Presidential primary next Tuesday will be conducted by a party with ideological chasms as wide and as deep as Death Valley.

description: A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn has awarded a 6yearold girl $1.25 million for the loss of a leg as a result of medical malpractice by Brookdale Hospital and two physicians.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW. June 2 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today denied charges by Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia that it had interfered in Angola and was engaged in a worldwide political offensive backed by force and propaganda.

title: Problems Seen by M.A.C. In New York's Cash Flow
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation warned yesterday, that there could be serious problems with New York City's tight cashflow plan requiring corrective action of a significant nature by next winter.

title: Ford Ads on TV Get A New Sales Pitch
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2President Ford has drastically changed his campaign's approach to television advertising, replacing commercials that portrayed him as a thoughtful and effective President with a new series of TV spots that employ the techniques used to sell toothpaste and floor wax.

title: People and Business
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobi Oil Corporation, said yesterday that he did not expert ???e Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices until the end of this year. But from then on it will increase them in pace with inflationary trends, he predicted.

title: Lebanese Catalyst
description: Shifting alliances are no new phenomenon in the Middle East, but the realignment of forces now exposed in the troubles of Lebanon is truly remarkable. First priority must go to the urgent task of pacifying a land torn by murderous civil war for an entire year; but is no less urgent for world diplomats to bring their ingenuity to bear in exploring how the new lineups can be used for softening the wider ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Bond Prices Rise Again After a Pause
description: The advance in fixedincome security prices that got under way last Friday continued yesterday even though it paused briefly when the Federal Reserve temporarily drained some money from the banking system. The central bank's action, which took place when the rate on Federal funds had dipped as low as 5 percent, was expected, and it did not appear to dispel the lowkey optimism that has developed this week.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two brothers have been charged with homicide in the shooting death of a policeman in Bradley Beach. Three other persons, including their sister, have been charged accessories, the police said. The principal suspects were identified as Frank Miller, 27 years old, of Belmar, and his brother, Charles, 24, of Wall Township. They were being held without hail after being charged with homicide, armed robbery, conspiracy and possession of a 38caliber pistol. The Millers's sister, Margaret Smock, 28, of West Belmar, was charged with conspiracy, giving false information and illegal transfer of a weapon. William Loland, 27, of Neptune City was charged with obstructing justice and George Maxwell Jr., 38, of Spring Lake Heights was accused of giving false information and of illegal transfer of a weapon. The charges stem from the death of Patrolman Jack A. Wright, 29, who was shot on a residential street after interrupting a holdup and pursuing the suspects.

title: Power And Illusion
description: BOSTON, June 2At his ranch after he left the Presidency, Lyndon Johnson would meet with four or five field hands early in the morning. His voice was as urgent as it had been with the White House staff, but this was the sort of thing he had to say.

title: Textile Union Official Foresees LivingCost Clause as Key Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Jacob Sheinkman, the general secretarytreasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, outlined today the broad range of proposals that the union planned to make this summer in negotiations involving 100,000 workers in the cotton garment field.

title: Out West, Simplot Says His Actions Were Justified
description: BOISE, Idaho, June 2Jack Richard Simplot, the man everyone in Idaho calls the Potato King, admitted here today that he saw nothing unethical or illegal with the default by himself and some friends last week on the delivery of nearly 50 million pounds of Maine potatoes.

title: Remote Galicia Feels the Stirrings Of the Political Resurgence in Spain
description: LA CORUNA, Spain, May 27 Even the remote and underdeveloped region of Galicia, In Spain, s northwestern corner, has been touched by the flowering of illegal but open political life in this country since the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

description: John Emmerling, 37yearold senior vice president and cocreative director of Richard K. Manoff Inc. is putting an Inc. at the end of his own name and opening up an agency.

description: Editorial employees struck Time magazine and its sister publications last night, but the company said publication would continue. Page 39.

title: 2 More Hushes Wills Filed
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 21 (UPI)Two more documents purporting to he the last will and testament of Howard Hughes arrived at the Clark County Clerk's office today, bringing to 28 the number of Hughes wills on file here. One of the documents bequeaths $4011 million to a man identified as Mr. Hughes's son, Dwayne Clyde Byron Hughes. According lo the will, the son was horn in a flying saucer over Oklahoma in 1946.

title: Fugate and Due11 Galvanize Tantaisie
description: Valse Fantaisie is a minor ballet by George Rehmchine, and Judith Fugate and Daniel Duell are young New Yok City Ballet dancers who are still at the beginning of their careers.

description: Braulio Baeza, out of action for 14 racing clays, apparently has lost no momentum as a result of his selfimposed exile.

description: For those now in the market for a used automobilesome call it a junglethere are many criteria to weigh before making a selection.

title: MEMPHIS SEXTET IS AT OTHER END
description: The Amazing Rhythm Aces, a curiously named sextet from Memphis that made its first New York appearances Tuesday night and last night at the Other End, is one of the increasing number of Southern rock bands that are trying to make a virtue of stylistic diversity. Sometimes such eclecticism works to rob a band of personality and its live sets of focus. For the Amazing Rhythm Ace,1 it all fits together.

title: 54 of 174 School Budgets Defeated in May Elections
description: ALBANY (AP)Fiftyfour of the 174 local school district, budgets up for voter approval in May were rejected, the State Education Department has announced.

title: Soviet Honors 5 Americans

Blout, biochemist; Henry M. Stamel, oceanographer; Robert B. Woodward, chemist, and Victor F. Weisskoff, physicist.

title: LOUIS RUCHAMES
description: Louis Ruchmaes, a professor of history at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, died yesterday at the New England Deaconness hospital. He was 59 years old. Professor Ruchames was horn in New York City and graduated from City College, Columbia University and the Jewish Institute of Religion in New York.

title: Sets Suffer Loss Without Mrs. King
description: PITTSBURGH. June 2 (AP) The New York Sets, playing without an ailing Billie Jean King, lost 3114 to the Pittsburgh Triangles tonight in a World Team Tennis match.

title: STACKS UP A MT IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market erased opening losses yesterday and closed moderately higher in continued slow trading.

title: Army Secretary Says He's Considering Review of West Point's Honor System
description: WFST POINT, N.Y., June 2Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann said today that he was considering a review of the honor system at West Point, but he indicated that ary such survey would remain within the military establishment.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Democrats Nominate Melcher For Mansfield's Seat in Senate
description: HELENA, Mont.. June 2 (UPI) Representative John Melcher, a member of the House of Representatives for seven years, won the Democratic nomination yesterday for the Senate seat being vacated by Mike Mansfield.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers Of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue such a report this week.

title: Worm Diggers End Strike
description: WISCASSET, Maine, June 2 (AP)  About 150 of Maine's bloodworm diggers ended a more than twoweek strike today, accepting a halfcentaworm price increase for wholesalers, but samlworm diggers were still reported out on strike. The bloodworm diggers accepted a ??? offer from dealers.

title: Gannett Buys Paper
description: RICHMOND, Ind., June 2 (AP)  The Richmond PalladiumItem, founded in 1831 by a relative of Daniel Boone, will he sold to the Gannett newspaper chain for a reported $4.72 million. The paper, which publishes both morning and afternoon editions, will become the 54th in the Gannett group.

title: O'Dwyer Is Backed For U.S. Senate Seat; Moynihan Wavering
description: Encouraged by Mayor Beanie, three of New York City's major Democratic leaders are preparing to support Paul O'Dwyer, the City Council President, for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate a move that has contributed to second thoughts by Daniel P. Moynihan on his own prospective candidacy.

title: In Memoriam
description: ANTONDavid. In cherished memory of my dearly beloved husband. Always in ray heart. All my love. FLO

title: Nadjari Says He'll Quit As Prosecutor if Curbed
description: Maurice E. Nadjari has told friends and associates that he will refuse to stay on as special prosecutor if Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, agrees to any request by the Governor to appoint a second prosecutor with full powers to handle new corruption cases as of July 1.

title: Empery Wins Epsom
description: EPSOM, England, June 2Lester Piggott, riding down the plush lawn of Epsom's stretch faster than Queen Elizabeth II had travelled by RollsRoyce just two hours earlier, won the English. Derby for a record seventh time today.

title: Candidate Defying Two Death Threats In Suburban Race

The St. George's leam of Phoebe Dempsey acid Carol Beinbrink finished seven strokes back over the 5.394yard Piping Rock Club course. The teams had been tied at 147 after the regulation 36 holes.

title: Filling In for Cunningham

Well, I'm just a calm, cautious person, explained Mrs. Johnson, a 65yearold greatgrandmother known as Judy who became the first black to head the state party when its chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, stepped aside Tuesday until legal charges against him are resolved.

title: Sales at City's Biggest Stores Fell 7.6% In May, the Sharpest Decline Since 66
description: After hovering at or falling behind the inflation rate in the earlier months of 1976, New York City retail sales in May plummeted 7.6 percent below the yearearlier level. It was the biggest monthly decline in more than a decade six of the seven largest Nev Ycrk department stores had declines in May ranging from 2.5 percent to 29 percent, a monthly spot check found. Only one store had a gain, which was 2.3 percent. In the metropolitan area the same spot check showed, the average sales decline was 5.6 percent, only slightly less than a 5.8 percent decline in April 1975.

Tillinghast, to build a course for them in the woods of Westchester County. Tillinghast proceeded to create what is considered one of the finest courses in the world for the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

description: Like a number of other cultural institutions, the Whitney Museum of American Art is discovering television, or at least video. Through this Sunday the museum's New American Filmmakers Series is featuring an 81minute program of blackandwhite videotapes made by William Wegman and John Baldessari. They are being shown daily at 12, 2 and 4 P.M.

title: Books of The Times
description: Dangerously neutral and bland is Fred Friendly's general evaluation of the current state of broadcast news. And the reason for it, he says, is the fear engendered among broadcasters and radio and television news organizations by the socalled fairness doctrine, a fear that the Federal Communications Commission, as the searching eye of Big Brotherthe Federal Governmentis counting the minutes and seconds and content of their newscasts and documentaries, waiting to charge unfairness bias or irresponsibility.

description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that a group of Arab investors had agreed to back up a proposed assistance plan for Detroit's troubled Bank of the Commonwealth.

description: Encouraged by Mayor Beame, three of New York City's major Democratic leaders are preparing to support Paul O'Dwyer, the City Council President, for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate a move that has contributed to second thoughts by Daniel P. Moynihan on his own prospective candidacy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Vice President Rockefeller's meeting earlier this week with Republican delegates resulting in the switching of the bulk of the uncommitted delegates to the Ford camp proved the need for reform in our primary system.

title: No One's Singing the Assembly Line Blues at Longfellow School
description: YONKERSIf there is a break in the fiscal clouds over Yonkers, a city that lives with default deadlines, a likely place to look is Longfellow Middle School, where a student toy factory has had no problem meeting its payroll.

title: Chess:
description: The standard method of exploiting an isolated QP 18 to use the square in trout of it as a knight outpost. The pawn, blind to what stands directly before it, also blocks its own pieces from making a vertical attack on such an outpost piece.

title: People
description: Edward B. Hughes named advertising sales director of Business Week.

title: 'Male of Century' Takes Film Jab at Male Arrogance
description: The sexual revolution leaves Claude a displaced person in his own house when Isabelle, his wife of six years, admits that she has just had a casual, perfectly satisfying one-night affair on the order of the casual affairs that he has admitted from time to time. Claude wants to kill Isabelle, but he doesn't. Because he loves her he contents himself by knocking her around a bit and then by brooding. As he tells his best friend, as if describing an irretrievable loss, "She was everything to me, a mother, a sister, a wife, a whore. . . ."All this happens a year before the start of Claude Berri's French comedy, "Male of the Century," but it adds substantially to Claude's worries when Isabelle becomes one of three hostages taken in the course of a bank holdup. Claude worries less that she will come to some physical harm than that she will fall in love with the bank robber."Male of the Century," which opened yesterday at the Juliet 2 Theater, is so humanely conceived and nicely cast that the principal target of its comedymale arrogance of an almost prehistoric orderis a lot more genial and fresh than it has any right to be.Mr. Berri himself plays Claude with an epically oatish self-assurence that is very funny. Claude is no answer to any maiden's prayer. He's suspicious, pot bellied and mean-tempered, but he somehow transmits his own grand vision of himself to others. It's typical that Claude, who runs a tiny boutique specializing in men's trousers, should describe himselfon the side of his battered delivery truckas The Pants King.Juliet Berto, looking more than ever like a young Jeanne Moreau, is equally funny as the resolutely liberated Isabelle, and Hubert Deschamps, who might remind you of a French version of Richard Haydn, has a surprising staunchness as Claude's best friend, a mild-mannered tailor with a ferocious hold on life, no matter what the disappointments.Unlike such earlier Berri comedies as "The Two of Us" and "Marry Me, Marry Me," "Male of the Century" does not deal in autobiography. It's a sort of humorous "Dog Day Afternoon," though it does display a strong Berri appreciation for family ties. Mr. Berri's mother plays the mother of Claude in the film in such a way that her lack of professional experience is both moving and comic, as when she visits Claude in the hospital and brings him, in her large shopping bag, one small orange and one hard-boiled egg.Mr. Berri also has a marvelous way of dealing with children, including his small son who plays that role in the film. The children remain un-self-conscious and light-hearted, and as totally self-absorbed as the character that Mr. Berri plays."Male of the Century" is not the greatest comedy of the year, but you probably won't see many comedies in the near future, containing a scene as firmly planted in life as the one in which Claude's two sons, eating a dinner consisting entirely of mashed potatoes, look up from their plates suddenly to recognize the television image of their mother in the bank holdup. They are absolutely delighted.

title: British Trawler Group Charges Sellout in Accord With Iceland
description: LONDON, June 2 (AP)Britain told its 21 trawlers off Iceland today to resume fishing under an agreement that ended a sevenmonth dispute over fishing rights in Icelandic waters.

title: 2 Jersey. Utilities Given Permission to Sell Gas
description: NEWARK, June 2 (AP)The Board of Public Utility Commissioners gave permission yesterday for two New Jersey companies to resume selling natural gas to new customers. The agency also established a priority list for gas users.

title: FORD URGES AIDES TO PRESS FOR CURB ON SCHOOL BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 2President Ford called in members of his Cabinet today to press for action that the White House said would severely limit courtordered busing to achieve racial desegregation of schools.

title: Bridge Stayman, the Player, Proves Wrong With the Right Move
description: For the international bridge world, Stayman means a convention that nowadays has more varieties than Heinz. But in New York there are two other possibilities. It might also mean the convention's author, Sam Stayman, NNOLO is having one of his most successful New York seasons in his long career. And it might mean his wife, Tubby, a fine player in her own right who came close to winning the world mixedteam title two years ago.

description: Maurice E. Nadjari has told friends and associates that he will refuse to stay on as special prosecutor if Louis J. Lefko witz, the State Attorney Gen eral, agrees to any request by the Governor to appoint a second prosecutor with full powers to handle new corruption cases as of July 1.

description: ALBANY, June 2In an attempt to alleviate the bleakness of life in some singleroomoccupancy hotels and remove the cloak of secrecy that often protects those responsible for the conditions, the Assembly passed a bill today to require licensing of the estimated 1,000 such structures in the city.

description: New York City's 153 offtrack betting shops will accept Belmont Stakes wagers starting tomorrow at 8 A.M. Betting on win, place and show, as well as on the exacta, will be offered until 5:10 P.M. on Saturday.

description: ALBANY, June 2 (AP)The Rev. Howard J. Hubbard of Troy was named vicar general of the Albany Roman Catholic Diocese today by Bishop Edwin B. Broderick.

description: Thirtythree New York City firemen received medals of honor yesterday for individual acts of heroism daring 1975.

title: Premiere of  Hero Simple and Funny
description: What this country needs as the Bicentennial sappiness rises is a good Swiftian kick in its red, white and blue pants. GianCarlo Menotti's The Hero, a comic opera that had its world premiere at Philadelphia's Academy of Music on Tuesday night, doesn't deliver it. Mr. Menotti, who wrote the music and the libretto and also staged the production, is simply not a serious enough man for this kind of comedy. The Hero is a diversion, a mldly diverting bit of theatrical japery, but the big targets get away almost untouched.

title: M. E. PELOUBET, ACCOUNTANT, 84
description: Maurice E. Peloubet, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse & Company, and resident of Cape May, N. J., died Tuesday at the age of 84. He was visiting Milvaukee at the time.

title: Ethioila, 18 Months After Coup, Is in Turmoil
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 28More than 18 months after a group of radical soldiers deposed Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia is in the grip of a political and social upheaval that has left it sliding into economic disarray, armed repression and a mood of disillusion and fear.

title: Metabolism for What?
description: Earlier this year the New Jersey Supreme Court set down guidelines for what was then widely regarded as legal homicide. It provided a formal procedure by which, under appropriate safeguards, this comatose patient's doctors could take her off the mechanical respirator and presumably let all remaining metabolism stop. Now it turns out that this remarkable patient can breathe without the respirator, and has done so for some time. Yet there appears to be no real hope that the patient can ever regain consciousness.

description: Virginia Stewart, a retired teacher and bookshop owner, died yesterday of cancer at her home in Washington Depot, Conn. She was 71 years old.

description: ??? Wednesday, June 2. 27th day. Weather cloudy for six laces, clear thereafter; track muddy for six races, good thereafter.

description: Two of Randall Thompson's works, Alleluia and The Testament of Freedom, are so popular that his other choral music is often neglected. So it was good to hear his The peaceable kingdom Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Ttenton Topics
description: TRENTON. June 2Attorney General William. F. Hyland today asked the Superior Court to order the Legislature to stop passing special measures that give permanent jobs to overweight policemen and policemen who are past the maximum age to join a police department.

title: KHADDAM OF SYRIA OPENS PARIS TALKS
description: PARIS, June 2The Syrian Foreign Minister, Abdel Halim Khaddam, arrived in Paris today to discuss the situation in Lebanon with French officials.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jun 2 (AP)The Senate was blocked today from debating a bill that would permit states to bring damage suits on behalf of consumers for antitrust violaions. Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, objected to a request of Majority Leader Mike Mansfield for unanimous consent to consider the measure. Mr. Allen and other Senators fighting the bill contend it would subject business concerns to unfair harassment and be costly instead helpful to consumers.

title: BERNARD G. HILDEBRAND
description: Bernard G. Hildebrand, a lawyer and former tax counsel for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Sunday at his home in Northfield, Minn. He was 71 years old.

title: Spread Is Widening For Corn Futures; Silver Prices Slip
description: In a trading session marked by large amounts of profit taking after a period of rising prices, corn futures turned in an unusual performance yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. July corn, the old crop month, gained a cent a bushel to close at $2.93, while December, a new crop month, lost almost 3 cents to close at $2.71.

title: Michigan to Sue in 4 Deaths
description: LANSING, Mich., June 2 (AP) The State Department of Labor said today that it would seek criminal prosecution of Detroit Edison Company and a contractor in the deaths of four workers at Edison's Monroe generating plant. The workers, employed by William Ferrel Inc., a contractor of Toledo. Ohio, fell to their deaths May 5 when a hoisting assembly collapsed inside a giant smokestack that they were repairing.

title: GOV. MANDEL'S TRIAL DELAYED UNTIL FALL
description: WASHINGTON, Joie 2The corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his personal and political friends was rescheduled today to open Sept. 8 in Federal District court in Baltimore, three months later than planned.

title: People in Sports
description: Tommy Davis, fast approaching the major league record for number of teams played on, signed a contract yesterday to play with the California Angels, his ninth club. The major league record is 12, but the modern record, since 1900, is only 10 shared by Dick Littlefield and Bob Miller. Davis's total does not take into account his two stints with the Chicago Cubs, or his brief stay with the New York Yankees this year. He attended spring training, but was dropped by the Yanks before the season opened.

title: Max Warmbrand Is Dead at 80; Wrote and Lectured on Nutrition
description: Max Warmbrand, who advocated fruits, vegetables, sun and exercise in his books and lectures on nutrition, died yesterday at his Stamford, Conn. home. He was 80 years old.

title: Fiscal Equity in Divorce Dies in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 2Chances for sweeping changes in the state's law governing financial settlements in divorce eases are dead in the Legislature for this year.

title: Panel Votes Debt Limit Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) A hill to raise the temporary public debt limit to $700 hill ion from $627 billion through Sept. 30, 1977, was approved today by a voice vote of the House Ways and Means Committee. The legislation was snt to the Rules Committee, which will be urged to clear it coon for consideration by the House.

title: Fleming Gives Eastern Tennis a Boost
description: Although beaten in the National Collegiate final, Peter Fleming has given Eastern tennis a shot of prestige. He came close to duplicating the feat of two other Easterners, Dick Stockton and Sandy Mayer, who won the N.C.A.A. title and then became professionals.

title: SHARES TENDERED TO HOUSTON GAS
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said in Houston yesterday that 2.8 million shares were tendered in response to its offer of May 7 to purchase all shares of the Ernpine Energy Corporation at $9 a share, for a total of $25.2 million. Houston said that all the shares would be purchased for cash. Before the offer, Houston owned 200.000 shares of Empire Energy, of Craig, Colo., company engaged in the exploration and development of coal properties.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nelson G. Gross, former New Jersey Republican state chairman, surrendered to Federal authorities in Newark begin a twoyear prison term. His conviction on March 29, 1974, on charges of managing an illegal campaign fundraising scheme stemmed from his involvement in the successful 1969 election campaign of former Gov. William Cahill. The 44yearold lawyer had delayed the start his sentence through a number of appeals. A spokesman at the Metropolitan Correctional Facility in Manhattan, where Mr. Gross was being processed, said Mr. Gross had not yet been assigned to a penal institution.

title: Mets Records
description: HR.RBI.PC. HR.RBI. PC.

title: BENJAMIN HOWELL, PALEONTOLOGIST, 85
description: Benjamin Franklin Howell Sr., who retired in 1959 as professor of paleontology at Princeton University, died last Friday in the Centre Community Hospital, State College, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: MRS. DAVID KRAFT
description: Sophie Surasky Kraft, widow of David Kraft, a textile manufacturer, died Tuesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif., at the age of 83. She previously had lived in New York City for more than 50 years.

title: April Plant Inventories Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Manufacturers inventories were essentially unchanged in April after a sizable increase in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Events Today
description: REBEL WOMEN, by Thomas Babe; directed by Jack Hofsiss; presented by The New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp, producer, at the Public Newman Theater, 4:5 Lafayette Street, 6:30.

title: Riders Who Lost Rail Luxury Seek The Ultimate Bus
description: SOUTHPORT. Conn., June 2A band of top New York executives accustomed to commuting in comfort and still not resigned to the loss of their private parlor car abandoned the railroad entirely this morning and sought solace on a specially outfitted bus.

title: Gross Surrenders to Begin A 2Year U.S. Prison Term
description: NEWARK, June 2Nelson G. Gross, former Republican state chairman, surrendered to Federal authorities today to begin a twoyear prison term on conviction of managing an illegal campaign fundraising scheme.

title: Philadelphia Is Cradle Of Menotti's 17th Opera
description: GianCarlo Menotti's The Hero, his 17th opera, is believed by its sponsors to be the first opera ever commissioned in Philadelphia. It was commissioned in 1974 by Lyric Opera of Philadelphia, a group that has since been merged into the Opera Company of Philadelphia, which presented the premiere.

title: Liberal Democrats Retreat on Pentagon's Budget
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Liberal and moderate Democrats, determined to prevent Republicans from making military spending a major issue in November, are going along with a $114 billion Pentagon budget that they privately believe to be excessive.

title: Barrera Primes Bold Forbes For Belmont's Endurance Test
description: Waving his horses into battle the way Cochise dispatched raiding parties, Laz Barrera continues to knock off the bigmoney wagon trains chased each spring by racing's best 3yearolds. Seldom has one trainer had 30 many good 3yearolds in his barn and seldom has a trainer lost so much weight worrying about them.

title: Jerseyan Guilty on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP)  The alleged mastermind of a plot to steal $3.5 million in Los Angeles municipal checks has pleaded guilty to three felony counts in the scheme, but has asked a Superior Court judge to dismiss seven other charges. Richard Keats, 391 years old, of Fort Lee, N.J., was', ordered to return July 1 for a hearing on his attorney's motion to dismiss the the remaining charges. He pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy, forgery and attempted grand theft.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES U. S. SCHOOL ROLE
