As the 12 horses and jockeys pounded toward the finish, an outrider stationed midway down the stretch, waved his arms and herded the jockeys toward the rail.

title: Poll Finds Public Is Hazy on Candidates
description: Ronald Reagan has made strong impression during this campaign year with his advocacy of higher military spending and a overhaul of the welfdre system, according to an Associated Press poll.

title: Oh! We've Been TrojanHorsed!
description: CLAREMONT, Calif.If socialism is defined, the way Marx did, as ownership of the means of production by the worker, the United States has become a truly socialist country. The pension funds of the employees of America, and especially of American business, own today more than enough to give them control: in excess of onethird of the capital of all largeand mediumbase businesswhether manufacturers, retailers, banks or insurance companies.

title: Carey Gets a Plan to End Coop City Tenant Strike
description: ALBANY, June 3Governor Carey has received a formal recommendationEndorsed by the tenant leader at Coop City to end the tenant strike there by temporarily permitting residents to establish their own rent levels if they promise not to increase the deficit in what they owe the state.

title: Sludge Coats Shore After L.I.Explosion; Youth, 16, Missing
description: ISLAND PARK, Li., June 3An explosion ripped through two sewage storage tanks at nearby Pearsall Hassock last night, apparently killing a teenaged youth and critically injuring another hay who was reportedly fishing with him.

title: Modern Opens Summergarden for Weekend Evenings
description: At six o'clock this evening, the Sculpture Garden gate in the East 54th Street wall of the Museum of Modern Art will be opened, and for thousands of visitors the 1976 Summergarden experience will begin. As those who have become familiar with it over the last five years are aware, the Summergarclen of fers a varied array of free short and informal concerts of experimental music, recitals of works by living American composers, country music or jazz at 8 every Friday and Saturday through the middle of September.

title: ExModel and Her Maid Slain in Greenwich Home
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 3 A wealthy former fashion model and her livein maid were found murdered last night in the upstairs bedroom of a $250,000 home in this affluent town's rural hack country.

title: Brewers Halt Tigers 4 Game Streak
description: Bill Travers, a lefthander, won his fourth consecutive game, and Don Money and Robin Yount furnished the power at the plate as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Detroit Tigers last night, 62, in Tiger Stadium.

title: Records: Tilting at Don Quixote'
description: This is an exceptionally deliberate and expansive reading by a cellist, a conductor and an orchestra capable of sustaining a drawnout line without letting a sag or crack show. Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic discover unexpected refinement in the Strauss score at times, but also can tear right into the famous pictorial passages such as the Don's rout of the bleating sheep and his sighting of the flying horse, Mstislav.

title: Art: Warhol Meets Wyeth
description: IT MAY or may not be true, as George Orwell believed, that every man gets the face he deserves at the age of 50. but it is undoubtedly true that certain faces sooner or later exactly when depends on the vagaries of publicityget the portraits they deserve.

title: Suspect in 2 Deaths Held
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 (AP)  A 34yearold security guard for the United States Mint has been booked for investigation of murder in the shooting deaths of two women, a fellow mint employee and a bank worker, beside a busy freeway. The police said Tilmon Brooks Jr. of San Francisco was arrested at gunpoint minutes after the shooting at about 4:30 P.M. yesterday. No motive for the killings was reported.

title: 5,000 to 6,000 Syrians In Lebanon, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reuters)The Defense Department estimated today that Syria had 5,000 to 6,000 soldiers in Lebanon.

title: Restaurants
description: SEA VENTURE, which has been in operation for about a year and a half at 1359 First Avenue, corner of 73d Street, is one of the rare New York fish restaurants that thinks a fish restaurant can be restaurant first and fishy second, by which I mean that doesn't pretend you're at dockside and hence ready to put up with crowded tables, casual accessories, and heaveho service all rationalized as atmosphere.

title: Cynicism Makes Inroads in Liberal Teaneck
description: TEANECK. N. J.The cost of heating the little brick house doubled and his wages did not move. His country and therefore he himself, he feels, was shamed in Vietnam. And somewhere along the line, he lost faith that no matter what happened, he could always support his family.

title: Soviet Airliner Is Missing On a Flight From Angola
description: MOSCOW, June 3 (AP)An Aeroflot jetliner has been missing for two days on a flight from Angola to Moscow, a Soviet aviation official said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: if a judge decided to impose punishment on a defendant after the jury had found the defendant not guilty, imagine the resulting outcry.

title: Notes on People
description: Catholic Relief Services announced in Washington yesterday that Bishop Edwin B. Broderick of the Albany diocese will be the new executive director of the agency. He succeeds Bishop Edward E. Swanstron, 73 years old, who since 1947 has developed the service into a $250millionayear American aid agency with programs in 86 countries.

title: Capitalism and Feminism Share the Dais at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 3A oneday conference designed to foster better utilization of human resources in the world of commerce attracted 1.500 members of the academic and business communities at Rutners University today.

title: History Barge Makes Berth At South St.
description: THE New York State Festival Barge, a floating open house that will ply state waterways between now and October, opens for its first full day today at Manhattan's South Street Seaport Museum.

title: ELIZABETH A. M'SHERRY
description: HARTFORD, June 3Elizabeth A. McSherry, a retired high school English teacher and literary editor of The Hartford Courant, died here yesterday. She was 83 years old.

title: Antiques
description: FOR 47 YEARS Mildred and Raft Y. Mottahedeh violated a basic tenet of collectingand in the process they put together what is possibly the finest holding of Chinese export porcelains in private hands in this country.

title: GEORGE BUCK, LED WATER COMPANY
description: George H. Buck, former chairman of the board and president of the Hackensack Water Company, died yesterday at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N. J. He was 81 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N. J.

title: Juan Carlos Opens Bicentennial Displays
description: WASHINGTON. June 3King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofia of Spain spent most of today in ceremonies presenting Bicentennial gifts and opening Bicentennial exhibitions.

title: Film: Football As Joy and Anguish
description: WE are fairly simple creatures when we bump down into a movietheater seat. The simplicity can be overcome and educated, but at the price of a certain residual strain. We have an emotional bias toward identifying with what we see on the screen rather than rejecting it. Great satirical and denunciatory films have been made, of course, but they tend to work by linking us with the victim. We experience our anger through him, rather than directly.

title: Moynihan Backs Off
description: Daniel P. Moynihan has tentatively decided not to seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, friends of the former representative of the United States to the United Nations said last night. Details, Page A16.

title: Time's Magazines Called on Schedule Despite the Strike
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that the production of its magazines liras proceeding on schedule and that there would be no change M the magazines whatsoever despite a strike by nearly 60 percent of its editorial employees.

title: Stage: Rebel Women
description: OF all the Civil War generals on the Union side, presumably Grant was the most successful, but surely Sherman, that icecold professional, that intellectual soldier, that passionless strategist, was the most interesting. That certainly seems to be the view of Thomas Babe, who in his play Rebel Women, which opened last night at the Newman Theater of Joseph Papp's Public Theater complex in Lafayette Street, takes as his theme the impact of Sherman's army, and Sherman himself, on the women left in a commandeered mansion during Sherman's march to the sea following the sacking of Atlanta.

title: Big Expense Cut Planned By Commonwealth Bank
description: DETROIT, June 3Merlyn Trued, chairman of the ailing Bank of the Commonwealth, told stockholders today that the bank planned to cut expenses sharply and also mount a drive to regain some of the business it has lost in recent years.

title: M.A.C. Task Force Offers Program Of Sweeping Tax Relief for Business
description: A sweeping program of tax relief for business and for people making more than $25,000 a year was proposed by a Municipal Assistance Corporation task force yesterday as the drastic medicine needed to staunch the flow of jobs from New York City.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 204.1 from 202.6 last week.

title: Change in Housing Code Defeated in Glastonbury
description: GLASTONBURY, Conn., June 3 (AP)A referendum to change the local housing code so a young family could continue living in a rural farmhouse without electricity or flush toilets has failed.

title: Stassen Enters the Race For G.O.P. Nomination
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP)  Harold Stassen, a fourtime loser in the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination, announced today he would try again this year.

title: Suspect Hunted in Phoenix In Bombing of a Reporter
description: PHOENIX, June 3 (AP)The police searched today for a man named John Adamson as a newspaper reporter fought for his life after his car was bombed.

title: Books of The Times
description: SO JAMES BALDWIN is still here, still pursuing us, a ghost of 60's past. Even though he long ago became unfashionable, long ago wore out his welcome even in the black revolution (because he dared to believe that whites and blacks could love each other despite everything), he goes on jumping up.

title: Weekend Film Revivals, A Critic's Guide
description: When we first meet Oscar jaffe, the Broadway producer played by John Barrymore in Howard Hawkes's splendidly lunatic comedy Twentieth Century, Oscar looks like an aged, shopworn Pan, lying on a fur rug in his office making notes with an oversize quill nen on the manuscript of his new play. The office is in the Oscar Jaffe Theater, where the cast of the new Oscar Jaffe production (artistic supervision by Oscar Jaffe) awaits the Oscar Jaffe presence.

title: Architecture: Barragan at Modern
description: Luis Barragan's architecture is little known to the American public, but his buildings and monuments are among the supreme works of contemporary architecture in Mexico. They are abstract in one sense because they rely heavily on simple geometric forms and straight lines, yet they tie deeply into the tradition of Mexico by their use of rich color, serene gardens and stucco walls.

title: 4 PLANS WEIGHED ON NADJARI POST
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz the State Attorney General, is considering at least four options for the future of Maurice H. Nadjari's office, one of which would require the special prosecutor to turn over new cases to the city's five district attorneys after July 1.

title: Car Is Reported Nearly PollutionFree
description: WASHINGTON, June 3California airquality officials said today that they had tested a nearly pollutionfree Volvo automobile that disproves the need for any relaxation of standards in the 1970 Clean Air Act.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT ALLOWED TO LEAVE
description: MOSCOW, June 3Vitali Rubin, a Soviet dissident and a specialist in ancient Chinese philosophy, said today that he had been granted permission to emigrate to Israel after a wait of more than four years.

title: Beirut Tense and Fearful As People Expect Syrians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 3i This Lebanese capital, more frightened than ever, its streets empty and garbage burning at every second corner, seemed today to be waiting for an enemy who did not come.

title: Brown Brings Spirituality to Political Ideas
description: In a recent campaign speech at a Roman Catholic college. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California remarked in a droll manner that the White House could use a little Jesuit logic.

title: Prices Slip on Amex but Rise on OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday declined while those in the overthecounter market rose slightly.

title: Picasso's Art by Picasso Is Valued at $260 Million
description: PARIS. June 3Pablo Picasso's collection of his own works, among them 1,185 paintings, has been valued by experts after more than a year's study at $260 million.

title: U.S. Production and Supplies Of Petroleum Rose for Week
description: Both production and supplies of gasoline in the United States rose in the latest week, taking some pressure off tightening supply lines of motor fuel in the nation.

title: Syrians Warn Beirut Leaders, Say Many Lebanese Asked Aid
description: DAMASCUS. Syria, June 3The staterun Syrian radio, television and newspapers issued veiled warnings today to Lebanon's political leaders to put their house in order, but there were no signs that Syrian armor intended to push on to Beirut from positions taken in eastern Lebanon two days ago.

title: Devon Title To Hunter From Coast
description: DEVON, Pa., June 3Modest Man, owned by the Lakeside Ranch of Morgan Hill, Calif., won the green conformation hunter class today at the Devon horse show and clinched the division championship.

title: EGYPT CONDEMNS SYRIA ON LEBANON, ASKS CONFERENCE
description: CAIRO, June 3Egypt today condemned Syria's military intervention in Lebanon and called for an urgent meeting of Arab foreign ministers to Put an end to it.

title: C. I. A. Informs Senate Leaders It Will Resume Destroying Files
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) George Bush, Director of Central Intelligence, has informed the Senate leadership that his agency intends to resume detroying its records, including those used by Senate intelligence and Presidential commission investigators.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: As more than 1,000 of his colleagues stood at attention outside the Roman Catholic Church of the Little Flower in Brooklyn funeral services were held yesterday for Fireman Patrick J. Cleary who died of a heart attack on Sunday after rescuing a woman and her 5yearold daughter from a burning building. Fireman Cleary, a 49yearold native of Lreland, was the seventh city fireman to die in the line of duty this year.

title: Sightseeing Planes Let Eaglets Soar
description: In his 12 years, Steven Kimmel had indeed been on an airplane beforea jumbo jet to Italy. It was a disappointment. It was like going to Italy in a house, Steven said. The jet was so big you didn't even know you were flying.

title: Betty Newfield, 14, Scores Net Upset
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 3Topseeded Marilyn Aschner and Betty Newfield, a 14 yearold from Jackson Heights Queens, won quarterfinal matches today in the women's New York State tennis championship.

title: Red Sox, With Tiant, Put Yanks to Rout, 82
description: BOSTON, June 3 The odds, lady fortune and tha big inning opted for the Boston Red Sox tonight. Destined to win at home after having lost two in a row, bound to reverse the tide of solid blows hit right at Yankee fielders and overdue to bunch their hits and walks, the Red Sox did all that and defeated New York, 82, behind Luis Tiant.

title: Market Place
description: Producers of machine tools tare engaged in one of the paost cyclical of cyclical businesses.

title: US. AIDES SCORE ANY OIL BREAKUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Administration officials testified against breaking up the nal tion's major oil companies today, saying it would lead to higher prices and still greater dependence on foreign producers.

title: Changing Carters In Midstream
description: What Jimmy Carter needs at this crucial stage of his campaign is a new Carter. In fact, there is considerable evidence that he is having one built. That joke about Jerry Brown's Zen Buddhism the other day and the harsh reference a few weeks ago to Hubert Humphrey as an old man could never have come from the old Carter.

title: Western Electric to Lift Prices By 3% on Bell System Supplies
description: The financially troubled Western Electric Company, the telephone equipment supply subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday 3 percent increase in the price of almost all products sold to the Bel System. Effective July 1, the increase is expected to produce about $121 million a year for Western Electric, which announced a 4 percent price rise in January designed to produce about $155 million a year.

title: Painting, Sculpture Show Opens at the City Museum
description: An exhibition of paintings and sculptures portraying impressions of New York by a group of Hispanic American artists opened yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: $300 Million Shortfall
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board has reasonably offered city officials one week to respond to a sharply critical staff report on Mayor Beame's new budget and many municipal management practices.

title: Sporting Their Sporty Furs
description: Who brought the change in fur fashions? Credit the sportswear designers, who have shaken up the usually conservative thinking of the men who deal in pelts. As more of them collaborate with furriers, a lot of timehonored Ideas are going out the window. Mink, these days, is for football, while nobody thinks anything of wrapping an evening dress in a rahrah, oversized raccoon coat.

title: Slain Greenwich Woman and ExSpouse Argued
description: GREENWICH. Conn.. June 4  James M. Klein quarreled heatedly with his divorced wife on Wednesday afternoon, the police said, only hours before the 30yearold former fashion model and her maid were found dead of gunshot wounds in the head.

title: Going, Going an Art Collection and a Way of Life
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., June 4 The auctioneer's hammer will fall next week on a lifetime of acquisitions by the late Max Dreyfus, one of the nation's most sucessful music publishers, and his wife, Victoria, who died last March.

title: Companies Report on Sales and Earnings
description: For periods ended April 30 unless otherwise Indicated

title: A Basenji Travels West,:, Takes National Specialty
description: DENVER, June 4A 116monthold bitch from the East, who was shown for the first time last week, scaled the heights today in the Mile High City as he led a field of 72 Basenjis in the National Specialty. The event was one of the shows being held here under the aegis of the Association for Allied Specialty Shows as part of the Colorado Centennial.

title: Laura Baugh Leads on 66
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4Laura Baugh, a 21yearold model, dress designer, author, actress in television commercials, and professional golfer, always attracts large followings during the early rounds of a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: AntiCancer Compromise
description: After five years of legislative impasse, an agreement is taking shape that promises at last to produce a law controlling the sale of toxic substances. The compromise worked out between Representatives Eckhardt of Texas and Broyhill of North Carolina comes none too soon. Some 60 to 90 percent of cancer is now authoritatively attributed to environmental factors. The exact proportion of that total that is caused by hazardous chemicalsrather than smoking, for exampleis not known, but the Department of Health, Education and Welfare reports that of the 30,000 chemicals now on the market, a great many are toxic to some degree and an appalling 1,500 have been shown to have carcinogenic effects on animals.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Fritin.

title: California's Crew Among 6 Finalists
description: SYRACUSE, June 4The University of California at Berkeley's Golden Bears returned to prominence in the sport of rowing today when their varsity eight won its qualifying repechage heat to advance to tomorrow's finale at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's national championship regatta.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO SPLIT 016 POOLING COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Moving cautiously, the Governi ment has begun sounding outl the oil industry on relieving the taxpayers of part of the cost of the strategic petroleum reserve authorized by Congress in December.

title: Jefferson a Winner at the National Gallery
description: WASHINGTONWhen the National Gallery of Art around for a subject tor its Bicentennial exhibition, it soon turned out that there was really no contest. Ideally, there was needed a theme with Presidential overtones; one that would exalt, onlighten and if possible entertain; one that had not been worked over by other institutions; and one that would suit the building, suit the gallery's director and his staff, 4nd suit the city.

title: U.S. Seen Heeding Rizzo Troop Request
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 4Federal authorities have all but, decided to dispatch armedl troops to this city on July 4, informed sources in Washington said today.

title: Business Briefs.
description: Government and utility officials dedicated yesterday geothermal energy test facility in southern California. At Niland, near the Salton Sea north of the Imperial Valley, salty steam from deep wells temporarily ran a turbine generator to light up a battery of 10 large light bulbs, each of 1,500 watts.

title: U.S. Disavows C.I.A. Analy,10 On Article About China Ties
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The United States disassociated itself today from a recommendation by a senior analyst of the Central Intelligence Agency that the United States consider full recognition of China before the death of Mao Tsetung.

title: CBS Ordered to Pay $250,000 In Trespass by TV News Crew
description: A State Supreme Court jury has ordered CBS to pay more than $250,000 to an exclusive midtown restaurant because the network's television camera crew entered it without permission and took pictures.

title: Political Left Is Quiet in Current Campaigns
description: The American political leftso visible and so vocal in earlier Presidential campaigns in its support of civil rights and its opposition to the Vietnam Warhas been dormant in this year's national political contests.

title: 2 ASSERT MARINES HAD RACIAL QUOTA
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) Two former Marine Corps recruiters said they had been ordered to limit the number of blacks and other racial minorities entering the corps, but senior officers denied that the orders had come from the top echelons of the Marines.

description: TRENTON, June 4A speciali citfzen's committee appointed by Governor Byrne last week reported today that it could not implement any program to take the place of public schools if they are closed July 1 becanse of the financing dispute between the State Supreme Court and the Legislature.

description: Governor Carey called yesterday on an angry and resistant Mayor Beame to increase his austerity measures sharply in the coming year, with more than $200 million in additional and accelerated cuts. Mr. Beame immediately denounced the Governor's proposal as unnecessary and impossible.

title: Legends of the Lochs: Quests by Saints and Science

Now members of a technologically advanced expedition are here testing new equipment in an effort to find that something, but they are aware that at the moment, their quest is one more episode in an ofttold tale of the highlands.

description: Marta Lorenzzi has lived in East Harlem for 53 years. Yesterday the 74yearold Puerto Rican woman said that she had never before seen anything similar to what she was witnessing in El Barrio.

title: 6 Mexico City Policemen Killed In Terrorist Attack at Roll Call
description: MEXICO CITY, June 4 (AP) Submachinegun fire from two speeding cars killed six policemen and wounded sixl others lined up for rollcalf, this morning in the Mexico City suburb of Ciudad Azteca, the police said.

title: U.S. Says Takeover Threat Led to NuclearPlant Alert
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the nationwide security alert to all 58 nuclear power plants for the Memorial Day weekend was based on intelligence reports that two groups may have plans to take over at least one nuclear plant.

title: Ballet
description: After more than a season's absence, Peter Schaufuss, the Danish dancer who joined the New York City Ballet last year, is back with the company. Thursday night at the State Theater, he brought his individual style and impressive technique to his first local appearance in the Rubies section of George Balanchine's Jewels.

title: Heistoski's Mother Dies
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 4.(UPI)  Margaret Helstoski, mother of Representative Henry Helstoski, died yesterday at the age of 87. Her death came one day after Mr. Helstoski was indicted on charges of taking money from illegal aliens in return for introducing citizenship bills in Congress.

title: DOW IS DOWN 9.90 IN LOAN RATE RISE
description: The stock market, reacting to higher loan charges announced by major banks, fell sharply yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 9.90 points to close at 963.90, its lowest level in more than three months.

title: Ford Says the Hays Case Disturbs Him and Nation
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)President Ford said today that he and the nation were disturbed by the possible misuse of taxpayers money when Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, put Mr. Hays's paramour, Elizabeth Ray, on the House payroll. Mr. Ford said he warned the House five years ago that such a scandal might happen.

title: South Africans Exultant Over Kissinger Meeting
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 4South Africa today hailed the coming meeting between Sec retary of State Henry A, Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster as a major breakthrough for the Government after years of diplomatic isolation. But the enthusiasm was tempered by a sense of the difficulty that the two men are likely to have in finding comissues ground on the principal issues they are to discuss.

title: Books of The Times
description: The attempt of the will to do the work of the imagination: \V. B. Yeats applied this phrase to an incorrect approach to poetry. In Lying, Despair, Jealousy, Envy, Sex, Suicide, Drugs, and the Good Life, Leslie Farber applies it to an incorrect approach to life. Ours, he says, is the age of the disordered will. It is our conceit that no human possibility is beyond our conscious will. T. S. Eliot had something similar in mind when he said that the bad poet is conscious when he should be unconscious, and unconscious when he should be conscious.

title: Con Ed Asks Rate Rise
description: After a 5 percent rise in electric rates less than three months ago, the Consolidated Edison Company requested a further increase of 10.4 percent to take effect a year from now. Page 16.

title: I don't want to be in that number, when the Saints go marching in.
description: As a former semiflowerchild, fervent peace marcher and honorable hippie of the sixties, observing the various Presidential hopefuls as they jockey for position is mildly amusing, at best. And as they each proceed to package and market themselves and become dangerous parodies of one another, it is there that my amusement ends.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Bergen Pines County Hospital in Paramus, which accommodates almost 1,000 patients in its 16 divisions, has awarded certificates of appreciation to 300 volunteers from 50 communities who contribute about 18,000 hours of service annually, according to Mary Catherine King, coordinator of volunteers for the general hospital.

title: Busing Politics
description: While the Justice Department flareup on school busing has been extinguished by Attorney General Edward H. Levi's proper decision not to intervene on behalf of one of the groups appealing the Boston busing order, the race issue has nevertheless been injected into President Ford's election cammien.

title: Ethnic Escape From the Quick and the Frozen
description: As difficult as it can be for a visitor to a city to get beyond the facade of mustsee allpurpose continental restaurapts that natives always seem proudest of, that is precisely what I was determined to do during a recent stay in Chicago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The multiple factors that finally converged in Chancellor Kibbee's decision to close the City University had the inevitable overtones of a Greek tragedy. Month after month both New York City and Albany allowed political expediency to foreclose decision and action, while the university drifted into a state of increasing chaos and demoralization.

title: Rider Is Shot Dead on IND in Village After Argument as 35 Witness Crime
description: As dozens of horrified riders looked on, a 33yearold Brooklyn man was shot to death, aboard a subway train in Greenwich Village early yesterday after an exchange of insulting remarks with his alleged killer, a visitor from Yugoslavia who then waited guninhand on a station platform for the nolice.

title: Merrill Lynch Will Pay $1.9 Million in Bias Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith agreed today to settle two antidiscrimination suits brought against it by paying $1.9 million to individuals it had wrongfully failed to hire or promote and by adopting a $1.3 million, fiveyear plan of affirmative action to employ more women and minoritygroup members.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States yesterday lost its fight to keep the Palestine Liberation Organization out of the 132nation World Employment Conference in Geneva. The governing body of the International Labor Organization, which had decided by the margin of one vote last Saturday to bar the P.L.O. from the conference, reversed itself under pressure from the League of Arab States, the Organization of African Unity and the Soviet bloc. Despite the rebuff, the American delegates decided not to walk out, but they will boycott sessions in whh the P.L.O. participates. [Page 1, Column 4.1

title: Biplane Flies Out of Past With a Jet Pilot at Stick
description: NEWARK, June 4  Appearing like a gnat amid a swarm of bees, a 1929 biplane made a series of takeoffs and landings at Newark International Airport today as dozens of giant 747's, DC10's and DC727's arrived and departed.

title: Shift Reported Set For Miss Quinlan To Nursing Home
description: Arrangements have reportedly been completed to move Karen Ann Quinlan to a nursing home in Morris Plains, N.J., presumably to end the use of the extraordinary means that have kept her alive for 114 months.

title: Guards of Amager Is Danced With Charm
description: To say that a ballet company is characterized by its charm may not sound all that pxciting, but to a certain extent this is true of the Royal Panish Ballet. It is one of the great companies of the world, and certainly it has itiany qualities to commend It other than charm. Yet Charm is a factor, and a considerable one, in its appeal. Much of this charm comes from the fact that it has an unparalleled collection of 19thcentury ballets by Its *eat choreographer August Bournonville.

title: People in Sports
description: The Nastase, who left the Hawaii Leis of World Team Tennis last week after playing in only nine matches, turned up yesterday in Paris as a spectator at the French open.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A judge sentenced five members of the Newark City Council to jail yesterday for refusing to vote for courtordered measures that could increase city taxes. The five were held in contempt of court by Judge Harry Margolis of Superior Court and told to report to the county jail at noon Monday and stay there until they change their votes. City Council resolutions for a new survey of values have been defeated 13 times in the last four years, most recently by a 5to4 vote on Wednesday. Henry Martinez, Anthony Carrino, Sharpe James, Donald Tucker and Marie Villani voted against the resolution, and all said they would do so in the future despite the jail sentence.

title: Photos of Corning Residents Bedeck New People Wall.
description: CORNING, N.Y., June 4Amory Houghton Jr. is on the wall. So is Jim Sheaffer. Charlie McGrady is up there, along with Karen Murphy and Joanne Winters, who are both in uniform. Over there is At Moses and just beyond, Joe and Eleanor Nasser.

description: In a provocative aside, the staff report of the Emergency Financial Control Board calls on New Yorkers to look at their budgetary problems in a more positive perspective.

description: MINEOLA, Li., June 4Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, pleaded not guilty in District Court here today to a charge of driving while impaired by alcohol. The plea was entered by his lawyer, Michael Stafford.

title: Swiss Buy Dollars; Pound Rises a Little
description: LONDON, June 4 (AP)The dollar gained today on the recently rising Swiss franc for the second consecutive day, and the ailing British pound staged a small recovery from yesterday's record low.

title: Capital Gains Tax Revives Era of Debate in Paris

description: Walter P. Cartun, the president of Emhart Industries Inc., died yesterday in Hartford Hospital. He was 60 years old and resided in Avon, Conn.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 4 (Reuters)Two youths shot dead a passenger in a taxi and critically injured the driver today in apparent retaliation, for an earlier raid in which two young Catholics here were shot) and wounded.

description: Katharine MacKenty Bryan, cofounder of the Princeton Society of Musical Amateurs and former concert manager of Princeton University Concerts, died yesterday morning of cancer at the Princeton Medical Center. She was 72 years old and was a resident of Princeton.

Her first event is a public reception sponsored by the Bay Area Reoublican Alliance in Oakland's Claremont Hotel.

description: An entire concert of compositions by Irwin Swack was giyen Thursday night at Carne gie Recital Hall. Mr. Swack, whose teachers included Vittoria Giannini, Norman Lockwood and Henry Cowell, proved to be a diligent manipulator of traditional musical forms and ai enthusiastic eclectic. His writing for a variety of instrumental combinations also showed competence and exDertence.

description: The conclusion must come at the top. Wine Untouched will play only today and tomorrow, and next Wednesday through Sunday, at the 18th Street Playhouse. There isn't much time to see it, and it is extraordinarily well worth seeing.

title: Six Arab Nations Back Talks on Lebanon
description: CAIRO, June 4Six Arab countries have agreed to attend an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the Arab League members to discuss the Syrian military intervention in Lebanon, a league spokesman said today. At least five more of the 20 members must agree before the meeting can be held.

description: King Juan Carlos I of Spain arrived in New York yesterday, stressing that he expected development in his country to remain in an orderly and stable framework.

description: TOKYO, June 4 (Reuters)Yoshio Kodama, a key figure in the Lockheed payments scandal, was indicted today on additional charges of having received money in violation of the foreign exchange and trade control law.

title: 2 Exiled Opposition Leaders Seized on Return to Spain
description: MADRID, June 4 (UPI) A judge ordered the arrest of two opposition politicians today who returned to Spain from exile following the death of Franco.

title: VIGGO KANIPMANN, EXDANISH LEADER
description: Viggo Kampmann, a former Danish Prime Minister, died. Thursday in Copenhagen. A Social Democrat, Mr. Kampmann took office in 1960 but was forced to step down two 1 years later because of a chronic heart ailment.

title: Avocado Success: Benign Neglect
description: Those who think they have green thumbs may well be humbled by the fact that Justin Kreuzer has accomplished what few gardeners have: He has raised an avocado tree indoors that flowers and produces fruit, He hasn't claimed any edible harvest records, yet, as the tiny avocados reach only six or seven millimeters in size before they drop off, but the fruits are genuine.

title: West Indies Posts 494 Cricket Score
description: NOTTINGHAM, England. June 4 (Reuters)Viv Richards hit a magnificent 232 in leading the %Vest Indiesto a fine first innings total of 494 runs today on the second day of the first cricket test against England at Trent Bridge.

description: WASHINGTON, June 4Dr. Malcolm R. Currie, a highranking Pentagon official who was severely reprimanded last March for accepting hospitality from a major defense contractor, has quietly been placed in charge of the development and acquisition of all weapons by the Defense Department.

title: Figure in Threats Seized
description: BRANFORD, Fla., June 5 (AP) Michael Lance Carvin, 21 years old, who first tried suicide and then jumped bail following his conviction for threatening Pres dent Ford, Vice President Rockefeller and Ronald Reagan, was caught by sheriff's deputies today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Equality vs. Liberty
description: The political upheavals of the 1960's and the economic crisis of the 1970's have spawned a revival of the centuriesold debate about the conflict between equality and liberty.

title: Dice Wins In Jumping At Devon
description: DEVON, Pa., June 4Mike Hunter rode Harry Gill's Determined Dice to an easy victory today in the intermediate jumper division at the Devon Horse Show.

title: Celtics Outlast Suns; Fan Attacks Referee
description: BOSTON, June 4Surviving three overtimes, thousands of rioting fans and two endings, the Boston Celtics defeated the Phoenix Suns, 128126 tonight. The victory was marred, however, by an attack by a Boston Garden fan on one of the referees, Richie Powers. The nearly miraculous, emotionpacked victory gave the Celtics a threegametotwo lead in the fourofseven National Basketball Association championship.

title: CRASH OF SOVIET JET REPORTED BY ANGOLA
description: LUANDA, Angola, June (AP)A Soviet jetliner missing since Tuesday crashed in West Africa shortly before it was, to land at Malabo, in Equatorial Guinea, with 36 passengers and 10 crew members aboard, TAG; the Angolan national airline, reported today.

title: Byrd Cites Carter Request
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) Senator Robert C. Byrd, winner of the West Virginia Democratic Presidential primary, said today that Jimmy Carter had asked to meet with him: He called me and indicated an interest in visiting with me after the primaries, said the West Virginia Senator. Asked about the topic for discussion, Mr. Byrd replied, He didn't say.

title: Full Potato Inquiry Vowed by Exchange In Reply to Charges
description: Stung by Government charges of lagging or lack of action on the large defaults in potato futures contracts, Richard B. Levine, president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, said yesterday that more time was required to undo this mess.

title: CON ED REQUESTS A 10.4% RATE RISE
description: Less than three months after a 5 percent increase in Consolidated Edison's electric rates took effect, the company yesterday requested a new increase of more than double that amount.

title: Deficit of Soviet Trade Widened During Quarter
description: MOSCOW. June 4 (UPI)The Soviet Union reported today that its huge trade deficit with the West widened again in the firit quarter of 1976, led by a doubling of imports from the United States.

title: Ford to Ask 3Year Review O Future Busing Cases
description: WASHINGTON, June 4President Ford said today that the antiquing legislation hel plans to send to Congress would require that every future court case ordering busing be reopened every three years to see whether court jurisdiction could be lifted.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut yesterday vetoed a bill that would have lowered the maximum penalty for possession of marijuana to three months in jail and a $250 fine. The Governor contended that the General Assembly had failed in not providing for one penalty for those carrying large quantities and another, lighter penalty, for those with small quantities. The existing law provides for penalties from one year and a $1,000 fine for persons caught the first time with less than four ounces of marijuana to 10 years and a $5,000 fine for second offenders with four ounces or more.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSAdam A. beloved husband of the late Ida, devoted father of Bryna Krackow and Bernard Abrams, adored brother and loving grandfather. Services Sunday, 10 A.M., at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike oh mbe east of Seaford. Oyster Bay Expressway), Woodbury, L.I.

title: Method of Screening for Breast Cancer Without Visiting Doctor Gets a Patent
description: WASHINGTON, June 4A new method invented by Government specialists is intended to enable women to undergo mass screening for breast cancer without visiting doctors.

title: to DEMOTION BID SURVIVED BY HAYS
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 House Democrats negotiated further disciplinary action today against Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio, but one attempt to strip him quickly, of / second committee chairmanihip failed.

description: France's Transport Minister Marcel Cavaille, told the French National Assembly yesterday that, although France and Britain had decided not to authorize any more Concorde production now, the way would be left open for increased output if new sales could be made.

title: Al Green Has Up Night Singing at Uris Theater
description: Al Green is a performer who gives new meaning to the word erratic, and his onstage variability has done much to dim a career that not too many years ago looked to be the most distinguished among contemporary black male singers.

title: EXGOY. BABCOCK SPARED JAIL TERM
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) A Federal district judge ruled today that former Gov. Tim M. Babcock of Montana will not have to serve a fourmonth jail term for hiding the identity of the donor of $54,000 to former President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 campaign. However, a $1,000 fine against him was =held.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4The renegade Lebanese Arab Army and the head of the leftistMoslem coalition, Kamal Jumblat, made appeals today that indicated that the groups were more interested in talking than fighting with the Syrian armed forces that have intervened in Lebanon.

description: Of course, Jimmy Carter is a Baptist and I know Baptists well. They are among the best and some are the worst people I have ever knownsubstitute any other religion and the same statement holds.

description: Iced broilers on the Chicago Board of Trade and cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange attracted traders interest yesLerday, in an otherwise dull trading session.

title: Spanning the Spectrum
description: COLUMBUS. Ohio, June 4Early in the 1976 Presidential campaign some politicians and journalists expressed surprise or wonder that opinion polls showed that conservatives seemed to see Jimmy Carter as a News conservative and Analysis liberals to see him as a liberal. There may be more political mastery than mystery in that fact. All politicians running for national office must address a national constituency of complex and widely diverse parts.

description: Citywide negotiations for new labor contracts covering 150,000 workers opened yesterday with the city telling the unions that they must give up $24 million in fringe benefits or face further layoffs.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES ENERGY AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 4A study of the records of two major Federal energy agencies has found that more than half Id their top officials came to the agencies from private enterprises holding contracts, licenses or permits from the agencies.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.. June 4 (AP)The class of 1951 has donated $1,445.700 to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, establishing record reunion gift at the school.

title: Rail Freight Rises 23%
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, 23 percent above the correspondirrg week a year ago, which included the Memorial Day holiday. Cnrloadings in the same period totaled 498,124 cars, 20,7 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity track tonnage was 34 7 nercent above last year.

description: New York City yesterday closed off till next week five miles of beaches in Queens as a precaution against contamination from sludge that exploded out of two sewage storage tanks in neighboring Nassau County, on Wednesday, night.

title: Lawyers on Nadjari Staff Warn They Too May Quit
description: Thirty of the 36 lawyers on Maurice H. Nadjari's staff have written to the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, threatening to resign if he agrees to any request by Governor Carey to appoint a second prosecutor to handle new corruption cases after July 1.

title: CBS Ordered to Pay $250,000 In Trespass by TV News Crew
description: A State Supreme Court jury has ordered CBS to pay more than $250,000 to an exclusive midtown restaurant because the network's television camera crew entered it without permission and took pictures.

title: Opportunity in Santiago
description: Chile's harsh military regime obviously hopes to gain a measure of international respectability by being host the Sixth General Assembly of the Organization of American States, now under way in Santiago. Mexico is boycotting the sessions to protest Chile's violations of human rights, and other critics of the military rulers had urged Secretary of State Kissinger to do the same.

title: Hudson County Democrats Oiling Up the Old Machine
description: JERSEY CITY, June 4Not too much. That would be unpredictable.

description: For the first time in the 21 years that the city has financed its Jonas E. Salk scholarships for City University students accepted by medical schools, women outnumbered the male winners by five to three.

description: The appointment of Hedrick L. Smith as chief of the Washington bureau of The New York Times was announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, managing editor.

description: Puppeteers of many countries, including Australia and Colombia, will join more than 1,000 American and Canadian members of the Puppeteers of America at the organization's 37th annual National Puppetry Festival at Connecticut College in New London, June 13 through 18. Cooperating in the Bicentennial meeting is the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford. Conn.

title: Reagan Is Far Backin Ohio, But He Has Rural Strength
description: WASHINGTON COURTHOUSE, Ohio, June 4If there is any influential Republican politician in this state who expects President Ford to do anything other than decisively defeat Ronald Reagan in next Tuesday's Ohio, primary, that politician has not yet made his opinion known.

The San Franciscobased SinoAmerican Buddhist Association, which bought the Mendocino State Hospital grounds in East Ukiah's Tale mage area three days ago, said it had immediate plans for a community of 10,000 followers of Buddha and likeminded individuals.

description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 4 (AP) Nine persons were convicted here today in Federal District Court of running a major heroin smuggling operation between Thailand and the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, June 4The State Department said today that a major goal of Secretary: I of State Henry A. Kissinger's; coming meeting with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa would be the coordination of views on how to avoid la race war in southern Africa.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES SLOWED INCREASE TO 0.370 FOR MAY
description: The rate of increase it wholesale prices slowed during May, the Government announced yesterday, providing evidence that the upward pressure on inflation had abated.

title: Ship Rams Pier in Boston.
description: BOSTON, June 4 (AP)A Coast Guard cutter rammed into a concrete pier at Boston Harbor today, causing considerable damage to both the ship and the wharf, the authorities reported. The 327foot cutter Ingham was arriving for dockside radar repairs when the accident bccurred.

title: OIL DEAL STUDIED BY PETROCANADA
description: Petro Canada, the Canadian Government oil company, said in Ottawa, yesterday it was considering purchasing between $300 million and $350 million of Atlantic Richfield's Canadian assets and not the whole company, which was valued at $400 million in the original sale offer. On March 5, tttlantic Richfield Canada startd discussions with PetroCanada for the sale of 100 percent of its common shares. The purchase price was based on reserve and engineering valuation of the assets of Atlantic Richfield Canada consisting of gas and oil rights on 11.4 million acres in Canada, a substantial portion of which are in the Hudson Bay area and the Arctic islands.

title: Carter Buying Simultaneous Time on Three Networks
description: CLEVELAND, June 4Jimmy Carter has purchased simultaneous fiveminute spots on the three commercial television networks in an effort to reverse an undercurrent of negative feelings about his candidacy that has been showing up in recent polls and interviews with voters.

title: Merrill Lynch Will Pay $1.9 Million in Bias Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & (Smith agreed today to settle two antidiscrimination suits brought against it by paying $1.9 million to individuals it had wrongfully failed to hire or promote and by adopting a $1.3 million, fiveyear plan of affirmative action to employ more women and minoritygroup members.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States yesterday lost its fight to keep the Palestine Liberation Organization out of the 132nation World Employment Conference in Geneva. The governing body of the International Labor Organization, which had decided by the margin of one vote last Saturday to bar the P.L.O. from the conference, reversed itself under pressure from the League of Arab States, the Organization of African Unity and the Soviet bloc. Despite the rebuff, the American delegates decided not to walk out, but they will boycott sessions in which the P.L.O. participates. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Jacobsen Suspended From Bar
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 4 (UPI)Jake Jacobsen, a lawyer who was a figure in the Texas stock fraud scandal and in the last of the major trials related to Watergate, has been suspended from practicing law.

title: I L.O. TALKS ADMIT THE PALESTINIANS,
description: GENEVA, June 4The United States tonight lost its fight to keep the Palestine Liberation, Organization out of the 132nation World Employment Conference.

title: Siderowf Gains Final In Scotland
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 4 (AP)Dick Siderowf, a Wall Street stockbroker and weekend golfer, scrambled from two holes down today to beat Allan Brodie of Scotland, 2 and 1. and reach the final of the British Amateur golf championship for the second time in four years.

title: Hitin Ninth Spoils Messersmith Bid
description: Andy Messersmith, baseball's secondrichest pitcher, lost a nohitter against Montreal last night when Pepe Mangual whacked a oneout single in the ninth inning.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHARPLY LOWER
description: Rising Interest rates sent prices sharply lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: 4 Injured in Clash of Italian Extremists
description: ROME, June 4Four persons were wounded tonight when rightwing and leftwing groups battled each other and the police in the Piazza Venezia in downtown Rome.

title: Satellite Traffic Is Shifted By RCA to Better Service
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had shifted traffic, as planned, from the first of its two domestic communications satellites to the second on Wednesday, and that it would move the backup craft westward next week.

title: Witness in Maiming Of Writer Gives Up But Refuses to Talk
description: PHOENIX, June 4 (AP)John Adamson, 32 years old, sought by the police as a key witness in a bombing attack that maimed a Phoenix newspaper reporter, surrendered today but refused to be questioned, the police said.

title: Kingman Hits 3 In 110 Victory
description: LOS ANGELES, Jun 4Dave Kingman and Tom Seaver of the New York Nlets emerged from slumps with a vengeance tonight and led their team to an 110 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Brown Decides to Stump In Jersey Again Monday
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 4 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. announced today that he would return to New Jersey on Monday for a lastminute flurry of campaigning for the uncommitted slate in that state's Democratic Presidential election Tuesday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EPSOM. England, June 4 (UPI)Pawneese, the 54 favorite, ran her unbeaten string to four races today with a fivelength victory in the running of the 198th Oaks, the premier British fillies classic.

description: The state's program to provide tuition aid for City University students will cost at least $S million more than is being called for in the university rescue package now languishing in the Legislature, according to an official of the corporation that operates the program.

title: CORRECTIONS

Genkins. Dr. Genkins is chairman of the mathematics department at the Collegiate School and clinical associate of mathematics education at Teachers College.

title: Waking up from the Canadian dream
description: MONTREAL. Every Canadian school child for the last 70 years has been brought up to believe the most celebrated of national aphorisms: The 19th century was the century of the United States. The 20th century belongs to Canada.

title: Mailbox:
description: There is much to be said on the issue of how blacks have fared in professional sports, but David Q. Voigt's pop sociology on the subject (Black Man and Baseball: A Melting Pot Is Dented, May 9) simply will not do. It only repeats a lot of old accusations that have not, as I see it, stood the test of time.

title: Andrea R. Franklin, an Artist, Is Bride of Richard A. M. Lyon
description: The marriage of Andrea Remsen Franklin to Richard Addison Mitchell Lyon. son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Lyon of Pittsburgh, yesterday afternoon, took place in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. John A. Bell performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. A. Kerr Franklin.

title: Ken Rosewall
description: Who is the greatest tennis player of all time? Devotees of the game are always ready to wade in on that question and the names roll out each with heavy supportTilden Kramer, Perry, Gonzales, Laver, Rfirive.

title: Wife of Beame's Counsel Called, Contender for Council Vacancy
description: The wife of Mayor Beame's counsel has the inside track for appointment to a vacancy on the City Council, according to some Manhattan politicians involved in the complex negoI tiations.

title: Cynthia Lou Wetherell Bride Of Frederic Ely Williamson 2d
description: St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mystic. Conn., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Cynthia Lou Wetherell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Wetherell Jr. of Bowie, Md. to Frederic Ely Williamson 2d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Long Williamson Jr. of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y. The Rev Dr. Arthur Lee Xinsolving performed the ceremony.

title: Preparing for Yesterday
description: STONY BROOK THREE years in the planning, one year in the creating and a frantic week of sawing, hammering, staking and settingup, Festival 76the Bicentennial celebration being held here this weekendis as much a tribute to the nearly 1,000 dedicated community volunteers who produced it as to the Colonial heritage it salutes.

title: Friesland: Within the Netherlands But a Place Apart
description: Mata Hari the femme fatale grew up here. So did Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch colonial administrator when New York City was New Amsterdam. Although Friesland lies within the boundaries of the Netherlands, its people speak a language of their own and when they refer to foreign visitors, they generally mean the Dutch.

title: Suez Canal Reopening Celebrated by Egypt
description: CAIRO, June 5Egypt today celebrated the first anniversary of the reopening of the Suez Canal with parades, singing and dancing and a sense of renewal in an area lergely destroyed in two wars with Israel.

title: Paul Hopkins Weds Mary Wallhauser
description: Mary Wallhauser, daughter of Louise G. Wallhauser of Hopewell Township, N.J., and George M. Wallhauser of South Orange, N.J. was married in New York yesterday evening to Paul Mitchell Hopkins. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Hopkins of Boonton Township, N.J.

title: Loans to Communists
description: Communist countries borrowing in the West is rising so much that the lending banks in this country and Western Europe are stiffening their terms and some American banks are said to be nearing their legal lending limits. Details, Section 3.

title: Hempstead Looks a Gift Horse in the Mouth
description: Berg termed our opposition to the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development intransigent and politically motivated.

title: Sue Hays Performs in Rodeo For Love and Not for Money
description: Sue Pirtle Hays speaks softly and shakes hands with a firm grip. Her quiet manner is probably the result of smalltown upbringing; her firm grip, the result of riding 1,500pound bulls Women and bareback broncs. It was in adolescent spunk that got Mrs. Hays involved in rodeos 12 years ago. Today that spunk has been replaced by a selfassurance that is an extra help in her profession.

title: COLEMAN DEFERS AIRBAG DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. has postponed his scheduled announcement on how the Government Mends to resolve the stormy question of whether to require the installation of air bags on all new cars sold in this country, until after next Tuesday's Presidential primaries.

description: EUGENE, Ore., June 5 (AP) Paul Geis qualified for the Olympic trials in the 5,000meters run today during the Steve Prefontaine Classic track and field meet.

title: Fast Servers Get Their Big Chance
description: Two tennis events are on hand that reflect the booming growth of the sport.

title: Book Ends
description: Forgotten Men. Elsewhere in this issue you'll see reviews of a plethora of political bboks. To this column falls the task of sweeping up the leavings mainly all the campaign biographies lying about that we've been unable to cover because of the profusion of candidates this year. Admittedly these are some of the more obscure hopefuls, whom you, the fickle public, has already consigned to forgetfulness with good reason. But attention must be paid to these upward strivers, all of whom suffer from negative recoenition factors.

title: Cosmos in Tampa to Battle the Rowdies
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 5 Looking like a group of wornout traveling salesmen, the New York Cosmos arrived from Santo Domingo yesterday. The reason for their stop here is tomorrow's scheduled North American Soccer League game against the Tampa Bay Rowdies. The contest, which has a pregame sale of 35,000 tickets, will be televised live nationally by CBS (Channel 2 in New York) at 1:30 P.M.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: VIRTUOSIPianist Rudolf Serkin, who has always been annoyed by the thickness of his hands, nonetheless caused Harold Schonberg to remark after a recent concert. From the beginning, Serkin has never hit a note that was an ideal, and false. He has always had an ideal, and has spent his life in pursuit of it. On Wednesday, Mr. Serkin will appear at the 92d Street Y. In a program consisting of Mendelssohn's Prelate and Fugue in E minor, Beethoven's Sonata in E, Op. 109 and Chopin's Twentyfour Preludes.

title: Man Who Fell to Earth Is Beautiful Science Fiction
description: There are quite a few sciencefiction movies scheduled to come out in the next year or so. We shall be lucky if even one or two are as absorbing and as beautiful as 'The Man Who Fell to Earth;  which opened yesterday at ?? Cmema I and Cinema II Theaters.

Coiled naturalrope sole is laced with rustcolored strings that match outside edge of shoe. Yves Saint Laurent. $22. 4th floor, Bloomingdale's. Classic sandal is thonged in red, white and navy leather. $16. 2d floor, Bonwit Teller. Grecian sandal barely covers the foot with braided strips of metallic leather. $38. Charles Jourdan. Summer shoes are flat as pancakes, Heels are barely visible lifts, and, more often than not, designs are simply bands or twists of leather or lengths of rope or ribbon attached directly to the sole.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe American Dream and inc Lessen. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June 26). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly. $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 675.1881.

title: Presidential Race: For Some, Part of Growing Up
description: PRINCETON IT was a few minutes past midnight when Vince Fabrizio returned home at the end of one of his 16hour days. He had just sped down the Garden State Parkway and U.S. 1 from Bergen County, where he was the principal speaker at the dedication of a local campaign headquarters.

title: The Industrial and Developing Worlds Do Have Common Interests
description: PARISThe poorer, more populous, mainly southern nations of the planet have been saying for some time that they no longer will be simply the hewers of wood and drawers of water for the more affluent industrial countries of the north.

title: The Search Begins at Loch Ness
description: DRUMNADROCHIT. Scotland, June 5The search for the Loch Ness monster has begun.

title: Elections: The Way We Were
description: THE way we did things before they changed the rules was predictable. This Tuesday, New Jersey confronts a real Presidential primary, with candidates having visited to solicit votes, the Democratic Governor and the Democratic state chairman on opposite sides and the outcome both questionable and of some significance.

title: Tibetan Judged Greenwich Best
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 5 Ch. Kontan's Shazam BuTsa, a Tibetan terrier owned by Eileen D. Wilk of Camp Springs, Md., was named best in show today in an entry of 1,903 dogs at the Greenwich Kennel Club Show held on the estate grounds of Richard Colhoun.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Oakland A's finish their series against the Yankees with a doubleheader today in Yankee Stadium beginning at o'clock. The California Angels come into the Stadium for 8 o'clock games Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights, and the Texas Rangers, for a weekend series, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and 2 o'clock on Sunday.

title: Paul HarveyShort on Objectivity, Big With Listeners
description: Paul Harvey, the veteran newscaster who makes no pretense to objectivity and whose name in middleAmerican circles is often mentioned in the same breath as flag waving, mainstream and the Veterans of Foreign Wars, has given the country a Bicefitennial gift a new daily radio series called The Rest of the Story. The program is only five minutes long and it consists of what Harvey terms factual fairy tales that tell the little heartbeats behind the headlines. The fairy tales range from how Mary Had a Little Lamb was composed to the inside account of how Harry Truman first caught the eye of Kansas City's former political boss, Tom Pendergast. In the New York metropolitan area, the series made its debut at 6:55 P.M. on May 10 over WMCA, an ABC Radio affiliate.

title: ExC.I.A. Head Proposes Penalizing Federal Officials Who Leak Secrets, Not the Press
description: PRICETON, N.J., June 5William E. Colby, the former director of Central Intelligence, proposed today that any rastraints or penalties on the release of secret documents to the press should be placed on Federal officials instead of on reporters.

title: Rug Importers Thrive
description: For some reason, said Archie Cherkasian, Fifth Avenue has always had a special appeal to rug merchants.

title: Anne Pelgrift, G. R. Crawford Have Nuptials
description: Anne Nicoll Pelgrift, daughter of Assistant Attorney General Robert Youngs Pelgrift of Connecticut and Mrs. Pelgrirt of West Hartford, and Cregorj Robert Crawford were married yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Crawford of Interlaken, N.J.

title: Doctor of Letters for a Musician of Note
description: Honored: Hugo Weisgail of Great Neck. The composerconductor, who is professor of music at Queens College, associate for education for the Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts and chairman of the Jewish Theological Seminary's College of Music, has been awarded the degree of Doctor of Letters by the seminary at its commencement exercises.

title: Iran's ExEnvoy to Britain Found Dead in His Home
description: LONDON, June 5 (Reuters) Iran's former Ambassador to London, Mohammed Riza Amirteymour, was found dead in his house here last night.

title: PreRevolution Bonds
description: In 1916, the Bryden Neverslip Company of Catasauqua, Pa., shipped thousands of dollars worth of military equipment. to Russiahorseshoes for the animals that pulled the guns of the Czar's artillery.

title: Lawyer Fiance of Miss Culbertson
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison Culbertson of New Vernon, N. J. and Sea Island, Ga. have made known the engagement of their daughter. Katharine Kirby Culbertson. to W. Miles Prentice Bd. son of E. Miles Prentice of Montpelier, Vt.. and the late Anna Kiernan Prentice. The future bride was presented in 1965 at the Morristown (N. J.) Debutante Assembly. She graduated from the Oldfields School in Glencoe, Md, attended the American School in Lugano, Switzerland, for one year, and received a bachelor's degree from Wilson College.

title: California Varsity Crew Victor
description: SYRACUSE, June 5The coach did not believe a victory was remotely possible but his athletes did. So the oarsmen from the University of California won the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today on Onondaga Lake, giving the Golden Bears from Berkeley the national championship for the first time in 12 years.

title: Circe Declared Winner Of City Island Y. C. Race
description: Emanuel Greene's Circe. a greenhulled Swan43 sloop out of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, Port Washington, L.I., was the correctedtime winner of the City Island Yacht Club's 24th annual day race on Long Island Sound today.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: A Banker's FiveYear Plan for the Cities (May 16) reasons: Closing the budget deficit, whether by raising taxes, cutting spending, or both, satisfies the bond market as to the value of city bonds. But it does so at the risk of weakening regional economic activity even further.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) Nearly four million students will enter the work force this summer as the nation's schools let out, all of them vying for' jobs in an already tight labor market, the Labor Department said today. Experts estimated this will cause the youth labor force to rise to 25.8 million by July, or about 600,000 more than last year.

title: American Accent For Haute Cuisine
description: GREAT NECK A GOOD many hostesses owe their usccessful dinner parties (to say nothing of their culinary reputations to Miriam Perle and Rhoda Kafer, Les Chefettes of Grea Neck.

title: Four Herbs for Flavor
description: Hyssop, burnet, germander, rue I couldn't do without these four handsome herbs. Their looks chiefly recommend them, but each has some usefulness, too. All are hardy perennials and practically evergreen.

title: New Nature Trail
description: HAWORTH PLEASE touch the flowers could be the motto of a mature trail that has been opened for the blind and visually handicapped on property owned by the Oradell Reservoir. The trail, a project of the Oradell Lions Club, is situated on a fiveacre peninsula of pine woods jutting into the reservoir itself; it runs for 2,200 feet, with 20 stations or points of interest linked by nylon rope that the blind follow.

title: Ohio: Urban and Industrial Yet Republican
description: CINCINNATIIn The Megastates of America, Neal R. Peirce begins his discussion of the nation's sixthlargest state with these words: Ohio, mother of secondrate Presidents, hung up about its own identity (East Westerners, West to Easterners), the personification of the middleclass society, is the least distinctive of the great industrial states.

title: The Exquisite Agony Of a Musical Olympics
description: Half an hour after the commencement of the finals of the 29th Leventritt International Competition 12 days ago, a possibly deranged individual wearing a purple beret strode up to the stage door of Carnegie Hall and announced that he had just arrived from Paris to take part in the prestigious piano contest.

title: ANGOLA PUTS OFF OPENING OF TRIAL
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 5The Angolan Government today postponed the opening of the trial of 13 mercenaries to give an American lawyer time to study the cases. The trial was to have started Tuesday.

title: Miss MacDonald Plans June Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Sterling MacDonald of Beverly, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Ames MacDonald, to Thomas A. Urquhart, manager of the Proposition, the improvised musical revue theater in Cambridge, Mass.

title: IDAHO DAM BURSTS; 30,000 EVACUATED
description: IDAHO FALLS, June 5A corner of the new Teton Dam, crumbled today, spreading water over 300 square miles in the upper Snake River Valley and forcing about 30,000 persons from their homes in six agricultural communities.

title: Mayer Helps Sets Beat Lobsters, 2519
description: UNIONDALE, L. I. June 5 Sandy Mayer led the New York Sets to a 2519 World Team Tennis victory over the Boston Lobsters before 2,452 fans in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A young man plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from the Unisphere on the grounds of the 196465 Worlds Fair in Flushing, Queens. The police said the man, tentatively identified as 23yearold Hector Zelez, apparently lost his footing while climbing on the circular steel structure and fell about 35 feet. He died of head injuries. The police last night were attempting to ascertain Mr. Zeliz home address, and notify his survivors of the fatal mishap.

title: Vacation Reading List
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 7, 1975. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted commentsare from earlier issues of the Book Review.

title: Rachel Ritvo Bride Of S. M. Beckman
description: The marriage of Rachel Zeporah Ritvo, a member of the class of 77 at the Yale School of Medicine, to Steven Mark Beckman, a candidate for a master's degree in economics at the University of Massachusetts, took place last evening in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Carter Tells Crowds in Jersey He'd Move to Strengthen Navy
description: PATERSON, N.J., June 5Jiminv Carter said today that the United States Navy was probably still superior to the Soviet Union fleet and that as President he would favor an aggressive shipbuilding program with concentration on quality and mobility of American vessels.

title: Being of Sound Mind, He May Try Snake Oil Next
description: When there's a will, there's a wayto make money.

title: A Lady for The Open?
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 5In an era when Janet Guthrie hoped to qualify for the Indianapolis 500 and female jockeys are as familiar at race tracks as the parimutuel windows, why hasn't a female golfer entered the United States Open golf tournament? The primary reason, judging by conversations with several prominent lady pros. in the Girl Talk Classic at the Wykagl Country Club, is that they had assumed the United States Open was a men's tournament. When they were informed it was open to them, JoAnne Carner and Amy Alcott each thought it would be fun but none of the others sounded that adventurous.

title: The West End Horror
description: By Nicholas Meyer. 222 pp. New York E. P. Dutton. $795.

title: Miss Babson Is Bride of M. R. McAvoy
description: The marriage of Katherine Lockhard Babson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Leveau Babson of Lyndeboro, N. H. and Wellesley Hills. Mass. to Michael Robert McAvoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earl McAvoy of Wellesley, Mass. took place yesterday afternoon in the First Congregational Church in Wellesley Hills.

title: Matlack Stops Dodgers, 31
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5 Dave Kingman and that good New York pitching did it agairt to the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: The Met Makes a Major Acquisition
description: Nowhere is there a museumman quite like Sir John Pope  Hennessy. Between them, the Metropolitan Museum and New York University's Institute of Fine Arts did a great day's work for this city when they insured  against competition from both Washington end Bostonthat as of Jan. 1, 1977, John PopeHennessy will have a doubleheaded appointmentas consultative chairman of the Department of Paintings at the Met and professor of art history at the Institute. New York will be the livelier for that elongated silhouette, those restless, highlyenergized movements and that unmistakable swooping utterance.

title: Voters to Have A Wide Choice
description: THOSE New Jersey voters not enthused over any of the major candidates for President will have other choices to pick from on the primary ballot this Tuesday. And in November, the ballot, in addition to listing the Democratic and Republican Presidential candidates, will include candidates from 10 splinter parties.

title: Corruption and a Dream
description: In this bicentennial year, it may be hard for modern America to identify with the pure idealism of the revolutionary heroes of 1776. It may be embarrassing acknowledge the greater similarities between today and the United States of a hundred years ago. Then as now, the dream of responsible government conducted by citizenpoliticians elected by their fellow free men seemed flawed by corruption and hypocrisy.

title: MARY ELIZABETH UHL
description: Mary Elizabeth Uhl, believed to have been the first woman actuary in this country, died Friday of cancer at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 330 East 53d Street.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Having owned a series of sailboats sailed out of Manhasset Bay for nearly a quarter century, I am alarmed by Miss Patterson's article (Opinion Page, May 2] which is, I believe, a biased account of the facts about pollution by boats.

title: Foyt Wins Texas 500 Pole Spot
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. June 5(AP)A.J. Foyt, characteristically waiting until the last minute to qualify, knocked Farrel Harris out of the pole position today for tomorrow's $100,000 Texas 500 stockcar race at Texas World Speedway.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: Bay er Uerdingan 0, H.S.V. Homburg 1.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's doubleheader, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 1 P.M.

title: Lace, Head of Con Ed, Gets $40,000 Raise
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, which on Friday asked the Public Service Commission for a 10.4 percent increase in electric rates, last month raised the salary of its chairman, Charles F. Luce, by 20 percent to $200,000 a year, a Con Ed spokesman said last night.

title: Massachusetts Tightening Security at Historic Sites
description: BOSTON, June 5 (AP)State and Federal agencies will provide increased protection for 14 historic sites in Massachusetts after a fire and a bombing attempt near two of the area's tourist attractions, Plymouth Rock and the Tea Party ship.

title: Rent Curbs In 7 Projects Superseded. By H.U.D.
description: In the first use of a controversial new policy, the Federal Government has superseded local rentlimiting programs in seven middleclass and luxury apartment properties in New York City and New Jersey.

title: GARDEIIING
description: ROSES, roses everywhere. New Jersey gardeners who love roses, but are up to their ears in vegetables and limply cannot spare the time to take proper care of a rose garden, can still grow a few of the hardy climbing varieties.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The intensity of primary battles in both political parties should not blind us to the fact that this is clearly shaping up as an election over fundamental principles, and not just strategies and tactics within parties. What forcefully brings this home are recent public statements by candidate Reagan and President Ford suggestive of a doublepronged attack on civil liberties and civil rights that clearly represent the position of both challenger and incumbent.

title: Elizabeth Welch, Stephen Glinick, Interns, Married
description: Dr. Elizabeth A. Welch and Dr. Stephen F. Glinick. interns at the Rogers Williams General Hospital of Brown University in Providence, R. I, were married yesterday afternoon in the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. Harry Baker Adams of the Disciples of Christ.

title: Libyan in Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5Maj. Abdul Salam Jalloud, the Libyan Prime Minister, arrived in Damascus tonight for urgent talks with Syrian leaders on the Lebanese crisis.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT was simply a question of color, and in the end the Board of Education voted red, modified. Of course, this doesn't really change anything in my town, which has been wrestling with color in the schools for at least a decade, because the state's Department of Education is most likely going to tell the town that red, even modified, is not the color.

title: The Texans
description: James Conaway's book is promising but patchy. In the end, his subjectwhich is the Texas establishment  helps him prove his thesis which is that the Texas establishment is as closemouthed, collectively, as a bed of clams. It would have taken a reporter with the combined assertiveness of David Halberstam, Sy Hersh and Daniel Schorr to pry open the likes of John Connally and George Brown (of Brown & Root), and Mr. Conaway doesn't have it. A rew or nib subjects, Bunker Hunt for example, elude him completely, at least in the flesh, and those that allow him into their actual offices elude him just as totally through a politeness that borders on contempt.
