For the most part he is left to chip away at the empires of the Hunts, the Browns, the Murchisons, Connally, H. Ross Perot the Houston law firms and the Houston oil companies from the outside only, through the use of public records. He gets the facts, but he misses the ambiance of the place and misses, also, those details of personality that a writer like Norman Mailer would have come up with, given the same amount of access.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: LOS ANGELES  When Bastian Hello wearies of running the most costly airplane project in the history of the world, he quits his desk and climbs into the cockpit of a tiny training plane. And then he goes flying, usually alone.

title: EAST BERLIN ACTS ON SOCIAL REFORM
description: EAST BERLIN, June 2Silence of the East German leadership on expected social reforms at the Communist Pan ty congress here last month stirred widespread discontent, but the Communists quickly caught up with the sensitive issue and moved to make amends.

title: Navy Chief in Dispute Over Use of Butter
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)  Navy Secretary J. William Middendorf 2d wants to switch from butter to margarine in both Navy and Marine kitchens for cooking purposes.

title: Royal Couple Gets to See The Goyas in Exhibition
description: The King of Spain began his day with scrambled eggs and toast. The Queen of Spain began her day with a trip to Bloomingdale's.

title: Correction
description: It was incorrectly stated in a dispatch in the Review last Sunday that Senators earn as much as $50,000 a year in outside speaking fees. This was true until 1975 when an annual ceiling of $15,000 was imposed; that was reised to $25,000 in the campaign bill enacted last month.

title: Rise in Cancer Death Rate Tied in Study to Plutonium
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Thee death rate from cancer found among a small group of plutonium workers was almost twice as high as the cancer death rate of all white males, according to a study of Government statistics. Though tiny amounts of plutonium have been known for many years to cause cancer in experimental animals, the study by the Health Research Group of statistics gathered by two leading radiation experts for the Government was believed to be the first strong evidence that plutonium also causes cancer in humans.

title: Consumer Unit Zeroes In On Gift Shops in Midtown
description: In anticipation of the Democrcttic National Convention and the Bicentennial, and the unusual number of visitors both Events will bring to the city, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has begun law enforcement campaign against dishonest souvenir gift shops that are concentrated in Times Square and along Fifth Avenue.

title: Shah Is Said to Plan Military Maneuvers During Sadat's Visit
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 5Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi Will personally supervise military maneuvers later this month in honor of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, wellplaced sources reported this week.

title: Andree GrosDaillon Affianced to Officer
description: Mrs. Andre Francois GrosDaillon of Northport, L.T. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Andree Veronique Gros  Daillon, to Capt. Paul Michael Severance, U.S.A. son, of Lieut. Col. Paul Vernon Severance, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Severance of Nashua, N.H.

title: The Middle West: Balance Wheel of the Republic
description: DUBUQUE, IowaThe rich, black soil of Iowa plays host to the recently planted corn. Farmers claim that only inclement weather can stop them from having another boomer year. Unemployment is lower here than in other regions. The Middle West, in this Bicentennial year, remains the balance wheel to the Republic. The heartland stretches from Ohio westward halfway through Nebraska, and from Minnesota south well into Missouri. It is not the most spectacular region in the nation, but surely is the steadiest. The Middle West considers the East's dictums and the West's enthusiasms, perhaps indulging itself for a while, but always comes to its thus moderation.

title: E. A. Stanley Jr. Weds Miss Berger
description: Jennifer Berger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Berger of Pittstown, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Edmund A. Stanley Jr., son of Mrs. Stanley of New York end the late Mr. Stanley.

title: Future Social Events
description: June 10If Governor Carey and Mayor Beanie each limits his solution of the school system's financial problems to three minutes, the annual Senator Wagner Memorial dinner dance in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom will come close to an evening of nonspeeches, as the Governor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement plans. Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner founded the Governor's Committee in 1955 to help the really great among graduating New York City public, parochial and private high school students meet tuition costs at colleges that cooperate with matching funds. This year's 281 Governor's Committee scholars are at 37 colleges and the dinner will send at least 100 new ones to college for one to four years. Constant committee contributors will receive diplomas from Governor Carey and all dinner guests wick get perfume and Jorwelry. Tickets, $150.

title: National League
description: FRIDAY NIGHT

title: China Proclaims the Rights of Its Minority Peoples but Works Steadily for Their Assimilation
description: KUNMING, ChinaSometime in the future all the nationalities in the world all their customs and their habits  will be universalized. As Communists, that is our ideal. If our ideal is realized, we will hold a grand celebration.

title: Anne Darneille, F. R. Snodgrass Wed in Captial
description: Anbe Lowndes Darneiile, an executive assistant with the City Council of the District of Columbia. and Francis Russell Snodgrass. associate director of market regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, were married yesterday afternoon in Washington.

title: Stratford on The Other Avon
description: Twentythree years ago, under a colorful tent beside the placid Avon River in Stratford; Ontario, Alec Guinness donned the crown of Richard Ill and launched the first Stratford Shakespeare Festival. The tent has long since been replaced a permanent theater, and this week Stratford begins its 1976 season in impressive style with no fewer than seven openings in four days.

title: The Soccer Spectacle: Bread and Circuses, Blood and Glory
description: For certain moralists, the explanation of Peld's universal popularity can be summed up in a few words. What do people want? Bread and circuses. In case they lack bread, you offer them circus games. And that's where Feld comes in.

title: Red Sox Conquer Angels in 9th, 43
description: BOSTON, June 5 (AP)Rick Burleson cracked a twoout single in the bottom of the ninth inning today scoring Doug Griffin from second base and giving the Boston Red Sox a 43 victory over the California Angels.

title: Suharto Retired as General of the Indonesian Army
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 5 (UPI)President Suharto has been retired as a general of the Indonesian Army, but he will retain his position as the supreme commander of the armed forces under the Constitution, according to an official announcement.

title: BIKEL IN SONG FORAY AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: By now, Theodore Bikel commented toward the end of his first performance at the Bottom Line'. I guess you've gotten the idea that I'm basically an actor. Any of the icluh's regular habitues who were on hand must have wonKlered net only what Mr. Bikel was up to but also where they were. The Bottom Line's soundto charm anyone, including this Bottom Line habitu.

title: E. German Women Set 4 Swim Marks
description: WEST BERLIN, June 5 (AP)East Germany's women swimmers set four world records today at its Olympic trials to pick a team for the Montreal games.

title: A Battery Plant and Lead Poisoning
description: VISALIA, Calif.The Prestolite auto battery plant here isn't narticularly imposing.

title: Celtics, Suns in Encore
description: Warning: Persons with weak hearts are advised not to watch or listen to today's sixth game of the National Basketball Association championship in Phoenix. After what happened to the Boston Celtics, who took a 1to2 lead in games Friday night with an incredible 128126 victory over the Phoenix Suns in triple overtime at Boston Garden, the possibility of cardiac arrest or some similar attack has become quite distinct.

title: King of Nepal Visits Tibet
description: HONG KONG, June 5, (Reuters)King Birendra of Nepal arrived today in Tibet, Hsinhua, the Chinese press reported. King Birendra is the first foreign head of state to visit Tibet, which has been closd for centuries to all but a handful of outsiders. His visit is part of a tour of China.

title: A Wordless Protest
description: BROOKLYN ALTHOUGH Tozer Szajna rarely mentions the five years he spent in Nazi concentration camps (Today I have a namethen I was a number), the experience has obviously left its mark on the Polish avantgarde theater director, designer and playwright.

title: Fingerware
description: All that glitters on that third finger left hand isn't gold.

title: Sandra Maguire Bride Of James M. Sinkula
description: In the First Congregational Church in Madison, Cormyesterday afternoon, Sandra Aileen Maguire of Duluth. Minn. became the bride of James Michael Sinkula of Superior, Wis. The minister the Rev. Franklin A. Bower performed the ceremony.

title: Red Smith
description: Through the big old trees came the amplified voice of Dave Johnson calling the second race: On the turn it's Modern Trend His voice throbbed with urgency, but the sprawling thousands on the Belmont lawns out behind the erandstand paid scant attention.

title: BROOKLYN SCHOOL GETS NEW ZONING
description: A new zoning plan for Franklin K. Lane High School on the BrooklynQueens border, which is intended to give the now heavily black and Puerto Rican school a more racially integrated enrollment next fall, was announced yesterday by Irving Anker, the New York City School Chancellor.

title: How to Build in an Extra Clothes Closet
description: There are very few homes or apartments where another closet is not neededor at lease desirablein a particular room where present closet space is considered inadequate.

title: Slow Growth in a Crucial Sector
description: CLEVELAND  Optimism is finally rising in the economically sensitive machine tool industry. But only 13 months after the industry's new order rate began its long, slow climb from bottom, there are signs of even another cloud behind the new silver lining.

title: The villain is, you guessed it, the President
description: By John Ehrlichman. 313 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $8.95.

title: Educating the Senate
description: THE Senate of the State of New Jersey has done it again. Nothing! Nothing in the interests of the people it is supposed to represent; nothing to help the school children who are defenseless against vested money interests. The majority of the Senate voted to defeat the incometax bill.

title: RUBIN CARTER IN BID FOR LOUISIANA BOY
description: A rally attended by about 200 people and addressed by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was held in downtown Brooklyn yesterday in support of Gary Tyler, 17 years old, who is believed to be the youngest person on death row in any of the country's prisons.

title: Lynn Laporte Married To Henry Andrews Jr.
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lynn Elizabeth Laporte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick. Laporte of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa. to Henry Piper Andrews Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrews of Cincinnati.

title: The Passport Vs. Freedom to Travel
description: Except for that snapshot of me smirking over the prospect of going abroad, my passport always seemed just about what a passport ought to be a toney grayishgreenish packet which feels almost leatherlike, big enough not to fall down an English sink drain but small enough to fit the pocket of a shirt shrunk by an Amsterdam laundromat.

title: Chicago Latest to Feel Impact of Urban Crisis
description: CHICAGO, June 5In this metropolis of more than threemillion people, widely acclaimed as the city that works, something seems to be going awry.

title: Pro and Con on Princeton I Building
description: WHIG HALL, an imposing Princeton University building that looks like a temple, was a monument to controversy when it was built as a gallery for debates by students and statemen.

title: Jimmy Carter, the campaign autobiography ofWhy Not The Best?
description: I have always looked on the Presidency of the United States with reverence and awe, and I still do. But recently I have begun to realize that the President is just a human being. I can almost remember when I began to change my mind and form this opinion.

title: Followup on the News
description: When the resurrected, redesigned 82 bill was introduced with Bicentennial drum rolls last April 13, the Treasury Department foresaw steady public demand for the note. It said it would print 400 million of them by July 4.

title: Utilities Pollution Costs Put at $30 Billion by 86
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) It will cost the oil refining and electric utilities industries more than $.10 billion in the next decade to comply with air and water cleanup rules, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: In London, 1776 and All That
description: LONDON. The English, orderly even in a time of economic calamity, have a sense of occasion that impels them to make culture into an outing. Memorable setpieces staged by English museums have been France in the 18th Century, The Byron Exhibition, Tutankhamun, Turner and Chinese Treasures, each one lending its peculiar mood to Londonindeed, the city never looked more magical or awash with color than when the Turner paintings at the Royal Academy gave it emphasis that exhibition taught people to see. And this year's extravaganza sparked by the Bicentennial, is The 1776 Exhibition, is designed to retell the story of the American Revolution in such a way as to flatter the Americans and console the British. British viewers are urged to consider 1776 as a bit more than a pathetic colonial collapse in a distant land; Americans are treated to descriptions of their national villains, Colonel Arnold and Major Andre, which cast them as worthy but bumbling secret agents.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES ROSE 0.3 PERCENT in May 181.8 [1967=100], compared with an 0.8 percent rise April. Prices of processed foods rose 1.3 percent against 1.9 percent in April, but livestock prices moved downward after a sharp increase in April Unemployment fell to 7.3 percent of the workforce from 7.5 percent in April Citicorp raised the prime rate to 7 percent from 7 percent and most major banks followed  The nation's money supplycurrency in circulation plus checking account balancewas at $303.1 billion in the latest week, unchanged from the prior week U.S. Steel, Jones & Loughlin and Armco raised steel prices by 7 to 8 percent.

title: What's Doing in MONTREAL
description: OLYMPIC CITYCanada's largest city plays host to the Summer Games of the 21st Olympiad from July 17 to Aug. 1. The second North American city to be assigned the Summer GamesLos Angeles was first, in 1932Montreal offers visitors during the month of July all sorts of accompanying nonathletic events as well. In addition, there are the usual attracti'ns of this cosmopolitan city fine restaurants, interesting shops, cultural activities and, above all, Parisian ambience.

title: On Striking It Rich
description: ONE of New Jersey's more enterprising ventures in the last six years, in the view of the public, was the creation of the state lottery, legalized games of chance that make spending money fun and the state a whole lot richerabout $250 million so far.

title: Robin Laidler Has Nuptials
description: Robin Laidler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Armington Laidler of New York and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Walter Brooks Scholl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scholl of Sands Point, L. I. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston performed the noon ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L. I.

title: 1% of Inmates in Massachusetts Found to Be Vietnam Veterans
description: BOSTON. June 5 (AP)Eleven percent of the male inmates in Massachusetts prisons are Vietnam warera veterans, and the majority make model prisoners.

title: Austria Plans to Finance A Chair at U.S. University
description: VIENNA, June 5 (Reuters)Austria plans to finance a chair of Austrian studies at a United States university to mark the Bicentennial, Chancellor Bruno Kreisky has announced.

title: NIXON MAINTAINS ELECTION SILENCE
description: SAUSALITO, Calif., June 5 Much of the suspense has gone out of Tuesday's California primary; almost everyone here expects the two local candidates, Ronald Reagan and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., to win without great difficulty.

title: The SixFigure Understanding
description: I never made it with either of them, and the other one never even called. Now a shy, private type of person such as I would scarcely come forward and publish this shocking, intimate secret in an election year, unless there were some truly compelling reasonsomething, oh, substantially into six figures.

title: Unholy Modal Rounders at Folk City
description: The Unholy Modal Rounders, who are at Folk City through tonight, have a history almost as interesting as their music. The group dates back to 1963, when a duo called the Holy Modal Rounders, consisting of Peter Stampfel and Steve Weber, terrorized the folk circuit. By the late 60'safter a period of serving as backup musicians for the Fugsthe Rounders had lost Mr. Weber and turned into a fuilsize electricacoustic folk band.

title: FAMILY CAMPING AIDUANDICAPPED
description: In its 100th year, the Fresh Air Fund has come up with a new twist on its basic theme of giving underprivileged city children an invigorating taste of country living.

title: Brakes Blamed in Bus Crash
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 5 (UPI)Faulty air brakes apparently caused the wreck of a charter bus that killed 28 Yuba (City High School choir mem1)ers and an adult adviser, the California highway patrol said yesterday.

title: Teacher Weds Anne E. Parker
description: Anne Elizabeth Parker daughter of Maj. Gen. David S. Parker, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Parker of Belvedere, Calif., was married yesterday to Terence Elliott Diggory, who has just presented his doctoral dissertation at Oxford University.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Miss Whelan Has Nuptials
description: Kathleen Whelan of Larchmont. N. Y.. manager of employment. for Macy's Herald Square, and Donald M. Frame, Moore Collegiate Professor of French at Columbia University, were marl ried yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: ALFRED FUNABASHI, IMPORTER OF CHINA
description: Alfred Funabashi, the presi dent of Mikasa, a china and dinnerware importer, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. He was 59 years old.

title: PEOPLE
description: AFTER 35 years in the record business, Albert Hassler of Verona has reason to rejoice. His Wonderland Records, based in Mountainside and managed by his son Jerry, has the bestselling Bicentennial children's album on the market: Eddie Albert Sings and Narrates America. Mr. Massler is responsible for several technological innovations that helped to bring down the prices of phonograph records, including the injectionmolding process for manufacturing them and a method for inking labels directly on disks. Both processes have been patented.

title: Power Follows the Treasury Dollars
description: WASHINGTON  New York City Hall was silent. The Senate Banking Committee and the Treasury Secretary had just laid down the law: No wage increases, reduce fringe benefits, examine rent control and take steps in other areas also considered the city's own business. Yet there were no protestations or anguished cries condemning Federal intervention in the city's internal affairs.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records

title: The Famous Politician Writers School
description: So you've been indicted  Or perhaps a fickle electorate has put you on the unemployment line. In either case, you need something to fill the inner void that comes after the cheering stops. Have you thought of a writing career?

title: N.B.A. Chamnionship*
description: Boston vs. Phoenix

title: DINING OUT
description: ***Squiies,47 Montauk Highway West, East Hampton. 3244466. LIKE a fine vintage, it has taken many years for Squires to mature. Try it now. Disappointing inconsistencies remembered from earlier seasons have been banished. The imaginative creations listed on the menu can be trusted. Imagination was always at work here. Two spare white dining rooms are gently lit with rows of tiny bare bulbs. Mirrors expand the space. The hardedged chic is tempered by gracious appointments. Glowing pewter, French porcelain linen napery. Fresh flowers would have been appreciated.

title: Letters
description: Have we already forgotten Egypt's closing of the Suez Canal soon after they assumed control? Do we want to take the chance that our highways may become cluttered with hundreds of thousands of truckloads of coasttocoast freight now transported through the Panama Canal (Storm over the canal by Richard Hudson, May 16)? Is it proper for us to turn this waterway over to a banana republic without the approval of the major maritime nations: Japan, the United Kingdom, Norway and Greece? JERREIVIS CHAMBERLAIN HART Litchfield, Conn.

title: ART VIEW
description: Edmund Wilson, in his book, O Canada: An American's Notes on Canadian Culture, published in 1965, tells the following story. Five years before this book appeared, Wilson had published in The New Yorker a laudatory article about the Canadian writer Morley Callaghan.

title: Stones Betters World High jump Record
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5Dwight Stones is a man of his word.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WHEN the surprising word went out tentatively a week ago that a second economic summit conference of the Western world's top leaders was being organized only seven months after their historic conclave in Rambouillet, France, some commentators immediately surmised  and perhaps with good reason  that political considerations were a more compelling factor than international economic problems as the motivating force this time.

title: FISHING
description: THE first bluefish schools of the season worked their way into range of the New Jersey party boats last week, hitting off Brielle and Manasquan. And from now through the end of the summer, the blues will be tracked as carefully as a space shot.

title: North Wins College AllStar Lacrosse
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 5 (AP)Mike French, Bill Marino and Jon Levine of Cornell, the National Collegiate champion, accounted for 12 goals and seven assists today as the North rallied in the second half for a 2297 victory over the South in he 34th annual college allstar lacrosse game.

title: CHRISTIAN RIGHT IN LEBANON BACKS SYRIAN INCURSION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sunday, June 6Lebanon's rightwing Christian leadership acted yesterday to endorse Syria's military intervention in Lebanon, and Syrian armor reportedly remained in an uneasy standoff with Palestinian guerrillas and their Lebanese leftist allies in the eastern part of the country.

title: Lary L.Speakman Weds Miss Poinier
description: Carolyn Ward Poinier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Poinier of Wilton, Conn. and Lary Lee Speakman were married yesterday afternoon in the Wilton Congregational Church. The Rev. Richard Brindle of New Milford, Conn. performed the ceremony.

title: Stones Sets Jump Mark
description: Dwight Stones of Long Beach State set a world record of 7 feet 7 inches in the high jump yesterday at the 55th annual National Collegiate track and field championships in Philadelphia. Details are in Section 5.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: My summer cottage has a crawl space with bare earth exposed and my water pump and water heater are located this space in the center of a plastic basin. There is about six inches of water in this basin (seeps in from the ground) and this winter dampness caused drops to form all over the 24's above this crawl space. Also Some of the floorboards have begun to rot. What can I do to get rid of this excess moisture and dampness in ??? space? A. 0., Jachson Heights, N.Y.

title: POLITICS
description: IT is New Jersey's political misfortune to hold its Presidential primary this Tuesday, the same day as California and Ohio. As a consequence, the candidates still in the running in both major parties have tended to ignore the Garden State and to concentrate, instead, in the two others, where there are far more delegates to be won and the cost of campaigning is far less.

title: TEHERAN PROJECTS FACE CHALLENGES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 5With Iran's oil boom slowing, planners and intellectuals in Teheran are voicing skepticism about the wisdom of further splurging on such urban embellishments as skyscrapers, a subway system and sewers.

title: Fragrant Flowers For Sunny Summer Borders
description: Each month of the flowering year brings its quota of sweetscented flowers. Never is the fragrance more noticable than on a summer evening but some of the most fragrant of all blossoms are to be found in the spring.

title: Radio
description: 7:308, WABC: Message of rael. Our Nation's Birthday.

title: Peter Coffin Weds Paula Colangelo
description: Paula Colangelo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Colangelo of Watertown, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Douglas Coffin, son of Mr. and Mrs. David D. Coffin of Hampton Falls, N.H. The ceremony was performed in Trinity College Chapel, Hartford, by the Rev. William S. Coffin, a cousin of the bridegroom. He was assisted by the Rev. Allan Tull.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME 3 FOR SURROGATE
description: A screening panel set up jointly by the regular and new Democratic coalition wings of the Manhattan Democratic Party named three candidates yesterday as most highly qualified for the post of Manhattan Surrogate.

title: Amer. Soccer League
description: Cork Hlbernians at Oakland.

title: He Went Op and Stayed Up
description: HISTORY moves so quickly these days that most events are considered historic even before they have run their course. What took place in the early 1970's is already seen as part of another era, and what took place 14 or 20 years ago is eminently fit for a revival, or at least a nostalgic celebration.

title: Skateboards Are the Hottest Thing on Wheels
description: In Huntington, L. I., a mailman do his thirties delivers the mail by scooting from one house to another on skateboarda plank something Tike a short ski with rollerskate wheels fastened underneath. The postman used to ride a bicycle, but now he finds his skateboard a lot more convenient.

title: Five Crimson Doves
description: Wild columbines nod in the thin woodland and on rocky hillsides with a flash of crimson and a golden yellow gleam. They were in bloom before the bloodroot faded and in more shaded places they will still be bloom for another month or more.

title: Seoul Police Arrest Youth For Refusing to Trim Hair
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 5 The South Korean police arrested a young Government office worker today on charges of disobeying an official order to cut his hair short.

title: Ford Busing Plan Differs From U.S. Argument in Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 President Ford is considering legislation that would place a maximum fiveyear limit on almost all busingforintegration orders by the Federal courts, as well as sharply curtailing the scope of busing that could be ordered within that time pefHod, Administration sources said today.

title: Anita Haider Bride Of R.H.MacDongall
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Anita Halder, daughter of Mrs. Paul Halder of New York and the late Mr. Halder, became the bride of Richard H. Mac Dougall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Mac Dougall of Rossmoor, N.J.

title: A Californian Named Neil Simon Heads for Broadway
description: LOSANGELES Why not try it out in Los Angeles?' the playwright said. I live here, and the Ahman son is an excellent theater. The only reason we have to move on to Broadway is that Los Angeles can't sustain a twoyear run. Yet. This playwright was Neil Simon, whose California Suite opens Thursday al the O'Neill in New York City.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: California: Unpredictable Yet Representative
description: LOS ANGELESAs California's restless millions prepare for another Presidential primary in this year of antibig government politics, a small but clangorous war that has been raging on the Santa Monica Freeway seems an appropriate backdrop. The struggle began on March 15 when the State Department of Transportation, launching a demonstration project for curbing the extravagant use of energy traffic jams, restricted one of four lanes to buses and cars carrying three or more people. The outcry that individual liberties had been violated was immediate and sustained.

title: The Communists Soaring Debt
description: PARISThe unflagging demands for hard currency by the Soviet Union and its partners in the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance have led to sharp increases in Communist borrowings in the West.

title: TV VIEW
description: The students had just filed into the classroom when a young man was accosted by two guards, charging that they thought he was the one they saw smoking marijuana in the hallway. The student protested his innocence, but the guards, hostile and verbally abusive, placed him under arrest and then discovered a switchblade knife in his briefcase. As the teacher protested, and as the other students and a guest observer looked on in embarrassment and indignation, the student was removed from the classroom.

title: The Inner City Summons 2
description: IN one neighborhood, they call me tonicy, and in the other they call me nigger lover, Jan Van Ardsdale said as he settled into a wing chair, stretching his long, denimclad legs comfortably in front of him.

title: Gambling With Future of New York Horse Racing
description: The hour grows late for horse racing in New York State as the politicians in Albany prepare to vote for legalized casino gambling and start a publicbenefit corporation. The stage will then be set for the beginning of the end of majorleague horse racing in New York State and the Northeast.

title: Siderowf Captures British Golf
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 5 (AP)Dick Siderowf, a 38yearold stockbroker from Westport, Conn., sank a 6foot putt today at the 37th holdthe first suddendeath holeand defeated John Davies of England to become only the third American to win the British Amateur golf championship twice.

title: Venezuela's Growth Pains
description: CARACASWith the successful nationalization of the key oil and iron industries, Venezuela is now turning toward the problem of how to use the nation's huge financial resources to create heavy industry, modern agriculture and a better life for its peuDle.

title: Major League Averages
description: Records Include Games Played Friday Night

title: END DRAWS NEAR FOR SEOUL TRIAL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 6 ln the historic Grand Courtroom of the Seoul District Criminal Court, the prosecution is nearing the end of its questioning in the trial of 18 opponents of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Smith Hints at New Talks With Vorster
description: JOHANNESBURG. June 5Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia raised the possibility today that he might meet with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa before Mr. Vorster meets with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in Europe later this month.

title: FORD, IN AD SHIFT, DESCRIBES REAGAN AS PEACE THREAT
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5In a sudden switch of tactics three days before the crucial California primary, President Ford's forces in the state scrapped a new advertising campaign and replaced it with radio and television spots depicting Ronald, Reagan as a threat to peace.

title: Missing: One Passport
description: That morning I did the last thins that had to be done before packing. There was no rush. I had signed up foe a sixweek stay on the southern coast of Spain, and the instructions called for me to be at Iberia Airlines at Kennedy Airport at 5 P.M. for a briefing and checkin for the 7 o'clock flight to Madrid.

title: Korvette's Puts Teens on a Leash
description: The three young girls, all giggles and streams of blonde hair, bounced through the glass doors of the E. J. Korvette department store in Flushing. They got as far as the doubleknit men's slacks counter before a young man, in a purple Kon.ette blazer with a yellow Inventory Control emblem, stopped them.

title: Gosforth Tops Essex In Rugby
description: Gosforth, the club rugby champion of England defeated Essex, the New York City titleholder, 708, yesterday in a hardfought match at Randans Island.

title: M. L. Jacobson And Jill Gerson Exchange Vows
description: Jill Beth Gerson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin C. Gerson of New Rochelle, N.Y. was married last evening to Michael Lee Jacobson of Washington, a staff assistant to Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

title: The Canfield Decision
description: Established novelists are notoriously hard on amateurs who try to invade their overcrowded industry. They say their characters are onedimensional. Among the amateur novelists available to review this book, John Lindsay would not do. His book was not an outstanding critical or commercial success except perhaps with former members of his administration. William Buckley did better but he is a disillusioned admirer of Mr. Agnew who has had also to recover from a moral commitment to Richard Nixon, John Mitchell and maybe also General Thieu. He could be dangerously bitter. Washington reporters are determined amateur novelists but for Spiro Agnew they are of the wretched of the earth. I am not an ideal reviewer but, on reflection, Mr. Agnew may well conclude that I am his last, best hope.

title: "201">Pampalche of The Silver Teeth
description: Sisterhood is powerful is the modern message of this old Russian tale. An innocent girl Pampalche of the Silver Teeth, is literally sold down the river by her father. One day while the old man is drinking from the lake, the monstrous Master of the Waters grabs his beard and threatens to drown him unless he gives him his daughter in marriage. The monster cunningly throws fishing rights to all his lakes and rivers into the deal, and the bargain is struck.

title: For young readers
description: My children and I used to know a wonderful woman named Teddy. Until last year when she died, she ran a pet shop full of puppies, kittens, snakes, lizards, rats, mice, a parrot who whistled The Star Spangled Banner and love. Teddy was particularly fond of children, whom she treated with respect, even if she was only selling twentyfive cents worth of mealy worms to feed a pet frog. She insisted that any youngster who cares for animals would grow up with an understanding of life and death and with a great capacity for loving people, too.

title: Wilson 5Mile Victor
description: Mike Wilson of the New York Pioneer Club won the St. John's University annual spring fivemile run yesterday at the Hilicrest campus in Jamaica, Queens. Wilson, 23 years old covered the course in 26 minutes 51.2 seconds and finished 85 yards ahead of Ed Burns of the Long Island Athletic Club.

title: Up a Tree: Where a House Isn't a Home, Usually
description: It's time again to head for the trees and the shacks, splitlevels and miniature mansions waiting there.

title: Headliners
description: Martha Mitchell is dead. The outspoken wife of the former Attorney General, John Mitchell, from whom she was estranged, died last week of a rare form of bone cancer. Mrs. Mitchell became a public figure during the first years of the Nixon Administration. She frequently and publicly voiced her controversial views on Vietnam War dissenters and what she viewed as the excesses of the press. She did not hesitate to criticize the Nixon Administration during the Watergate scandal. As early as 1973, Mrs. Mitchell insisted that the scandal had indeed originated at the White House and that President Nixon was to blame. Mrs. Mitchell, who had suffered from the malignancy since early 1975, was alone when she died.

title: Endpaper
description: Aficionados of the mystery genre know that Newgate Callendar is the pseudonym of the critic who, for the last five years, has written the Criminals at Large column in The New York Times Book Review. During his tenure the inscrutable Mr. Callendar has read something like 1,500 myste. ries. By now his mind is a collagelike repository of plots, dialogue and style. He has, therefore, devised a mystei y story that is at once a melange of the whodunit styles that he has encountered, and also a miniature history of the genre. The story is also a quiz, and readers are invited to guess the inspiration for each section of the tale (the answers printed below).

title: Susan Henry Wed to H. Thayer West
description: The Rye (N. Y.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Earle Henry. daughter of Mrs. John Robert Henry Jr. of Rye to H. Thayer West, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Margerum West of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Bold Forbes Holds On for Neck Victory in the Belmont
description: In barely more time than it takes to rattle off an Ole! or two, PuertoRicanowned Bold Forbes turned probable defeat into wildly exciting success yesterday in the 108th Belmont Stakes.

title: Epilogue
description: According to its own documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation tried in the mid1960's to prevent the authors of a book about Julius and Ethel Rosenberg from discussing their work on a Chicago television program. In a memorandum written on Oct. 16, 1965, William C. Sullivan, then an assistant bureau director, wrote to his superiors that he believed that Walter and Miriam Schnell', authors of Invitation to an Inquest, intended not only to exonerate the Rosenbergs, who were executed as spies in June, 1953, but also to attack and undermine the F.B.I. in its investigations.

title: Coast Guard Offers Advice to Visitors for Operation Sail
description: The vision of 219 craft in the Hudson River parade of tall shipsflanked by at least 47 destroyerclass ships in the international naval review and an unpredictable spectator fleethas the United States Coast Guard holding its breath. The Coast Guard expect anywhere from 5,000 to 10,000 pleasure boats in the Upper Bay and Hudson River for Operation Sail July 4.

title: Beame Opposes Con Ed Increase; Calls Rates Here Highest in U.S.
description: Mayor Beame yesterday denounced Consolidated Edison's request for a major new electric increase and directed the Corporation Counsel's office to oppose the application.

title: Today's Rhetoric: Antipolingo
description: Rhetoric  once the proud subject matter of a book by Aristotleis going through an underground period. The word rhetoric itselfthe art of argument, the poetry of persuasionhas declined in current meaning to mere talk, or as Wendell Willkie would sheepishly admit, campaign oratory.

title: Explosion Shatters Windows at Cuban Mission
description: An explosive device went off; near the doorway of Cuba's; Mission to the United Nations at 6 East 67th Street early today, shattering windows on the first two floors of the building and in townhouses in the neighborhood.

title: Atlantic Dumping Extended
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency granted a oneyear extension yesterday on the city of Philadelphia's interim permit to dump sludge in the Atlantic Ocean. But the agency said that the city must reduce the number of pounds dumped annually from 141 million to 116 million and that further reductions would be required in succeeding years with a cessation of all dumping by 1981.

title: Albany Plays the Game, With an Eye on Election
description: ALBANY, June 5  Their bodies may be in Albany, but the hearts and minds of legislators and their leaders are increasingly concerned with the election campaigns back home. The long legislative session  which members had hoped would end two weeks ago and which now shows signs of sputtering on for the rest of the month  has kept the leadership from devoting full attention to election strategy, but a steady fundraising effort has provided both Democrats and Republicans with sizable campaign War chests.

title: 2 Brothers Win Finals In Boxing
description: CINCINNATI, June 5 (AP) Leon and Mike Spinks of St. Louis became tht first brothers to take division titles in the 72year history of the United States Olympic boxing trials tonight.

title: The Infernal Tower
description: ASIDE from its use as New York's bedroom, New Jersey also serves as the nesting  ground for the transmitters of a number of New York radio stations. To the casual observer, this fact may mean little outside of the fine radio reception afforded New Jersey residents. However, if you are one of the unfortunates who live in their shadow, the towers become a frustration of Jersey living.

title: Notes: Expanded Network Newscasts Are on the Way
description: Just about everyone in the television industry knows that a longer earlyevening newscast on the networks is inevitable, but no one can say exactly when the expansion will harmen. A few months ago a safe guess would have been sometime in the 1980's, but now the prospects are as close as next year. What has moved up the still uncertain timetable was ABC's loud hint, when it recently hired Barbara Walters away from NBC, that the network planned to expand its 30minute newscast to 45 minutes with her arrival in September.

title: SHOP TALK
description: GREAT NECK THOMAS WOLFE said you can't go home again, but many residents of Great Neck, Kings Point, Lake Success and nearby communities find that they almost can. They go to Mati's Place.

title: state G.O.P. Nationality Unit Backs Nomination of Ford
description: The Republican State Committee's Heritage Groups Council, with 32 organizations representing 19 nationality groups, voted yesterday to support President Ford for the party nomination for President.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Much current research on cancer is concentrated on identifying the environmental factors that predispose victims to the disease. The search for such factors becomes more complex when specific types of cancer occur with unusually high frequency in widely separated areas that appear to have no special environmental factors in common.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The military has always loomed large in the developing history of Americano less in 1776 than now. Some artistic reminders of this can beseen in the Government's numismatic commemorations of the Bicentennial, including some of the medals issued by the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration and, most notably, in the U.S. Mint's soontobecompleted 40piece battle heroes series entitled America's First Medals.medal, and both sides were executed by S. Joseph Winter of the Mint's engraving staff. The obverse carries the birth date of the CorpsNov. 10, 1775and a scene representing the first major military action of the Continental Marinesthe landing at New Providence in the Bahamas on March 3. 1776. The emblem of the Corps is superimposed on the battle scene. The reverse shows a group of modern Marines in their typical roles of riflemen on the attack.

title: The Grass Is Getting Higher
description: That new lawn mower may still be down a bit en Mr. Homeowner's mustbuy list.

title: Singlehanded Yachts Begin Atlantic Race
description: PLYMOUTH, England, June 5 (UPI)A gun boomed across Plymouth Sound today and 126 sailors from 17 countries started on a 3,000mile ocean voyage to Newport, R. L, in the royal western observer singlehanded transAtlantic yacht race.

title: Sheila J. Smith, William Peters Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Joyce Smith of Southport, Corm. and Block Island, R. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Joyce Smith, to William R. Peters of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Peters of Great Neck, L. I. A wedding in August is planned.

title: Gail Kaufman Is Bride of James Furgal
description: Gail Susan Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Kaufman of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to James Walter Furgal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Furgal of Watertown, N.Y.

title: U.S. Says Grain Outlook In China Is Oiminishint
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)  The Department of Agriculture reports that the prospects for bumper grain crops this year in China are perhaps not as optimistic as originally envisioned.

title: Museum Garden Opens a Series With Kirk Nurock
description: Kirk Nurock and his Natural Sound Workshop opened the Museum of Vlodern Art's Summergarden concert series Friday evening to stiff competition from jets roaring overhead and a traffic snarl outside. Mr. Nurock's ensemble uses only unamplified voices, so portions of the first piece, Track, were virtually inaudible.

title: Outtook Hopeful For Girl in Love
description: Girl in Love, who broke clown Friday after scoring an upset victory in the $50,850 Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont Park, suffered a broken bone in her right front leg, the track veterinarian, Dr. Manuel Gilman, said yesterday

title: A Pas de 50 on the Morgan Lawn
description: GLEN COVE DAVID RICHARDSON, a dancer and assistant ballet master with the New York City Ballet and guest of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Samuels 3d, sprawled on the lawn of the former Morgan estate, drinking in the sheer splendor of it all.

title: Changing Perspective on Congress
description: JOSEPH TENNER eased himself carefully into a chair and began pulling papers from every pocket. Finally, he found what he wanted, carehilly unfolded it, peered intently for a minute or so through thicklensed glasses, and began to talk to a visitor. It was as if he were practicing the speeches he avould give later.

title: Indy: Rains Sink Another Big Race
description: After a week of drying out from the rain, some final thoughts on the 1976 Indianapolis 500: An old saw about Indianapolis weather around the time of the 500 is, if you don't like it, wait five minutes and it will change. Unthat changing weather keeps wiping out races.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: 67:55 A.M., WNYCFM: Choral Eestival. Saint Matthew Passion, Part IL Bach.

title: Music: Britten's Paul Bunyan Sung
description: ALDEBURGH, England, June 4The 29th Aldeburgh Festival started tonight and will continue through June 20, during which some attention will be paid to the American Bicentennial. By far the most significant nod in that direction took place tonight, with a performance of Benjamin Britten's Paul Bunyan.

title: Older Men Entering Priesthood
description: WHEN he was 30 years old. Mark O'Connell seemed well on the way to a successful career on Wall Street. He had worked as a credit analyst and then as a systemsimprovement analyst for Dunn & Bradstreet while earning a law degree at night.

title: ARCHITECTURAL VIEW; Design (Good and Bad) Down by The Levee
description: ST. LOUIS Nowhere are the mysteries and Incongruities of the urban process more apparent than in St. Louis; occasionally the Red Queen seems to have been in charge. Downtown, the handsome pink granite levee slopes to the muddy Mississippi, where a handful of riverboats provide food and entertainment, anchored below the familiar, dense steel of the historic Eads Bridge. Close to the riverfront, the soaring parabola of the stainless steel Gateway Arch frames the high dome and lantern of the old Greek Revival Courthouse with unsurpassed drama.

title: Lily Tomlin: Not just a funny girl
description: When Lily Tomlin was nominated this year as Best Supporting Actress for her widely acclaimed film debut in Nashvilleearlier she had won New York Film Critics and Society of Film Critics awardsshe thought of creating a mask of two smiling red lips which she would raise and lower as discretion warranted throughout the ceremonies. Fair comment on the evening's proceedings; and neat bit of selfmockery, too. For this writerperformer, a onewoman theater made famous by television, has been fighting the public's image of her as funny lady, comedienne, standup comic assoluta.

title: Snug Harbor Faces Cash Shortage as Culture Center
description: Sailors Snug Harbor, a landmark institution on the Staten Island waterfront, will begin shortly to chart a new course under a new captain. By early June, the old mariners who reside at this 143yearold home for retired seamen will relocate to a modern facility in Sea Level, N.C., leaving New York City as landlord for the 80 acres of parkland and centuryold buildings. The city, on behalf of the Parks Department, purchased the site from trustees of the home in two transactions for a total price of $9.7million.

title: Shortage of U.S. Funds May Delay Subway Link
description: A funding shortage threatens to delay completion of the ManhattanQueens trunk subway line, which is to run from Central Park to Jamaica via the new 63d Street tunnel under the East River.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Lyndon Johnson And the American Dream
description: The Johnson literature gets richer. Once the most neglected of our major political figures, Lyndon Johnson now becomes even more of a major historical subject and a rich biographical figure. The passions and divisions of the immediate past recede, leaving us to survey the contradictions in his life and the fierce human force he brought to political life. Too, he is no longer around to serve as the custodiancensor of his own story; he was after all the keeper of his own flame. When George Reedy, his talented and trusted press secretary, wrote a thoughtful and reflective book about the impossibility of being President, The Twilight of the Presidency, Johnson was enraged and, not having read it, decided it was a personal attack and sought to bar Reedy from all future Johnson festivities. When mutual friends protested that it was a fine book and not in the least antagonistic, the then exPresident held firm. He had shown the book, he insisted, to three of his secretaries, they had read it and voted two to one that it, was disloyal.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: IN an article on ShortChanging Hempstead Town, [May 16 Ada Goldberg, director of the humanresources committee of the League of Women Voters of the Town of Hempstead East, urged Hempstead Town officials to exert what she termed farsighted leadership to educate our communities to accept the Federal Government's demand that our town construct 75 units of scattersite, lowincome family housing. Ms. Gold.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7 No Title

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10 No Title

title: Kidney Disease Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) Some 26,000 kidney disease patients will receive $450 million in Medicare subsidies in the year ending June 30, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has announced. The subsidies approved by Congress in the Social Security amendments of 1972 established the first national health insurance for specific disease and extended Medicare benefits to persons of all ages.

title: The Region
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the New York State special prosecutor whose methods have often been criticized, has now been told by the state's highest court that he has exceeded his legal jurisdiction. In a 43 decision, the Court of Appeals has narrowly defined Mr. Nadjari's mandate, thus providing a strong basis for challenge of several indictments by Nadjari grand juries that seemingly went beyond the mandate.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ONE of our neighbors keeps late hours, likes the music volume up and entertains a great many guests. Such behavior could earn the displeasure of a neighborhood. Not so in this case. Our neighbor is the Garden State Arts Center, and our family has developed a special feeling for it ever since it moved in eight years ago and changed our lives.

title: The Effects of Ice on Scotch
description: In countries where Scotch has been consumed for centuries, ice and whisky rarely mingle. But on this side of the Atlantic, the picture is quite different. While a small percentage of American Scotch drinkers take it neat, better than 35(7 drink it on the rocks. The rest of us add varying amounts of water, club soda, etcetera. And ice. Always plenty of ice  the great American drink requisite.

title: State Hopes to Slow
description: TRENTON AFTER several years of delay, New Jersey has set out to find, if possible, a way to slow down the increasing rate of cancer in the state.

title: ALBERT TO RETIRE; O'NEILL FAVORED AS NEW SPEAKER
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Carl Bert Albert, the speaker of the House of Representatives for the last five and a half years, announced today that he would retire from Congress when his current term expires at the end, of this year.

title: Television This Week
description: ted by the noted children's book illustrator.

title: Nuclear Power Is Cheaper and Less Danger
description: The role of energy in sustaining and advancing modern industrial society is fundamental. Since the Industrial Revolution, we have increasingly replaced human labor with inanimate energy obtained from a variety of sources falling water, coal, petroleum and, most recently, nuclear fuels.

title: Coal is the Answer to the Energy Problem
description: I was born in the mountains of West Virginia, and my views are the views of a coal miner. Coal mining is hard, dirty work, and when you have time to think on the job, you mainly think about your survival. I have spent most of my life just trying to survive, and what free time I had left over I spend on trying to reform the union I belonged to. This is hard work, too. So my views are generally geared to getting from one day to the next.

title: SCHOOL AID PLAN OPPOSED IN STUDY
description: The issue of whether education's neediest students are those from the most impoverished families or the ones with the lowest test scores has been raised by a study by the Educational Testing Service.

title: Summer Reading for Candidates
description: In a moment of characteristic honesty. President Ford admitted last year that he gets through about one book a month. The network correspondents who heard the response paused a moment in awkward silence and then went on to another question. Obviously. the President's reading intake is higher than that of most politicians, but he certainly broke the rules by admitting how little he read.

title: Music:
description: Stiffelio was the opera that Verdi wrote just before the enormously brilliant and successful Rigoletto. Its production in Trieste in 1850 was a failure. Libretto revisions, even the transfer of much of the music to a whole new libretto, did not help. Still, the composer always expressea a certain regard for it, and when the full score, thought to be lost, turned up in Naples some years ago, it was revived. On Friday night it was given its American premiere by the New York Grand Opera under the direction of Vincent La Selva at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Purtzer Is Tied at 208 by 4 Others for Golf Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA. June 5For the last three days everyone has been asking, Who's Tom Purtzer? Today at least Tour more men were added to the list, those being the four pros who were tied with him after the third round of the Bicentennial Classic.

title: Liguori in Quandary Over Olympic Race Choice
description: Time is running Out for Marty Liguori. America's best miler must decide soon whether to run the 1,500 or the 5,000 meters in the Olympic Games in July. The choice Will not About be easy. Liguori has been known and primarily as a miler since he first won fame as a subfour minute scholastic performer at Essex (N.J.) Catholic H. S. in 1967. He was an Olympian at 1,500 meters in the 1968 Games, and then blossomed into the world's No. 1 ranked miler in 1969, his sophomore year at Villanova. He earned that honor again two years later, but a foot injury kept him out of the 1972 Olympics.

title: Syria Is Picking Its Way Between the Arab Camps
description: DAMASCUS, SyriaSince Egypt and Israel signed last September's disengagement agreement on the Sinai desert, the Government of President Hafez alAssad has been maneuvering between the two broad camps that have developed in the Arab world. His position has been made especially difficult by his involvement in Lebanon, where more Syrian troops were deployed last week, and by his relationship with the Soviet Union, whose Prime Minister has been visiting Damascus.

title: Paul Getty Dead at 83; Amassed Billions From Oil
description: J. Paul Getty a symbol of oil, wealth and power, died early today at his country mansion near London. He was 83 years old. The cause of death was reported to be heart failure.

title: ALBANY NOTEBOOK
description: AS the Legislature lumbers toward adjournment  something that seems to recede into the increasingly distant futurethe controversy over the proposed onecent increase in the Nassau County sales tax has emerged as a fullblown product of Albany's Byzantine legislative politics.

title: O. A. S. Aide Cautions Chile On Norm of Human Rights
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5Foreign Minister Dudley Thompson of Jamaica told President Augusto Pinochet of Chile today that all American republics, including military dictatorships, should respect a common international norm of human rights.

title: Tough on the Kennedys, easy on Jack
description: The assumption may be that The Search for J.F.K. debunks the Kennedy myth (assuming, of course, there is anything left to debunk), but in a rather odd way it enhances it. The Search for J.F.K. is a diligent, even exhaustive, inquiry into the life of the late President from 1935, when he was graduated from the Choate School, until 1947, when he entered Congress. It is written without malice, which adds to its credibility, and it is mostly a story about media hype, public gullibility and private coverup, and how an egomaniacal father can turn a rather malleable son into a President; he does it by working at it.

title: Moderate Recovery.
description: The economic recovery, after the strong advance of the first quarter, is continuing, but at a slower pace. In part, this is a natural consequence of the fact that the upturn is entering its second phase, after the first big swing from inventory cutting to inventory building. In part, however, the slower rate of recovery is due to deliberate efforts of the monetary authorities to moderate the expansion as a means of preventing a resurgence of inflation.

title: The Movie Will Star
description: LOTS of good things have been happening to 29yearold Billy Hayes of North Babylon since he escaped eight months ago from a Turkish prison after serving five years for possession of hashish.

title: The Delights of Summer at the Island's Edge
description: IF Long Island were not an islandthat is, if it were surrounded by solid ground covered with other suburbs would it have nearly as much appeal? We're only 15 minutes from, Tones Beach is one of the most common justifications for high taxes, wicked housing costs and the claustrophobia of Hempstead Turnpike at 5 P.M.

title: Mary Gibbs Scripps Married Upstate to Jeffrey Dieffenbach
description: Mary Gibbs Scripps, daughter of Capt. James E. Scripps, a retired Merchant Marine officer, and Mrs. Scripps of Loudonville. N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Dieffenbach. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs.. Fred Dieffenbach 3d of Tenafly, N.J., and Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Bandit Gangs Prey on Mexican Aliens Crossing Border to Seek Work in U.S.
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., June 5Ruben Ochoa is 16 years old and one of 12 children of a poor farm laborer whose home is a dirtfloor shack in the Mexican state of Michoacan.

title: Solutions to last week's puzzles
description: Solutions to last week's puzzles

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment to foreign aid bill that would authorize $25 million for countries in southern Africa other than Zaire and Zambia, which passed, 61 to 12, June 2.

title: Controversy Over Access Laps at Jersey Shore
description: ALTHOUGH thousands of tourists and bathers flock to the Jersey shore every summer, helping to transform it into a billiondollar resort industry, miles and miles of beachfront along both the Atlantic Ocean and its adjoining bays remain privately owned and closed to the public.

title: The Canfield Decision
description: Established novelists are notoriously hard on amateurs who try to invade their overcrowded industry. They say their characters are onedimensional. Among the amateur novelists available to review this book, John Lindsay would not do. His book was not an outstanding critical or commercial success except perhaps with former members of his administration. William Buckley did better but he is a disillusioned admirer of Mr. Agnew who has had also to recover from a moral commitment to Richard Nixon, John Mitchell and maybe also General Thieu. He could be dangerously bitter. Washington reporters are determined amateur novelists but for Spiro Agnew they are of the wretched of the earth. I am not an ideal reviewer but, on reflection, Mr. Agnew may well conclude that I am his last, best hope.

title: August Vacations Remain A Popular Habit in France
description: PARIS, June 5 (Reuters)Only one in five of the French plan a vacation abroad this year and most intend to cram their time off into the traditional vacation month of August, according to the French tourist office.

title: The wellplanned enigma of Jimmy Carter
description: Early on one frosty morning back in late January, a sleek Lear jet paused hesitantly at the end of a runway on the outskirts of Oklahoma City, its wing lights pulsating in the gray darkness, its engines screaming against the prairie's peaceful silenceand suddenly, with a thunderous acceleration, it lurched into its takeoff roll.

title: Teacher Held in Smuggling
description: A Newburgh, N. Y., school teacher was arranged in united States District Court in Brooklyn Friday on charges of attempting to smuggle two pounds of cocaine into the country. The teacher, Thomas Costa, 25 years old, attempted to bring the cocaine through Customs after arriving at Kennedy International Airport from Aruba, authorities said. Mr. Costa was held in $25000 half by Judge A. Simon Chrein, pending a hearing June 25. He faces a penalty of up to 15 years and a $20,000 fine.

title: BROTHELS RAIDED AND 48 ARE SEIZED
description: Local and Federal officers raided midtown brothels and massage parlors overnight arresting 20 men and women on criminal charges and detaining 28 as illegal aliens.

title: Randy Cowley Weds Wendy Hafer
description: Patricia Anne Genovese and Emil Raymond Di Lollo were married yesterday afternoon in St. Edward Confessor Roman Catholic Church, Syosset, L. I.. by the Rev. Lawrence D. Costello.

title: Diplomats Fear EthiopianSomalian Feud Over Port Will Become War
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaThe Ethiopian Government, seeking to crush a breakaway movement in the northern province of Eritrea, is also facing a set of foreign problems that center on deepening tension with neighboring Somalia.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: LISBON AIDE TELLS OF COMMUNIST BID
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Joao Tomaz Rosa, the Portuguese Minister of Labor, said here that the Communist Party of Portugal came very close to seizing power on several occasions last year by splitting the leadership of the ruling Armed Forces Movement.

title: American League
description: FRIDAY NIGHT

title: He Refuses to Be an UghTonto Indian
description: CANON CITY, COLO. Any casting director with an Indian part to fill in a new picture might well have let out a war whoop of joy at the sight of Will Sampson in his acting debut as Chief Bromden, the silent giant of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. The high cheekbones impassive stare, the impression of dignity tinged with menace were straight out of the paintings of George Catlin or the photographs of Edward S. Curtis. On the basis of Cuckoo's Nest, Sampson was quickly signed to featured roles in three forthcoming westerns: Robert Altman's Buffalo Bill and the Indians, opening in New York on June 25: Clint Eastwood's The Outlaw Josey Wales. coming later in the summer; and J. Lee Thompson's The White Buffalo, which started shooting here in April.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONCould the nation's rate of inflation he significantly less over the next year or more than the 5. percent minimum that conventional wisdom and most economic forecasts imply?

title: LABOR AGENCY FILES FIRST PENSION SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) The Labor Department has chosen a small restaurant company with about 60 employees as the target of its first enforcement suit under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.

title: Deborah Anne Farrington Is Bride
description: Deborah Anne Farrington and Roy Stuart Clauss, who will receive Master of Business Administration degrees from Harvard University on June 17, were married yesterday afternoon in the Second Congregational Church in Cohasset, Mass. The Rev. George A. Hodgkins performed the ceremony.

title: Christine Wren: Another Season
description: Several weeks ago, excerpts from two books about baseball and black Americans appeared on this page. Their sociologically specific point should have been clear to every reader. Interestingly enough, both statements concluded with references to baseball and the American woman, who is still a minority of one.

title: Royal Glint Scores, Nears Million Mark
description: HAZEL PARK, Mich., June 5 (AP)Royal Glint posted a threelength victory today in the $50,000 Hazel Park Trial Stakes and moved within $14,000, of $1million in career earnings.

title: The Dance
description: Settling in to do a danced autobiography, Daniel Nagrin presented Ruminations on Friday evening. It was informal, humorous, spontaneous good fun, a solo tour de force and a little boring and somewhat untidy toward the end. The last chapters are always the hardest to write or perhaps tidy up in choreographic terms. The work was given at the Dance Gallery.

title: D.C. Medical Fund Extended
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) President Ford signed a bill today extending for one year, through the fiscal year 1977, the District of Columbia Medical and Dental Manpower Act, which provides grants to Georgetown and George Washtigton University medical and dental schools. It provides for grants of $5,000 per medical student and $3,000 each for dental students.

title: All the dreams have come true but one
description: In August of 1935, a 24yearold druggist from Huron, S.D., visiting Washington to be at the college graduation of his sister, wrote an excited letter to his fiance back home.

title: Princetonian100 Years Old, and Something More Than Usual
description: PRINCETON, N.J.When The Porinct Ionian was created on June 14, 1876, it described its purpose as very usual  It does not expect to startle anybody, nor to produce any profound effect on the intellectual progress or moral destiny of man.

title: Public Hearings Set By Council Committees
description: New York City Council Committees will hold the following public hearings this week:

title: Best Seller List
description: Eased on reports frees more than 250 bookstores thronalsout the United States. Wrens are Not neeeseartie censeestive.

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on Cambridge University, I should appreciate hearing from American men and women who studied there 19451955.

title: Where Women Made History
description: Shiny plaques mark every bed that sagged under the weight of George Washington and every trail blazed by Daniel Boone, but few signposts direct tourists to the sites where women made history.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WE drove out to visit some people in Oceanside the other Saturday and I must say that the directions our host gave us were the best I have ever received. It is amazing how often people give you slovenly instructions for the quickest route to their home, and the manhours I have spent asking vagrant passersby for a bearing would qualify me for retirement.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: A look at New Jersey's instant millionaires. Page 21.

title: Baugh, Palmer Tie at 142
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 5 Laura Baugh, described as someone who wants to win so desperately, let a firstround lead dwindle to almost nothing today for the second week in a row on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Egypt Shuts Embassy in Syria After Student Attack
description: CAIRO, June 5Egypt tonight recalled its entire embassy staff in Damascus and ordered all Syrian diplomatic personnel in Cairo out of the country in 48 hours in response to an attack today on the Egyptian Embassy in Damascus.

title: Confrontation Over Condominiums
description: VERONA NEW JERSEYANS past and presnet are volunteering some angry testimony these days at Congressional hearings on condominums, and few are angrier than Jerome D. Greco, Mayor of this normally placid Essex County borough.

title: Some Ways for Keeping a Dog Cool During Summer Months
description: With summer rapidly approaching, it is time to reflect on the care of the dog during the hot weather. The owner can help his pet get through the sweltering days with just a little extra care. Since the dog is going to be thirsty, cool clean drinking water always should be available. Many owners, particularly those with shortnosed breedsbulldogs, pugs and Pekingese, carry ice cubes. Most dogs like to chew on the cubes. They are cooling, and because not so much fluid is consumed, there is less chance of the animal becoming ill.

title: A son's homage;. My Father's House By Yigal Alton. Translated from the Hebrew by Reuven BenYosef. Illustrated. 204 pp. New York W. W. Norton 8c Co. $7.95.
description: The father thought to name the son Yigael, which means He will be redeemed, but decided that was too passive a name, and chose instead Yigal, which means He will redeem. The RussianJewish farmer's son became a watchman, a British policeman, member of a kibbutz, a leader of the ragtag 1948 liberation war, a scholar, a major general and Israel's deputy prime minister and minister for foreign affairs. This book. Yigal Allon's act of homage to his father, shows a public man turning inward. He has no political argument to make, unless the word of his father about Mount Tabor makes a declaration of intention about the land of Israel: Maybe there are others more beautiful, but none is just as beautiful.

title: Amy Lombardo Is Bride of Lorn C. Tryk
description: Amy Charlotte Lombardo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Lombardo of Pound Ridge and Brantingham Lake, N. Y., was married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y., to Lorn Cameron Tryk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Tryk of Santa Fe, N.M. The Rev. Francis V. Logue performed the ceremony at noon in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Tryk, who graduated from the Kenwood Academy of tire Sacred Heart in Albany and from the Pace University School of Nursing, is a registered nurse in the delivery room at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe. Her father is president of Dan Lombardo Associates, an advertising agency. Her mother is a psychiatric social worker and marriage and family counselor in private practice.

title: The World
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger will meet in Europe later this month with John B. Vorster, the Prime Minister of South Africa, the first recent meeting between a high American official and a South African head of state. They are meeting at this time because each country, for its own reasons, wants to bring down the white minority regime in Rhodesia, an objective shared by Western and black African nations whose opposition to the Pretoria regime would have otherwise made American participation in such a meeting unlikely.

title: EMILY SANDER
description: Emily Sander, educator and specialist in the New Testament, died Friday at her home in Cambridge, Mass., following a heart attack. She was 56 years old.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: One of the most effective, yet most often neglected, methods of enhancing almost any home movie is to add titles in appropriate places. Titles are not very difficult to make, and they do not have to be especially elaborate to add a real finishing touch to any film and to add some visual variety to the collection of scenes.

title: Louisville, a Place Where Busing Seems to Work
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.At the beginning, last September, white reaction to courtordered desegregation in Louisville was no different from that in Boston. There were violent demonstrations as whites opposed to busing attacked blacks, stoned school buses and fought with police. The National Guard was called in. Scores were injured. White parents kept their children out of school, and thousands marched weekly in protest, The Federal judge who ordered desegregation was cursed and scorned (and still is). Just like in Boston.

title: The Candidate
description: The Candidate

title: Meadowbrook Tops Piping Rock in Polo
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.L, June 5The Meadowbrook polo team defeated Piping Rock, 63, at Ilickox Field today in a charity match for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

title: 12,000 Warehouse Worketi Strike California Concerns
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (UPI)About 12,000 San Francisco bay area and northern California warehousemen were on strike for higher wages today, throwing up picket lines at hundreds of warehouses 04 halting the flow of many goods: from wholesale concerns.

title: Objet d'Art: New Town Near Paris
description: VITRY. France. June 5This workingclass suburb of 95,000 people a few miles south of Paris boasts France's most ambitious program of urban embellishment throuah contemporary art.

title: N. C. A. A. Track Results
Up Against a Fiscal Wall
description: In trying to meet the terms it accepted for the state and Federal money that saved it from bankruptcy, New York City has ended free tuition at its universityone of the most painful reductions in spending made so farand has begun contract negotiations with its labor unions by demanding that city workers give up fringe benefits they have received for years.

title: The Walkaway Mental Patients
description: THE mentallyi 11 have long been society's lepers. Recent events in New Jersey suggest that when mental illness is coupled with criminality  either alleged or provenpublic attitudes are likely to be not only apprehensive but almost hysterical.

title: INSPECTION LACK SEEN IN SKI DEATHS
description: DENVER, June 5A United States Forest Service report released yesterday charged that the gondola at the Vail, Colo., ski resort involved in the March 26 accident that killed four persons had not been inspected properly.

title: What the Thunder Has Not Said
description: VIENNABy far the biggest political event in years, as far as Europe is concerned, is the forthcoming Italian election, where the Communists are trying to oust the Christian Democrats after their thirtyyear rule by the novel formula of first defeating them at the polls, then joining them in coalition government.

title: Olympics
description: In the 1908 Olympics in London, expenditures for equipment, police supervision and messengers came to less than $5,000. In the 1976 Olympics in Montreal. supervision will cost at least $100 million, making it the most expensive security operation in history. The Canawlian armed forces will provide 5.650 combat troops. with another 3,350 in support. The Olympics thus represents Canada's biggest military operation since the Second World War, beating even the Korean War. A combined policemilitary force of 16,000 has been mobilized to protect 12.000 participants at a cost of more than $8,000 per athlete, for an occasion, begining July 17. that will last 16 days.

title: Kissinger Denies New U.S. Moves on the Mideast,
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 5, (Reuters)  Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States was not engaged in any specific new initiative to bring about a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Design
description: Not long ago, the architects of a house such as this fourbedroom, multilevel structure of glass and wood in the Washington, D.C., suburbs would have proudly proclaimed its line of descent from the early modernist work of Le Corbusier. Now, Warren J. Cox of HartmanCox, the Washington firm that recently completed the house, says he feels more comfortable connecting the structure's design to the old attitude that you have to have an idea for each project, and that's far more important than style. The house obviously has overtones of Le Corbusier, but we are really trying to do other things.

title: Personal Secretary Seized in April Slaying of Interior Designer in Park Ave. Apartment
description: The 28yearold personal secretary of Michael Greer, the prcfminent interior designer foimd strangled in his Park Avenue apartment seven weeks ago, was arrested yesterday an4 charged with slaying his employer in a dispute over business transaction.

title: At Gallery, The Crowd Was Ogling Itself
description: Half the crowd could probably best he described as frciik and flamboyantone guest even carried a human skelcion. They were the Warhol crowd. The other half were vary by Leaguish and spoke with a Locust Valley Lockjaw accent and were, well, a hit staid. That was the Wveth crowd.

title: Brown Sr. Stumps in jersey for Son
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 5It was Jerry's idea, not minebut let me tell you, it feels great, said Edmund G. Brown, as he set forth this morning on his first day of campaigning in New Jersey for his son, Edmund Jr., Governor of California.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: DRUMNADROCHIT, Scotland  Alistair Stewart was sipping a pint of bitter at the Lewiston Arms and talking of Loch Ness. He is a sturdy, darkhaired man, a carpenter by trade. He has never seen the Loch Ness monster, but believes you canna any more oass it as a ioke

title: The Dialogue Deepens
description: Slowly, painfully, the rich and poor countries are learning to talk to each otherand to move beyond propaganda toward genuine negotiation.

title: College Swimmer Denied Olympics
description: TUSCALOOSA. Ala. June 6 (AP)A House subcommittee has turned down a request for a waiver of immigration citizenship rules for a University of Alabama swimmer, a move that, apparently, will keep him out of the Olympics.

title: Can a Little Ritz in the Midwest Find Success?
