description: Since the RitzCarlton of Chicago opened its elegant doors last December, at least part of its business has been booming and its best customers have been Chicagoans themselves.

title: The Nation
description: Representative Wayne Hays has begun what could become a precipitous decline from power because of his sexual relationship with a former Congressional secretary who says he hired her to be his mistress. At the urging of fellow House members and Democratic leaders, Mr. Hays last week relinquished one of the two committee chairmanships that had been the source of his influence in Congress, and he is under pressure to give up the other one.

title: But Not Enough Jobs
description: The most serious flaw in the economy remains the high rate of unemployment. With rising G.N.P. the jobless rate has continued to inch downward; last month it dropped twotenths of one percent more to 7.3 percent, compared to its peak level of 8.9 percent in May one year ago. Nevertheless, seven million workers are still unemployed, and if one adds the parttime unemployed and those who have dropped out of the labor force, the iobless rate would be about 10 percent.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Fighting a Broker's Use of Its Name
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 5 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has begun legal action against a mortgage broker who, the federation says, has been using its name in soliciting large loan applications and collecting tens of thousands of dollars in fees from potential borrowers in at least seven states.

title: Roland L. Redmond to Marry Marvie McGregor on July 17
description: Marjory Lindsay McGregor and Roland Livingston Redmond plan to be married on July 17.

title: Three New Roses Are Winners
description: A popular misconception is that modern roses have lost their scent. In 1956, Dr. James Alexander Gamble published a statistical study of of the world listed in Modern Roses IV. He found that only 49 percent of roses brought forth by 1900 had some fragrance. The figure rose to 59.5 percent for roses introduced between 1901 and 1930, and to 68 percent after that date.

title: May Heads 15 Selected for U.S. Five
description: RALEIGH, N. C., June 5Scott May, the college player of the year, three New Yorkers and four players from the University of North Carolina were among 15 players selected today for the United States Olympic basketball squad.

title: They shall take up serpents
description: In Carson Springs, Tenn., services at the Holiness Church of God in Jesus Name follow no set format. It depends on how we're moved on by the Spirit, explains the Rev. Liston Pack, the Holiness Church pastor. Mr. Pack is perhaps the most prominent exponent of the practice observed by some evangelical Christian sects in the Southern United States of handling poisonous snakes  cottonmouths, copperheads and rattlesnakesin their worship. The service went to was attended by 45 people of all ages. It opened with gospel songs like It's God All Over the Ocean, led by a dozen women and girls in long dresses who stood up front with tambourines and cymbals and were accompanied by a guitarist. This was followed by a Pack sermon in the fast, forceful fundamentalist style that sounds atmost like tobacco auctioneering. Then came testimonies and prayer requests from the congregation, announcements, more singing, more sermons from Mr. Pack, a guest sermon, more testimonies.

title: MAILREGISTRATION OF VOTERS BEGINS
description: Religious leaders, politicians, trade unions, civic and community groups and college students have begun an intensive drive to register hundreds of thousands of potential New York City voters under the liberalized state law permitting registration by mail.

title: Sunday Observer
description: In Manhattan where I live, the block just to the south of us is always being dynamited. Sometimes it happens two or three times during dinner. Then two or three weeks will pass without a single explosion.

title: Job Deadline in Bergen
description: TOMORROW is the last day that the Bergen County Community Action Program will accept applications from teenagers for the 1.200 federally funded summer jobs available in the county.

title: Stocks Sell Off for Second Week
description: The stock market closed Friday on a discordant note  Citicorp's announcement of a quarterpoint increase in the prime lending rate to 7.25 percent.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE GREAT VICTORIAN COLLECTION, by Brian Moore. (Ballantine, $1.75.) A man dreams of a great collection of Victoriana, wakes up and finds it outside his window a teasing, insoluble mystery that vastly entertaining.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Sunset And the Time for Striped Bass
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  A strong and bitter easterly breeze had blown the day's tattered clouds down the west.

title: Trade News.
description: About twothirds of the office space at the Galleria at 115 East 57th Street has been leased or committed, according to Edward S. Gordon of the Edward S. Gordon Company, which is managing the property.

title: Trouble in Many Places
description: The essential judicial questions about busing were ostensibly answered back in 1971 when the United States Supreme Court unanimously endorsed it as a means of integrating a public school system.

title: Robert Fenster, Holly Williamson Wed in Vermont
description: The marriage of Holly Williamson to Robert S. Fensteti son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Fenster of New Britain, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Richard Cockrell of St. James Episcopal Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Maclean Williamson.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A WATERCRESS (May 16) M.V.K., Lake Katrine, N.Y. has an ideal brook for growing. watercress. They have tried seed, but it always produces spindly sprouts. They would like some help on raising the lovely thickstemmed watercress found in the supermarkets. Mrs. Benton H. Deming. a Connencticut reader, has worked out this method. Buy a fresh bunch of watercress at the supermarket. Separate the stalks and place broken stalks into the earth under the water of a very gentle brook. They root themselves in days and establish in a few months. The cress will then grow roots and spread across the water. The color will change to a dark brownred but the texture and flavor is superb. In six months, tops can be snipped off in a year, it becomes a solid mat across the water.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It's January in June, and the movie industry could be in trouble. With the exception of That's Entertainment, Part 2, there hasn't been a new film in the last two weeks that looks as if it could become a big hitwhether for the right or wrong reasonsand That's Entertainment, Part 2 isn't strictly a new film. It's a new appreciation of a lot of old tilms. All of the other recent openings are alsorans, meaning that people going to the movies in the next month will continue to be paying most of their money to see only three pictures, All The President's Men, The Bad News Bears and That's Entertainment, Part 2. The rest of the films will have to fight it out for what's left of the public's movie allowance. Hardly a healthy situation.

title: Roderick MacRae 3d Will Wed Robin Beck
description: Dean Robert A. Beck of the School of Hotel Administration of Cornell University, and Mrs. Beck of Ithaca, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Maria Beck, to Roderick MacRae 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. MacRae Jr. of White Plains.

title: College Faculties Are Building Union Muscle
description: Many inhabitants of the academic world, accustomed to looking with disdain on those who earn their living with muscles rather than minds, are starting to find that they have something in common with the nation's truck drivers, longshoremen and auto assembly line workers unionism.

title: Solvency's Price At C.W. Post
description: GREENVALE THE C. W. Post Center of Long island University is suffering from an embarrassment of riches. It is one of the few institutions of higher learning aroundcity, state or privatethat is operating in the black.

title: MRS. GANDHI SET FOR SOVIET VISIT
description: NEW DELHI, June 5Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will leave on Tuesday for a fiveday visit to the Soviet Union aimed at solidifying India's relationship with its principal ally among the world's major powers.

title: Parent and Child
description: Developmental psychologists are skeptical lot. Yet until recently, few questioned the theory that a child's future intelligence, social competence and general ability to learn are largely determined during the first year or two of life. Moreover, there was also general acceptance of the hypothesis that intellectual deficits in adults are due primarily to sensory deprivation in early childhood.

title: Old Fords In Our Future
description: Whenever lists of alltime favorite films are being drawn up, there are mire to be several John Ford classics in the running. Starting Wednesdayand continuing on each Wednesday through August 18the Carnegie Hall Cinema will pay tribute to the master by reviving 22 choice specimens of his art, including The Informer, Steamboat Round the Bend, Stagecoach, Young Mr. Lincoln, Grapes of Wrath, How Green Was My Valley, My Darling Clementine, The Searchers and The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance. Teeing off the series will be the 1935 comedy The Whole Town's Talking, at right, teaming Jean Arthur ancl Edward G. Robinson.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I am writing in regard to the article concerning legal casinos (May 2). It is not business that says yes to casino gambling but, rather, Charles H. Marciante, president of the State A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: ART
description: Locus VALLEY EVLR since the Renaissance coldshouldered the mystical abstractions of the Middle Ages for an art based pn the simulation of the real world, the West has shown a special affection for representational painting and sculpture.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COPIAGUELionel Hampton and his orchestra, presented by the Babylon Citizens Council on the Arts, Friday, 8:30 P.M., Coplague High School, Dixon Ave. Tickets $4. 6677505.

title: GARDENING
description: THE flowering dogwood is considered by many Long Islanders to be our nicest flowering tree, and it would be difficult to disagree; But it has a close relative, the Kousa dogwood, which should also be considered. While the native tree completed its flowering period a month ago, the Kousa is blooming now, so it is appropriate to discuss them together for purposes of comparison.

title: POLITICS
description: THE tail wagged the dog when seven Republican national convention delegates from Suffolk County decided to remain uncommitted rather than follow Vice President Rockefeller and State Republican leaders in endorsing President Ford.

title: Dream Houses Become Reality at U.N. Conference
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 5In these days of painful real  estate prices, how about a twostory home for $5,000?

title: Borg, Dibbs, Orantes Reach Round of 16 in French Tennis
description: PARIS, June 5Never has the French tennis championship been won three times in a row, but today Bjorn Borg reached the round of 16 in his quest for that exalted triple.

title: All in the family
description: The Rockefeller family has exerted a singular fascination over the American people for almost a century. From the first lurid descriptions of Standard Oil's new wealth in the 1880's to the Congressional hearings to confirm Nelson Rockefeller as Vice President of the United States, the public has watched and judged the country's most powerful and intriguing family.

title: Letters: Volunteers For the Spy Brigade
description: To the Editor: In regard to Lorraine Dusky's article, The Life and Times of an InterContinental Hotel Spy (Travel Section, May 16), I would like you to know that since my wife and I have traveled all over the world (including stays at about a dozen InterContinentals) and since I am a former journalist, we have hit upon the same idea that has no doubt struck many other Times readers: I'm in the process of writing to volunteer our services as assessors.

title: Notes: Youth Circuses
description: Life is Just one big circus at the home of Janice and Joe Russo in Hamilton, Ohio. Of the nine Russo children, Toni Marie, 16, is busy morning, noon and night walking the tightrope blindfolded; Jo Ann, 15, is swinging on the trapeze; Bobbi, 13, is executing a limbo six inches off the floor; Felix, 11, is pedaling his unicycle and Janelle, 10, is perfecting her highwire act.

title: Candidates Appear Sure Of Fate in California Race
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5The California Presidential primary, which will elect more delegates to the two major national conentions than any other, will be run off in an atmosphere that makes it appear strongly that candidates in both parties have conceded its results.

description: S??? ??? BEGINNING OF OUR NATION. Americans authors have created a heritage of great literature distictive and unmatched in all the world. here monumenta1 works have not only brought untold enjoyment and enrichment to every generation of Americans but have actually helped to Shape the very course of our nation.

title: N.F.L. Owners Will Take Up Cut in Player Limit
description: The owners of the National Football League will meet in New York on June 15, as is their springtime custom, and the primary issue for them to resolve is one over which the usually placid N.F.L. family could quickly take sides. It is the player limit. How many players will be allowed on the squads, which now total 28 with the start of the Seattle and Tampa Bay outfits?

title: A Select Guide to Summer Dance Festivals
description: American Dance Festival (New London): This summer institute of dance classes and related courses at the picturesque Connecticut College campus features performances by Bill Evans (June 28 and July 29), Annabelle Gamson (June 29), Pauline Koner Dance Consort (July 2 and 3), Chuck Davis Dance Company (July 8), Metropolitan Opera Ballet Ensemble (July 9 and 10), Kirk Nurock and Natural Sound Workshop (July 14). Nikolais Dance Theater (July 1517), Mabou Mines (July 18 and 19) Bella Lewitzky Dance Company (July 2325), San Francisco Dancers Workshop and GuthrieRotante Company (July 30Aug. 1) and Murray Louis Dance Company and Nancy Meehan Dance Company (Aug. 6 and 7). The Festival moves to Newport later in the summer, with performances by Pilobolus Dance Theater (Aug. 22), Judith Jamison and the American Dance Machine (Aug. 23 and 24) and Paul Taylor Dance Company (Aug. 26 and 27). (American Dance Festival, Connecticut College, New London, Conn.

title: CHESS
description: A firedup Washington Plumbers team pulled the rug out from under the heavily favored New York Threats to capture the championship of the National Chess League, a ninecity roundrobin of telephone matches. Each team won six matches while drawing two, but the tie was broken by game points in which Washington's 3315 beat New York's 3116.

title: In Memoriam
description: AVRUTISJohn. June 8, 1974. Time does not heal our great loss beloved brother. BLANCHE, CLARA and DAN.

title: CHURCH SAYS VOTE IN OHIO IS CRUCIAL
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, June 5This could he the telling election, Senator Frank Church told a group of rubber workers in Toledo this morning. As Ohio goes, so probably will go the national convention.

title: Regulations to Aid Tourist
description: Broadway theaters, horsedrawn cabs, parking garages these are some of the attractions and facilities sure to used this summer by many visitors to New York City and fortunately they are regulated by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

description: America's 200th birthday has inspired the nation's record companies to document practically every event of our history in song and story.

title: Except for Security Measures, Nursing Home Says It Will Treat Miss Quinlan the Same as Any Other Patient
description: Aside from security measures to keep out kooks, Karen Anne Quinlan will be treated as any other patient when she is transferred to the countyoperated Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains, N. J., within the next two weeks, according to family and nursinghome spokesmen.

title: Owner's Son Thought Bold Forbes Was Defeated
description: For Esteban Rodriguez Madura, disappointment changed to joy in a matter of a few seconds as Bold Forbes outlasted McKenzie Bridge and Great Contractor a4 the three approached the wite in yesterday's Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: MOTHER MARY SIENA, AIDED THE INCURABLE
description: Mother Mary Siena of the Dominican Sisters of Hawthorne, Servants of Relief for Incurable Cancer, died Friday at the order's mother house, Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. She was 84 years old.

title: FISHING
description: FLUKE are making strong showing in the Island's hays and inlets, with blackfish not far behind. But offshore, the fishermen are casting an eve on the bluefish schools that last week were as far north as the Klondike Banks off New Jersey.

title: Five Schoolboys Claim Relay Mark
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., June 5 (AP)Five New Jersey high school distance runners claimed a world record today for the fiveman 24hour relay.

title: A Pyrrhic Defeat
description: Not all the heeldragging in Nairobi was on the side of the Third World countries. The United States, together with West Germafiy and Britain, opposed efforts of the less developed countries to establish a common fund to stabilize wild price fluctuations in ten key commodities.

title: But Vorster Is Trying to Affect Events in Rhodesia and Black Africa
description: JOHANNESBURGAmong the more vehement opponents of apartheid abroad it is not uncommon to hear South Africa referred to as a suicidal state, meaning that the mass of white people here will march resolutely to their doom rather than compromise on the essentials of a racial policy that has ranged much of the world against them.

title: But the Hand Was the Hand of Humphrey
description: On April 23, just before the Pennsylvania primary, Senator Hubert Humphrey wrote me to insist that if I wanted to be a candidate for President, I would enter the primaries. Six days later, he announced that he would not enter the New Jersey or any other primary, seeming to confirm what he had further written me:

title: Fbod
description: While the American table is blessed with yearround produce from distant points of the compass, most of us watch for local seasonal offerings with the same kind of pleasure a bird watcher awaits the arrival of a longabsent call. The Italian kitchen, for centuries bound to the produce of the month rat hand, treats each season's newcomers with reverence and patience. Thin asparagus, the tiniest of peas, the tenderest of firstharvest spinach and the ripest of strawberries are used in dishes that go well with the everlengthening, everwarmer days of June. Here are four recipes to celebrate the month.

title: Dorothy Noyes, Jose Rodriguez Set Fall Bridal
description: The engagement of Mildred Dorothy Noyes to Jose Vidal Rodriguez has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes Jr. of Darien, Conn. and Fishers Island, N.Y. parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of MN. Jose Rodriguez of San Juan, P.R. and the late Mr. Rodriguez. An October wedding is planned.

title: They Govern a Third of New York State's Residents
description: The Nassau County Republican organization is generally rated as one of the most effective political organizations east of Mayor Daley. But at the moment, it is confronted with a rare and potentially devastating split between Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, the highest ranking Republican officeholder in the county, and the powerful man behind the throne, Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican leader. Last week Mr. Caso said he would run for reelection even if he did not get the party's nomination.

title: Nicholas Angelini Jr. Weds Moira A. Perez
description: Moira Ann Perez. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Perez of New. York, was married yesterday morning to Nicholas Anthony Angelini Jr., son of Lucia Z. Angelini of Pittsburgh, and the late Mr. Angelini.

title: DINING OUT
description: IT Is not necessary to be at the New Jersey seashore to eat good fish. In fact, it can be a handicap. The Green Dolphin, an attractive, rusticlooking place once known as the Old Salt Chop House, serves better seafood tpan a number of much betterknown seafood restaurants at the shore.

title: TAXES FOR DUTCH HIGHEST IN WEST
description: PARIS, June 5Dutch, Swedish and Norwegian people, in that order, are the most highly taxed in the industrialized West, with their governments taking roughly half of the national wealth, according to comparative figures from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Devolopment.

title: Campaign without a knockout punch
description: The first hard decision Gerald R. Ford faced when he was thrust into the Presidency nearly two years ago was a choice of heroes. Portraits of three predecessors were, by custom, to be hung in spots of honor along the walls of the White House Cabinet Room. They would remind the new Chief Executive of all he never had been and, were he more fortunate than most, what he might attain.

title: BRIDGE
description: The first American success in the recent world cham???onships in Monte Carlo was in the Venice Trophy, & challenge' match between women's teams representing North America and Europe. A sextet consisting of Gail Moss, Jacqui Mitchell. Dorothy Hayden Truscott. all from New York. Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, Tex., Carol Sanders of Nashville, Tenn, and Betty Ann Kennedy of Shreveport, La.. won by the substantial margin of 184 match points against a British team spearheaded by the world women's pair champions Rixi Markus and Fritzi Gordon.

title: Diesel Days
description: The 50 miles to the gallon automobile may be closer than you think.

title: Helen L. Hamilton to Be Married
description: Helen Lippincott Hamilton and Guy A. Griscom plan to be married on Friday in a civil ceremony in Antibes, France. A religious ceremony will be held Saturday.

title: In Plymouth Notch Time Stands Still
description: It is common enough in this country to find a house identified as the birthplace or home of a Famous Person arid preserved in tribute as a museum. In fact, there are hundreds of such monuments in all parts of America. But a whole village kept largely as it was in the Famous Person's daythat is another story. And that is what visitors find at Plymouth Notch, Vt., the birthplace and childhood home of President Calvin Coolidge.

title: Soviet Accuses U. S. on Arms Pact Delay
description: MOSCOW, June 5The Communist Party newspaper Pravda today charged that, the Ford Administration was not doing enough to help conclude a longdelayed SovietAmerican agreement limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Sewage Spill
description: Because of the explosion Wednesday evening at sewage storage tank in Island Park, beaches are closed to swimming at Point Lookout, Lido Beach, Long Beach, Atlantic Beach and Hewlett Bay. The first three are closed for sampling and may be reopened shortly, while the latter two may he closed down longer because of potentially toxic water, according to an official of the Nassau County Department of Health.

title: A Commuter Talking To Himself May Be Learning a Language
description: I shared my car Fast summer with about 25 German friends, none of whom I ever met. They were actors who had been engaged by the Berlitz people to dramatize the scripts of three language cassette tapes.

title: Chow Chow Is Best Of 3,551 in Denver
description: DENVER, June 5Joel Marston, a former stage and screen actor known recently for a part in the ABC television show General Hospital, played a, stellar role today as his chow chow, Ch. Starcrest Lemon Kid, was judged best in show at the Colorado Springs Kennel Club fixture.

title: Rutgers Budget Picture Brighter
description: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY has come through a winter of discontenta period threatened by massive budget cuts, burdened by long and bitter contract negotiations with its faculty and troubled by the illness of its presidentand has emerged in better shape than many had reason to expect.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: What is one to say? I had intended to write this week on Flemming Flindt's The Triumph of Death. for the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House, and on the new Louis. Falco Ballet for the Alvin Ailey. And, of course, these must be mentioned. but at the end of May came the death of a man of enormous importance to all of us who are interested in dance. His name and achievements must be accorded recognition, because was the dance historian of our time, and his contributions to the making available of the archives of dance were incredible. We all, simple dance critics and other scriveners, borrow from his researches all the timeoften without even realizing it.

title: Carter Woos Jewish Vote; Some Gain in North Cited;
description: Jimmy Carter has been fervently courting Jewish voters in the North, and his suit seems to be paying off. Several Jewish leaders report a small but definite movement toward the for, mer Georgia Governor during recent weeks.

title: Miss Stoll, 15, Wins State Tennis Crown
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 5  Youngsters continued to dominate Eastern women's tennis as Carolyn Stoll of Livingston, N. J., won the New York State claycourt championship today by defeating Betty Newfield of Jakson Heights, Queens, 61, 62, in the final at the Beach Point Club. Miss Newfield will be 15 years old next week and Miss Stoll is 15.

title: One Never Wants for Anything Is Lore of Jungle Village in Bali
description: TENGANAN, Indonesia, May 31  Last October, Mangku Widel finished his studies in Bali's capital, returned to this jungle village on the island's eastern coast, married and at the age of 27 joined the 30member Council of Elders.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TERMITES can be found in almost every part of New Jersey, and at this time of the year the mail we receive inevitably turns up at least a few letters from panicstricken homeowners who have just spotted swarm of termites in or near their house.

title: Lucinda Moran Becomes Bride
description: Lucinda Ann Moran. daughter of John J. Moran of New York and Myrtle Beach, S.C. and the late Mrs. Moran, was married yesterday morning in in Madison, N.J., to Robert Keith Albiston. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Albiston of Convent Station, N. J.

title: Diamond Polishing
description: WHEN the umpire shouts, Play Ball, the beginning of the Little League season I wish some of the amateur and professional psychologists who have written about the peer pressures and the adult hangups these games would sit on the grass with me and see what I see.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Now let's just lay down a few rules around here: (1) If you're doing a musical that is also supposed to be a whodunit, it's best not to kill off the entire chorus. It thins out the sound. Something's Afoot. in which British musichall entertainer Tessie O'Shea's white teeth and spread talons seem more ferocious than the electrical storms that rage outside (especially when Miss O'Shea, wearing a straw hat, is also to be seen busily plucking a banjo), ignores this simple principle to its peril. Obviously indebted to Agatha.

title: Reflections on Hoboken
description: ON the opposite of the North River, about three miles higher up, is a place called Hoboken. A gentleman who possessed a handsome mansion and grounds there also possessed the right of ferry, and to render this productive he has restricted his pleasure grounds to a few beautiful acres, laying out the remainder simply and tastefully as a public walk.

title: Barbara Tallent Wed in Suburb
description: Barbara Joan Tallent, daughter of Dr. William J. Tallent of the Bronx and the late Matilda Tallent, was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Eric Zegarelli. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward V. Zegarelli of North Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: The Campaign On TV: Some Cancellations
description: LOS ANGELESFor five months now, the media men have been buying television time to promote the hopes of Presidential candidates who are driven by the commercial exigencies of that communication system and the impatience of its audience to rely on the 30second spot as a prime tool for reaching and moving voters.

description: New York 27, Pittsburgh 17.

description: Suburban builders are stepping up their office construction activity in the metropolitan area u the national economy improves.

title: Fire Island Parks
description: For peaceful ferry rides to ocean beaches, visitors can try the Fire Island National Seashore at two locations across the Great South Bay from the mainland. Sailors Haven Park can be reached by ferry from Sayville, while Watch Hill Park can be reached from Patchogue. Both offer sunken forests, excellent surf and sand, concessions and shower facilities. In addition, Watch Hill has camping for families or groups while Sailors Haven has a 36boat marina.

title: But less than perfect
description: Dick Dabney chooses a quote from Camus to introduce this book: I know myself too well to believe in pure virtue. There are other, clues to indicate that while Mr. Dabney sees former Senator Samuel J. Ervin, hero of the Watergate hearings, as a good mane he finds him less than perfect.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: All future music critics come equipped at birth with the gift of omniscience, which is a help in later life. But an almost equally valuable attribute, omnipresence, is denied them by an allwise nature, and that can make planning summers something of a problem. It would not be possible without resort to a portable timespace warper, for instance, for even the most fanatical patriot and Bicentennial buff to be in Central Park and at Tanglewood at 8:30 P.M. on July 4. Appropriately starspangled concerts are promised in both places and in fact there seems to be some overlap in concept and content. In the Sheep Meadow, Leonard Bernstein will lead the New York Philharmonic in an Independence Day program of American composers, including Mr. Bernstein, while in Lenox, Mass., Seiji Ozawa will be presenting a similar package of American composers, including Mr. Bernstein. In both parks the Bernstein selection will be the dances from West Side Story, so in a way the Philharmonic's laureate conductor will have solved the problem of being in two places at once.

title: National Cathedral Window Delights Artist Who Spent 2 Years Making It
description: WASHINGTONSome children want to be garbage collectors, or circus bareback riders. Others fancy themselves as astronauts or baseball players. Rowan LeCompte wanted to make a glorious rose window for. Washington's National Cathedraland, some 35 years later, he has done exactly that.

title: Devon Jumper Crown to Narcissus
description: DEVON, Pa., June 5Narcissus, one of the most consistent mounts in the division, won the bonus point open jumper stake and captured the championship tonight at the closing session of the nineday Devon Horse Show.

Moog's Dynamo, Vincent (Bizzy) MonteSano 2d's chartered Love Machine 2, and Anthony Widmann's Freebootr were class winners on Long Island Sound today in the New York Yacht Club's 122d annual ergatta, a twoday fixture for cruising yachts.

description: WASHINGTONWilliam T. Bagley was weary and somewhat bitter as he slumped in his office sofa well after 7 o'clock one recent evening.

Later that night, Jazzmania, 14 East 23d Street, and Environ, 476 Broadway, joined in the festivities identified as the New York Loft Jazz Celebration.

description: TURIN, Italy, June 1It was a midweek holiday, and the people of Turin were crowding the large park on the banks of the Po RiverA young worker from the giant Fiat automobile complex lounged on the grass and said he was voting for the Christian Democrats.

description: BUENOS AIRES, June 5 (UPI) Former President Isabel Peron has been formally charged, with administrative irregularities that could bring a prison sentence of up to 10 years.

title: A's Triumph on Munson Error
description: Don Baylor, whose speed has replaced Reggie Jackson's bat in the Oakland A's lineup, beat the Yankees yesterday by stealing second and scoring on the same play on Thurman Munson's wild throw and a belated backup effort in the outfield.

title: Barbara Tousley Wed To Lieut. W. B.Thomas
description: Barbara Tousley, daughter of Mrs. Bennett E. Tousley Jr. of Chatham, N. J., and Mr. Tousley of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Lieut. William B. Thomas of the Coast Guard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Thomas of Rellevue. Wash. The Rev.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week: Feed asparagus when last spears are cut and allow tops to develop. Side dress rows of corn with a high nitrogen fertilizer.  Deudhead rhododendrons when flowers fude encourage more blooms.  Keep up rose spray schedule; black spot is appearing, use phaltan, or benomyl. Sow biennial and perennial seed in nursery beds.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syria's military intervention in Lebanon was endorsed yesterday by Lebanon's rightwing Christian leadership. Syrian armored forces meanwhile reportedly remained in an uneasy standoff with Palestinian guerrillas and their leftist allies in eastern Lebanon. President Suleiman Franjieh, who has moved his headquarters to the small village of Zouk Mikhael, issued a statement that said in part that it is only natural that we should support any measure that would lead to the stability of Lebanon. He had the support of the other rightwing leaders: Interior Minister Camille Chamoun, the Phalangist party chief, Pierre Gemayel and the Rev. Charbel Kassis, head of the Order of Maronite Monks. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: How to Reach the Nursery
description: Leave the Long Island Expressway at Exit 41 or the Northern State Parkway at Exit 35, Routes 106107, and head north toward Hicksville. Continue on 106 to Route 25A, the first main intersection (Rothman's restaurant will be on the left corner). Turn left on 25A and continue about one mile, when the nursery will be visible on the left.

description: TodayGlen Head, King's Dary Farm, Jericho Turnpike, Huntington. L.I. Regular, green, nonthoroughbred, special maiden, amateurowner and children's working hunters; novice intermediate and junior jumpers; pleasure, adult horsemanship, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: TERMITES pose a potential threat to every homeowner on the Island, but seldom, if ever, is there a need for panic or for rushing into drastic measures. Protective steps are definitely advisable in almost all cases, however, and the more one knows about the enemy U the better one will be equipped to take the necessary corrective or protective measures.

title: Editors Choice
description: poems of the Italian Nobel Laureate; mom private yet paradoxically more accessible than previous work.

title: Earthquake in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June (AP)An earthquake of moderate intensity yesterday struck the Matta district, about 80 miles from here, damaging scores of buildings, according to reports reaching Karachi today. One person was reported injured.

title: RACISM CHARGED TO SCHOOL BOARDS
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 5 The deputy charvcellor of the New York City school system charged today that racist practices in some of the city's decentralized school districts had created allwhite staffs or, at the other extreme, staffs with heavy minoritygroup representation rn many schools.

title: Margaret Lender Wed to W.C.Phyfe
description: The Bloomfield (N. J.) Presbyterian ChurchontheGreen was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Helen Lender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lender of Bloomfield. to William Churchill Phyfe, greatgreatgrandson of Duncan Phyfe, the cabinetmaker.

title: An Authority on the History of the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Until last summer, Anne Karalekas's only acquaintance with the nether world of foreign intelligence services was her study, for her doctoral thesis, of records of British and American espionage efforts in Greece in World War II. Since then, by dint of what she describes as 80hour weeks, and a special entree into the dead files and living memories of American spies and agents. she has become an authority on the history of the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Missing L.I. Girl Slain In Woods Near Home
description: The Suffolk County police yesterday mounted a search for the killer of a 13yearold girl who was reported missing from here home last Thursday and found slain Saturday night.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 6In a light cool rain that should have embarrassed weather forecasters who had predicted that it would be warm and sunny, a group of beachlovers today began a sixdayIcing walking tour down New Jersey's 101 miles of ocean beach.

title: Callous CUNY Impasse
description: The legislative package that is essential to provide for the future funding of the City University is endangered not by any substantive disagreement over its basic contents but by the legislators reluctance to be associated with unpopular decisions in an election year.

title: Kissinger in Latin America, Makes Appeal on Rights
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 6 (AP)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger opened his trip to Latin America today with an appeal for preservation of human rights, an issue expected to dominate the eightday iourney.

title: HAROLD K. WORK, ENGINEER, 75, DIES
description: Harold Knowlton Work, consultant in chemical engineering and former associate dean of New York University's School of Engineering and Science, died Saturday at his home in, Fairfax. Va. He was 75 years Dr. work's affiliation with the School of Engineering of N.Y.U. began in 1949 when he was appointed director of its research division. He was named associate dean in 1957, remaining in that post until his semiretirement in 1960.

title: Tie in City Council Vote Settled by Turn of Card
description: SHOW LOW, Ariz., June 6 (AP)Robert Pittman won a seat on the city council in this town in eastern Arizona by drawing the deuce of clubs on the third try in a card game at high noon yesterday at the rodeo grounds.

title: Haiti Reports Arrival Of Burton for Divorce
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, June 6 (AP)Richard Burton arrived here yesterday to get a divorce from Elizabeth Taylor, the Office of Tourism and Information said.

title: Riverside Church Installs Its First Woman as Pastor
description: The Rev. Evelyn Newmanher two sons and daughter at her side in the procession to the chancelwas installed yesterday as the first woman minister of the Riverside Church.

description: Joy Devra Levitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Levitt of Centerport, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Rabbi Louis Zivic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zivic of Skokie. III.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Planes were reported to have bombed Palestinian and Lebanese leftist positions yesterday in eastern Lebanon, where Syrian forces were stationed. Both the Beirut radio, controlled by leftists, and the rightwing Phalangist radio, reported the attacks. Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was reported to have sent an urgent message to Arab heads of state charging that Syria had started an allout offensive. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: T.W.A., Flight Attendants Reach Tentative Contract
description: Negotiators worked yesterday on language in an unsigned, tentative contract agreenient that would avert a strike by 5,500 Trans World Airlines flight attendants, United Press International reported.

description: How do you feel this morning? Did you have a good sleep? How was your day? Did you get the work you wanted? Are you glad to come home at night? Do you like the children? What about the baby's face? Do you think it's beautiful? Do you think I'm beautiful? Do I look my age? Younger? How much younger?

title: Primary Climax
description: The first phase of the Presidential election process comes to its noisy end tomorrow, with climactic primaries in New Jersey, Ohio and Californiaall three of them heavyweights in population, delegates and electoral impact. As the crucial primary day approaches, both President Ford and former Georgia Governor Carter have their parties nominations almost within their grasp. If there are to be upsets now, they will have to be big ones, to permit the one Republican challenger or the halfdozen Democratic contenders to stay alive.

title: God Did a Hell of a Job, Too
description: God must he a Latin, Laz Barrera said, because there's no way you could run a horse like he came out the Freakness. Lazaro Sosa Barrera is a Latin trainer. Angel Cordero Jr. is a Latin jockey. Esteban Rodriguez izol is a Latin owner and his horse, Bold Forbes, began life racing for Latins among Latins at El Comandante, the track at San Juan, Puerto Rico. When, after winning the Kentucky Derby, Bold Forbes finished third in the Preakness bleeding from a cut on his left hind foot, everybody concerned realized it would take prayer as well as veterinary medicine to get the horse patched up for the Belmont Stakes three weeks later. That's where God came in. I didn't think we had a 25 percent chance, Laz said, hut between my brother Luis and me and the blacksmith, we did a hell of a job.

title: Elaine Shapiro Bride Of Eric John Appellof
description: The marriage of Elaine Joy Shapiro to Eric John Appellof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Appellof of Middletown, Conn., took place yesterday in Tenafly, N.J. Magistrate Donald de Cordova performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harris L. Shapiro.

title: Brown's 16Month Record Shows Perplexing Array of Ambition and Accomplishment
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4The thing about Jerry is that he is a blend of contradictions, explains a man close to Edmund G. Brown Jr. the 38yearold Governor of California and lateblooming Democratic Presidential candidate. He Is part radical and part conservative, part priest and part pure politician.

title: GISCARD CONFERS ON GAULLIST RIFT
description: PARIS. June 6  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, conferred in a secluded corner of southern France today in an apparent attempt to find a solution to the serious dissatisfaction that has arisen In the Gaullist Party over some of the President's programs and pollcies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Three gunmen invaded a private dub in lower Manhattan forced 30 patrons to disrobe, then escaped with an undetermined amount of money and a Lincoln Continental limousine belonging to one of the victims, the police reported. Several of the patrons were pistolwhipped but no one was seriously injured and no shots were fired.

title: Homer by Gamble Gives Yanks Split
description: Chuck Tanner, the Oakland manager, received no ecstatic telephone call from his boss, Charles O. Finley, after the second game of yesterday's doubleheader at Yankee Stadium.

title: Delaying Tactics and Quirks in Rules May Help Hays Retain Authority in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Representative Wayne L. Hays faces four tests of Dower this week but quirks in the rules of the House may be working in his favor and his use of delaying tactics could help him weather the Elizabeth Ray controversy and hang on to most of his power on Capitol Hill.

title: 2 Schoolboys Win Twice In State Catholic Track
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. June 6A steady rain hampered performances today in the New York State Catholic High Schools outdoor track and field championships at Mont Pleasant High School. But Kendall Jackson of Buffalo's Bishop Timon managed to toss a slippery discus 179 feet 2 inches, the best throw in the state this year.

title: Ted Gross, ExLindsay Aide, Is Found Slain in a Car in Brooklyn
description: Ted Gross, who rose from helping keep peace on the city streets to become Youth Services Commissioner and who then plunged spectacularly, serving a 16month prison term for taking contract kickbacks, was found murdered yesterday morningexecution style.

title: JOHN STORER, 88, CONSERVATIONIST
description: John H. Storer, conservationist, wildlife photographer and author, died Saturday at his home, 2 East 86th Street. He was 88 years old.

title: Miss Dennis Signs For Same Time
description: Sandy Dennis has been signed to star in Same Time, Next Year beginning June 21 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Miss Dennis is replacing Loretta Swit in the Bernard Slade comedy. Her last Broadway appearance was in Absurd Person Singular.

title: 6 Dead, 53 Missing in Idaho Flood; Devastation Is Vast
description: IDAHO FALLS, June 6Six persons were reported dead today and 30,000 were left homeless after a flood that surged through the Upper Snake River Valley after a controversial new dam on the Teton River burst yesterday. Property damage was estimated by the state government at more than $500 million.

title: A New Guard Officer Outranks Her Father
description: SEA GIRT, June 6 (UP1)Ttie first three women ever to graduate from the New Jersey National Guard Officer Candidate School received their commission today, one of them ranking higher than her father and another finishing first in the class.

title: P.E.N. Elects Carlisle President
description: Henry Carlisle, a novelist, was elected president of P.E.N. American Center at its annual meeting held in the trustees room at the New York Public Library recently. He succeeds Muriel Rukeyser. Five vice presidents were also elected.

title: Peru Valley's Fate Studied
description: COLUMBIA, Mo. (UPI) An archaeological team from the University of Missouri is trying to learn what happened to the Chica Valley in Peru, which in prehistoric times supported the Palomans and other settlements. The study, financed with a $60,000 grant from the National Science Foundation, will last through January.

title: Text of Findings on C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON. June 6Following is the text of the conclusions of the final report of the Senate Intelligence Committee on the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency. In the text, D.C.I. is the Director of Central Intelligence, D.D.I. is the Directorate for Intelligence, D.D.O. is the Directorate for Operations and N.S.C. is the National Security Council.

title: Kissinger Reported Ready To Seek Full Peking Ties
description: TOKYO, June 6 (UPI)John K. Fairbank, the China scholar said today that Secretary of state Henry A. Kissinger might visit Peking in September to begin negotiations toward full diplomatic recognition of China.

title: RAY SCHUSTER, 76, LITERARY FIGURE
description: Ray Schuster, widow of M. Lincoln Schuster, a found er of the publishing company of Simon & Schuster Inc., died Saturday of cancer at her home. She was 76 years old and lived at 11 East 73d Street.

description: Amy Beth Satuloff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Satuloff of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to L. Craig Lemle, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Lemle of White Plains.

title: Spain's New Politics Finding Noisy Outlet at Galician University
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTE LA, Spain, May 27In the uncertainty in which Spanish potical life is reemerging while Generalissimo Francisco Franco's restrictions on politics remain in force, the universities have become havens of relative immunity. The police stay out, most of the time.

title: Carter Victory Is Forecast In Jersey Vote Tomorrow
description: TRENTON, June 6  Knowledgeable Democratic Party leaders in New Jersey seemed fairly sure today that former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia would win the victory that had been widely predicted for him in Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary in the state.

title: FIGHTING FLARES IN EAST LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, June 7Air strikes and shelling attacks were reported last night on Palestinian and Lebanese leftist positions in eastern Lebanon, where Syrian troops lately entered the country in strength.

title: Wallace at the End of a Long Trail
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 Politically spent and thoroughly dispirited after a dozen unsuccessful years of campaigning for the Presidency, Gov, George C. Wallace of Alabama made one final, feeble foray onto the hustings this weekend.

title: Nuclear Decision

title: Report on Chilean Arrests
description: WEST BERLIN. June 6 (Remtors) About 130,000 people have been arrested in Chile since the overthrow of the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens in September 1973, according to a report issued today by the German section of Amnesty International. The report said that about 2,000 people had disappeared after having been arrested.

title: 200 Attend a Protest Against Nuclear Power Plants
description: TRENTON, June 6  More than 200 citizens and environmentalists lined the State House steps here yesterday and listened to warnings that nuclear power threatens the future of life on earth. They were attending a threehour rally against the continued development of nuclear technology as a solution to America's longterm energy demands.

title: Former Gov. Robert D. Holmes Of Oregon, Death Penalty Foe
description: ASTORIA, Ore., June 6Former Gov. Robert Dennison Holmes of Oregon, who was noted for his opposition to the death penalty and his promo, tion of economic development in the state, died of brain cancer here today. He was 67 years old.

title: Carter Gets an Ovation After Assuring Jews in Jersey on His Religious Views
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., June 6Jimmy Carter was interrogated before an audience of Jews today about his evangelical Christian beliefs and expressed his belief in the absolute and total separation of church and state in a pluralistic society.

title: Burial in Mexico Expected For ExPresident of Bolivia
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 6 (Reuters)The body of Gen. Juan Jose Torres, the assassinated former President of Bolivia, was expected to be flown to Mexico for burial after the Bolivian Government today canceled plans to repatriate it.

title: State Told It Can Save By Leaving Trade Center
description: New York State could save as much as $4.2 million a year in rent by moving most of its offices from the World Trade Center into a new office building at 1166 Avenue of the Americas state officials said yesterday.

title: Variations on a Theme
description: Inventiveness is not what every woman is looking for when she chooses new clothes. The majority feel much more secure with familiar things, perhaps in a different color, or with a slight variation in detail.

description: ALBANY, June 6Governor Carey has not accepted the compromise fashioned by Mario M. Cuomo, the Secretary of state, to end the residents strike at Coop City and has directed Mr. Cuomo to resume his negotiations to try to get differences and adjustments in it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Moody's Investor Service is to be congratulated for its forthright stand in rating the bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation on their investment merits instead of by politicized arithmetic. It ill becomes Felix Rohatyn, M.A.C.'s chairman, and Simon Rifkind, M.A.C.'s chief counsel, to accuse Moody's of gross negligence and gross incompetence.

title: Miss Kranz Bride Of Barry Shrage
description: Eleanor Leslie Kranz, daughter of Gertrude Kranz of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Henry B. Kranz, was married yesterday noon to Barry Shrage, an associate in the program development and research department of the National Jewish Welfare Board in New York.

description: At Temple BethEl in Cedarhurst, L.I., last evening, Mary Elizabeth Hopkins, daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Leonard Hopkins of West Orange, N.J., was married to Dr. Richard Stephen Casden, son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Casden of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Raphael Ostrovsky performed the ceremony.

title: Large Manufacturers Cut Plans for Capital Outlays
description: The country's 1,000 largest manufacturers have appropriated an estimated $11.1 billion for capital improvement in the first quarter of 1976, the Conference Board said over the weekend.

title: Leading Democrats Decry New York Party Disunity,
description: Five weeks before the Democratic National Convention, the New York State Democratic Party, the host for the convention, is in probably greater disarray than it has been in many years despite the fact that the party has a Democratic Governor and a Democratic Mayor of New York City who would normally unify and guide it.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Two years after an Arab oil embargo focused national attention on energy independence. efforts to create a syntheticfuel industry based on the country's huge reserves of coal and shale remain bogged down by controversy and uncertainty.

title: Tenafly Church Offers Taste of Athens
description: TENAFLY, June 6The music of bouzoukis filled the air this weekend as 8,000 people attended a Hellenic festival and bazaar here at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. John the Theologian.

title: Leon Katz, Realty Broker, Father of State Senate Aide
description: Leon Katz, a realestate broker and developer and father of Sandra Katz, counsel to New York State Senate minority leader, Manfred Orenstein, died yesterday at Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, following a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived at 19325 Keno Avenue, Holliswood, Queens.

title: Triad Sings Black Composers Works
description: The Triad Chorale's Bicentennial Celebration yesterday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall explored a relatively unknown area of American musicsongs and choral works by black composers of the last 100 years. Figuring most prominently was the music of William Grant Still. 81 years old last month and a hardy pioneer among blacks in this country's seriousmusic life.

title: SUDAN IS REPORTED WARY ON ERITREA
description: LONDON, June 6The Sudanese Government, worried about an offensive by Ethiopian peasants against Eritrean rebels, has sent thousands of troops along the border with Ethiopia, according to diplomatic sources in London.

title: RICHARD FLINT, 74, EOGEOLOGY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Richard F. Flint, emeritus professor of geology at Yale and a leader in the application of the radiocarbon method to the dating of glacial periods, died Saturday at his home, 265 Bradley Street, New Haven, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: 2 Foster Sisters Run Away to Protest Ruling Giving Natural Mother Custody
description: Two young sisters who had pleaded with a court not to take them from their Long Island foster parents of five years, after a bitter twoyear custody fight between the girls natural mother and the foster parents, ran away Saturday from the temporary foster home in which they were placed.

title: Castro Confirms A Gradual Pullout From Angolan War
description: HAVANA, Monday, June 7 (Reuters)Prime Minister Fidel Castro confirmed at a rally here last night that Cuban troops were being gradually pulled out of Angola, but said they wound may there until the Angolan armed forces were able to insure the security of the country.

title: Death Squad Arousing New Concern In Rio, With 21 Murdered in 10 Days
description: NOVA IGUACA Brazil, June 2 Late every night, Robinson da Silva ciimhs to the roof of his house to enjoy what he culls my favorite diversionwatching the death squad kill its victims.

title: Customers Protest Threatened Closing Of Italian Bakery
description: The sidewalks in front of a bakery are an unlikely site for a battle scene, but on a drizzly Sunday afternoon the sides were clearly drawn in front of La Continentale bakery on East 30th Street and Second Avenue.

title: 150 Pedal Down Manhattan to Promote Bike Rights
description: With a touch of joyous faftaticism about 150 bicylists pedaled down Broadway in a steady drizzle yesterday to promote the theme bikes have rights.

title: Trenton Fire Kills 4 Children and Their Grandmother
description: TRENTON, June 6 (UPI)Four children and their grandmother were killed in a fire that broke out at their twostory house here, early today, authorities reported.

description: The Boston Celtics won their 13th National Basketball Association title in the last 20 years by defeating the Suns, 8780, yesterday in Phoenix. Details on page 39.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 6 (UPI) Six policemen have been arrested in death squad murders of 23 people in 15 days, the Rio de Janeiro state security chief said today.

description: WASHINGTON, June 6 An authoritative history of the Central Intelligence Agency released today holds that the agency has failed over the last three decades to fulfill several of its essential missions.

title: Adirondack Mischief
description: Governor Carey's sound legislative proposals for improving the workings of the Adirondack Park Agency necessarily involved the risk that they would be so amended by the Legislature that the end result would be harmful. That is why some of the agency's champions were doubtful about any tampering with the law. A serious attempt is indeed now being made to weaken the Governor's bills through amendments. But it is this effort that should be beaten back and not the legislation itself.

title: Israelis Plan to Boycott Security Council Session
description: TEL AVIV, June 6 (AP)Israel said today that it would boycott a coming meeting of the United Nations Security Council called to discuss a plan for creating a Palestinian state on Israelioccupied Arab land.

title: Ann McNamara Is Bride of a Lawyer
description: Ann McNamara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William McNamara of Rye, N. Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Marschall I'mboden Smith, son of Col. Lowell B. Smith, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Smith of Paoli. Pa.

title: Alexander Captures Canoe Race Honors
description: PHOENICIA, N.Y., June 6. (AP)Bob Alexander of East Brunswick, N.J., won the oneman kayak and canoe races, and shared the twoman canoe honors today at the White Water Canoe and Kayak Atlantic Division American Canoe Association championship here at Esopus Creek.

title: Luce, Head of Con Ed, Gets $40,000 Raise
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, which on Friday asked the Public Service Commission for a 10.4 percent increase in electric rates, last month ralsed the salary of its chairman, Charles F. Luce, by 25 percent, to $200,000 a year, a Con Ed spokesman said Saturday night.

title: Ashe, Solomon Advance
description: PARIS, June 6 For some time now, Arthur Ashe has been proclaiming loudly that he wanted to play Paris.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 6 Salty Goose, Duva, Love Machine 2 and Lenore were respective corrected time race winners on Long Island Sound today. title: Jodi Mayo Married To Alan F. Kremen
description: Jodi Catherine Mayo, greatgrandaughter of Dr. Charles H. Mayo, cofounder of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Alan Frazier Kremen. The Rev. Merrill Peal, pastor of the Rochester Congregational Church, performed the ceremony at Mayo Wood.

title: ANDERS EMILE, 83, A MUSIC EDUCATOR
description: Anders Emile chairman of the music department at Hunter College from 1938 to 1963, died Saturday in Bethesda Lutheran Hospital, Minneapolis. A former resident of Port Richmond, SI., he was 83 years old and had been living in retirement in St. Paul, Minn.

description: MOSCOW, June 6  An Americanproduced documentary on the famous Vaganova Institute of Choreography in Leningrad has been filmed and is scheduled to be released next autumn, Earle Mack, its producer, has announced.

title: Cordero Cornpletes a Weekend Stakes Double
description: Angel Cordero, who captured Belmont Stakes with Bold Forbes Saturday, brought home his second stakes winner in two days by triumphing with Live Oak Plantation's medieval Man yesterday. The occasion was the $38,700 Youthful Stakes at Belmont Park, an event that has provided a stepping stone to fame for such past winners as Man o'War, Chance Play, Battlefield, Native Dancer and Bold Ruler. This was its 63d running.

description: Haskel Jacobs, who had practiced law in Manhattan since his admission to the bar in 1917, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 311 East 72d Street. Surviving are his wife, the former Lillian Friedman; a son, Arnold; a sister. Rita Dunn; a brother, Ell; and a grandson, Ross.

title: House Leadership: Stronger Role Is Seen

The announcement yesterday by Cart Albert of Oklahoma that he would resign at the end of the year and the near certainty that he would be succeeded as Speaker of the House by Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts could thus signal a new mood of aggressive Democratic partisanship on Capitol Hill.

He had trained for three weeks in his hometown, Marshall, Tex.

title: The Marx Brothers and How They Grew
description: Did you know that the Marx Brothers once tried to make a silent film comedy? Of course, you won't be able to see it during the MaytoJanuary retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art that embraces everything from John Bunny to Woody Allen. As everyone might have expected, about threequarters through the filming the Marxes threw up their hands, threw out the completed footage (one British historian reports that the footage still exists, but Groucho tells me he doesn't believe a word of it) and went hurriedly back to their then natural home, the stage.

The citations are published in a section entitled extensions of remrks and, although that suggests that they were offered in ringing perorations during floor debates, they were, in fact never uttered. Instead, they were submitted in writing by a Congressman for publication.

title: Books of The Times
description: My first visit to the Central Park Zoo occurred when I was 7 years old. It was feeding time in the lion house and I remember thrilling to the roars of the hungry animals as they leaped up on the bars of their cages. This was before television, and wild animals had not yet become commonplace. As an adolescent, I returned alone to the zoo, hoping to repeat the experience. I was still impressed, partly through having read the entire Tarzan series, with large animals. The second visit was a failure: The lions, tigers, leopards and cheetahs lay silent and indifferent in their cages as their food was thrown in. What had happened? I wondered. Perhaps, I thought, these were the same animals I had seen 10 years earlier and they had grown bored with zoo life.

The baby boys, joined at the abdomen and weighing 10 pounds, were born to Nyla Bongiomi in Fredonia. She was in satisfactory condition today.

description: Four crews of New Jersey firemen rowed the murky waters of the Kill Van Kull into New York Harbor yesterday in a race that the last leg of George Washington's trip to New York City for his inauguration as President in 1978.

title: Jazz of Jankry Group and Monty Waters, In Loft Festival, Adheres to Mainstream
description: A sampling of some of the groups that played during the first two days of the threeday New York Loft Jazz Celebration this weekend indicated that the musicians performing in these informal alternatives to the standard jazz clubs are not essentially different from the groups that appear in those clubs. They cover all the customary jazz formations  big bands, small groups, instrumental and vocal  and play in styles that are close enough to the contemporary mainstream to be completely at home in a club such as the Village Vanguard.

title: GETTY BURIAL SET FOR CALIFORNIA
description: LONDON, June 6 J. Paul Getty, the oil billionaire who died early today at the age of 83, will be buried in California later this week.

title: Film: 'The Last Woman':French Erotic Satire by Marco Ferreri
description: It's not chance that Marco Ferreri, the Italian director ("The Ape Woman." "La Grande Bouffe"), has set "The Last Woman," his new French film, in a landscape composed entirely of modern factories, superhighways, shopping centers and handsome high-rise housing developments where each apartment has its own balcony (to overlook other balconies) and where the grass looks as if it had been installed by a carpet company.There are no visual references to nature in "The Last Woman." Like a meadow that has been turned into a parking lot, nature has been cemented over, effectively sealed off. But there are cracks, and it's these cracksterrible crevasses, reallythat are the subject of Mr. Ferreri's initially buoyant and erotic comedy that becomes, at the end, a satire of such literal brutality that most people may want to be warned. The film opened yesterday at the Fine Arts. Like "La Grande Bouffe," which was about four bourgeois gentlemen who gorge themselves to death. "The Last Woman" is, finally, easier to talk about than to watch, especially on a full stomach. It may be the year's most ferocious satire, a film that only a very sophisticated society could support, but it's also full of brilliance, especially in the performance of Graid Depardieu, who has quite suddenly emerged as France's most talented young actor.As Grard in "The Last Woman," Mr. Depardieu is the thinking man's lug. Built like a truck driver who drinks too much beer, a slob with a good deal of wit, he is a primal force too powerful to be controlled by the system of checks and balances he's been equipped with. He's not stupid. He's a bunch of outmoded attitudes that can't survive in the kind of concrete landscape that is Mr. Ferreri's comic metaphor.Grard is a factory engineer by profession and a colossally self-assured male supremacist by nature. He lives with Pierrot, his young son who doesn't yet walk, on a high floor of a spanking-new apartment house in a flat furnished with stereos, hip posters and all sorts of superfluous time-saving gadgets, including an electric carving knife.Some time before the start of the film Grard's wife has walked out on him to find her own identitywhich is all right with Grard, who doesn't mind playing mother as well as father to his son and who has no trouble finding temporary mistresses. In fact, he rather likes the temporariness of his sex partners. They don't question his ego nor invade the territory he rules as a fatheruntil the appearance of Valerie.Valerie (Ornella Muti) is "The Last Woman," a voluptuous green-eyed beauty who teaches in the factory's nursery school. One night when Grard goes to pick up Pierrot, he also picks up Valerie and takes her home for what he expects will be another limited liaison. But Valerie is different. Between bouts of furious love-making she begins to settle in.In the way no other woman ever has, she also begins to invade his consciousness, which, to a Narcissus like Grard, is somehow to diminish him. When she tells him that he never succeeds in giving her an orgasm, she says it matter-of-factly, without accusation, but the effect is eventually devastating.When she tells him that Pierrot needs to be touched, cuddled and loved, he sees it as a threat to him. "I need to be loved," he yells at her. Finally Valerie, sweet, beautiful, apparently passive, persuades Grard his sex is the root of his egocentricity."You are nothing without it," she says, which prompts Grard to make the ultimate gesture to prove her wrong. What is Mr. Ferreri up to? Sometimes I think I know and sometimes I'm not sure I want to. Then again I suspect that he may be the most passionately wicked satirist since Jonathan Swift. His satire is an electric carving knife that cuts two ways at once. Grard is part buffoon, part tragic hero. Valerie is Eve, and the film, which begins as an uproariously erotic comedy, concludes as a spectacle so bloody it could send eroticism back to the closet forever.The film is immaculately played by Mr. Depardieu, Miss Muti, Zouzou (as Grard's first wife) and David Biffani, a little boy who apparently learned how to act even before he learned how to walk.

description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) The United States should accelerate the development of nuclear power to help assure the nonCommunist world of independent energy alternatives, a private advisory group said today.

title: Energy Dependability
description: WASHINGTONThe Administration's policy for achieving energy security is to decrease United States dependence on foreign oil. This would be done chiefly by increasing domestic energy sources, by energy conservation, and by coordinating our energy planning with other industrialized countries. This is good but not enough. It needs to be supplemented by a longrange effort to make the international energytrading system snore dependable. After all, even if the United States could become embargoproof, this would not make us very secure if some of our chief trading partners (Europe, Japan, Latin America) were still vulnerable to an oil embargo.

title: A MakeWork Nation?
description: BOSTON  The main highway between Boston, and Providence, Interstate 95, has been torn up for months now. Although it is quite new, a sixlane limitedaccess road of high standard, it is being rebuilt under a Federal highway safety program. Rock ledges are being torn out of the median, entrance lanes shifted a few feet, shoulders widened.

title: Nancy Goldfluss Wed To Dr. Sanford Taffet

title: Former Ambassador to U.S. Dies in Buenos Aires at 81

description: SAN DIEGO, June 6 (UPI)A 140footlong oil company research vessel caught fire in the Pacific Ocean 30 miles northwest of here yesterday, but all 22 persons aboard were rescued by a Navyguided missile frigate.

title: A Beautiful Voice Backed By a Perfect Technique
description: Elisabeth Rethberg not only had a beautiful voice, she also had a perfect vocal, technique to hack it up. Other great sopranos of the day conquered by means of their temperament, or beauty, or acting ability. The celebrated Lotte Lehmann, for instance. was the first to admit that she had problems with breath control. Elisabeth Rethberg never had any problems. She was one of those singers, like Rosa Ronselle, from whose throat floods of controlled sound came forth in an effortless manner.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne has called on New Jersey physicians to promote a planned mass swineflu immunization program in a speech before the Medical Society convention in Cherry Hill on Saturday, he promised participating doctors protection against liability.
