She was Ch. Jay Mac's Impossible Dream owned by Dorothy De Maria of Downey, Calif., and handled by Joe Waterman.

title: Lisbon's High Court Rules Azevedo's Candidacy Legal
description: LISBON, June 6 (Reuters)The Supreme Court ruled today that Prime Minister Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo's candidacy in Portugal's presidential elections was legal after the admiral alleged that there was a military conspiracy against him.

title: Met Star Dies at 81
description: Elisabeth Rethberg, a soprano who for 20 years was one of the Metropolitan Opera's brightest stars, died yesterday at her home in Yorktown Heights, N. Y., at the age of 81. Page 32.

title: SECURITIES PANEL FOR PLAN TO TEST ELECTRONIC SETUP
description: A special committee of the Securities Industry Association, a trade group representing securities firms, has endorsed a pilot program to test a controversial electronic system on the nation's securities markets, according to Wall Street sources.

title: Rev. Henry J. Phillips, 51, Chaplain of Nassau Police
description: The Rev. Henry J. Phillips, 51  year  old pastor of Holy Name of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Valley Stream, LI, and Catholic chaplain of the Nassau County Police Department, was pronounced dead in Nassau County Medical Center Saturday evening after an automobile accident in Point Lookout. L.I.

title: Forest Fire in Ontario
description: TORONTO, June 7 (Reuters) Forest fires raging in virtually the entire northwestern sector of Ontario Province may damage more than a million acres of woodland before they can be brought under control, the Ontario National Resources Department said today. The fires have so far spread to over 250,000 acres.

title: Udall Ohio Commercials Are Found to Help Rival
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 7The fourth advertising spot in the third break for commercials on the Saturday night movie featured Representative Morris K. Udall in shirtsleeves.

title: Excerpts From the Address by Nadjari
description: Following are excerpts from the address last night by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari to the Commercial Law League of America:

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: Belmont Jockeys

title: Pro Transactions
description: PHILADELPHIA (NBA)Signed Melvin Bennett, forward.

title: News Summary and Index
description: To help support the declining British pound, the United States and other industrialized countries provided Britain with a $5.3 billion standby line of shortterm credit. The United States contributed $2 billion of the total. The pound promptly rose strongly in foreignexchange markets, closing at 81.77 in New York. This compared with a low of $1.70 touched briefly last Thursday after a sustained decline. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Firestone Admits It Paid $330,000 in Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Firestone Tire &. Rubber Company disclosed today it had paid out about $330,000 over a 2year period in a largely illegal program to finance political campaigns in the United States.

title: Primaries To Reach A Climax Today
description: Primaries To Reach A Climax Today

title: Stones Part of Cast At Las Vegas Net
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 7 Dwight Stones, who set a high jump record last Saturday in Philadelphia, was tied for sixth place after firstround play today in the sixth sports celebrity tennis tournament for the Dewar's Cup at the Riviera Hotel.

title: Dow Off by 5.81 to 958.09
description: Stock prices moved lower again yesterday in continued light trading. Declines in Du Pont and General Motors, two of the 30 components of the Dow Jones industrial average, accounted for almost half of the day's total loss of 5.81 points.

title: Mills Sees Democratic Loss If Party Rejects Carter
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 7 (UPI)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills. Democrat of Arkansas, said today that he believed the Democrats would lose the Presidential election in November if they ignored the results of the primaries and nominated someone other than Jimmy Carter.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Reading Joy
description: On a recent evening when the wind, which had moaned out of the southwest for three days, died, and I could hear the surf grumbling on the shore nearly three miles away, I finished hoeing the last row of potatoes in my garden and repaired to the house to write.

title: New York Telephone Planning a $200 Million Issue
description: The New York Telephone Company is scheduled to sell $200 million of toprated debentures today at a yield of 8.68 percentthe highest rate of return on a longterm Bell System bond issue Since last October. The bond sale is the first significant test of the strength of the corporate market's current recovery since it began May 28.

title: Rockets Deal Makes Lucas No. 1 Pick
description: After a strange turn or events yesterday, John Lucas, the Maryland backcourtman became the first choice in today's National Basketball Association college draft. The Houston Rockets obtained the first pick from the Atlanta Hawks and will use it to select Lucas. There are also reports that they already have signed him.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on a financial page in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified a woman at the right as Ingrid Palmer of the Bureau International du Travail in Switzerland. She is, in fact, Hannah Papanek, associate professor of sociology at Boston University.

title: Dalrymple Is Ousted In Westchester Golf
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 7The Fenway Golf Club, a par70 layout that demands precise shotmaking along its 6,537 yards, took its toll immediately today as the 57th Westchester amateur championship began a threeday run.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Boy, 3, Fails Five Floors To Death in South Bronx
description: A 3yearold boy fell to his death from a fifthstory window in the St. Mary's Park section of the South Bronx last night, the police reported.

title: MIXED MARRIAGES SUBJECTOFREPORT
description: A joint Roman CatholicAnglican report on mixed marriage, released yesterday by the two churches, has proposed changes that would further relax the requirements for recognition of such marriages.

title: India's Delegation to U.N. Rejects Charges of Torture
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7The Indian delegation rejected as groundless today a complaint from the International League for the Rights of Man charging the Indian Government with suppressing individual freedom and permitting torture of political dissidents.

title: Playing With Fire
description: It is ironic that in the year when a Southern Democrat, having long rejected the old traditional politics of his native Georgia, is making a serious bid for his party's Presidential nomination, a Northern Republican President is making a sustained effort to make race a significant issue in the campaign. After first frantically leaping on the busing issue, the President has now ventured the opinion that private schools have a right to reject children on account of their race.

title: Rubin Carter Is Accused By a Woman of Assault
description: The former head of the New Jersey Defense Committee for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter said yesterday that Mr. Carter a former boxer assaulted her while they were in Maryland last. April to attend a heavyweight championship fight.

title: MORTON WOLF, 69, REALTY EXECUTIVE
description: Morton S. Wolf, who, with his late brother, Charles S., founded. SpencerTaylor Inc., 100 East 42d Street, a real estate development and hotelmanagement concern, died in New Rochelle Hospital Saturday after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Record Sales and Net Reported By Gulf and Western Industries
description: Gulf and Western Industries, the conglomerate, achieved its highest sales and earnings for any quarter or ninemonth period with profits up 93.6 percent in the quarter ended April 30 and 48 percent, in the nine months, the company said yesterday.

title: National Airlines Lands at Bates
description: The $10 million National Airlines account has touched down at Ted Bates & Company after circling in a holding pattern since May.

title: Brown, in Jersey, Presses For LateBreaking Surge
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California returned to New Jersey yesterday in a final campaign effort to exploit what he and Democratic leaders in the state perceive as a latebreaking surge for him in today's Democratic Presidential primary election.

title: Goldin Reports City Is Being Victimized On DayCare Rents
description: Auditors for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charge that New York City has agreed to high rents for daycare centers it leases directly, without relation to cost, resulting in excessive profits to developers.

title: Robert Cook Dead at 40; Was Advertising Executive
description: Robert William Cook, automotive advertising manager for the publication W published here by Fairchild Publications Inc., died of a heart attack Saturday in Mountain Lakes Camp, North Salem, N.Y., while on an overnight hiking trip with a group of Chappaqua Cub Scouts. He was 40 years old.

title: Chile Study Says Torture Goes On
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission has accused Chile's miitary Government of continuing arbitrary jailings, persecutions and torture while issuing decrees and statements to tranquilize or confuse world opinion.

title: $5.3 BILLION IN AID PROVIDED BRITAIN TO BOLSTER POUND
description: WASHINGTON. June 7The United States joined with other industrialized countries today to provide a $5.3 billion standby line of shortterm credit for Britain to bolster the pound. The United States put up $2 billion of the total.

title: NoFrills American Look'Sweeps Japan
description: TOKYO, June 7When 18yearold Kazuko Wakuzawa decided she needed some new clothes here the other day, she knew exactly what she wanted. Jeans, she said, I'm buying more jeans. I think they are very American.

title: Reagan in Disneyland
description: Ronald Reagan's remarks about sending a token force of American soldiers to keep peace in combustible Rhodesia may have been misunderstood or even distorted, but this much is clear: The former California Governor knows as little of the facts of life in volatile southern Africa as he does about the origins of the Panama Canal treaty, the realities on Cyprus and the intricacies of strategic nuclear weapons control.

title: Architects Have a Blueprint for Habitat
description: VANCOUVER. British Columbia, June 7  Architecture has been little discussed at the weekold United Nations Conference on Human Settlements here, but pressure is growing to include a provision for the quality of design in the final declaration to be adopted later this week.

title: MAX M. WISEMAN, 47, OF MENORAH HOME
description: Max Michael Wiseman, a proponent of community psychiatric care for the aged and for the last nine years executive director of the Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm, 871 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 47 years old.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Exam In Which Blacks Scored Low
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Supreme Court ruled today, to 2, that a statute or other official act is not unconstitutional just because it places a substantially disproportionate burden on one race.

title: Corporate Profile
description: Twenty or even 10 years ago, the death of J. Paul Getty might have been a blow to the fortunes of the crown jewel of his financial empire, the Getty Oil Company. But today, thanks to Mr. Getty's stewardship, the company has become large enough to stand on its own, according to financial analysts.

title: Helping New York
description: Blanche Leventhal stands in the doorway of the waiting room at Manhattan Family Court surveying the faces of the waiting parents. She is trying to decide which one to approach.

title: British Economic Actions And Credit Buoy Pound
description: LONDON, June 7The battered British pound staged a strong recovery today, buoyed by domestic economic developments as well as by a $5.3 billion international line of credit.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx. 1 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11. 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA. 8 P.M.)

title: Michigan State's Young Medical School Becomes College of the Bedside Manner
description: EAST LANSING, Mich. Michigan State University's young and innovative medical school, with its headquarters here and students in training all over Michigan, could be called the College of the Bedside Manner.

title: Jacob S. Chalat, Specialist In Civil Law, Dead at 84
description: Jacob S. Chalet, a lawyer in private practice here who specialized in civil and international law, died yesterday morning in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Furloughed G.M. Workers Back on Job After 2 Years
description: LINDEN, June 7For the first time in a long time, the employee parking lots at the General Motors Corporation assembly plant here were jammed this morning.

title: QUAKE FROM PACIFIC HITSCENTRALMEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, June 7 (AP)An earthquake in the Pacific off Acapulco struck central Mexico today causing panic but only slight damage. There were no reported casualties.

title: U. S. Is Learning From Setbacks Suffered at U.N. Labor Talks
description: GENEVA, June 6The United States, which has made restoration of respect for due procless a mainstay of its campaign to banish politics from the International Labor Organization, is learning once again that reliance on the elastic rules of any United Nations agency can open up a bottomless pit of new frustrations.

title: Big Board Admits Firm
description: The admission of Front Street Securities as a member of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday. Burton G. Freidlander and Alexander E. Chapro, former executives of Baker, Weeks & Company, a retailoriented brokerage firm, were named chairman and president, respectively. The firm, situated at 110 Wall Street and Front Street, specializes in institutional stock and option trading.

title: CRITICISM UNFAIR, NADJARI ASSERTS
description: Maurice H. Nadjari defended his methods and record as special state prosecutor last night and called criticism of his office baseless and unfounded and unfair.

title: A.T.&T.ACCUSED BY 3 LITTON UNITS
description: Three subsidiaries of Litton Industries filed an antitrust suit yesterday against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a group of its subsidiaries, alleging violation of antitrust laws by monopolization of the telephone terminal equipment market.

title: 200 More Families Are Homeless as Snake River, Swollen by Dam Break, Ravages Two Idaho Towns
description: IDAHO FALLS, June 7The Snake River, swollen out of its banks by waters that broke through a controversial new dam two days ago, rampaged through two more southeastern Idaho towns today, leaving an other 200 or so families homeless.

title: Notes on People
description: It's Daniel Patrick Moynihan controversy time again. The usually bluntspoken former United States representative to the United Nations is a center of dispute on the Ohio State University campus in Columbus because of an honorary Doctor of Laws degree he is supposed to receive on Friday.

title: Yanks Getting Big Crowds Big Headaches at Stadium
description: Fans became part of the show at Yankee Stadium during the weekend and most likely will continue in that role the rest of the season. Their significance at Yankee games lie on two levels  their numbers and their rowdiness. The numbers are impressive, the rowdiness upsetting. Based on the first 24 playing dates at home, the Yankees are almost certain to outdraw the Mets this season for the first time since 1963. Assuming they remain in the pennant race the entire season, there also is a chance the Yankees could reach the 2 million mark for the first time since 1950.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Hays Scandal Spurs Procedural Reforms in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Democratic representatives took two procedural steps today to try to clean up administrative disarray and blunt electionyear criticism of their behavior.

title: 4 Minor Quakes in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 7 (Reuters)Four minor earthquakes jolted different parts of Japan in twoandahalfhour period last night, causing a temporary halt in train services, the Meteor logical Agency said today. There were no reports of damage or casualties.

title: ADMIRAL SHIMADA, LED JAPAN'S NAVY
description: TOKYO, June 7 (AP)Adm, Shigetaro Shimada, who was Navy Minister when Japan went to war with the United States in 1941, died in a Tokyo hospital today. He was 92 years old.

title: SYRIANS MOVING TROOPS AND TANKS CLOSER TO BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, June 8  Syrian troops held Beirut in a stranglehold as Syrian armored columns were reported yesterday to have advanced toward the capital from positions taken last week in eastern Lebanon.

title: $100,000 to Be Given To Women Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)A women's fundraising group announced today that it expected to contribute $100,000 to female candidates this year to try to break up a virtually exclusive men's club in the Senate.

title: Rugby AllStars Play French Tonight
description: The New York Metropolitan Rugby Union has named the squad that will face the French national rugby team tonight at 7 P.M, in Downing Stadium at Randalls Island.

title: Brooklyn Judge Upholds Indictments Against Steinkut and His Son
description: A Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn upheld yesterday a twocount felony indictment charging Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, and his son, Robert, a Brooklyn Councilman at Large with corruptly using their offices to arrange a city job for a Bronx haberdasher in return for a $2,500 contribution to the son's campaign.

title: Nuclear Safety or Shutdown?
description: California voters choosing their national convention delegates probably will reject another item on their ballotsProposition 15, a citizens initiative calling for drastic new safety standards and tests for nuclear power generators. Even so, the vote in California Is likely to mark the beginning, not the end, of a national reexamination of this complex matter.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RIME PICKINGS With little fanfare, a singing guitaristcowboy from North Carolina named Harry Robbins arrived in a midtown showcase. The guitarist has two musical backers, Vin Leary on the bassguitar and Sailor Bob Smith on the harmonica, both seasoned New Yorkers. Among them, with Mr. Robbins to the fore, they make country sounds as soothing and irght as rain on an apple barrel.

title: 1 United Nations Plaza: a Serious Cause for Rejoicing
description: The new 1 United Nations Plaza Building, a combination public hotel and United Nations related office complex, is arguably the hest glass curtainwall structure. New York has seen in a decade. The architects are Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo and Associates, and what they have produced is serious cause for rejoicing: it is a Dunning mat deserves to rank with the Lever House, the Seagram Building and 140 Broadway as one of the finest postwar skyscrapers in the city.

title: SYRIANS MOVING TROOPS AND TANKS CLOSER TO BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, June 8  Syrian troops held Beirut in a stranglehold as Syrian armored columns were reported yesterday to have advanced toward the capital from positions taken last week in eastern Lebanon.

title: Greek Collector Denies Plot To Move Egyptian Antiques
description: ATHENS, June 7 (Reuters)A Greek art collector has strongly denied Egyptian suggestions that he intended smuggling out of Egypt a quantity of antiquities found in the basement of his villa in Alexandria.

title: Brown Will Decide Soon How Far to Battle Carter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 7Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. will decide in a few days whether to carry his latestarting battle with Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination all the way to the party's national convention in New York City next month.

title: Goldwater Has Hip Surgery
description: PHOENIX, June 7 (UPI)Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, underwent hip surgery today because of worsening degenerative arthritis. Officals at Good Samaritan Hospital here said that Mr. Goldwater was doing very well after the surgery to replace his right hip joint. Mr. Goldwater, 67 year old, was expected to remain in the hospital for two to three weeks.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Short History of Guerrilla Warfare, by John Ellis (St. Martin's Press, $8.95).

title: FILE DESTRUCTION BY C.I.A. REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The new Senate Intelligence Committee will retain and review 100,000 classified intelligence documents, despite a Central Intelligence Agency plea that the agency be allowed to resume the routine destruction of outdated files, it was announced today.

title: Jauffret Bid Falls Short; Borg Wins
description: PARIS. June 7With Roland Garros Stadium in hysterics. Bjorn Borg and Francois Jauffret turned what was expected to be a rcutine match into a 3hour40minute struggle today before Borg won and advanced to the quarterfinals of the French open tennis tournament.

title: Market Place
description: The axiom that wall Street takes unkindly to adverse surprises, particularly on the earnings front, has been borne out anew in the case of Simplicity Pattern, the leading maker of paper patterns for women's and children's clothing.

title: Ballet: Flying Giselle
description: American Ballet Theater returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time since 1968 and the company looked fine and very much at home in the kind of operahouse setting that it has always desired but never settled in.

title: Selfhelp Community Agency Is Given $50,000 by Ali
description: Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight champion, has given the Selfhelp Community Service, a social service agency at 44 East 23d Street, $50,000, the service said yesterday.

title: Is the Paradise Restaurant Lost?
description: I can't get over it, Costas Kokis was saying the other day, throwing up his hands in a gesture of despair. They are opening a fancy $7 million restaurant down there and closing my place up here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on a financial page in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified a woman at the right as Ingrid Palmer of the Bureau International du Travail in Switzerland. She is in fact. Hannah Papanek, associate professor of sociology at Boston University.

title: Chamber of Commerce and N.A.M. Agree to a Merger
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UM) The Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers have agreed in principle to a merger, the nation's two largest business organizations said today.

title: Body of Murdered Bolivian Flown to Mexico for Burial
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 7 (Reuters)The body of former President Juan Jose Torres of Bolivia, who was murdered here last week, was flown today to Mexico after the Bolivian Government canceled plans for burial in La Paz.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued to decline yesterday as investors concern mounted over rising interst rates.

title: No.Amer.SoccerLeague
description: No.Amer.SoccerLeague

title: Business Briefs
description: Weekly steel production for the latest week showed its first setback since the week ended April 3, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association placed output for the most recent week at 2.67 million tons, a drop of 3.2 percent from the previous week when 2.76 million tons were poured. However, the 1976 week included the Memorial Day holiday.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: SPECIALTY STEELS WILL FACE QUOTAS
description: President Ford announced yesterday the signing of documents that will lead to the imposition of quotas on imports of specialty steels.

title: Jesse Jackson Begins a Model Program in Chicago to Improve the Moral Atmosphere in Black Schools
description: CHICAGO, May 28 The young audience at Kenwood High School, in the Hyde Park section on the Near South Side, responded enthusiastically to the wellknown I am somebody chants of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson. I may be poor, but I am somebody. I may be on welfare, but I am somebody, the students repeated after the president of People United to Save Humanity (PUSH).

title: Senate Maintains Feature Section Of Antitrust Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Senate, by the narrowest of margins, defeated today repeated attempts to eliminate the central feature of one of the three main sections of a pending antitrust bill.

title: The Trials Of EverAftering
description: The further adventures of Cinderella and the Prince as recounted in The Interminable Happy Ever After:

title: Antitrust Suit Lays Illegal Paint Pricing To the Du Pont Co.
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) The Justice Department today charged E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co. in a civil suit with using a cooperative advertising plan to suppress price competition in the retail sale of its Lucite paint.

title: Raul Castro Visits Congo For Talks With President
description: HAVANA, June 7 (Reuters)Defense Minister Raul Castro of Cuba paid a visit to Brazzaville, capital of Congo, last week for talks with President Marian Ngouabi, the official Cuban daily Granma reported here today.

title: Newark Councilmen Facing Jail Terms Get Day's Reprieve
description: NEWARK, June 7Five City Councilmen scheduled to go to jail today for refusing to vote for a courtordered revaluation of Newark real estate received a 24hour reprieve.

title: Changing the Guard
description: The decision of Speaker Carl Albert to retire means that at least three of the top leadership posts in the next Congress will be filled by men new to the job. Mr. Albert joins Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, and Senator Hugh Scott, the minority leader, who had already decided to step down.

title: ANDERSON SEEKING A CITY U. ADVANCE
description: ALBANY, June 7The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, called this afternoon for the appropriation of a $24 million advance to reopen the bankrupt City University immediately.

title: 4 Injuries Are Reported in 4 Chicago Explosions
description: CHICAGO June 7 (AP)At least four persons were injured, none seriously, when four explosions occurred within of each other in Chicago's downtown shopping areas tonight, officials said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: To help support the declining British pound, the United States and other industrialized countries provided Britain with a $5.3 billion standby line of shortterm credit. The United States contributed $2 billion of the total. The pound promptly rose strongly in foreignexchange markets, closing at $1.77 in New York. This compared with a low of $1.70 touched briefly last Thursday after a sustained decline. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: PLANE CRASH STIRS A CRISIS IN SABAH
description: SINGAPORE, June 7  The crash of a light plane last night in the remote northwestern corner of Borneo has thrown into further contusion what was already one of the most bizarre cases of political intrigue in Southeast Asia.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WORK ON THE MALL CONTINUES: Joseph Ghallagher adjusting the center piece of a brickwork geometric design on the south mall of the Empire State Plaza in Albany yesterday. The view is south from the Capitol with the Tower and unfinished Meeting Center at left, the CulturalEducation Center at center, and agency buildings at right.

title: C.I.A. Agrees to Restrict Its Use of Missionaries
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI)The Central Intelligence Agency has agreed not to seek intelligence information from United States missionaries stationed abroad but many continue to approach such missionaries in the United States, according to the agency's director, George Bush.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL RAISES PRICES 78%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the second largest steel producer, yesterday followed the industry leader, the United States Steel Corporation in announcing increased prices.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Time Publishes Issue
description: Time magazine made its regular weekly appearance yesterday with an 8Opage issue dated June 14 and a cover on Italy: The Red Threat. Later in the day, George V. Byrnes, Federal mediator, arranged for Time Inc. the parent company, and striking editorial employees to resume negotiations today.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WARSAW. June 7 (UPI)RCA has concluded an exclusive contract with the Polish Government for production of color television sets for sale in Eastern Europe, the technical weekly Inowacje said today.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: TOKYO.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRAUNSTEINMeyer, June 8, 1974. Lovingly remembered, sadly missed.

title: CHINA DEFENSE CHIEF RETAINS HIS POSITION
description: PEKING, June 7 (Reuters)China has confirmed that Yeh Chienying still holds the key post of Defense Minister.

title: Leningrad Elects Mayor
description: LENLNGRAD, June 7 (Reuters)Lev Zaykov, a 53yearold engineer, was elected mayor of Leningrad today, Tass the Soviet press agency, reported. He succeeds Vasily Kazakov, who has been appointed a Deputy Prime Minister of the Soviet Union.

title: Arab League Summons Key Ministers on Lebanon
description: CAIRO. June 7The Arab League today called an emergency meeting of its member nation's foreign ministers for tomorrow to discuss the war in Lebanon.

title: SEVERAL BANKS BUY GOLD AT LM.F. SALE
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reuters)The Bank for International Settlements was awarded 162,400 ounces of gold, or about 20 percent of the total, at the International Monetary Fund's auction last week, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Brooklyn to Get Plant Designed To Produce Steel From Refuse
description: New York City will become the site for what its promoters describe as the world's first plant to produce highquality commercial steel from metal scrap recovered from incinerated municipal refuse.

title: Wrong Envoy Is Shot In Assassination Bid
description: ASUNCION. Paraguay, June 7 (UPI)A gunman shouting Free Croatia! shot Uruguay's Ambassador to Paraguay today, apparently mistaking him for the Yugoslav Ambassador who was expected to be in the same area.

title: BRITISH AIR SHOW BARS ISRAELI JET
description: LONDON, June 7The organizers of Britain's principal air show have stirred a controversy by barring an Israeli fighter plane from participating.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS FORD TV TACTICS
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., June 7Ronald Reagan lashed out today at President Ford's endorsement of the radio and television campaign in California that attempts to portray the Republican challenger as a threat lo peace.

title: Rosemary Gunning, at 71, Ends Legislative Career
description: ALBANY. June 7Assemblywoman Rosemary R. Gunning. ConservativeRepublican of Queens, who entered politics when she was in her 60's and who has been one of the Conservative Party's most effective ??? the Legislature, told colleagues today that at ???age of 71 she had decided not to run for a fifth term.

title: Worm Diggers End Strike
description: WISCASSET, Me., June 7 (AP)  A statewide marine worm diggers strike that began May 16 has ended, and sandworm diggers have joined bloodworm diggers on the mudflats. The bloodworm diggers returned to work Thursday, but sandworm diggers held out for a $7.50 increase in the price they get per thousand wormup to $37.50. They settled for the bait dealers initial offer of a $3 increase and returned to work yesterday, a spokesman said.

title: The Celtics Tradition and the Olympics
description: When the Boston Celtics were preparing for their championship season, their 13th in 20 years, a rookie was trying to beg off from Going wind sprints. What's the matter? Paul Silas asked. I've got cramps, the rookie explained. We've all got cramps, Silas snapped. The rookie did his wand sprints. And when another team might have begged off with cramps in the third overtime of their memorable tripleovertime game with the Phoenix Suns last Friday night and in the fourth quarter of Sunday's decisive game, the Boston Celtics won the National Basketball Association title. No longer do the Celtics dominate the N.B.A. as they did in winning 11 championships in 13 years. the last seven seasons, they have won only two titles. But when the Celtics have qualified for the final round, they invariably win. Of their 14 appearances in the final round, they won 13 times. Their only loss developed in 1958 the St. Louis Hawks after Bill Russell incurred a sprained ankle in the third game of the series. And in winning their last four championships, the Celtics won the final game on the road.

title: New Indictment Charges Coercion by Cunningham
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, indicted nearly two weeks ago in the alleged sale of a judgeship, was accused in a new indictment yesterday of threatening a Bronx weekly newspaper with financial retribution unless it silenced its criticism of two Bronx politicians.

title: Oriental Hotel Marks Its 100th Anniversary
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 7 (AP)The Oriental Hotel. one of the oldest in Asia and a haunt of the rich and famous, celebrated its 100th anniversay today.

title: Carter Appears Near Goal In Last 3 Primaries Today
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7on three fronts, Jimmy Carter delegates tomorrow to put him Barring unforeseen collapses appears likely to win enough within relatively easy hailing distance of the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Wilson and Bond St. in Jazz Fete With John Fischer's Interface
description: John Fischer's Interface, which performed at Sunrise Studio on Sunday during the weekend's Loft Jazz Celebration, has refined the often explosive free improvisational style of the 1960's into a rather more studied approach. In this respect, the group is reminiscent of some of the progressive jazz ensembles of earlier decades, particularly Lennie Tristano's ensembles and Dave Brubeck's Quartet.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to free Nelson G. Gross, the former New Jersey Republican state chairman, while he appeals for a new trial on charges of taking part in an illegal campaign financing scheme. The justices rejected Mr. Gross's application for a stay of a decision of the United States Circuit Court in Philadelphia denying him a new trial. He said he planned to appeal that decision to the High Court and asked that his prison term be stayed in the meantime.

title: A Mudd Report on Candidates Rejected by Cronkite Program
description: A fiveminute report on how political candidates stage events for the benefit of television coverage was rejected by the CBS Evening News last week, reportedly creating a rift between Walter Cronkite, the anchorman, and Roger Mudd, the correspondent.

title: Belmont Charts
description: ??? Monday, June 7. 32d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Colonels, Spirits Would Fold if Paid
description: The Kentucky Coronests and the Spirits of St. Louis are willing to bow out of the proposed merger between the American and National Basketball Associationsunder one condition. The four remaining A.B.A. teams must buy out the Colonels and the Spirits.

title: People and Business
description: Three topranking New York City officials were named yesterday by Mayor Beams to a special committee to work with representatives of the New York Stock Exchange for more effective cooperation between the city's government and the Big Board.

title: Chile Study Says Torture Goes On
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission has accused Chile's miitary Government of continuing arbitrary jailings, persecutions and torture while issuing decrees and statements to tranquilize or confuse world opinion.

title: MRS. CHARLES SMITH Jr.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 7 (UPI)Mrs. Charles H. Smith Jr., chairman of the hoard of the Knoxville Journal, died yesterday at her home. She was 61 years old and had been in declining health since December. She was the widow of the former president and publisher of The Journal.

title: V1OLATIONSCHARGED TO 15 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The Health Department has announced the names of 15 food establishments operating in violation of the health code at the time of a first inspection, and the names of 30 establishments and ther disposition after a final inspection. They are as follows:

title: British Economic Actions And Credit Buoy Pound
description: LONDON, June 7The battered British pound staged strong recovery today, buoyed by domestic economic developIlion as well as by a $5.3 billion international line of credit.

title: Students in Bronxville Give Howard Hughes a Will (81 in Fact) of Their Own
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.Well, 81 last wills and testamentsall signed Howard Hughes, all purporting to be the one true willhave now been filed here at St. Joseph School.

title: For Breathtaking Golf Finishes, Women Are Upstaging the Men
description: The Professional Golfers Association is staging some exciting tournaments these days with playoffs two weeks in a row deciding the winners at Jack Nicklaus's Memorial tournament at Dublin, Ohio, and at the Bicentennial Classic at Whitemarsh, Pa. But the women are way ahead of the men in exciting finales lately. The Ladies Professional Golf Association has played five consecutive tournaments that went down to the last green to determine the winner.

title: Where Women Are Credit Cards
description: WINTHROP, Mass.The saga of Elizabeth Ray, who made headlines by telling all about her affair with Representative Wayne Hays, is more than simply the story of an aging man and an available woman. It has much to do with power and its uses, and it may really say more about the role of women in the American power structure than the reports of the various commissions on the status of women.

title: SALT Violations
description: For more than a year conservative critics of the strategic arms limitations talks (SALT II) with Moscow have sought to discourage agreement by charging that the Soviets had been violating the 1972 SALT I treaty in order to gain military advantage over the United States. These charges have been rejected not only by President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger, but by former Defense Secretary James Schlesinger.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 (Cunard). Left Southampton June 3; due a A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Books of The Times
description: Of Brook Farm, Nathaniel Hawthorne made The Blithedale Romance. Of The Village Voice, Ellen Frankfort has made a kind of Gay Talese with feminist bells on. The difference is not only between what each expected, reasonably or unreasonably, from utopian enterprises; it has to do as well with artfulness, distance, an organizing perception, naivet. Writing a novel is a good cure for naivet because, in making your characters plausible to the reader, you are obliged to understand them yourself. Miss Frankfort, who has the ability, should have written a novel.

title: Udall Visits Garfield's Horne and Hopes To Follow Ohioan to the White House
description: CLEVELAND, June 7The final event on Representative Morris K. Udall's schedule yesterday took him to the back porch of a Victorian house in Mentor, a 30minute drive from here. The house was Lawndale, the home of James A. Garfield, the last man to go to the White House from the House of Representaives.

title: Bomb Suspect Chanzes Plea
description: MADISON, Wis., June 7 (AP) The Federal trial of David S. Fine, charged in a fatal bombing at the University of Wisconsin in 1970, was postponed today after prosecution and defense lawyers said they had reached a plea bargaining agreement over the weekend. Proceedings for a change in plea are to begin her tomorrow.

title: Pakistani Duststorm Kills 11
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, June 7 (Reuters)At least 11 persons were killed and several others injured when a duststorm struck the Sahiwal and Lyallpur districts of Punjab Province yesterday, newspapers here reported today.

title: A World Series of Tennis Announced
description: A new men's tennis tournament with a first prize of $75,000 was announced yesterday. It will match the winners of the world's premier tournaments. Called the PepsiCola World Series, the tournament is scheduled July 9 at the Myrtle Beach Tennis Club in South Carolina, and will be nationally televised by CBS. Three of the four contestants have been selected on the basis of their 1975 triumph in the following tournaments: Arthur Ashe, Wimbledon; Manuel Orantes, United States Open and Bjorn Borg, French Open. The fourth player for this year only, will be the 1976 Wimbledon champion, who will be crowned July 3. If any of the above three also wins this year's Wimbledon title, the fourth player will be the 1975 Italian champion, Raul Ramirez. The tournament's runnerup will get $40,000. Third and fourth places will be worth $20,000 and $15,000.

title: The Southern Connection
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The decision of the Democratic Party on whether to nominate Jimmy Carter goes to the fundamental problem of the South's political relationship with the rest of the nation.

title: MARY K. KEELEY
description: Mary K. Keeley, a former field secretary of conferences and institutes of the Child Welfare League of America, died Saturday in St. Paul, Minn., where she had moved last year after retiring from the staff of Travelers AidInternational Social Service of America. She was 65 years old. Miss Keeley was a gradute of St. Teresa's College in Winona, Minn., and did graduate work at the University of Minnesota and at Columbia University, where she received a master's degree in social work. A sister, Mrs. Leo B. Faricy, survives.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER NASSAU NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Morgan of the Cincinnati Reds leads all players in the first week of balloting for the National League AllStar team that will oppose the American League AllStars in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium on Tuesday night, July 13. Morgan, the league's most valuable player last season, has received 54,133 votes in the balloting that will continue through July 4. His closest competitor for the starting secondbase job is Dave Cash of Philadelphia, with 30,322 votes.

title: Value of Ford Incumbehoy Eliminated, Strauss Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that President Ford's conduct of the Presidency had been abominable and had eliminated the value of incumbency to the Ford campaign.

description: Money

title: Helen Hayes Honored by Boston Repertory
description: BOSTON, June 7When Helen Hayes walked onto the stage of the Shubert Theater here last night, it was as if someone had turned up a rheostat.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 7After six years of urging by the State Legislature, the rents on more than 1,000 stateowned homes occupied by physicians and other staff members at state institutions will probably be raised for the first time since 1944.

title: Villella Quits Pal Joey Over Differences
description: Edward Villella resigned yesterday from the cast of Pal Joey, the Rodgers and Hart musical in which he was to have attempted his first major Broadway role Mr. Villella, who has long been a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, said he was leaving Pal Joey because of artistic differences with the show's management.

title: Opposition Party in South Korea Beset by Bitter Factional Disputes
description: SEOUL. South Korea, June 2 South Korea's New Democratis Partythe only remaining major political opposition to the Government of President Park Chung Heeis severely split and consumed these days with bitter internal factional disputes.

title: Nerves and Calm on a Lebanese Front
description: RUESSAT SOFAR, Lebanon, June 7A charred Syrian T62 tank slumps by the roadside 12 miles east of Beirut, its barrel pointed toward Damascus.

title: Padres Subdue Mets, 51
description: SAN DIEGO, June 7  A fielding error that led to two unearned runs marred a fine pitching performance by Craig Swan of the Mets and gave the Padres a 51 victory tonight.

title: Chess:
description: I suppose these players believe that, if they are going to put in the kind of demanding precise calculation involved in combination, they want to be rewarded by a gross and obvious result. That's very natural, but it is also bound to lead to their missing some golden opportunities.

title: CHAPTER XI SOUGHT BY EASTERN FREIGHT
description: Eastern Freight Ways, which on April 28, consented to be adjudicated a bankrupt, yesterday filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Potvin Wins Top Award For Defense
description: MONTREAL, June 7Tomorrow will be Bobby Orr's day: today was Denis Potvin.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The General Motors assembly plant in Linden, N. J., recalled 1,000 workers yesterday and hired another 1.000. The work was made possible because the company had increased its production schedule. It was on Jan. 4, 1974, when the 1,000 recalled workers on the second shift the plait were laid off because of the energy crisis and the national slump in car sales. Yesterday the parking lots at the plant were jammed, the first time they have been so full since 1974.

title: Bobby Hackett, the Cornetist, Dies at 61
description: Bobby Hackett, the cornetist whose mellow tone and graceful style made him a favorite of both jazz and pop music audiences died yesterday after a heart attack at his home in West Chatham, Mass. He was 61 years old.

title: Death Sought for Mercenaries in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 7Government investigators have asked for the death penalty for two Americans and 11 other prisoners who are to be tried on charges of having fought as mercenaries in the Angolan civil war.

title: Brynner to Tour 7 States in King and I
description: Twentyfive years after he won fame in The King and I Yul Brynner will return to his role of the monarch in an anniversary production of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical. In real life, Mr. Brynner says, I am now the age [55] the king is in the musical.

title: Bridge:
description: On most deals the defenders have one considerable advantage: They know much more about the declarer's hand than he knows about theirs.

title: Lefkowitz Opinion Asked In CityState Fiscal Feud
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board has decided to seek a legal opinion from Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz into one of the touchier differences between Governor Carey and Mayor Beame in the fiscal crisis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In recent editorials, The Times has joined the growing ranks of Supreme Court watchers who express misgivings over a shrinking Constitution and a further diminution of individual rights. Critics perceive a determined effort to limit access to the Federal courts. It is difficult to establish that such an effort is under way, although the Chief Justice has affirmed the need to insure a major role for the state courts. In part, recent decisions may have prompted legislative initiatives to protect such personal rights as privacy. A notable example is the Bill of Rights Procedures Act, which is being considered by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Dutchess Sheriff Accused Of Selling Captured Guns
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7Lawyers for the State Commission of Investigation charged today that the Dutchess County Sheriff had sold seized pistols that legally should have been destroyed and had intervened in drunkendriving arrests. Deputy sheriffs. they charged, sold weapons to local gun dealers.

title: Ford, Stumping in Ohio, Warns G.O.P. Of a Debacle if Reagan Is Nominated
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 7 President Ford traveled the length of Ohio today raising the specter of 1964.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: 34 More Cadets at West Point Are Facing Cheating Charges
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7An internal review panel charged 34 West Point cadets today with cheating bringing to 164 the number facing appeal boards of officers in the honor code investigation at the United States Military Academy.

title: Music: Community Group
description: The New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra, despite being cursed with a name that sounds like something a bureaucrat invented at the end of a hard day, has developed into an excellent young community group. The NYCHASO, to be quick about an identification, gave a concert on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall that marked its fifth season of existence. The orchestra, according to the program notes, is made up of players from housing projects and music schools.

title: $53 BILLION IN AID PROVIDED BRITAIN TO BOLSTER POUND
description: WASHINGTON. June 7The United States joined with other industrialized countries today to provide a $5.3 billion standby line of shortterm credit for Britain to bolster the beleaguered pound. The United States put up $2 billion of the total.

title: Brooklyn to Get Plant Designed To Produce Steel From Refuse
description: New York City will become the site for what its promoters describe as the world's first plant to produce highquality commercial steel from metal scrap recovered from incinerated municipal refuse.

title: Robert S. Rankin Dies at 76; Member of U.S. Rights Panel
description: DURHAM, N. C., June 7 (UPI) Dr. Robert Stanley Rankin, a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, died Friday night at a Duke Hospital. The cause of death was not disclosed. He was 76 years old.

title: Capital Outlay Plans In 76 Up Only a Bit
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Business plans to invest in plant and equipment in 1976 have been revised upward only very slightly since earlier in the year despite the vigor of the recovery in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRITISH EXPERTS SEE U.S HOUSING
description: NEWARK, June 7Patrick Jackson, an official of Britain's Department of the EnvironIment, stood in the oncetroubled Stella Wright public housing project here and said that the renovations he had just seen were very impressiveit obviously was very severely distressed here.

title: Events Today
description: POULENC'S THE HUMAN VOICE, solo opera, Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, 7:30.

title: Italians Try to Salvage Art Damaged in Quake
description: UDINE, Italy, June 7Inside the Church of San Francesco here, dozens of brightly colored lifesize statues of saints stand in groups along the walls, somber woodcarved sculptures of Jesus on the cross lie in orderly rows, paintings stripped from chapel walls stretch across the floor, marble cherubs, silver crucifixes and carvedstone altar pieces fill the cavernous room.

title: BRITISH EXPERTS SEE U.S. HOUSING
description: NEWARK, June 7Patrick Jackson, an official of Britain's Department of the Environment, stood in the oncetroubled Stella Wright publichousing project here and said that the renovations he had just seen were very impressiveit obviously was very severely distressed here.

title: Jacob Ark, Retired Judge Of New York State Court
description: ROCHESTER, June 7 (AP)Jacob Ark, a retired State Supreme Court justice, died last night in Genesee Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Ground Is Broken For Unit to Service Trains to Buffalo
description: Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, broke ground yesterday at Rensselaer, N.Y., for a $14.8 million maintenance facility for the new highspeed turbinepowered trains to go into service this year on the New YorkAlbanyBuffalo run.

title: Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The keynote session this morning of the annual convention of the American Advertising Federation was a rousing testimonial to the free enterprise system.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Triple Pays $9,146
description: A disqualification that moved a 151 shot into second place and a 311 shot to third helped send the triple soaring to $9,146 for $2 yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ExConvict Sought as Ted Gross Killer
description: The manager of the Bronx bowling alleys that figured in the kickback charges that sent Ted Gross to prison was sought by the police yesterday as his killer.

title: JOB HEARINGS WON FOR U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: Three and a half million Federal civilian employees became entitled yesterday for the first time to hearings on whether they should be eligible to receive unemployment benefits after loss of jobs, according to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Bill to Seal Arrest Data Gains in Albany
description: ALBANY. June 7The State ??? passed a bill today calling for the sealing of arrest records for persons accused and then cleared of crimes. enforcement agency that could show that the interests of justice so require.

title: GAF Takes Over WNCN, Names General Manager
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday officially assumed ownership of classicalmusic station WNCNFM and, on completing the $2.2 million purchase from the. Starr Broadcasting Group, announced that Robert E. Richer had been hired as general manager.

title: Tammany Lives On in a Queens Club
description: In southeastern Queens, where potholes become wading pools after a heavy rain, there is a Democratic clubhouse that still believes in Tammany Hall. The club's 54yearold district leader, George A. McCracken, when called a machine politician recently, thrust out his heavy jaw, squared his powerful shoulders and retorted:

title: Police Raid Hotel Room, Rescue Kidnap Victim and Capture 2
description: The 22yearold son of White Plains lawyer was res ued yesterday afternoon in west Side hotel where 10,000 ranspm was recovered ad two alleged kidnappers were apprehended, the police eported.

title: Carter Appears Near Goal In Last 3 Primaries Today
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7Barring unforeseen collapses on three fronts, Jimmy Carter appears likely to win enough delegates tomorrow to put him within relatively easy hailing distance of the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 8, 1976

title: POWER LOSS TRAPS 6,000 L.I.R.R. RIDERS
description: A power failure at the end of the morning commuter rush hour halted traffic on Long Island Rail Road tracks into and out of Pennsylvania Station yesterday morning for 75 minutes and stalled six trains and 6,000 people in tunnels under the East River.

title: Albert Is Hailed in House; Drive for Key Posts Is On
description: WASHINGTON, June 7As the House of Representatives paid tribute today to its Speaker, Carl Albert of Oklahoma, who is retiring, a number of Democrats began openly campaigning for their party's top leadership posts in the 95th Congress that convenes in January.

title: WALDHEIM VOICES CONCERN ON CYPRUS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7The fate of thousands of Greek Cypriots in areas occupied by Turkish forces in northern Cyprus has become matter of serious concern, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim warned in a report today to the Security Council.

title: Soybean and Grain Prices Rise; Farmers Withhold Their Crops
description: To the surprise of many floor traders, soybean and grain prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans for July delivery jumped more than 18 cents to close at $6.03 a bushel. Corn for July delivery ended at $3.06, up 9 cents.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Demonstrators in San Francisco yesterday urging a yes vote on Proposition 15, which would permit future nuclear power plant operation in California only under very stringent conditions.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Exam In Which Blacks Scored Low
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Supreme Court ruled today, 7 to 2, that a statute or other official act is not unconstitutional just because it places a substantially disproportionate burden on one race.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New Bond Issues

title: Summaries in Westehester Golf
description: John Dreyfus, Century, defeated Jack Dalrymple, Siwanoy, 1 up; Manny Doppelt, Brae Bum, defeated Mark Squires Jr., Silvermine, 2 and 1; William Dober, Birchwood, defeated Charles Hansen, Westchester Hills, 6 and 5; Peter Nisselson, Hampshire, defeated Ivan Meisner, Brae Burn, 7 and 6; Dave Muraskin, Fenway, defeated Marty Connelly, Wykagyt, 7 and 5; Michael Becker, Fenway, defeated Dick Rubin, Hampshire, 5 and 4; Mike Volpe, Tamarack, defeated Mike Dopeit, Brao Burn, 3 and 2; Dave Christie, Siwanoy, defeated Ken Suchy, Ardsley, 2 and 1.

title: High. Court Lets Nader Sue Airline for Overbooking Flight
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today that Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, could sue an airline that had bumped him from a flight because it had sold more tickets than it had seats.

title: Olympic Site Will Be Ready, Says Official
description: Victor C. Goldbloom, the former baby doctor responsible for delivering the Montreal Olympics, gave final assurances here yesterday that all was well.

title: Rickover Warns of a Shipyard Ripoff
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Adm. Hyman G. Rickover said today that the settlement of shipbuilders claims proposed by the Defense Department could turn into one of the biggest ripoffs in the history of the United States.

title: Special Jobless Pay Backed For Ford Victims of Imports
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Labor Department approved special unemployment benefits today for 22,300 workers at eight Ford Motor Company parts plants in Ohio and Michigan who lost their jobs because of increased competition from imported cars and parts.

title: $10,66 PRICE SET ON MAY POTATOES
description: The fair market value of the defaulted Maine potatoes for May delivery has been set at $10.66 a hundredweight, in Icluding delivery costs. This price was announced yesterday I by the New York Mercantile Exchange, whose chairman, Jai cob Stern, had appointed al threeman committee to set the price.

description: Dividends

title: 3 Rhodesia Whites Killed
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 17 (Reuters)A woman and her two young daughters have died in a landmine explosion, raising to five the number of white civilians killed in Rhodesia's guerrilla war in the last two days, security force headquarters announced here today. The blast was thought to have occurred near Chifinga, on Rhodesia's eastern border with Mozambique.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: LONDON

title: Students, Angry at Fair, Want $1 Back
description: Some of the 5,000 schoolchildren who last week paid to attend a musical hook fair in Central Park that did not deliver what it had promised have turned critic in angry letters to the producer.

title: Power Failure Affects 2,500 in North Bronx
description: A power failure affected more than 2,500 Consolidated Edison customers in the Woodlawn section of the North Bronx last night.

title: KUWAIT REDUCES PRICE FOR CRUDE
description: KUWAIT, June 7 (AP)Kuwait has reduced the price of crude oil by seven cents a barrel as of June 1 the Oil Min. istry Under Secretary, Mahmoud al Adassani, announced today:

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 7President Ford has expressed his determination to try to limit the power of the Federal courts to use busing as a tool to desegregate schools.

title: ANDERSON SEEKING A CITY U. ADVANCE
description: ALBANY, June 7The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, called this afternoon for the appropriation of a $24 million advance to reopen the bankrupt City University immediately.

title: 91 VIETNAMESE ASK THAIS FOR ASYLUM
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 7 (Reuters)  Ninetyone South Vietnamese refugees, including two men and a woman who were shot and seriously wounded as they fled their country, sought asylum today after landing in a fishing boat in southern Thailand, the police said.

title: $568 AirConditioners Are Setting a Consumer Trend in the Soviet
description: BAKU, U.S.S.R. The consumerism that has begun to captivate the Soviet Union now has a new monument: a huge, highly automated Japanesedesigned factory that makes nothing but home airconditioners.

title: Chicago Suburbs to House 400 Families in Accord
description: CHICAGO, June 7 (UPI)A oneyear trial program to place 400 families needing public housing outside the inner city and into apartments in Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: 2 Women Win Day in Court In Cases Involving Sex Bias
description: A Federal Appellate court ordered an upstate District Court yesterday to hear the case of two women who had charged that they had been discriminated against because of sex and been denied posts, respectively, as a college teacher and head of a surgical team.

title: New Indictment Charges Coercion by Cunningham
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, indicted nearly two weeks ago in the alleged sale of a judgeship, was accused in a new indictment yesterday of threatening a Bronx weekly newspaper with financial retribution unless it silenced its criticism of two Bronx politicians.

title: BACKING SOUGHT ON BANK REFORM
description: BOSTON, June 7Banking regulators from seven Northeastern states agreed today to seek approval from Federal authorities in Washington to undertake financial reforms on a regmnal basis.

title: 900,000 Expected to Vote in Jersey Primary Today
description: TRENTON, June 7Officials here estimate that 900,000 of New Jersey's 3.5 million registered voters will cast ballots tomorrow in the primary elections for President, a United States senator and 15 members of the House of Representatives.

title: Soviet Official Meets With Tito On Parley for European Reds
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia June 7an apparent effort to break a twoyear deadlock delaying a conference of European Communist parties, a senior Soviet negotiator conferred with President Tito of Yugoslavia today on problems facing the international workers movement.

title: Helping New York
description: Blanche Leventhal stands in the doorway of the waiting room at Manhattan Family Court surveying the faces of the waiting parents. She is trying to decide which one to approach.

title: Indians Lose Despite Triple Play
description: Butch Wynegar of the Minnesota Twins hit into a triple play to snuff out a fifthinning Twins rally last night, but that didn't stop the rookie from becoming a bit of a hero in a 72 victory over the Indians in Cleveland. Wypegat came right back to hit a tworun homer in the eighth and Craig Kusick followed with another home run, which helped send Cleveland to its fifth defeat in the last six games.

title: Surgery Performed On Hundley of Cubs
description: CHICAGO, June 7 (AP)Randy Hundley, catcher for the Chicago Cubs, had a disk removed and the two connecting vertebrae fused in his neck during an operation today at Northwestern Memorial Hospital.

title: Two Safe in Plane Crash
description: NEW HAVEN, Vt. June 7 (AP)An Air Force FB111 jet crashed here today while returning to the Air Force base at Plattsburgh, N.Y., after a training mission, a base spokesman said. Both crewmen aboard parachuted to safety. The crew men were identified as Capts. Raymond T. Wilson of Ogden, Utah, and of Highland Park, III. Both are 33 years old.

title: GOLDIN FINDS CITY A DAYCARE VICTIM
description: Auditors for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charge that New York City has agreed to high, rents for daycare centers it leases directly, without relation to cost, resulting in excessive profits to developers.

title: The Tall Men: Life Grows Complicated Away From Arenas
description: The long playing season ended officially Sunday, for the tall and the short in the National Basketball Association. But for the tall men, those hovering round 7 feet, there is a season that never ends: when they look back unexpectedly and find a short man measuring himself up against them. It happens to Kareem AbdulJabbar, Tom Boerwinkle, George Johnson and Luke Witte among others.

title: VIETNAMESE DENY REPORT ON P.O.W.'S
description: PARIS, June 7 (UPI) No American prisoners of war are still alive in Vietnam, North Vietnam said today, and any claim to the contrary is erroneous.

title: Swine Flu False Alarm?
description: President Ford may not know it; but with each passing day the Federal Government's $135 million emergency swine flu immunization program appears less necessary and more unwise.

title: Udall Is Said to View Ohio Primary As a Sign of CarterChurch Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona is said to be wondering whether he is running in the Ohio primary against the concerted force of a Carter  Church ticket. It was Senator Frank Church of Idaho, a latecomer to the Democratic primary campaign, who urged Mr. Udall to drop out of the race after Mr. Udall failed to win the South Dakota primary last week.

title: Nevada Pupfish Have Their Day in Court and Win
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) The oneinch pupfish, which has battled nature to survive 110,000 years in a Nevada cavern, won a unanimous Supreme Court ruling today that assures its water will not be drawn away.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: Tuesday, June 8, 1978

title: Zoos Using Birth Control to Stop Overpopulation of Their Big Cats
description: BROOKFIELD, Ill., June 5 Chuma, one of the Brookfield Zoo's most productive mothers, was lolling in her cage, unaware that she represents yet another ecological paradox.

title: SPECIALTY STEELS WILL FACE QUOTAS
description: President Ford announced yesterday the signing of documents that will lead to the, imposition of quotas on imports of specialty steels.

title: Pound Rally Falters
description: The pound rose in London by 4 cents to $1.80 before closing at $1.77. The 10nation credit that spurred the increase was seen as buying time for Britain's economy but doing nothing for its underlying problems: Page 53.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Jackie Wilson, Stricken While Singing, Wins Suit
description: CAMDEN. N.J., June 8 (AP)A Camden County probate judge approved a settlement today between an insurance company and the rock singer Jackie Wilson, who suffered a severe heart attack while performing.

title: Canadian Loan to Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, June 8 (Reuters)  The Peruvian Governemnt said yesterday that Canada had agreed to lend Peru $300 million to finance several development projects.

title: Closeup Pictures of Mars Are Expected on TV July 4
description: The first closeup pictures the world has ever seen of the surface of Mars are scheduled to be shown to millions of television viewers on July 4. minutes after the Viking landing unit is to touch down on the planet's surface.

title: CITY SETS CHANGE IN SCHOOL ZONING
description: New zoning plans for Bronx and Manhattan high schoolsintended to meet the needs created by a shifting population and, wherever feasible, to improve school integrationwere announced yesterday by School Chancellor. Irving Anker.

title: Dollar Advances in Zurich
description: BRUSSELS, June 8 (UPI)The dollar rose in Zurich today to 2.4960 francs from Friday's close of 2.4525its best showing in three weeks and well above last week's low of 2.3815.

title: DEMOCRATS DROP PLANS FOR PICNIC
description: Undaunted by the usual hazards of red ants and rain, a deluxe $125aplasticplate picnic sponsored by the Democratic State Committee on the lawn of Gracie Mansion scheduled for next Monday, foundered yesterday on another hazardReoublicans.

title: Democrats Plan to Aid City University Is Said to Gain
description: ALBANY, June 3The floor leader for the City University rescue plan backed by the State Assembly's Democrats said today that the Senate's Republican majority was moving closer to agreement with his plan. But at least publicly, the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, and other ranking Republican Senators insisted that they were still opposed to the Democratic plan.

title: Osteopath Is Booked in 10 Baby Deaths on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP)An osteopathic physician convicted of seconddegree murder 16 years ago has been booked for investigation of murder in the deaths of 10 infants at his cutrate medical clinic.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 8  The state auditor's office an arm of the Legislature said today in a report on welfare spending that millions of dollars had been kept in nonintetestbearing bank accounts and that the state had been losing $600,000 or so a year in interest.

title: Negotiations Will Resume In Rubber Plant Strike
description: WASHINGTON. June 8 (AP) Two days of exploratory talks in the sevenweek rubber industry strike were very productive and resulted in an agreement to resume full negotiations in Cleveland tomorrow, James F. Scearce, chief Federal mediator, said today.

title: JAMES NUGENT, 62, RETIRED REPORTER
description: James Nugent, a retired police and courtroom reporter for (The Associated Press, died yesterday at the Rosary Hill Home hospital in Hawthorne, N.Y., at the age of 62. He was a resident of Queens Village, Queens, and had reported from the Bronx for nearly 40 years.

title: 10Nation Aid Seen Buying Time, Not Ending Problems
description: LONDON, June 8The pound jumped 4 cents this morning to $1.80 here, following yesterday's announcement of a record $5.3 billion standby credit. However, it later fell back and closed at $1.77.

title: Legalization of Parties Due in Madrid
description: MADRID, June 8The approval by a reluctant and doubtful Parliament of the first free political parties since the end of the Civil War in 1939 was expected tomorrow after a lastditch fight by followers of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

title: Osteopath Is Booked in 10 Baby Deaths on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES. June 8 (AP)An osteopathic physician convicted of seconddegree murder 16 years ago has been booked for investigation of murder in the deaths of 10 infants at his cutrate medical clinic.

title: Swords Into Shares
description: THIS COUNTRY'S foreign militarysales program has been widely abused and little understood. Much of the abuse derives from a mythology about arms sales, rooted in the merchants of death exposs of the 1920's and 1930's. The mythology is worth examining and analyzing.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CONVEYOR (ACL). Helsinki June 19; sails from Elizabeth. N. J.

title: Knicks Pick 68 Shelton; Player Has A.B.A. Pact
description: The Knicks, who illegally signed George McGinnis last summer and paid for it yesterday by giving up their firstround selection in the National Basketball Association college draft, may have involved themselves in another legal entanglement.

title: Cosmos 824 Launched
description: MOSCOW, June 8 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched another unmanned earth satellite. No. 824, in its Cosmos series to continue the study of outer space. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

title: TERRORISTS LINKED TO CHICAGO BLASTS
description: CHICAGO. June 8The police here blamed Puerto Rican terrorists today for four bombings that shook the downtown section and injured five persons last night.

title: Large Oil Terminal Is Opened in China
description: China has announcea the opening of a large new oil terminal in the Manchurian port of Dairen, further strengthening its position as a petroleum exporter to Far Eastern and other Asian markets.

title: Tiffany Attains Record On Sales and Earnings
description: Tiffany & Company, which derives about 75 percent of salcs from jewelry sold at its main store on Fifth Avenue and five other branches, attained record sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended April 30, according to yesterday's report.

title: Plans to Return to TeachingPolicy Dispute Denied
description: WASHINGTON. June 8Thomas E. Kauper, who has headed the Justice Departmerit's antitrust division since 1972, will leave that job at the end of July.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Beirut was in a state of siege with continued shelling and fighting in the Moslem neighborhoods of the Lebanese capital. Western diplomats reported more Syrian troops, armor and artillery entering the country. President Hafez alAssad seems to have withheld an allout attack. A high level delegation representing Syria, Libya, Algeria and the Palestine guerrilla movement arrived in Beirut on a mission to defuse the crisis between Syrian and Palestinian forces. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Decency and Courage Amid Lebanese Horror
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6There are no prisoners in the Lebanese civil war. A prisoner is put to deathoften slowly. Many have been mutilated before or after death.

title: Nixon's Aides Held To Have Weighed Drugging Columnist
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) The Nixon White House was considering a plan in March 1972, to discredit Jack Anderson, the columnist, by drugging him so he would appear incoherent in a public appearance, a Senate committee renorted today.

title: Athletes to Aid Drive On Multiple Sclerosis
description: Jack Nicklaus, Tom Seaver, Hank Aaron and other figures From the world of sports have joined this year's fundraising drive of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Ruling Returning Abused Child To Parents Reversed on Appeal
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn, in an opinion critical of a Family Court judge on Staten Island, yesterday reversed his decision to return a sick and battered 8monthold child to his parents and ordered a new hearing before another Family Court judge.

title: GENE WAYNE FENTON
description: Gene Wayne Fenton of Incline Village, Nev., a former security analyst for Oppenheimer & Co., Inc., New York, died June I of acute myelogenous leukemia in the University of California Medical Center, San Francisco. His age was 46.

title: Many in Naples, Fearful and Confused, Will Cast Votes Negatively
description: NAPLES, June 4I've always voted for the Christian Democrats, but they're going to the dogs, said Anna Maria Florida as her three children tugged at her skirts. There is so much disorder and confusion, and the police are not efficient any more. We're outsloe the law now, we're outside God's will.

title: Jackson Sounding As if He'd Accept 2d Spot to Carter
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, who has dropped his active Presidential candidacy, sounded like a VicePresidential contender last night as he met with a group of New York Democratic National Convention delegates pledged to support him.

title: Soviet General Dead at 57
description: MOSCOW, June 8 (Reuters) Lieut. Gen. Arkady Shelepin, a deputy head of the Soviet armed forces chief political board, died Saturday after a long illness, the Defense Ministry announced today. General Shelepin, 57 years old, was appointed to the chief political board in August. The board is concerned with the political education of Soviet troops.

title: A.T. &T. Sued by 12 Reporters On Subpoena of Phone Records
description: WASHINGTON. June 8 (AP) Twelve reporters and four organizations asked a Federal court today to order American Telephone and Telegraph Company to inform newsmen when their phone records were subpoenaed by the Government.

title: COURT GIVES LIFE TO RURAL SCHOOL
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. June 8 (AP)A small high school in the Nevada desert has been brought back to life by a court ruling that puts greater emphasis on the closeness between school and home than budget figures.

title: Books of The Times
description: I'm tired of the detective as catalyst, he who moves without being moved. I remember a film called Bullitt, I believe, in which Steve McQueen changed his expression only once, to smile at a woman. During the rest of the hour and a half of the movie, his face had that look people get when they ride in an elevator. While it is not true of all American suspense novels, it seems to me that, in too many of them, the detective is laconic and detached, an outsider who brings no mystery of his own to the mystery to be solved, no personal intimacy to the intimacy of murder.

title: Dance: Taylor Company in 3 Romps
description: Paul Taylor no longer dances, but his ideas do in the three score and ten works that he has created since the start of his career. His company presents the dances as if they were special offerings for dour delectation, and they are. They are full of verve and life with an occasional glimpse into the darker corners of our lives. The company opened its twoweek season at the Billy Rose Theater last night with a glittering selection from repertory.

title: U.S. IS CONCERNED
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The United States, unable to bring any influence on the warring parties in Lebanon to halt the, fighting, expressed concern again today that the steppedup conflict might touch off a wider war.

title: U.S. IS CONCERNED
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The United States, unable to bring any influence on the warring parties in Lebanon to halt the fighting, expressed concern again today that the steppedup conflict might touch off a wider war.

title: Jersey Ballots Confuse Voters, Delaying Compilation of Returns
description: The complexity and irregularity of the New Jersey priMary ballot caused so much confusion among voters and tabulators last night that returns from important delegate contests were delayed for hours.

title: Funeral Services Today For Elizabeth Rethberg. 81
description: Funeral services will be held today for one of the Metropolitan Opera's leading stars, Elisabeth Rethherg.

title: PROTESTERS OCCUPY STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: A group of protesters demonstrating against the cutoff of educational benefits under the Bill barricaded themselves inside the Statue of Liberty last evening. There was no indication how long they planned to occupy the monument.

title: in Memoriam
description: KARPJoseph. After thirteen years, stilt sorely missed.

title: Katharine McBride
description: Katharine McBride  scholar, scientist, teacher and expert administrator never viewed the mission of a women's college in particularly feminist terms. The reason undoubtedly was that she demanded for men and women equality of effort as well as of opportunity. Her sense of quality and of equality permitted no artificial academic distinction to be made between men and women.
