title: FIRST ARAB UNITS ARRIVE IN LEBANON TO OVERSEE TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10The first units of a symbolic peacekeeping force that the Arab League has decided to send to Lebanon arrived today as quiet was reported from most or the fighting fronts around the country.

title: RHODESIAN REPORTS ZAMBIABASED MOVE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 10 (AP)  Black nationalist guerrillas have entered Rhodesia from neighboring Zambia and opened a second front in their fight against the white minority Government here, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Underwater Photos Taken in Loch Ness Show Other Camera
description: DRUMNADROCHIT, Scotland. June 10Charles W. Wyckoff, photographic coordinator of the Loch Ness expedition of the Academy of Applied: Science and The New York. Times, made a round trip to London yesterday to have eight; reels of 16millimeter color film. processed.

title: Bridge
description: Until recently, the problem of slow play in tournaments as been an insoluble one. But this year the Greater New York Bridge Association, giving a lead to the national body, has pioneered the use of effective timing devices that allow players to be aware of the time available to them. They can adjust their speed accordingly, and may be subject to penalties if they fail to do so.

title: Eager Foreman Tilts at Skyscrapers
description: After shadowboxing in a limousine and sparring on the Avenue of the Americas, George Foreman stopped pulling punches at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

title: Moynihan Enters U.S. Senate Race
description: Daniel P. Moynihan announced his candidacy for United States Senator from New York yesterday, putting on display his considerable support in labor circles and explaining at length the statement he made last year that it would he dishonorable for him to seek political office.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ANGOLANS ASK DEATH FOR MERCENARIES: Demonstrators in Luanda on Wednesday demanded the death penalty for 13 mercenaries captured by Popular Movement forces during the recent civil war. The prisoners, who will go on trial today, are nine Britons, one ??? man, one Argentine and two Americans.

title: Carey Bill Would Make Cities Issue Data Before Selling Notes
description: ALBANY, June 10Governor Carey today asked the legislature to require all local governments in the state to adhere to uniform standards of financial disclosure before issuing bonds or notes.

title: ACTORS MOVE IN AT42DST. THEATER
description: Off Off Broadway actors toppled signs proclaiming live Burlesque Theater at 416 West 42d Street as they celebrated their takeover of the building.

title: Tokenism or Symbolic Achievement?
description: In a fair and just society this history of black men at Amherst would be unnecessary. Thus wrote Harold Wade Jr. one of the bright young men of the John Lindsay administration as he finished this work in June 1974. Then he went off for a brief holiday in the Caribbean, where, on the eve of his 26th birthday, he drowned, cutting short what his colleagues believe would have been a brilliant career.

title: Albany Legislators Approve a Package To Save the H.F.A.
description: ALBANY, June 10  In the face of still another fiscal deadline, the Legislature approved a complicated group of bills tonight that cleared the way for Federal assistance to rescue the state Housing Finance Agency and help New York City meet its cash needs later in the year.

title: Belfast Army Post Raided
description: BELFAST. Northern Ireland June 10 (UPI)  Gunman believed to have been members of the Irish Republican Army attacked a British Army camp on Belfast's outskirts today. There was a brisk exchange of fire but no casualties were reported.

title: Lockheed and 24 Banks Reach Accord on New Financing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today an understanding with its 24 lending banks on a new plan for overhauling the financial structure of the heavilyindebted aerospace company.

title: How to Get There
description: Bard College is 99 miles north of Manhattan in AnnandaleonHudson, N. Y.

title: Children Open Courtyard as Memorial to Classmate
description: This week 30 eighth graders at the Little Red School House in Greenwich Village opened a redesigned courtyard they built as a memorial to a classmate who died last year at the age of 13 from bone cancer in his left leg.

title: Chileans Ponder the Effect, If Any, of Kissinger Visit
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10Up to the hour of his airport departure for Mexico today, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had seen large, patient crowds waiting outside his hotel and lining the streets as he drove to and from the general assembly of the Organization of American States.

title: Long Poem By Dickey Due in Fall
description: IN THE years between 1960 and 1970 James Dickey carved himself a substantial niche as a poet, publishing seven volumes of poetry, and collecting all sorts of prizes: a National Book Award and a Guggenheim Fellowship among others. Then in 1970 came a first novel, Deliverance, a powerful violent work about men fighting themselves and nature on a threeday canoe trip down a wild stretch of river. Deliverance received good reviews, was a best seller and became a financially successful movie, for which Mr. Dickey wrote the screenplay and in which he had a small role.

title: Right of Public Employee, To Job Limited by Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Supreme Court found on a 5to4 vote today that the Constitution gives state and public employees only limited protection against being summarily dismissed from their jobs, even when the employer? reasons for the dismissal are incorrect.

title: Electronic Market Test Urged
description: A toplevel committee of Wall Street brokers, planning for an automated stock market, proposed yesterday that an electronic order system they advocate be tested for effectiveness. But other industry sources maintained that, if implemented as proposed, the system could cut sharply into the income of New York Stock Exchange trading floor specialists.

title: Business Trends
description: WASHINGTONFor years the Government Employees Insurance Company was a success story. Now, with losses of more than $150 million since Jan, 1, 1975, it is fighting for survival.

title: Open Interest
description: In contract Wednesday

title: Restaurants
description: DI ANNI, at 1122 First Avenue near 62d Street, goes in for what they call cuisine historique. dishes based on recipes ranging across 1,800 years. Beginning in ancient Rome with Chicken With Jupiter's Acornshalf a boned fowl roasted with cream and walnuts, which Pliny credits with magical propertiesthe historical menu winds up only yesterday in findesicle Paris with ToulouseLautrec's recipe for roast leg of lambGigot d'Auvergne, with herbs and pears poached in crme de menthe. Pliny comes at $6.50, Lautrec at $7.50.

title: Armco and Inland Join Price Rises; Exxon in Discounts
description: The Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth largest steel producer and the Inland Steel Corporation, the sixth largest, yesterday joined other leading companies yesterday in raising prices. The increases of both are effective July 16. The base price for Armco's carbon and highstrength steel plates will rise $25 a ton. Alloy steel will go up $17 a ton. Rod and wire products are increasing an average of 7 to 8 percent, or about $25 a ton.

title: Anne Perlo Married To Michael A. Levine
description: The marriage of Anne Barbara Perlo to Michael A. Levine, a vice president of the Consumer Services Group of Citibank, took place at the Plaza Hotel last evening Rabbi Ephraim Kolatch performed the ceremony.

title: SENATORS TO LOOK AT ACADEMY CASE
description: A subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee announced yesterday that it would begin hearings later this month in Washington on the operation and possible abuse of the West Point honor code.

title: Carter Adviser in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 10 (AP)Prof. Jerome Alan Cohen of Harvard University, an advisor to Jimmy Carter, arrived here today to confer with Kim Dae lung, a former presidential candidate here, about human rights in South Korea. Mr. Kim has been under detention since his arrest in March with 10 political and religious leaders who had joined in a ??? ??? demanding full democracy and the resignation of President park Chung Hee.

title: Matlack Shuts Out Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, June 10The reluctant offense of the Mets, dormant the previous three nights, awoke tonight against the Padres and led New York to a 60 victory over San Diego.

title: Dividends Announced
description: IRREGULAR

title: Troop Movements by Iraq Stir Concern in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS. Syria, June 10 The Syrian Government announced today that it was obliged to take urgent and appropriate measures to counter a reported buildup of Iraqi military forces near the SyrianIrani border.

title: McCloy Says Governments and Officials Must Share in Corporate Bribery Blame
description: Corrupt governments and politicians are at least as much to blame for questionable corporate payoffs as the companies themselves, John J. McCloy told a business audience at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday.

title: Audit by Goldin Office Says City Loses $2 Million a Year in Park Concessions
description: New York City is failing to collect more than $2 million a year that it should be getting from park concessionseverything from Good Humor trucks to the TavernontheGreenaccording to a draft audit by the Comptroller's office.

title: A Key Figure in 1963 Prof umo Scandal Is Thriving in the Israeli Cafe Business
description: TEL AVIVMost people spend their lives trying to prove to the world who and what they are. With me, it's the opposite. It's a constant battle to prove what I'm not.

title: Highs and Low's
description: Apache Cp Chosbroh wl Cln Mllcrn Cooper Ind Dresser wl FedPap Bd FePa 1.20Pf Fluor pfB Gon tnstru Gulf Oil Halllburtn

title: Olympic Diet: Hold the Steak, Vitamins
description: Spaghetti, mashed potatoes and dried fruit will do more for Olympic athletes this year r than steak and vitamins, a nutritionist with a fondness for raisins contended here yesterday.

title: Reserve Report
description: Reserve Report

title: Park, Klein Win SportsStar Tennis
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.. June 10 Brad Park of the Boston Bruins and Bob Klein of the Los Angeles Rains defeated Lynn Swann of the Pittsburgh Steelers and John Cappelletti of the Rams, 97, today in the final of the Dewar's Cup sports celebrity tennis tournament at the Hotel Riviera.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Incline Village, Nev.Mike Colbert, 163 pounds, Portland, Ore., outpointed Vincente Medina. 160 Tucson, Ariz, 10 rounds.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: INDIAN LEADER IN MOSCOW: Indira Gandhi, India's Prime Minister, being welcomed to the Kremlin by Leonid I. Brezhnev, Communist Party chief. They held talks described as friendly and hearty. Mrs. Gandhi is on an official visit to the Soviet Union.

title: HAYS IS IN A COMA IN OHIO HOSPITAL
description: Representative Wayne L. Hays was taken unconscious to the Barnesville, Ohio, hospital yesterday morning suffering from what his physician described as an overreaction to an accidental overdose of sleeping pills.

title: Reporters Find Hospitality in Soviet but Little News
description: MOSCOW, June 10The policemen in the southern town of Kuba all wore shiny new epaulets. Schoolgirls were waiting with flowers. Along the roads the visitors bus would follow, the first several rows of the fields and orchards had been newly harrowed for the sake of neatness.

title: City Ballet in Porte et Soupir
description: IT was a distinctly sluggish evening at the State Theater on Wednesday as the New York City Ballet presented Variations pour une Porte et un Soupir. The piece reunited its original pairing. Karin von Aroldingen and John Clifford, guest artist, who did their utmost to make something of the rather intransigent score, but they remained oddly puppetlike amid its stormy creakings and sighings.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PLYMOUTH, England, June 10 (UPI)Gale force winds in the eastern Atlantic today forced several craft to withdraw from the Royal WesternObserver singlehanded transAtlantic yacht race, which left Plymouth Sunday on a 3,000mile voyage to Newport, R.I. Guy Cornou of France was escorted back to Falmouth by the French Corvette Le Fringant after he suffered a back injury. Three French officers boarded the yacht oft Ireland yesterday after Cornou sent a distress signal. Cornou said he had slipped a disk while sailing in heavy seas. He planned to fly back France for treatment.

title: Doctor Says Orr Will Play by Fall
description: TORONTO, June 10 (AP)Doctors examined Bobby Orr's left knee today, and said the National Hockey League defenseman should be able to play hockey this fall. Orr, who had played out his option with the Boston Bruins, agreed yesterday to the terms of a multiyear arrangement with the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Jim Farley
description: The official proceedings of the 1924 Democratic National Convention at Madison Square Garden list Franklin D. Roosevelt of Hyde Park as a delegateatlarge entitled to a halfvote and James A. Farley of Stony Point as a delegate with a full vote. Eight years later the astute political organizer helped promote his fellow New Yorker from the Hudson River Valley to the Presidency.

title: For Mrs. Carter, a Rest at Last
description: Rosalynn Carter, the Democratic frontrunner for First Lady, says the grueling 14month prenomination campaign that she and her husband, Jimmy, have just concluded was like being in a tunnelI don't know any of the new books, I don't know any of the new movies, don't know anything.

title: WARSAW PACT GIVES. TROOP LEVEL DATA
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The Soviet  block Warsaw Pact countries today gave an accounting of their troop strengths in Central Europe to Western powers at the Vienna talks on mutual reduction a forces, an Administration official reported.

title: U.S. High Court Lets Stand the Order That Could Close State Schools July
description: TRENTON, June 10  The United States Supreme Court let stand today a New Jersey Supreme Court order that could close the state's 2,500 public schools on July 1, and the State Senate President. Matthew D. Feldman, said here that the action might produce enough support to pass some form of a personal income tax in the Senate next week.

title: Quintet Quintessentially Delectable
description: THE relatively small repertory for woodwind quintet happens to be singularly choice and there are crack ensembles to play it, providing some of the more delectable listening experiences. One of the latest of such expert groups to make its appearance on the scene is the New England Woodwind Quintet, which gave its Carnegie Recital Hall debut on Wednesday night. The group is made up of Stephanie Jutt, flute; Sandra Aspeseche, oboe; Ian Greitzer, clarinet; Richard Sharp, bassoon, and Pamela Paikin, horn. Miss Aspeseche studies at the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston, the rest are alumni.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Restructuring United Nations System3 P.M.

title: Marshal Katukov Is Dead; Soviet Tank Commander
description: MOSCOW, June 10 (AP)Mikhail Y. Katukov, a Soviet tank commander in World War II and later a senior official in the Defense Ministry, died after a long illness, the official Tass press agency reported today. He was 76.

title: Ethics Panel Calls Miss Quinlan's Coma Irreversible
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N. J., June 10A newly formed ethics committee at the Morris View Nursing Home here ruled today that Karen Anne Quinlan was in an irreversible coma with no reasonable possibility of recovering to a cognitive, sapient state.

title: Lawyer Is Given Up to 3 Years in Fraud
description: A lawyer once charged with bilking $2.5 million from two Wall Street law firms where he was a partner was sentenced yesterday to up to three years in jail after pleading guilty to a lesser charge of seconddegree forgery.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Syrian Office Is Seized
description: VIENNA, June 10 (AP) About 20 Arab students occupied the office of the Syrian cultural attach here today to protest Syria's military intervention in Lebanon. The police said the students discussed the situation with Syrian officials.

title: Mayer Helps Sets Conquer Triangles
description: PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP)Sandy Mayer claimed a singles victory and teamed with Phil Dent for a men's doubles triumph tonight to lead the New York Sets to a 2622 verdict over the Pittsburgh Triangles in World Team Tennis action.

title: COURT PROLONGS EMPIRE GAS WRIT
description: Judge Frank A. Kaufman of the Baltimore Federal District Court yesterday extended indefinitely his injuncton against the Empire Gas Corporation of Lebanon, Mo., preventing it from pursuing its tender offer for 2 million shares of Pargas Inc, at $18.50 a share. Empire Gas indicated yesterday that it would appeal the injunction and, added that a hearing on the appeal was scheduled for today in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond.

title: The Pop Life
description: MPLURALISM is the word in criticism these days, no matter what the art form. Perhaps it's just that things are happening so fast that critics without the perspective of time find it impossible to sort out their beloved categories and trends. In the jumble of the immediate moment, we appear to be beset by variety of every sort, and so it seems safest simply to label our time as pluralistic, with all the arts marked by extreme diversity of style.

title: MEDIATORS RECESS TIME INC. PAY TALKS
description: Federal mediators yesterday recessed negotiations between Time Inc. and the the Newspaper Guild of New York, citing no progress in talks to end a 10day strike of editorial employees against Time, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, Money and People magazines and TimeLife Books.

title: Broadway
description: Cy FEUER and Ernest Martin, who have done as much for musical comedy as anyone, say they will be back on Broadway again, and that they will bring with them not only Betty Comden, Adolph Green and Cy Coleman, but a musical version of Twentieth Century, too. Among other things, Mr. Feuer and Mr. Martin have produced Where's Charley?, Can Can, Silk Stockings, Guys and Dolls and How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, and the movie Cabaret, although most recently they have been in California, running the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera. Mr. Feuer and Mr. Martin are a couple of old pros.

title: Democrats to Make Fund Pleas Over TV At July Convention
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Now confident that its nominating convention will be model of order and unity, the Democratic Party is planning to use national telecasts of the event for a major fundraising experiment.

title: City Investigating Effort to Sell Park Audit Report to The News
description: New York City's Department of Investigation has been called in to investigate a man who tried to sell to The Daily News a draft audit report about the Parks Department.

title: U.S. Ammunition to Thais
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 10 (AP)  The United States has agreed to transfer its large stocks of ammunition in Thailand to the Thai Government after the withdraway of the last American forces next month, Foreign Minister Bhichai Rattakul said in Parliament today.

title: Eve Higgins Bride Of Stephen Miller
description: In Calvary Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Virginia Evalena Higgins, editor of special features of the syndicate of The New York Times, was married to Stephen Hillborn Miller, businessnews editor of The Associated Press. The Rev Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony.

title: Quinlan Stay Denied
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the United States Supreme Court today rejected a move by two New Jersey men to prevent Miss Quinlan from being deprived of lifesupporting equipment.

title: Carter and Grappelli: Jazz Legends Return
description: The last time Benny Carter, the most influential jazz alto saxophonist until Charlie Parker arrived during World War II, played in a club in New York was 34 years ago. That was in 1942, when he led a sextet that included Dizzy Gillespie at the Famous Dobor on 52d Street.

title: Auction To Aid Library
description: At 11 o'clock tomorrow morning the new eighthfloor events gallery at B. Altman & Company in Manhattan will reverberate to cries of Going  going  gone  An unusual selection of 70 to 90 paintings, prints and photographs will be auctioned, ranging from a brooding seascape by Marisol, a Pop sculptor, and estimated in value from $800 to $1,200, to a lighthearted print, valued at from $600 to $900, created especially for the auction by Larry Rivers.

title: EXREP. HASTINGS ACCUSED BY AIDE
description: The former executive secretary of an upstate Representative who resigned last year his told Federal authorities that she paid part of her $23,686 annual salary as a kickback to her boss and that other members of the Congressman's staff did the same thing, a Congressional source said last night.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON FISCAL DISPUTE
description: An attempt to reach a private compromise on the fiscal differences between Governor Carey and Mayor Beanie was under way yesterday after business leaders involved with the Emergency Financial Control Board warned that the situation was degenerating into a purely political dispute that was harmful to the city.

title: Box Scores and Standings
description: Box Scores and Standings

title: Habitat
description: If technology and logic could have solved the world's shelter problems, they would have done so long ago. The issues that Habitat, the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements, has faced in the meetings ending today in Vancouver, are political, economic and philosophicalthe kind of basic needs and value systems that ultimately prove more divisive than unifying among the advanced and developing countries.

title: Persuasions at the Other End
description: The Persuasions, who are performing at the Other End this evening, have forged a career from their recalcitrant attachment to a tradition. The fourman group sings a cappella, without accompanying instruments, in the style of the oldtime gospel quartets and rhythmandblues vocal groups, and for the most part they get along well without instruments.

title: Colavito's Banning Delayed by League
description: CLEVELAND, June 10 (UPI) The threegame suspension of Rocky Colavito, Cleveland Indians coach for bumping Umpire Dave Garcia during an argument last Sunday has been postponed, the team said today.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results; (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)
description: Exacta (Miss Mikes Lady and Nick Quinton) paid $27.

title: Laos to Build New City
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 10 (Agence FrancePresse)A SovietLaotian agreement for construction of a 15,000resident new city in the Plaine des Jarres has been signed here.

title: Urban Gorilla Defeated In Battle of Times Sq.
description: A 33foothigh King Kong that could withstand 100mileanhour winds lost the battle of Times Square last night. Its opponent was Community Board 5.

title: John MacCrate, Sat 35 Years On New York Supreme Court
description: John MacCrate, who served on the New York State Supreme Court bench for 35 years after one term in the United States House of Representatives, died Wednesday in the Madonna Residence, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. His age was 91.

title: The Chief Awards
description: The Chief Awards

title: Missouri Convention
description: In Missouri, where the Republicans will choose 19 delegates at a convention Saturday, John Powell, Mr. Reagan's state campaign director, accused Ford supporters yesterday of attempting to steal national delegates at the state convention.

title: 2 L. I. Runaway Foster Children Decide Reluctantly to Give Selves Up Today
description: Two young sisters who ran away from a temporary foster home and have been moving from friend to friend since then to avoid being found said reluctantly last night that they would turn themselves in early today to protect the concerned adults with whom they had been living.

title: JAKARTA RAZING OLD SHANTYTOWN
description: JAKARTA. Indonesia, June 6  Last week, a squadron of riot policemen swept through the decaying shantytown along the Banjir Canal where more than 10,000 people live and work, reminding them that by Friday they all had to be out.

title: Antiques
description: YOU don't need a patroon in the family tree appreciate the robust heartiness of the Dutchstyle art and antiques on view this weekend at the Bard College Bicentennial Antiques Show and sale in AnnandaleonHudson. N.Y.

title: F.P.C. Anticipates Shortages of Gas Will Grow Worse
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A Federal Power Commission report to be issued shortly anticipates that the natural gas shortage would get worse next winter and that four pipelines may be unable to deliver enough gas to cover the needs of their toppriority customers schools, hospitals, homes and small commercial users.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday.

title: The Labor Scene
description: DUSSELDORF, West GermanyFor an industrialist who supposedly has just come out on the winning side of a bitterly fought legislative battle with labor over corporate control, the chief spokesman for West Germany's employers is remarkably unhappy these days.

title: Miss Phillips Rings True in La Voix Humaine
description: In 1930, Jean Cocteau wrote a onecharacter play about a woman abandoned by her lover after a liaison of five years. A few days after their separation, the man telephones her. The play consists entirely of the woman's end of an extended conversation.

title: Algerian Force Arrives
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 10  Syrian Government sources said today that a contingent of Algerian troops, from 100 to 200 men, arrived in Damascus last night and was sent immediately into Lebanon, under the Arab League agreement in Cairo.

title: Banquet Protest at Syria
description: PEKING, June 10 (Reuters)Guests from the Palestine Lib eration Organization and diplomats from Egypt, Kuwait and Southern Yemen staged a protest walkout at a banquet here last night when the Syrian Ambassador made a speech defending his country's military intervention in Lebanon.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions ??? designates OTB listing

title: 2 Women Set Pace In Sprints
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10 (AP)Rosalyn Bryant of Los Angeles and Brenda Morehead of Tennessee State qualified easily today for the semifinals of the women's 200meter dash at the opening session of the threeday Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet.

title: Congressman's ExAide Links Her Salary to Sex
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A former Congressional secretary has said she was paid a premium salary by Representative John Young of Texas for sexual favors in addition to her assigned work.

title: Labor's Opportunity
description: The Labor Government has thus far avoided making any new commitments to take stronger monetary or fiscal actions to halt inflation in exchange for the standby credit it has received. Chancellor Healey has, to be sure, spoken in general terms about his willingness to make additional moves if they become necessary; but the danger remains that, behind the immediate easing of tensions, the rallying of the pound and the acceptance by the unions of the 4 percent pay limit, the Government may permit an excessive buildup of monetary pressures, resulting primarily from too huge a deficit in the national budget. Sooner or later, a loose monetary and fiscal policy could cause wage restraint to collapse as the impact of inflation on labor's real wages and living standards became unbearable.

title: No Move for Owls
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10 (UPI)  Albert A. Savill, owner and president of the Columbus Owls of the International Hockey League, said today, that the team would remain in Columbus for the 197677 season. He had threatened at the end of last season to move because of poor attendance. Savill said he changed his mind because of increased seasonticket sales and renwed fan support.

title: Yugoslavia Beats U.S.
description: PHILADELPHIA. June 10  Yugoslavia defeated the United States, 30, in team competition at the 46th annual United States open table tennis championships today at the Northeast Racquet Club. Mulivoy Karakasevic defeated John Tennehill, 217. 2114, and Dragutin Surbek beat Jerry Thrasher, 2112, 2111. In doubles, Rarakasevie and Surbek beat Tennehill and Thrasher, 2118.

title: Events and Openings
description: JACKSON COUNTY JAIL, dirried by Michael Miller, starring Yvette Mimieux, et neighborhood theaters.

title: FIRST ARAB UNITS ARRIVE IN LEBANON TO OVERSEE TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10The first units of a symbolic peacekeeping force that the Arab League has decided to send to Lebanon arrived today as quiet was reported from most of the fighting fronts around the country.

title: People and Business
description: Pieter Oechsle, a 43yearold Peruvian retailer, has been named president of F. A. O. Schwarz, the Fifth Avenuebased chain of 16 toy specialty stores.

title: Albany Votes Mental Hygiene Package
description: ALBANY, June 10The Legislature approved today amended versions of a package of mental hygiene reforms to comply with objections from Governor Carey and still bring about greater participation in mental health programs by local communities and the lawmakers themselves.

title: PAUL GETTY BURIAL ON ESTATE DELAYED
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10 (Reuters)J. Paul Getty, the oil magnate, was commemorated at a simple church service here today, but his burial in a marble mausoleum at his Pacific Ocean villa was held up by red tape.

title: Judge in Connie Francis Case Excludes Press and Spectators
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn excluded both the press and spectators yesterday from a $5 million negligence trial involving the rape of singer Connie Francis.

title: How to Get There
description: To get to the Westport Country Playhouse from New York City, take Exit 17 from the Connecticut Turnpike (195), turn left off the ramp and follow Riverside Avenue to Route 1. Turn right on Route 1 and follow it for half a mile through town to the theater archway on the left.

title: Reno Sweeney Salutes Its Past
description: It will be hail and farewell for Reno Sweeney at Carnegie Hall tonight.

title: Democrats Will Begin To Draft Platform Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)  The 15 members of the Democratic Party platformwriting subcommittee will open three days of closed meetings tomorrow to draft a statement of principles for the national convention to ratify next month.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: There is a pair of Marlene Dietrich movies running today only at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street, at LaGuardia Place (6742560). Both Hollywood films were directed by Josef von Sternberg. Miss Dietrich once said that The Devil Is a Woman (1935) was her favorite movie because she was at her most beautiful (she plays a temptress) in it. Many others agree. With Cesar Romero and Lionel Atwill. Musical background is RimskyKorsakoff's Capriccio Espanol in keeping with the setting, Old Spain. At 3:45, 7:05, 10:20. The other feature is Blonde Venus, seen somewhat more than The Devil, made in 1932, with Herbert Marshall and Cary Grant. About a nightclub singer married to a chemist but mixed up with another man. At 2, 5:15, 8:35 and midnight. Admission: $3; students, $2; 65's and over $1.50.

title: CITY U. REOPENING LIKELY ON MONDAY IN ALBANY SHIFT
description: ALBANY, June 10  The State Senate's Republican leadership, in a major political concession to its Democratic opponents, has accepted most of the City University rescue plan passed last night in the Assembly. Action on the compromise measure in both houses is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Nation Stirred 200 Years Ago Today
description: Finally, the Continental Congress was all but ready to say that the tie was past, and 200 years ago today the Congress appointed a committee of five to draw up the papers of separation.

title: 3 WIN LIBEL AWARDS AGAINST THE TIMES
description: A jury of two men and four women in Federal District Court in Manhattan has awarded $21,000 to one scientisteducator and $20,000 each to two others it found had been libeled by a news article in The New York Times of Aug. 14, 1972.

title: Miss Longet Pleads Not Guilty in Killing
description: ASPEN, Colo., June 10Claudine Longet, the Frenchborn actress and singer, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of felony manslaughter in the March 21 shooting death of her lover, Vladimir (Spidery Sabich, the ski racing champion.

title: Historic Cattle Roundup in 78 By Wayne Is Being ReEnacted
description: THOROFARE, June 10Since Revolutionary War heroes did more than pepper the British with musket fire, the Salem County Bicentennial Commission reached deep into the history books today to reenact a South Jersey cattle roundup conducted by Mad Anthony Wayne to ward off starvation among Washington's troops at Valley Forge.

title: Sports
description: TENNIS

title: Moynihan Enters U.S. Senate Race
description: Daniel P. Moynihan announced his candidacy for United States Senator from New York yesterday, putting on display his considerable support in labor circles and explaining at length the statement he made last year that it would be dishonorable for him to seek political office.

title: Travel Ills Laid to Various Organisms
description: Turista, the diarrheal illness that afflicts some 1.5 million American travelers to Mexico each year, is not a single disease but is a syndrome caused by a variety of bacteria, viruses and parasites, according to results of a study published yesterday.

title: Nation Stirred 200 Years Ago Today
description: Finally, the Continental Congress was all but ready to say that the tie was past, and 200 years ago today the Congress appointed a committee of five to draw up the papers of separation.

title: Cloven Kingdom'A Mad, Mad Whirl
description: THE name of the game is irony in Cloven Kingdom, an exuberant and witty dance work by paul Taylor that had its premiere Wednesday night at the Billy Rose Theater.

title: Study on Alcoholics Called Misleading
description: Executives of the National Council on Alcoholism said yesterday that a Rand Corporation study suggesting that some alcoholics could safely return to normal drinking was dangerous and misleading and should never have been released to the public.

title: Notes on People
description: Weatherford, Tex., whose heart belongs to Mary Martin, born and raised there, is going to honor its most famous native on July 4 by erecting a lifesize statue of the musical comedy actress as the crowning event of its Bicentennial celebration.

title: Carter's Position on Issues Designed for Wide Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, June 10An examination of Jimmy Carter's stands on the range of campaign issues shows that, in nearly every case, he seems to have taken the positions designed to satisfy the most possible voters and alienate the fewest.

title: DELANEY OPPOSED ON A JOB FOR SON
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The prospect that the son of Representative James J. Delaney of Queens may be named to the Securities and Exchange Commission has created an unusual and bitter governmental struggle, giving rise to charges that Mr. Delaney is trying to use his influence to get his son onto the public payroll.

title: Tanana Blanks Arguing Yanks
description: Like manager, like captain. Just as Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, was ejected by Umpire Larry McCoy from the game with California in the third inning Wednesday night, Thurman Munson, the Yankee captain, was ejected by Umpire Larry McCoy from the game with California in the third inning last night.

title: Belmont Charts
description: Belmont Charts; 1976. by Triamqe Pablcations, Inc. (The Daily Form); Thursday, June 10. 34th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Congressman's ExAide Links Her Salary to Sex
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A former Congressional secretary has said she was paid a premium salary by Representative John Young of Texas for sexual favors in addition to her assigned work.

title: Paul Taylor Dance Company At the Billy Rose, Marks 20th Year
description: Dance is the most ephemeral of the arts. It exists on stage for a few fleeting moments and then disappears from sight until the next performance. But there is nothing ephemeral about Paul Taylor's Aureole. It is a joyful celebration of dance itself.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker:
description: A BOUT 250,000 people will visit Stratford. Conn., a residential and industrial suburb east of Bridgeport, this summer, as they have in similar numbers every year since the American Shakespeare Theater was founded there in 1955.

title: Con Ed Returns Fort Slocum Site To New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y, June 10David's Island was returned by the Consolidated Edison Company to the City of New Rochelle today, a transaction described by Mayor Vincent Rippa as a shortterm loss, but, hopefully, a longterm gain.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 10 (UPI)The dollar showed slight advances on all Continental money markets except Zurich today. In London the pound closed unchanged yesterday's $1.77125, following a day of light trading.

title: Mineola Nine Triumphs
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 10Mineola High School defeated North Shore High of Glen Head, 80, today and won the Nassau County North Shore baseball title. Doug Williams hurled a threehitter for Mineola and Joe Letoski had three runs batted in.

title: DeKalb County, Ill.
description: DeKALB, Ill., June 10  DeKalb County, Ill., is corn and Republican country. This is the home of the barbedwire fence and hybrid corntwo inventions that revolutionized American agriculture. It is not worrying too much about Presidential politics these days. Its mind, as usual, is on the land.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is distressing that, shortly prior to the announcement by several Senators of significant progress toward reaching a constructive compromise on S. 1, your recent editorial Issues 76: Liberty reiterated the unfounded charge that S.1 contains many questionable sections that are incompatible with the First Amendment.

title: At the Movies
description: SHOOTING has ended on Martin Bregman's third film production, The Next Man. It stars Sean Connery as an Arab, and it is a thriller that tangles up oil, politics and murderers, one of them beautiful. It will have to go some to match the sweep of at least one line of the synopsis now being circulated by the movie company:

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday:

title: A ByrneWilliams Collision in Prospect
description: TRENTON, June 10There was no endorsement of Jimmy Carter today from the Democratic Party's uncommitted delegates who defeated him Tuesday. Instead, there was the prospect of a political collision between Governor Byrne and Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. that could embarrass the party and undermine efforts now under way to unite it behind Mr. Carter's prospective Presidential nomination.

title: Hays in Ohio Hospital
description: Representative Wayne L. Hays, accused of using Government funds to maintain a mistress, was in guarded condition in an Ohio hospital after falling into a coma in an overreaction to a prescribed sleeping pill. Page B5.

title: Market Place
description: When stocks were booming early this year on soaring volume, Wall Street analysts seemed to peer only upward in forecasting the trend of prices.

title: Stocks in Strong Finish; Dow Industrials Rise 6.30
description: Stocks advanced markedly yesterday and, powered by a strong last half hour, finished at their highs for the day. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 6.30 points to 964.39.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: First it was the trees. Then the grass. In another couple of months it will be the ragweed. Each in its turn, like some kind of lovely sadist, releases pollen into the air. Together they render 14 million Americans sneezy, wateryeyed or worse.

title: U.S. Team Favored In Curtis Cup Golf
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, June 10 (Reuters)The American women golfers are strong favorites to win the 19th Curtis Cup match against Britain, which starts tomorrow.

title: A Celebration In SoHo
description: THERE'LL be dancingand music and poetry and paintingin the streets of SoHo tomorrow, at least eight blocks of them, from 1 to 5 P.M. In celebration of Artists Daya fete staged by a group of galleries run by artists (or coops)  bands of artists and their friends will stage shows, demonstrations, jazz concerts, poetry readings, dance and theater performances and at least one sym???.

title: How to Get There
description: The best way to get to Stratford is to sail your yacht straight up the Housatonic River and dock one of the four marinas on the Stratford side that nrnvide overnieht slips for as little as 30 cents a foot.

title: Hopper Exhibition at His Home
description: The morning sun still bleaches the white clapboard siding of the twostory house at 82 North. Broadway in the village of Nyack, N.Y., where Edward Hopper as a young boy sat alone on the front porch sketching sloops on the hazy Hudson River below.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: LONDON, June 10 (AP)The Esso and Shell Oil Companies agreed today to enter talks with Britain's Labor Government on state participation in their North Sea oil fields.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KUNGSHOLM (Flagship). Left Jamaica June 7; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St. VENDAM (Holl. Amer.). Left St. Themes June 7; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: RADIO
description: 69 A.M., WNCNFM. Six Landler, Beethoven; Italian Serenade, Wolf; Kikimora, Liadov; Rumanian Folk Dances. Bartok; German Dances (K. 510), Mozart; In questa reggia, from Turandot, Puccini; Hungarian Dances, Brahms; Acis and Galatea Overture, Haydn; Barcarolle, Tchalkovsky; Sonata in B flat for Violin, Cello and Piano, Schubert; Sinfonia, Vitali.

title: Body Found in Stolen Car
description: The body of an unidentified man who was about 30 years old was found yesterday in the trunk of a stolen car parked in front of 1475 54th Street in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. The victim had been shot in the head and his feet had been tied with rope. The body was wrapped in a blanket.

title: Chemical Bank Chairman New Head of United Fund
description: The United Fund of Greater New York announced yesterday the election of a new chairman. He is Donald C. Platten, chairman and director of Chemical New York Corporation and Chemical Bank.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI. DAY: NEW JLRSEY 12011 MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTENASSAU ND NORTHERN NEW. YORK STATE COUNTIES (1914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7767.
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI. DAY: NEW JLRSEY 12011 MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTENASSAU ND NORTHERN NEW. YORK STATE COUNTIES (1914) WHITE PLAINS 95300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7767.

title: DELANEY OPPOSED ON A JOB FOR SON
description: WASHINGTON. June 10The prospect that the son of Representative James J. Delaney of Queens may be named to the Securities and Exchange Commission has created an unusual and bitter governmental struggle, giving rise to charges that Mr. Delaney is trying to use his influence to get his son onto the public payroll.

title: Solomon and Ramirez Gain
description: PARIS, June 10A match that should have been played in the Davis Cup at Mexico City last December will be a semifinal tomorrow between Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md. and Raul Ramirez of Mexico.

title: Youthful Band Is Solid as Rock
description: Herman Szobel, the Austrian pianist who is appearing at Folk City this weekend opposite the folksinger Chris Rush, looks even younger than his 18 years, and the median age of his band members appears to ne 19 or so. But when the group begins to play, everyone sits up and takes notice. Their music, which is composed and arranged by Mr. Szobel, is some of the most intricate and original jazz/rock currently being performed.

title: Riggins Is Lured By Redskin Gold
description: New York, the diminishing big apple, suffered another loss yesterday. John Riggins, the Jet fullback, who had become a free agent, signed a longterm agreement with the Washington Redskins that will have repercussions around the National Football League.

title: Paraguay's Oppressed Suffer Behind a Wall of Silence
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 8 Human rights violations have emerged as the main topic at the meeting of the Organization of American States in Santiago, Chile this week. But rights advocates in Paraguay were too frightened to send a representative.

title: SOYBEANS HIGHER ON BUYING ABROAD
description: Heavy buying of soybeans, soybean meal and oil in London and West German markets yesterday led to sharply higher prices for those commodities on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Requiem for Farley Set for Tomorrow: Cooke Will Preside
description: A funeral service for James A. Farley will be held at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Terence Cardinal Cooke will preside at the requiem mass.

title: SENATE APPROVES DILUTED VERSION OF ANTITRUST BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Senate passed a greatly diluted version of its antitrust bill tonight, by a vote of 65 to 19, after supporters agreed to accept a substitute measure that virtually eliminated two of the original bill's three major sections.

title: Canada Announces Price Rise
description: OTTAWA, June 10 (UPI) Minister of Energy Alastair Gillespie today announced increases in the export price of natural gas that will raise energy costs of United States consumers next year by $320 million. The Minister said the price of natural gas exported under all existing licenses would rise from the current $1.60 per thousand cubic feet to $1.80 Sept. 10 and to $1.94 next Jan. 1.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New Bond Issues

title: So Diplomats Can Rent That Homey Atmosphere
description: For less than toprank diplomats, life is constant movement, and in many cases, they are sent here for a couple of years. When their stay is to be so temporary, how can they hope to achieve a homelike atmosphere?

title: Study on Alcoholics Called Misleading
description: Executives of the National Council on Alcoholism said yesterday that a Rand Corporation study suggesting that some alcoholics could safely return to normal drinking was dangerousand misleading and should never have been reI leased to the public.

title: CITY U. REOPENING LIKELY ON MONDAY IN ALBANY SHIFT
description: ALBANY, June 10  The State Senate's Republican leadership, in a major political concession to its Democratic opponents, has accepted most of the City University rescue plan passed last night in the Assembly. Action on the compromise measure in both houses is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Dispute Over Costs Delays Transfer Of a 2,340Acre Estate to the State
description: HACKENSACK, June 10An unexpected dispute over surveying and title search costs postponed today for at least a week the transfer of a 2,340 acre estate in the Ramapo Mountains to the State of New Jersey.

title: RollCall of Albany Vote on City U.
description: ALBANY June 11Following are the votes taken in the senate tonight and in the Assembly Wednesday, approving City University rescue package:

title: Disaster Area in Georgia
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) President Ford today declared the areas of Georgia hit by severe storms and flooding since May 28 a major disaster area. The action permits the use of Federal funds for relief and recovery efforts in designated areas of the state.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: 2 Kinds of Banks Battling For CheckAccount Funds
description: A fierce battle for consumer deposits that could change the competitive balance in the banking industry is heating up among commercial banks and, savings institutions across New York State.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement disagreed on how to use the symbolic peacekeeping force being sent to Lebanon by the Arab League, but outright opposition to any such force was expressed by Lebanon's rightwing Christian leader, Interior Minister Camille Chamoun, who warned that the league would be responsible for drowning Lebanon in blood. The Libyan Prime Minister, Abdel Salam Jalloud, who has taken the role of mediator in Lebanon and who was a supporter of the Syrian position, was said to be leaning toward the Palestinian view that the peacekeepidg force should replace Syrian troops. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Power Plant Cooling Grid Tested
description: GENEVAWest German energy specialists believe they may have found a way to avoid what many fear will become the most critical problem as power plants, nuclear or conventional, proliferate over the globe. This is getting rid of their heat.

title: Mrs. Breer Leads By Stroke at 70
description: TORONTO, June 11 (AP)Murle Breer, who has not won on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour since 1969, shot a twounderpar 70 today for a onestroke lead in a $60,000 tournament at the Cedar Brae course.

title: Students at Teaneck High Agonize Over the Holocaust
description: TEANECK, N. J. Informal classroom study of the Holocaust has developed into morality dramas in two New Jersey high schools. The students agonize over prejudices of all hinds, consider demagoguery in politics and sometimes weep as they watch a short French film documentary about the concentration camps in which millions of Jews were killed.

title: 2 More Bodies Found in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 11 (UPI)The bodies of two more persons believed tortured and killed by Brazilian death squads were discovered today a Rio de Janeiro suburb. The latest victims were found in the Western suburb of Baixada Fluminense Both showed signs of having been beaten and tortured.

title: U.S. Studies Charge Of SexforVote Bid
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Federal investigators are looking into charges by Elizabeth Ray that she was ordered by former Representative Kenneth J. Gray of Illinois into a sexual encounter with Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, to further Mr. Gray's hopes of securing the Senator's assistance in passing legislation, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Primaries Show G.O.P. Needs Outside Aid to Win Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)Voting figures from the Pesidential primaries detail for Republicans the extent to which their candidate must attract voters from outside the party to retain the White House.

title: House Votes Amtrak Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (API)The House voted today to give Amtrak $S78 million in the next fiscal year to run its passenger trains, buy new ??? and improve its fa???. The authorization includes $430 million for operating expenses, far more than the Ford Administration proposed but $30 million short of what Amtrak said it needed to keep its trains running.

title: Kissinger, in Mexico, Wary on Cubans
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today appared to stiffen Washington's conditions for an improvement of relations with Havana by demanding that all Cuban troops must first be withdrawn from Angola.

title: Humphrey Backs Mondale
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (UPI)  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey wants Senator Walter F. Mondale to he the Democrats VicePresidential capdidate. Mr. Humphrey, speaking to a group of black publishers last night and conceding that former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter Would win the Democratic nomination, said I hope my friend, Senator Mondale, will be the Vice President. Both Senator Humphrey and Senator Mondale are Minnesota Democrats.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD ??? UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI. DAY: NEW ??? (201) MARKET 3.3900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (514) 7470500; SUFFOLK Co. (516) 669.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7767.

title: Is This Convention Necessary?
description: It would be a refreshing harbinger of things possibly to come if Jimmy Carter were to exercise his newly granted Caesarian powers to spare the nation the ordeal of the Democratic convention, now scheduled to afflict the people in midJuly. Cancelling it would not only be an act of mercy but also an acknowledgment that antiquarian political machinery can finally be retired to the museums where, as Carter's victory proves, it now belongs.

title: MORTIMER L. MEDRICH
description: Mortimer L. Medrich, an investment broker, died Thursday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y., of cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: FORD AND REAGAN PUSH VOTE QUEST
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 11 President Ford and Ronald Reagan began personal scrambles here tonight for the remaining Republican National Convention delegates in II states who are pivotal to their contest for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Fiat Executive Runs Initaly as New Face
description: ROME, June 11The question being asked about Umberto Agnelli in the present election campaign is whether a rich, handsome automobile executive can find happiness in the Christian Democrats. He thinks he can.

title: RIGHT IN LEBANON OPPOSES TROOPS FROM ARAB LEAGUE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement were at odds today on how to use the symbolic peacekeeping force decided upon by the Arab League but outright opposition to any such force was expressed by Lebanon's rightwing Christian leadership.

title: Trial of 13 Mercenaries Opens in Angolan Capital
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 11The trial of 13 Britons and Americans charged as mercenaries opened here this morning with a sweeping denunciation of a mercenary war of aggression against the Angolan people and the People's Republic of Angola.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After a lengthy private discussion by Governor Carey and Mayor Beam of their fiscal and political differences, city officials displayed a far more conciliatory tone towards sthe Governor's call for additional municipal budget cuts.

title: 600 Cubans Back Home
description: HAVANA, June 11 (Reuters)  About 600 Cuban soldiers who fought in Angola's civil war returned to Havana earlier this week, informed sources said.

title: Tito Ends Turkey Visit
description: BELGRADE, June 11 (Reuters) President Tito returned today after a threeday official visit to Turkey.

title: The World, Old and New, in the Trenton Farmers Market
description: TRENTON, N.J.The season begins here with spring apples. Baskets of them in rows and rows on the right side of the Farmers Market entrance a triumph of American horticultural ingenuity: Red Rome, McIntosh, Stayman Winesap, Delicious (red and golden), Jonathan, Granny Smith, Macoun.

title: Canada Will Begin Reductions In Oil Exports to U.S. on July 1
description: OTTAWA, June 11 (AP)The Canadian Government announced today that it would, cut oil exports to the United States by 12 percent on July I as part of a series of gradual oil export reductions. The Na. tional Energy Board said the shipments would be reduced by 60,000 barrels to 450,000 barrels a day.

title: People and Business
description: Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, praised Congress yesterday for acting constructively in trying to limit total spending under the new Congressional budget control proceaures. In contrast, President Ford, while applauding the new budget process, has been consistently critical of the $413 billion spending target that Congress approved last month, saying that it was too high.

title: CAREY AND BEAME SOFTEN DISPUTE
description: After a lengthy private discussion by Governor Carey and Mayor Beams of their fiscal and political differences, city officials displayed a far more conciliatory tone yesterday toward the Governor's call for additional municipal budget cuts.

title: Monmouth Heats Up the Racing Scene
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., June 11 A potential shortage of horses rather than of fans seemed to concern officials at Monmouth Park today as a crowd of 14,641particularly impressive in view of hot, humid weatherturned out for the opening of a 132day meeting.

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONRichard. In cherished memory of our beloved father, who passed away June 13, 1923.

title: Daniel Fox, Photographer And Reporter in New York
description: Daniel Fox, a former newspaper reporter, photographer and public relations man, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 75 Henry Street, Brooklyn.

title: Chemical and White Weld Said To Default on Utility Bonds:
description: A spokesman for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District charged yesterday in California that the Chemical Bank and White Weld & Company were lin default on the purchase of a $25 million bond issue. The investor group failed to close the purchase last Tuesday.

title: Rights Unit Appeals to Havana To End Cruelty to Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON. June 11 (AP) The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission has appealed to the Cuban Government to take immediate steps, to end what it calls cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment of political prisoners.

title: Import Quotas Put on Specialty Steels; Shipments From Japan to Be Curtailed
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Government announced the details today of the longheralded import quotas on stainless steel and other specialty steels. The only significant cutback from recent import levels involves shipments from Japan.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news article and chart in The New York Times on Wednesday gave erroneous figures on net tuition costs at the City University of New York and erred in describing which students were eligible for Federal tuition grants. A corrective article appears on Page 21.

title: DeCamp Officer Expects Strike to End on Monday
description: NEWARK, June 11The general manager of DeCamp Bus Lines said today that he had great hopes of reaching a settlemen on Monday of the threeweek strike by drivers and garage workers. the downtown area board the Conrail trains, once of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad at their suburban stations for the trip to Hoboken, when PATH trains transport them to Lower Manhattan.

title: Eisenpreis Out as Beame Presses to End Job Drain
description: Alfred Eisenpreis resigned his past as Economic Development Administrator yesterday as Mayor Beame moved ahead with plans to restructure the city's efforts to aid New York's sagging economy and to give those efforts the highest policy priority.

title: Congress to Study Rating AgenciesBond Holders Consent to Changes
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation deferred yesterday its plans to sue Moody's Investors Service after Congressional hearings on the bondrating agencies were scheduled June 2324.

title: MORGENTHAU SET FOR PARK INQUIRY
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday that he was prepared to open a grand jury investigation into allegations that New York City might have been defrauded by some concessionaires operating in city parks and public places.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news article and chart in The New York Times on Wednesday gave erroneous figures on not tuition costs at the City University of New York and erred in describing which students were eligible for Federal tuition grants, A corrective article appears on Page 21.

title: Bargain Hunting Buoys Amex; Counter Stocks Also Advance
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market posted their second consecutive advance yesterday in continued sluggish trading.

title: JERSEY PROPOSES CANCER REGISTRY
description: TRENTON, June 11 Faced with ??? by the American Cancer Society that more than 14.000 Nev: Jersey residents will die of cancer this year, state officials proposed a broadrange program of research into the causes of the high incidence of the disease in the state. New Jersey leads the naticn in the cancer mortality rate.

title: Jim Konstanty Dies
description: Jim Konstanty, the relief pitcher who led the Philadelphia Phillies to their last National League pennats in 1950, died yesterday in Oneonta, N. Y. He was 59. Konstanty won 16 games, saved 22 and was the National League's most valuable player that year. Details, Page 26.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: DEMOCRATS START PLATFORM DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11In an unusual spirit of unity, a 15member subcommittee began today to draft a Democratic Party platform that will almost certainly reflect the views of former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia.

title: Two Top Executives of a L.I. Company Found Slain in Its Office in Penn Plaza
description: The president and executive vice president of a Long Island dataprocessing company were found shot to death yesterday morning in the small office it maintained at 2 Penn Plaza in the Madison Square Garden complex.

title: Stage: Cleopatra and Earnest in Canada
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  It should be the quality of a festival to be festiveto be different, to be special. It brings people together; audiences, artists, and in a drama festival, plays. Robin Phillips, now in his second season as the director of the Canadian Stratford Festival, has a sure understarlding of the necessary ingredients of a festival. He obviously sees a festival not simply as a succession of plays, but as a progression of events.

title: Officials Go to Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 1] (Reuters)  The Arab League's Secretary General, Mahmoud Riad, arrived here today heading political and military committees set up by the league to try to bring peace to Lebanon.

title: Ballet: Giselle Via Lynn Seymour
description: To Lynn Seymour must go our thanks not only for her magnificent performance in Giselle Thursday night with American Ballet Theater, but also for reminding us that there are many performing traditions behind this celebrated ballet.

title: U.S. COURT FAVORS GOLDMAN, SACHS
description: United States District Court Judge H. Kenneth Wangelin ruled in St. Louis yesterday in favor of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking house, in a $625,000 suit for damages brought by the Alton Box Board Company of Alton, ni.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso yesterday signed a bill providing for the merger of Connecticut's trial courts into a single court system in the expectation that criminal justice will be made swifter by the more efficient use of judges. Two years ago, the Assembly approved a reform absorbing the circuit courts, at the bottom of the ladder, into the Court of Common Pleas, one rung up. The new reform, which will take effect on July 1, 1978, will complete the process, absorbing the 61 judges of the Court of Common Pleas and the six juvenile court judges into Superior Court, which now has 51 judges, including the six who are also justices of the Supreme Court.

title: Value of Bold Forbes Soaring; Forego Assigned 132 Pounds
description: A week after he won the Belmont Stakes, Bold Forbes looks like more than just a million. He looks like four millionat least.

title: SOY MEAL PRICES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Soybean meal continued its price surge yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, closing up $2.50 at $203.50 a ton for July delivery. During the session it hit a contract high of $207.50.

title: SYRIANS BOLSTER FORCE IN LEBANON
description: RIYAQ, Lebanon, June 11Syria has reinforced its military occupation here in the Bekaa Valley of central Lebanon with scores of tanks, communication camps and armed patrols at virtually every passable road leading to the main highway between Damascus and Beirut.

title: U.S. Studies Charge Of SexforVote Bid
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Federal investigators are looking into charges by Elizabeth Ray that she was ordered by former Representative Kenneth J. Gray of Illinois, her employer at the time, into a sexual encounter with Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, to further Mr. Gray's hopes of securing the Senator's assistance in passing legislation, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Cuts in Health Aid Scored By a ChildWelfare Group
description: WASHINGTON. June 11 The Children's Defense Fund, a child advocacy group, charged today that health services that could improve the wellbeing of America's most needy youngsters were suffering from government cutbacks and inaction that would probably cost the government more to treat illness in the future.

title: MANY AT FESTIVAL BURT IN STAMPEDE
description: A Latin street festival attended by 8,000 people in East Harlem erupted into a stampede just before midnight Thursday in which scores of persons were injured, including a 3yearoldgirl who was reported in critical condition.

title: Geico's Shareholders To Meet on Stock Sale
description: A special meeting of shareholders of the Government Employees Insurance Company has been scheduled for July 23 in Washington, the company's chairman, John J. Byrne, announced yesterday. The shareholders will be asked to approve issuance of $75 million in convertible preferred stock, to be used to help the company ease its pressures.

title: Union Counters Charges
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 11A teamster spokesman said of the report:

title: Ford Loses 3 Delegates To Reagan in Ohio Vote
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11 (Reuters)  President Ford won 88 Republican National Convention delegates and Ronald Reagan nine in last Tuesday's Ohio primary election, the Ohio Secretary of State's office said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There can be no question that the strictures of the Honor Code at West Point will be variously interpreted by each individual and that the general condition of the honor system will be a reflection of the attitudes of the cadet population as a whole.

title: Fashion: In the Heat, Anything Goes, If It's Cool
description: Miniskirts are fading away and the ranks of blue jeans, which once presented a solid phalanx, are being decimated. The ones that pass on the street are not battered, patched and embroidered with love as they were a while back  they're lust pants.

title: American Express Bids $1,000 To WNET for Claiborne Dinner
description: American Express won a return of sorts with Craig Craiborne last night on Chtnnel 13 by bidding $1,000 for a dinner for two to be prepared by Pierre Franey and Mr. Claiborne, food editor of The New York Times, at his home in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Panel Votes $382 Million For Public Broadcasting,
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) A Senate Appropriations subcommittee approved today legislation to provide $382 million in longrange financing for public broadcasting.

title: Trade Center Tower To Open on 4th of July
description: The World Trade Center twin towers will be open Sunday, July 4, to give tenants of the buildings and their guests a spectacular view of Operation Sail in the Hudson River.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Calls Talks in Moscow Very Successful
description: MOSCOW, June 11Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ended a fourday visit to Moscow today in an extremely friendly atmosphere after talks that she said had strengthened SovietIndian ties.

title: RIGHT IN LEBANON OPPOSES TROOPS FROM ARAB LEAGUE

Such a view does not take Into account the continuing doubts concerning Mr. Nadjari's ability, his methods, his attitude toward civil liberties and his tenure, which have grown to such proportions as to be obstacles to the accomplishment of his task.

title: Albany Colleagues Remember Hastings's Parties
description: ALBANY, June 11When James F. Hastings was a member of the State Legislature from 1963 to 1968, he and two colleagues shared a downtown Albany apartment for a time that was known as a super pad, a rendezvous where parties began when the bars closed. On the snowy capital scene, it was a place of refuge for legislators, aides and sectetaries.

title: Mr. Jimmy's Sleepy Hometown Is Starting to Awake
description: PLAINS, Ga., June 11 Ain't nothin ever gonna change this ??? ole beat town, says Tammy Wiggins, a 14yearold resident of Plains, Ga., birthplace of Jimmy Carter. It never changed when Mr. Jimmy was Governor, and I don't think it'll change if he gets President. A lot of people say Mr. Jimmy will do a lot for Plains, get us a restaurant and a big ole motel, but Mr. Jimmy says he won't.

title: The Ballet: Watermilf
description: It is difficult to imagine anyone other than Edward Villella in the central role of Jerome Robbins's Watermill. Perhaps because no one else has done it? More likely it's because of Mr. Villella's incredible intensity, which makes the work move around him like a twisting cloud circling the still eye of a storm. He danced, or perhaps more accurately performed it in his first appearance with the New York City Ballet this season Thursday evening at State Theater.

Jimmy Carter would win the Democratic nomination, said I hope my friend, Senator Mondale, will be the Vice President. Both Senator HumphreY and Senator Mondale are Minnesota Democrats.

Perhaps once in every generation a building is conceived that changes the way people think about buildings, says the lavish hardbound promotional brochure for the project. It goes on to exclaim that the building has created a new attitude toward urban living.

title: Bobby Orr, Bobby Hulland Jim Norris
description: And now Bobby Orr, the only pig in a poke ever worth $30,000 a pound, will be skating for the Chicago Black Hawks instead of the Boston Bruins, if he can skate. All those doctors in Toronto predict he'll be able to skate on his damaged left knee, but only Bobby Orr's left knee loom for sure. His left knee won't know until training camp. That's when the Black Hawks will learn if their reported $3 million investment was worth it. The irony that the Black Hawks agreed to pay $3 million to Bobby Orr because they wouldn't pay $3 minion to Bobby Hull four years ago. Ever since Bobby Hull joined the Winnipeg Jets of the World Hockey Association, the Black Hawks attendance at Chicago Stadium has gradually decreased. Desperate now, the Black Hawks are betting $3 million that Bobby Orr will stimulate ticket sales enough to justify their investment. They would have bean better off investing in Bobby Hull, but their owners, Arthur Wirtz and William Wirtz, didn't realize that; Now they're paying the price$3 million that will be worth only Bobby Orr can skate.

Va., for what he has named the Telecharge. He has organized Telecharge Inc. in Little Rock, Ark., to manufacture the device.

title: Henry Fonda, 71, Talks of Life and Art
description: The long body is leaner than ever. The blue eyes are alive with curiosity and as clear as a fjord. At 71, Henry Fonda is content and relaxed. He has come through several major operations, is still enamored of the acting profession, is astonished and grateful that roles like Clarence Darrow happened to me when I was 70 years old, and is looking forward to working with his daughter, Jane, and son, Peter, on a major film project involving the American Revolution.

title: People in Sports
description: The Buffalo Sabres and Boston Bruins, of the National Hockey League announced a strange deal yesterday. The Sabres traded the freeagent rights of Peter McNab, their center, to the Bruins for the freeagent rights of Andre Savant Boston center. Both players became free agents when their contracts expired June 1, and technically, could have signed with any club in the N.H.L. However, the Bruins quickly announced that they had signed the 24yearold McNab and Punch Imlach, Buffalo's general manager, said he has talked to Savard and his agent and hopes to sign him i nthe near future. According to a league spokesman contacted in Montreal, what both teams have actually traded are their rights to be compensated for their loss under N.H.L. by laws. Savard, 22, Boston's first pick in the 1973 amateur draft, had 17 goals and 23 assists in 79 games last season McNab, who played college hockey at Denver, scored 24 goals and had 32 assists, also in 79 games.

It probably comes from the way students are trained: One has to do problem 17 and problem 17 has an answer. Maybe that's what's wrong with the way we train people generally: problem 17 has an answer. Physics isn't like that, and life isn't like that.

title: 'Jackson County Jail,' Fine Melodrama With Yvette Mimieux, on Local Screens
description: "If you are who you say you are," the small-town sheriff tells the young woman, "you won't have any trouble." The young woman (Yvette Mimieux) is Dinah Hunter, who has just thrown over her job with a Los Angeles advertising agency, as well as her lover of two years, and has been driving back to New York. However, all her identificationalong with her money and her carhave been stolen by a pair of pill-popping hitchhikers she picked up earlier in the day, thinking she was doing a good deed.When the hitchhikers pulled a gun on her and threw her out of the car somewhere in southern Arizona, they dropped Dinah into a nightmare land from which she probably will never emerge. "If you are who you say you are . . ."the line becomes the theme of a fine, tough little melodrama called "Jackson County Jail," which opened yesterday at the Embassy 49th Street and other theaters in New York.It isn't the film's very dismal view of Bicentennial America that gives "Jackson County Jail" its vigor. The film lays on the ironies and hypocrisies so heavily that it sometimes seems to be the work of especially snobbish film makers, people who think that everything between Los Angeles and New York is the boondocks."Jackson County Jail" is film making of relentless energy and harrowing excitement that recall the agitprop melodramas of the 30's. It's not exactly in a class with Lang's "You Only Live Once," but it possesses the kind of fury that can breathe life into a melodrama even when the point of view is simple-minded.The film was directed by Michael Miller and written by Donald Stewart, neither of whom I'd heard of before. Roger Corman, sometimes known as the king of the B's, was the executive producer, and it has the drive, movement and economy of narrative that are the marks of Corman films, good and bad."Jackson County Jail" shows how someone as self-aware, self-assured and secure as its middle-class heroine can, literally overnight, find herself in a landscape where nothing she has ever known or believed still holds.Unable to produce identification for the sheriff, Dinah is put into the county lockup for the night. She is raped by the jailer, whom she murders in self-defense, and the next mornnng is out on the road, sharing a get-away car with a young man who is an accused murderer and admitted truck hijacker.It's preposterous, and the movie works within its own terms, though one shouldn't overanalyze it for the wrong (political) reasons.Mr. Miller and Mr. Stewart picture a land of unremitting evil and brutality where everyone is corrupt, from the wise-cracking waitress, who attempts to shortchange Dinah the first morning out, to the policeman-rapist. The only good guy is the truck hijacker who admits to thieving because he likes it and who will rationalize his life only to the extent of saying, "The whole country is a rip-off."The film manages to stay clear of sentimentality of the conventional sort, though when the hijacker, nicely played by Tommy Lee Jones, says with a shrug just before the final shoot-out, "I was born dead anyway," it's dealing in its own sort of sentimentality.Miss Mimieux is excellent in a role that subjects her to as many bruises, humiliations and indignities as she might get in the boxing ring. All of the performances are fine and to the point. I hesitate to say too much, thus to oversell a movie that is best come upon without great expectations. I would suspect that Mr. Miller and Mr. Stewar are new film makers to watch.

title: Books of The Times
description: Almost everyone knows the Frank Harris of My Life and Loves, the once covertly (and now openly) circulated recital, in four volumes, of prodigious, even Herculean, feats of sexual prowess. I remember reading a smuggled copy some 40 years ago and wondering even then if such superhuman delights as he described in ardent detail had actually been experienced. It turns out according to Philippa Pullar's exceedingly knowledgeable biography, that Harris, a minor but fascinating figure in modern literature, dictated them in his declining years when he was impotent and in need of money and drew liberally on his imagination and abundant fantasies. The lubricity of My Life and Loves, largely fiction though it was, nonetheless gave Harris an undeserved reputation as little more than a merchant of sex. There was indeed much more to Harris than this. In London in the last 20 years of the 19th century he was an imaginative editor who helped start the career of H. G. Wells and published Bernard Shaw on music and John Addington Symonds on art and letters. He wrote some excellent short stories, including Montes the Matador, that are still worth reading. And he did a novel, The Bomb, which is a minor classic.
