title: HARRY LIEBERMAN
description: Harry Lieberman, a lawyer, died Wednesday at his home of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 350 Richmond Terrace, New Brighton, S.I.

title: Students at Teaneck High Agonize Over the Holocaust
description: TEANECK, N. J.Informal classroom study of the Holocaust has developed into morality dramas in two New Jersey high schools. The students agonize over prejudices of all kinds, consider demagoguery in politics and sometimes weep as they watch a short French film documentary about the concentration camps in which millions of Jews were killed.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syria and the Palestinian guerrilla movement disagreed on how to use the symbolic peacekeeping force being sent to Lebanon by the Arab League, but outright opposition to any such force was expressed by Lebanon's rightwing Christian leader, Interior Minister Camille Chamoun, who warned that the league would be responsible for drowning Lebanon in blood. The Libyan Prime Minister, Abdel Salam Jalloud, who has taken the role of mediator in Lebanon and who was a supporter of the Syrian position, was said to be leaning toward the Palestinian view that the peacekeeping force should replace Syrian troops. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Payments Dsiclosed by Allied Chemical
description: The ??? Corporation disclosed yesterday that improper payments totaling $835,750 were made to a purchasing agent of one domestic customer in a fouryear period.

title: Mr. Jimmy's Sleepy Hometown Is Starting to Awake
description: PLAINS, Ga., June 11Ain't nothin ever gonna change this lil ole beat town, says Tammy Wiggins, a 14yearold resident of Plains, Ga., birthplace of Jimmy Carter. It never changed when Mr. Jimmy was Governor, and I don't think it'll change if he gets President. A lot of people say Mr. Jimmy will do a lot for Plains, get us a restaurant and if big ole motel, but Mr. Jimmy says he won't.

title: Market Place
description: While investor enthusiasm over the stock market has waned in recent months, sales of shares in municipal bond funds by brokers continue to boom.

title: Nettles Belts 2 in 75 Victory
description: When Graig Nettles reported for work in Yankee Stadium last night, he didn't have much to write home about. He was batting only 198 with five home runs and he had knocked in just 17 runs all season as the powerhitting third baseman for the New York Yankees. Still, he reasoned, the manager has confidence in me and I always come to work knowing that I'll play.

description: Contract No. 2 Open High Low Close Prev.

title: Refugees in Buenos Aires Abducted From 2 Hotels
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 11 (AP) Heavily armed men stormed into two hotels before dawn today and took away at least two dozen political refugees including two teenagers, United Nations refugee agency officials said.

title: Man, 36, Slain in a Bronx Cab In Apparent Narcotics Rivalry
description: An alleged narcotics dealer was slain early yesterday in a barrage of gunfire aimed at the gypsy cab in which he was riding. The slaying was an apparent retaliation for the killing of two men who allegedly kidnapped and shot the dead man's stepdaughter two months ago.

title: NEW TREMORS HIT NORTHEAST ITALY
description: UDINE, Italy, June 11 (Reuters)A strong earth tremor followed by three lesser ones shook the Friuli area of northeast Italy tonight, but the police said no one was injured.

title: CITY U. TUITION AID HAS BEEN WIDENED
description: A news article in The New York Times on Wednesday describing tuition assistance programs available to students at the City University of New York, incorrectly said that student who began college before 1973 were not eligible for the program known as Federal Basic Education Opportunity Grants.

title: ALBANY APPROVES A 15MONTH PLAN TO RESCUE CITY U.
description: ALBANY, June 11The Legislature passed a Democratic designed rescue plan for the City University of New York tonight that will allow the university to reopen its doors to 270,000 students on Monday and to function with its state support intact for the next academic year.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Government debt rose faster than private debt last year for the first time since World War II, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ABC Gets Rights To Winter Games Of 1980 Olympics
description: ABC yesterday was granted exclusive United States television rights to the 13th Olympic Winter Games to be held at Lake Placid, N.Y., in 1980, ending a fivemonth contest with its rival networks that at times grew acrimonious. Reportedly, ABC's bid exceeded $15 million, for the rights.

title: Notes on People
description: Queen Elizabeth II issued her annual birthday honors list yesterday, and notable on it were Benjamin Britten, the composer, and Barbara Ward, the writer and lecturer on economics and ecology. Both were made life peers.

description: ALBANY, June 11The Legislature passed a Democratic designed rescue plan for the City University of New York tonight that will allow the university to reopen its doors to 270,000 students on Monday and to function with its state support intact for the next academic year.

title: Hebrew Newspaper Slated
description: TEL AVIV, June 11 (AP)A Hebrewlanguage daily newspaper will be published in New York starting in October, its editor, Abraham Paz, announced today. Mr. Paz said the paper, to be known as The Israel Daily Herald, would appear daily except Saturday. It would be the first Hebrew daily in New York, he said.

description: Article 1  No Title

title: Does Violence Sell?
description: Experts have deplored the steady diet of gore and violence on television. Psychologists have denounced its effects. Civic groups have cajoled the programmers to play down the mayhem. Task forces have urged change. The impact of all these pleas has been minimal.

title: Jersey Casinos Are Opposed
description: PASSAIC, N.J., June 11 (AP)  The Rabbinical Council of New Jersey has voted to reaffirm its opposition to legalized casino gambling in New Jersey.

title: U.S. Reports Mobsters Tapped Teamster Local for $1.1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Teamsters in a New York City local were bilked out of $1.1 million from a life insurance plan by individuals connected with organized crime, a Senate subcommittee report said.

title: Hays's Pill Dose Called 10 Times Usual
description: BARNESVILLE, Ohio, June 11  Representative Wayne Hays's personal physician said today that laboratory tests indicated that the 65yearold Ohio Democrat had taken 10 times or more of the prescribed amount of a sleeping medicine that put him into a coma last night.

title: Hirohito's Chef Dies
description: TOKYO, Saturday, June 12, (Reuters)The chef for Japan's Emperor Hirohito, Denjiro Nakajima, died of intestinal cancer at a hospital here yesterday, it was announced today. He was 79 years old. Mr. Nakajima was a member of the Cooking Academy of France.

title: Ohio Court Orders Judge To Open a Murder Trial
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11 (AP)The Ohio Supreme Court orered a Dayton judge today to open his courtroom to the public and press during pretrial hearing in a murder trial.

title: Brown Still Running
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California has denied reports that his race for the Democratic Presidential nomination is near an end after recent gains by Mr. Carter.

title: CYPRUS AIDE SAYS TURKS EXPEL GREEKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11  Foreign Minister John Christophides of Cyprus charged in the Security Council today that thousands of Greek Cypriots were being driven from their villages in areas controlled by Turkish forces in preparation for outright annexation of the territory by Turkey.

title: Expeditions, Too, Area a Loch Ness Legend
description: DRUMNADROCHIT, Scotland, June 11Jimmy McLennan is one of the oldtime crofters in the highlands. For most of his 62 years, he has worked 75 inhospitable acres on a ridge high above Loch Ness, renting the property from some distant landlord and doing well enough to raise five children. But he has never seen the monsterunless, of course, one counts a piece of garden furniture.

title: Companies Report Profits
description: Companies Report Profits

title: CITY U. IS CALLED SET FOR OPENING
description: Several college presidents at the City University said yesterday they expected that the university could be reopened on Monday if the package to rescue it was passed by the Legislature last night, which it was.

title: Europe's Recovery Held Periled by New Inflation
description: BRUSSELS, June 11The yearold economic recovery in Western Europe is threatened by a new bout of doubledigit inflation, according to reports released this week by both the Common Market and the Organization or Economic Cooperation and Devetopment.

description: As the June 29 deadline set by Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz for Maurice Nadjari's tenure as special state prosecutor approaches, Governor Carey and Mr. Nadjari have resumed the wary circling and artful sniping that characterized their strange encounter last winter.

title: 2 U. S. Stock Cars Take a Whirl at 24 Hours of Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, June 11 More exciting than McDonald's hamburgers and less chic than shrunken Levi's jeans, stock cars are the latest American intrusion into the French way of life. Will they last? Ca, c'est le question.

title: Two in House Stage SitIn At Arms Bill Conference
description: WASHINGTON, June 11In a challenge to one of the more revered institutions of Congressional elders, two junior members of the House Armed Services Committee staged a sitin today at a meeting of a SenateHouse conference of the Armed Services Committee.

title: ANDREW KAUL 3D
description: Andrew Kaul 3d, former president of the Airpo Speer Company carbongraphite division, died yesterday at his home near St. Mary's, Pa. He was 68 years old.

description: Thirty minutes before the curtain rose on the New York premiere of California Suite on Thursday evening, Jack Weston, wearing baggy blue underdrawers and a white Tshirt, handed a delivery tag from the Plaza Florist to a visitor backstage.

title: KIM QUITS IN SEOUL AS OPPOSITION CHIEF
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 11 Kim Young Sam stepped down from presidency of the opposition New Democratic Party today, 24 hours after a constitutional body ruled that he was no longer qualified to lead the country's largest opposition in Parliament.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON June 11 The Office of the Public Advocate, in a report on its first 18 months of operation, said today that it had found discord in state agencies and a disastrous lack of cooperation between public and private social agencies.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Assemblyman Byron M. Baer said yesterday that he would ask for a recount of votes in his Ninth Congressional District race with the incumbent, Representative Henry Helstoski, because of allegedly unusual voting patterns. Mr. Baer, Democrat of Englewood, was defeated by Mr. Helstoski by 1,656 votes last Tuesday.

title: RAE JEPPSON
description: Rae Jeppson, a former president of the Haarlem Philharmonic Society, died Thursday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Jeppson, is survived by a daughter, Dr. Janet Jeppson, and a son, Dr. John R. Jeppson.

title: Setback for Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 11The prolonged fighting in Lebanon has sent Soviet fortunes in the Middle East sliding to their lowest point in nearly a decade, with Moscow unable to exert decisive influence despite its long identification with the Arab cause. The eventual impact could yet compare with the blow that the Soviet Union suffered when Israel defeated its Arab clients in the 1967 war. For this time, the Russians have been reduced to watching the Syrians and Palestinians, whom they have backed politically and materially, fight each other with weapons of Soviet design.

title: Syria's Lebanon Intervention Said to Cost a Million a Day
description: WASHINGTON, June 11American and Israeli officials said today that they believed it was costing Syria as much as $1 million a day to maintain its growing military presence in Lebanon.

description: Foreign Exchange

title: Guerrillas in Angola Declare They Continue to Fight
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11A spokesman for an Angolan nationalist movement that was defeated in the recent civil war said here today that his faction had rallied support and was scoring gains in a continuing guerrilla campaign.

title: Reeducation Plan Pressed in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Fourteen months after they seized power in South Vietnam, the Communist authorities in Saigon have published a decree that seems to tighten controls over farmer members of the old antiCommunist Government and armed forces.

description: The Independent Investor Protective League, which claims a membership of 1,000 investors, has joined with Robert G. Morris, a Carmel, Calif., dentist, in filing a $30 fraud suit against the American Stock Exchangs and six Amex brokers identified only as John Does.

title: Production Ordered For Condor Missile As Tests Are Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, June 11(AP) The Pentagon today ordered initial production of a new Navy airtosurface missile following special tests to assure its reliability.

title: Prisoners of Castro
description: International agencies, official fir private, that try to monitor human rights violations around the world are often accused of concentrating their fire on rightwing governments and ignoring abuses by Communist regimes. The truth is that Communist rulers are often more ruthless and more effective in maintaining closed societies; and documented information from those countries difficult to acquire.

title: Bulova Tries to Make Up Lost Time
description: The Bulova Watch Company, which lost more money in the nine months ended last December than it earned in the four preceding years put together, is drawing a deep breath of hope.

title: Garbage: Where to Now?
description: FIVE years, they tell us. That's all we have, according to the state's Department of Environmental Protection, before New Jersey runs out of solidwaste disposal sites and starts drowning in garbage. Every solid citizen should stop wasting time and start being concerned, we are warned.

description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 12Syria and other members of the Arab League were reported to be close to agreement today on the details of establishing an Arab peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title: Olympic Trials Drama Starts Saturday

For more than 400 others, however, that road will reach a dead end at Hayward Field on the campus of the University of Oregon where the United States Olympic Trials begin Saturday and continue through June 27.

That is one day ahead the climax of the whole Operation Sail program, the marine parade up the Hudson River on July 4 and what will be the most elaborate extravaneanza of all the Bicentennial celebrations.

Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sarah Wiggin Slater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edmund Slater Jr. of Tuxedo Park, to Robert Armistead Wooldridge Brauns Jr., son of Mr. Brauns of Fishers Island, N. Y., and Naples, Fla., and the late Virginia Rue Brauns.

title: Trap Door Adds Twist To Don Giovanni Plot
description: LONDON, June 12 (AP)The bassbaritone Ruggero Raimondi, making his Covent Garden debut in Mozart's opera Don Giovanni, sank through a faulty stage trap door last night, leaving a firstnight audience aghast.

title: ARGENTINES FREE 25 LATIN EXILES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) All 25 political refugees from rightwing Latin Ameri can regimes who were abducted yesterday from two hotels were released today, United Nations officials said. Some had broken ribs and all had bruises.

title: Orioles Fall, 76; Loss Is 8th in Row
description: KANSAS CITY, June 12 (AP)John Mayberry blasted his fourth home run in four games and scored twice today, powering the Kansas City Royals to a nationally televised 76 victory over the staggering Baltimore Orioles.

title: French Driver Dies in Crash At 5Hour Mark at Le Mans
description: L.E MANS. France. June 12 A 30yearold French driver was killed today when his Datsun crashed into a guard rail and exploded about five hours after the start of the Le Mans 24hour auto race.

title: A Screwgy by Any Other Name
description: If you are a golfer and don't know your ace from a holeinone, you need a sports dictionary. On the other hand, if you think that holeinone is the sole meaning in sports of the word ace, you need such a dictionary even more. At least four other meanings of the word flutter around the sports world and they all appear in Webster's Sports Dictionary, a most unusual and, instructive book.

description: Susan Roy Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Thomas of Essex Fells, N. J., was married there yesterday afternoon to John James Heidrich Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Heidrich of Highland Park, N. J. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

It's not even to be read by parents and adult guardians who refuse to believe that there are occasions when it's impossible to write about a film withoutin the phraseology of angry letterwritersgiving away the plot. It's not only that one cannot write coherently about The Last Woman, a new Frenchlanguage film, without describing it in detail, but one isn't cautioning the reader about matters that, in this case, are the reader's right to know.

title: N.A.S.L. to Add 4 Clubs for77 Season
description: The North American Soccer League will expand to 24 teams next season, Phil Woosnam, the commissioner of the league, disclosed. He said each new franchise for 1977 would cost $1 million and added that several of the existing franchises were worth in excess of $2 million.

description: TORONTO June 12 (AP)JoAnne Carner shot a twounderpar 70 today to move into a threeway tie for the lead after the second round of a $60,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTONThe scenic view from the banks of the Potomac this week was as pleasant and inspriational as it usually is, but the perspective on the American economy from this vantage point was as cloudy and controversial as ever.

title: Literary New York
description: When the English took over New York in 1664 there was, except for one unmemorable poet, no literary New Amsterdam. Not until the 18th century could New York claim to be respectably literary, and this with claims that were mostly journalistic. Yet as the century advanced New York could boast of literary names who were also famous menPhilip Freneau; Alexander Hamilton and John Jay as writers for The Federalist; and Tom Paine, a lateinlife New Yorker.

title: Music
description: Robert Guthrie's first New York recital, Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, stamped him as a guitarist of intelligence and sensitivity with a welldeveloped classic technique. But the recitalist, who is chairman of the guitar department at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, played in an unremittingly bland style throughout his program, without sufficient rhythmic bit and with a soft, unassertive tone that gave a rather spineless air to generally clean and respectable performances.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayMotocross racing at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J. Gates open 3 A.M., practice at 9:30, races start at 12:30 P.M.

title: Epilogue
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence now reports that in March of 1972 the Nixon White House planned drug the columnist Jack Anderson, so that he would appear incoherent in a public appearance. According to the report, E. Howard Hunt, a White House aide and former C.I.A. employee, tried to obtain a hallucinogenic drug for the project from a retired Central Intelligence Agency physician. Mr. Anderson angered the Nixon Administration by publishing White House transcripts concerning the war between India and Pakistan in 1971.

description: PARIS, June 12The fact that other peoples do not suffer from liver attacks simply astounds most Frenchmenand their doctors as well.

title: INJURY CLAIMS SOAR IN NAVY SHIPYARDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The Navy's costs for injury compensation payments to shipyard employees is soaring, but the Labor Department will not investigate any of the claims, a Navy official says.

title: Albritton, Bell and Coghlan Capture A.A.U. Track Titles
description: LOS ANGELES, June 12 (UPI)Terry Albritton and Earl Bell, a pair of world recordholders, tuned up for the Olympic trials with triumphs in the shotput and pole vault, respectively, and Eamonn Coghlan coasted to victory in the 1,500meter run today at the 88th National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

title: What's Doing in ST. LOUIS
description: NEW SPIRIT OF ST. LOUISSt. Louis has stopped singing the bluesits own blues, that isthough W. C. Handy's version is still popular in jazz haunts down by the river. There is, in fact, a new spirit of St. Louis in the air; the old one, of course, was the plane, financed by St. Louis businessmen, that carried Charles A. Lindbergh nonstop from New York to Paris in 1927. With a population of 534,000. St. Louis remains the dominant city in the state of Missouri and is currently in the midst of its greatest period of construction since the St. Louis World's Fair of 1904. Eero Saarinen's 630foothigh Gateway Arch completed in 1965, is not only the monument to the conquest of the West that it was designed to be, but also a symbolic gantlet through which St. Louis has passed to reenter the American mainstream. The downtown area has been almost entirely rebuilt, beginning with the clearing of the 91acre Jefferson National Expansion Memorial, on which the arch stands. The memorial occupies the original site of the city, which was founded in 1764 by a New Orleans fur trapper, Pierre Laclede Liguest, and named for King Louis IX of France.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Price gains last Thursday and particularly Friday put the stock market ahead last weekinterrupting a sixweek decline that had left the Dow Jones average 30 industrials at its lowest levels since midFebruary.

title: Winning Their Hearts and Minds
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation once seemed as unapproachable as Chairman Mao.

title: ALBANY NOTEBOOK
description: NASSAU County Democrats in the state assembly predicted last week that the 1centonthedollar increase in the county sales tax, so ardently sought by the county's Republican leaderi, was dead for the session.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Several weeks ago (May 23) this column commented on the fact that there should be 11, not 10, medals in the U.S. Mint's special Bicentennial series of pewter reproductions of America's First Medals. The Continental Congress voted gold or silver medals for 11 military heroes of the Revolution, including Washington and John Paul Jones, but the Mint's series omits the medal awarded to Maj. John Stewart, a hero of the Battle of Stony Point. A Mint Bureau spokesman reports that the office staff has had to deal with a substantial flow of phone calls and letters protesting and questioning this omission. An official explanation is said to be in preparation; it will be published here as soon as received.

title: Knicks Hold the Key to Possible Merger With Rival American Association
description: The Knicks hold the key.According to the National Basketball Association constitution and bylaws, no team can move into an established team's territory without the consent of the original team in that territory. Merger?

description: In the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Priscilla Brooks Cushman, who will graduate from Harvard College on Thursday, was married to Rodney Lawrence Petersen, who will receive a Master of Theology degree on Thursday from the Harvard Divinity School.

description: ACASUAL observer of New Jersey government might feel that things had got into a mess while his attention was diverted by the Presidential primaries during the last three weeks.

title: Competition Keen in Black Magazines
description: Essence, a New Yorkbased woman's monthly reports revenues are up 45 percent in the first six months this year from last year, circulation is approaching 500.000, and ad pages are up 35 percent. We started off as a fashion magazine but realized that the black woman wasn't one dimensional, says Edward Lewis, publisher. The magazine now carries feature fiction, a frank sex column and general interest stories about blacks.

title: U.S. Open, Starting Thursday, Hard to Handicap
description: As the railbirds gather to handicap the 76th United States Open which begins Thursday at the Atlanta Athletic Club in Georgia, the customary procedure is to suggest Willie Wedge is hot, he's won three tournaments, countered with But that was back in February and March. I'd go with Peter Putter because he won his two more recently.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE 400 EELS OF SIGMUND FREUD. by A. G. Mojtabai. (Simon & Schuster,. $7.95.) Precocious teenagers work on esoteric scientific projects under frustrated adult dominance; intelligent, moving.

title: New Life for The Dead Man
description: Frank Furness's restored masterpiece of Victorian architecture, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, was such a dazzler when it reopened on its hundredth birthday last month, that the collection it houses was hardly noticed. Even Benjamin West's heroic Death on the Pale Horse in its conspicuous location in the main hall took on the air of a respectfully subservient decoration, a large mural commissioned in the romantic spirit of the building.

title: Jones's Putting Gives Him Stroke Lead Over Inman on 65205 in Kemper Golf
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 12 (AP)Grier Jones, trying to fight his way out of a long slump, oneputted 12 times on his way to a 65 that gave him a onestroke lead today in the third round of the $250,000 Kemper open golf tournament.

description: Hollywood Thinks War Is a Hell Of a Way to Make Money

title: Italian Migrant Workers in North Europe Begin Homeward Trek to Vote Communist in June 20 Election
description: SERAING, Belgium, June 7When Giuseppe Postillone returned to his native Potenza In 1945 from an Allied war prison, the economic plight and political immobilism of southern Italy drove him to the Communists. A few years later he left to work the coal mines of the Meuse River basin in Belgium, but he never left the. Italian Communist Party.

title: RAIDERS HARASS ANGOLA RAILROAD
description: LOBITO, AngolaThe railroad war Is dragging on with its heroes and deserters and at a steep cost for Angola, as well as the neighboring countries of Zambia and Zaire.

title: Sleeping Beauty The Crown Jewel Of Ballet
description: When Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov lead off a week of performances of The Sleeping Beauty for American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday, they will take part in a major event in the history of American ballet. For the first time, an American company will present the fulllength, fouract Sleeping Beauty on the operahouse scale in which it is usually seen abroad.

title: Handyman's Guide to Simple Masonry Repairs
description: When cracks appear in concrete or masonry walls, walks or patios, it is always a good idea to patch them as soon as possible in order to keep the condition from getting worse. Open cracks allow moisture to enter, which can hasten the deterioration process still further. In addition, during the winter when temperatures drop below freezing, moisture inside these crevices will freeze and expand, opening the crack or joist still more.

title: Sets Down Leis; 6th Victory in Row
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., June 12 The New York Sets won their sixth straight match tonight, beating the Hawaii Leis, 2824, before 3,289 at the Nassau Coliseum. The Sets now lead the Eastern Division with a 174 wonlost mark as World Team Tennis prepares to break for Wirdbledon.

title: A Concert Salute By Eight Vocalists To Reno Sweeney
description: A sampling of the performers who have played at Reno Sweeney since the West 13th Street cabaret was opened less than four years ago gave a salute to the club at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening.

title: A Dane Best at Denver
description: DENVER, June 12 The Great Dane frequently is called the Apollo of dogs. Today one climbed to the greatest heights in his show career, when he was named best in the field of 3,183 at the Buckhorn Valley Kennel Club fixture in the shadows of the towering Rockies.

title: NEWARK DIOCESE GETS COADJUTOR
description: NEWARK, June 12  The Rev. Dr. John Shelby Spong of Richmond was consecrated Bishshop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark this morning in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart. The ceremony was the first Episcopal service held in a Catholic church in New Jersey.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Satire, according to an ancient theatrical definition, is what closes in Philadelphia. That probably will not be quite true of Gian Carlo Menotti's The Hero, which had its world premiere in Philadelphia the other day. For one thing, fails as satire. But Mr. Menotti's skills and reputation are such by now that any major effort by him is sure to be picked up. The Hero will make the usual international rounds. And yet, what a difficult task Mr. Menotti set for himself. Verdi, turning to comedy when nearly 80, had it easy compared to Mr. Menotti, at 65, taking on the composing of a satirical opera on a political theme for America's Bicentennial.

title: A worthy heir of Coleridge
description: W. K. Wimsatt, who died last December at the age of 68. was more than a scholarcritic of distinctive and distinguished power, he was an institution. In an age which has more and more come to distrust institutions, he wielded his genially stringent mind to urge upon literature and criticism the fact that much of their own value is like that of a living Institution: a balance of past and present, of freedom and service of theory and practice of the concrete and the universal, of independence and interdependence.

title: One Artist's World

title: Endorsement, but Davits Won't Join In Senator Buckley Seems Sure of G.O.P.
description: Although Senator James L. Buckley is virtually certain to win the Republican State Committee's endorsement for reelection next Thursday, his Republican colleague. Senator Jacob K Javits, won't be endorsing the junior Senator. And no wonder. The two Senators are hardly peas in a pod. Quite the contrary, it's no mean feat for one pod and one party to accommodate their diverse views.

description: Mary Elizabeth Giegengack, professor of philosophy at Le Moyne College in Syracuse, will be married in August to John F. Jureller, a manager in the electronics system division of General Electric, also in Syracuse.

description: Nancy Patience Harden and Kevin Kellogg McGinnis were married yesterday morning in the Manning Chapel of Brown University. The Rev. Charles Baldwin and the Rev. Richard Dennenfelser, chaplains at the university, performed the Episcopal ceremony, which was written by the couple.

title: How the Voters Viewed It: With Yearning
description: WASHINGTONBack when the main question in the minds of many political handicappers was whether Senator Hubert H. Humphrey would be entering the Presidential race in early or late March, Carolyn Allen had already written him off. He might make the bestqualified candidate, she allowed a couple of weeks before the New Hampshire primary, but if it took somebody we overlooked all those times before it would be an admission of error on the part of the voters and therefore, she thought, kind degrading to us as a nation.

title: Food
description: Paul Poiret, who once called himself the King of Fashion, was also interested in the culinary arts and in 1928 he published a cookbook entitled 107 Recettes ou Curiosites Culinaires. Four of those recipes were chosen for the dinner at the opening night, May 24, of the Poiret exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology. I adapted the recipes, printed on this page, without many changes, except for the inevitable omission of exorbitant ingredients such as fresh truffles.

title: Breeze Causes Upsets In Olympic Sail Trials
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N. Y., June 12  Trials to select the United States Olympic sailing squad began here today in unexpectedly gentle fashion. A moderate breeze, hesitant and fickle, drooped for the final legs of the approximately twohour opening race and forced several of the favorites into the wrong place at the wrong time.

description: A pleased Governor Carey signed into law yesterday a $27 million aid package that will permit the reopening tomorrow of the 20 units of the City University, but at a cost of setting tuition in September for the first time in the 129year history of the institution.

So it has been for the Nassau Coliseumthe great institutional leap forward for Long Island that opened three years ago as much as a symbol of having arrived as a place for being entertained.

title: Medical Facility Is Beneficiary In New Purported Hughes Will
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 12 (AP)  Another purported will by Howard R. Hughes has been filed here, the 30th since the billionaire's death on April 15. It names the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Miami as the sole beneficiary.

title: Erwin Boy Captures 5th Race in Row on Turf
description: Sea High Stable's Erwin Boy, who has been climbing in class with surprising success ever since his trainer James Conway, decided last winter that the gelding was more partial to racing on grass than on dirt, reached his greatest heights yesterday.

title: 2 BUSING GROUPS MEET WITH FORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 12President Ford held separate meetings today with a group of prominent opponents of courtordered school busing and a group of citizens from five cities where busing is either in effect or in immediate prospect.

title: The Pick of the Crop
description: ANOTHER strawberry season is upon us. Anyone with a little time, an empty basket and a constitution resilient enough to weather some bending and stooping can gather ripe berries by the quart at half the store price or less. The season is a short onefour weeks at the most and the future may be short, too. There are half as many farms growing strawberries as there were five years ago.

title: Design

Not surprisingly, auctioneers in resort areas schedule the majority of their sales when they can attract the largest crowds. Collectors, they reason, will travel great distances to bid on bitters bottles. Tang horses, patchwork quilts, French bisque dolls or a rolltop deskespecially if sunning or surfing is possible between sessions.

Robert Edwin Sheridan Jr. of the Air Force in a double ceremony performed by the Rev. Theodore Ludlow in St. Thomas Episcopar Church.

title: The Three Worlds of Maui
description: When I step off the airplane in Maui, I feel cloaked by the climate, a kind of invisible suppressant that seems to retard the normal accelerations of mind, body andI suspecteven the functions of inanimate objects. I can imagine placing a record album on a turntable here and watching it circle at something less than 33.

description: THE Island's Democratic Congressmen are carefully staying out of the spotlight in the maneuverings growing out of the scandal involving Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, and the allegation, that he kept 33yearold Elizabeth Ray on the public payroll to serve as his mistress.

title: Chilean Wins Jumpoff
description: COLOGNE, West Germany. June 12 (UPI)Americo Simonetti of Chile won a jumpoff victory today at the international horse show from Hugo Simon of Austria, with Dennis Murphy of the United States placing third. The Chilean, on Alegandro, had a faultless 43.7 seconds to Simon's 44.1 aboard Lavendel. Murphy also faultless, was third in 51.2.

So can Ed Marinaro. Pro Johnson, the forFootball mer Giants running back who became a free agent last May 1 along with Riggins, Marinaro and 21 others in the National Football League, has not found the markes to be particularly responsive as he works the telephone along with Ernie Green, his agent.

title: RACE STILL ISSUE TO BRITISH PUBLIC
description: LONDON, June 12There is nothing quaint about the west London neighborhood of Southall. Americans who have bisected it on their way in from Heathrow Airport will recall if they recall enything about it, that Southall is uninviting and utilitarian, with broad, hot streets lined with flatfront discount houses and grocery stores.

title: TEAMSTERS UNION MEETS TOMORROW
description: LAS VEGAS, June 12If James R Hoffa were here, he would undoubtedly be challenging Frank E. Fitzsimmons for control of the largest and most powerful union in the country when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters first convention since 1971 opens here on Monday.

title: Keep Your Eyes Off My Paycheck
description: Ask anyone who works for a living the question, How much do you make a week? and in most cases the answer will range from the evasive to the downright hostile. In the etiquette of the workplace from the factory floor to the boardroom, it is gauche for one employee to pry into another employee's paycheck.

title: Paperbacks

One woman's journey from adolescence to maturity during the fractious 60's: a picaresque novel that touches down on the Florida Keys, at New England schools, in Manhattan's art world. THE ART OF EATING, by M.F.K. Fisher. (Vintage. $5.95.) Five books originally published in the 30's and 40's now in one volume: How to Cook a Wolf, Consider the Oyster, Serve It Forth, The Gastronomical Me, An Alphabet for Gourmets; the work of a writer who transforms the culinary arts into belleslettres.

title: The Bureau of Reclamation and Its Many Critics
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Bureau of Reclamation, an agency of the Interior Department, is almost unknown in the East. Its 73year history as the Government's major builder of damsbillions of dollars worth so far, and still risinghas been made in remote reaches of the Western states. But the bureau is no stranger to the bureaucratic canyons of Washington. And it is no stranger to controversy either.

title: Satellite Orbit Shifted
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. June 12 (UPI)The Marisat II marine communications satellite has been placed in a stationary orbit 22,300 miles over the Pacific Ocean with the firing of an onboard maneuvering rocket. The 1,445pound satellite, launched Wednesday, was in an elliptical orbit until Friday, when the rocket kicked it into its permanent orbit.

title: Danny Thompson
description: In his debut with the Texas Rangers recently. Danny Thompson got a single, a threerun homer and a double. His next time up, he got a standing ovation. I didn't know what to do. the 29yearold infielder recalled. I never had a standing ovation before. I had goose bumps all over. I didn't know whether to stand there or get in and hit or what. with two strikes, he *Sports got another single. *of Line drive up the *The *Times middle. he said. Four for four. It was great. I never had standing ovation before. But he deserves one every day. Danny Thompson has leukemia.

title: A Few Verses for Nixon
description: So revered in China is Chairman Mao Tsetung that public release of a poem by him inevitably mobilizes the multitudes to give homage and receive instruction. The poem must appear simultaneously in a number of journals. It must be searched for lessons, praised, translated, set to music, answered with other poems. Understandably, Maowho is believed to write many poemspublishes them seldom and tardily. Perhaps he would prefer to call this part of his life his own. Like others of his age and education, Mao writes reflective and epistolary verses, in a classical language and style that he confessedly hesitates to encourage among the young. Since few even understand such works, mass adulation of them risks seeming grotesque. Mao does publish his more edifying poems and those that have already spread uncontrollably in hand copies. Two new poems, made public this January, were actually written in 1965; one of them had longbeen known in the West from unofficial sources.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I followed with great interest your series on racial change.

title: AROUND THE  Garden
description: House plants can be moved outdoors, but not in direct sunlight; partial shade is best. Pinchback chrysanthemums if new growth is six inches taller. Take softwood cuttings of azaleas this month; root in sand and peat mixture.  This is the time to control taxus weevil; use a soil drench or spray basal foliage of rhododendrons and yew, particularly.

title: Growing Up With Phil Ochs
description: The last time I saw a performance by Phil Ochsthe young folksinger who committed suicide in April and was honored at a memorial concert at the Felt Forum on May 28was the day they buried Martin Luther King. It was April 9, 1968, and Ochs was singing on a doublebill with Richie Havens at the Westbury Music Fair, Long Island's theaterintheround. Westbury has a large, predominantly poor, black community, and as we left for the theater that nightfive nice Jewish boys wearing jackets and tiesrumors were circulating of a possible riot (reports of the revolution had spread all over the island that day, seeping into my high school, where a frightened administration enlisted the aid of the varsity club to guard the entrances in the event of an invasion). One friend almost didn't make it to the concert because her father had refused to let her attend unescorted. Arriving safely, we sat through the Havens set wondering whether we would be able to make it out alive.

title: ALBANY PRESSING FOR MERGED FUND
description: ALBANY, June 12Speaker Stanley Steingut Joined with follow Democrats in the Assembly this week to push for a sweeping consolidation of billions of dollars in state and local cash reserves for investment in inierestbearing accounts and use as a source for government borrowing.

description: Governor Carey endorsed Jimmy Carter for the Democratic nomination for President yesterday, joining a bandwagon already laden with supporters ind conventiondelegate strength.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A ceasefire first announced over the Damascus radio appeared to be taking a shaky hold in Beirut yesterday despite a report by the Beirut radio that a Syrian armored column was moving toward the sensitive Arkub region near the Israeli border. The Beirut radio confirmed the ceasefire, the result of mediation but it maintained that Syrian troops would be obliged to leave Lebanon in 10 days. The Damascus report of the ceasefire provisions was considerably less precise. It said that an end of hostilities should lead to an overall solution. There was no sign of a Syrian withdrawal in Beirut, but a blockade of the city's western neighborhoods eased a little. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: College Degrees Awarded To 24 Federal Inmates
description: LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 12 (AP)Proud relatives who came to graduation ceremonies here Tuesday night had to pass through metal detectors on their way to the ceremonies. The ceremonies were held in the Federal Penitentiary.

title: Quick Crops To Grow When Space Is Limited
description: If vegetable growing space Is limited, choose those crops with the greatest yield. Also those that mature quickly will make room for successive plantings during the season.

Guggenheim, industrialist, pioneer sponsor of aviation and rocketry and a cofounder and publisher of Newsday, at his death in 1971.

title: Mexico elects a symbol
description: MEXICO CITY. On July 4, Jose Lpez Portillo will be elected President of Mexico. Because he has no opponent, he will win 100 percent of the valid votes cast. Yet, since October, he has been stumping the country as if the result were in doubt. By election day, he will have traveled perhaps 40,000 miles, giving hundreds of speeches, attending thousands of meetings and being seen by millions of Mexicans.

description: Elizabeth Maria PlaterZyberk and Andres Martin Duany, architects and principals in Arquitectonica of Coral Gables, Fla., were married yesterday afternoon in St. Norbert Roman Catholic Church in Paoli, Pa. The pastor, the Rev. Walter J. Burke, performed the ceremony.

title: Sunday Observer
description: At first I did not recognize Grimsby. He had undergone a radical change of clothing since our last meeting in Washington during the Kennedy Administration. In those days he always wore a dark threebutton suit with narrow lapels and a hard nose, which was the uniform of the New Frontier. Now he was wearing a frayed straw hat, bare feet and overalls, and was carrying a fishing pole. On Park Avenue he looked so out of place that I would have passed by hurriedly  New York streets teem with maniacs, many of whom think they are Huckleberry Finnhad he not extended his hand and said, Howdy, y'all.

title: Jeweler Slain, Policeman Shot, Two Seized in Brooklyn Holdup
description: A Brooklyn jeweler was killed in front of his wife, an offduty police officer was shot in the chest and two suspects were arrested yesterday following a holdup in Brooklyn's Gravesend area.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the March 21 issue James Joll, in an otherwise favorable review of my book, The Last European War, included the disturbing statement that my implication almost seems to be that Hitler made it impossible for honest antiSemites to express their not totally unfounded views. I have neither written nor implied anything of the kind. Since many of your readers will not have read my book I am compelled to quote from it. The decisive argument, I wrote, is the mass murder of the Jews. It is be cause of this sad and horrible deed that Hitler may never inspire the respect that is sometimes the due of a Napoleon. Innocent Jewish children, mothers, old men, young people, together with other millions, vanished without a trace from the earth. Their blood stains our memories, a stain that may have saved later Jewish generations from the scourge of persecution, a stain that is large enough to darken Hitler's place in history, for a long time perhaps forever.

title: China Reports on Gains For Its Television Network
description: PEKING, June 13(AgenceFrancePresse)China has de??? its television network greatly over the last 10 years, the newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao reports.

title: Meeting Mr. Vorster
description: Southern Africa is drifting toward catastrophic racial war. Obviously the United States must do whatever reasonably can to help avert such unnecessary disaster. Recognition of these realities has brought nearly every': one even remotely concerned with the problem approve Secretary Kissinger's decision to meet in West Germany later this month with South Africa's Prime Minister, John Vorster.

title: U.S. COURT SHIELDS DATA OF SCHOLAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 12A Federal judge in California has ruled that a Harvard professor need not disclose information obtained confidentially in the course of adadernic research.

title: Accusations in Fiscal Crisis
description: The RockefellerLindsay years may have spoiled New Yorkers in more ways than one, for not only were the state and city budgets richer and blacker then; so were the public tiffs of their two chief executives. In contrast with the waspish, photogenic enmities of Mayor John V. Lindsay and Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, New Yorkers have been left with a much more cryptic struggle between Mayor Beame and Governor Carey.

title: BRIDGE
description: Forming a partnership is a very simple matter for the vast majority of bridge players. A few simple questions such as Do you use Stayman? or Twobids, weak or strong? usually suffice. For a duplicate game, five minutes may be needed to fill in a variety of items on a convention card. And for wouldbe national champions two or three hours may be required not only to discuss scientific devices but also to avert misunderstandings by determining whether bids are forcing or not.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: L.B.S., Kingston, N.Y. lives on a campus that has 100yearold ginkgo trees, two female and one male. The female produces odiferous fruit in fall. He asked if there was a way to prevent fruit, and also if the fruits are edible. We have checked with several nurserymen and tree specialists and there appears to be no way of preventing the old female ginkgo trees from setting fruit. Modern nurserymen, well aware of this undesirable fruiting habit, propagate only the male trees which do not fruit. In fact, female trees are difficult to obtain now for this reason. Although the ginkgo fruits are not edible, the nuts are a delicacy in Chinese cuisine. The nuts are about the size of jelly beans, and are cooked, never eaten raw. They can be obtained canned or sold by the pound in Chinese markets. Ed.

title: ART VIEW
description: About the Andr Masson retrospective that has now come to the Museum of Modern Art, it is difficultperhaps impossibleto have anything but a divided response. Mr. Masson is now 80 years old, a veteran of the Surrealist epoch in French art who, during his wartime exile in the United States in the early 1940's, also played a role in shaping the formation of the New York School. His place in the history of modern art, though by no means a major one, is thus more or less assured, yet as an artist he is a curiously elusive figure. In the past, reading about him and seeing certain pictures, one had every reason to believe in his importance, yet these pictures were never quite numerous enough, and never quite powerful or definitive enough, to confirm that importance. One had to take a great deal on faith. It required, one felt, a fullscale retrospective to settle the matterto reveal the artist who somehow remained obscured by a distinguished career.

title: Solomon, Panatta Gain French Final
description: PARIS. June 12  Harold Solomon has done it again.

description: Belmont Charts

title: New Phone Calculates While You Chatter
description: Add one more to the growing list of calculator gadgetry aimed to tantalize the fingers of the publicthe telephone calculator.

title: Reagan Wins 18 of 19 AtLarge Delegates in Missouri
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 12 Ronald Reagan dealt President Ford a severe blow today, taking 18 of 19 atlarge delegates in Missouri, a state where the Ford forces once thought they faced no serious threat.

title: The pill turns twenty
description: It was in the spring of 1956 that the Massachusetts biologist Gregory Pincus and a group of collaborators embarked on the first widespread trials of the contraceptive pill in Rio Piedras, a workingclass suburb of San Juan. Puerto Rico. Since that time, its use has grown to the extent that today some 30 million women use it all over the world, including 10 million in the United States and 2.8 million in Britain. It is a pharmaceutical product unlike any other, and its continuing daily use by those 30 million women must constitute one of the most remarkable programs of medical treatment in the history of the human race.

title: Scorpion Is Sailing Winner
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 12Jack Sutphen's Scorpion, a 10yearold Trippdesigned, aluminum sloop from Larchmont, N.Y., won the top class in the Off Soundings Club's annual spring racing series, which ended here today. The large fleet of 172 distance racing yachts, most of them small, completed the second day with a race around Block Island in a nearperfect. 20knot northeast breeze.

title: Jennifer C. Hoagland Is Married
description: Jennifer C. Hoagland, aneditorial assistant with Classic, a magazine about horses and sports, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael D. Sargent, a trainee with Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers.

title: Bring Back Ferries
description: NlCK CARRAWAY, In Great Gatsby, described end of the Island's SUM season this way: Most the big shore places were closed I and there were hardly any lid except the shadowy, moving glow a ferry boat across the Sound.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater 3, 21

title: Alive and together in the park
description: A lovely Sunday in June, warm and soft. Coming out of my building I walk my bike around the dog droppings and broken glass. Our block, mostly renovated, middleclass, seems deserted for the weekend, except for the Puerto Ricans in the welfare tenement who have taken their Schaefers and Maltas outdoors. Bags and boxes of garbage, set upon the overflowing cans, ripen in the sunlight, but the men languishing on the stoop or on folding chairs seem oblivious to the smell, the indignity.

title: U.S. Envoy in Johannesburg Shuns Whites Only Concert
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 12 (AP)The American Ambassador to South Africa, William Bowdler, has refused to attend a symphony concert for whites only to mark the United States Bicentennial, a Johannesburg newspaper reported today.

title: At Farley Funeral, All Is Not Sadness
description: James A. Farley was buried yesterday after a final salute from the great clan of politicians whose ambitions and stratagems were the consuming joy of his long life.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: On Brook Trout
description: ENFIELD, N. H.We made the 35minute climb up the mountain to Cole Pond with a little less alacrity than when we first visited it 25 years ago. But the surge of delight when we reached its wooded shores was the same.

title: Teton Dam Disaster
description: The saddest aspect of the Teton Dam disaster that has cost many lives and enormous physical damage in Idaho is that it was wholly predictable indeed, it was predicted. In 1973, Shirley Pytlak, a former Bureau of Reclamation geologist, warned that the geological structure of the land on which the dam was Constructed made it a highly dangerous venture.

title: Air Force to Train Six As Women Navigators
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 12 (AP)  Six women officers who are to be chosen as the first women Air Force navigators will start training at Mather Air Force Base here next March.

title: Major League Averages
description: Records Include Games Played Friday Night

title: Norway Fights Oil Pollution
description: OSLO, June 12 (Reuters)The Norwegian Parliament has decided that six depots should be established along the coast to fight possible oil pollution.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Burlington County K.C. allbreed and obedience, Parade Grounds, Fort Dix, N.J.; 9 A.M.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ??? guests, inandouters and stayovers. The door opened and a pleasant man came in carrying a small, empty planting box. He looked thoroughly distraught.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jane 12 (UPI)Rhodesia said today its jet fighters have pounded a Mozambique army post in retaliation for a threehour mortar and rocket barrage from its neighbor and told another neighborZambiato take it as a warning.

title: B1 Prototype Ends Tests
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (Ap) The first prototype B1 bombcompleted its performance and flying quality tests with a flight yesterday at Edwards Air Force Base in California, the Pentagon has announced. The flight, the 32d for the prototype, included a performance climb to 26,000 feet, lowspeed operations and a sound and vibration test. The plane achieved top speed of 510 miles an hour.

title: Ford's Invitations To Big 4 in Europe Irk Small Nations
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 12President Ford's invitation to four West European leaders to attend a meeting in Puerto Rico in late June has caused a dispute inside the Common Market.

title: Blocking Drug Channels
description: SINCE November 1974, New Jersey has been trying to slow what it considers an alarming increase in the diversion of legitimately manufactured drugs into illegal channels. The state believes it may be making a big dent in this multimillion  dollar  a  year racket.

title: Conservatives Endorse Buckley, Liberal Party Picks Stern for U.S. Senate Race
description: Senator James L. Buckley, whose term expires this year, was designated by the Conservative Party's state committee yesterday for the party's nomination for reelection. And the Liberal Party's state committee chose Henry J. Stern, the Manhattan Councilman at Large, for its nomination.

title: What the Aid to Britain Proves
description: WASHINGTON  Last week, the United States and the other major industrial countries of the West assembled another massive international package to rescue the beleaguered pound, putting up $5.3 billion in standby credits to help support Britain's ailing currency.

title: National Affairs
description: DETROIT, June 12 (UPI)Mayor Coleman A. Young, entorcing a centuryold residency statute, suspended 132 city employees without pay yesterday. Most of them were white policemen and firemen who vowed to appeal the move.

title: A Farewell to Moms
description: ALL along Northern Boulevarc the last week in June is the occasion for an annual ritua as huge crowds gather a parking lots lots for Camp Departure.

title: What Part Does The Pentagon Play?
description: With Midway scheduled to open Friday, and Apocalypse Now and A Bridge Too Far currently shooting, Hollywood is obviously betting that war movies will once again make a boxoffice killing. If these films prove successful, future war movies are sure to be made and doubtless will continue to benefit from the Pentagon's longstanding policy of providing filmmakers with technical adviceand more importantuse of personnel and equipment, either free or at minimal cost.

title: Portugal Prepares to Choose President
description: LISBON  Portugal is about to elect a new president, thus completing a twoyear effort to organize a democratic republic after a half century of dictatorship. But settling the institutional problems will still leave the country as unsettled as it has been since the revolution in April 1974.

title: LANCASTER HELPS NEEDY CHILDREN
description: Lancaster County in Pennsylvania is a region of old home steads and farms spread over acres of green land.

title: The Nation
description: With the announcement by House Speaker Carl Albert that he will retire at the end of this Congress, the season for canvassing for support for positions in the House Democratic leadership has officially opened. The turnover in the House along with that which will occur in the Senate next year, will constitute one of the most complete changes in Congressional leadership in recent history.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Miss Rogers, Designer, Wed
description: The First United Methodist Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Virginia Beatrice Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight L. Rogers Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, to Jeffrey Vance McCormick, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Stanley McCormick of Manchester, Conn.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Our house is located at seaside and we have steel windows and doors. Contrary to specifications, these metal frames were not galvanized, and as a result we have rust forming on many of them and the paint is now peeling off in places. Ripping all these out and replacing them would not only he very expensive, it would be quite a mess. Would it he possible to strip all the paint off and then apply some kind of undercoat that would protect against the seawater and rust before new paint was applied? H. W. Chicago.

title: INVESTING
description: Advertising agency securities, viewed as high flyers in the 1960's and then relegated to the basement as unseasoned issues, have started to pick up some steam again. Many of themalthough still selling well below their historic highsare near their highs for the year.

title: New Towns Facing Growing Pains
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Conceived in a visionary atmosphere, nurtured by promotional hyperbole and born in the construction industry's boom times, America's new towns are now experiencing growing pains and learning that the gap between design and execution can be a formidable one.

title: End of Impasse On I78 Sought
description: THE state's Department of Transportation is moving to end the deadlock that has blocked completion of a fivemile gap in Interstate 78, which is already finished over most of the distance between the Holland Tunnel and a point south of Easton, Pa.

title: Raising the Legislative Profile
description: When a planeload of Vietnamese children crashed near Saigon last year, a 19yearold student nurse who had volunteered to be an escort on the airlift to the United States helped rescue survivors despite her own injuries. Her name is Susan Derge and she lives in Centerport. In recognition of her heroism the Air Force has presented her with a certificate of annreciation

title: New TwoYear Contract Covering School Supervisors Is Aimed at Increasing Their Productivity
description: Negotiators for the New York City Board of Education and the Council of Supervisors and Administrators have reached agreement on a new twoyear contract aimed at increasing the productivity of principals and of other supervisors.

title: Soviet Runner Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, June 12 (UMValentina Gerasimova, a Soviet runner, set a world record today in the women's 800 meters of 1, minute, 56 seconds at a Soviet athletics meeting in Kiev, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. Miss Gerasimova, 27 years old, shaved 1.5 seconds off the former mark held by Svetla Zlatevoi of Bulgaria.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, CHAIRMAN of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the economy is in better shape than the forecast at the beginning of the year.  The Commerce Department revised its estimate of capital spending to $121.03 billion, up from the March estimate of $120.06 billion.  Ford and General Motors set tentative price increases of 6 percent on 1977 model trucks.  Savings banks in New York state had a net deposit inflow of $293 billion in May, up from April's $261 million net inflow.

title: The Changing Junior League
description: FOR years, Junior Leaguers were the elite and the rich, the debutantes and the dilettantes, the elegantly coiffed and dressed, the wives sand daughters of the ruling class. Some still are.

title: Lyric Arts Trio Offers Mostly Romantic Music
description: The New York Lyric Arts TrioMary Freeman Blankstein, violin; Marion Feldman, cello, and Gena Raps, piano, all Juilliard graduates played mostly romantic music in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night.

title: Internal Chaos and an Embarrassed Pound Are Only Part of
description: LONDONThe British pound, adorned with bejeweled portraits of Britain's kings and queens, was once the oil of world trade. But now the pound in trouble and it has become a symbol for all the other troubles afflicting Britain.

title: Joan L. Roosevelt to Be Bride Of Peter Lasher Schoonmaker
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Roosevelt of New York and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. Roosevelt's daughter, Joan Lindsay Roosevelt, to Peter Lasher Schoonmaker. The bridetobe is a daughter also of the late Anne Clark Roosevelt and a granddaughter of the late President and Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: PIPELINE FAULTS IN ALASKA PERSIST
description: ANCHORAGE, June 12Despite management shakeups, Federal intervention and supposedly tightened inspection practices, reports of construetion flaws and technical violations continue to come almost daily from the halffinished 800mile Alaska oil pipeline.

title: Foreman vs. Frazier: Knights Go Forth
description: One more time, Joe Frazier kept saying, one more time.

title: Nader Today: His Main Interest is in Getting Others Organized
description: WASHINGTONTen years ago this month a relatively obscure Connecticut lawyer was haunting the halls of Congress, lobbying for a bill he passionately supported. On June 24, 1966, the Senate overrode the objections of one of the most powerful segments of American industry and passed legislation requiring the Federal Government to set automobile safety standards.

title: 159 ANIMALS JOIN ENDANGERED LIST
description: WASHINGTONThe Interior Department, in its most sweeping such action to date, is adding 159 animals to the Federal list of endangered species, assuring protection to animals of the world from every continent.

title: Forger Freed by Bad Check
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 5 (AP)The Alabama Supreme Court, admitting it is unfair and repugnant to logic, ruled yesterday the a forger cannot be sent to prison for writing a check that is worthless because it was dated on Sunday. With few exceptions, state law makes a check void if it is dated on the Sabbath, the court noted in nullifying an eightyear sentence given to Roosevelt Williams in Madison County.

title: It helps to invent outies who are not you
description: High school, like youth itself, is best appreciated from a safe distancesay, 20 years. Even then, it hurts when you laugh. And if you stop laughing, it hurts worse.

title: Craig McDaniel Weds Jean Robertson
description: Jean Ellis Robertson, daughter of Dr. Douglas Hosmer Robertson and Mrs. Robertson, known professionally as Dr. Ruth Geissinger, of Mount Kisco, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Craig Milton McDaniel, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. McDaniel of Suitland, Md.

title: Dance: Thesmar Visits
description: Ghislaine Thesmar, a French dancer who has star ranking at the Paris Opera Ballet, made her debut with the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater. She was seen in Suzanne Farrell's original role in In G Major, the first Jerome Robins ballet given at the City Ballet's Ravel Festival last year.

title: PANAMA IS URGING PATIENCEON CANAL
description: PANAMA, June 6The Panamanith Government has adoptel an unexpectedly lowkey approacli to the problem of a new canal treaty with Washington just as the issue is attracting public attention for the first time in the United States.

title: The Politics Of Defense
description: PARISOne of the least understood political issues in France is military policy including relations with NATO and the United States. The misunderstanding is more divisive for the governing coalition of President Gistard d'Estaing's Independent Republicens and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's Gaullists than between the Government and the Socialistled opposition.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DESTINY (Hellenic). Dubai July 13. Karachi 20, Manama 26, Darman 30; sails from 57th St. Brooklyn.

title: Barbara Wilson Is Bride
description: The marriage of Barbara Elise Wilson to Arthur St. Clair Morse Jr. took place last night in the St. Regis Roof. Rabbi Richard A. Weiss performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Wilson of West Hempstead, L. I. Mr. Morse's parents are Mrs. Clifford De Haven of Interlaken, N. J., and Mr. Morse of North Long Branch, N. J.

title: Beautful  Swimmers Watermen. Crabs and the
If It's Pants You Want, Pants You'll Get In Many Styles
description: It's not exactly that women are losing their pants. They're lust gaining some variants.

title: Eyewash? Or an Open System?
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 12Primaries, President Harry Truman said, just before losing one to Estes Kefauver in 1952, are eyewash. So it proved that year. Senator Kefauver won all the primaries in sight but Mr. Truman and the other Democratic Party leaders counted him out on the third ballot at the convention, and drafted Gov, Adlai E. Stevenson of millinois.

title: Hooooooowwwwwwwwllllllll
description: JAMESTOWN, R.I.One of my ancestors, George Clymer, signed the Declaration of Independence. Another of my ancestors came over here during the Irish potato famine and found life here better than life there. One of my grandfathers was a Naval Academy graduate. My father was a career naval officer. I didn't graduate, but I was and am a member of West Point's class of 54. With a history like this, you'd think I'd be a reasonably patriotic sort of guy. If you thought that, you were wrong.

title: Texas Rescued by Double Play
description: The New York Yankees pursuit of their long, lost championship was interrupted last night when four pitchers for the Texas Rangers combined to defeat them, 21, in Yankee Stadiumwhere no pennant has flown in 12 years.

title: O'Connor's Triumph in Mile Is Highlight of State Track
description: The mile, with an outstanding field of young runners, was won by Dave O'Connor of Valley Central in the junior class state record time of 4 minutes 10.8 seconds. O'Connor had an exciting homestretch duel with Steve Francis, also a junior, from Arlington High outside of Poughkeepsie, who was second in 4:11.2 on the handsome facility at White Plains High School.

title: Role Reversal
description: Four weeks before its national convention, the Democratic Party is in the unusual position, for it, of having already acquired its nominee, Jimmy Carter, and with a minimum of intraparty strife. The Republicans, on the other hand, not only lack a nominee nine weeks before their convention, but wilt pass that time in murderous internal warfare between President Ford and Ronald Reagan.

title: San Diego Nude Beach Draws Tourists From as Far as New York
description: SAN DIEGO, June 12A portly man in a flamboyant plaid jacket, his camera loaded, got out of a crosscountry bus at the Greyhound depot this week and announced:

title: Best Sellers
description: Mau market paperbacks are sold on newsstands, In supermarkets and variety stores, as well as bookstores. This analysis based on report: from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10.000 outlets in the United States.

title: Tinker to Evers to 76
description: This is my 40th year as a follower of the Chicago Cubs. I am not your basic cardcarrying Cub fan, born out there someplace and reinforced in my allegiance by an entire subculture. I was born on Crown Heights in Brooklyn within the shadows cif Ebbets Field and just a nickel away from the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium. Since our early choices have such an influence on our future selves, I am using this anniversary and this Bicentennial year to reflect on this decision and to chronicle its subsequent history.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It is difficult to imagine two major dance companies more dissimilar than New York City Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet. Admittedly, City Ballet can boast of a few Danish dancersincluding that Danishdefected superstar, Peter Martinsand it's true, also, that the Danish Ballet can boast that soon after the death of Serge Diaghilev in 1929 and the subsequent breakup of the Diaghilev Ballet, for a brief period George Balanchine was its balletmaster. What would have happened had he stayed? Just as the eloquently arrogant Balanchine claimed in an interview that had he stayed le London there would be no Royal Ballet today, presumably he would imagine that had he stayed Copenhagen there would be no Royal Danish Ballet today. It is amazing that in New York, in the face of such an ego, American Ballet Theater has managed to survive! Undeniably, Mr. Balanchine runs a different kind of shipbut luckily there are many kinds of captains. No company, not even City Ballet, can claim to represent the State of the Art, as it does in its mildly pretentious advertisements. Such copywriting whimsy is merely offensive to people of cultural sensibility.

title: Mary C. Stern And F. G. Sykes, Banker, Marry
description: Mary Congden Stern, daughter of Mrs. Oscar N. Stern of Wilmington. Del., and the late Dr. Stern, was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick George Sykes of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ainsworth Sykes of Dwcbury, Mass., and Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

title: Guns as Sport
description: STATE Senator Alexander J. Menza, Democrat of Union, has proposed legislation that would phase out legal ownership of handguns. An article by Nathaniel Sheppard Jr. on Feb. 15 quoted Mr. Menza as having said: The response to my white paper has been incredibly vicious and I am shocked and amazed.

title: Recognizing Poison Ivy
description: POISON IVY may fool you. It likes to grow along fence rows and rock walls, often mixing with other shrubby or vining plants in such a way that it is not noticeable.

title: Beirut CeaseFire Gains; Syrian Drive Is Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12A ceasefire appeared to be taking a shaky hold in Beirut tonight, though the Beirut radio charged that a Syrian armored column was moving toward the Arkub region near the Israeli border.

title: New York Representatives Seek Leadership Positions in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The 39member New York State delegation, the secondlargest in the House of Representatives, has decided to seek to place a New Yorker in the House Democratic leadership with the hope that he will eventually rise to become majority leader or Speaker.

title: DINING OUT
description: THEY'RE not kidding. This is an authentic chalet, complete with overhanging roof, balcony and decorative wood trim set into a hillside opposite the railroad in alpine Roslyn. It was built 100 years ago as the gate house of an estate.

title: Endpaper
description: 1. Being nostalgic about things in New York that never were so great.

title: Pop Notes: A Grateful Reunion For All Dead Heads
description: Hard  core fans of the Grateful Dead  and hardcore fans alone  will pack the Beacon Theater on June 14 and 15 when the San Francisco rock band plays its first engagement in the metropolitan area in two years. Tickets to these concertsboth have long been sold out had been made available only to Dead Heads, the 78,000 enrolled members of the Grateful Dead fan club. To accommodate the overflow, the group will also play at Jersey City's 30,000seat Roosevelt Stadium on July 2, violating for the occasion its rule of playing only in moderateSized arenas.

title: U. S. Aides Decry Arab Motion Against Israel at U.N. Conference on Housing
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 12A victory by the Arab bloc in persuading the United Nations Conference on Human Settlement to adopt a resolution obliquely criticizing Israel has evoked a threat by United States spokesmen to boycott such United Nations meetings in the future unless extraneous politics is excluded.

title: Dance: Alicia Alonso
description: The return of Alicia Alonso to the fold of American Ballet Theater had been long overdue. It is always unfortunate when politics interferes with art, but, of course, it is usually politicians rather than artists who make it so. However, we in the United States have been denied Miss Alonso for many years, ever since Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba, and although in the last year she has given three gala performances with the company, she has not really danced here in her own proper repertory.

title: 33% Slain in New York Don't Know Killer
description: One of every three murder victims in New York City last year did not know his killerapparently giving New York the country's highest rate of slayings classified as stranger murders.

title: Stamford A Small Hub Of Wealth And Power
description: STAMFORD, Conn.The workers look like ants, the trucks like toys and the buildings like those cardboard models that architects and planners like to exhibit when announcing grandiose projects.

Lawn chairs or blankets suggested. (201) 7978705. In the event of rain on either night, a performance will be held on June 20.

title: Young Voters Bolstering Italian Communists
description: ROME, June 12Maria Louisa Grossi is 22 years old, a student of architecture at the University of Rome and the daughter of a government engineer. Her parents are both voting for the Liberals, a small conservative party, but she is voting for the Communists.

title: Two Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: The movie makers are feeling a nagging slump at the box office this year and are resorting to sequel mania to cure it.

description: The level of anxiety in the household of Arlene Goldman, a senior at Brooklyn College reached a peak on Friday just before it became definite that the Legislature would approve money to reopen the City University.

description: Carol Ann Black was married yesterday morning to Jonathan Lenard Levy.

title: Miss Herbert
description: Christina Stead was born in Austrails and began to write there, ??? moved to England and to the United States, where she married an Amer ican, a bestselling novelist who called himself William Blake. During the 1950's the couple left New York ??? England, and, after his death a ??? years ago, Miss Stead returned ??? Australia, where she now lives, ??? come full circle. Fourteen dazzlin works of fiction make splendid use ??? her intimacy with all these locales.

description: Karen Clews Ramsing and Christopher Noel Luhn, graduates of Washington College in Chestertown, Md., were married yesterday afternoon in Holmdel. N.J.

description: The marriage of Susan Ilene Goldberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Goldberg of Baltimore, to Martin Joel Weintraub, son of Mrs. Loy Nilson of Englewood Cliffs, N. J., took place yesterday evening in the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation Temple in Pikesville, Md. Rabbi Herbert M. Brockman performed the ceremony
