description: Yachting Results

title: TV VIEW
description: Barbara Walters is only the most publicized tip of the changes being made in television news departments this year. Other recent shifts in talent, both on and behindcamera, have been widespread and will affect all areas of newscastingnational and local, daily and documentary, event ccveratze and specials. Something is happening: yet, oddly enough, no one seems to know precisely what it is. The changes are merely cyclical, some say. They are cosmetic, others say. They reflect profound concern. They are indications of panic. And so on. Whatever the explanation, the general upheaval cannot be denied.

title: New Kid on the Block
description: A sportswriter visiting Los Angeles wound up one evening in the home of Bill Goetz, the movie man who collected art and racehorses. There was hardly time to discover that a party was going on before one of the guests, a pleasant man with blue eyes and a sorrel cowlick, strolled up. Without preamble he asked: Who played second base for the St. Louis Browns of 1929

title: Kira F. Albertson Wed to David Gee
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kim Faith Albertson daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Albertson of Locust Valley, L. I. and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., to David Stephen Gee, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Gee of Greenville, Del., and Buck Hill Falls.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Criminals At Large

title: Artificial Wrist Joint Hailed In Fight Against Arthritis
description: CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) An Arizona physician says that a newly developed artificial wrist joint has permitted about 50 patients to regain had mobility after losing it because of arthritis.

title: PostIndustrial Capitalism
description: STOCKHOLMSweden, as much as any nation can, has served as a laboratory for the democratic industrial societies of the world. And it may be doing so again, for the postindustrial society.

title: Traveling Wayward Buses
description: We all want our DeCamp driversa most competent, polite and pleasant group of mento obtain every cent and concession they want in their new contract. We also want the owners of the DeCamp lineI understand they have gone to Florida to weather the striketo make profits never before contemplated, simply because we like them. And we want all the potholes on all the roads between where we catch our DeCamp bus and the Port Authority terminal to be filled and smoothly tarred.

title: Of Tourism and the Soul: The Caribbean Dilemma
description: Smile, said the dapper little man with the Adolphe Menjou mustache. That's right. Turn to your neighbor and smile. His audience, most of them women, most of them black, reacted on cue. See how easy it is. he said. They giggled. A tiny gray banana bird flitted over their heads.

title: Democratic Platform Unit Calls for 3% Jobless Rate
description: WASHINGTON, June 12A subcommittee of the Democratic Platform Committee approved unanimously today a section of the platform calling for the right of all Americans to jobs and setting a goal of a 3 percent national adult unemployment rate within four years.

title: SALYUT 5 SLATED, 2 ASTRONAUTS SAY
description: PHILADELPHIA. June 12 (UPI) Two astronauts who spent 83 days in the Soviet Union's Salyut 4 space laboratory last year said today that a Salyut 5 was in the works and might house men in orbit for as long as three months.

title: Miss Weeks Wed To T. R. Miner Jr.
description: Barbara Alice Weeks and T. Richardson Miner Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in the Mead Memorial Chapel of Middlebury College. The bride has recently been named director designate of alumni relations at the college, where her husband is assistant to the president.

title: Ships to Salute July 4 Their Own Way
description: All the noise that will be heard on the Fourth of July will not be attributable to firecrackers and cherry bombs. A good deal of it will be cannon fire from what the Navy calls honors and ceremonies.

title: Deaths
description: ABBOTTFrances M., June 9, 1976. Beloved sister of Helen T. Abbott and the late Harrison R. Abbott. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 3d Ave. at 85th SI., N.Y. Funeral Mass, Our Lady of Poaco Church, Monday, 10 A.M., E. 62d St. and 2d Ave., New York City. Interment St.

title: Ox Ridge Show to Open Wednesday
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Showthe only major event in the East managed entirely by its membersgets under way for five days on Wednesday with the $10,000 Grand prix the featured attraction. Except for two years recently, the Ox Ridge show, one of the most prestigious in the country, has been run entirely by its membership for its 47 years of existence. The cochairmen this year are David M. Wright and Bill Williams.

title: Yesterday's fashion fits today
description: The lines are soft and flowing. The mannequins in sinuous crepes and sheer cottons do not wear bras. Other mannequins are in dresses held in loosely at the waist by means of drawstrings. Most coats are either cocoonshaped or are full and roomy at the top with deep armholes. There are headwraps, boots, harem pants. The interplay of brilliant color and luxurious fabrics is rich and arresting. Throughout, adroit use of handcrafts of various national origins expresses a cultivated, eclectic appreciation of artistry.

title: Amy Nixon Married to Peter C. Blasier
description: Amy Bovaird Nixon and Peter Cole Blasier were married yesterday afternoon in the Shadyside Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh by the Rev. Dr. Robert C. Holland.

title: Lion Berrie
description: TWENTYTWO Junes ago, memb of the North Shore Lions Club Mattituck went into the lo strawberry fields and picked abt 300 quarts of berries. Then they bak shortcakes, whipped cream, arranged booths and kiddie rides and held a Stray berry Festival as a fundraising projec About a 1,000 people showed up. TM Strawberry Festival has since become annual event.

title: B.E.P. Aids Tourists
description: In order to accommodate the steadily increasing number of Bicentennialyear visitors who want to tour its paper money production facilities, the U.S. Bureau of Engraving and Printing (located at 14th and C Streets in Washington, D.C.) has streamlined its tourhandling system. Admission tickets (no charge) will now be issued on a firstcome, firstserved basis, beginning at 8 A.M. for morning tours and 12:30 P.M. for afternoon tours (Monday through Friday, no weekends or holidays). A limited number of people can be handled on each 25minute tour, and only that number of tickets will be distributed. When all available tickets have been issued, a notice will be posted to save purposeless waiting by visitors who arrive after that time. The B.E.P. emphasizes that tour tickets cannot be obtained in advance; they will be honored only on the date of issue. A 24hour B.E.P. tour information telephone service has been installed; the number is 2029647611 or 2029647173.

title: Italian Leaders Prompted U.S. Stand on Communists
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The State Department last fall began taking a strong public stance against Communist participation in the Italian government in part because of encouragement from Christian Democratic Party leaders, according to Administration officials.

title: GAIILLISTS AGREE TO BACK TAX BILL
description: PARIS, June 12France has narrowly avoided a political crisis that threatened to break up a coalition Government, but tensions remain high between President Valery Gismrd d'Estaing and the Gaullists, who form the biggest part of his parliamentary majority.

title: Truck Sales Gain Outpaces Autos
description: DETROITBusiness has been picking up for me and everyone else, says Harold Dixon who makes his living hauling 110,000 pound loads of steel to auto and appliance manufacturing plants in Michigan.

title: Miss Ray Said, to Link Tryst to Building Project
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Elizabeth Ray has told Federal investigators that Represerttative Kenneth J. Gray, her employer at the time, ordered her to engage in sexual activity with Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, because he wanted to influence the Senator's vote on the construction of a parking and visitor information facility at Washington's Union Station, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: Scranton Off on 3Week Africa Tour
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 12William W. Scranton, the United States delegate, left today on a threeweek African tour.

title: Can'tDo Gooders
description: ALOCAL employer contacted the Division of Vocational Rehabilitation Services here recently and said he wanted to employ a handicapped worker. The job vacancy consisted of a clerical position with light typing and related clerical duties.

title: CARROLL KEARNS, EXCONGRESSMAN
description: MEADVILLE, Pa. June 12 (UPI)Carroll D. Kearns, 76, a former Republican Representative from the 24th District, died Friday in Meadville City Hospital.

title: Pro Boxing in Peril For Women in N.Y.
description: A bill that would have allowed women to obtain a license for boxing, sparring or wrestling in New York State has been amended in such a way that it could limit women to boxing only on woman In Sport in Women an amateur level. The bill, which Sports was introduced in Albany in March by Senator Linda Winikow and Assemblyman Charles E. Shumer has caused concern among some woman boxers who feel the bill will take away their right to earn a living.

title: ART
description: WHAT might possibly be a first for art buffs is being offered by the Summit Art Center, where the sculpture of Anne Arnold, Toshio Odate and Isaac Within is now on view. The coincidence of such a mixture is unlikely, for their works are so different in form and feeling that even the most enterprising curator would not think of mixing them.

title: Hood Wins Astor Race With Abino
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 12Ted Hood's new One Ton sloop. Abino Robin from Marblehead. Mass., won the 175mile Astor Trophy race today which began off Oyster Bay. L.I., yesterday evening. The event was a feeder race for yachts assembling here before the start of next Friday's ocean race to Bermuda.

title: Wary Truce Between Allies
description: ONE year after a bitter personal feud between Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, and Eugene R. Kelley, the County Police Commissioner, flared into the open, their professional relationship remains strained.

title: C. A. Saks Weds Mauranna Lynn
description: Mauranna Gerarda Lynn and Christopher Andrew Saks were married yesterday afternoon in St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. The pastor, the Rev. Thomas Guinan, performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Mark Connolly.

title: Book Ends
description: Book Clubs. As is our wont from time to time, let's take a look Into the crystal balls the two major book clubs employ to predict what their over twomillion members will want to buy several months from now. Before the prognostication, though, we'll run down some of the current winners with the clubs. The losers were left unsaid; book club people live in the future.

title: Louise Whipple Is Wed in Chapel At Princeton U.
description: In the Princeton University Chapel yesterday afternoon, Louise Barton Whipple, daughter of Mettle Barton Fisher of Princeton, N. J., and the late Sherman L. Whipple 3d of Locust Valley. L. I., became the bride of Andrew MacCornack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. MacCornack of West Sayville, L. I.

title: ExNixon Aide to Head Ford's Effort in South
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., June 12 (UPI)Harry Dent, a lawyer here, who was an aide to President Richard M. Nixon, says he will head President Ford's Southern search for delegates.

title: City University Plans
description: Baruch: Remaining examinations will be given as appropriate. Commencement date to be announced. Summer session registration will begin June 21 with classes opening on July 3.

title: Susan Douthit, Boston Alumna, Wed to Analyst
description: Susan Helen Douthit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Douthit Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Watch Hill, R. I., was married yesterday afternoon to James MacLeod Alexander of Hartford, son of Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Mrs. Alexander of Washington and Cincinnati.

title: The $359 Waikiki Package
description: I always wanted to go to Hawaii, said the man from Erie in the powderblue leisure suit. We were standing in line to check our bags at the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport. But all of the programs I looked at were too expensive. Now this one cost my wife and me less than $400 apiece. He suddenly got a worried look on his face. But, I've got to admit, I'm a little apprehensive. These packages are new and as cheap as they are, well, they may not be so great. I have my fingers crossed.

title: Suzanne Wiedel, Writer, Bride of Eric Pace in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 12Suzanne Monique Wiedel, a freelance writer, was married here today to Eric Dwight Pace, The New York Times Teheran bureau chief.

title: The British Embassy Has a QueenSize Problem: Getting Set for Elizabeth's Bicentennial Visit to the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The embassy's roses have been pruned with hopeful vigor, the ballroom's chandeliers have been taken down for cleaning, prism by prism, and it has already been decided that Mrs. Abraham Beame will stand next to the Duke of Edinburgh.

title: Sun Valley Lodge Burns
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 12 (AP)The original Sun Valley at the Sun Valley resort was badly damaged by fire early today. Spokesmen said that all 160 occupants had been evacuated in orderly fashion.

title: Crime by Computer
description: Donn B. Parker, a senior information processing analyst at Stanford Research Institute, has put together a detailed account of computer abuses that range from filching a competitor's trade secrets out of a timesharing computer system to the multibillion dollar Equity Funding fraud in which computers were used to create 64,000 bogus insurance policies and to flummox four auditing firms and armies of supposedly sophisticated investors.

description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 12Residents here ended a twoyear wait this week when the State Commission on Special Revenue granted a license to a Long Island promoter to build a $55 million thoroughbred and trotter track on the northwestern edge of the city.

title: June Feiss Is Married
description: June Olivia Feiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Feiss was married yesterday to Ronald Leonard Hersh, on of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Hersh. Both families are of New Rochelle, N. Y., where the ceremony was performed kg Temple Israel by Rabbi Amiel Wohl, Rabbi Ronald Gerson and Cantor Sumner Crockett. Mrs. Hersh is a magna cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Her husband graduated last year from Johns Hopkins University.

title: Era Dawris fot Atldritic City With Debut of Night Racing
description: MAYS LANDING, N. J., June 12Blighted by steady declines in attendance and betting, Atlantic City Race Course finally saw the light tonight.

title: Oxygen Monitor May Reduce Birth Defects
description: A West German wifehusband team of doctors has invented a device that promises to reduce significantly the number of common birth defects such as mental retardation and blindness that are caused by abnormal oxygen levels in the blood during and shortly after birth.

title: Newspaper Reader in Princeton
description: At present, the Johnson institute occupies both a former Penns Neck school off U.S. 1 and a former warehouse nearby. Mr. Johnson hopes to put up his own building in the area within six years, when present leases expire.

title: Mariette Ladd Becomes Bride In Connecticut
description: Mariette Chandler Ladd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delano W. Ladd Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Madison, Conn., was married yesterday to Oliver W. R. Champagne Jr., son of Mr, and Mrs. Champagne of Paris.

title: Some Viewing Sites
description: NEW JERSEY officials expect the outpouring of tourists to watch Operation. Sail on July 4 to be the biggest in United States history, 5 million people or more. A large number will be on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River during the festivities.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Not a man jack of us will ever get it through his head just how treacherous stage life can be. The real thing can appear in the meanness of an eye, no more than that, in the sudden uncoiling of a body hitherto immobile against a pillar. It says Here I am, and you listen, and drama's with us without warning. But it can also promise and promise and promise to appear a whole night long, two and onehalf hours of teetering on the verge of meaning and excitement, without ever finally putting in an appearance: the groping never touches a hot stove, an exposed nerve. And it can be there and disappear with a terrible finality, taking permanent leave without so much as the tip of a hat or the hint of a forwarding address.

title: U.S. Ombudsmen Urged For Small Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Senator John J. Sparkman says that each Federal agency should establish an ombudsman through whom small businessmen anonymously could funnel complaints regarding the Government.

title: Diana F. Schereschewsky Is Bride
description: Diana Faulkner Schereschewsky of Washington, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Covington Hardee, board chairman and president of the Lincoln Savings Bank of New York. The Rev. Haig Nargesian performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 9:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Maria D. Gravel, director of the Seton Day Care Center.

title: When It's Roundup Time in Chincoteague
description: The little town of Chincoteague on Vir ginia's Eastern Shore is preparing for its 51st annual pony roundup and auction from July 28 through 30 this year, an event that is expected to attract 50,000 visitorsand upwards of 150 ponies.

title: The MindReader
description: Among those middleaged poets who speak in a moderate voice, Richard Wilbur has won his share of awards and plaudits, but his virtues leave us somewhat uneasy. While we acknowledge his erudition and urbanity, we regretfully liken his mildness to the amiable normality of the bourgeois citizen. Emergencies are absent in his poems; he is unseduced by the romantic equation of knowledge and power; he seldom rails at the world. Suspicious of grandiose gestures, of parading the ego, he mediates experience through reason.

title: Two Retrospective Reports on the Presidential Primaries
description: WASHINGTON  If only he would have listened, there Were dozens of professional politicians and political analysts who could have explained to Jimmy Carter two years ago why he could not make it as a Presidential candidate. They (actually we) would have told him that the lesson of 1972 was clear proliferating primaries drive out the moderates and aid the extremists.

title: Raspberries Taste Best If Grown At Home
description: Let's face it, the only way to have good fresh raspberries these days is to grow your own. Roadside stands sell them out as fast as they can be picked. And fresh frozen ones are just not the same.

title: Military in Uruguay Ousts President Over Policy Differences
description: MONTEVIDEO. Uruguay. June 12 (AP)  The armed forces ousted President Juan Maria Bordaberry today because of irreconcilable differences and replaced him with his SOyearold vice president, Alberto Demicheli.

title: How to Get To Falaise
description: Visitors must call 8831612 for an appointment before driving to the estate for a tour. Take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 36 and drive north on Route 110 (Searingtown Road, later becoming Port Washington Boulevard and Middle Neck Road). Falaise is about a mile north of the IBM Country Club, beyond Port Washington, on the righthand side of the road.

title: Hays Alert for First Time After Overdose of Pills
description: BARNESVILLE, Ohio, June 12  Representative Wayne L. Hays, fully alert for the firsts time since he took an overdose of sleeping pills Wednesday night, ate a light liquid breakfast and asked to see a newspaper today but made no mention of why he swallowed what doetors say could have been 10 times the prescribed dosage of the drug.

title: Letters: On Taxis, Buses and Subways
description: The Letters Column this week is devoted entirely to correspondence addressed to the Travel Editor in response to the three articles under the heading, New York by Subway, Taxicab and Bus, which appeared in this section on May 23.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Transit Authority's Culture Bus Loop II will operate on a new summer schedule beginning today. The loop's buses will depart from Court and Remsen Streets, in Brooklyn's Borough Hall section, every 20 minutes instead of 30 minutes between 9 A.M. and 6 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and selected holidays. The buses may also be boarded at any of the loop's 32 stops in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: DINING OUT
description: Because the older crowd eats fairly early, trie restaurant is virtually empty by 8:30 P.M. and the kitchen closes at By that time, however, the action has moved to the bar the next room, a convivial spot that keeps going for several more hours.

title: Gay E. Jenter Is Wed To Warren K. Flynn
description: Gay Elizabeth Jenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Jenter of Pelham, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Warren Kingsley Flynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren G. Flynn of Pelham Manor, N. Y.

title: Why they love Earl Butz
description: He has antagonized or alienated food shoppers, environmentalists, labor leaders, social reformers and religious and ethnic groups. He is blamed for high food prices, accused of hurting small farmers and of playing politics with malnutrition and hunger and he is charged with disrupting the nation's foreign policy. His only real friends are the big farmers, and, if this summer's expected bumper crop on the Great Plains affects their income as some anticipate, he may soon lose them, too.

title: Ruling Due Soon on Status Of Cohn in Rosenstiel Will
description: MIAMI, June 12A Dade County Probate Court judge expected to make a ruling next week that Is likely to decide control over the estate of Lewis S. Rosenstiel, the financier, whose holdings have been conservatively estimated at close to $75 million.

title: Hofstra Law School Dean Sues F.B.I. for Data in File on Him
description: The dean of the Hofstra University Law School has filed suit in United States District Court in Brooklyn to require the Federal Bureau of Investigation to disclose to him everything in its files regarding his activities beyond 27 items already turned over.

title: Crazy Angelo meets the Preacher
description: It's 9 o'clock on a Thursday night and Crazy Angelo from Brooklyn has been waiting for the Preacher for more than a halfhour. Angelo is known in the street as a scary dude, the very model of a young Mafia hit man. But on this brisk March evening he is nervous, and he sits behind the wheel of his Cadillac in the parking lot of the Belrose Diner in Queens stroking his mustache and chainsmoking Marlboros.

description: Intelligence reports from field trapping stations monitored by the Los Angeles County Agricultural Commissioner contained disturbing news in September 1975. Wild Mediterranean fruit flies had invaded that area of California, and their ranks were spreading. The flies have been known to attack and injure some 200 varieties of fruits and vegetables.

title: CHESS
description: The National Chess League, a ninecity series of sixman team matches, started its first season conducting the play by telephone. Travel expenses and time were saved and, consequently, players other than fulltime professionals were able to take part. The matches were held on Wednesday evening.

description: VANCOUVER. British ColumbiaHabitat, the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements, came out strongly in favor of public participation in community planning, and for major clearance and renewal projects only when renewal of existing neighborhoods is not feasible.

Club.

description: Susanna Whitney Griswold, daughter of Mrs. A. Whitney Griswold of New Haven and the late Mr. Griswold, president of Yale University from 1950 until his death in 1963, was married yesterday afternoon in New Haven to Edward G. Kaleck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Kaleck of Shelton. Conn.

description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) 7 The Senate sent to President Ford yesterday a bill authorizing the Government to acquire Gen. George Washington's winter campsite at Valley Forge, Pa., as a national park.

description: TEAST HAMPTON HERE'S nothing to do. We're just waiting for something to happen.

title: At the Front With Joe Levine
description: In this sleepy Dutch town, with its brick church towers and arching iron bridge over the Ijssel River, Richard Attenborough is directing what he calls a totally antiwar film for Joseph E. Levine. The movie, A Bridge Too Far, based on the best seller by the late Cornelius Ryan, is the true story of the tragically fouledup Allied paratrooper attack on the Rhine Bridge at Arnhem. It is a tale which strikes Attenborough as the perfect vehicle to demonstrate the stupidity, the suffering and the desperate heroism which go hand in hand in war.

title: The Real Provence: Getting Lost Is The Way to Find It
description: ??? slopes (cateaux) of Tricastin named for the hills which rise gradually from the valley of the Aygues River; when there are hills to protect vineyards from the mistral, and gradual slopes to let them baste in the sun, the wine is likely to be very good indeed. The devil in me wanted to stop at every winemaker along the way (they had evocative names like Cave Costebelle, Cooperative des Meaux, Cellier des Dauphins). In St.MauricesurAygues I stopped to watch housewives who had brought their laundry to wash in the public lavoir. They weren't expecting guests, and I tried not to be conspicuous.

title: A Respite of Sorts at Stony Brook
description: FACULTY members at the State University Center at Stony Brook last week hailed a decision by a State Supreme Court justice that struck down the university's plan to eliminate its education department.

title: Political News Showed Up Show Biz On TV
description: In this year of supposed antipolitics, when the political spirit of 76 has been widely pictured as drooping and negative, the Neilsen ratings reveal that the special coverage of the state primary elections on television has drawn significantly larger audiences than the networks usual lateevening programming. For example, in the period between Feb. 24 and April 6, when primaries were held on six of seven Tuesdays, the networks lateevening programs averaged these ratings: The Johnny Carson Show (NBC), 6.8; movies (CBS), 5.4; Wide World of Entertainment (ABC), 5.8. The average ratings for, the coverage of the results of the primaries, which preempted the first halfhours of these entertainment shows, were: NBC 8.8; CBS 7.1; ABC 6.0. In terms of votes, a combined audience of 18 million was tuned to Carson, et al., while some 25 million viewers had cast their ballots for the primarynight coverage.

title: Democrats Coalesce
description: If a political planner back in January had written script to contrive the best possible result from the Presidential primaries for the Democrats and the worst possible result for the Republicans, he could hardly have improved on what has actually occurred.

title: Kintucky Plane Crash Kills 2
description: WEST LIBEATY, KY., June 12 (AP)Two persons were killed today when a twin engine aircraft crashed shortly after takeoff at the airport here, according to the Morgan County Sheriff's office. The dead were identified as Sohn Frederick and James May, both of West Liberty. Two other persons in the plane escaped serious iniury.

title: The Franchiser
description: By Stanly Elkin.342 pp. New York:Farrar, Straus & Giroux. the American delta, and pulls into a service station. There he asks the attendant just where the hell he is? The attendant answers first with the street name, but then, when Ben persists, with the name of the city. Birmingham. But Ben still isn't satisfied. Michigan? Alabama? he asks the bewildered attendant. The answer happens to be Alabama, butto judge by the view from the highway (low modern buildings of new industrial parks, their parking lots comfortably settled with latemodel cars)it could just as well have been the other.

title: LETTERS
description: To The Editor: In Hilton Kramer's article. A Yearning for Normalcy The Current Backlash in the Arts (May 23), there is no disputing his contention that we are witnessing the decline of the avantgarde in the arts, as we are witnessing the decline of radicalism in politics. It is also true, as. Mr. Kramer suggests near the end of his provocative article, that avantgardism has in fact come to the end of its term.

The result may be to give Prime Minister James Callaghan and his Government a breathing space to deal with the underlying causes of Britain's economic difficulties.

title: Serious games, tasty crabs and a natural writer
description: and the Consecration of the American Spirit. By Michael Novak. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: Basic Books. $10.95. ??? be of a higher order than mere entertainment: Sports are far more serious than the dramatic arts, much closer to primal symbols, metaphors, and acts, more ancient and more frightening. To justify his fandom, he will get it down and break its knees: instead of crying uncle, it will be made to mumble of a Kingdom of Ends, an Age of Enhumamnent and liturgical enactments of animal perfection and the struggles of the human spirit to prevail.

title: Seewagen Victor, Gains Tennis Final
description: Butch Seewagen, the Columbia University coach, and Herb FitzGibbon of New York reached the final of the New York State men's tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside. Queens. They played in the final last year and Seewagen won.

title: Meadowlands Park Planned
description: THE Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders is weighing proposals to create a park on 200 acres of the Hackensack Meadowlands below the new Sports Complex.

description: ALBANY ACUT in electric bills that may amount to as much as 15 to 30 percent is forecast for residents of the three Long Island villages with municipally operated power systems.

title: Condominiums Due in Queens Project
description: After years of controversy, the VlussTankoos Corporation is close to inal approval for its plan to build a $150 million apartment, shopping and office complex in Rego Park, Queens.

title: The Audience Can Almost Hear Him Ticking
description: In David Rabe's new hit play, Streamers, when a sad sack of a soldier called Carlyle stumbles into a barracks, chin sunk onto his chest, eyes moving restlessly, searching for another black soldier he's been told about but never met, the audience can almost hear him ticking. By the time the explosion conies, two acts laterhe kills two men, and subsides into a whimpering bundle of olive drab ragsa spectator feels only pity and tiredness, not anger. It is a triumph of the playwright, of course, but some of it belongs to an actor named Dorian Harewood.

title: KOREAN HOPEFUL ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: SEOUL, South KoreaOver many years of struggle to restore democracy in my country. I have often lost courage, said the 78yearold man, but I have a hope. I have a hope now that some day we will once again have democracy in South Korea.

title: Seasickness Study Tale of Woe
description: A recently released survey shows seasickness is a problem for 22 percent of all boating families and 37 percent of their guests. And that applies only to those who admit it. According to the study, made at the National Boat Show in New York by Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical concern, seasickness occurs more frequently in an adult than a child, and a woman is more susceptible than a man. There also is a slight tendency for a person to become more sensitive to motion sickness as weight increases, says the Pfizer study.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMThe most recent developments in the Lebanese civil war have demonstrated both the strength and the limitations of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: FISHING
description: NEW JERSEY fishermen have a choice this week. The surest way to guarantee a catch is to stick with fluke inshore and seabass offshore. But for the sportsman, June is stripedbass monththe best time to land that elusive fighter.

title: Proponents Win Fight to Keep Berkeley Traffic Barricades
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 12 City officials in this politieally highstrung town, all too familiar with riots and barricaded streets in the 1960's, found themselves at the barricades again last week fighting to keep them up. They won.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: There has been a great deal of interest in old photographs in recent years on the part of museums, galleries, historical societies and individual collectors. This has caused many to realize that insufficient attention has been paid to determining the best methods for caring for them, or restoring those that have already begun to deteriorate.

title: Outdoor Heroics In Sculpture
description: PENNS NECK IF J. Seward Johnson Jr. had his way, there would be sculpture on view in every community the United States. Big sculpture. Human sculpture. Superrealistic sculpture.

title: J. R. Matson Weds Cornelia B. Long
description: Cornelia B. Long, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Long of Jackson, Miss, was married yesterday to J. Richard Matson at the Park Avenue Methodist Church by the Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke.

title: Economically, Suburbs and City Can't Escape Each Other
description: We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang separately.

title: Fashion
description: It was inevitable that the age of extravagancethe childhood of this century, which today we call, wistfully, La Belle Epoqueshould beget an arbiter etegantiarum as extravagant as itself. He appeared in the person of a couturier who described himself as imperious and Venetian; who carried on a longlasting love affair with gold lame; who had his initials perforated on his shoes; who bridled women in pearl chin straps half a century before Paco Rabanne began harnessing them in metal; who pillaged the exoticism of the Orient to evolve Chinese goldembroidered cloaks and Hindu turbans sprouting aigrettes; who appeared at one of the fancydress balls he liked to give as Jupiter, hair and beard painted gold; and who outdid even this fantasy in the spring of 1911 when he entertained le ToutParis at a Ball of the Thousand and Second Night, which has yet to be surpassed in sumptuousness.

title: How Crude
description: Oil prices in America probably will keep climbing during the year despite the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Bali to freeze prices at the existing $11.51 a barrel level.

title: 4 Charged in Car Bombing Of Rothschild Bank Branch
description: PARIS, June 12Four members of an antiZionist group were charged here yesterday with responsibility for the bombings of a Rothschild bank branch office and a police station late last month.

title: Winner Ridden By Miss Bacon
description: KENT, Conn., June 12 Twentieth Century Limited, a consistent foxchaser all season, captured one championship and finished as reserve titleholder in another division today at the Kent School horse show.

title: Developing World Gets More Economic Help From the West
description: WASHINGTONIn Rome this week, major Western nations and oilrich Arab states will join together to pledge funds for a SI billion reserve to help poor countries grow more food. Absent from the proceedings of the International Fund for Agricultural Development will be both the Soviet Union and China.

title: U.S. Takes Curtis CUD Golf
description: LYTHAM. England, June 12 (AP)Beth Daniel, the Ame'ican women's amateur golf champion, led the United States to its ninth straight victory over Britain today in the Curtis Cup matches.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: New York Racing Future
description: To the Sports Editor Clyde Hirt's attack on OTB in this space was surprisingly shallow and unfortunately biased. He is a reporter in the racing industry and, therefore, should know better.

title: Kansas City, Arena for the Last FordReagan Joust
description: WASHINGTONWhen Republicans gathered four summers ago in Miami Beach to pick a Presidential nominee, they knew not only what the outcome would be but when. A splitsecond White House script choreographed everything from the impromptu demonstration that was to interrupt one convention speaker in midsentence to the precise duration (10:3310:45) of the hoopla that was to greet the renomination of Richard M. Nixon.

title: Weddings
description: Weddings

title: Notes: Trails Cleanup Faces an Uphill Climb
description: A campaign to persuade backpackers to clean up and otherwise improve the nation's trails has so far produced almost 200,000 hours of work. The project, called One for the Trail (the One refers to one hour's work per person), was initiated last July by the International Backpackers Association, which was formed four years ago by Lance Feild of Lincoln, Me. The idea was to encourage hiking clubs and trail associations in each of the 50 states to put in 20,000 hoursa million hours ha allcleaning up backpacking routes by July 4 of this year as a cooperative Bicentennial effort. The drive has been lagging, however, and the association has extended it through Dec. 31.

title: Gouverneur Hospital Periled by Political Controversy
description: Gouverneur Hospital on the Lower East Side, born only four years ago out of political controversy, is threatened with death now by the same process.

title: Headliners
description: In 1912. a political unknown, James A. Farley, ran for Town Clerk in Stony Point. N.Y., and advertised his campaign by sending postcards to every voter. The voters responded by electing him. Afterward, he sent each a thankyou note. That personal touch became Mr. Farley's political trademark, and helped him to rise through the ranks of county and state organizations to become the most powerful Democratic party leader in the country. Mr. Farley almost singlehandedly maneuvered the Democrats into nominating Franklin D. Roosevelt for President in 1932. He was a party loyalist above all else, and prided himself on having attended every Democratic Convention since 1924. Democratic leaders said he was to have been named honorary chairman at next month's Democratic convention. But last week he died, at age 88.

title: STAMPS
description: John Trumbull was the inevitable choice for a commemorative issue to observe the Bicentennial of the American Revolution. It is through Trumbull's eyes because of the effective way his paintings depicted the momentous events of 200 years ago and the men who took part in them, that Americans of today envision the climactic moments in the struggle of the Colonies to gain their independence.

title: NEW YORK STATE SELLS MORTGAGE
description: ALBANY, June 12With little fanfare, the state completed the first of a chain of critical transactions this week to divest itself of $260 million in mortgages on middleincome housing projectsa step that aides to Governor Carey said marked a significant turning point in the long fiscal crisis.

title: Old South Bows to New As Wallace Meets Carter
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 12Jimmy Carter came to this old city today to express his sincere gratitude to Gov. George C. Wallace for a public endorsement of his Presidential candidacy.

title: Predicted Order of Finish in Olympic Track Trials
description: MEN

title: The City's Biggest Gallery Show Twits The City
description: They gape and giggle at the Subway, an oversized version of a lurching IRT car, jammed with oddball plaster people. They're titillated by the Porno Shop, a Times Square storefront where juicy paperbacks are pawed by prurient peepers made of vinyl. And they're mesmerized by the Woolworth Building, a 15foothigh extravaganza of carved wood and fiberglass, with a money dragon wrapped around its middle.

title: The Proper Perspective
description: ONE of the most portant and influtial art historians the 19th century Alois Riegl a German I losopher whose enlighter writings greatly broader the idea of the nature of art work.

title: Man Sentenced to 20 Years in 72 Loan Sharking
description: A lian shark who preyed on borro ofs in Westchester County and in the Tampa and Clearwater areas of Florida has received a maximum sentence that could keep him in jail for the rest of his life.

title: Dogsleds, a Mountaineer's Pick and a Balsa Raft Help a Shy Japanese Adventurer Fulfill a Few Dreams
description: Among the future plans of the 35yearold Japanese are dogsled journeys from Canada across the ice cap to the North Pole and another across northern Siberia from the Bering Strait to Norway to complete his overland circuit of the Arctic Ocean.

title: Peter Martins Emerges As a Star
description: I'm a stubborn Dane. When I first came to the New York City Ballet, I thought I knew everything. I certainly didn't think George Balanchine could teach me anything. I was also going through a phase then when wanted to be Erik Bruhn. I was fascinated by his image and his elegance; I wanted to be everything he was, and more. It took me a couple of years to get over that and begin to grow up. What really happened was that Balanchine took over. He took over my mind, and he educated meas a dancer and as a person.

title: Letters
description: I am not a closet atheist. I would have gone to the Society of Separationists convention (There are no churches for atheists by Walter Goodman, May 16) had I known of it. If in the course of a discussion the argument warrants it, I declare that I am an unbeliever. But I recognize that from the earliest days of primitive man there has been a vital inner need for a faith, a belief, a worship of something outside themselves on the part of great masses of people.

title: RacingTire Boom Is Predicted for 76
description: Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, which drastically cut back its involvement in motor racing after the 1974 season, anticipates a 50 to 60 percent increase in the production and sales of race tires for the 1976 season, according to Firestone's race tire sales manager. In a recent issue or the NASCAR International Newsletter, William R. McCrary was quoted as saying that NASCAR's modified and latemodel sportsman divisions and other pavedtrack racing will make up the major part of the expansion plans, although increases were anticipated in drag racing and sports car competition as well.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The results of a study made by The Rand Corporation under the sponsorship of a division of the United States Public Health Service suggests that, contrary to general thinking, some alcoholics can safely return to normal drinking after receiving treatment. The findings, disclosed last week, were criticized as dangerous and misleading by groups seeking to cure alcoholism, which regard abstinence as the only reliable form of recovery.

title: G.O.P. Contenders Woo Uncommitted in Missouri
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 12The uncommitted delegates at the Missouri Republican convention were not saying today just what they were looking for. For those delegates, whose decision may ultimately prove crucial at the party's National Convention at Kansas City in August, and possibly the Presidential nomination, it was enough that President Ford and Ronald Reagan were looking for them.

title: The Lardners
description: I was struck by the enormous deference that the Algonquinites felt for Ring Lardner  he was somehow aloof and inscrutable, by nature rather saturnine, but a master whom all admired, though he was never present in person. It may be that all any such circle demands is such a presiding deity, who is assumed to regard them with a certain scorn. So at least says Edmund Wilson, our late flowering Pepys.

title: Discord at East Berlin Meeting Dims Outlook for Reds Parley
description: EAST BERLIN, June 12Prospects for the longawaited European Communist conference have dimmed once again as Communist officials from East and West have run into fresh trouble during a twoday preparatory conference here.

title: Europe's Worry: Prices, Not Jobs
description: LONDONAt a meeting of European finance ministers in Brussels a few days ago, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, made an observation that raised a good many eyebrows.

title: Simpson Asks Trade
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 12 (UPI)  O. J. Simpson, tired of being away from his family in Los Angeles during the football season, said today that he had asked to be traded by the Buffalo Bills to a West Coast team  preferably the Los Angeles Rams  for one last year of football.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees conclude their series against the Texas Rangers at 2 o'clock today in Yankee Stadium then entertain the Mets tomorrow night at 8 o'clock in the Mayor's Trophy game. The Los Angeles Dodgers come into Shea Stadium for 8:05 P.M. games against the Mets Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. The San Francisco Giants play the Mets here Friday night at 8:05, Saturday at 4:05 and Sunday at 2:05.

title: Court Keeps Highway Ban In Plea for SandhiII Cranes
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 12 (UPI)A Federal appeals court has refused to reconsider its decision blocking construction on an interstate highway that conservationists say would destroy the only home of the world's last 40 Mississippi sandhill cranes.

title: Gale Winslow Married To Winthrop G. Minot
description: Gale Oakley Winslow and Winthrop Gardner Minot were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: Youth Stabbed In London
description: LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) A white youth died from stab wounds in East London tonight following a series of demonstrations organized by immigrant groups protesting recent attacks on Asians and by rightwing groups objecting to Asian immigration.

title: Golf Clinic
description: Weekend golfers often are told they get too much right hand in their swings. Actually, it isn't so much that they overuse the right hand as it is that they don't use the left hand enough.

description: ROME. June 12The Italian election campaign, entering its final week is generating increasingly bitter exchanges between the governing Christian Democrats and the challenging Communist Party.

description: Here is what I see: Directly ahead, the lawn slopes to a fastflowing wide creek, at this moment dazzling with sunlight. On the far side, a wooded hillside rises. Between creek and hill lies the road, along which perhaps one car has passed in the last hour.

description: OLD FORGE, N.Y., June 13 (UPI)A 41yearold hair stylist won top honors today at the seventh annual New York State fiddler's contest at the Enchanted Forest here.

description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 13 They had to do things very badly, a Reagan manager said of the Ford managers, even to let us make it close.

description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., June 13 (UPI)  Jimmy Carter, reaffirmed his support, of the equal rights amendment and announced the creation of a women's committee to advise his campaign staff and seek women to serve his administration.

title: The Vice Presidency
description: Acting in accord with an old political tradition, Jimmy Carter as the prospective Democratic Presidential nominee has made it clear that he intends to keep his own counsel on the choice of the VicePresidential candidate. Moreover, he plans to withhold the name of the person he has selected until after he himself has been nominated. Mr. Carter would do well to reverse himself on both points.

title: SYRIA HAS NO PLAN TO QUIT LEBANON
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 13 Syria made it clear today that it had no intention of withdrawing a sizable portion of its military forces from Lebanon in the immediate future.

description: PEKING, June 13 (Reuters)Chinese arrested after the political riots here in April have been subjected to mass criticism at meetings attended by hundreds of workers, it was learned today.

title: BUILDING IN JERSEY SHOWS AN UPTURN
description: Homebuilding activity in New Jersey, after dropping last year to the lowest level in a quarter century, is on the upturn again in most counties. New construction across the state is running 21 percent ahead of last year's pace.

title: One Large Formula for the Baby, Please
description: Taking a baby on a shopping trip can require the logistical planning of an expedition into space. Common prohibitions against carriages and strollers in stores, revolving doors, escalators, the distance between departments are all barriers to cross. And, if the child is struck with hunger or needs a diaper change, buying generally comes to a halt.

title: Organized Crime Spreads To FastGrowing Arizona
description: PHOENIX, June 13Under ??? gaze of a sweltering desert sun, a hybrid breed of organized crimeincluding Mafiastyle emigres from elsewhere and a homegrown species of seemingly respectable business and professional menis blossoming in Arizona, the nation's fastestgrowing state.

title: Viking I to Get Route Shift
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 13 (UPI)  Scientists prepared today for a midcourse correction maneuver of the Viking 1, made necessary because of a helium leak aboard the spacecraft, which is rocketing toward Mars for a July 4 landing. The course change is scheduled for Tuesday. A spokesman for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said Viking I was still expected to go into Mars orbit Saturday and begin surveying probable landing sites.

title: Suspect in Killings Helps Police Find Body of Woman Victim
description: CANTERBURY, Conn., June 13 (AP)The police dug up the body of a 21yearold woman in this rural town today after Robert Frederick Carr 3d showed them the grave site, the state police said.

title: 5 Killed in Train Crash
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 13 (UPI)A freight train collided with an automobile at a railroad crossing today, killing all five persons in the car. The names of the victims were not immediately available.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Officials of DeCamp Bus Lines and leaders of 210 striking drivers and mechanics are scheduled to meet today in Clifton for the first time in more than a week in an effort to end a threeweek walkout. John Kolster, general manager of the bus company, which serves northern New Jersey counties, said negotiators for Local 1317 of the Amalgamated Transit Union had agreed to meet with management.

title: Towers Home May Be a Landmark]
description: The vacant and vandalized Towers Nursing Home on Central Park West between 105th and 106th Streets is being considered for designation as a landmark, which may jeopardize a $10 million proposal to erect a 175unit apartment building on the site.

title: WELFARE PROGRAMS DEFENDED AT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Critics of big government, whose main target is often the nation's social welfare programs, overlook the fact that Federal dollars saved many peopie from suffering in the recent recession, a public welfare authority said here today.

title: Crosby, Manhattan Music School's New Head, Weighs Santa Fe Opera Tie
description: When John Crosby's appointment as president of the Manhattan School of Music was announced recently, it was assumed that his new post would entail fundraising and administration for the largest conservatory in the United State. There was also excited speculation that some kind of tiein might develop between the school and the highly esteemed Santa Fe Opera, which Mr. Crosby founded 20 years ago and still heads. Such a relationship would be unusualpossibly the only one in this countryand could be fruitful to both organizations.

title: Historian's Three Movements Method Acclaimed and Censured
description: Fernand Braudel is a grand panjandrumslightly emeritusof history. He roams the seas of Academe, picking up art honorary degree here, a worshipful audience there.

description: PASADENA, Calif., June 13 (UPI)  Scientists prepared today for a midcourse correction maneuver of the Viking 1, made necessary because of a helium leak aboard the spacecraft, which is rocketing toward Mars for a July 4 landing. The course change is scheduled for Tuesday. A spokesman for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said Viking 1 was still expected to go into Mars orbit Saturday and begin surveying probable landing sites.

description: Toni Mercer of New York defeated Mary McGowan of Edinburgh. Scotland, 1510, in the final of the New York Lawn Bowling Club's 50th annual singles championship in Central Park Saturday.

title: Courts Easy on Rising Family Violence
description: It was about 4 o'clock in the afternoon when a call came into the 103d Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens, from a woman who said her husband had beaten her, that her face was bleeding and bruised. She thought some of her ribs had been broken.

title: Smoking Laws Defined
description: ROME, June 13 (Reuters) Italian smokers are still allowed to light up in restaurants, bars and dance halls, a top judicial body has ruled. The Council of State said that a new law banning smoking in indoor places did not apply to premises such as restaurants and bars, but did apply to theaters and movie houses.

title: World Team Tennis
description: World Team Tennis

title: U.S. Envoy Warns Canada OneSided Actions Hurt Ties
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (ReuIters)The United States Am bassador to Canada, Thomas O. Enders, warned in an interview published today that Canada could not cut hack on its ties to the United States without a counteraction from Washington.

title: 2 U.S. Aides Fight Stiffened InterestConflict Law
description: WASHINGTON. June 13Two Federal regulators have strongly objected to a bill, Passed last month by the Senate, that would prohibit commissioners from practicing before their commissions for two years after leaving the Government.

title: Seewagen Retains State Tennis Title
description: Butch Seewagen retained his New York State men's tennis championship yesterday by defeating Herb FitzGibbon, 7  5, 6  3, 5  7, 62, at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens. The victor received $500.

title: State's New Museum in Albany Will Open for a Preview Today
description: ALBANY, June 13Ten stuffed animals a moose, two beavers, three gray wolves and four black bearshave been moved from the old State Museum here to the new State Museum, which opens for its first preview tomorrow.

title: CHICAGO TO MEET ORDER ON HOUSING
description: CHICAGO. June 12  The Chicago Housing Authority has announced that the construction of 51 lowincome apartments in predominantly white neighborhoods would begin soon.

title: 'WINTERHAWK' FILM ON LOCAL SCREENS
description: "Winterhawk," now at the Victoria and other theaters, is a mostly slumbrous Western about a Blackfoot Indian chief named Winterhawk and the terrible time he has dealing with white men as he tries to get their remedy for the "white man's disease," which is ravaging Winterhawk's people. They are referred to as Blackfeet when two or more are gathered together, and the disease that afflicts them is smallpox, not syphilis. The film is a tiny mine of information.Charles B. Pierce wrote, directed and produced "Winterhawk" as if he were making a public service movie on the visual beauty of litterless national parks. (It was filmed in neatly tended parks in Colorado and Montana.)"Winterhawk, which has been rated PG, is generally discreet about the violence, but it includes one brutal rape that ends in murder and a scene in which the leg of a little boy is speared as if it were a Vienna sausage impaled on a toothpick.

title: Progress in Spain
description: Spain has made its second substantial break from Generalissimo Franco's political system with the lopsided passage by the Cortes of a bill to legalize political parties. This action followed by barely two weeks the virtually unopposed approval of the first plank in the Government's reform programa bill to legalize most political meetings for the first time in 37 years.

title: Pittsburgh Gets New Galleries
description: The Ailsa Mellon Bruce Galleries, housing a major collection of decorative arts, has opened at the Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, in Pittsburgh. The newly reconstructed galleries, given and endowed by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation of New York, provide permanent exhibition space for the museum's extensive collection of European and American antique furniture and related decorative arts.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 13The State Legislature is gearing up for several hectic sessions over the next two weeks to balance the state's school budget and vote the money to run the state government for the next year before adjourning for the summer.

title: DR. FRANZ J. LUST
description: Dr. Franz J. Lust, a specialist in gastroenterology, died Saturday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 114 East 84th Street.

title: Bond Analysts Expecting Prices to Climb Gradually
description: The credit markets have become convinced that the Federal Reserve is not going to push interest rates higher for a while, so the mood of most bond dealers and investment bankers is optimistic. If there is a consensus in the fixedincome markets, it is that the recovery in prices that began two weeks ago is likely to continue. Prices in the bond market rose last week, but their advance generally was less pronounced than in the rally the week before, when fixedincome securities finally bounded back after having dropped almost nonstop since midApril.

title: Cleaver's Lawyer Quits
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 13 (UPI)George V. Higgins, the authorlawyer, said today that he was quitting as Eldridge Cleaver's lawyer because of profound differences of opinion betwen him and the former Black Panther leader, whose trial had been set for tomorrow. Mr. Cleaver is charged with attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon in a 1968 Panther shootout with the police. Mr. Higgins's request is expected to be granted tomorrow.

title: Belgian Princess Visiting
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Princess Paola of Belgium arrived here today for an informal visit. She will attend performance here tomorrow night of Belgium's Ballet of the Twentieth Century.

title: Advertising
description: Do you think you could measure a nation's insecurity quotient by its mouthwash consumption? Well, then, where do you think that puts the great United States of America, where 72 percent of the adult population are users?

title: 203 Blind Persons Serving as Social Security Information Aides
description: JERSEY CITY, June 12Since the passage of Medicare in 1967, the number of Americans having dealings with the Social Security Administration has increased tenfold. At present, more than a million citizens call their local Social Security office each month.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Top Pentagon officials said yesterday that the United States had agreed to discuss plans for military aid programs to Kenya and Zaire. This is a major policy departure intended to counter growing Soviet military and political influence in Africa. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will go to Nairobi and Kinshasa this week for talks in the first official mission of a United States Defense Secretary to Africa. [Page Column 8.]

title: Kan, Africa Expert, Hired By Detroit Arts Institute
description: With the goal of improving its African art collection, the Detroit Institute of Arts has hired as deputy director Michael Kan, a leading specialist in the field of preColumbian and African art. Mr. Kan's task will be aided by a $1 million fund established for the purpose by an anonymous donor.

title: Hunter Beaten By Rangers, 71
description: What can you say about a 71 game in which your ace pitcher gets rapped for six runs in the first two innings, your team gets only five hits, two of them lucky, and it's 60 before you even get a base hit?

description: Article 2  No Title

title: Jungherr Wins At Horse Show
description: KENT, Conn., June 13 Mark Jungherr, riding master at Coach House Stables in Rye, N.Y., piloted Just Plain Wilbur to victory in the DerringDo jumper classic today at the closing session of the threeday Kent School horse show.

title: moceiT
description: CENTRAL HEATING Henry Mancini and his orchestra will be joined by the singer Morgana King as the Schaefer Music Festival starts its 11th season tonight at 7:30, returning to the Wollman Skating Rink Theater in Central Park, off Fifth Avenue at 63d Street (entered at 59th Street). Between now and September, the series will offer 51 outdoor evenings of pop, jazz, folk, rock and soul sounds.

title: Jones Beats Phils, 50, for 12th thvictory
description: Oh, those bases on halls! was the frequent lament of Frankie Frisch, the former star recond baseman, when he was broadcasting the games of the New York Giants. His listeners came to understand that Frisch could not tolerate any batter's getting a free trip to first base. When the batter wound up scoring a run, Frisch considered it a gift.

title: Japanese Whaling Ports Are Distressed As Quotas Are Cut and Industry Slumps
description: AYUKAWA, JapanShortly after the sun rose over the Pacific Ocean and began to burn away the cool morning mists shrouding the tiny harbor here, the peaceful seaside air was shattered by the raucous sound of metal blades grinding tons of ice into splinters.

title: Assembly Asks Education Of Voters on Constitution
description: The issues involved in revising the New York Constitution are so complex, the Assembly Task Force on Constitutional Revision says, that a temporary commission should be created to educate voters in preparation for a November 1977 referendum.

title: Ford Rests at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., June 13 President Ford took a respite from campaigning to relax today at Camp David in the Catoctin Mountains of western Maryland. He slept later than usual, according to his deputy press secretary. John Carlson, and Planned a pretty relaxed day that did, however, include some Presidential paperwork. The President and Mrs. Ford came to Camp David by helicopter last night, bringing three family dogs for the overnight ???.

title: Chinaglia Scores 2 As Cosmos Win
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 13 (AP)Giorgio Chinaglia scored two goals on breakaways to lead the New York Cosmos to a 30 North American Soccer League victory last night over the Portland Timbers, before a crowd of 32,249.

title: The Memory of Verdun Is Still Alive in the Minds of 6,000 Old Soldiers
description: VERDUN, June 13They came from all over France, 6.000 of the old soldiers who 60 years ago survived what was probably the most destructive military confrontation of all times.

title: Personal Finance
description: It's like a dream come true. Under the old deposit slips, paper clips and pencil stubs in the back of a desk drawer, a longforgotten savings Account passbook is discovered. The account has been dormant for years, while interest presumably has been building up to a sizable level.

title: 3Way Senate Fight Confronts Democrats
description: A complicated threeway struggle emerged yesterday among Democrats seeking the nomination for United States Senator from New York.

title: Colonial Cattle Drive Takes to Trucks at End
description: MOUNT HOLLY, June 13 (UPI)  Twentyfive head of cattle arrived here this weekend, ending a threeday drive reenacting Gen. Mad An thony Wayne's 1778 march to feed troops at Valley Forge, Pa.

title: BRITISH LAWYERS AID MERCENARIES
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 13The Angolan Peoples Revolutionary Tribunal agreed today to allow a team of four British lawyers to take over the defense of British mercenaries in midtrial to give every opportunity to the defense.

title: Yugoslav Wins U.S. Table Tennis Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 13 Dragutin Surbek of Yugoslavia won the United States men's open table tennis championship today by defeating Zlatko Cordaf of Canada, 1921, 2119, 2117, 2117 at the Northeast Racquet Club. Surbek teamed with Milivoj Karakasevic of Yugoslavia to win the doubles final from Cordaf and Errol Caetano of Canada, 1621, 821, 2113, 2115, 2115. Soon 0. K. Kim took the women's title by defeating Hye Soon Son, 1521, 2117, 2118, 2325, 2118, in an all Korean final.

title: Uruguayans Take the Fall of President With the Utmost Calm
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 13An atmosphere of absolute calm prevailed here today after the overthrow of President Juan Maria Bordaberry by the armed forces, which had governed with him for three years.

title: Sandra C. Kremnitzer Is Married
description: Sandra Caryn Kremnitzer, public relations director of Hotelworld Management Group Inc., was married yesterday to Andrew P. Garvin, chairman and chief executive officer of Information Clearing House Inc., a New York company that operates the FIND/SVP information service.

title: Inman Takes Kemper by Shot
description: CHARLOTTE. N. C., June 13 (AP)Joe Inman turned back the challenge of Torn Weiskopf with a gritty, oneunderpar 71 and won his first professional golf tournament today in the Kemper open.

title: In Baseball the Score Is 3691
description: Marvin Miller has been touring the major leagues to bring the players up to date on baseball's capitallabor situation, which has not changed materially since March, when the players agreed to open the season without union contract. There is still no basic agreement, no salary arbitration, no grievance procedure, no effective reserve system and no substitute for the reserve system. One the first questions the players ask the executive director their union is whether the club owners will continue payments to the pension fund this year. The owners refuse to say yes or no. Aware that the manufacturers of Bowie Kuhn's favorite shaving cream are busy counting hundreds of thousands of votes for the AllStar teams, the players ask: Do we have to play in the AllStar Game? No, they are told, that is entirely voluntary. If we didn't play, they ask, would that get the owners off their swivel chairs? Hard to say. The commissioner and league presidents consider the game important and probably some owners regard it as a valuable showcase for their merchandise. The exhibition bores others.

title: Panatta Wins French Title After Solomon's Late Bid
description: PARIS, June 13Almost counted out when down by two sets, a woozy Harold Solomon came off the floor and was within 2 points of taking the fourth set before losing to Adriano Panatta of Italy in the final of the French open tennis championships.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Panel's Proposals May Curtail Medical Experiments in Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Recommendations that will probably result in a moratorium on most medical research conducted in prisons in the United States were voted today by the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjicts of Biomedical and Behavioral Research.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A twoyear project has uncovered marriages of convenience between illegal aliens and welfare recipients that have led to the removal of 736 persons, including 103 aliens, from the welfare rolls, according to the New York City Human Resources Administrator, J. Henry Smith. The saving is about $76,500 a month, he said.

title: A Swedish Baron Buys Bergman's Baltic Home
description: LESJOEFORS, Sweden, Tune 13 (Reuters)A Swedish baron has brought Ingmar Bergman's home and film studio on the Baltic Island of Gotland and will turn part of it into a summer resort, a member of the baron's family has announced.

title: SALVATION ARMY COMMISSIONS 49
description: Forty  nine new Salvation Army officers smartly turned out in their dress blues, vowed yesterday to care for the poor, feed the hungry, clothe the naked, love the unlovable and befriend those who have no friends.

title: Brokers Report a Revival In HomeBuying Market
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., June 13 The warm weekends that annually prompt thousands of pavementweary New Yorkers to stream toward the Jersey Shore are producing another influx this year, an influx of home buyers.

title: 75,000 Parade in Honor Of Israel's 28th Birthday
description: Parade in Honor Of Israel's 28th Birthday

title: BOYS TOWN FACING $1 MILLION DEFICIT
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 13 (UPI) Boys Town, a home for boys that drew national attention when it was learned its assets were about $200 million, is facing a $1 million deficit this year and a projected $500,000 deficit next year.

title: VaduzWins Sea Cliff 2Day Race
description: SEA CLIFF, L.I., June 13Michael Lichtenstein's Vaduz, a Ranger37 from the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, captured the Challenge Cup, emblematic of overall honors in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's ninth annual twoday cruise race today.

title: Choosing the VicePresidential Candidates
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. RICHARD M. NIXON chose Spiro T. Agnew as the VicePresidential nominee at the Republican convention in 1968 with little advance thought, only superficial consultation with carefully screened political advisers, and no significant personal knowledge of his running mate.

title: Levitt Audit Assails M.T.A. and Pennsy
description: Management practices affecting financial operations of the Harlem, Hudson and New Haven railroad commuter lines were criticized as sloppy or poor yesterday by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt in an audit report.

title: Messel Reawakens His Sleeping Beauty
description: For tomorrow's new production of The Sleeping Beauty by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House, Oliver Messel has enlarged, corrected and generally improved the famous production he made for the Royal Ballet in 1946. I prefer painting now, really, but this was something I just couldn't refuse. And we can add (though he won't approve) that it marks his 50th year as a stage designer.

title: Russians Try to Raise Caspian Sea's Oil Output
description: NEFTYANYE KAMM, U.S.S.RJSome 50 miles off the western shore of the Caspian Sea, a sprawling city of oil wells, storage tanks, movie theaters, dormitories and dining halls is perched on a rambling steel spiderweb of piles driven into the seabed.

title: Dungan Would Not Accept A 3d Term as Chancellor
description: Chancellor Ralph A. Dungan has told members of the New Jersey Board of Higher Education that he would not accept a third term should it be offeted to him when his current fiveyear term ends next June.

title: About New York
description: Every year or so a newly discovered Oriental martial artkung fu and taekwando, for examplegives Americans a chance to get into kimonos, straw sandals and whitecanvas suits to earn green, brown, purple and black belts, to speak learnedly of exotic philosophies and to daydream of disarming vicious muggers.

title: Loch Ness Expedition Using Sonar to Probe for Skeletal Remains
description: DRUMNADROCHIT, Scotland, June 13The search for creatures in Loch Ness was broadened today with the beginning of sonar probes into the deep waters of the Scottish lake.

title: SYRIA HAS NO PLAN TO QUIT LEBANON
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 13 Syria made it clear today that it had no intention of withdrawing a sizable portiod of its military forces from Lebanon in the immediate future.

title: Susan Strauss Bride of Harlan Hurwitz
description: Susan Lyrrn Strauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Strauss of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Harlan Arthur Hurwitz, son of Mrs. Louis Joshua Hurwitz of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Mr. Hurwitz. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in the BethEl Chapel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: State's New Museum in Albany Will Open for a Preview Today
description: ALBANY, June 13Ten stuffed animals a moose, two beavers, three gray wolves and four black hearshave been moved from the old State Museum here to the new State Museum, which opens for its first preview tomorrow.

title: Shih Tzu From New York Best at Denver
description: DENVER, June 13The Colorado Centennial Canine Circuit, celebrating the nation's Bicentennial and the state's 100th anniversary, ended on a high note today in this Mile High City, with the strongest finish of the six shows.

title: Tells Congress Erosion of Monopoly May Result in Higher Home Phone Bills
description: The nation's established telephone industry, led by the powerful American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has launched an intense campaign to stop the expansion of competition in the telecommunications industry.

title: 300 Bicyclists Compete in Englewood Mile
description: ENGLEWOOD, June 13 Normal vehicular traffic was diverted off several major thoroughfares of downtown Englewood today as more than 300 contestants took to the streets on 3, 5 and 10speed bikes as part of the second annual Tour of Englewood Bicycle Race.

title: The Good Guy
description: WASHINGTONCongressman Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Boston, is a certified media Good Guy. He has earned his position of unassailability by dint of hard work, a cheerful accessibility, close Kennedy connections and a colorful personality. He even has an engaging nickname: Tip, after a baseball player who specialized in hitting foul tips until he received a walk.

title: James Joyce's Son Dies In West Germany at 70
description: PARIS, June 13 (AP)Giorgic Joyce, the only son of the writer James Joyce, died in a clinic near Konstanz, West Germany yesterday after a long illness, the family announced here to day. He was 70.

title: What's New in Capital? Sin Denounced in 1860's
description: WASHINGTON, June 13It she is young and pretty, she is surrounded by men who seek her moral destruction.

title: PHYSICIAN, 36, SLAIN; WIFE IS ARRESTED
description: A 36yearold resident in pathology at Metropolitan Hospital Center was stabbed to death yesterday during a quarrel, with his wife in their apartment on the West Side, the police reported.

title: U. S. WILL DISCUSS ARMS PLANS TO AID KENYA AND ME
description: BRUSSELS, June 13The United States has agreed to discuss plans for military aid programs to Kenya and Zaire in an important new policy departure intended to meet growing Soviet influence and military capacity in Africa, according to top Pentagon officials.

title: Rights Panel Acts to Bar BlockBusting in Bronx,
description: The City Commission on qiuman Rights has extended its neighborhood stabilization program to a large residential sec tion of the Northeast Bronx to nrevent blockbusting realestate practices that could affect the ethnic makeup of the racially untegrated area.

title: Brokers Report a Revival In HomeBuying Market
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., June 13 The warm weekends that annually prompt thousands of pavementweary New Yorkers to stream toward the Jersey Shore are producing another influx this year, an influx of home buyers.

title: NO THREAT TO ISRAEL SEEN IN SYRIAN DRIVE.
description: TEL AVIV, June 13 (AP)Israeli military analysts said today that Syrian troops operating in southern Lebanon only 14 miles from Israel were attacking Palestinian bases there and were not threatening Israel.
