title: Tony Martin Sings At Rainbow Grill With a New Style
description: Tony Martin no longer has the zing in his voice that once enabled him to belt out big, reverberating notes on Begin the Beguine or on Tenement Symphony. which he sang in The Big Store with the Marx Brothers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Now they are digging him up not to find out how many people killed him and why, but to check on whether he had been alive at all, at least the John F. Kennedy we remember, the young President who made us feel sexier, as a nation, than we had ever before permitted ourselves to feel. There are so many revisionistsas I type, I think they are in the kitchen, revising my breakfast cereal and the catthat they have to stand in line with their shovels and hooks and ropes, their scissors and slide rules and metronomes. Their business is the conversion of Prospero into Caliban; they torture the record as alchemists tortured metals; it is a good business when we feel lousy about ourselves, which of course we didn't while Kennedy was alive. Judith Exner will, presumably, turn the Kennedy story into a novel by Harold Robbins. Bruce Miroff has turned it into a Marcusian cartoon.

title: Trade Book Gives Financial Figures For TV Networks
description: The CBS television network had profit before Federal taxes of $106 million in 1975, while NBCTV had $73.5 million and ABC $29 million, according to Television Digest, a trade newsletter that has reliably reported the network figures for 12 years.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: New Corporate Bonds

title: Mets Top Giants, 42, 41, For Lolich and Seaver
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 The San Francisco Giants presented the New York Mets with the first game of a doubleheader, then Tom Seaver took the second and ended the team's California trip on a mildly successful note.

title: Argentine Navy Officer Dies
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 13 (Reuters)An Argentine Navy captain was shot dead today in La Plata, south of here, by gunmen believed to be leftwing guerrillas, Capt. Jorge Raul Bigliardi, was cut down by machine gun bullets fired from two passing cars as he left his home. The gunmen escaped.

title: Susan M. Grimsley Wed to Physician
description: Susan M. Grimsley, an assistant county attorney for Dodge County, Minn., was married yesterday at noon to Dr. Jerome D. Aronowitz, a fellow in ophthalmology at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

title: U. S. WILL DISCUSS ARMS PLANS TO AID KENYA AND ZAIRE
description: BRUSSELS, June 13The United States has agreed to discuss plans for military aid programs to Kenya and Zaire in an important new policy departure intended to meet growing Soviet influence and military capacity in Africa, according to top Pentagon officials.

title: Book Parties: Egos Are Inflated And the Gossip Flies
description: It was Doris Schwerin's first book and her first literary party, given, as is almost always the case, by her publisher. The book was Diary of a Pigeon Watcher and the party was in the East Side town house of her publisher, Lawrence Hughes, president of William Morrow, who has a glasswalled living room overlooking a patio.

title: Motorcyclists Hold Rally
description: TRENTON, June 13 (UP1)Some 2,000 motorcyclists roared into Trenton today to protest a state law requiring cyclists to wear protective helmets. The riders, many not wearing helmets, held a rally in front of the State Hausa to protest the law, which went into effect in 1968. Government offices were closed and the cyIclists did not megt with any state officials.

title: Frances Levine Bride Of Neal B. Abraham
description: Frances Ruth Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Levine of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Neal Broadus Abraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart B. Abraham of Hagerstown, Md.

title: Opera: Last of Mohicans Presented in Wilmington
description: It was probably inevitable that the current rash of operas commissioned for the Bicentennial celebrations would eventually yield a musical setting of James Fenimore Cooper's novel 'The Vast of the Mohicans.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Forego Easy Victor At Belmont
description: Hey Jacinto, tell em how you won the race! Patrick Day yelled across the Belmont Park jockeys room.

title: A COFFEE CHEMICAL LINKED TO CANCER
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The National Cancer Institute said today that a chemical used last year in making decaffeinated coffee causes cancer of the liver in mice.

title: Black Elected as Bishop
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Rev. John T, Walker has been elected Bishop Coadjutor, the second highest office, for the Episcopal Diocese that includes Washington and four Maryland counties. Bishop Walker is the second black to reach the rank of Bishop Coadjutor. The first, Bishop John Burgess, retired from the Diocese of Massachusetts last year.

title: Rhodesia Blamed for Blasts in Lusaka
description: LUSAKA. Zambia. June 13 (Reuters)  The high court building and central post office here were damaged by explosions today and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia blamed the Rhodesian Government.

title: Royals Drop Bid For Ken Holtzman
description: KANSAS CITY. June 13 (AP)  The Kansas City Royals will not trade for the Baltimore Orioles pitcher, Ken Holtzman, Royals officials announced tonight. The Royals withdrew from negotiations for Holtzman after an impasse was reached in efforts to sign him.

title: Courts Easy on Rising Family Violence
description: It was about 4 o'clock in the afternoon when a call came into the 103d Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens, from a woman who said her husband had beaten her, that het face was bleeding and bruised. She thought some of her ribs had beers broken.

title: Hays Continues Recovery
description: SARNESVILLE, Ohio. June 13 AP)  Representative Wayne Hays continued to show improvement today and was alert and and walking around in his private room, according to his doctor. Mr. Hays, an Ohio Democrat, took an overdose of a prelicribed sleeping medicine three days ago.

title: Swiss Voters Bar a Loan for Poor Nations
description: GENEVA, June 13Switzerland's voters severely rebuffed Ithe Government and the Parliament today by voting down a proposal for a $80 million interestfree loan to help the world's developing nations.

title: Five French Climbers Fall to Their Deaths
description: BRIANCON, France, June 13 (Reuters)  Five French climbers, all roped together, plunged to their deaths today while trying to conquer a 11,194foot mountain corridor.

title: French Yacht Abandons Ocean Race
description: PLYMOUTH. England. June 13 (AP)Joel Charpentier, French yachtsman, radioed today that he was retiring from the singlehanded transAtlantic race with badly damaged rigging aboard his 63foot schooner Wild Rocket, race organizers reported. Charpentier said his schooner was battered in a day long storm by 60mileanhour winds that swept through the fleet of racing boats Wednesday. He was headed back to France. Charpentier was the 10th dropout among 126 competitors who left Plymouth eight days ago for Newport, R.I.

title: Commodities
description: Grain producers, brokers, traders and speculators, who must deal constantly with the problems of supply and demand, weather, inflation and the like, are now confronted by a new one:

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: CITY U. REOPENING AMID PAY DISPUTE
description: The City University reopens today to complete its spring semester amid a controversy over whether employees will be paid for the two weeks in which the institution was closed.

title: DEMOCRATS BACK CALL IN PLATFORM FOR SOVIET AMITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The drafting subcommittee of the Democratic Platform Committee voted today to commit the party to seeking areas of cooperation with the Soviet Union while maintaining a strong American military deterrent.

title: SYRIA SAID TO PUSH ARMORED ATTACKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, June 14This battered capital of Lebanon was quiet yesterday, but rival radio stations reported attacks by Syrian armor in the mountains northeast of Beirut and in the strategic Arkub region lying in the shadow of Mount Hermon.

title: CITY It REOPENS AS KIBBEE SEEKS TO WITHHOLD PAY
description: The City University of New York reopened yesterday after a twoweek shutdown as students, teachers and staff members returned to 20 campuses in an atmosphere of relief, confusion and anger.

title: Syrians Said to Capture Lebanese Dissident Unit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14A garrison of the dissident group called the Lebanese Arab Army today was said to have fallen to Syrian troops in southeastern Lebanon while light fighting was reported from the mountains northeast of Beirut.

title: U.S. Rowing Team Nearly Completed
description: The assembly of the United States Olympic rowing team, which will include women for the first time, is about threefourths complete with the selection last weekend of two of the smaller boats, the pairwith  coxswain and the double sculls. Dr. Larry Klecatsky, the 34yearold medical professor from the New York Athletic Club, and his new partner, Bill Belden from Undine Boat Club of Boston, make up th double. For Klecatsky, who has won 64 United States and Canadian national championships and has rowed what seems like 1,000 miles over the New York A.C. course at Orchard Beach in the Bronx, making an Olympic team at last is a dream come true.

title: Talks With Italian Communists Yield Only Few Insights
description: ROME, June 14What are the Italian Communists really like? What is their appeal to the voters? Are they really different, as they say they are, from the Communists of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe?

title: $700 Billion Debt Limit Is Approved in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)The House voted 184 to 177 today to increase the limit on the national debt to $700 billion in three stages, through Sept. 30, 1977.

title: Bicentennial Pilgrims Are Making Progress
description: NYACK, N.Y., June 14A convoy of 30 wagons and 50 riders on horseback crossed the Tappan Zee Bridge today and then began a 16day tour of New Jersey on its way to a Fourth of July rendezvous at Valley Force. Pa.

title: Boycott on Big Board Is Investigated by U.S.
description: The Department of Justice is investigating a boycott of a tradingfloor specialist on the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street sources disclosed last night.

title: TwoFaced Policy On Chile
description: If the Ford Administration can be said to have a left hand, it seems to knoweth not what the right hand does in Chile.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. The Virtuous Wife, Purcell; Sonata for Viola Da Gamba and Harpsichord No. 2, Bach; Piano Concerto No. 3, Mozart; Deus in Nomine tuo, Mielczewski; Suite from Love for Three Oranges, Prokofiev.

title: Isler Is Victor In Yacht Race
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 14The Yale Corinthian Yacht Club of New Haven, represented by Peter Isler of Norwalk, Conn., won the Area B semifinal of the United States Intercluh match racing championship series off Larchmont Yacht Club today and will sail for the Prince of Wales Bowl in the final series at California Y.C., Marina del Ray, Calif., Aug. 2326.

title: Rotary Elects President
description: NEW ORLEANS. June 14 (Reuters)W. Jack Davis of Hamilton, Bermuda, was elected today as president of Rotary International for 197778 at the organization's 67th annual convention here.

title: SENATE APPROVES $9.4 BILLION IN AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Senate approved a 27month, $9.4 billion foreign aid hill today, but yielded to conservative opposition to the Ford Administration's new African policy and deleted $35 million that had been sought for economic assistance to countries in southern Africa.

title: Helping New York
description: I could sit back and do nothing, said Lucas Ferrara, who started summer vacation a week ago from Xavier High School in Manhattan. But I'm already bored.

title: Stage: Diana Ross Bridges a Gap
description: If the mountain will not come to Mohammed then Mohammed must go to the mountain. So runs conventional wisdomand conventinohal wisdom is frequently right, which is why it became conventional. There is a gap betwen most pop music and the Broadway theater. In recent years some pop singers have begun to leap that gap with staged evenings of their songs, thoughts, hopes and all that kind of jazz. An Evening With Diana Ross, which opened last night at the Palace Theater, is precisely such an occasion.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Investment and insurance companies will be allowed to own up to 5 percent of broadcast and cable television companies as long as they don't exercise any control over management or policies of the companies, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today.

title: BERLIN PARTY AIDE HELD AS RED SPY
description: WEST BERLIN, June 14The press spokesman for West Berlin's governing Social Democratic Party and his former wife have been arrested on suspicion of spying for East Germany, the city prosecutor announced today.

title: LAOS IS REPLACING ITS CURRENCY TODAY
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, June 15 (Agence FrancePresse) The Laotian radio has announced that the national ourrency, the kip, will be withdrawn from circulation and replaced with a new currency today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The collapse of an Idaho dam that should never have been built, with the resultant tragedy of lives snuffed out and millions of dollars in property destroyed, points up one more victory for the smug builders of tomorrow who strive incessantly to put the kook environmentalists in their place. So it's: Oops, we goofed! Sorry about that! and they'll go blithely ahead, ignoring the apprehension of concerned citizens and the arguments of alarmed scientists who lack expertise because They aren't on somebody's specialinterest payroll.

title: Sea Grab
description: With the slowmoving United Nations Law of the Sea Conference adjourned until August, leaving critical issues of ocean law unresolved, the moves to stake out everwider national claims to jurisdiction at sea appear to be accelerating ominously.

title: Panel in Hospital Dispute Urges Talks on CostofLiving Increase
description: A Federal factfinding panel, set up to try to avert a strike by 40,000 workers in New York City's voluntary hospitats, recommended yesterday, the negotiation of a costofliving increase and binding arbitration if The union and the hospitals reach an impasse.

title: Lebanon
description: Which Middle Eastern country will be the next Lebanon? The Lebanese crisis may differ according to the political, economic and social circumstances of the particular country, but the same basic convulsion threatens them all. The nopeace nowar situation maintained in the entire region either by accident or design heads it inevitably toward violenceon the IsraeliArab borders and/or within any of the involved countries.

title: CONCERT SALUTES ELLINGTON GROUPS
description: For its 16th annual concert, given Sunday afternoon at the New School, the Duke Ellington Society dipped into both the work of the Ellington small groups and its own past. Bob Wilber led a septet in a program built around the early 1940's recordings of groups led by Rex Stewart, Johnny Hodges, Barney Bigard and Cootie Williams, which was subsequently a repeat of the society's sixth concert in 1966, which was also orginized and conducted by Mr. Wilber.

title: Braves of N.B.A. Sold, Seek a Shift to Florida
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 14 While the National Basketball Association owners wrestled with several plans here today for a merger with the rival American Basketball Association, about 450 miles away in Buffalo, the Braves were sold and would be moved to Hollywood, Fla., if the sale is approved.

title: LABOR PREPARES TO BACK CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 Cautiously and with varying degrees of enthusiasm, labor leaders are moving toward public support of Jimmy Carter.

title: Concerned Simon Sets Up a Meeting On New York Loan
description: Expressing concern at the pace of New York City's budgetcutting efforts, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon yesterday abruptly scheduled a meeting Thursday between his staff and the Emergency Financial Control Board to discuss questions involving the city's financial plan.

title: LEVITT QUESTIONS MORTGAGE PLAN
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt has questioned New York City's wisdom in continuing to operate a mortgageinsurance program that, until yesterday, had been unable to insure a loan in its 32 months of existence.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The American oil industry has grown to world dominance under a structure in which the major companies control all their operations from production through marketing. But in recent months a question raised with growing intensity is whether the consumer is best served by such an arrangement.

title: Soviet Military Exercises Near Finnish Border Open
description: MOSCOW, June 14 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today began five days of army and air force maneuvers near the Finnish border. Military observers from Finland, Norway and Sweden have been invited to attend.

title: TAFT B. SCHREIBER; AIDED FORD DRIVE
description: Taft B. Schreiber, national cochairman of the President Ford Committee and a director and member of the executive committee of MCA Inc., died yesterday in Los Angeles as a result of complications following surgery. He was 68 years old.

title: GEZA ANDA DIES; CONCERT PIANIST
description: Geza Anda, the Hungarian pianist, died at his home Sunday night in Zurich. An associate of Mr. Anda said that the 54yearold pianist had died of internal hemorrhaging. Mr. Anda underwent surgery a year ago for cancer of the esophagus.

title: FRASER TOUR SEEN AS SOVIET COUNTER
description: SYDNEY, Australia June 14 Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser began a series of overseas visits this week that were interpreted here as an attempt by the Australian leader to counter what he sees as a growing Soviet threat, by developing closer ties with Japan, China and the United States.

title: Wagons Wheel Into New Jersey
description: NYACK, N. Y., June 14A train of about 30 horsedrawn Conestogatype wagons crossed the Tappan Zee Bridge this morning on its way to a Fourth of July destination in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: Maine Shipyard Struck
description: BATH, Me., June 14 (UPI)Local 6 of the International Union of Marine and Shipyard Workers struck the Bath Iron Works today. The strike, to back demands for higher wages, put 2,500 employes out of work at the shipyard.

title: City University Offers a Course Called Mussels Marseillaise
description: In the 18thfloor cafeteria of the newly reopened City University Graduate Center on West 42d Street yesterday, there was chicken Tetrazzini in almost every pot.

title: Maior League Box Scores and Standings
description: Tuesday, June 15, 1976

title: Ford Acts to Curb U.S. Bribes Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 President Ford, saying that bribes paid by United States corporations to foreign officials threatened to harm our foreign relations, called today for legislation that would require the disclosure of all such questionable payments.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 14  A group of 25 noisy demonstrators who did not identify themselves disrupted the State Senate session today, calling for jobs and labeling Senators tools of the rich.

title: Rumsfeld Flies to Africa Today For Talks in Kenya and Zaire
description: BRUSSELS. June 14 (Reuters) Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will fly to Africa tomorrow to discuss the security situation in eastern and central Africa with Government leaders in Kenya and Zaire, the United States delegation to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced today.

title: Three Singers Enliven Pop Scene
description: Sunday night, Randy Newman, Dave Van Ronk and Warren Zevon all appeared in Manhattan, and Mr. Newman, crusty eccentric that he is, managed, all unawares, to cast the other two quite decisively into the shade.

title: Jamaica Curse on ForemanFrazier
description: After the bell rings for the first round tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, a new frame of reference will surround the boxing futures of George Foreman and Joe Frazier, each a former world heavyweight champion. Each needs a new frame. Each has never been quite the same since their 1973 title bout in Kingston, Jamaica, when Joe Frazier was knocked down six times and dethroned by George Foreman inside two rounds. But that fight was merely the splash created by a rock thrown into a pond. The ripples have affected each's boxing career much more. In the weeks before that bout, some boxing people described it as the Jamaica Affair because of the shadows of intrigue cast on the island in the sun, notably in the intrigue of the finances. In addition to the $850,000 for Frazier and the $375,000 for Foreman, the boxers were whispered to have reecived secret bonuses to sweeten the dealbonuses that everybody involved has denied. But since then, the Jamaica Affair appears to have evolved into the Jamaica Curse, as if someone under a palm tree there has been sticking pins In voodoo dolls, Consider these developments:

title: New York City Seeking Curb of Nonmayoral Units
description: New York City will ask the state's Emergency Financial Control Board for direct power to deal with socalled nonmayoral agenciessuch as the City. Universitythat disregard the spending restraints of the city's fiscal plan.

title: LABOR PREPARES TO BACK CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Cautiously and with varying degrees of enthusiasm, labor leaders are moving toward public support or Jimmy Carter.

title: Rockaway Hospital To Be Taken Over By Episcopal Group
description: Over 100,000 residents of the Far Rockaway area were assured of continued hospital care yesterday when Church Charity Foundation, an arm of the Episcopal church, agreed to take over the South Shore Division of Long Island Jewish Hospital on July 1.

title: Syrians Said to Capture Lebanese Dissident Unit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14A garrison of the dissident group called the Lebanese Arab Army today was said to have fallen to Syrian troops in southeastern Lebanon while light fighting was reported from the mountains northeast of Beirut.

title: IndianPakistani Talks Begin
description: NEW DELHI, June 14 (Reuters)Delegations from India and Pakistan began talks here today, to work out details for resuming air links between the two countries and transit lights across each other's territory. The two Governments agreed last month to resume diplomatic relations and restore air, rail and road traffic.

title: 10 File Class Action Suit Against N.Y. Mercantile
description: Nine individual holders of May potato futures contracts and an investing company have filed the latest in a series of lawsuits against the New York Mercantile Exchange, the traders who defaulted on contracts sold and their brokers.

title: Women Tennis Players Find the Grass Tough
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 14Twentyfour hours after she had won the French championship on slow clay, 20yearold Sue Barker came on the grass center court and had considerable trouble beating Jackie Fayter, ranked 12th in Britain, 98, 64, in the $90,000 Eastbourne tournament, a prelude to Wimbledon.

title: PRESS CAN COVER SUIT, COURT SAYS
description: The Federal Court of Appeals overturned yesterday an order excluding the public and press from a trial of a $5 million negligence suit brought by Connie Francis Garzilli, the singer and entertainer.

title: JOSEPH BOLITZER
description: Joseph Bolitzer, of Worcester, Mass., an etcher in the photo engraving department of The New York Times who retired in 1966, died last Thursday in Worcester General Hospital. His age was 86. Mr. Bolitzer, who had worked for many years on the old New York Sun, is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Irma Bernstein of Worcester: a son, Bernard, of Brooklyn, and five grandchildren.

title: Philadelphia Transit Union Threatens July 4 Shutdown
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP)  City transit workers have approved a plan to shut down all trolley, subway and bus service in Philadelphia on July 4.

title: Suits by Federal Judges
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Justice Department argued today that judges on the United States Court of Claims need not disqualify themselves from deciding lawsuits brought by 82 other Federal judges seeking salary increases. The suits by the 82 Federal ditrict and Federal appeals court judges contend that the President and the Congress violated the Constitution by rejecting raises for them in 1974, 1975 and 1976.

title: Church Withdraws
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Senator Frank Church withdrew formally today as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination and endorsed Jimmy Carter, the former Georgia Governor, as truly a candidate whose time has come.

title: Drive Set for Council on Aging
description: The Bloom Agency of Dallas has become the first Texas agency to prepare a public service campaign for the Advertising Council. And it has done it in behalf of the National Council on the Aging.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: Nearby Golf Results

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: Scranton Visits Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal June 14 (Reuters)  William Scranton, the United States delegate to the United Nations, arrived here today from Sierra Leone for a oneday visit to Senegal.

title: Frank H. Canaday. 83. Dies: Was Advertising Executive
description: Frank H. Canaday of Woodstock, Vt., a retired executive of the United States Advertising Corporation, Toledo, Ohio, and an art enthusiast who donated contemporary American paintings to museums in New Zealand died Sunday in Many Hitchcock Memorial Hospital, Hanover, N. H., after a proenged illness. His age was 88.

title: Advertising
description: American Home magazine, into which the Charter Company is pouring about $100,000 an issue, expects to be running monthly issues in the black by the end of the year and be operating at a breakeven point in 1977.

title: Baldwin Nine Wins, 21
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 14A twoout single in the 10th inning by Bob Arcario scored Bob Birns with the winning run as Baldwin High School edged Mineola, 21, today at Eisenhower Park in the opening game of the twoofthreegame Nassau scholastic championship baseball series. The second game will be played tomorrow night. Doug Williams drove in the Mineola run.

title: Market Place
description: Banks, which customarily operate as repositories of other people's money, need funds themselves these days. They are seeking to add to their own capital in order to support increases in future loan demand.

title: Gotbaum Asserts Agency Study Distorts Municipal Labor Costs
description: Victor Gotbaum, exective director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employees, charged yesterday that the Temporary Commission on City Finances had misrepresented labor and fringe benefit costs for New York City employees in a report earlier this month.

title: Bright Briefcase for the Arrived Woman
description: Once a woman's gotten her name on the office doorand, of course, a carpet on the floorwon't she also want a goodlooking briefcase, instead of shoving papers higgledypiggledy into a tote bag?

title: The Casts
description: BEWARE THE JUBJUB BIRD, a play by Sandra Jennings. Directed by Haro'd Guskin; setting and lighting by Lee Goldman; music by Sandra Jennings and Richard Cameron; production stage manager, Janet Sonenterg. Presented by Pegasus III, At Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street.

title: Soviet Tall Ships Lead
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 14 (UPI)Two Barques from the Soviet Union, Tovarishch and Kruzenshtern, were declared the unofficial winners today of the Tall Ships race from the Canary Island to Bermuda. Race officials declared the two vessels the winners after correcting the times of the 42 ships involved. Confirmation of the results was expected tomorrow.

title: Wilson Homer Mark Resists Challengers
description: When Philadelphia's Mike Schmidt hit 16 home runs in his team's first 55 games, and Dave Kingman wound up with 22 in the first 62 Met games, the possibility arose that either or both night challenge one of baseball's most neglected but truly noteworthy records the National League mark for homers in one season, set at 56 in 1930 by Hack Wilson of the Chicago Cubs.

title: Body of 1950 Suicide Found
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 14 (AP)The skeleton of a man missing since he left a suicide note almost 26 years ago was found by children in the woods a few miles outside this Franklin County village. The state police said today. He was Sidney Case of Saranac Lake, who died of a selfinflicted rifle shot in the head, the police said. He was reported missing on Dec. 29, 1950, when he was 37 years old.

title: 8 LETTER BOMBS SENT TO 4 CITIES
description: Eight letter bombs mailed in manila envelopes were delivered yesterday to seven business corporations and one business executive in four American cities, including one device that exploded in a Manhattan brokerage house injuring four women.

title: Burma Skips Olympics
description: RANGOON, Burma, June 14 (AP)Burma, will not send a team to the Olympic Games this summer because of financial stringency, the official newspaper, Working People's Daily, said today.

title: JAMES B. FAHEY
description: James B. Fahey, associate director of development for Fordham University, died Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old and a resident of Upper Montclair, N.J. Mr. Fahey was born in Brooklyn and had been a New York City teacher before entering the fundraising field.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syrian troops were reported yesterday to have captured a garrison of the dissident group called the Lebanese Arab Army in southeastern Lebanon. The Voice of Palestine, the Palestinian radio, said that Syrian troops and armor had taken the garrison at Rasheiya, 15 miles southwest of the main Syrian encampment at Masnaa in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. The, Damascus radio had announced earlier that the Moslem soldiers at Rasheiya who had defected from the regular Lebanese armed forces had rallied to what were described as the Syriansponsored vanguards of the Lebanese Army. [Page 1, Columns 56.]

title: SIMON QUESTIONS LOAN TO NEW YORK
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 2 Simon's aides will have met formally with the Control Board since the initial loan agreement with the city was signed it December. The Secretary is scheduled to be represented by Robert A. Gerard, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who is in charge of the New York City loan program.

title: Sanok Paces Jersey Golf By 3 Shots
description: FLORHAM PARK, N. J., June 14The New Jersey golf scene has changed over the years, but Chet Sanok, the premier amateur in the state for three decades, hasn't changed much. He even keeps saying this year will be my last for these big tournaments.

title: People in Sports
description: For a long while, Willie Montanez has been saying he would like to play baseball in a warm climate. The 28yearold native of Puerto Rico has spent four years of his majorleague career in Philadelphia and one in San Francisco's windswept Candlestick Park.

title: UDALL CONCEDES TO CARTER, ENDS DELEGATE SEARCH
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, holding the second largest bloc of Democratic convention delegates, ended yesterday his active pursuit for more and conceded his party's Presidential nomination to Jimmy Carter.

title: Ashe a PreWimbledon Loser
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 14 (UPI)Arthur Ashe, named earlier the topseeded player for next week's Wimbledon tennis championship, was upset by Roger Taylor, 75, 62. in the first round of the $100,000 Nottingham open today. This is the final grass competition before Wimbledon.

title: A Fruitful Exchange
description: In Washington, New York politicians are famous for their naivet. And justly so. Right now, for example, New York politicians believe it is terribly vital to clear the pimps and prostitutes from the streets of midtown Manhattan during the week of the Democratic convention.

title: Byrne Dedicates a Park Close to Statue of Liberty
description: JERSEY CITY, June 14New Jersey's first urban state park was dedicated today by Governor Byrne, with the flags of 90 nations snapping in the breeze and the notes of a brass band echoing under a cloudy sky.

title: Meat importer's Kidnappers Demand Beef Sale in Rome
description: ROME, June 14 (UPI)Kidnappers abducted meat importer Giuseppe Ambrosio today and threatened to kill him unless 71 butcher shops in workingclass areas of Rome cut their prices of prime beef by 75 percent on Wednesday.

title: SCHOOL RACIAL TEST SATISFIES DETROIT
description: DETROIT, June 14 (AP) Detroit's first semester of courtordered integration is over, and most school police and community officials agree that it was more successful than expected.

title: Talks on Rubber Strike
description: CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP)Peter Bommarito, president of the striking United Rubber Workers, said that the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company offered nothing new or really interesting in a full afternoon of talks here today. The strike, which started April 21, shut down tireproducing plants operated by Firestone, B.F. Goodrich, Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company and Uniroyal Inc.

title: Troops Aid Quake Area
description: TOKYO, June 14 (AP)Chinese Army units have been helping with crops in the areas of Yunnan Province jolted by two strong earthquakes on May 29, Hsinhua, China's official press agency, said today. As in previous reports on the quake, Hsinhua gave no details of casualties or damage.

title: Uncommitted Jersey Bloc Bars Byrne as Leader at Convention
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 14 (AP)The uncommitted Democratic delegates elected in the New Jersey primary overwhelmingly rejected Governor Byrne today as leader of the delegation and voted to support Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: Chess
description: The Euwe Quadrangular, a fourplayer doubleround tournament held in Amsterdam to celebrate the 75th birthday of Max Euwe, world champion from 1935 to 1937 and current president of the International Chess Federation, was won by Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the present champion.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: No. Amer. Soccer League

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: AMEX STOCKS UP; OPTIONS ADVANCE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday in moderate trading.

title: RHODESIA REVISING LAWS ON BLACKS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 14 (AP)Rhodesia's white minority Government recommended several moves toward racial equality today, including the establishment of nonsegregated election rolls and nonsegregated ownership of commercial and agricultural land.

title: CARTER LEADS FORD AND REAGAN IN POLL
description: Jimmy Carter ended the primary season with a substantial popular lead over both President Ford and Ronald Reagan, according to projections based on an NBC News telephone poll conducted late last week.

title: The New York Times to Change To a 6Column Format Sept.
description: The New York Times will take on a new appearance next September by changing its format of eight columns on a page to one of six columns for news and nine columns for display advertisements, the newspaper's publisher. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, announced yesterday.

title: New York City Seeking Curb of Nonmayoral Units
description: New York City will ask the state's Emergency Financial Control Board for direct power to deal with socalled nonmayoral agenciessuch as the City Universitythat disregard the spending restraints of the city's fiscal plan.

title: TEAMSTERS CHIEF SCORES DISSIDENTS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 14The International Brotherhood of Teamsters went on the offensive today, defending the union, flaunting its success and opening a stinging attack on union dissidents.

title: Sea Grant Program Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  The Senate approved today a threeyear expansion of the national sea grant program at an estimated cost of $288.8 million. The bill would, among other things, establish the office of marine resources, science and technology within the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to coordinate the program's related ocean and coastal activities.

title: TAX BASE SHRINKS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City's property tax base shrank this year for the first time in 33 years, and independent experts predicted yesterday that the tax rate would rise by nearly 8 percent, to $8.836 per $100 of assessed valuation.

title: U.S. MERCENARIES EXPLAIN MOTIVES
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 14A Vietnam War veteran on trial here as a mercenary antagonized the court today by saying he had come to stop a Russian Communist takeover. Another won congratulations on testifying that he had come for money, for adventure but was sorry.

title: Prosecutor in Queens Opens Investigation After Jury Criticizes Conduct of Nadjari's Office
description: District Attorney Nicholas A. Ferraro of Queens opened an investigation into the behavior of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor. The action was taken after a jury, in acquitting a man charged with selling drugs, criticized the methods Mr. Nadjari used against the defendant.

title: Businessmen Cite Threats Over Busing in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, June 14Several business leaders testified today that they were the victims of an intense campaign of intimidation and harassment including boycotts and threats to bomb, burn and kill, during desegregation of schools here last fall.

title: E.B. White Takes On Xerox and Wins
description: E. B. White, the American essayist who has lived secluded with his hens, his hayfields and his typewriter on a farm in Maine for close to 40 years, has persuaded the Xerox Corporation, in an exchange of letters, to abandon the under writing of magazine articles.

title: Ford Praises Space Show
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 14 (UPI) President Ford praised a bicentennial space exposition at its dedication ceremony today, calling it another chapter in America's history of reaching out to the unknown.

title: Dow Up 12.44 to 991.24; Volume Rises to 21 Million
description: Picking up from where it left off last Friday, the stock market registered another broad advance yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 12.44 points to close at 991.24. Volume also increased to 21.25 million shares from 19.74 million on Friday, when the Dow rose by 14 41 points. Prices opened on the up side and moved ahead almost without interruption, ending at their highs for the day. Most major groups took putt in the upturn, in which advances topped declines by an 11to3 ratio.

title: Commercial and Savings Banks Get New York State Warning on Ad Fight
description: The New York State Banking Department warned commercial banks and thrift institutions yesterday against potentially unfair advertising in the current struggle for checking account customers.

title: Ford Aides Still Confident Despite Setback in Missouri
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Ford's setback in Missouri will not prevent him from converting enough convention delegates to win the Republican Presidential nomination, White House political strategists said today.

title: In Memoriam
description: GLASSHamlette P. Died Juna 14, 1974. Ford and loving memories, devoted wlle, mother and grandmother.

title: 12 WOMEN NAMED IN THE GETTY WILL
description: LONDON, June 14 (AP)J. Paul Getty, who died June 6 at the age of 83, named 12 women in his will. A number of them can recall romances or dearromance with the American oil billionaire.

title: Turk in U.N., Disavows Cyprus Partition As Aim
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 14Ilter Turkmen, Turkey's chief delegate here said in the Security Council today that no effort to partition Cyprus would be made by the Turkish forces, which now control 40 per cent of the island.

title: McDonald, 85, First Black To Play in Pro Football
description: GENEVA, N.Y. June 14 (UPI) Henry McDonald, professional football's first black player, died Saturday at Geneva General Hospital, where he had been admitted recently for hip surgery. He was 85 years old.

title: New York City Decides to Replace Its Concrete Trash Containers With Traditional Wire Mesh Baskets
description: New York City's concrete waste containers are going to the scrap heap. Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarelto disclosed yesterday. He said they were more trouble than they were worth and the Sanitation Department had begun quietly removing them from sidewalks.

title: Foreman 85 Pick Tonight
description: Joe Frazier plays cool. Boogie, boogie, boogie, he says to the snap of his fingers. I'm gonna boogie, boogie boogie.

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company is wrong when it says that building nuclearpowered generators would be cheaper than coalfired plants, consultants said in a study that the state released yesterday. In fact, the study said, new coal plants would cost about 20 percent less if state airpollution standards were relaxed to Federal levels.

title: Syrian Troops Put at 12,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The State Department estimated today that Syria had 12,000 troops in Lebanon, an in crease of 2,000 since late last week.

title: Court Lets Stand Natural Gas Rate
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Supreme Court today declined to review a Federal Power Commission order setting uniform ceiling price for sales of natural gas at the wellhead by producers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Brussels dispatch in The New York Times yesterday erroneously reported that the United States only current military aid program in black Africa was with Ethiopia In recent years Washington has given significant military aid to Zaire and Kenya as well. Corrective material appears in a dispatch on Page 5.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: JUNEAU. Alaska, June 14 (UPI) The United States Forest Service and Champion International of Stamford, Conn., have agreed to the cancellation of the biggest sale of national forest timber ever negotiated by the Federal agency, it was announced today.

title: Helping New York
description: I could sit back and do nothing, said Lucas Ferrara who started summer vacation a week ago from Xavie High School in Manhattan. But I'm already bored.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Father's Pride Glows in Mixed Doubles Tennis Event
description: Jennifer Lynch hesitated before stepping onto the tennis court and turned to her father. But what if we lose? she said softly.

title: SPAIN'S POLITICS: ALL IS CONFUSION
description: MADRID, June 14 The Spanish people have become confused about their political future after a week of contradictory events and conflict both within the Establishment and in the opposition camp.

title: Coast Guard Ships in Japan
description: YOKOSUKA, Japan, June 14 (AP)The United States Coast Guard training ships Munro and Campbell arrived at the U.S. Naval base here on Tokyo Bay today for a sixday visit. The 343 men aboard include 120 Coast Guard Academy cadets.

title: Hostos, Rescued at the Last Moment, Is Looking Forward to Another Year
description: Hostos Community College, the sixyearold bilingual institution that seemed a prime candidate for extinction because of the city's fiscal crisis, reopened yesterday along with the other schools in the City University cystem under a state rescue pian in which it was given a favored status.

title: Books of The Times
description: A CORONARY EVENT. By Michael Hatberstant M.D. and Stephan Lesher. 208 pages. Lippincott. $8.95.

title: Surge Continues in Soybean Prices
description: Rains over growing areas usually dampen speculators enthusiasm for buying corn and soybean contracts. Yesterday, however, prices for soybeans soared, and corn showed slight or no declines in various trading months despite heavy rains and more expected in key Middle West growing areas.

title: Williamsport Sets Opener
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., June 14 (AP)Canada will oppose Latin America and the United States East will meet the United States West in opening games of the 30th annual Little League World Series here on Aug. 24.

title: WILLIAM J. CLOSS, TURBINE DESIGNER
description: William J. Class an engineer who helped make Pratt & Whitney a leader in the manufacture of aircraft engines, died Sunday while vacationing at Rangely, Me. He was 61 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: The Ballet
description: Appoaring in her first Concbrot Barocco anywhere, Ghislaine Thesmar has undoubtedly discovered that George Balanchine's choreography is her best friend on stage, though it never hurts to have Peter Martins there as well. Colleen Neary was the other principal Sunday afternoon at State Theater during a beautiful, lyric performance of the piece.

title: Institute Proposes Nuclear Power Plants on Pacific Atolls to Supply Most of the World
description: LAXENBURG, AustriaAfter three developmental years an international institute established here under SovietAmerican auspices to attack the longrange problems of the industrialized countries has come of age.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities. The average rate for the threemonth bill was 5.380 percent, down form 5.459 percent for the preceding week. The average rate for the sixmonth bill was 5.695 percent, down from 5.768 percent from the previous week.

title: People and Business
description: Irving S. Shapiro, chairman of E. I. du Pont de Neinours & Company, yesterday was elected chairman of the Business Roundtable, a study group of 160 topranking corporate executives.

title: CAUCUS IN ACCORD ON AN INCOME TAX
description: TRENTON, June 14Twenty Democratic Senators were reported to have agreed in caucus this afternoon to support a 1.5 percent state tax on personal income, and Senate President Matthew Feldman said a floor voted on the tax would come on Thursday.

title: A Giant Portable HiFi In Park Debut Tonight
description: Portable hifi sets are not exactly unknown in the city's parks in the summertime, but this one is something special. It cost more than 8600,000, has 52 speakers and 16 dual 80watt amplifiers, and is compact enough to fold onto five 40foot tractortrailers.

title: Mary Hartman, Almost Profitable to Return in Falli
description: Although he last $1.2 million in the first year's production of Mary Hartman. Mary Hartman, Norman Lear, the producer, said yesterday the syndicated comedy soap opera would be continued next fall.

title: A Nursery School That Welcomes Under3'sand on an Hourly Basis
description: NEW CITY, N. Y.After Nancy Katz had been stricken with multiple sclerosis, she had to go to a hospital for therapy twice a week. What to do with her son, David, on those mornings? He was not quite 2 years old, and nursery schools here in Rockland County as elsewhere usually take only children who are at least 3.

title: Floridians Win Again In Tornado
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N.Y., June 14 Barring an unforeseeable chain of disasters, 16yearold Keith Notary and his football player crewman, David Gamblin, appear to be headed for Olympic uniforms. The pair from Merritt Island, Fla., are sailing themselves and their Tornado catamaran onto the Olympic yachting team which will compete in Kingston, Ontario, next month.

title: ISIDOR STRASSNER
description: Isidor Strassner, a musician, died Sunday at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Miami. He was 80 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Top New York Democrats Voice Support for Carter
description: Resigned rather than enthusiastic, New York's top Democrats, jumped aboard the Jimmy Carter Presidential bandwagon yesterday.

title: COURT LETS STAND INTEGRATION PLAN IN BOSTON SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Supreme Court refused without comment today to review the courtordered plan for desegregating Boston's public schools a plan that requires substantial busing and that President Ford has repeatedly criticized.

title: Gotbaum Scores Agency On Study of Labor Costs
description: Victor Gotbaum, exective director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employees, charged yesterday that the Temporary Commission on City Finances had misrepresented labor and fringe benefit costs for New York City employees in a report earlier this month.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Twins, at Minnesota. (TelevisionChannel 11. 9 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, P.M.)

title: May Trade Deficit In Britain Widened To $684 Million
description: LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) Britain announced today its worst trade figures for nine monthsa deficit of $684 million in May.

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: New York City P.A.L. Protests Ad Campaign
description: A telephone solicitation campaign, in which Manhattan businessmen are being asked to buy advertisements in a publication called the National PAL Magazine, has drawn a strenuous objection from officials of the Police Athletic League in New York City.

title: Taxi of Future Rolls Into the Present: Roomy, Comfortable, Easy to Get Into
description: If a panel of designersor antidesigners, as the case may betook it upon themselves to create the most uncomfortable, inconvenient and unattractive vehicle possible, they would probably come up with something resembling the New York taxicab. The Dodges that fill city streets may be excusable as private cars, but they are utterly unworkable when it comes to the space, comfort and ease of entrance and exit that are necessary if a vehicle is to earn its keep prowling the streets for paying passengers.

title: Panel in Hospital Dispute Urges Talks on CostofLiving Increase
description: A Federal factfinding panel, set up to try to avert a strike by 40.000 workers in New York City's voluntary hospitals, recommended yesterday, the negotiation of a costofliving increase and binding arbitration if the union and the hospitals reach an impasse.

title: Nigeria in Sugar Agreement
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 (UPI)Nigeria has acceded to the extended International Sugar Agreement 1973, the United Nations announced today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WHEELCHAIR FLAG PARADE: Patients at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island celebrated Flag Day yesterday. Flags of 50 states were carried by the patients.

title: Two Share Medal In Women's Golf
description: SUMMIT, N. 3., June 14Mrs. Harriett Doppelt of Brae Burn and Mrs. George Guard of North Jersey each carded an SO to share the medal in the qualifying round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association match play championship today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

title: EISENPREIS TO TAKE A ROLE AT CHAMBER
description: George Champion, chairman of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, announced yesterday that Alfred Eisenprels, who resigned as the city's Economic Development Administrator last Friday, would become a fulltime but temporary special consultant to the cham ber.

title: 50,000 Tin Miners On Strike in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 14 (UPI)About 50,000 Bolivian tin miners went on strike today in protest against a state of siege declared by President Hugo Banzer Surez.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Despite increasing doubts about the threat of a swine flu epidemic, New Jersey health officials are going ahead with preparations for inoculating seven million state residents, but have asked Federal authorities to maintain a worldwide surveillance for further outbreaks before beginning the inoculations. We have to be ready, Dr. Joanne E. Finley, the state's Commissioner of Health, told 65 state health officials meeting in Piscataway, N. J., to discuss the state's $2 million inoculation program.

title: Jersey Is Preparing Flu Vaccine Dosage For 7 Million People
description: PISCATAWAY, June 14State health officials said today they were preparing to inoculate seven million New Jersey residents against swine flu and asked the Federal Government to maintain worldwide surveillance for outbreaks of the disease.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Help Save CenterCity Neighborhoods
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 More than 2,000 residents of centercity communities around, the nation came here over the weekend to ask for Federal help in saving their neighborhoods from destructionsome of it at the hands of Federal agencies.

title: Runner Strides Toward Major Success
description: The stumbler shows signs of running. Saying so could jinx things, but Milan Stitt's play, which took 11 discouraging years and lots of rewrites to reach Broadway, teeters on the edge of creeping success.

title: Some Restaurant Diners Have Appetite for Accessories Too
description: Although it has been fully open for business only a few weeks, Windows on the World, the elaborately designed restaurant in the sky, atop the World Trade Center, has already lost many of its more distinctive and expensive table appointments to souvenirhun tins customers.

title: alustices Bar State's Taxation of Reservation Indians
description: WASHINGTON, June 14A 44yearold Minnesota Chippewa who fought a $147.95 county tax on his mobile home won his case in the Supreme Court todayand won as well a subtantial victory for American ndians seeking to assert tribal sovereignty against state interference.

title: 5th and 6thGrade Change Shelved by School System
description: Faced with opposition from some community school districts, Chancellor Irving Anker has shelved, at least for the present, a controversial plan to save $8.2 million a year by returning all fifthgrade and sixthgrade pupils who are now in intermediate and juniorhigh schools to elementary schools.

title: Air Mail for Lebanon Being Held at Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  The United States Postal Service announced today that all air mail and military mail to Lebanon was being held at John F. Kennedy Airport in New York because of the fighting in Beirut.

title: New York City Tax Base Drops to $38.827 Billion
description: New York City's property tax base shrank this year for the first time in 33 years, and independent experts predicted yesterday that the tax rate would rise by nearly 8 percent, to $8.836 per $100 of assessed valuation.

title: Foreign Stock Index
description: fFinancial Times. III Sole dDow Jones. sSwiss Bank Corporation, nTokyo new. oTokyo old.

title: Uruguay Awaits Form of Democracy Army Says It Will Eventually Restore
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 14The overthrow of the eleeed president, Juan Maria Bordaberry, has eliminated the last pretense of democratic government in Uruguay.

title: GRAHAM M. BROWNELL
description: Graham M. Brownell, a proofreader at The New York Times since 1963, died on Saturday at the age of 45. A freelance cartoonist and portrait artist in his spare time, Mr. Brownell was found dead at his apartment, 33 West 75th Street. The cause of death was not known. He is survived by his father, Frederick G. Brownell of Grosse Point Park, Mich.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Syrian troops were reported yesterday to have captured a garrison of the dissident group called the Lebanese Arab Army in southeastern Lebanon. The Voice of Palestine, the Palestinian radio, said that Syrian troops and armor had taken the garrison at Rasheiya, 15 miles southwest of the main Syrian encampment at Masnaa in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. The Damascus radio had announced earlier that the Moslem soldiers at Rasheiya who had defected from the regular Lebanese armed forces had rallied to what were described as the Syriansponsored vanguards of the Lebanese Army. [Page 1, Columns 56.]

title: Aaron Shows a Spark of Power As Brewers Rout Tanana by 82
description: Henry Aaron, the major league's career home run leader, is not hitting home runs the way he once did, and his prowess finally may be winding down after 22 big league seasons. But Aaron showed some of the old spark in Milwaukee last night, hitting one of the three home runs that led the Brewers to an $2 victory over the California Angels.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: CITY U. REOPENS AS KNEE SEEKS TO WITHHOLD PAY
description: The City University of New York reopened yesterday after a twoweek shutdown as students, teachers and staff members returned to 20 campuses in an atmosphere of relief, confusion and anger.

title: LOAN FROM 16 BANKS BY CHILE HELD SAFE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (Reuters)A $125 million loan to Chile by 12 United States and four Canadian banks appears safe, the Comptroller of the Currency, James E. Smith, said today in response to statements by the House Banking Committee's chairman, Henry Reuss, that the money might not be repaid.

title: Woman Rider Is Fatally Injured
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 14 (AP)Nelma Joan Henderson was fatally injured today when a horse she was exercising at Churchill Downs struck the rail, throwing her the track.

title: COURT LETS STAND INTEGRATION PLAN IN BOSTON SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Supreme Court refined without comment today to review the courtordered plan for desegregating Boston's public schools a plan that requires substantial busing and that President Ford has repeatedly criticized.

title: Top 2 Disqualified
description: The top two finishers were disqualified in the ninth race at Belmont Park yesterday, which may have provided a windfall for stoopers, those bettors who search the ground after a race looking for discarded winning tickets.

title: Supreme Court Issues Proxy Guides
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) In a major securities ruling, the Supreme Court today established the standard that companies must follow in disclosing information to stockholders when soliciting their proxies.

title: Kansas City, the Fretful Host, Prepares For the G.O.P. Convention in August
description: KANSAS CITY, MoIn anticipation of the Republican National Convention here in August, this city is trying hard to make its face resemble the famous smile button. But preconvention problems including shortagges of policemen, cabs and hotel spacejust will not go away, and the smile sometimes seems upside down. Nevertheless, smile is the word.

title: Civil Rights Leaders Urge Ford to Drop His Efforts to Limit Busing
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Civil rights leaders urged President Ford today to aban don plans to introduce legislation to limit court ordered school busing, warning that such a course would encourage defiance of the law and incite violence.

title: Boston Busing Foes Assail Court's Refusal to Review Case and Hint Violence May Result
description: BOSTON, June 11 White antibusing leaders denounced the United States Supreme Court's refusal to review courtordered school desegregation here today, and several made thinly veiled hints that it would spur new violence.

title: ISIDOR STRASSNER
description: Isidor Strassner, a musician, died Sunday at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Miami. He was 80 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Divorce Epidemic
description: The latest United States Government statistics show that the divorce epidemic is still in full swing and is even growing. In 1975 the number of marriages ended by divorce or annulment exceeded the million mark for the first time in history. There was almost one divorce for every two marriages last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Brussels dispatch in The New York Times yesterday erroneously reported that the United States only current military aid program in black Africa was with Ethiopia. In recent years Washington has given significant military aid to Zaire and Kenya as well. Corrective material appears, in a dispatch on Page 5.

title: E. B. White Takes On Xerox and Wins
description: E. B. White, the American essayist who has lived secluded with his hens, his hayfields and his typewriter on a farm in Maine for close to 40 years, has persuaded the Xerox Corporation, in an exchange of letters, to abandon the underwriting of magazine articles.

description: Dividends Announced

title: Saudis Seeking 1,900 AirtoAir Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Saudi Arabia is seeking to buy more than 1,900 Sidewinder interceptor missiles from the United States, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: Panama to Spur Copper Project Despite Cost and Price Outlook
description: PANAMA  The Panamanian Government has decided to press ahead with development of its vast Cerro Colorado copper deposits despite the enormous cost of the project and the uncertain outlook for world copper prices.

title: Hearst Judge Dies
description: Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter, who was the presiding judge in the trial of Patricia Hearst, died yesterday in San Francisco of a heart attack. Page 40.

title: 10 Die in Bulgaria Crash
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 14 (UPI)A passenger train collided with a freight train at Jasen, 100 miles northeast of Sofia, killing 10 persons and injuring 3, authorities said today.

title: Seoul Reports the Seizure Of 2 of Its Fishing Boats
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 14 (AP)Two South Korean fishing boats and 16 fishermen have been captured, apparently by Chinese fishing boats, in in ternational waters off the west coast of Korea, the Government's Office of Fisheries announced today.

title: Amex Seat Price Up $3,000
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that a scat was sold at $58,000, up $3,000 from the previous sale on June 10. Seats on the exchange are currently quoted at $50,000 bid and $65,000 offered.

title: THOMAS A. MAGUIRE
description: Thomas A. McGuire, retired president of Local 15 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, died Sunday at his Bronx home. He was 71 years old.

title: Levitt Deplores Policy of City In Keeping Mortgage Plan
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt has questioned New York Citv's wisdom in continuing to operate a mortgageinsurance program that, until yesterday, had been unable to insure a loan in its 32 months of existence.

title: SENATOR REGRETS SECRECY ON FUNDS
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 14 (AP)Senator J. Glenn Beall, Republican of Maryland, said today that he made an extremely poor decision six years ago when he concealed information that the Nixon White House funneled $180,000 into his successful campaign against former Senator Joseph D. Tydings, a Democrat.

title: BERLIN PARTY AIDE HELD AS RED SPY
description: WEST BERLIN. June 14The press spokesman for West Berlin's governing Social Democratic Party and his former wife have been arrested on suspicion of spying for East Germany, the city prosecutor announced today.

title: PRINCE KNUD DIES; DANISH CLAIMANT
description: COPENHAGEN, June 14 (AP) Prince Knud, an uncle of Queen Margrethe II, died today of a heart attack, the court announced. He was 75.

title: Higher Soviet Tax Brings Flurry of Gift Packages
description: Cosmos Parcel Express's drab storefront on Second Avenue and Fourth Street was closed yesterday, not because of a holiday or too little business, but because of too much.

title: Police Disperse a Crowd of Disappointed Rock Fans
description: The police dispersed a crowd of several hundred disappointed rock music fans who gathered outside the Beacon Theater on Broadway at 74th Street last night, hoping to buy admission tickets to a concert by the Grateful Dead rock group.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Subcommittee on small territories 3 P.M.

title: Howe Is Told His Arrest on Sex Charge Could Hurt Utah Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Senator Frank E. Moss, the head of the Utah Democratic delegation to Congress, told Representative Allan T. Howe today that Mr. Howe's arrest by Salt Lake City police on charges of soliciting prostitution had gravely diminished the Congressman's chances of reelection in November.

title: Chirac's Hand Strengthened by BehindtheScenes Crisis in French Cabinet
description: PARIS, June 14Prime Minisier Jacques Chirac emerged ??? today from a behindthescenes crisis that nearly ??? the French Government.

title: and Unsafe Dams
description: It is ironic that a little over a week after the catastrophic Teton Dam disaster, the Bureau of Reclamationthe agency that built the dam despite the expert judgment that it would be unsafehas submitted a bloated appropriation request to the House of Representatives. This year's money bill for one of Congress's favorite means of distributing its largesse stands at $751.6 milliona record that exceeds the agency's appropriation for the current year by $110 million.

title: Sentencing Delayed in Trial Of Man Who Faces Death
description: An acting State Supreme Court justice yesterday postponed the sentencing of Joseph Velez, 30 years old, who faces the mandatory death penalty for killing a policeman.

title: Bank of America in Egypt
description: LONDON, June 14 (UPI)The Bank of America has opened its first branch in Egypt and the 111th overseas branch of the bank, the bank said today.

title: Syria's Aims in Lebanon Clearer
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 14In the 12 days since Syria sent large numbers of troops into Lebanon, the Syrian objectives and the tactics President Hafez al Assad is using to achieve them have become more sharply defined. Through the confusion of politicaI and military activity in the Arab world in the last two weeks, President Assad has been methodically working toward the eventual creation of the kind of Lebanon the Syrian Government wants, and seeking to prevent the emergence of a Lebanon it does not Went.

title: INVENTORY GAINS SLOWED IN APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Manufacturers and merchants expanded their inventories in April for the fourth consecutive month but at a slower rate than in the previous month, the Government announced today.

title: Libertarian Party Confirms Its Presidential Campaign
description: DALLAS, June 14 (AP)The Libertarian Party confirmed Roger MacBride, 46 years old, of Charlottesville, Va., as its presidential candidate during a meeting in Dallas yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Lila. LIFTS NET 17.6% TO A RECORD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported record revenues and earnings in the three and 12 months ended May 31, with profits up 17.6 and 9.7 percent for the respective periods.

title: Hearst Judge Dies
description: Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter, who was the presiding judge in the trial of Patricia Hearst, died yesterday in San Francisco of a heart attack. Page 40.

title: 36,361 See Yankees Defeat Mets, 84
description: The Yankees beat the Mets, 84, at Yankee Stadium last night for their sixth Mayor's Trophy game victory in the last seven games and their eighth in 14 over all. More significant than this continued mastery over their borough rivals, perhaps, was the return to action of two injured outfielders for the first time this season.

title: Councilman Velez Mounting a Strong Challenge to Badillo for Seat in Congress
description: Ramon S. Velez, a Bronx Councilman with a powerful grass  roots organization in community agencies and supporters in the regular Democratic Party, announced yesterday that he would challenge Representative Herman Badillo for the nomination from the 21st Congressional District.

title: Judge Oliver Carter Dies at 65; Presided Over Hearst Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 14Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter, who presided over the Patricia Hearst bank robbery trial earlier this year died today of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Duffy Sq. (Naturally). To Get a Dab of Green
description: A dab of green is about to be added to the Great White Way.

title: Belmont Charts
description: ??? by Triansie Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, June 7. 38th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Bridge:
description: Four is certainly the lucky number for the New JerseyWestchester team that triumphed unexpectedly in the Grand National zonal playouts in Boston during the weekend. The margin of 4 international match points sufficed to defeat two more experienced groups, New York in the semifinal Saturday and then New England in the final Sunday.

title: 3 Die in Upstate Collision
description: SHANDAKEN, N. Y., June 14 (AP)Three persons were killed and a fourth was critically injured last evening in a twocar collision in this Ulster County town. Carol Hogan, 23 years old, of Daybrook, and her 5monthold daughter, Heather were killed. Mrs. Hogan's Husband, Michael, was in critical condition this morning in Benedictine Hospital in Kingston. Also killed was the woman driver of the other car.

title: Pentagon Presidency
description: WASHINGTONThe debate over the size of the $114 billion Pentagon budgetlargest in peacetime history is live ammunition in the Presidential race. Two arguments for even higher defense appropriations have impressed some audiences in the primary contests: First, that unless the arsenal of new weapons is increased, the United States will be secondbest to the Soviet Union; second, that unless defense contracts are put into the economic pipeline now, many workers will be laid off and new jobs will be unavailable.

title: Identity Study Urges Matching Of Birth and Death Documents
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) A Justice Department study group said today that a number of actions, including the matching of birth and death certificates, are necessary to ease a nationwide identification crisis costing at least $20 billion a year.

description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, June 14 (UPI)A bus that had swerved to avoid collision with another skidded off a highway near here yesterday and plunged into a ravine, where it burst into flames. The police reported that 17 persons were killed and 40 injured.

title: BarnesRevlon Pact Ends Syntex Talks
description: BarnesHind Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., announced yesterday it had terminated merger negotiations with the Syntex Corporation in favor of an agreement with Revlon Inc. for the sale of all BarnesHind shares. Under the new agreement, Revlon will exchange, on a Itaxfree basis, 0.733 shares of Revlon for each outstanding share of BarnesHind. At the closing price yesterday of 78 on the New York Stock Exchange, the value of Revlon shares to be exchanged totals about $4.9 million.

title: Nuclear Safety

Only the most enthusiastic industry lobbyists, however, could claim that the vote flashed a green light for untrammeled nuclear expansion. Quite the opposite message is being registered in state capitols across the country, where legislative measures are gaining support to enforce stringent requirements on the construction of new nuclear power facilities.

title: Notes on People
description: All decked out in blue velvet and white ostrich plumes, Sir Harold Wilson, former Prime Minister of Britain, went to Windsor Castle yesterday to be inducted by Queen Elizabeth II into Europe's oldest and most exclusive order of chivalry. In the simple installation service, the monarch strapped a garter just below Sir Harold's left knee, making him one of the 26 members of the Order of the Garter, which has only 26 knights on its active roll at a time. The order. steeped in legend, dates back to the year 1348, and it has been called the most exclusive club in the world. One of Sir Harold's predecessors, Winston Churchill, was a member. Queen Elizabeth knighted Sir Harold for services to his country when he stepped down April 5 and turned over the Prime Minister's office to James Callaghan. He's been criticized by several leftwing colleagues in his ruling Labor Party, for accepting what they consider a symbol of class.

title: DEBT ISSUE PRICES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Fixedincome security prices continued to rise yesterday, and the Federal Reserve reinforced the credit market's more optimistic atmosphere by purchasing Treasury bills for its own account an action that added reserves to Lila banking system.

Eugene Ormandy conducted the premiere concert in the eyecatching pavilion in West Fairmount Park, across the Schuylkill River from the old Robin Hood Dell music shell where the orchestra for the last 46 years has bridged the gap between spring and fall concert seasons.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An unemployed schoolteacher surrendered to Federal authorities rather than testify before a Federal grand jury investigating terrorist bombings in 1975 attributed to a Puerto Rican independence group, but was released three and a half hours later pending review of the case. The teacher, Lureida Torres, a 26yearold Bronx woman, had appealed a Federal Court contempt order but the appeal had failed. A member of the Puerto Rican Socialist Party, she contended that she had been called before the grand jury solely because of her political beliefs and not because of any act she had committed. Miss Torres and two other independence sympathizers were called before the grand jury in January. Subpoenas given the others were dropped. When she refused to testify, with a grant of immunity, she was cited for contempt. However, Thurgood Marshall, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court who is the supervising jurist for the district, granted a stay of United States District Judge Charles E. Brieant's contempt order.
