title: New Script but
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., June 15The adage is wrong. You can teach an old dog new tricks, after all, but it doesn't do any good. A new Joe Frazier, barely recognizable as the old heavyweight champion of the world with his head shaved as bald as a doorknob, fought an entirely new sort of fight tonight in his second battle with George Foreman. Instead of attacking, he countered. Instea dof smokin', as he calls it, boring straight in and punching ceaselessly, he circled, shifted, bobbed, ducked and covered up, firing mostly at long range. Instead of the grim and relentless destroyer, he was the happy warrior, laughing at his foe.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company agreed to Federal charges today that the company illegally contributed more than $300,000 to campaigns of Federal, state and local politicians.

title: Insurance Concerns Ask for an Open Market SysteM
description: TRENTON, June 15Representatives of the insurance industry called today for an end to the present priorapproval system of rate  setting for homeowner and automobile insurance and its replacement by an openmarket system, where rates would result from competition among the companies.

title: A.U.S. Yacht Wins Onion Patch Race
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 15 Williwaw and Rattler, both new sloops to the yacht circuit this year and already established at the top of the speed curves, placed first and second for the United States team here today in international competition for the Onion Patch trophy. In a warmup day race, prior to the start of the 635mile ocean race to Bermuda on Friday, a fleet of 77 yachts went to sea off Brenton Reef in two concurrent competitions for the Onion Patch and Henry du Pont trophies.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Chinese Government announced yesterday that Chairman Mao Tsetung was no longer receiving visiting foreign leaders. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said that the decision had been made by the Central Committee of the Communist Party, but he said that the chairman was still able to work despite his age of 82 years. (Page 1, Column 1.]

title: U.S. ASSAILS I.L.O. OVER COMMUNISTS
description: GENEVA, June 15 (UPI)The head Of the American delegation to a world employment conference denounced the International Labor Organization today for unforgivable bias toward Communist countries.

title: F.B.I. Links Letter Bombs To 200 Extortion Demands
description: Letter bombs that are turning up in the mails throughout, the country were described yesterday as followups to extortion demands addressed to about 200 leading business executives since last fall.

title: A's Sell Blue to Yanks for $1.5 Million, Rudi, Fingers to Boston for $2 Million
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15Charles O. Finley, the maverick owner of the Oakland A's, stunned the baseball world tonight by selling three of his biggeststarsVida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million and Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers to the Boston Red Sox for $1 million each. No player ever has been sold for that much money in baseball history.

title: Study Finds Shoppers Have Problems With 25% of Purchases
description: Consumers have problems with one out of every four of their purchases, but most of these problems go unreported to business or complaint agencies, according to a study that drew upon the experiences of 2.500 urban households.

title: RISE IN EXPORTS OF ARMS SCORED
description: MIAMI, June 15Growing American exports of modern weapon systems and nonmilitary technology could be detrimental to the nation's defense and economy, Dr. Fred C. Ikle, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said here today.

title: Fleet Owners Shun Taxicabs of Future
description: New York City's major taxicab fleet operators are reporting no interest at all in those roomy, comfortable cabs of the future to be on display starting Friday at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prim Tuesday, London: Morning flying $125.75, down S0.05; afternoon fixing $125.70, down S0.10. Paris: Afternoon market quotaflod $127.9. up 50.09.

title: Soybean Futures Fall
description: Prices of soybean futures fell sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn also declined. Page 54.

title: Toxicologist Doubts Antibiotics Caused Beaten Marine's Death
description: SAN DIEGO. June 15 (API)A Navy toxicologist said today that Lynn McClure, a Marine recruit who was severely beaten in combat training, did not die from an overdose of antibiotics. Medical witnesses had said that such an overdose could have caused death.

title: Grateful Dead Returns To New York in Triumph
description: The Beacon Theater was caught up in a time warp Monday and Tuesday nights, for the first of five metropolitanarea performances in theatersized halls by the Grateful Dead (the remaining three are tomorrow through Saturday at the Capitol Theater in Passaic, N.J., long since hopelessly sold out).

title: Miss Evert Wins Twice On Grass
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 15Chris Evert came back to grass for the first time since last year's Wimbledon tournament and won two matches to enter the round of 16 at the $90,000 Colgate women's invitation today.

title: INCREASED BENEFITS TO VETERANS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON. June 15 (AP) The House Veterans Affairs Committee voted today to increase monthly payments for 5.5 million veterans and dependents receiving pensions and disability payments to match costofliving increases.

title: About Education
description: The University of Cincinnati has lost its long struggle to retain its independence as a municipal institution and will become part of the Ohio state university network in July 1977.

title: U.N. Council Renews Its Force On Cyprus for 6 Months More
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15The Security Council, approved tonight a sixmonth renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peace force in Cyprus 17 minutes before the scheduled expiration of its cur rent term at midnight.

title: SixDay Olympic Swimming Trials Get Gun Today on Coast
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 15The toughest swimming meet in the world starts here tomorrow. For six days, the best American men and women swimmers will compete in the United States Olympic trials, and the best of the best will go on to the Olympic Games, July 17 through 31 at Montreal.

title: ExFootball Official Dies
description: SCRANTON. Pa., June 15 (AP) Cosmo lacovazzi, 47 years old, a former commissioner of the defunct Atlantic Coast Foot ball League, died last night in Mercy hospital, five days after undergoing surgery. Mr. lacovazzi, long active in sports, was a dress manufacturer in Scranton and a former owner of the Scranton Miners, which was afMinted with the New York Giants football team.

title: Loch Ness Panel Set
description: The Ocems Festival '76, a fair at the New York Aquqrium in Coney Island centering around the sea and marine life. will run every day through Sunday from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. A panel on the Loch Ness monster will be held on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 12:30 P.M.

title: Gerald D. Morgan Dead at 67; Helped Draft TaftHartley Act
description: Gerald Demuth Morgan, a lawyer who served as special counsel to President Eisenhower, died yesterday while vacationing in Mustique, St. Vincent Island in the Grenadines, West Indies. He was 67 years old.

title: First. Catch a Wild Boar (or Else Get Plenty of Fresh Pork)
description: ROBERTS ISLAND, Nova Scotia  Young wild boars can be cooked exactly like fresh pork. But one difference between a wild boar ranging the woods and a domesticated pig, Carlo Amato was saying as the plane circled Yarmouth Harbor, is that a wild boar climbs higher and will step over obstacles in his path. A domesticated pig walks around them

title: Hyde Park Gets a Mansion to Help It Cater to New Flow of Visitors
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.The empty rooms of the Bellefield mansion here adjacent to the home of Franklin Delano Roosevelt echo these days only to the occasional footsteps of National Park Service rangers and local visitors.

title: Books of The Times
description: For anyone to write objectively about his father is approximately as easy, I would imagine, as describing an elephant from a vantage point inside its belly. To write about a father one has every reason to dislike would seem only infinitely more difficult. Consider then the small miracle that Gregory H. Hemingway has wrought in Papa: A Personal Memoir. Dr. Hemingway's father, the prepotent Ernest, gave his third son plenty of reason to resent him in the course of their bittersweet relationship. He neglected him as an infant, leaving him with a tyrannical nursemaid while he took off on the sort of long safaris that produced The Green Hills of Africa. He divorced Gregory's mother, Pauline, his second wife, when the boy was still a preadolescent. He accused Gig of killing Pauline, when she diedof a tumorous adrenal gland, as it turned outin the midst of a family squabble over a mindstimulating drug Gig had taken long before it was fashionable to do so. And of course he was the worldfamous author, the ultimate celebrity, a wild bull elephant whose very existence would have had to seem threatening to its young.

title: E.H. BOECKH, AUTHOR OF BUILDING INDEX
description: WASHINGTON, June 15E. H. Boeckh, engineer and author of the Boeckh Index of Building Costs, which has been widely used in the United States and Canada in estimating costs and economic trends in the construction industry, died at his home in Alexandria, Va, last Saturday. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. Role Again Becomes An Election Issue in Italy
description: ROME. June 15  United States policy toward Italy is coming alive again as an issue in the present election campaign, to the unhappiness of American officials and the beleaguered Christian Democrats.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Inststing that carpeting is the single homefurnishing item most misunderstood by consumers and the one most subject to fraud at their expense, Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois has urged the Federal Trade Commission to conduct a thorough investigation of the carpet industry and to issue industrywide regulations.

description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., June 15 Following are excerpts from a conversation Jimmy Carter held with reporters lae last night on a flight from Texas to this resort:

title: Reward Offered in Slaying
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June IS (AP) Camden County Prosecutor; Thomas Shusted is offering a $2,500 reward in the slaying of a Cherry Hill housewife. Using authority granted him by the Camden County Board of Freed holders in 1974, Mr. Shusted is offering the reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer of Ann Goffinet. Mrs. Goffinet, who was 51 years old, was found bludgeoned to death last March 29 in her home at 372 Cresson Road. A baseball batI was found near the body.

description: WASHINGTON, June 15With the Democratic Party apparently united for the first time in years, its Platform Committee adopted a platform tonight that was extetled by all the factions of the party.

title: Market Place
description: Before there was a listed option market, the small investor rarely got involved in arbitrage, in which a profit is sought through price disparities in related securities. Commission expenses ordinarily precluded reasonable profits, and the game was thus left to Wall Street professionals.

title: Bond Prices Slip
description: The credit markets declined slightly yesterday, moving toward lower prices and higher interest rates as traders became nervous about a rise in the Federal funds rate above 5 percent. The Fed eral Reserve added reserves to the banking system by purchasing couponbearing Treasury securities but the action by the central bank did not make the market recover. Later in the day, the Treasury announced plans to sell $2.5 billion of twoyear notes on Monday to refinance $2 billion of similar securities that come due June 30 and to raise S500 million of additional cash. The Treasury will also sell S5.2 billion of threemonth and sixmonth bills Monday, a sale that will result in a reduction of S300 mfillion of bills outstanding.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers By 21
description: Jon Matlack hurled a strong sixhitter for his eighth victory against one defeat. Dave Kingman scored a run and batted in the winning one. John Milner saved the game with a tremendous running catch in left field.

description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.The empty rooms of the Bellefield mansion here adjacent to the home of Franklin Delano Roosevelt echo these days only to the occasional footsteps of National Park Service rangers and local visitors.

title: Lebanese Crisis Realigns Arab Politics, Isolating Syria and Focusing on P.L.O.
description: CAIRO. June 15The Palestine Liberation Organization headed by Yasir Arafat is at the center of the political jockeying that has sharpened old tensions land created new alignments in the Arab world since Syria's military intervention in Lebanon.

title: Jimmy Dykes Dies
description: Jimmy Dykes, whose major league baseball career as a player and manager spanned 50 years, died yesterday in Philadelphia. He played on A's championship teams in 1929. 1930 and 1931 and succeeded Connie Mack as the team's manager in 1951. He was 79 years old. Page 42.

title: BIASED STUDY LAID TO CIVIL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A toughly worded Civil Service Commission report last month, which acknowledged wrongdoing and complicity in preferential Government hiring practices during the Nixon years, was part of a commission plan to limit damage to its reputation and to ward off serious scrutiny from outside.

title: U.S. AND PHILIPPINES RENEW BASES TALKS
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, June 15 The United States and the Philippines resumed negotiations here today for a new agreement covering the American use of military bases in this country.

title: BONN SHIFTS SITE OF VORSTER TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15West Germany announced today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa would meet next week in the countryside and not in Hamburg as originaily planned because their talks were vital and they needed a secluded Place.

title: WINE TALK
description: Last week this space was given over to the results of a blind tasting of California white wines and some topgrade white wines of Burgundy. The tasting was held in Paris, the tasters were all French and the American wines took first, third, fourth and sixth places when all the points were added up.

title: DOCKER TESTIFIES ON FALSE CLAIMS
description: A blackhooded undercover agent for the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor testified yesterday that port employees had easy access to a network of lawyers and doctors who helped them file and collect on fraudulent claims for workmen's compensation.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 15New Jersey's proposed new penal code, which among other things decriminalizes social gambling, drunkenness and consensual sexual deviance, will come up for a second round of debate in the State Assembly tomorrow.

title: U. S. Mirror in Spain
description: MADRIDThe biggest result of King Juan Carlos's recent visit to the United States was proofto Americans and Spaniardsthat this country is committed to a democratic system under constitutional monarchy. Although the speeches and private conversations of the monarch and his Foreign Minister, Jose Marfa de Areilza, Count of Motrico, were addressed to American public opinion, political leaders and economic tycoons, perhaps their greatest initial impact has been felt inside Spain.

title: Fouling the Air
description: The air New Yorkers breathe was officially labeled unhealthy for three days running last week. On Friday evening, traffic out of the city was as congested as it has been for yearsand the real summer is yet to come. Nevertheless, New York officials, city and state, continue to stonewall Federal efforts to prod them to take some action on a threeyearold, locally developed plan that would ease traffic congestion and raise the quality of city air to federally prescribed standards.

title: F.B.I. Links Letter Bombs To 200 Extortion Demands
description: Letter bombs that are turning up in the mails throughout the country were described yesterday as followups to extortion demands addressed to about 200 leading business executives since last fall.

title: BANK IN JERSEY HELD INSOLVENT
description: JERSEY CITY, June 15 (AP)A Hudson County bank, the former president of which admitted misusing bank funds, has been declared insolvent and its assets sold to another New Jersey bank.

title: Climbing Wall Is Way of Life For Two Washington Women
description: WASHINGTON, June 15When she tells people about her job, Barbara Gale has to watch her words. Otherwise, she says, people think you're passing bad checks. Barbara Gale is a paperhanger.

title: Kvancz Named to Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)Jack Kvancz, Catholic University head basketball coach, will also become the school's athletic director effective Sept. 1. Kvancz succeeds Brian McCall, who will take over as business manager, a newly created post.

title: U.S. AND PHILIPPINES RENEW BASES TALKS
description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, June 15 The United States and the Philippines resumed negotiations here today for a new agreement covering the American use of military bases in this country.

description: Kalman H. Silvert, a program adviser for the Ford Foundation and an authority on Latin American affairs, died yesterday of a heart attack at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 55 years old and lived with his family in Greenwich Village.

title: Husband Gets Life in Slaying
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 15 (AP)A Garfield man has been found guilty of firstdegree murder in the death of his wife, whom he bludgeoned to death with a baseball bat. A jury today declared Robert Augustine, 25 years old, guilty in the slaying of his wife Noreen, 25, on Dec. 3. Judge Alfred D. Schiaffo in Bergen County Court immediately sentenced him to life in state prison.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS SELECT O'DWYER, QUALIFY 3 OTHERS

title: and the Waterways
description: The sight of sails and sleek fishing boats splicing a wake in the waterways around New York can lift the spirits of onlookers from afaruntil they try to dip a toe in the water and discover that on some days the shoreline resembles a sewer. Efforts to enforce marine regulations are branded government encroachment, and are frequently ignored or resisted.

description: It was a nightand a day to remember for the Class of 76 at Glen Rock High School.

title: AUTO SALES ROSE 41% FOR 10 DAYS
description: DETROIT, June 15 (AP)Domestic new car sales during the first 10 days of June registered a 41 percent increase based on the daily selling rate, the nation's automakers reported today.

description: The Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday a net loss of $9.6 million for April, but said it would not disclose a comparable figure for April 1975 because at that time it was primarily a railroad company whereas today it is basical a real estate holding company.

France and the United States then compromised their difference over centralbank intervention to deal with erratic and disorderly foreign exchange markets, but agreed to allow floating rates as part of the international monetary system.

title: 6 in Illinois Family Die in Fire

The dead were identified as Carl Mauck, 33 years old; his wife, Patricia, 33; their daughters Julie, 14, and Amy Jo., 1; Mr. Mauck's mother,. ;Naomi Mauck, 67, of Hudson, and Mrs. Mauck's mother, Mrs. Kathryn Jackson, 64, of Bloomington.

title: People in Sports

His award was named for the late Arthur Daley, longtime sports columnist for The New York Times and a Pulitzer Prize winner.

description: TRENTON, June 15 (AP)The State Bicentennial Commission reported Tuesday that 512 of the 567 municipalities in New Jersey have been designated as official Bicentennial communities.

description: The chancellor of the City University of New York said yesterday that he would pay faculty members for the two weeks the system was shut down, an action that could leave the university $15 million short of meeting its other obligations for the rest of the fiscal year.

title: 3 Quakes Hit Central Japan, Causing Slight Damage
description: TOKYO, Wednesday June 16 (Reuters)Three earthquakes jolted central Japan today, causing one casualty, leaving minor damage and disrupting train services. The casualty was caused when a boulder hit a driver's car.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The value of Revlon Inc. shares to be exchanged for BarnesHind Pharmaceuticals Inc. stock in a corporate merger story in The Times yesterday was incorrectly reported. The correct figure is $44.9 million. Also, Revlon's correct 1975 net income was $62.6 million.

title: Viking Slowed to Allow Mars Landing on July 4
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 15 (UPI)Viking I, approaching the planet Mars, was slowed slightly today and put on a course that probably will permit an historic landing on the red planet on the 200th birthday of the United States.

title: Angolan Witnesses Testify Against Mercenaries
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 15Angolan prosecution witnesses accused 13 British and American mercenaries today of murder, massacre, laying minefields, abuse of civilians, pillage and the destruction of property.

title: Advertising
description: The seers of the Interpublic Group of Companies are predicting that 1976 will show the greatest percentage increase of advertising spending over the previous year for any year since the end of World War II.

title: Montreal Receives First Oil From New Pipeline
description: MONTREAL, June 15 (AP)The first continuous flow of crude oil from Western Canada arrived in Montreal today through a new 520mile pipeline extension from Sarnia, Ontario.

title: Dance: Sumptuous Sleeping Beauty
description: Time flew back 30 years at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was the premiere of American Ballet Theater's new and sumptuous production of the Petipa/ Tchaikovsky classic The Sleeping Beauty. But in a very real sense it was a reproduction of the staging Britain's Royal Ballet first unveiled at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, in 1946, and the very same production that conquered New York three years later.

title: Heavy Markdowns By Retailers Seen
description: Thomas M. MaCioce, president and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, said yesterday that he anticipated heavier markdowns in the retail industry during the current second quarter than in 1975 since onethird of the quarter is already represented by lower sales than a year ago.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Lenore Overture No. 3, Beethoven; Sonata a Tre, Schmelzer; Classical Symphony, Prokofiev; Harpsichord Suite in D minor, Dandrieu; Symphony in G, Mozart.

title: Simon Sets New Conditions On Loans to New York City
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Treasury Department officials said today that they had asked New York City to submit a revised financial plan and obtain new labor agreements as a condition for further Federal loans.

title: Television
description: Television

title: SIGNATURES STUDIED IN RECALL OF RIZZO
description: PHILADELPHIA. June 15 (UPI)  City commissioners have 15 days to determine if there are enough valid signatures to force a recall referendum in answer to a petition to recall Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, presented today.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: Met Begins Parks Season With a Resounding Aida
description: The Metropolitan Opera presented Aida last night with the world's most spectacular set, the Manhattan skyline, as a backdrop. Colored balloons hung over the Central Park audience, a searchlight played across the skies in the finest Hollywood premiere style, and a flashing sign in the distance proclaimed that the temperature was a warm but not suffy 84 degrees.

title: SCHOOL IN CHICAGO CATERS TO INDIANS
description: CHICAGO, June 15When urban American Indian teenagers are graduated from Little Big Horn High School in Chicago, they receive the usual diplomas, but they have learned more than mathematics, English and history. They have learned about themselves.

title: Events Today
description: SEXUAL. PERVERSITIES1N CHICAGO and DUCK VARIATIONS by David Mamet; directed by Albert Takazauckas; at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, 7.

title: OIL BREAKUP BILL GOES TO SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today, by an 8to7 vote, to send to the floor a bill to break up 18 large oil companies into separate production, refining and refiningmarketing entities.

title: Arafat Meets King Khalid
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 15 (Agence FrancePresse)The Palestine Liberation Organization's chairman, Yasir Arafat, had a meeting here today with King Khalid on the first leg of a tour of Arab capitals. Mr. Arafat is seeking support for the Arab League's measures to end the Lebanese civil war.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Manufacturers Trust Sues Franklin on Nondisclosure
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company disclosed yesterday that it had filed a $30 million suit against the defunct Franklin National Bank on charges that Franklin failed to disclose its precarious financial position when Manufacturers Hanover was lending it money in 1974.

title: Senate Panel Approves Strong Wiretapping Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (Reuters)The Senate Judiciary Committee overwhelmingly approved today a proposal by President Ford requiring the Government to obtain court orders for virtually all wiretaps for foreign intelligence and national security purposes in the United States.

title: 6 Killed in South Africa as Blacks Protest on Language
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 16At least six people died today when a demonstration by 10,000 black students turned into a riot.

title: Foreman Faces Long Wait for Title Shot
description: While Joe Frazier grows back his hair and the promoers of Tuesday night's fight pull theirs, George Foreman must talk up a fight with Jimmy Young.

title: Levi Believes the Courts Try to Heed Busing Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he thought the Federal courts had tried to follow the 1974 law that calls on the courts to order busing in school desegregation cases only as a last resort.

title: Music: 'Quintessence
description: When a music ensemble names itself The Quintessence, one assumes that five performers are probably involved, and that proved to be at leastpartly true of the group that gave a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

title: Ford Signs Witness Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)President Ford signed today a bill providing for leave. for Federal employees to testify as witnesses in court proceedings where the Government is involved. The legislation provides that, when an employee is summoned in his personal capacity to appear in a judicial proceeding on behalf of a state or local government, he is entitled to court leave. The provisions do not apply to an employee summoned to testify in personal capacity on behalf of private parties.

title: 3 in Lockheed Case Fight Ruling on Japan Testimony
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) Two former Lockheed Aircraft Corporation executives and one of its marketing officials are appealing an American court's decision that they must lanswer Japanese prosecutors questions on the company's payoffs in Japan, it was disclosed today.

title: 6 Die in South Africa Riot After Black Student Protest
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 16At least six people died today when a demonstration by 10,000 black students against instruction in the Afrikaans language turned into a riot.

title: 2Hour Strike Is Ended At Trust Company of Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY, June 16 (UPI) Tellers, clerks and secretaries for the Trust Company of New Jersey have returned to work following a twoandahalfhour strike that closed 18 of the bank's offices in four counties.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday. June le, 1976 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Suit Says Community Has Gone to the Dogs
description: A New York University art professor, who says that for the last two and a half years he has been harassed by yelping hordes of dogs, is seeking to muzzle a midtown pet shop.

title: Flushing Center Opens Wednesday
description: After two years of extensive restoration, the former Flushing Town Hall, at 137 35 Northern Boulevard, Queens, will open Wednesday as a performingarts center, it was announced by Stephen Philips, impresario. Mary Travers will headline the openingnight bill starting at 8:30 P.M. In addition to Miss Travers, Mr. Phillips has scheduled for later programs such artists as Lana Cantrell, Phyllis Newman and Irwin Corey.

title: Head of F.A.A. Predicts U.S. Will Produce SST
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration predicted yesterday that the United States would follow up the Concorde program by producing a secondgeneration superconic airliner, probably in cooperation with the Europeans.

title: Crosland Sees a Wider War in Rhodesia
description: LONDON, June 16The Brit??? Secretary, Anthony Crosland, predicted today that unless Rhodesia accepted majority rule quickly the country would face bloody conflagration involving the United states, the Soviet Union and Cuba.

title: Unregistered Stock Sites Charged to Former Broker
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit yesterday against Robert C. Drucker, a former stockbroker, on charges of attempting to sell unregistered stock in Beneficial Labs of New York.

title: Biggest U.S. Banks Shun Soviet Loan
description: A $250 million Eurodollar, borrowing by the Soviet Union was virtually completed yesterday with the two largest United States commercial banks deciding not to participate.

title: Women and Rights Units Assail Prostitute Decoys
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 16The prostitute decoy program. under which Representative Allan T. Howe was arrested last Saturday night here, is one that has long troubled both civil libertarians and feminists.

title: Top Insiders and Some Outsiders Put Out Time
description: The law section in the current Time magazine was written by James R. Shepley. Time Inc., president. It says the United States Supreme Court faces an unprecedented spillover of court decisions into July.

title: CARTER CAMPAIGN $1 MILLION IN DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Jimmy Carter's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination has left his campaign organization with a deficit of more than $1 million, but no one is worrying much about it.

title: Elephant Dies in Surgery
description: MIAMI, June 16 (AP)Dixie, a 21yearold elephant, died today at Crandon Park Zoo durling a second operation to cure an arthritic right leg. A zoo spokesman said the threeIon elephant had had a heart attack while under sedation as a team of doctors was preparing to remove pins inserted in her ankie last Saturday and place her foreleg in a cast. The pins slipped out of position over the weekend. She died before surgery was performed, said the spokesman.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Lisbon dispatch in The Times Sunday reported that five candidates were seeking the presidency in Portugal. The number should have been four, because the Supreme Court has disqualified Wenceslau Pompilio da Cruz, who sought to represent. Portuguese refugees from Africa.

title: Doctor, Blind Since He Was 8, Is Honored by 400 at Dinner
description: Graduation from medical school is an event well worth celebrating, hilt last night's blacktie dinner that drew 400 people to a tribute to Dr. David W. Hartman, a 1976 graduate of the Temple University School of Medicine, was unusual, to say the least.

title: Babashoff Excels at Swim Trials
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 16The United States Olympic swimming trials started today with two American records by Shirley Babashoff and impressive victories by Bruce Furniss and John Hencken in events in which they hold the world records. It was an auspicious start to a sixday meet that will result in selection of 27 men and 24 women to represent the United States next month in the Montreal Olympics.

title: The Cast
description: THE CRUCIBLE, by Arthur Mil er. Directed by Michael Kann setting or David Jenkins; costumes Dv Jane Greenwood; lighting or John McLain; music selected and arranged by Herbert Kaplan; hairstyles by Steve Atra: music director and conductor, Mr. Kaplan; stage manager, Suzanne Egan. Presented by the American Shakespeare Theater, Michael Kahn, artistc cirector. At Stratford, Conn.

title: Personal Finance: Country Club Membership Cost
description: J. P. Morgan, the famous financier, is said to have remarked that if you have to ??? what It costs to run a yacht, you can't afford one. Today many people believe that a similar statement might be made about joining a country club.

title: Arizona Advances In Title Baseball
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 16 (AP)A tiebreaking home run by Steve Powers touched off a fiverun eighth inning tonight and lifted Arizona to an 116 victory over Eastern Michigan in the 30th Colylege World Series. The loss was Eastern Michigan's first in four series games and left the nation's top three rated teams alive for the championship.

title: The Steinbrenner AllStars
description: Now that the New York Yankees have acquired Vida Blue and Ken Holtzman the way the Metropolitan Museum of Art collects precious paintings, they might win the American League East and the pennant and the World Series, and if that happens, George Steinbrenner and Gabe Paul deserve the credit for putting their money where their heart is. Not every club owner is willing to do that. Too many look at the bottom line each morning before they look the standings. From that viewpoint, the Steinbrenner All Stars ought to be applauded. But yet a sense of embarrassment dominates what the Yankees did. Pennants and World Series should be won by planning, by selecting and developing players, by working to create a team not by writing checks for stars. Anybody with money can write checks. Pennants and the World Series should be earned, not purchase4. But whatever the Yankees accomplish now, they will have purchased. And that diminishes the value, if not desecrates it.

title: The Religious Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The religious issue raised against Jimmy Carter says more about the people raising than it does about him.

title: Harald T. Friis, 83, Dead; Communications Pioneer
description: Harald T. Friis, a pioneer in several branches of radio communications, died Tuesday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83.

title: Charles R. Anthony Dead in Oklahoma; Began Store Chain
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 16(UPI)Charles Ross Anthony, founder of a department store chain, died today in St. Anthony's Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: Kelley Says Apology for Abuses of F.B.I. Was to Placate Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Clarence M. Kelley, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has said privately that his recent apology for the bureau's past abuses of its power was made in the hope that it might well prevent or at least somewhat retard the proliferation of highly restrictive legislation directed at the bureau by Congress.

title: Sale of Offshore Leases For Oil Drilling Slated
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The the lands in the middle Atlantic first leasesales to United offshore area would he offered States oil companies of rights; for sale in early July and that to drill for oil and gas off the Aug. 17. was the date the bids Atlantic coastline have beentwould be opened. The departscheduled for Aug. 17 in New ment then will choose specific York City, Interior Secretary oil companies to do the drilling.

description: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries

title: Spain Is Seeking Credits to Spur Its Lagging Economy
description: MADRID. June 16Spain has begun an effort to extract economic advantages from the political good will that has accompanied its preliminary moves toward democratic institutions.

title: DR. A. M. SELIGMAN, TUMOR EXPERT, DIES
description: BALTIMORE, June 16 (UPI) Dr. Arnold M. Seligman, chief of umor research at Baltimore's Sinai Hospital and a native of St. Johnsbury, Vt., died at the hospital yesterday of the type of cancer he was researching. He was 64 years old.

title: CONNALLY COUNSELS FORD ON CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 16John B. Connally, convinced that President Ford will win the Republican Presidential nomination, counseled Mr. Ford today on strategy for the Nov. 2 election campaign.

title: Williwaw Captures Third Race in Row
description: It was the third victory in a row for the new 41foot Two Ton Class sloop owned by Seymour Sinett of Metuchen, N.J. Williwaw's first place, a sixth for Ted Turner's Tenacious and a seventh for Jon Kirk's Rattler kept the United States team well ahead in the international racing for the Onion Patch Trophy.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: As part of a continuing campaign to attract Wall Street firms to New Jersey, top officials from New Jersey, including Governor Byrne, have been conferring with top officials from the American Stock exchange, the Amex disclosed yesterday. An Amex official, responding to reports that the Amex was being wooed, said the exchange was compelled to take into consideration offers from both Connecticut and New Jersey but that only the most commanding circumstances would make us move.

title: Bank of England Linking Oil Nations to Pound Drop
description: LONDON, June 16The Bank of England identified the leading oilproducing countries today as the likely agents behind the yearlong decline of the British pound.

title: PERJURY CHARGED AT ANGOLA TRIAL
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 16An Angolan court ordered the arrest today of an important prosecution witness for perjury in the trial here of 13 British and American mercenaries.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold Prices Wednesday. London: Morning Fixing $125.10. down$0.60: afternoon fixing $125.00. down $0.70. Paris: Afternoon market quotationS127.27, down $0.12.

title: Events Today
description: MUSICAL HOLDOUTS, three documentaries, at the Film Forum.

title: Israelis Resist Move To Return U.S. Man Who Burned a Car
description: TEL AVIV, June 16  ProGovernment members of Parliament made a dramatic move today to prevent the extradition of a young Jew wanted in California, where he is accused of setting fire to an autoImobile to draw attention to Nazi war criminals who live in the United States.

title: Smithsonian Urges Public to Dig at the Family Tree
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Parents make children, and children make parents. But what do families make?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians at City Center
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet, which performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in April but obviously desired a Manhattan season, popped up Tuesday night at the City Center for a run through Sunday afternoon.

title: Bergman Urges Judge to Show Mercy And Not Jail Him for AgedHome Fraud
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursing home promoter, appealed to a Federal judge yesterday not to send him to prison for his confessed role in a S1.2 million Medicaid and tax fraud.

title: France Is Assuming Rights In 200Mile Offshore Zone
description: PARIS, June 16 (Reuters)France announced plans today to declare a 200mile economic zone: laying claim to all fishing and mineral rights within it.

title: People in Sports
description: The promoters are calling the series the Dream Mile Triple, and Marty Liguori, one of the eight milers who will compete in the three races after the Olympic Games this summer, is calling it a dream come true, to get all the top guys together.

title: Theft by Computer: Programmer Taps U.S. Data Secrets
description: BALTIMORE, June 16 (UPI)A computer programmer who said he wanted only to prove the laxness of computer security has been convicted in Federal court of tapping classified Federal energy information from a computer.

title: Chess:
description: Anatoly Narpov's first prize in the Euwe Quadrangular in Amsterdam was his fourth in a row, coming after his international tournament victories in Portoroz, Milan and Skopje. The 25yearold World Champion has enjoyed a perfect record since April 1975, when he was proclaimed Bobby Fischer's successor by the International Chess Federation.

title: TShirt Designers Rate an A In Geography
description: Busy executives drop what they're doing when the Great Northern Land and Cattle Company calls.

title: Stage: Miller's Crucible in Stratford
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 16There are some plays that have a background, other plays that have a context. A few plays have both. The background to Arthur Miller's play The Crucible, which was staged here this afternoon by the American Shakespeare Festival, and which I saw at a preview, is the notorious Salem witchhunts that rocked New England in 1692. But the context of the play is far more contemporaryfor it is Mr. Miller's response to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's hearings, that later witchhunt that, in fact, rocked the entire world during the early 50's.

title: U.S. to Sell Kenya 12 F5's In $70 Million Arms Deal
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 16The United States has agreed to sell 12 F5 jet fighter planes to Kenya in one of the biggest single American arms deals in Africa, according to senior United States officials. The agreement, which needs Congressional approval, was discussed today by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Kenya's Defense Minister, James S. Gichuru.

title: G.E. Charged With Exposing Workers to High PCB Levels
description: ALBANY, June 16 (AP)Federal jobsafety officials have charged the General Electric Company with exposing employees to potentially deadly levels of PCB's at its upstate New Yark plants in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial [June 9] concerning the recent report of the Secretary General of the United Nations to the Security Council on the U.N. operation in Cyprus accentuates the negative aspects and ignores the positive sides.

title: $5 Million Sought for New Dance Center
description: Joanne Woodward, the actress, is heading a drive to raise S5 million for the establishment of a dance company and dance center that would challenge the assumption that the performing arts must be a moneylosing proposition.

title: Cosmos Protest 32 Loss
description: After losing, 32, in overtime to the Boston Minutemen at Yankee Stadium last night, the New York Cosmos protested the North American Soccer League contest because Boston apparently didn't follow the rule on the taking of penalty kicks to determine a winner after a game has ended in a deadlock.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: BRITAIN'S UNIONS BACK PAY CURBS
description: LONDON, June 16The Government won overwhelming union support today for at least one more year of its effort to reduce Britain's inflation through severe wage restraint.

title: SENATE EXTENDS ENERGY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Senate approved today and sent to conference with the House a bill to continue the Federal Energy Administration and require major energy companies to disclose costs and profits for major functions, such as oil production or refining.

title: ASSAD DEFERS TRIP TO EAST EUROPE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 16Government sources said today that President Hafez alAssad was postponing scheduled trips to Yugoslavia and Rumania. which were to have taken place immediately after the President's threeday visit to Paris beginning tomorrow.

title: Majestically Tall Ships to Create Logistically Tall Problems for Short Time
description: As happens with public events of such magnitude as the city's celebration of the Bicentenniala weekend affair that will combine Operation Sail and the International Naval Review in the waters around Manhattan and the July 4th in Old New York Festival on the land of Lower Manhattanlogistics become complex, and everybody's desire to become a V.I.P. with visiting and viewing privileges becomes intense.

title: Payments Balance Swings Into Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The United States balance of payments on current account swung, as expected, into modest deficit in the first guarter of this year after a strong surplus all through 1975, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Gamble's 3Run Homer Helps Yanks Top Twins
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 16Following a clubhouse scene that sounded like a 25th anniversary high school reunion, the Yankees went out and routed the Minnesota Twins, 94, tonight.

title: Market Place
description: When a brokerage firm acts as a dealermanager of a hostile tender offer, a conflict of interest inevitably results. Customers of the broker who own the soughtafter shares call in, asking whether they should tender. The registered representatives are on the spotthey cannot offer impartial advice.

title: Angola Ousts Correspondent Of The Times of London
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 16The Ministry of Information accused The Times of London tonight of waging a libelous campaign against the Government of Angola, withdrew official accreditation from the correspondent and asked him to leave.

title: 6 Slain in Guerrilla Clash
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 16 (AP)Two more white Rhodesian soldiers and four black nationalists have been killed in Rhodesia's guerrilla war, the Government announced today.

title: ALBERTO MORE DIES; U.N. CORRESPONDENT,
description: Alberto More, former United Press International correspondent at the United Nations, died Tuesday of cancer at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 14041 Quince Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Stockholdings of Insiders
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following.

title: Head of Mailers Honored
description: George E. McDonald, president of Local 6 of the Mailers Union, was given a special award last night by the Newspaper Guild of New York for his success in promoting unity and solidarity among newspaper unions during the 197576 contract negotiations. The award and a plaque were given to Mr. McDonald, who heads the Unity Committee of Newspaper Unions, at the Princeton Club, where the guild's previously announced Page One Awards for journalistic achieve ment were also presented.

title: Kuhn Holds Up Sale of A's Stars
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered a hearing yesterday on the mass sale of stars by the Oakland A's. He ordered the players not to change sides until he had investigated the new issues raised by the money revolution sweeping the sport.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization committee 1030 A.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Lisbon dispatch in The Times last Sunday reported that five candidates were seeking the presidency in Portugal. The number should have been four, because the Supreme Court has disqualified Wenceslau Pompilio da Cruz, who sought to represent Portuguese refugees from Africa.

title: Pal Joey Slated To Open June 27
description: The Circle in the Square production of the Rodgers and Hart musical Pal Joey has settled on Sunday, June 27, at 3 P.M. for its opening. It was delayed when two principal players, Edward Villella and Eleanor Parker, left the cast. They have been replaced by Christopher Chadman and Joan Copeland, who are featured along with Janie Sell, Joe Sirola and Boni En ten.

title: CB: Banding Together
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 16If my rug rats want to send 80.8's around the house, they can get me ears for Father's Day.

title: New Youth Program for Counties Draws Criticism at Convention
description: CHERRY HILL, June 16James E. Girzone, commissioner of New York's Rensselaer County Department of Youth, said today that New Jersey blundered in imposing a new youth program on its counties two years ago.

title: Zuccotti Says City May Aid University
description: Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti said last night that the city might be able to find the $15 million the City University needs to meet its June payroll, but would not do so until the university submitted a plan showing how it intended to close a $48 million budget gap for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: Drama Critic a $13 Smash Hit In Fashion Stakes at Belmont
description: Will Elmendorf's Drama Critic follow in the steps of Ruffian and Dearly Precious? The 2yearold daughter of Reviewer scored her first career triumph in the $38.375 Fashion yesterday at Belmont Park. Ruffian, in 1974, and Dearly Precious, last year, used the 5furlong Fashion, which yesterday had its 78th running, as a stepping stone to 2yearold filly championships. Judging by Drama Critic's performance, this filly may also be on the way to a crown.

title: The China Knot
description: Increasing signs that Mao Tsetung's health is failing and that the succession struggle in China is intensifying have revived proposals in Washington to normalize relations with Peking. It is acknowledgedbut proponents brush over the factthat this step would require termination of the American defense treaty as well as diplomatic relations with Taipei.

title: HECHT TO RESIGN; SEEKS JUDGESHIP
description: ALBANY, June 16Assemblyman Burton G. Hecht, who as chariman of the Ways and Means Committee holds they third most powerful leadership post in the Assembly, has decided to run for a Civil Court judgeship in the Bronx rather than seek reelection to an eighth Assembly term.

title: O.A.S. APPEALING TO CHILE ON RIGHTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile. June 16A large majority of American governments called on Chile today to allow the InterAmerican Human Rights Commission to continue monitoring violations and collecting information in this country.

title: WALDHEIM DEPLORES KILLINGS IN BEIRUT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16Secretary General Kurt Waldheim in a statement deplored today the shooting of Francis E. Meloy Jr., the United and Ambassador to Lebanon, and of two staff members, and called the slayings a senseless act of violence which adds yet another fatal chapter to the tragedy of Lebanon.

title: SENATE EXTENDS ENERGY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Senate approved today and sent to conference with the House a bill to continue the Federal Energy Administration and require major energy companies to disclose costs and profits for major functions, such as oil production or refining.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLOCKHoward, 7/10/516/17/68. Dearest Howie, when evening shadows are falling and we are sitting here alone, In our ??? there comes a longing, If you only could come home. Love, Mom, Dad, Patti and Mitch.

title: New England Jobless Off
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)There were 45,600 fewer people out of work during April than in March in New England the United States Labor Department reported today. The regional unemployment figure for April was 492,000, or 8.7 percent of the work force, compared to 9.7 percent in March. More jobs in construction, trade and services contributed to the improvement, the agency said.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street. Flushing Meadow. Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9. 8 P.M.) (RadloWNEW, 7:50 P.M.)

title: Dodgers Top Mets By 4 to 1
description: The goodpitch, nohit Mets did their thing last nightfor six innings. And the Los Angeles Dodgers cooperated for six innings. So far, so good: 10, Mets.

title: Giscard, on TV, Asserts Right To Determine Policy of France
description: PARIS, June 16In a wideranging television interview to night, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing asserted his right to determine basic French policy and to decide the composition of the Government.

title: Finley: No Plans To Sell the A's
description: OAKLAND, June 16Charley Finley's sale of three star players for $3.5 million and no players in exchange triggered widespread speculation here that he is getting ready to sell his American League franchise, the Oakland A's.

title: Noel R. Weiss, Producer, Is Dead in Buffalo at 44
description: Noel R. Weiss, a theatrical producer died of a liver ailment Sunday in a hospital in Buffalo. He was 44 years old and had lived at 39 East 78th Street and in East Hampton.

title: Chicago Man, 30, Charged In Slaying Stranded Woman
description: CHICAGO, June 16 (UPI)A 30yearold Chicago man was charged with killing Phyllis Anderson, 51 years old, of Buffalo Grove, Ill., and wounding her husband while the couple sat stranded under a flooded viaduct on the city's South Side during Sunday's night's storm.

title: India Adds Year to the Preventive Detention Period
description: NEW DELHI, Junt 16 (AP)The Indian Government today extended for one year its right to hold political prisoners without trial or formal charges.

title: HIRING OF NEWSMEN BY C.I.A. TO BE TOPIC
description: Representatives of the National News Council and the, Central Intelligence Agency will meet next Thursday in an attempt to clarify the council's position on employment of journalists by the intelligence community, the council's chairman, Stanley H. Fudd, announced yesterday.

title: State Responsibilities
description: Although the weight of Federal pressure for tighter budgetary controls falls on City Hall, Albany must share responsibility for helping New York to overcome its fiscal troubles.

title: Becoming Juxtaposes Haphazard Melodies and Skits
description: The young people responsible for the songs and skits collectively labeled Becoming must have mothers in the audience.

title: Phils Top Giants Behind Kaat, 61
description: Jim Kaat didn't cost the Philadelphia Phillies a million dollars when they acquired him from the Minnesota Twins last winter, but he's Ditching like a million.

title: Toxic Fumes From Fire Force Evacuation on Coast
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., June 16More than 4,000 persons were forced from their homes last night after a swimming pool supply center caught fire and sent toxic chlorine fumes billowing over a large part of this San Fernando Valley community, a suburb of Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Is Said to Caution Jordan Against Buying Soviet Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) United States officials have cautioned King Hussein that Jordan stands to lose millions of dollars in American military and economic aid if it buys an antiaircraft missile system from the Soviet Union.

title: Restored Chamber Dedicated by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Sitting where Webster and Clay and Calhoun once debated the crucial issues of an earlier era, the Senate officially dedicated the newly restored Old Senate Chamber today.

title: Swordfish Rams Vessel
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)A 73foot fishing vessel was rammed by a swordfish and seriously damaged early today about 150 miles cast of Nantuckst, the Coast Guard reported. The vessel, the Carla Joyce, was towed to the port of Chatham for repairs. The size of the swordfish was not known.

title: CARTER CAMPAIGN $1 MILLION IN DEBT
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Jimmy Carter's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination has left his campaign organization with a deficit of more than $1 million, but no one is worrying much about it.

title: Jonathan Logan Planning To Expand in New York
description: Jonathan Logan Inc.; one oft the nation's biggest apparel manufacturers, signed a 20year lease yesterday for 150,000 square feet of spacethe rough equivalent of a city block ??? a major expansion in New York City of its Etienne Aigner handbag and shoe division.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: TAKING AIM

title: Insurance Group Asks Rate Raise For Malpractice
description: ALBANY, June 16 (UPI)The Medical Malpractice Insurance Association asked the State Insurance Department today to approve a 90 percent increase in the malpractice coverage rates paid by about 4,000 participating doctors.

title: Olympic Sail Trials Off
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND. N.Y., June 16Severe squalls forced the postponement of the Olympic yachting trials today. The fifth in the sevenrace series was rescheduled tomorrow.

title: Carter Opposes Use Of Troops in Lebanon
description: SEA ISLAND, Ga. (AP)Jimmy Carter said today that the United States should encourage a complete survey into the slaying of the United States Ambassador to Lebanon, Francis E. Meloy Jr., and an aide, but added that the United States should not become involved militarily in the Lebanese conflict because of the slavinas.

title: Wine, Women and Uneducated Palates
description: PARIS, June 16Under normal circumstances, the steward presents the bottle of wine to the male diner, who tastes the wine and approves it ceremoniously with a nod. But that exclusive male role faces a challenge as many American women in Paris are tasting wines seriously and analytically.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an Arrangement by OPTEL CORPORATION, 230 Fifth Ave., N.Y Liabilities 52,145,689; assets 57.975,191 Signed by Gerald Heller, president.

title: U.S. JUDGE BARS HONORCODE TEST
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday rejected a request by Cadet Timothy D. Ringgold and others for a special threejudge court to test the constitutionality of the West Point honor code.

title: Carrino Fined in Invasion Of Mayor Gibson's Office
description: NEWARK, June 16 City Councilman Anthony Carrino was fined $850 today, given a suspended sixmonth jail sentence and placed on six months probation for leading demonstrators into Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's office on March 23. Mr. Carrino's lawyer said he would appeal.

title: G.O.P. Is Planning to Weaken Key House Panel Led by Hays
description: WASHINGTON, June 16House Republican leaders said today that they would try to shame the Democrats into agreeing to rules changes that would prevent anyone from again amassing as much power as Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio.

title: Bank of England Linking Oil Nations to Pound Drop
description: LONDON, June 16The Bank of England identified the leading oilproducing countries today as the likely agents behind the yearlong decline of the British pound.

title: MORTON M. KLEIN
description: Morton M. Klein, executive secretary of the Carbonated Beverage Institute, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home, 36 East 36th Steet, He was 69 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: The Rev. Dr. James Sullivan, retired head of the Southern Baptist Sunday School Board, was elected president yesterday of the Southern Baptist Convention, whose 12.7 million members comprise the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

title: Levi Contends the Courts Have Heeded Busing Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he thought the Federal courts had tried to follow the 1974 law that calls on the courts to order busing in school desegregation cases only as a last resort.

title: Melnick Reelected
description: Sgt. Harold H. Melnick has been reelected president of the Sergeants Benevolent Association for a twoyear term, the union announced yesterday.

title: Companies Report on Sales and Earnings
Ziegler Pulls Out
description: Larry Ziegler, winner of the New Orleans open earlier this season, suffered a pulled muscle in his shoulder and withdrew from the Open. Ziegler's spot in the 150man field was taken by Mark Boyajian of Belleville, Ill., an amateur.

title: TRADING VIGOROUS IN CORN FUTURES
description: Corn futures attracted some vigorous trading yesterday, and at the close the July contract was down 1 cent to $2.95 a bushel But newcrop December corn was up 2 cents a bushel at $2.81.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The first gas turbine and electric commuter train, capable of operating on either electrified or nonelectrified lines of the Long Island Rail Road, will go into regular passenger service on the Oyster Bay and Port Jefferson branches starting today.

title: 4 Dead, Thousands Routed By 12Inch Rain in Houston
description: HOUSTON, June 16Unusually heavy rains, up to 12 inches in some areas, flooded vast sections of Houston yesterday, causing at least four deaths and sending thousands of residents fleeing their inundated homes and businesses.

title: A Critic's View of Tulle Harris's Rise
description: The tiniest tower of strength now on Broadway is Julie Harris, and therein lies a lesson for all who would add invisible cubits to their stature. Some people are born to be actors and actresses. They just look like that's what their mothers and fathers had in mind. Others have the talent, all right, but in effect it's their secret: They look like mud fences, tame mice, the Monday wash, oras I believe Miss Harris was once calledan unshelled peanut. In which case they must create themselves in order to let their secret out.

title: School Official Says Louisville Allowed Resegregation to Grow
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., June 16Almost as soon as Louisville's public schools were desegregated last September, the school administration began allowing a pattern of resegregation to develop through the transfers of white students from their assigned schools and through the suspension of black pupils for disciplinary reasons, a school official said today.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 16 The Senate version of a proposed state income tax may, be in some trouble in the Assembly even before it comes to a vote in the Senate tomorrow.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's an archetypal dream: You'll do your thing, put to work a particular talent you've been repressing all your life, and the world will beat a path to your door. You can see this impulse at its most pathetic in the sidestreets of Manhattan: a bookstore in the basement of a building in the middle of an untraveled block; an antiques shop with an attractively designed window display and nothing older or more interesting than a wooden rolling pin; a boutique featuring clothes that not even Manhattan girls are neurotic enough to buy.

description: Prices in the credit markets slipped for the second straight day yesterday as the market became a trifle nervous when the interest rate on Federal fundsthe rate that is re

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A Federal Appeals Court in Richmond, yesterday partly removed a stay that blocked connection of nonBell communications gear with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company lines.

title: Moynihan So Dazed He Forgot the Newsmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Daniel P. Moynihan, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York, failed to keep a luncheon appointment here today with about 25 newsmen to discuss his candidacy.

description: Residents of New York City's suburbs standing watch for Operation Sail 1976 will have a busy time of it on the first three days of July.

title: New York State Act Eases Way To Consumer Fraud Conviction
description: Governor Carey has signed into law a bill that will make it easier to obtain criminal convictions of businesses and indi viduals who defraud consumers and that will subject such offenders to greater penalties.

title: People and Business
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission criticized the Secretary of Commerce yesterday for his remarks questioning the authority of the commission to ferret out corporate bribery and other improper payments.

title: Planners Hear Landmark Hotel Plan
description: A controversial proposal by Harry B. Helmsley, the realty developer, to erect a $65 million luxury hotel behind the landmark Villard Houses on Madison Avenue received conditional backing from architectural, business and civic groups at a City Planning Commission hearing yesterday.

title: Washington Post Plans Modified 6Column Format
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) The Washington Post said today that it planned to switch from an eightcolumn page to a sixcolumn format on its inside news Danes on Aug. 2.

title: New York SST Trial Urged
description: PARIS, June 16 (UPI)Wilham T. Coleman Jr., United States Transportation Secretary, expressed guarded optimism today that the supersonic aircraft was here to stay, and again urged New York to permit trial flights of the BritishFrench Concorde.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Today's Entries at Belmont

title: Senate, in Compromise, Passes $3.95 Billion Public Works Bill
description: WASHINGTON. June 16 (AP) The Senate passed today a compromise $3.95 billion public works jobs bill to replace the one that President Ford vetoed last winter.

title: Bergman Asks U.S. Judge Not to Send Him to Prison
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursing home promoter, appealed to a Federal judge yesterday not to send him to prison for his confessed role in a $1.2 million Medicaid and tax fraud.

title: Congress Leaders Deplore The Murders in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Senator John J. Sparkman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, deplored as a despicable act the murder today of the United States Ambassador to Lebanon, his aide and driver, and asserted that the dying in Lebanon must stop.

title: U. S. Steel Again Fights E .P . A. Over Mill Pollution in Alabama
description: United States Steel Corporation, which is involved in a number of air pollution conrtroversies around the country, has reopened a dispute with the Environmental Protection Agency over mill emissions in Birmingham, Ala., the South's most polluted city.

title: Kuhn Holds Up Sale of A's Stars
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered a hearing yesterday on the mass sale of stars by the Oakland A's. He ordered the players not to change sides until he had investigated the new issues raised by the money revolution sweeping the sport.

description: Angels Box Score

title: A rtemus L. Gates, at 80, Served As Under Secretary of the Navy
description: Artemus L. Gates, a former Under Secretary of the Navy and former president of the old New York Trust Company, died Monday at his home on Peacock Point in Locust Valley, LI., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Big Board Margin Debt Up
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that customer margin debt increased for the ninth successive month in May, or by $250 million, to $6.94 billion. This compared with $6.69 billion for April and $4.70 billion in May last year.

title: A British Midlands City, Its Industry and Employment Down, Is Wary of Asian Newcomers
description: LEICESTER, England, June 12  The new roof over the big openair market here behaves in a way that could ??? of the whole British economy. It leaks.

title: Union Vote Lifts Pound
description: BRUSSELS, June 16 (UPI)The pound made strong gains in early trading today, buoyed by a landslide vote by Britain's trade unions in support of the Government's pay policy.

title: Kotz 296 Wins in Jersey
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J., June 16A short, 29yearold Pennsylvanian came across the Delaware River and went back home to Morrisville, Pa.. late today with the 75th New Jersey Golf Association amateur championship. He is Bob Kotz, an electrical engineer and the father of two girls, who played the steadiest golf during the difficult doubleround final day at the Braidburn Country Club to register a winning score of fouroverpar 296.

title: VERDERY A. ROOSEVELT
description: Verdery Akin Roosevelt, widow of Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, a New York City investment banker, died Tuesday in a Birmingham, Ala., nursing home. Her age was 87.

title: I.L.O BOGS DOWN ON BIG COMPANIES
description: GENEVA, June 16The International Labor Organization bogged down tonight In its efforts to arrive at a consensus on how to deal with multinational corporations. charging that the Soviet bloc and third world forces use it as a launching pad for antiAmerican activities.

title: Stenmark Honored
description: STOCKHOLM, June 16 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark, winner of last winter's Alpine World Cup, received a gold medal from King Carl Gustaf XVI today.

title: Teenager Outruns Jersey City Mayor
description: JERSEY CITY, June 16Mayor Paul T. Jordan led at the start today, was neckandneck at midpoint, then faded quickly and lost a 100yard dash to an eighthgrade student from the Frank R. Connell School.

title: Soviets Loft 8 Satellites
description: MOSCOW, June 16 (AP)The Soviet Union put eight unmanned satellites into orbit yes terday for continuing space research, the Tass news agency said.

title: Court Approves Special Lottery For $1.7 Million Left in 1975
description: In a reversal of an earlier decision, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday tht special state lottery drawings could be conducted to distribute more than $1.7 million in prize money that had not been awarded when the lottery was suspended last October.

title: Beame Deputy Hints At Aid for City U.
description: Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti said last night that the city might be able to find the $15 million the City University, needs to meet its June payroll, but would not do so until the university submitted a plan showing how it intended to close a $98 million budget gap for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

description: BRIDGETON, N. J., June 16 (AP)The National Oil Company of AlgeriaSonatrach has awarded a contract in excess of $10 million to the Spartan Engineering Company, a petroleum consulting concern here, according to Frank App Jr., the owner of Spartan and former mayor of nearby Fairfield Township. We're going to drill between 12 and 15 wells for them near HassiMasoud in Algeria, Mr. App said.

title: MAJOR SEGMENTS OF THE ECONOMY EXPANDED IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Industrial production, personal income and housing starts all rose in May as the expansion of the economy continued, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Ford Says Lebanon Policy Is Undeterred by Killings
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The United States said today, that its efforts to help promote a political solution in Lebanon would continue despite the kidnapping and murders of Ambassador Francis E. Meloy Jr., his economic aide and his chauffeurbodyguard in Beirut this morning.

title: Carey Names Labor Aide
description: ALBANY, June 16 (AP)Gov. ernor Carey announced today the appointment of G. Douglas Pugh to the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board. Mr. Pugh, 32 years old, of the Bronx, will serve on the $35,250ayear post through Nov. 18, 1981. He will succeed Herman B. Zipser of Manhattan.

title: Advertising
description: You've got to admit that Aunt Bluebell ranks right up there with George Whipple leader of the antisqueeze squad as far as being an irritating television commercial character.

title: James in the Abbey
description: The welldeserved attention given earlier this month to the display of the oldest original copy of the Magna Carta in the Capitol Rotunda should not obscure a comparatively small ceremony in the Poets Corner of Westminster Abbey today. A plaque will be unveiled honoring Henry James, the transplanted New Yorker whose writings symbolize the lasting AngloAmerican literary connection.

title: Connors Victor, Nastase Defeats Smith
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 16 (AP)Jimmy Connors moved confidently into the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Nottingham grass tennis tournament today as the only American survivor.

title: BehindtheScene View of Yanks Super Deal
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 16Gabe Paul, the Yankee president who engineered the molding of the new pitching staff with the invaluable assistance of George Steinbrenner's apparently freeflowing bank account, could not have known all he would accomplish when he walked out of his office at Yankee Stadium last Monday afternoon at 12:55 P.M.

description: Prices on the American Stocks Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished higher Yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Festival of American Folklife, something of a summertime tradition here for the last decade, opened its Bicentennial version today. It is the longest, most expensive, and its organizers hope, the best one yet.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Senate Defense Appropriations Subcommittee approved today a $104.7 billion budget for the Pentagon that is $3.3 billion less than that requested by the Ford Administration.

title: PIPE BLAST KILLS 2 IN LOS ANGELES
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) Workmen widening a busy Los Angeles street touched off an explosion in an underground gas pipeline today that enveloped stores and passing cars in a wall of flames. Two persons were killed and 26 injured.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS 12 FOR KEY POSITIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate today confirmed 12 nominations for high positions in the State Department, the Federal judiciary and various Government agencies.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) President Ford signed into law today a measure ordering Federal agencies to keep more and better statistics on Americhns of Spanish origin in order to help them achieve a better life.

description: United Airlines announced yesterday that in May it achieved its first profitable month since October, while, American Airlines said that it turned a yearago loss into a profit.

description: Crude oil imports into the United States rose to a record high last week according to statistics issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Alcoholism Treatment: Rand Finding on Resumption of Drinking Sets Off Dispute on New Therapies
description: A Rand Corporation study released last week suggesting, that some alcoholics can, after treatment, resume moderate social drinking without risking relapse has brought to the surface a longstanding dispute that some experts say has stifled the development of new approaches to treating alcoholism.

title: Dissidents Win Concession On Bicentennial Activities
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (UPI)A coalition of dissident organizations seeking permits for demonstrations on July 4 has won a split decision. They can hold most of their activities as planned but far away from the City's scheduled Bicentennial events.

title: Tejeira Ties Mark; Rides 8 Winners
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 16 (AP)Jorge Tejeira equaled a North American record today by riding eight winners in one day. Tejeira finished first on three of his six mounts at Keystone during the day and five of his six mounts tonight at Atlantic City. The record was set June 11, 1944 by Hubert Jones, who won eight of 13 races at Caliente in Tijuana, Mexico.

title: MAJOR SEGMENTS OF THE ECONOMY EXPANDED IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Industrial production, personal income and housing starts all rose in May as the expansion of the economy continued, Government reports disclosed today.

title: Congressman Cites Kindness to Explain ExProstitute's Pay
description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (UPI) Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, said yesterday that a woman living in California the last several months and who had a police record for prostitution was kept on the payroll of his local district office out of compassion.

description: The host and hostess teams assigned to each of the delegations to the Democratic National Convention met yesterday at Gracie Mansion with Robert P. Tisch, chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Democratic National Convention, and Thomas H. Baer, who is coordinating plans for the teams.

description: William Heller, a retired jersey fabric manufacturer, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach. He was 86 years old.

description: When Andrea Rago of Levittown, L.I., became pregnant in 1970 with her first child, her obstetrician handed her a prescription for what she assumed to be vitamins.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott trudeau of Canada flew to Washington this afternoon for an eighthour visit that included a talk with President Ford in the Oval Office and dinner With the president on the yacht Sequoia.

description: Three senseless deaths were added yesterday to the tens of thousands of innocent victims already fallen to marauding civil war in Lebanon: the United States Ambassador, his economic counselor and the embassy driver, executed in Beirut by elements unknown.

title: SERVICE FOR ZUKOR IS HELD IN HASTINGS
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., June 16Adolph Zukor, who died last Thursday in Los Angeles at the age of 103, was buried today after a brief graveside service at Temple Israel Cemetery.

title: U.S. Open Starts Today With Weiskopf Choice
description: DULUTH, Ga., June 16It was the day before the opening of the 76th United States Open, and for a change there were no hassles, backbiting or overstated criticism of the golf course. It was a relaxed day in the hot Georgia sun as 150 players tuned up on the Highlands Course of the Atlanta Athletic Club, looking for the best placement of tee shots and studying the breaks of the greens.

title: Doctor Reports That Getty Had Cancer of the Prostate
description: LONDON. June 16 (AP)J. Paul Getty's doctor says the American oil billionaire had cancer of the prostate when he died of a heart attack June 6.

title: 'Martyr,' a Film About the Nazis And Heroic Jew
description: "The Martyr," which opened yesterday at the Juliet 1 Theater, is a reverential, absolutely stolid, English-speaking Israeli-German co-production based on the heroism of Dr. Janusz Korczak (Leo Genn), the Polish Jewish doctor and novelist who elected to stay with the orphans he was caring for in the Warsaw ghetto in 1942 rather than go underground to escape the Nazis.The film, which was made in 1973, was directed by Aleksander Ford, the veteran Polish director who moved to Israel in 1968. As was Mr. Ford's film version of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's "The First Circle," released here three years ago, this movie is full of good intentions that get smothered by the sentimental, deliberate manners of a cinema style better suited to early sound films.The only moving portions of the film are provided by Mr. Ford's occasional use of black-and-white still photographs of life in the Warsaw ghetto. They haunt the mind in the way that makes the fictional pieties look almost complacent.

title: 4 U.S. DIPLOMATS SLAIN IN 8 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 16(Reuters)Seven senior United States diplomats have been kidnapped in the last eight years and four United States ambassadors or chiefs of missions have been killed, according to State Department figures.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, acting under a newly approved Security Council resolution, moved today to arrange an early resumption of talks between representatives of the Greek and Turkish communities of Cy prus.
