description: SUMMIT, N.J., June 16Well, I played my best golf today, said Mrs. Albert (Bea) Bower of Pelham, N.Y. as she gained the semifinal round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 73d match play championship.

Meloy Jr., was reportedly taken from his car and shot to death and dumped in a garbage pile. Also shot and dumped in the same garbage pile were Robert O. Waring, the embassy's economic counselor and their driver, Zoheir Moghrabi. title: BRUCE CARPENTER
description: Bruce Carpenter, a retired instructor at New York University, died last Friday at his home, 7 Washington Square in Greenwich Village. He was 82 years old.

title: Botswana's Open Border
description: OTTAWA, June 16 (UPI)Sir Seretse Khama, President of Botswana, said yesterday he would not take up the United States on its pledge to assist countries that close their borders to Rhodesia because such a move would mean economic suicide for his country.

title: Bridge:
description: If you were playing for the first time in a world championship and your intended partner dropped out at the last moment, leaving you to form a new partnership, you might feel that your chances were distinctly unpaired. And if you came from a country indeed a continentthat had never won a world title, and were scheduled to play the greatest players of all time, you might feel you were facing a hopeless task.

title: Federal Prod
description: Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's decision to send top aides to New York today to confer with the Emergency Financial Control Board on the disputed new municipal budget and financial plan underscores the city's continued dependence on Federal loan assistance that cannot be taken for granted.

title: THOMAS W. FLYNN
description: Thomas William Flynn, who retired in 1966 as vice chairman of the board of Acme Fast Freight, New Hyde Park, L. I., died Tuesday at his home, 330 Hollywood Avenue, Crestwood, N. Y. He was 75 years old.

title: 3 ARE FOUND GUILTY ON TIDAL SHIP LOANS
description: Tried in the absence of several major defendants, three men were found guilty in New York yesterday of conspiracy in connection with S60 million in loans for freighters or tankers, operated by GreekAmericans.

title: JohnsManville to Increase Prices of Plastic Pipes 5%
description: The JohnsManville Corporation announced yesterday price increases of 5 percent on its full line of polyvinyl chloride plastic pipe products, effective July 1. It follows an increase of about 7 percent effected June 1 on selected plastic pipe products. Recent resin price increases necessitated the higher price move by JohnsManville, the an nouncement explained.

title: Antitrust Advance
description: The antitrust bill passed by the Senate last week by a vote of 65 to 19 was sharply modified to make it less objectionable to business lobbyists; but it still would help to protect consumers in cases where damage is widely spread regionally and among individuals.

title: ndiana Abortion Rule Voided
description: INDIANAPOLIS. June 16 (AP) The Indiana requirement that abortions be performed only in a hospital or licensed facility has been struck down as unconstitutional by a threejudge Federal court. The ruling means that physicians may perform legal abortions in their offices.

title: 2 Nurses Are Accused in Deaths At Michigan Veterans Hospital
description: DETROIT, June 16  Two nurses were arrested today on first degree murder charges relating to last summer's mysterious series of deaths at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: A Bicentennial Rebellion Smolders in Jersey
description: I hope it rains for three solid days. I'm praying for it.

title: 5 Sponsors Quit Afternoon Horror Movies
description: Five national advertisers have withdrawn their commercials from the Saturday and Sunday afternoon horror movies on KCOPTV in Los An geles in response to a campaign by a citizen's group against the scheduling of violent programs during the hours most accessible to children. KCOPTV programs chiller movies at 3 P.M. on weekends, often with the announcement. parental discretion is advised.

title: U.S. to Sell Kenya 12 F5's In $70 Million Arms Deal
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 16The United States has agreed to sell 12 F5 jet fighter planes to Kenya in one of the biggest single American arms deals in Africa, according to senior United States officials. The agreement, which needs Congressional approval, was discussed today by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Kenya's Defense Minister, James S. Gichuru.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP; DOW 39(13 2.70) List Retreats Following the Death of U.S. EnvoyVolume at 21.62 Million
description: The stock market shook off Tuesday's spell of profit taking yesterday to post a modest gain in moderately active trading.

title: Progress Is Seen In N.B.A. Merger
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 16 Enough progress was made today in merger talks between the National and American Basketball Associations to summon Prentice Vancey here from Atlanta. Yancey is the general counsel of the A.B.A. Players Association and he is under mandate from his players to oppose any form of consolidation that would not include all six A.B.A. teams. He has threatened court action to prevent an unacceptable merger plan.

title: Paul C. Smith, 67
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., June 16 Paul C. Smith, who assumed the editorship of The San Francisco Chronicle in 1937 at the age of 26, then 15 years later vainly fought to save three CrowellCollier magazinesthe American, Collier': and Women's Home Companion died here today of a strok'. He was 67 years old.

title: Conferees Approve Curb on Exporting and Importing Plutonium Reprocessing Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A, growing number of Government and academic experts have concluded that the present policies of the United States. Germany and France encouraging the commercial use of plutonium and the development of the breeder reactor will undermine existing international controls and could lead to the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Extortion Note Preceded Letter Bombs
description: Several large companies that received letter bombs this week reported yesterday that they had earlier ignored extortion letters demanding that they (place payments in bank accounts in Matamoros. Mexico.

description: FLORHAM PARK, N. J., June 16 (AP)Motorists planning to use their Citizen's Band radios in Canada or Mexico must obtain permits or the radios may be confiscated, according to the president of the New Jersey Auto Club.

description: DETROIT, June 16  Two nurses were arrested today on first degree murder charges relating to last summer's mysterious series of deaths at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: The Rev. William Buell, 89; ExHead of Church School
description: MIDDLFTOWN, R. L, June 16 (AP)The Rev. William Ackerman Buell, former headmaster of St. George's School in Middletown, died today after, a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Bank for Savings Announces Merger
description: The New York Bank for Sayings announced yesterday that it would merge with the First. Federal Savings and Loan Association of Syracuse.

title: Miss Evert 60, 61 Victor
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 16In less than 40 minutes today Chris Evert trounced Greer Stevens of South Africa 60, 61 and en tered the quarterfinals of the $90,000 Colgate grass tennis tournament, the last women's tuneup for Wimbledon.

title: Territories Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill authorizing an additional $10 million in loans to the Virgin Islands to bolster its depleted unemployment compensation fund. The bill, previously passed by the House, was amended in the Senate to extend to the new United States territory of the Northern. Marianas Islands the provisions of Social Security programs applicable to other territories.

title: San Juan Week Proclaimed
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday officially proclaimed next week as San Juan week in honor of the Fiesta De San Juan, the traditional Puerto Rican feast day. The figsta will he held Sunday in the bandshell of the Central Park Mall.

description: Belmont Charts

title: Blythe Danner Signed for Shaw
description: Blythe Danner, who was highly praised two years ago for her performance as Nina in The Sea Gull at the Williamstown Theater Festival, will return to the Massachusets playhouse to do Shaw's Heartbreak House from July 1 to July 10.

title: New Tower to Bring Cable TV to 2 Bergen Towns
description: BERGENFIELD, June 16A ceremonial groundbreaking for the construction of a 200foot antenna tower at TwinBoro Park here today was a major step toward paytelevision service for this Bergen County community and neighboring New Milford.

title: Italian Reds Gain in Foes Stronghold
description: AVEZZANO, Italy, June 16 Newmown hay has brought the sweet smell of summer to the Abruzzi Mountains. Red poppies blaze across the fields like pools of fire. In the cool of evening, the people of Avezzano gather in the piazza and celebrate an ancient ritual: talking and walking, watching and being watched.

title: Former Narcotics Detectives Are Sentenced to Prison Terms
description: Two members of the now disbanded Special Investigation Unit of the New York City Police Department's antinarcotics team were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judgelohn M. Cannella to three months of oneyear terms and to pay $1,000 fines.

title: Envoy in Foreign Service for 30 Years, Economic Aide Had Lebanese Contacts
description: WASHINGTON. June 16Francis Edward Meloy Jr., the United States Ambassador to Lebanon who was killed in Beirut, was a career diplomat whose 30 years in the Foreign Service had taken him all over the world.

title: Going out Guide
description: STEPPING BACK Ballet fans at Lincoln Center might care to look at a colorful new display of 55 items called 100 Years of Dance Posters, on view through Aug. 28 in the secondfloor gallery of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts.

title: Huge Share Offer By A.T.&T.Sold Out
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday successfully sold 12 million shares of its common stock, Valued at $658 million, in the largest direct common stock offer in American history.

title: Reagan Leaders Raiding Delegates Pledged to Ford
description: WASHINGTON. June 16Ronald Reagan's campaign leaders said today that they had made successful raids in New York and several other states on Republican National Convention delegates nominally pledged to President Ford.

title: Increased Price of Meat Brings A Second Kidnapping in Rome
description: ROME. June 16 (UPI)Masked gunmen protesting the price of meat in Italy today kidnapped a Rome poultry merchant, hours after the pohce freed an abducted meat importer whose life was bargained for a cutrate beef price.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BOSTON (AL)Acquired Rollie Fingers, pitcher, and Joe. Rudi, outfielder, from Oakland for $I million apiece.

title: Democrats Abroad Continue Feuding Over Choice of Convention Delegates
description: LONDON, June 16Maybe they have been living abroad too long. Maybe they haven't received the message. Whatever the reason, the Democrats overseas are still engaged in family feuding even though the party at home is luxuriating in um accustomed harmony..

title: TEAMSTERS HEAD WINS REELECTION
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 16Frank E. Fitzsimmons was unanimously reelected today to a fiveyear term as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and all of the union's international officers were also reelected.

title: Uncommitted Is Defined Differently by Delegates
description: CHICAGO, June 15Uncommitted means different things to different delegates.

title: Fruehauf in Court Appeal
description: DETROIT, June 16 (UPI)The Fruehauf Corporation announced today plans to appeal a court ruling denying the corporation a new trial in a $50 million excise tax fraud case. Fruehauf, former chairman William E. Grace and former president Robert D. Rowan were found guilty July 17, 1975, of conspiring to defraud the Government of $12 million in excise taxes and assessed $38 million in penalties.

title: A Recorded Message Gives Data on Op Sail
description: A telephone number that gives recorded information about Op Sail 1976 went into operation yesterday. By calling 9991414 you will hear starting times for movements of the sailing and naval vessels on July 3 and 4.

title: Fed Barred a Rate Cut On 22 Occasions in 75
description: WASHINGTON, June 16On 22 occasions last year the Federal Reserve Board voted to disapprove requests by one or more of the 12 regional Reserve Banks to reduce the discount rate, it was disclosed today in the board's annual report.

title: Approval Seen for Listing of Legal Fees
description: The New York State Bar Association is expected to revise its rules on ethics this weekend to permit, for the first time, limited advertising by lawyers of their fees.

title: New Magazine Format On ABC News Closeup
description: It isn't clear from the publicity materials devoted to tonight's ABC News Closeup (Channel 7, 10 P.M.) whether the new magazine format is a oneshot, a trial balloon or major surgery. Closeup, under the auspices of Av Westin, was a deservedly Emmied hour of investigative reporting on a single topic, usually a malfeasance. Mr. Westin no longer associates with ABC. Closeup this evening is a series of snippets, a sort of 60 Minutes with John V. Lindsay standing in for Mike Wallace, Morley Safer and Dan Rather.

title: Film: 'Boy and His Dog':L.Q. Jones Fantasizes a Postholocaust World
description: "A Boy and His Dog," a fantasy about the world after a future holocaust, is, more or less, a beginner's movie. It has some good ideas and some terrible ones. The good ideas are marred by awkwardness; the terrible ideas are redeemed somewhat by being, at least, unpredictable.The world has become one great mudflat, a desert roamed over by armed men, sometimes alone, sometimes in bands. They build shelters out of scrap and old tires, eat stockpiled canned food and also use it for barter, and kill weak strangers. For recreation, they go to outdoor enclosures where pornographic movies are shown on an eight-millimeter projector.All this comes under the Good Idea heading. It is a spare, miserable world L. Q. Jones, director, has set up; mean, dry and barren, where everyone wears worn and dirty clothes because there is no way to make new ones and no water to wash with. The future is poverty.Vic, a young man, well-played by Don Johnson, is the protagonist. His companion is Mr. Jones's main Terrible Idea: Blood, a talking dog. There is nothing that can be done in a movie with a dog that talks. After only a few minutes, the old adage is modified to: He doesn't do it very well, and you're not surprised that he's doing it at all.Vic meets a woman, makes love to her, and lets her entice him down into the underground society from which she has emerged. Blood advises against it, and he's right.It is a weird, rural American community, bucolic to all appearances but run as the most savage dictatorship. The dictator is Jason Robards and he's splendida kindly, folksy farmer type who gradually becomes as frightening as Heinrich Himmler.Vic runs into all kinds of trouble before the film ends. The underworld part, brilliantly grotesque as it partly is, breaks the realistic vision of the beginning. The two parts don't really work together; their contrast, and a ridiculous ending, shatter the picture. And the talking dog chews up the pieces.This is the second film directed by L. Q. Jones, better known as an actor. It is not really a success, but I hope he goes on directing.

title: Miss Paul Wins At Darien Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 16At the age of 14, Maurica Paul, of Springfield, Mass., isn't worried about this year's Olympic Games.

title: Harlem Group Urges City To Run Torn School Area
description: A coalition of Harlem elected officials and parents groups has urged the New York City Board of Education to appoint, trustees to run the embattled Community School District No. 5 and to dismiss the eightmember elected school board.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Carey Signs a School Tax Measure That Legislators Say May Be Illegal
description: ALBANY, June 16Governor Carey signed into law today a bill allowing local school districts to tax beyond their legal tax ceilingsa measure that New York State legislators generally agreed as they passed it last week was of doubtful legality.

title: 3 Democrats Win Endorsement For Surrogate by Other Parties
description: The Liberal Party has endorsed Democrats for the Surrogates Courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and the Republicans have endorsed a different Democrat in Brooklyn and are running a member of their own party in Manhattan.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/Edward Hauser

title: In Soweto Township, Living Is a Mixture of Privilege and Passes
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 16  Soweto, the sprawling black township where several people died in rioting today, is the most populous urban concentration in southern Africa. Yet, a motorist driving there from Johannesburg, 10 miles away, finds no signpost to indicate the way.

title: U.S. SAYS CORN CROP IS IN GOOD CONDITION
description: WASHINGTON. June 16 (UPI)The nation's corn crop the key to prospects for continuing ample supplies and stable prices of meat, milk and, poultry  was in generally good condition through the, end of last week, the Agriculture Department says.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Workers in New York City's voluntary hospitals have voted overwhelmingly to strike after their contract runs out at the end of this month. Their union, District 1199 of the National Union of Hotpital and Health Care Workers, said its negotiating committee would meet Monday to set a date for the strike, expected to be after the Fourth of July weekend. The union and the hospitals have reached an impasse over wage increases that the hospitals say they cannot pay because the state has refused rises in Medicaid and Blue Cross payments, which are the main source of income, to cover any increased wages.

title: Bower Gains Final
description: SUMMIT, N.J., June 17Mrs. Charles Crawford of Apawamis and Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham advanced today to the final of the 73d Women's Metropolitan Golf Association matchplay championship.

title: Pay Cuts Restored
description: The Yankees took the first step today toward satisfying their new, unsigned players, restoring the 20 percent pay cuts that Ken Holtzman and Doyle Alexander had endured in Baltimore. The pitchers had been cut, under their renewed contracts from the salaries of $93,000 and approximately $35,000 they earned last season.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: When the central character in Time and Again, Jack Finney's novel about passage through time, is transported back to the New York of 1882, he goes first to Gramercy Park. As well as I could remember, it looked the same now, he observed. Around the park three sides of the square were just as I'd always seen them, old old houses of brownstone, brick, tray stone.

title: Jackson, Shriver Lose Bids for Campaign Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Federal Election Commission refused today to authorize payment of campaign subsidies to two inactive Democratic Presidential candidates who apparently failed to comply with various provisions of the campaign law.

title: TEAMSTER CHIEFS UNDER SUBPOENA
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 17Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, disclosed today that he and other top union officials had been subpoenaed to appear in Washingtdn.

title: Stockholm Peace Institute Sees Greater Risk of Nuclear War
description: STOCKHOLM, June 17 (UN) The risk of a nuclear war has been increased by official campaigns aimed at lessening fears of such a holocaust, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute said today.

title: JAMES SINGER DEAD; MATH PROFESSOR, 70
description: James Singer, professor emeritus of mathematics at Brooklyn College, died yesterday at his home, 3054 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

title: Management
description: As the midyear approaches, jobs and the price tags they carry become a favorite economic indicator. This applies both to the new graduates seeking a place on the business ladder and to seasoned executives wanting a change of assignment or simply to be rescued from the beach on which the recession cast them.

description: U.S. Open Scores

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday that a review of its international operations conducted by a special committee of its outside directors has disclosed that improper payments amounting to about $1.3 million in connection with foreign government business were made by its subsidiaries in four foreign countries.

title: Trenton Editor Is Named To Washington Post Job
description: TRENTON, June 17 (UPI)Richard Harwood, editor of the Trenton Times Newspapers, was named today as deputy managing editor of The Washington Post.

title: Pinning the Tail
description: Political Establishments have taken on such unsavory connotations that candidates for statewide office in New York now try their best to avoid being tagged as the choice of their respective parties state committees. Democrats in particular recall that two years ago four out of their five nominees for statewide officeHugh L. Carey, Mary Anne Krupsak, Robert J. Abrams and Ramsey Clarkwere all chosen by voters in the primary over those designated by the party leaders. A consequence is this week's ludicrous performance in which Democratic Senatorial candidates fought to round up committee votes for their opponents in the hope of weighing each other down with the burden of being the bosses choice.

title: Leon Dinkin Is Dead at 83; Known as Refugee Doctor
description: Dr, Leon Dinkin, a New York physician who had a following among European refugees of the Nazi era, died in the city yesterday at the age of 83.

title: Inquiry Warns of an Influx of Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) A newly declassified Central Intelligence Agency study says there is a good chance that in the next few years foreignlinked terrorists will be increasingly tempted to stage major actions in this country.

title: Tim Hardin Sings
description: Tim Hardin, the singer and songwriter who recently returned from selfimposed exile in London, and is performing at the Other End through this weekend, was one of the most talented writers to emerge from the Greenwich Village folkmusic gestalt of the 60's. Indeed, his jazzinfluenced songs, with their worldly lyrics and often striking imagery, sound quite contemporary when compared to the rest of today's popular music.

title: Stage: A Lyrical Winter's Tale
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 17Thrift, perforce, seems to be the overriding factor of this season of Michael Kahn's American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn. Money has been very short. The season offers two major new productions, Arthur Miller's The Crucible, already reviewed, and As You Lace It. with Eileen Atkins. There is also a revival of last season's production of The Winter's Tale, which was officially unveiled last night and which I saw at a preview.

title: Greece Bears Gift Of Olympic Stone
description: ATHENS, June 17 (UPI)The Greek Olympic Commit tee will send next month a piece of limestone from ancient Olympia, site of the first Olympic Games, to each of the 13 countries that have organized the Summer Games since their restoration in 1896.

description: It may he too soon to ring down the curtain on the Age of the Ballerina, but this weekend is a fine opportunity to catch up with an important trend in balletthe strong upswing in male dancing.

title: Henry James, at Last, Admitted to Hie Abbey
description: LONDON, June 17The British celebrated the memory, today of one of their favorite American expatriates, the novelist Henry James.

description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 17The commercial banking industry in New York State has undertaken an intensive lobbying effort to get Congress to abolish the interest rate differential that enables savings institutions to pay more than commercial banks for deposits.

description: Maria Milagros Montero used to play hooky inside her high school. She checked in each morning at Seward Park, where she was enrolled four years ago, and then spent the day wandering the halls, avoiding her classes.

title: Bergan Given 4 Months
description: Bernard Bergman, the central figure in the New York nursinghome scandal who had been convicted of Medicaid and tax fraud, was sentenced yesterday to four months in a Federal correction center. The special state prosecutor immediately charged that the promoter had reneged on a plea bargain, and threatened to reopen the prosecution of the Bergman family in state courts.

title: La Scala, Act II
description: After a libretto of troubles that matched those in almost any Italian opera, La Scala of Milan will finally come to Kennedy Center in Washington this September. Following 14 performances there, Europe's mostrenowned opera company will perform Verdi's Requiem in Philadelphia and New Yorkthe first time in its 198yearold history that the Teatro alla Scala will fill the air with music in the United States.

title: Dog Kills 2WeekOld L.I. Baby While the Mother Sleeps Nearby
description: A 90pound German shepherd dog mauled and hit to death a 14dayold infant in Brentwood, L. I., yesterday morning while the infant's mother, exhausted from caring for the baby during the night, ??? nearby.

title: DOLLAR UP SHARPLY IN TRADING ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, June 17 (UPI)The dollar rose sharply against the Swiss franc today and it also strengthened on other markets, reversing its downward trend of the last three days. Sterling held steady in modest trading.

title: Rauh Asks Liberals To Wait and See On Backing Carter
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Joseph L. Rauh Jr. said today that he was advising fellow Democratic liberals to take a wait and see attitude toward supporting Jimmy Carter for President, but he conceded that he would almost certainly vote for the former Governor of Georgia.

title: Israel Taking Part In Operation Sail
description: TEL AVIV, June 17The Israeli Government changed its mind today and said it would be represented by two missile boats in Operation Sail and the International Naval Review in the waters around Manhattan on July 4.

title: Ballet: The Pennsylvanians
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet's second program of its current season at the City Center started off Wednesday with three ballets by choreographers who had been associated with the Netherlands Dance Theater.

description: ALBANY, June 17  The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the Legislature could vote a limited number of extra allowancespopularly known as lulusto supplement lawmakers salaries this year.

description: In an article on winetasting courses for women in The New York Times yesterday, the caption incorrectly idenitied the teacher conducting a lesson. The teacher shown was Patricia Gallagher.

description: BRUSSELSThis was a city of promises a decade ago, the cradle of the Common Market and the burgeoning capital of Europe. Brussels was a city of fear as well.

description: JOHANNESBURG, June 17The rioting and bloodshed now troubling South Africa began with what was a relatively nor cause, in the context of apartheid.

title: Madrid Investigating Torture Reports but Orders Press to Be Silent
description: MADRID, June 16The widest publicity given by the Spanish press in the last 40 years to the problem of torture in Spain has prompted the Government to open an investigation and to declare its opposition to such practices.

description: TELEVISION TODAY

title: The Newest * * * * Restaurant; Restaurants
description: THEY serve food at the Grand Cafe, a new restaurant at 28 East 63d Street, but they could serve sawdust and we would still recommend a Visit, just for the decor. There are a number of handsome restaurant interiors in New York, but this is the only one that can be mentioned in the same breath withor maybe the next bieath afterMaxwell's Plum for wit, and imagination in the application of a recently revived style. The Grand Cafe is pure 1970's Art Deco revival, which means the most highfashioned style of the 1920's and 30's brought back to life with a nostalgic affection for its preciosities and a historical distillation of its virtuespreciosity included.

title: Butterfly Is Free at Stadium
description: Anna Moffo in a baseball cap is apparently doing more for the Metropolitan Opera's image than a decade of park concerts could do. The opera company's free concert performance of Puccini's Madama Butterfly with Miss Moffo in the title role at Yankee Stadium tomorrow night at 8:30 is not only a symbol of an institution with an aloof image reaching out to all the people. It's also become a genuine event.

title: TAXREFORM BID LOSES IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Tax reform advocates lost their first test of strength in the Senate tonight by the significant margin of 46 to 33.

title: Art: Westport Artists of Past A Frame of Historic Reference
description: CONSULT any history of American art in this century, and you are unlikely to find the town of Westport, Conn., conspicuous among the places where artists have gathered either to reshap the course of their medium or simply to enjoy one another's company. A Provincetown, a Woodstock or an East Hampton, Westport certainly is not.

title: PELLI NAMED DEAN OF SCHOOL AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, June 16Yale University has announced the appointment of Cesar Pelli, one of the nation's leading designers, as dean of its school of architecture.

title: HUMPHREY SEEKS MANSFIELD'S POST
description: WASHINGTON. June 17The fight for the post of Senate majority leader intensified today as Senator Hubert H. Humphrey became an active candidate.

title: Market Place
description: The holders of 6 percent New York City notes now subject to a threeyear moratorium are once again faced with a difficult decision. Should they accept an exchange for unrated 8 percent 15year Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds before the option to do so runs out on Monday or sit tight?

title: U.S. Disputes British Aide Over Warning on Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (Reuters)The State Department said today that the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony) Crosland, had no basis for his warning yesterday that the United States might intervene, in Rhodesia.

description: GENEVA, June 17A fragile. consensus on a generationlong. world program to combat unemployment and poverty emerged today at the close of a twoweek World Employment Conference.

description: TRENTON, June 17If the Legislature waits long enough, the state may eventually be able to balance the publicschool budget from windfalls.

title: Ratio of Inventories t Sales
description: A high ratio of inventories to sales usually means that businesses will reduce their orders for new goods, and production and employment will consequently decline.

title: Equal Justice?
description: In imposing sentence, United States District Judge Marvin Frankel said, I've undertaken to impose sentence on what you did and admitted, and not what was reported and rumored. It therefore is hardly useful, in discussing the sentence, to rehearse the history Mr. Bergman's involvement in the nursinghome business. It is worth noting, however, that after his arrest, Mr. Bergman entered into negotiations with the prosecutor which resulted in his plea of guilty to a charge of conspiring to commit fraud against the United States, a felony carrying a top sentence of five years, and filing a false incometax return, another felony, carrying a top sentence of three years.

title: Pleas of Not Guilty Are Entered For 2 Nurses in Hospital Deaths
description: DETROIT, June 17  Two Filipino nurses who worked together in an intensive care ward of the Veterans' Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor were arraigned today on charges of murdering five patients and poisoning 10 others at the hospital last year.

title: ADELAIDE MOFFETT
description: Adelaide Moffett, a popular nightclub singer in the 1930's and an active horsewoman, died Wednesday in her home in San Francisco after a long illness. She was 59 years old.

title: U.S. Boxing Team Bows
description: LONDON, June 17 (UPI)Britain's Olympic boxing hopefuls defeated an American amateur team, 65, at Wembley last night. American highlights were three firstround knockouts. James Rayford, a United States Army champion, knocked out the Scottish light middleweight Willie Lauder with a hard right to the jaw. Jerry Bennett, a middleweight, stopped Eddie Burke and Jimmy Clarke, a heavyweight, halted Rovston Hunte.

title: High Court Strengthens Right to Silence at Arrest
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Supreme Court held today that a defendant's silence after being advised of his right to remain silent under questioning could not be used against him in a trial.

title: Excerpts From the Ruling
description: We have before us once again the problem presented by what are commonly called the Sunday blue laws. And while the notion of a quiet Sunday is unquestionably valid in principle, we believe that two of the sections challenged here are constitutionally defective.

title: A New Course in Motoring: How to Avert Assassination
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I.Even as the world was learning about the assassination of the United States Ambassador to Lebanon on Wednesday, five men sat in a darkened room on a lonely hillside here pondering similar episodes: How Rafael Trujillo made the fatal mistake of stopping his car, how Charles deGaulle survived by racing through a roadblock.

title: For Children
description: BIBLICAL GARDEN, on the Close of tne Cathearal Church of St. John the Divine, oxen 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily, is filled with trees, plants and flowers that were grown in biblical clays. On the tranquil grounds one may sre tamarix that produces manna, myrrn and frankincense, and species of nlant life that existed in the Holy Land 2000 years ago. The cathedral, which also has a gift shoo, is on view 11 A.M. And 1 P.M. Monday ??? Saturday; 12:30 Sunday guided tours. 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Free. 67868R9.

title: E.R.A. Set Back in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 17 (UPI)About 300 women, both supporters and opponents, came to the Louisiana Capitol yesterday to hear the House Civil Law and Procedure. Committee debate the equal rights amendment. The panel voted, 10 to 6, against the measure. It was the fourth time in five years Louisiana hos voted against ratifying the E.R.A., which needs four more states to pass it.

title: F5 Deal Troubles Clark
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  A key Senator said today that he had strong doubts about the an nounced plan to sell 12 F5 fighter planes to Kenya as part of the Administration's new emphasis on improving ties with Africa.

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach To Buy Rapp & Collins
description: It was just talk up to now, but yesterday an agreement was signed by Doyle Dane Bernbach to acquire Rapp & Collins, a direct marketing ad agency with about $10 million in billines.

title: Unions and Some Retailers Oppose Sunday Openings
description: There will be no rush to open most department and retail stores on Sundays despite the (Court of Appeals decision yesterday striking down the state's I bluelaw bans, according to spokesmen for merchant organizations.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rioting continued for a third day in Soweto, a black township near Johannesburg, with the rioters, mostly young people, directing their fury at government buildings and vehicles. The death toll increased as more than 1,000 policemen armed with rifles and sten guns moved into the streets. The official toll yesterday was 54 dead and 300 injured. [Page AI. Column 8.]

title: Execution for Robbery
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 17 (AP) A 24yearold man ??? of wounding a shopkeeper during a robbery was executed today, officials reported. Huang Chilimine and tare other stabbed the owner of a ??? shop in August 1974. then robbed him of $183, the police said.

title: TRIP DATA IS SOUGHT ON 9 CONGRESSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Justice Department confirmed today that it has asked the House Administration Committee for financial records of nine House members who allegedly received Federal travel funds to which they were not entitled.

title: House Defeats Attempt to Delay Decision on Building B1 Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The House passed a $105 billion defense appropriations bill tonight after refusing, by a 20vote margin, to delay a decision on production of the B1 bomber until next February, under a new Administration.

title: In memoriam
description: GRIBINJane. Your birthday. Remembered with love. All your loved ones.

title: Reid, Amateur, Leads in Open
description: DULUTH, Ga., June 17One hundred fifty of the best golfers in the country, starting the 76th United States Open today, did battle with the Highlands Course of the Atlanta Athletic Club, and the 7,015yard course complacently beat them all but one.

title: Carter Opposes F.B.I. Check of Possible Running Mate
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., June 17Jimmy Carter has all but ruled out using the Federal Bureau of Investigation to make background checks of those he is considering as a VicePresidential nominee for the Democratic Party.

title: Reagan Men Predict Sweep in Colorado
description: VAIL. Colo., June 17President Ford's annual Christmas visits to this charming village in the Colorado Rockies have done much to promote the state's skiing industry but seem to have earned him few political credits.

title: GROWTH SLOWING IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: Growth in the nation's money supply has dramatically slowed in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Privacy and the I.R.S.
description: Two years ago, when Congress established the Privacy Protection Study Commission, it specifically asked that group to determine whether the Internal Revenue Service should be allowed to make individual tax returns or individually identifiable data from those returns available to other Government agencies. In its first report, the commission, headed by David Linciwes, has called correctly we believefor significant new limitations on such access to individual tax returns. Thus, the Linowes commission has asked for the restoration of the kind of privacy that most ordinary taxpayers always thought their dealings with the I.R.S. enjoyed.

title: 161 Boats To Sail to Bermuda
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 17 There were 161 yachts and crews poised here today for the start of the 30th ocean race to Bermuda and one of the skippers is Dr. Arthur B. Lee Jr., a heart specialist from Buffalo. He has a beautiful yacht, a Swan 65 by class designation meaning a 65foot ketch built in Finland four years ago by Nautor to Sparkman & Stephens designs. It is called Vinceremos.

title: LILLIE L. VOGEL, 100; OF LEWISOHN FAMILY
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Lillie Lewisohn Vogel, widow of a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in World War II, died yesterday at Normanstone, her residence in the Rock Crek section of Washington.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Doug Stein of Glen Oaks putting for a birdie on the first hole at Oceanside, L.I., yesterday. He shot a 76.

title: Dow Average Soars
description: The Dow Jones industrial average soared 14.57 points yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to penetrate the 1,000point level for the sixth time this year. Trading was the heaviest in almost three months. Page D1.

title: A DEALER GUILTY IN SALE OF HEROIN
description: Rufus Boyd Jr., described as one of the largest drug dealers in New York City, has been convicted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on charges of selling a little more than half a pound of heroin to an undercover police officer.

title: Floyd B. Odium, Financier, 84, Dies
description: Floyd Bostwick Odium, a financier who became a selfmade millionaire in the Depression, died yesterday at his desert home in Indio, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Events and Openings
description: Saturday

title: Yankees Defeat Chicago
description: CHICAGO, June 17Billy Martin, the Yankees fiery manager, lashed out at Bowie Kuhn tonight, charging that the commissioner was interfering with the Yankees chances of winning the pennant.

title: S. E. C. TO APPEAL DU PONT DECISION
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would file a petitior asking the Supreme Court to review a lower court's decisior blocking a proposed merger of tne unnstiana securities Company into E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. The S. E. C. had approved the plan in December 1974. A commission spokesman in Wilmington, Del., said that the petition would be filed next Friday, the deadline for such a move.

title: Bankers Optimistic on Monetary System
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17American and foreign bankers gathered here for the International Monetary Conference of the American Bankers Association expressed cautious optimism today that, despite recent upheavals, the development of a more stable monetary system was proceeding favorably.

title: Phillies Top. Giants, Lead by 7 Games
description: The biggest lead in majorleague baseball grew a little bit larger last night. The Philadelphia Phillies, atop the National League's Eastern Division, continued to pile victory on top of victory, downing the San Francisco Giants. 32. at Philadelphia.

title: How They Voted
description: TRENTON, June 17 (UPI) Here is a rollcall of how the Senate voted today on the 1 percent income tax:

title: U.S. RIGHTS PANEL WINDS UP HEARING
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 16Serious deficiencies in this city's school desegregation were turned up by the United States Commission on Civil Rights in three days of public hearings that ended today.

title: Nigeria. Discarding British Model, Seeks to Adopt U.S. Form of Qovernment,
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 17Nigeria has discarded the British Parliament as a model for its civilian government three years from now and is looking instead to the presidential system of the United States.

title: 800 Pulling Strings To Attend Festival
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.To judge from the festival atmospnere, puppeteers enjoy their own company almost as much as they love a crowd; a gathering of them is like the reunion of a huge, happy, uninhibited family.

title: Floyd Odlum Dies
description: Floyd B. Odium, the selfmade millionaire who founded the Atlas Corporation, made a fortune in the Depression and left an imprint on virtually every facet of American capitalism, died yesterday at the age of 84. Page D16.

title: Baseball's First Game Recreated
description: The 130th anniversary of the first officially recorded game of baseballbetween the New York Knickerbockers and the New York Ninewill be commemorated tomorrow when the game is recreated as part of Hoboken's Bicentennial celebration.

title: Clam Broth House, Dating to 1899, Making Its Debut on Television
description: HOBOKEN, June 17From the Marlin Room of the world famous Clam Broth House in beautiful downtown Hoboken, we bring you the Rena Romano Show.

title: Blue Laws ate Bach To the Old Testament
description: The history of what came to be known as blue laws dates back to the Bible and, at various times in this state, the edict against work on Sundays was called an Act against profanation of the Lord's Day, called Sunday, or an act for suppressing immorality.

title: Assad, in Paris, Vows to Continue Lebanon Action
description: PARIS, June 17 (Reuters)President Hafez alAssad of Syria arrived here today for talks with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing and vowed to continue his country's present military action in Lebanon.

title: Federal Police Chief in Buenos Aires Dies In Blast at His Home
description: BUENOS AIRES, Friday. June 18(UPI)The chief of the federal police, Gen. Cesareo Cardozo, was killed early today by a powerful bomb that exploded at his suburban home the police said.

title: To Buy and Sell Men Like Hogs
description: Selling a human being for $1.5 million is not really more obscene than trading a man for a turkey, as Joe Engel did when he was the Charley Finley of the Southern Association. It just seems that way bcause it is more vulgar. Commenting yesterday on the unappetizing activity in baseball's flesh market, Dave Anderson wondered why the Yankees were willing to give Finley $1.5 million for Vida Blue when they had been unwilling to give Andy Messersmith, a pitcher whose talents are comparable with Blue's, more than $200,000 as a bonus. The answer is that owners like George M. Steinbrenner 3d are men of lofty, principle. By the rules of their religion, it is immoral to debauch players with large sums of money but permissible and sometimes adinirable to enrich another owner.

title: Jacob Krisel, a Specialist In Corporate Tax Law Die
description: Jacob Krisel, a specialist in corporate tax and finance law, died yesterday of a heart attack at New York Hospital.

title: Summary of Actions by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June VGThe Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: People and Business
description: William M. Batten, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the exchange was planning a campaign to counter the recent sharp decline in share ownership. He said the program would enlist the aid of companies listed on the exchange and would be one of our ??? ???

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Television prolongs the life of movies, and Fridays is where they gather now. Four begin simultaneously at 9 P.M., the peak of the evening. CBS is offering a 1973 arty Western never before shown on television. The Culpepper Cattle Company. and ABC is showing Olympic Visions, a movie on the 1972 Olympic games. The oldies are on public television: the silent What Price Glory? on Channel 13 and Alec Guinness's Run for Your Money on Channel 21.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: U.S., E.E.C. Ask Japan To Reduce Export Drive
description: American and European authorities, expressing concern over the massive increase In Japanese exports to the United States and the European Economic Community, have urged the Japanese Government to take steps to reduce an export drive expected to produce a record Japanese trade surplus this year.

title: How to Get There
description: By automobile: The Garden State Parkway south to Exit 38: turn onto Atlantic City Expressway to the city. Allday parking is available at base of the pier Virginia Avenue for $l or $2, depending on which lot is chosen.

title: High Society Hails Taxis At Museum
description: Taxi! All those folks who usually purr along in limousines with interesting license plates switched to cabs the other night at the Museum of Modern Art. They didn't have any trouble catching them, but then the taxis weren't going anywhere. The museum's annual spring benefit party centered on two American and three Europeandesigned cabs that form the newest exhibit, called Taxi. The cars certainly proved that a taxi needn't fit a rider like an iron lung.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants. at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street. Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: RICHARD B. BLASS
description: Richard B. Blass, a mechani cal engineer, died Wednesday in Monmouth (N.J.) Medical Center of a brain tumor. He was 74 years old and lived in Deal, N.J.

title: Companies Nationalized
description: LUANDA, June 17 (Reuters) Angola today announced the nationalization of 36 agricultural companies, including a coffee corporation described as occupying almost an entire province.

title: How to Get There
description: Gramercy Park is just enough off the beaten track to have allowed it to preserve its serenity, but close enough to make it reasonably accessible from anywhere in Manhattan. The BMT 23d Street station is the Flatiron Building and is a fiveminute walk from the park itself; the Lexington Avenue IRT stop at 23d Street and Park Avenue South is even closer. Third Avenue and Broadway buses, among others, stop almost at the park.

title: Brief Challenge Stuns G.O.P. Meeting
description: Seated around tables covered with yellow cloth, like suburbanites waiting for the garden club meeting to start, New York State Republicans reacted with frosty politeness yesterday to the only disruption on the official schedule a speech by Peter A. Peyser charging that the party's leaders were kowtowing to Conservatives.

title: A Playground for Handicapped and Able
description: Nathan McNeil, who is 11 years old and who travels mostly by wheelchair, swung himself hand over hand along a metal arch eight feet above the ground at the Heckscher playground in Central Park yesterday.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It is Saturday afternoon. Father and children are at a puppet show or, at this time of the year, they're at the ball game. Dinnertime? You can find them at the Cattleman or Burger King.

title: Wherein Future Shock Is Disputed
description: Future shock is a myth. Future shock is the false journalistic premise that the pace of change has accelerated, discomforting everyone.

title: The Pop Life
description: GOTHAM is an ebullient vocal trio that is ending twoweek run this weekend at the Grand Finale, 210 West 70th Street. The act is an amusing one, full of crackling, stylish, goodhumored oneliners and tight, sophisticated but heartfelt arrangements 1930's pop (the Boswell Sisters are the biggest influence) and contemporary material by such writers as Louis St. Louis.

title: 1976 Business Recruiting on Campus
description: Number of Graduates at Master's Level to Be Recruited at Various Monthly Salary Levels

title: AIDE TO N.A.A.C.P. SCORES PRIMARIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Clarence M. Mitchell Jr. of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has criticized the Presidential primary system, saying that it bypassed the interests of minorities and women.

title: Koreans in Saudi Contract
description: SEOUL, South Korea. June 17 A South Korean company announced today that it had signed a construction contract for almost a billion dollars with the Saudi Arabian Government. Initialed by the Korean Ambassador and Saudi officials in Riyadh yesterday, the contract calls for building an industrial harbor at Jubail, in northeastern Saudi Arabia.

title: Business Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 17 (AP)The National Iranian Oil Company confirmed today the discovery of one of the world's largest offshore natural gas fields in the Persian Gulf near Bushehr, about 500 miles south of the capital. The field, with an estimated reserve of 200 trillion cubic feet, is being developed by a consortium of Iranian, Japanese, American and Norwegian companies. It was discovered by a joint IranianShell venture several years ago, but Shell, apparently uncertain of the commercial value, pulled out and the company was taken over by the consortium.

title: Kissinger Says He'll Stress Apartheid in Vorster Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States regretted the outbreak of violence in South Africa and that he would express continued opposition to apartheid when he met next week with Prime Minister John B. Vorster.

title: Chris Evert Is Victor In Britain
description: EASTBOURNE. England. June 17 (UPI)Chris Evert defeated Betty Stove of the Netherlands, 75, 64, today to reach the semifinals of the $100.000 Colgate tennis tournament. Three other Americans failed to get past the quarterfinal rounds.

title: Loose Truck Kills Woman
description: ALLENSVILLE, Pa., June 17 (UPI)A disabled truck broke loose from a tow truck yesterday and drifted across the highway into an oncoming pickup truck, killing the driver and seriously injuring her four sons. Josephine Haup, 42 years old, was pronounced dead at the scene of the accident. Mrs. Haup's sons all were reported in serious condition at Lewistown Hospital. They were identified as Joseph, 14; Brian, 6; Mark, 4, and James. 2.

title: Art Deco Is Prelude To Grand Cafe Finale
description: *** 28 East 63d Street. EL 5.2121.

title: College Series Delayed
description: OMAHA, June 17 (UPI)Rain forced postponement of today's elimination game between Arizona and Arizona State in the college world series. The game was rescheduled for tomorrow. The winner will face Eastern Michigan in the championship game Saturday.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Federal Reserve Statement

title: Mr. Carter's Origins
description: In a conversation with reporters aboard his campaign plane the other night, Jimmy Carter talked about his political origins in a way that may tell us something about where the nation may be heading if he is elected President.

title: Italian Voters Mood: Time for a Change to Efficiency
description: ROME, June 17The Italians feel that the country is in the modern age but their bureaucracy and their government are in the feudal age. It is less a matter of ideology than a matte': of knowhow and talent.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: 52d Street Becomes A Sunday Bazaar
description: CARAVANS of crafts and antiques dealers and dozens of performers will gather on 52d Street Sunday to stage what has been described as the nation's greatest urban street fair.

title: Ford Orders Evacuation Of Americans in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, June 18President Ford has directed the United States Embassy in Beirut to evacuate Americans from Lebanon, a State Department official said early today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: 3 in Beirut Are Said to Confess to the Slaying of U.S. Ambassador
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17Palestinian security agents said today that three Lebanese men had confessed to involvement in the slaying yesterday of the American Ambassador, Francis E. Meloy Jr. the embassy's economic counselor and their chauffeur.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES OFF 20C A BUSHEL
description: Soybeans prices jumped 8 cefits a bushel yesterday at the opening of trading as speculators rushed in to buy on a rumored soybean sale to China, but by the end of the trading session prices were off almost 20 cents a bushel for the nearby contracts.

title: The New Steel Pier Opens
description: Hurry, hurry, hurry! Step right up! Star ting tomorrow, the place that once gave you the world's longest gingerbread pier jutting a halfmile into the Atlantic Ocean, the one and only Victoria music hall built entirely over water and the world's first and most accomplished diving horse, is about to do it all over again.

title: Saks for Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, June 17Saks. Fifth Avenue has leased a fourstory building in downtown Pittsburgh formerly occupied by the W.T. Grant Company and plans to open a store in early 1977, it was announced today.

title: Lord Casey Is Dead at 85
description: Lord Casey, a former Governor General of Australia, died yesterday in a hospital in Mel??? He was 85 years old.

title: Legislation Urged to Lure Film Industry to the State
description: NEWARK, June 17Sidney Kingsley, the Pulitzer  Prize winning playwright who heads the New Jersey Motion Picture and Theater Commission, appealed to state business and communications leaders today to support legislation designed to help revive the state as a filmproducing center.

title: Jazz and Latin Blend at Beacon
description: Three important figures in Jazz and Latin musicEddie Palmieri, the pianist, Cal Tjader, the vibraphonist and Airto Moreira, the percussionistwill join for an unusual concert at 7:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Beacon Theater, 74th Street and Broadway.

title: Mao's Seclusion and His Health
description: HONG KONG, June 17 China's dramatic announcement that Chairman Mao Tsetung would no longer meet foreign visitors raises a serious question over how well he is functioning in the delicate, demanding task of leading China's 800 million people. And if he is not in control, at a time the country is in the midst of a divisive political campaign and a succession crisis, who is?

title: The Labor Scene
description: GENEVADaniel Patrick Moynihan was too busy trying to become a United States Senator from New York to attend the International Labor Organization's World Employment Conference, which has just conchided here. But his spirit, as expressed in many bruising clashes with Soviet and third world officials during his combative period as United States Ambassador to the United Nations, animated many members of the American delegation to the job conference, especially on the union side.

title: 70 Wins Amateur Medal
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I., June 17Dick Hanington had trouble driving onto fairways today at the tight Middle Bay Country Club seaside links. But he knew how to scramble and get up and down well enough to shoot two under par and win the medal in the 53d annual Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship.

title: A Judge Is Persuaded by Hyland to Reverse Himself
description: TRENTON, June 17 (UPI)A Federal judge reversed himself today and decided not to accelerate hearings on New Jersey's school closing case after he received a telephone call from state Attorney General William F. Hyland.

title: Cochell Named Coach
description: TULSA, June 17 (AP)Larry Cochell, a former Creighton baseball coach and the coach at California StateLos Angeles for the last five years, was named baseball coach today at Oral Roberts University. Cochell replaces Herb Dallis who resigned two weeks ago to become a fulltime physical education instructor.

title: Abroad
description: Abroad

title: No Purple Planks
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Eight years ago in Chicago, there were an uproar in the International Amphitheater and rioting in the streets when the Democratic National Convention considered the Vietnam plank of the party's platform. Four years ago in Miami Beach, an 11hour platform debate on such emotional issues as busing, homosexual rights, capital punishment and abortion on demand left the impression that the party was a collection of exotics.

title: Hope Cooke: From Queen of Sikkim to Regular New Yorker
description: Hope Cooke Namgyal, the debutante. who 13 years ago married the Crown Prince of Sikkim and became the first Americanborn woman to be crowned a queen, sat crosslegged yesterday on the floor of her East Side apartment. sipping tea and watching her children and a neighbor play.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Just as pearls can come from diseased oysters, some of the most enduring songs have come from shows that were unmitigated flops. Over in Brooklyn this weekend, at Gallery 91, 91 Atlantic Avenue, the Atlantic Players are doing a show called Hit Tunes from Flop Shows. There are almost a score of songs, including numbers by George M. Cohan, Euhie Blake, Vincent Youmans, Kurt Weill. It's being done by three singers, Phyllis Young, Alexa Grant and Vincent Tauro, under the direction of Vincent Napoli, who wrote the book with Chuck Reichenthal. With narration and little sketches. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Arts and Cultural Association. Showtime tonight through Sunday, 8:30 P.M. Admission: $2.50. Information: 654 2271, 7834469.

title: Jersey Senate Approves A 1.5% State Income T ax
description: TRENTON, June 17The New Jersey State Senate today ended two years of virulent opposition to a personal income tax and voted to impose a 1.5 percent levy on personal gross income, with the proceeds earmarked for public schools.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JeanClaude Suares

title: Notes on People
description: The State Court of Appeals in Albany denied yesterday the request of John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, to be reinstated as a lawyer while his Watergate convictions are being appealed.

title: U.S. Reported Ready to Attack Curb on Lawyers Advertising
description: WASHINGTON. June 17 (AP) The Justice Department is almost certain to sue in Federal court to force the American Bar Association to lift a longstanding prohibition on advertising by lawyers, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: Dow Climbs 14.57 to Break 1,000 Level 6th Time in 1976
description: The Dow Jones industrial average soared 14.57 points Stock Exchange to penetrate yesterday on the New York the 1,000point level for the sixth time this year. Trading was the heaviest in almost three months.

title: New York Appeals Court Voids Sunday Sale Bans
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, in a unanimous decision, yesterday declared unconstitutional the section of the state's blue laws that forbids the sale of most items on Sundays.

title: Policy on Trial
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's new African policy is undergoing a severe testboth in Washington and in southern Africa itselfeven before it has been accepted across the United States Government. The open question, as racial tensions erupt into violence, is whether or not this country's diplomatic interest has been expressed too late to be felt where it could count.

title: TOP WEEKEND FILMS
description: 1:00 P.M. (13) As You Like It (1936). Elisabeth Bergner, Sir Laurence Olivier. Filmed as a play, but these two add something.

title: Opera: Met Parks Troupe in Queens
description: One of the nice things about the new portable arqmstical shell that the Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic are using in the parks this summer is its looks. It was on display for the second time, Wednesday night, when the Met gave a concert performance of Puccini's Madama Butterfly in Crocheron Park in Queens, and as a structure it blended into the surrounding greenery far more ac ceptably than its predecessor.

title: RADIO
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Ports of Call, Ibert; Piano Trio in E flat minor, Haydn; Flute Concerto No. 6, Pergolesi; Piano Variations, Copland; Organ Concerto No. 5, Handel.

title: TEAMSTER CHIEFS UNDER SUBPOENA
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 17Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, disclosed today that he and other top union officials had been subpoenaed to appear in Washington.

title: Finley Defends Sales In Hearing by Kuhn
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn held a 90minute hearing yesterday on the mass sale of star players by the Oakland A's, but made no immediate move to nullify the $3.5 million deal with the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS OF A SPLIT IN G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, June 17President Ford promised today not to engage in a grudge battle with Ronald Reagan, and he urged Republicans to unite behind the winner of the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Books of The Times
description: GRANTED. T. S. Eliot unquestionably is a towering figure among 20thcentury poets. And in this 35th addition to Viking Press's Modern Masters series, Stephen Spender has unquestionably advanced our understanding of Eliot, as well as providing a useful introduction to the poet's life and work. All the same, what the editor or the series, English critic Frank Kermode. says he means by Modern Mastersor at least what he used to say in a statement that regularly appeared as part of the series old format, which has now been alteredis the men who not only have changed but also are changing the life and thought of the age. And after reading Spender's study, one can't help questioning the relevance of T. S. Eliot's work to contemporary American literary art.

title: Advertising
description: Working women, who constitute a massive and growing segment of American societythe Government puts them at 37 million strongare giving advertisers a little trouble.

title: Yanks and British at Schaefer Music Festival
description: The 11th annual Schaefer Music Festival will present its first weekend show of season in Central Park tonight in a spirit of AngloAmerican unity with two bandsone British and one American.

title: Kingman's Homer in 14th Gives Mets 10 Victory Over Dodgers
description: Pitchers think they know everything. Before last night's final of the threegame series between the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgrs, Jerry Koosman of New York said a Met pitcher would have to throw a shutout to win. Charlie Hough of the Dodgers asserted he had the kind of knuckler that could get Dave Kingman out.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: The Silly Season
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The official silly season in this country runs roughly through the hot dog days from the Fourth of July to Labor Day. It is a time invented by and for reporters when minor characters fill in dull days In the news, and this year it is starting early.

title: Addresses Corrected On Operation Sail Data
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday about arrangement for Operation Sail 1976, the names and addresses of two groups offering vantage points for the seaborne parade were accidentally transposed. The correct information follows:

title: Dutch Bank Lifts Rate
description: AMSTERDAM, June 17 (Reuters)The Netherlands raised its bank rate to 5 percent from 4.5 percent, effective tomorrow, the Dutch Central Bank said today.

title: Beleaguered Census Bureau Counts on Texas Experiment
description: AUSTIN, Tex.Mike Kramer, who ought to know something about counting heads as a father of 15 nudged his battered old Dodge into a driveway in the dusty Texas hill country just west of Austin. No census form had been returned from the neat, white house.

title: Democratic Platform
description: An analysis of the platform adopted by the Democratic Platform Committee and scheduled to be submitted to the party's convention here next month appears on Page 13. Excerpts from the platform are on Page A12.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: ADMITTED BRIBER IS FREED BY COURT,
description: A gambler and oddsmaker indicted by the state's special prosecutor. Maurice H. Nadjari, on bribery charges has been acquitted by a Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn after a sixday trial.

title: Bergman Given 4 Months
description: Berriard Bergman, the central figure in the New York nursinghome scandal who had been convicted of Medicaid and tax fraud, was sentenced yesterday to four months in a Federal correction center. The special state prosecutor immediately charged that the promoter had reneged on a plea bargain, and threatened to reopen the prosecution of the Bergman family in state courts.

title: Broadway
description: THIS is likely to be a very good year for Anton Chekhov. Irene Worth will do The Cherry Orchard for Joe Papp at Lincoln Center, while Jeanne Moreau probably will do the same play at the uptown Circle in the Square. Moreover, Eugenie Leontovich will direct her own adaptation of The Seagull somewhere. Off Broadway in the fall. Miss Leontovich, who was in The Seagull in Moscow in 1920, will not appear in this new production because there is no part in it for a woman of her age. Miss Leontovich jogs several times a week around the Central Park reservoir and swims every day at the Henry Hudson Health Club, but she is, after all, 76. equity will allow miss Leontovich 12 weeks or work shop rehearsals for her Seagull, which may well be a record gestation for an Off Broadway, or even Broadway. production. Miss Leontovich will cast the 13 roles for Seagull in July, start rehearsing in August, and open some time in November.

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: Musical Holdouts': Hidden Talent
description: With one small harmonica tucked into his old hand, Sonny Terry is a swarm of musical bumblebees, three dozen hopping whistling teakettles and a whole bluegrass convention of fiddlers. He plays and he whoops and he clicks and he ticks with the rhythmic precision of a kettledrum and the tearaway shriek of a steam calliope.

title: Blue Times, $7.40, Triumphs on Turf
description: Laz Barrera, who this season has been in the winner's circle to greet such stakes winners as Bold Forbes, Life's Hope and Due Diligence, was back at his fimiliar stand yesterday at Belmont Park. This time, the Cubanborn traier turned out to greet a member of his tring who had been unsuccessful in all eight of his previous starts this year.

title: Louisville Plan Accepted
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., June 17 (AP)  Judge Gordon accepted today a revised desegregation plan calling for the busing of 900 additional black pupils during the next school year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rioting continued for a third day in Soweto, a black township near Johannesburg, with the rioters, mostly young people, directing their fury at government buildings and vehicles. The death toll increased as more than 1.000 policemen armed with rifles and sten guns moved into the streets. The official toll yesterday was 54 dead and 300 injured. [ Page A1, Column 8.]

title: ALBERT T. JOHNSON
description: Albert T. Johnson, a manufacturers representative, died Wednesday in New York Hospital of complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old and lived in Sagatonack, L.I. He had been a vice president of Youngstown Steel Door Company with offices in Manhattan. Recently he had headed ParkeJohnson Associates. He also had been president of the village of Roslyn Estates.

title: Jersey Senate Approves A 1.5% State Income Tax
description: TRENTON, June 17The New Jersey State Senate today ended two years of virulent opposition to a personal income tax and voted to impose a 1.5 percent levy on personal gross income, with the proceeds earmarked for public schools.

title: SOUTH AFRICATOLL RISES TO 58 DEAD; NEARLY 800 HURT

Buckley as the party's candidate for reelection by an overwhelming margin yesterday over Representative Peter Peyser of Westchester, but Mr. Peyser, nevertheless, said he would challenge Mr. Buckley in the Republican primary on Sept. 14.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 6.4%
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Association of American Railroads eported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion tonmiles, 6.4 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same pefiod totaled 486,243 cars, 3.7 percent above last year. The American Trucking Association Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 10.8 percent above last year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on winetasting courses for women in The New York Times yesterday, the caption incorrectly identified the teacher conducting a lesson. The teacher shown was Patricia Gallagher.

title: EXCONVICT TELLS OF ROLE IN MURDER
description: A 28yearold onetime bartender, exconvict and decorated Vietnam War veteran gave a matteroffact account yesterday, at a Police Department trial, of how, he said, he helped a city detective murder a Denver businessman last October.

title: Screen: 'Harry and Walter'
description: "HARRY and Walter Go to New York" is a movie based on an original story and screenplay, but it's so implacably cute that you might suspect that it was based on a coloring book based on "The Sting." It's big and blank and so faux naif that you want to hit it over the head in the way that used to bring people to their senses in true farce, of which this is no example.The time is 1892, which you can roughly guess because the men wear bowler hats and those stiff collars that become partially detached whenever someone is harried. The story is about Harry (James Caan) and Walter (Elliott Gould), a couple of third-rate vaudevillians who become sidetracked as would-be safecrackers.It's also about Adam Worth (Michael Caine), an elegant, internationally applauded safecracker whom Harry and Walter have met during a brief stay in a Federal pen, and Lissa Chestnut (Diane Keaton), the pretty, passionately committed editor of an anarchist newspaper who decides, for reasons that are perfectly unclear, to rob the Commercial Bank and Trust Company of Lowell, Mass.There are two funny moments in the entire film: Miss Keaton's stirring declaration that "If that bank has to be robbed, let it be robbed in the name of decency!" and a scene in which she attempts a genteel seduction of Charles Durning, who plays the bank's president, a furiously incompetent lecher.Miss Keaton, Mr. Caine and Mr. Durning are able farceurs, which means that they lower their sights so that their entire concentration appears to be on a space of approximately one cubic inch. This lunatic enveloping preoccupation with the trivial is one of the things that make farce funny as well as liberating. It's like watching the combat in an ant palace.Neither Mr. Caan nor Mr. Gould plays it this way, and I suspect that that was the intention of the director, Mark Rydell, as well as of the script writers, John Byrum and Robert Kaufman. If "Harry and Walter Go to New York" were to work at alland I'm not sure it couldHarry and Walter would have to be played straight, as believably bumbling innocents, not as a couple of leading men impersonating ineptitude and incompetence Mr. Gould can be a good comedian, but here he seems to have caught some of Mr. Caan's way of appearing to wink at the audience, as if to disassociate himself from the character.The two stars don't act, as they are perfectly capable of doing. Instead they cut-up in the desperate manner of performers appearing "live" on television talk shows, or of "guest stars" on television variety shows who can't help cracking up with laughter at jokey ad libs they've already heard 40 times in rehearsal.Tony Bill, the film's executive producer, was also one of the producers of "The Sting," which makes comparisons between the two films inevitableand very unfortunate for "Harry and Walter." The new film, which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, features a lot of stylish interior decoration that you will see only in big-budget movies, but the comedy is inconsistent, diluted, the kind that seems to be television's unhappiest gift to theatrical films."Harry and Walter" has been rated PG, apparently because some of its language is what once was called bold, which isn't the same thing as obscene.

title: I. C. C. Supported By Supreme Court On Railroad Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  The Supreme Court ruled 6to2 today that the Interstate Commerce Commission can specify how railroads, must spend a rate increase as the price of freeing them from lengthy and costly hearings.

title: Art: Regards to Piancastelli
description: TO BE director of the Borghese Gallery in Rome would be better than begging in the streets, even today. In 1899, when Giovanni Piancastelli became the first holder of the post, it was paradise. Rome in those days was the place where everyone wanted to be. Not for nothing did Henry James place most of the action of his last novel there: Rome was Rome, a city of unparalleled amenity, and it seemed only yesterday that the best painters and sculptors from all over had fought to get there.

title: Bridge:
description: Most experts are aware that standard signaling methods are slightly inferior, but very few of them are willing to make the effort to change deeply ingrained habits. One example is the normal length signal, in which a defender plays highlow with two cards or tour. The high card in a doubleton holding is often useful and cannot be spared, so the Scandinavians are theoretically right in playing high with three cards in the opponents suit.

The Senate had been stalled on the income tax issue, which had halted action on virtually every aspect of the legislative process.

title: Conner Reverses Role From Big to SmallBoat Pilot
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N.Y., June 17A few miles from here, at the edge of a meadow filled with grazing cows, a small billboard discreetly advises visitors they are approaching Henderson Harbor, Home of the Black Bass.

title: Wife of Exxon Official Receives Letter Bomb at Houston Home
description: HOUSTON, June 17 (UPI)The wife of an Exxon Corporation officer found a manila envelope bomb in her mailbox to day, and a police bomb squad defused it.

Buckley as the party's candidate for reelection by an overwhelming margin yesterday over Representative Peter Peyser of Westchester, but Mr. Pevser, nevertheless, said he would challenge Mr. Buckley in the Republican primary on Sept. 14.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 29 editorial Rational Sentencing asked a very important question about our criminaljustice system: What purpose does incarceration serve? Having been confined for eighteen of the past 23 years, I can assure you, Senator Kennedy or any of the almost 1,000 sentencing Federal judges that rehabilitation is a facade, punishment is a joke (and punishment for the sole sake of punishment only results in retributive reactions), protection of the lawabiding is virtually nonexistent and uncertainty of release from prison is precipitous of violence and disorder.

title: Chock Full o Nuts Posts Loss; Others Issue Earnings Figures
description: The Chock Full o Nuts Corporation reported yesterday substantial losses for the three and nine months ended April 30 despite increased sales. The deficit operations were attributed in part to the closing of the Rheingold brewery in BroOklyn and its relocation. plus a decline in the value of marketable securities.

title: 31st Caramoor Festival to Begin
description: Tomorrow night in Katonail. N.Y., Julius Rudel will give the downbeat for the performance of a Mozart symphony on a Venetianstyle stage at one end of a sunken garden, thus opening the 31st Caramoor Festival. It is the start of probably the most elegant and aristocratic, as well as the earliest, of the annual summer festivals in the metropolitan area.

title: Conflicting Signals
description: Another of the ten points in Mr. Kissinger's Lusaka speech was the promise to work for repeal of the notorious Byrd Amendment, which permits the United States to import Rhodesian chrome in defiance of the U.N. sanctions. On this issue, as well as Mozambique aid, there has been ample room for skepticism about the degree of President Ford's commitment to the Kissinger policy particularly since it is under attack by conservative forces inside Congress and the Republican Party.
