description: A team of physicists believes it has found in mica specimens from Africa one and possibly more of the longsought superheavy elements.

title: BOND PRICES RISE ON ACTION BY FED AFTER 2DAY FALL
description: After declining for two days the credit markets recovered yesterday, pushing bond prices up as much as half a point and interest rates down for the first time since Monday. The advance in prices came after the Federal Reserve injected reserves temporarily into the banking system yesterday morning, and it was extended in the afternoon after the central bank reported a drop in the nation's basic money supply and a decrease in New York City bank commercial loans.

title: Art People
description: WITH Picasso's threestory concrete lass, Sylvette, in the courtyard, who needs another oeuvre? That was the feeling of some of the tenants at 505 LaGuardia Place, a middleincome cooperative overlooking the Picasso work in University Plaza, facing Bleecker Street. But other tenants felt differently, including Sasson Soffer, himself a sculptor who thinks large. In November, 1973. with the backing of some of the cooperative's board members, Mr. Soffer brought his own work to 505, a 24foot high double spiral of steel called West Gate.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A threealarm fire in Union City destroyed a fourstory brick warehouse filled with furniture. The fire in the LaCasa Tony Furniture Store on Bergenline Avenue was discovered when the store was first opened. More than 65 firefighters from Union City, Weehawken, West New York and Jersey City battled the blaze for more than three hours before it was brought under control.

title: Howar Novel: Thistles in the Thicket
description: Making Ends Meet is one of those putative a clef novels that will have everybody in the know clucking about the author's portrayal of soandso. The rest of us, who lack thc key, though, will find in it both characters who seem tile romantic idealizations necessary in this kind of fiction and some sharply dissected case studiesall menwho pass through the portals (revolving door rather) of the heroine's overscheduled romantic life.

title: Beleaguered Census Bureau Counts on Texas Experiment
description: AUSTIN, Tex.Mike Kramer, who ought to know something about counting heads as a father of 15. nudged his battered old Dodge into a driveway in the dusty Texas hill country just west of Austin. No census form had been returned from the neat white house.

title: Albany High Court Rules Lulus Legal But Sets Up Curbs
description: ALBANY. June 17  The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the Legislature could vote a limited number of extra allowancespopularly known as lulusto supplement lawmakers salaries this year.

title: Hamptons: A Taste of Variety
description: Weekend dining in the Hamptons covers an everwidening range of possibilities. Tables are set invitingly in the rambling old inns and houses, shiny new storefronts and weathered dockside buildings of the tidy villages that stretch from the eastern end of Moriches Bay to Montauk Point. Clam bars, fastfood chains and discotheques line the highway that links them.

title: Publisher Sees Smooth Selling on High Seas Saga
description: BACK IN 1974 plans were being made in Hawaii by the Polynesian Voyaging Society for a trip from Hawaii to Tahiti under the same conditions encountered by the early Polynesians. The plan was to construct a doublehulled canoe that was to he used without recourse to charts and instruments.

title: 42 Prisoners Hurt As Racial Fracas Erupts on Rikers

Naber and Roil Strachan, his University of Southern California classmate broke American records, and Ernie Vandeweghe's daughter made the Olympic team.

description: LUANDA, Angola, June 17The public prosecutor accused 13 British and American mercenaries of the crime of genocide; today and demanded the death penalty for them ail.

The victory, before a crowd of 5,000 at the Osaka Municipal Gymnasium in western Japan, was the second for the East.

Simpson, a Buffalo running back, and Fran Tarkenton, a Minnesota Quarterback were named today the National Football League Players Association most valuable players in the American and National Conferences, respectively. Simpson and Tarkertton, along with 10 other individual winners chosen by N.F.L. players in each conference, and 17 statistical winners, will be honored at an awards dinner in Chicago June 27.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  President Ford has ordered flags flown at halfstaff on Monday at all federal buildings and installations in respect for Ambassador Francis E. Meloy Jr. and Robert O. Waring, who were killed in Lebanon yesterday.

title: Yes Is In Good Form Here
description: The first albums by Yes, the fiveman English rock group that performed at Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday, were widely hailed as masterpieces of art rock, but then the group's music grew more pretentious and gimmickladen. At the same time, a flock of English groups that came along in the wake of Yes's initial success drove the artrock idiom into the ground with plodding, overarranged musical excesses and lyrics full of pseudoprofundities.

description: PARIS, June 17 (Reuters)Fourteen countries and international organizations meeting within the framework of the Club of Paris agreed to reschedule a major part of Zaire's foreign debts, wellinformed sources said today.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  Violent crimes decreased sharply in the country's big cities in the first three months of this year, as against the same period last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

The bill, whose principal sponsor is Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, is based on his theory that there is a lack of competition because of the unique convergence of intense concentration and vertical integration.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17Both Mr. Kissingor and Ron Nessen, the White House spokesman, reiterated today that the Administration was not even considering intervention by American armed forces in the Lebanese fighting.

description: Dr. Sylvan A. Broadman, pediatrician, died Tuesday at his home in Farmington, Mich. He was 61 years old.

title: 5 Die of Bubonic Plague
description: GENEUR, June 17 (Reuters) Five people have died of bubonic plague and 21 are suffering from the disease in Madagascar, according to a spokesman for the World Health Urganization. Madagascar is one of the few places in the world where there are regular outbreaks of bubonic plague.

title: GEORGE H. HOWARD
description: George H. Howard, manager of the Commodore Hotel from 1936 until his retirement in 1964, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Howard, who lived at 333 East 68th Street, was 74 years old. He was one of the original employees of the 2,000room hotel, which opened in January 1919 and closed last May. Mr. Howard is survived by his wife, Lillian Keller Howard.

title: Coffee Prices Up At General Foods; Bean Costs Cited
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the wholesale prices of its grocery brands of coffee as a result of the confirming upsurge in the costs of green coffee. This would be the third increase in coffee prices by the company this year and would bring the price at supermarkets to $2 or more than $2 a pound, depending on the store location, in the next few weeks.

title: Goldin Checks Out Tax
description: The owner of a midManhattan loft building was rubbed the wrong way yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who refused to approve an assessment reduction on his property because it harbors a socalled massage parlor.

title: Dividend Rise Seen
description: BUFFALO, June 17The F. W. Woolworth chain expects a 10 percent increase in sales this year, which will increase its volume well over $5 billion, the company's president and chairman said at the company's annual stockholder's meeting here today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Buoyed by favorable economic reports, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over  the  counter market advanced sharply yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: All the Ness That's Fit To Print
description: We take you now to Loch Ness where a New York Times expedition has deployed powerful underwater photographic equipment in a search for the notorious Loch Ness Monster. Standing by at the monitor is Times publisher Arthur O. Sulzberger. Have you had any monster sightings yet, Mr. Sulzberger?

title: Bogatyryov, a Soviet Poet, Dies After Moscow Beating
description: MOSCOW, June 18 (AP)Konstantin Bogatyryov, a Soviet poet and translator of German poetry, has died after being beaten outside his Moscow apartment, his friends said today. He was 51 years old.

title: Helen T. Haskell, Engineer Marry
description: Helen Talley Haskell, widow of Amory Lawrence Haskell Jr., was married here yesterday to Robert George Sampson, vice president and treasurer of Remsco Associates construction engineers in Old Bridge, N.J. The ceremony was performed in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. J. Douglas Ousley.

title: Dance: Sleeping Beauty
description: For this first week of its new production of the Petipa/Tchaikovsky classic The Sleeping Beauty, American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House is putting out many, many casts. Rightly so, because this is the kind of ballet intended to extend the company, to give all its principals, guests and soloists an opportunity to shine, and for its ensemble to look perfect and elegant.

title: People in Sports
description: Carmen Cozza, whose football teams have won more games for him than for any other Yale coach, also was named the school's athletic director yesterday. The 46yearold Cozza will succeed DeLaney Kiphuth, who is stepping down after 22 years to become special assistant to the Yale president. Kingman Brewster Jr.

title: FRANCIS J. HUGHES
description: Francis J. Hughes, a retired negligence trial lawyer, died yesterday at the Peninsula Hospital Center, Rockaway Beach. He was 76 years old and lived at 14415 Cronston Avenue in the Neponsit section of Rockaway Beach, Queens.

description: NEW HAVEN, June 18 (AP)A Superior Court judge today rejected a plea bargaining recocmmendation for a lessthanmaximum sentence against a New Haven teenager accused of murdering a Yale University student.

description: Bernard Bergman was ordered yesterday to give the records of his Park Crescent Nursing Home to a courtappointed receiver in 24 hours under penalty of contempt.

When the 21yearold Seattle amateur strolled onto the putting green at the Atlanta Athletic Club before the second round, Chi Chi Rodriguez, waved.

description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 18Betty Newfield of Jackson Heights, Queens, 15 years old, won the New York State girls tennis championship, for girls to 18, by defeating 17yearold Stacy Bowman of Bedford, N.Y., 36, 75, 63, at Bronxville Field Club today.

He said his yacht, Achille, christened by Princess Grace, had come through the storm without damage.

title: Bay of Fundy Is Restudied for Tidal Power

title: Carter's Constituency
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Jimmy Carter, the selfproclaimed outsider who promises to bring love and compassion to Government as President, begins the competition against the Republicans with a powerful, yet unusual contituency of Americans behind him.

title: Hofstra Head Resigns in Move Tied to View of His Fiscal Role
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 18Robert. L. Payton, president of Hofstra University for the last three years, said today that he had handed in his resignation to the board of trustees.

title: 2 Brooklyn Democrats Admit They Took $100,000 in Party's Funds
description: Two former officials of the Brooklyn Democratic organization pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they siphoned off (about $100,000 the party's annual dinner funds over three to four years.

title: Greater Control by State Is Urged on Nuclear Sites
description: CHERRY HILL, June 18David L. Morell of Princeton University's Center for Environmental Studies called today for a greater state and local role in deciding where nuclear power plants and other major energy facilities are placed.

title: A Public Facility
description: The attempt to bar the press and public from a negligence suit brought by singer Connie Francis against the Howard Johnson motel chain has quite properly been decided in favor of open hearingsand of the Constitution.

title: Ford Aides Deny Politics In Canceling Trip to Iowa
description: WASHINGTON, June 18White House officials credited, President Ford today with putting policy ahead of politics in deciding to monitor the departure of Americans from Lebanon rather than campaign in Iowa.

title: U. N. Council Asked to Condemn South Africa and Act on Riots
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Saturday, June 19The Security Council was called into emergency session last night at the request of 47 African nations to consider a resolution on the situation in South Africa.

title: The Plutonium Danger
description: Plutonium, when ingested, can be one of the most poisonous substances known to man. In metal form it is relatively safe to handle, but potentially far more lethal than poison. A stolen quantity the size of a grapefruit, shaped into a bomb by urban guerrillas or saboteurs, could destroy a city the size of Hiroshima.

title: GRAIN QUOTATIONS HELD MISLEADING
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Two staff investigators told a Senate subcommittee today that misleading price information quoted by large grain corporations on their European trade made it possible for them to influence United States markets and prices to be paid to American farmers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony No. 92, Haydn; Piano Concerto No. 2, Barsukov; Ballet Excerpts from Gustaf Wasa, Haumann; Royal Hunt and Storm, Berlioz; Salome, Hadley; Sinfonia in B, Scarlatti; Violin Concerto, Strauss; Gymnopedies Nos. 1 and 3, SatieDebussy; Entrance of the Guests from Tannhauser, Wagner.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 19, 1976

title: Rikers I. Inmates Agree to Moratorium If No Action Is Taken Against Rioters
description: Benjamin J. Malcolm, the city's Commissioner of Correction, said last night that ado lescent inmates at Rikers Island had agreed to a moratorium on further violence in return for a decision by authorities not to take action against anyone for the racial riot that broke out Thursday night.

title: FALL IS INDICATED IN G.N.P. GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The growth in the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, is likely to slow substantially in the current quarter to considerably less than 5 percent on an annual basis, Government economists said today.

title: Mrs. Crimmins Files For a New Appeal In Daughter's Death
description: Alice Crimmins, the former cocktail waitress now serving five to 20 years in a halfway house for manslaughter in the death of her 9yearold daughter, Alice Marie, filed papers in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday seeking a new chance to appeal her conviction.

title: Rudd, Meryl Streep, Actors to Hilt
description: I might have been in that series for five years. I didn't want to become a living room fixture, a household word. I don't want to be identified with one character like other actors. I'm not quarreling with them. If I had five kids, I might do it, but I don't.

title: Soweto Bitter Over Apartheid, but Fearful of Rioters
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18 Moses Dineka, a quiet man who hates violence, was on the lookout for a weapon when he returned to Soweto last night from his job in a Johannesburg restaurant.

title: PBS WILL EXTEND SATELLITE TV USE
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has signed a sevenyear contract with Western Union for the use of three transponders on its Westar satellite to distribute public television programming to stations of the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Rioting spread yesterday to a number of black townships around Johannesburg. Prime Minister John Vorster assured the country over radio and television that there is definitely no reason for any panic and said that orders had been given to maintain law and order at all costs. This Government will not be intimidated, he said. On the third day of the rioting, the police stopped giving out official casualty figures when the death toll reached 60. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: AGNES M. CLIFFORD
description: Agnes M. Clifford, who retired in 1971 as executive administrator of nursing at Montefiore Hospital, died Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. She was 69 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y. She attended Georgetown and Columbia Universities and is survived by a daughter, Juliana Parascandola and one grandchild.

title: 3 IOWA DELEGATES WON BY PRESIDENT
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, June 18 President Ford won the first test of strength tonight at the Iowa Republican district conventions, but former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California was showing more strength than had been expected.

title: Jersey Legislators Seeking Tax Accord
description: TRENTON, June 18Democratic leaders of the Senate and the Assembly said today they had scheduled a weekend meeting to attempt to hammer out a personal income tax bill that would be acceptable to both houses.

title: Man Slain on 42d Street
description: A heated dispute during a craps game in Bryant Park on West 42d Street adjacent to the New York Public Library culminated yesterday afternoon in the stabbing death of one of the participants. Found at the scene by the police was Thomas Richburg Jr., 34 years old, of 2833 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx. The players and the assailant fled from the park at about 4 P.M. and witnesses were being questioned by homicide detectives.

title: Goodell Shatters Record
description: LONG BEACH. Calif., June 18Brian Goodell, a 17yearold high school student from Mission Viejo, Calif., set a world record in the 400meter freestyle tonight, beating Tim Shaw, the record holder, in a spectacular battle over the last 50 meters in the Olympic swimming trials at the Belmont Plaza Olympic Pool.

title: ROGER A. BARTON, 72, AD MAN AND EDITOR
description: Roger Avery Barton, an advertismg executive and founder of MediaScope magazine, an advertising journal, died Wednesday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Pittstown, N. J.

title: BANKERS ADVISED ON LOAN LOSSES
description: ??r bankers from four cou?? ?? before than ?? other senior banking executives from around the world today and told them what they already knewbankers made grievous errors during the last five years because they were caught up in a euphoria that made them disregard some of the fundamental rules of their business.

title: I Am God! Do You Hear  God!(For a Minute.)
description: PARISIn 356 B.C., a man named Herostratos set fire to the most famous temple of the goddess Dianamerely, as he confessed, to make himself famous. Even though the mention of his name was declared a capital offense, this criminal is still famous today. When the attention of contemporaries is drawn to a man totally unremarkable except for some unusually destructive act he has committed or threatened to commit, we speak of herostratism.

title: Plea on Sentencing In Slaying at Yale Rejected by Judge
description: NEW HAVEN, June 18 (AP)A Superior Court judge today rejected a plea bargaining recommendation for a lessthanmaximum sentence against a New Haven teenager accused of murdering a Yale University student.

title: Tenneco Oil Sues a Top Officer; Links Action to Kickback Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The directors of Tenneco Oil Company, which had 1975 revenues of $1.5 billion, have sued the company's vice chairman, S. V. McCollum, after he allegedly refused to cooperate in an investigation of suspected kickback payments to a Tenneco employee.

title: Bergman Sentence Is Discussed
description: When former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew pleaded no contest to an income tax evasion charge in 1973 and received no prison sentence, large segments of the public reacted with shock, disbelief and outrage. Similarly, many, felt that sentences meted out to several Watergate figures we.re too lenient. Those same reactions were evident yesterdayfrom taxi drivers, dozens of irate individuals who telephoned newspapers, politicians, lawyers and judgesfollowing the fourmonth prison term given Bernard Bergman, the central figure in the New York nursing home scandal.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 18What it cost the Democratic leadership in the Legislature to get 21 votes for the income tax in the State senate is not yet entirely clear. If any deals were struck, they were made in closed caucus or in private conversations, and the details have not leaked out.

title: Southern Baptists Show Signs of Unrest
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 18The mythical wall of theological uniformity once thought to bind Southern Baptists together is showing further signs of crumbling under the pressures of increasing diversity of thought.

title: N.C.A.A. World Series
description: (Arizona St. eliminated)

title: Guilty Verdict Is Returned In fire at Connecticut Plant
description: ALBANY, June 18 (AP)A Federal court jury here has, found a Michael J. Tiche of Boyers. Pa., guilty on three of four counts in connection with the firebombing of a Connecticut sponge rubber factory last year.

title: Lawyer Linked to Cunningham Is Indicted in Bronx Liquor Case
description: The former law partner of previously indicted judge was accused yesterday of participating in a liquor license britery and conspiracy scheme, which accidently led to the controversial corruption investigation of Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader.

title: Trust Grows Amid Shots and Salutes
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18 (UPI)  The black woman, wearing a colored doek scarf around her head and a pink smockthe dress of a servant of a white homeran across the road, tears from the smoke streaming down her cheeks.

title: Notes on People
description: James A. Farley Jr., chairman of the State Athletic Commission, and his sisters, Elizabeth Montgomery and Anne E. Hickey, were named principal beneficiaries in the will of their father, former Postmaster General James A. Farley, filed for probate in Manhattan Surrogates Court yesterday. The younger Mr. Farley will also receive two of his father's prized mementoes, a chair and a clock.

title: Companies Report Profit
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Strife Likely on July 4, Senators Told
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee heard testimony today that radical groups were planning disruptive demonstrations at Fourth of July Bicentennial events.

title: Chris Evert to Play Miss Wade in Final
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 18It will be a repeat of the 1974 final here when Chris Evert meets Virginia Wade in this $90,000 Colgate women's invitation tennis tournament on the fast green lawns of Devonshire Park tomorrow.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES OFF 6C A BUSHEL
description: In quiet preweekend trading soybean prices fell yesterday about 6 cents a bushel in terms of the July contract to close at $6.17 a bushel, down from $6.23.

title: Text of Vorster Statement
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18Following is the text of a statement by Prime Minister John Vorster to Parliament in Cape Town today, as recorded here from a broadcast:

title: South African Office Is Vandalized Here
description: An unidentified man wrecked computer equipment and smashed a large plateglass window yesterday at the Fifth Avenue offices of the South African Airways. The vandal was said to have been accompanied by another man who snapped photographs of the incident. No one was injured and the two men escaped.

title: FORD DROPS TRIP, CITING LEBANON
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 President Ford canceled an election campaign trip to Iowa today after having directed the United States Embassy in Beirut to assist American citizens who, wanted to leave Lebanon.

title: Loyal to New York
description: The decision of Jonathan Logan Inc., one of the nation's leading apparel manufacturers, to expand an important manufacturing and distribution operation in Manhattan offers bold and timely testimony to this hardpressed city's continuing viability as a good place to do business and to produce quality goods.

title: Some Schools Shut as Rolls Decrease
description: EAST NORTHPORT. L.L, June 18The parents and teachers at the Grace L. Hubbs School here decided to get together one last time, and they promised one another they wouldn't cry.

title: LAWYER BIDS ANGOLA TREAT 13 AS P.O.W.'s
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 18The Angolan Peoples Revolutionary Court heard today a calm but firm plea by an American lawyer that the 13 mercenaries on trial here be treated as prisoners of war under the Geneva Convention.

title: Miss Gerulaitis Wins
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 18 (AP)Ruta Gerulaitis of New York, the No. I Eastern player, reached the semifinals of the Birmingham Tennis Classic today with a 76, 61 victory over Ann Dielen of Birmingham. The tournament is part of the Southern circuit.

title: Services to Commemorate Monsignor Escriva's Death
description: A memorial mass observing; the first anniversary of the death of Msgr. Josemaria Escriv de Balaguer, the founder and president of Opus Dei, will be held June 26 at 10:45 A.M. at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, 347 East 47th Street. Monsignor Escriva died in Rome last June 26, at the age of 73.

title: TaxiDriver Leaders and Museum Clash
description: Two leaders of independent taxi ownerdriver associations have clashed with officials of the Museum of Modern Art over the museum's exhibit of prototype cabs of the future, and one leader said that he was ejected from the show.

title: U.S. Attorneys Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Philip M. Van Dam to be United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan, and Nicholas P. Geeker to be United States Attorney for the Northern District of Florida.

title: Yanks Beat White Sox In 14th, 32
description: CHICAGO, June 18Ken Holtzman, one of two expatriate Oakland pitchers the Yankees have been allowed to keep, made his first start for New York tonight, but all he got was a tie. Grant Jackson, another new Yankee, finished the game and he was the winner in the 14inning, 32 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: F.B.I. Director Gets Threatening Letter Containing Harmless Dead Ticks
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Federal. Bureau of Investigation said today that its di rector, Clarence M. Kelley, had received a threatening letter containing dead ticks similar to ones sent to business executives this week.

title: Hope Fades in Rubber Strike As Plan to Break Impasse Fails
description: WASHINGTON, June 18An attempt by federal mediators to find a castofliving formula that would break the impasse in the long rubber workers strike appears to have failed, sources close to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said today.

title: Bridge: Departure In Bidding Leads To Confusion Around Table
description: A slight departure from normal bidding practice is sometimes sufficient to spread confusion around the table. On the diagramed deal from a recent regional mixed pair championship in Norfolk, Va., South decided to respond with a threecard suit. His partner showed great enthusiasm for the suit, taking the partnership to a shaky contract, but it was the opponents who suffered in the long run.

title: VIKING IS NEARING AN ORBIT OF MARS
description: PASADENA. Calif., June 18The long and largely uneventful flight of Viking 1, a spacecraft launched from the earth 10 months ago to look for life on Mars, is scheduled to reach a critical phase tomorrow night when the spacecraft's engine will fire for about 40 minutes to put the craft into an orbit around Mars.

title: Britons Win Title Sail
description: KIEL, West Germany, June 18 (UPI)  Reg White and John Osborn of Britain won the European Tornado Class sailing championship today in Kiel Bay. The defending world champions took the trophy after winning four of the six races.

title: Hope for Reforms
description: ROME, June 18Vittorio and Marcella Roffo live with their two children in a roomy, tastefully decorated apartment in a quiet residential area here.

title: Jersey Gets Option to Buy Scenic Tract In Ramapo Mountains for $4 Million
description: HACKENSACK, June 18New Jersey formally gained the right today to buy for $4 million a scenic 2,340 acre property atop the Ramapo Mountains in Bergen and Passaic Counties.

title: U.S BIDS CITIZENS LEAVE LEBANON; CONVOY DEPARTS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18The United States Embassy today strongly urged all remaining American citizens in Lebanon to leave the country, but with Beirut continuing relatively quiet, there seemed little interest in doing so.

title: Africans Assisting Fleeing Officials
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18 (UPI)  Whites who escaped from the eruptions of violence in riottorn black areas of South Africa gave harrowing accounts today of their experiences.

title: Harrises Lose Plea on Delay; Trial Set to Start Monday
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18 (AP)  The trial of William and Emily Harris will apparently begin on schedule.

title: A Founder of Arab League And First Head Is Dead
description: PARIS, June 18 (AP)Abdul Rachman Hassan Azzam Pasha, the first Secretary General of the Arab League, died early this month in a Cannes hospital. The body was flown to Cairo.

title: HAYS FORCED OUT OF KEY HOUSE JOB; REFORMS WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Representative Wayne L. Hays, the focus of a Capitol Hill sex controversy, resigned under pressure from his colleagues today as chairman of the once obscure committee that he had expanded and used to exert power in Congress.

title: HAYS FORCED OUT OF KEY HOUSE JOB; REFORMS WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Representative Wayne L. Hays, the focus of a Capitol Hill sex controversy, resigned under pressure from his colleagues today as chairman of the once obscure committee that he had expanded and used to exert power in Congress.

title: Arthur B. Foye, Retired C .P . A., And N .Y . U. Alumni Fund Head
description: Arthur B. Foye, retired managing partner of Haskins & Sells, international public accounting firm, died yesterday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J., lat the age of 82. He would have been 83 tomorrow.

title: BERGMAN ORDERED TO YIELD RECORDS
description: Bernard Bergman was ordered yesterday to give the records of his Park Crescent Nursing Home to a courtappointed receiver in 24 hours under penalty of contempt.

title: Guide
description: JUNE TUNES Brooklyn visitors and residents of the Park Slope area who have missed this week's Cobble Hill Festival of Song can attend the final program tonight at 8 o'clock at the First Reformed Church, Seventh Avenue and Carroll Street. The featured festival performers, professional musicians who are residents of the brownstone district, are the Cobble Hill Chamber singers, conducted by Lin Garber. The group will sing works of Monteverdi, Faur, Druckman and Bach.

title: BANK INVESTIGATING 2 FORMER OFFICERS
description: CHICAGO, June 18 (AP)Two former trust officers are under investigation by the Continental Illinois National Bank for possible conflict of interest while they headed the oil and mineral section of the bank's trust department, the bank disclosed today.

title: KARL ADAM
description: SALZULFEN, West Germany, June 18 (AP)  Karl Adam, prominent rowing coach, died of a heart attack today while jogging with his wife, a spokesman at this spa reported today. He was 64 years old.

title: Bermuda Sail Begins in Fog
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 18It's just as well the honor code prevails in yacht racing. Otherwise there might have been wholesale cheating on the foggy starting line off Brenton Reef today as the 635mile ocean race to Bermuda began. Visibility was 100 yards at best, but the starting line between the Brenton Tower and the Coast Guard cutter Active was 1,000 yards. If someone had decided upon a headstart who would know? A radar that can read sail numbers has not yet been invented.

title: Campaigning in Italy Closes With Big Rallies
description: ROME, June 18Italy's momentous election campaign came to a close tonight as Communists and Christian Democrats both promised a stable and secure future if voters would support them in the national balloting on Sunday and Monday.

title: The Tall Ships at Anchor, Bermuda Still Keeps Its British Cool
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18  The unflappable island carries on.

title: Soweto Bitter Over Apartheid, but Fearful of Rioters
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18 Moses Dineka, a quiet man who hates violence, was on the lookout for a weapon when he returned to Soweto last night from his job in a Johannesburg restaurant.

description: PHOENIX, June 18The N?? bil Corporation today came the Mobil Corporation its shareholders approved reorganization leading to ?? proposed merger of Mobil a?? Marcor Inc.

title: Prince's Memorial Slated
description: A solemn pontifical memorial service will be celebrated for Prince Alexis Droutzkoy, founder and editor of the American Helicopter magazine, at the Russian Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign at 75 East 93d Street on Wednesday, at 7 P.M. The Prince died on May 15.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Union Corporation won final approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to manufacture soft contact lenses. The company said that its wholly owned subsidiary, UCO Optics Inc., would market contact lens called Aquaflex. The Union Corporation did not say when it would begin fullscale production and marketing.

title: CourtMartial Witnesses Call Dead Marine a Troublemaker
description: SAN DIEGO. June 18 (AP)Pvt. Lynn McClue was a troublemaker who brought on his own fatal injuries by antagonizing his fellow marines during a training exercise, GoVernment witnesses testified today at the courtmartial of Sgt. Harold Bronson.

title: Jordan Backs Syrians
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 18Jordan is firmly but unostentatiously giving Syria the staunchest public approval in the Arab world for the military intervention in Lebanon.

title: Beth Greenberg, Robert Rosenthal Wed
description: In the Branford Chapel of Yale University yesterday, Beth Ellyn Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Greenberg of Skokie. Ill., was married to Robert Louis Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Zeitz Rosenthal of Sands Point, L. I. Rabbi David Wartman officiated.

title: Assad, in Paris, Says He Backs Arab Peace Force in Lebanon
description: PARIS, June 18President Hafez alAssad of Syria said today that he favored a panArab peacekeeping force in Lebanon and insisted there were no serious problems between Syria and other Arab countries over the Lebanese crisis.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Independent pharmacists inNew Jersey, long troubled by the competitive threat posed by large chain stores that have pharmaceutical departments, are now concerned about the new wave of advertising the chains have begun, even before new rules governing prescriptiondrug advertising have been drawn up.

title: 2 Lightweight Sailors Shun Light Diets
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N. Y., June 18In a new Olympic yachting class whose heavyweights must be lightweights, Skip Whyte and Neal Fowler are breaking all the dietary rules

title: NOMINEE ANNOUNCED BY BLACK ASSEMBLY
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The National Black Political Assembly named Frederick Douglass Kirkpatrick today as its nominee for the Presidency and called the move the first step in the development of an independent black political party.

title: A Dying City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18 Bicycles are enjoying a sudden vogue in western Beirut these days, threading through the dusty packs of sheed that waddle through the streets, littered with splintered glass, shrapnel, shards of brick and smoking piles of garbage. On the sidelines cows graze on patches of grass in vacant lots.

description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: FASHION TALK
description: She can swing down the runway like the best of the newwave mannequins, but she has a sensitivity for fabrics and the way clothes move that gives her the aura of oldtime models, the ones who looked remote and untouchable.

title: Coed Driver Wins With a Loser
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 8It took a woman amateur driver to guide Fritzie Patchie to his first 1976 victory at Roosevelt Raceway tonight after 19 defeats. The occasion was the National Collegiate Championship, in which six students representing five harness tracks competed. Virginia Rich of Rosary Hill College in upstate Snyder won in a squeaker. Fritzie Patchie, a brown stallion, passed Fort Norman just before the wire and won by a neck in 2:08

title: Dynamo in Cup Soccer
description: ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP)The Dynamo Kiev soccer team of the Soviet Union will oppose the St. Louis Stars of the North American Soccer League in the annual Strassenfest International Cup game July 7. The contest at Francis Field will be the last for the Soviet players before they journey to Montreal to represent the U.S.S.R. in the Olympic games.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A grand jury has not found sufficient evidence to bring charges against the operator of a pleasure boat that capsized on Greenwood Lake last October, resulting in the drowning deaths of two elderly New Jersey women. An Orange County grand jury returned no bills on manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide charges against William Doig, 52 years old, of Greenwood Lake, N. Y. Doig was piloting a 28foot boat with 19 elderly aboard when capsized about a half mile from shore because it was overloaded, according to District Attorney David Ritter. There was no evidence that Mr. Doig's operation of the vessel had been improper. The United States Coast Guard is still investigating.

title: BOMB IN BED KILLS ARGENTINE OFFICER
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 18 (Reuters)The Argentine federal police chief was killed today when a bomb hidden under the mattress of his bed exploded, police sources said.

title: F.C.C. Finds 24.7% of TV Not Entertainment or Sports
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The average commercial television station devoted 24.7 percent of its broadcast day to programs that were not entertainment or sports, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

title: GERMANS PICK SITES OF KISSINGER TALKS
description: WASHINGTON. June 18Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa have agreed to hold their meetings next week in two small West German towns, the State Department announced today.

description: ?? by ??ingle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday. June 18. 41st day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Tentative Accord Reached In DeCamp Line Dispute
description: CLIFTON, N.J., June 18 (AP) A union spokesman said today a tentative settlement had been reached with management to end the fourweek strike against the De Camp Bus Lines Inc.

title: Kuhn Voids Player Sales; Finley Threatens to Sue
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn nullified the biggest sale of talent in baseball history yesterday when he ordered the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox to return the three stars they had bought earlier in the week from the Oakland A's for $3.5 million.

title: Simon Asks Fiscal Plan for 79 And Revision for Next 2 Years
description: Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, in addition to requiring New York City to revise its threeyear financial plan for the remaining two years before receiving Federal loans next month, will later require prompt submission of a program for 1979

title: Nirvana Ties For Lead in Jump Event
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 18Nirvana, a graybeard in the equestrian set, pulled into a tie for the amateurowner jumper championship today by winning the faultandout event at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

title: AMEX VALUE INDEX INCHES UP BY 0.55
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday in moderate trading.

title: DON LOFGRAN, 46, BASKETBALL STAR
description: Don Lofgran, a former allAmerica basketball star at the University of San Francisco and professional player, was found dead Thursday morning in a hotel room in Salt Lake City. The police there suspected alcoholic poisoning as the cause of death. He was believed to have been 46 years old.

title: 18,612 Sees Cosmos Win By 30 and Take First
description: Patience, confidence and purpose in their play were the ingredients that gave the New York Cosmos a 30 victory over the Toronto Metros before 18,612 fans at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Putting Title Won by Florin
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 18 (UPI)Dick Florin, a ??ank executive from Atlanta, defeated Manuel Serrano of Australia, 3 and 2, today to win the $320,000 world putting championship.

title: Malcolm Johnson Is Dead at 71, Won Pulitzer for Docks Expose
description: Malcolm Johnson, the star reporter of the old New York Sun who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1949 for his articles exposing terrorism and racketeering on New York's waterfront, died of cancer yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Killingworth, Conn.

title: Secret Service Agent Is Ousted In Missing Ammunition Inquiry
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18 (AP) A Secret Service agent who occasionally guarded President Ford has been dismissed after an investigation of missing Treasury Department ammunition that later turned up in the possession of a convicted murderer.

title: Guards Hold Tight Rein At Teamster Gathering

Agnew pleaded no contest to an income tax evasion charge in 1973 and received no prison sentence, large segments of the public reacted with shock, disbelief and outrage. Similarly, many felt that sentences meted out to several Watergate figures were too lenient. Those same reactions were evident yesterdayfrom taxi drivers. dozens of irate individuals who telephoned newspapers, politicians, lawyers and judgesfollowing the fourmonth prison term given Bernard Bergman, the central figure in the New York nursing home scandal.

The great cellist, conductor and humanitarian was so admired and loved that his anniversary is being celebrated in his native Spain, and in France, Switzerland, Mexico and Japan.

Section 210 of the latter law requires that municipal employees who engage in work stoppages must be notified no later than 90 days from the time an official determination is made that their action violated the nostrike law.

In each case the ultimate goal is obvious: peace between Israel and the Arabs in the second instance; democracy and constitutional monarchy in the first.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 18 (AP)  A bomb ex plotted in a crowded north Belfast bar today, killing one man and wounding at least 36 people, some of them seriously, the police reported. The bomb demolished Conway's Bar, ??urying most of the customers under a pile of rubble.

For an estimated 1,400 Americans, plus scores of British, French and United Nations personnel, this will be their first opportunity in about two weeks to depart the war zone since the enforced closure of Beirut's oncebustling international airport.

title: On Film, the Battle of 'Midway' Is Lost
description: "Midway" is a kamikaze attack against one of the greatest sea battles of modern times. The battlehistorysurvives while the movie blows up harmlessly in a confusion of familiar old newsreel footage, idiotic fiction war movie clichs, and a series of wooden-faced performances by almost a dozen male stars, some of whom appear so briefly that recognizing them is like taking a World War II aircraft-identification test. Is that a single-wing Robert Mitchum? A modified Cliff Robertson? A rebuilt Glenn Ford?The film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, attempts to recreate the circumstances leading up to the battle of Midway Island, June 4-5, 1942, when a perilously small United States Navy task force decisively defeated Admiral Yamamoto's much larger Japanese fleet whose mission had been the invasion and occupation of Midway. It was the turning point of the war against the Japanese who lost four large carriers and never again seriously threatened American sea power in the central Pacific. It was also the battle that established beyond doubt the leading role that carriers were to play in the Pacific war.Most of these things are reported quite dutifully by the film, but for anyone seriously interested in Midway, I'd recommend a reading of the late Samuel Eliot Morison's fastidiously documented account in his "History of United States Naval Operations in World War II."As did "Tora Tora Tora," that earlier movie disaster about the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, "Midway" solemnly cross-cuts between the war councils, chart rooms and communications offices on the American side and those on the Japanese side, with characters, who often have to be identified by subtitles, laboriously trying to give us all of the exposition necessary to make the battle coherent.There's no way to act such roles, though Henry Fonda as Admiral Nimitz shows a certain amount of ease reading decoded messages and shaking hands with junior officers. Charlton Heston plays a fictional character who might have been stolen from some terrible movie made shortly after World War IIa Navy officer whose Navy pilot son has the bad judgment to fall in love with an American-born Japanese girl.Mr. Heston is given the movie's silliest lines, though the fact that there really was an Admiral Yamamoto doesn't exactly protect Toshiro Mifune from his share of duds. "Ah," says the movie's Yamamoto when informed of Gen. Jimmy Doolittle's token air raid on Tokyo in early 1942, "this is a blessing in disguise. There'll be no more foot-dragging by the general staff." Small-talk among flag officers is one of the "film's more minor problems.The major one is the battle, which is a badly edited and badly matched series of scenes made up of studio stuff, miniatures and actual battle footage that was much better used (if my memory serves me) in John Ford's 18-minute documentary, "The Battle of Midway" and Louis De Rochemont's "The Fighting Lady." Jack Smight, the film's director, and his editors also appear to repeat battle footage when it's really good. Maybe not, but it certainly seems that way.At many theaters, the film is being shown with sound effects in Sensurround, the system of low-frequency sound signals (used more effectively in "Earthquake") that are supposed to recreate the sense of the battle butheresimply annoy the ears. At the beginning of the movie, the producers warn that they will not be responsible for the audience's physical or emotional reactions to Sensurround. They say nothing about the audience's physical or emotional reactions to the movie itself. Producers aren't completely stupid.The film has been rated PG. It would be difficult to make a movie, even a bad one, about a battle like Midway and not show some violence or overhear some of the men using rude words to describe their occasional impatience.

title: Pupfish Upheld
description: The United States Supreme Court has unanimously decided to protect the right to survival of 200 or so pupfish in a Nevada caverneven if some nearby ranchers have to make do with a little less water. Invoking the legal principle of de minimis, the Justices might have held that these inchlong fish at Devil's Hole were indeed among those trifles with which the courts are not concerned. But they perceived, instead, that the disappearance of an animal species is not a trifle at alland still less so when a piece of Federal land has been devoted to its survival.

description: OMAHA, June 18 (AP) Ken Bolek rapped a tworun home run, and Steve Powers hurled a fourhitter tonight as Arizona eliminated Arizona State, 51, from the 30th College World Series.

description: WASHINGTON, June 18The growth in the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, is likely to slow substantially in the current quarter to considerably less than 5 percent on an annual basis, Government economists said today.

description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I., June 18  The parents and teachers at the Grace L. Hubbs School here decided to get together one last time, and they promised one another they wouldn't cry.

Instead of allowing the ballfield to be turned into a bank vault, he has voided the multimilliondollar deal that would have sent three Oakland A's stars to the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox. His reasoningthat the transaction was contrary to the best interests of baseballseems to be right in the strike zone.

Police officials conceded, however, that the actual toll was far higher. They stopped

Now the 57yearold Rockville Links player is trying to prove that he can still beat younger men, as he attempts to win his third Long Island amateur title.

title: The Nation
description: In their quest for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan have been paying an increasing amount of attention to a decreasing number of available delegates to their party's national convention. In all likelihood, they will not know the results of their efforts with certainty until the convention is held in August and perhaps not until the first ballot is taken.

title: Music Notes: The Visual Delights Of Mozart's Manuscripts

Installed in cases in the East Room of the Renaissance palazzo, the Mozart items summon up a host of reflections on the life, genius and industry of that composer.

title: Religion
description: Since Roger Williams, a religious fugitive from Massachusetts Bay Colony, founded the first Baptist Church in 1639 in Providence, R. I., Baptists have written a remarkable chapter into America's spiritual and cultural history.

title: Cornell Veterinary College Given Probationary Accreditation
description: The State College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University in Ithaca, long regarded as one of the best institutions of its kind in the country, has just been put on probation because of deficiencies in its physical facilities and an inadequate number of teachers.

title: Summer
description: Summer comes as quietly as sunrise. The solstice, which marks the midyear and the end of spring by the almanac, Is a solar calculation, not a change in the weather. The green leaf and the bright petal, which are the very essence of summer, will go about their business tomorrow with not so much as a whisper about change.

title: In Summary
description: The Ford Administration has continued to emphasize its intention to try to limit busing for the purpose of school desegregation, but significant distinctions between the President's approach to busing and that of Attorney General Edward H. Levi have begun to emerge.

title: Big, Shaggy and Loving
description: HEADS turn when Bucky struts along the streets of Summit. Sometimes, passersby blink twice for, although Bucky resembles a small pony, he is actually a dog known as a Bouvier des Flandres.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  An early version of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975 contemplated requiring industry to get Federal energyuse permits, with full public hearings where companies would have to justify their proposed energy consumption and show what they were doing to conserve.

title: 3 U.S. Tourists Die As Bus Overturns On Tour of England
description: GATWICK, England, June 19 (AP)A bus carrying 16 Americans, two Britons and a French national on a tour of historic sites related to the American Bicentennial skidded off a rainslick road and overturned in a ditch today. The police said that three American women were killed.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Rockefeller Center Inc. has agreed in principle to purchase the construction and research division of the Tishman Realty & Construction Company for $9.5 million, all cash.

title: Death Stalks Cult Of Hawaii Gliders
description: HONOLULU, June 19At certain seasons the north east trade winds beating steadily at about 20 knots against the 1,200foot sheer cliffs at the east end of the island of Oahu create a superb hangglider range, but for a group that followed a middleaged guru, it has been an ill wind that brought sorrow and death.

title: Big Bill Tilden
description: In 1916, when he was already 23 years old, William Tatem Tilden II was the 70thranked amateur tennis player in the United States. Given the small number of tournament players in those days, it was hardly a ranking at all. By 1920, at an age at which many sports careers are beginning to fade, he won the American and English titles. For the next five years he dominated world tennis, becoming a sports idol of the dimensions of Ruth, Grange and Dempsey.

title: The Democrats' (Read Carter's) Document Meets the Test; The Platform Art: Specific Is O.K., General Is Better
description: WASHINGTONPolitical parties write platforms for one reason: to win votes.

title: Assad and Giscard Back Lebanon Talk
description: PARIS, June 19The leaders of France and Syria agreed today on a need to organize peace negotiations in the Lebanese conflict to reconcile the warring factions and to work toward a political settlement.

title: Paperbacks
description: ANOTHER PART OF THE WOOD, by Kenneth Clark. (Ballantine, $2.25.) The first half of the life of one of Britain's most influential connoisseurs and bureaucrats of the arts: a deceptively offhand and selfdeprecating autobiography.

title: SociologistPriest Reported Detained By Yugoslav Police
description: Yugoslav authorities have detained the Rev. Lujobo Krasic, a Croatianborn Franciscan priest who became a permanent resident of the United States in 1974, and have ordered him not to speak to reporters, according to Dr. Sylvan Tomasi, director of the Center for Migration Studies here.

title: HOSPITAL TO OPEN A MATERNITY UNIT
description: MANHASSET, L.I. June 19At a time when many privat hospitals are closing their maternity operations, the North Shore University. Hospital here has unveiled its new 10story Payson Whitney Tower of Health to provide maternity and child care.

title: Baseball Crown To Whitman High
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 19Walt Whitman High School of South Huntington defeated Baldwin, 43, today and retained its Long Island scholastic baseball championship. The winning pitcher, Jim Walker, allowed 10 hits and raised his wonlost record over the last two seasons to 181.

title: Cathy Egan of CBS Wed in Larchmont
description: Ann Cathleen Egan, manager of marketing services of the CBS television stations division, was married yesterday afternoon to William H. Cronin 3d, an account executive with Summerfield Industries in New York.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The whole legend about Neil Simon has got to be upended. The legend grew in two stages. Stage one held that this sunniest, most productive, most successful, most Broadwayoriented of comic playwrights was, as a result of his television gagconference training, a master of what was scarcely worth mastering: extravagant situation comedy liberally laced with oneliners. Stage two softened the attitude a bit. It'd been noticed that every now and again during a Simon charade an honest observation, funny and yet not all that funny, might hit home and hit hard, that a flicker of despair, still funny and yet not all that funny, might cross the face of a figure we'd been thinking merely a cartoon. And so Simon came to be regarded as a man whose natural impulses led him to ask for a laugh at any price but who, when he tried hard enough, could rise a wee bit above himself. He could create something nearer people than parrots to deliver his yocks, could train his gags to attach themselves like creepers to the nearest solid, homely truth. But only if he tried hard enough, resisting the itches he was born with. In effect, we were praying that he would become less and less true to himself.
