title: But Hays Is Hardly Typical
description: WASHINGTONThe national preoccupation with sex has worked its way east from Hollywood and the flamboyant world of entertainers to Washington. Behind the institutional conservatism and professional piety of Congress, it has suddenly become clear, lurk at least some members with social habits that shock their constituents and some of their colleagues.

title: POLITICS
description: ALTHOUGH it no longer makes much difference view of the fact that his Presidential nomination now appears assured, Jimmy Carter actually won the popular vote in the Democratic Presidential primary in New Jersey, a contest he was supposed to have lost. True, the uncommitted forces supporting Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California won 83 of the state's 108 convention delegates. And that is what really counted.

title: Mission Employable
description: In an election year, the Ford Administration is under pressure to show its doing something about unemployment. And recently the Department of Labor gave preliminary approval for jobfinding programs like the experimental one originated by a behavioral psychologist in Carbondale, Ill., to be set up on a pilot basis in from three to five other U.S. cities.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: HOUSTON  John Bookout, the new president and chief executive of the Shell Oil Company, has, as they used to say in Vaudeville, a tough act to follow.

title: Commuters' Friend
description: A commuter may be confronted at any time with an unexpected problem that requires special services or hospital care. A heart attack or an accident may occur on the way to or from the office. Chances then are that the help will come from a United Fund agency. Last year one of every seven patients in a fund hospital was a commuter.

title: The Golden Shores of Heaven
description: Eighteenyearold Mary Curlew leaves her family in Baltimore and goes to Nashville alone, hoping to break into the Grand Ole Opry. Nashville is the golden shores of Heaven, and Heaven itself is the chance to sing there. The book begins when she steps off the plane and ends when she gets her first good job on a new country music variety show. Shades of Nashville!

title: Surf's Up, Jobs Aren't
description: JONES BEACH NINETY lifeguards rushed frantically toward the surf here last weekend and dived headlong into the breaking waves. But it wasn't to save livesit was to get jobs.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Naples: A Sort Of Homecoming
description: For those of us who grew up in the industrial towns of America's Northeast, Italy is part of our cultural heritage. No matter if our names were O'Brien or Jaroszewski, Rosenberg or Roberts, the Italian influence in our lives was pungent and flavorful, like tomato sauce with garlic.

title: DEMOCRATS SHIFT DELEGATE MAKEUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Women, blacks and young people will not be as well representedamong delegates to the Democratic National Convention in New York City next month as they were four years earlier in Miami Beach when a quota system was in effect.

title: New Playwrights Stir The British Stage
description: LONDON There is probably some very good sociological explanation as to why British playwriting is flourishing in the midst of the worst economic crisis since 1927, but I can't provide it. What is irrefutable is that, as the pound sinks and inflation rises, a bevyof new playwrights, many of them under 30, are delineating a vision of contemporary England as accurate and as exciting as the works of John Osborne and Arnold Wesker were in the mid1950's.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, June 19 (Reuters)India is building two new plants to recover plutonium from nuclear reactor waste: the press agency Samachar reported today.

title: Reflections of a Young Romantic
description: ISLESFORD, Me.When I was a kid I read Emily Bronte and believed every word. While other children gobbled Cheerios and watched the Mickey Mouse Club, I was fed on sterner stuff: oatmeal and Edgar Allan Poe. My parents didn't approve of television, so we didn't have one, except on special occasions: We rented a set during elections and assassinations. The rest of the year we read. Every night my father read aloud while Mother, my sister and I embroidered.

title: The truth about sex in Washington
description: At a certain time I traveled extensively with a man who wanted to be President of the United States. He was known in Washington as an outrageous Don Juan, a lover so ardent that no woman was safe in the same city with him. The truth was that he was not a lover of women. but a consumer. Women were brought to his quarters in the wretched morning hours after a day's campaigning and ejected 15 minutes later.

title: A New Kind of Mountie To Patrol Airport Range
description: COVINGTON, Ky., June 19 (AP)A new kind of mounted policeman will be swinging into the saddle and riding across the rangeriding the fences, looking for bad guys and trying to keep out of the way of airplanes.

title: A Landmark Designation Asked for Eastern Parkway
description: Borough President Sebastian Leone, describing Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn as fulfilling the high hopes of its famous designers, Frederick Olmstead and Calvert Vaux, has called on the Landmarks Preservation Commission to designate the parkway as a scenic landmark.

title: Swedish Monarch Marries German as 150,000 Turn Out
description: STOCKHOLM, June 19The King of Sweden, Carl XVI Gustaf, married the daughter of a West German businessman to day and gave his 8 million countrymen a weekend of lighthearted pomp and entertainment.

title: Arms Cache Found, Jamaica Declares State of Emergency
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 19 (AP)A state of emergency was declared in Jamaica today after Prime Minister Michael Manley warned of a planned escalation of violence and the army reported the discovery of an arms cache.

title: Kate Furtnett Bride of Air Force Officer
description: In the Vassar College Chapel in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Kathleen Furtnett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Joseph Furtnett of Fishkill, N. Y., became the bride of First Lieut. John Richard Flavin of the Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Flavin of St. Louis.

title: Pucker Up, Yale Says, And Get Mononucleosis
description: NEW HAVEN (UPI)infectious mononucleosis, often called the kissing disease, is indeed spread by kissing, according to researchers at Yale University.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT in 1972 dollars rose by an 8.7 percent annual rate to a figure of $1,241.8 billion, in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said, instead of 8.5 percent reported earlier in May. But government economists said the increase for the current quarter might be well under 5 percent .... Corporate aftertax profits in the first quarter Increased $5.8 billion to a seasonally adjusted, annual rate of $85.7 billion. This follows a rise of $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter of 1975.... The United States balance or payments on current account showed a deficit of $80 million as compared with a surplus of $2.09 billion in the fourth quarter of 1975, and an average quarterly surplus of $2.9 billion in all of 1975.

title: Hoboken ReEnacts 1846 Ball Game
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Some 19 (AP)The only thing missing from today's recreation of the first regularly played baseball game in America was a 6cent fine for cursing.

title: Parley Set On Economy
description: TRENTON THE New JerseyManufacturers Association contends that the state will not fully recover from the depths of the recession until answers are found to some major problems. According to the association, acceptable legislative solutions must be fund to the problems that have contributed most to New Jersey's inability to join the national economic recovery, a situation that has left the state lagging far behind.

title: Patricia White Wed To W. W. Friend 3d
description: Patricia Dean White, daughter of Dorothy Dean White of Brewster. Mass., and Frederic P. White of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday afternoon in Brewster to Waiter William Friend 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Friend Jr. of South Norwalk, Conn.

title: Radio
description: A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Address by Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg of Congregation Mishkan Israel, Hamden, Conn.

title: 200Meter Bettered by More Than a Second
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 19The Olympic trials swimming competition swept past its midway point at the Belmont Plaza pool tonight, with men's and women's 200meter backstroke and butterfly finals taking the program through 14 of the scheduled 22 events in the sixday meet.

title: The Best Years
description: When Fonzie was still in swaddling clothes, when Eisenhower was the hope of the future, when Dr. Kinsey's statistics shocked peoplewas that the Age of Lost Innocence that historianarcheologists have been looking for? Ever since Frederick Lewis Allen popularized instant nostalgia in Only Yesterday, the near past has been the Atlantis of social historians. Was that blessed time Allen'sand Scott Fitzgerald's and Calvin Coolidge's1920's or was it the 1930's of Walker Evans, Busby Berkeley, and Franklin D. Roosevelt? Joseph C. Goulden offers an entry as bold and engaging as its title, The Best Years: 19451950.

title: Reagan Aides Borrowing Ford's Electability Issue
description: SPOKANE, Wash., June 19Ronald Reagan's agents are telling the last few wavering Republican delegates that if President Ford is renominated he will lose as badly as Barry Goldwater did in 1964.

title: Dragons In the Waters
description: There is enough adventure in Dragons in the Waters to make Nancy Drew and her chums squirm: a shipboard murder that could have been committed by any one of the passengers or crew; a kidnapping; an attack by a wild boar: a young boy lost in the Venezuelan jungle. . . . And much more.

title: A Suit Tomorrow In Finley vs. Kuhn
description: Joe Rudi, at least, was happy even if everybody else in baseball was up in amid yesterday. The World Seried hero of the Oakland A's, still unsigned and apparently untraded, watched the great controversy gathering around him and said: My family is all here, we have a home here, I'm happy to stay here.

title: Lawrenceville Church Honors
description: THE memory of Raymond Hamill Nassau, a pioneering medical missionary who founded the African mission station where Dr. Albert Schweitzer built his celebrated hospital, was honored last week at a ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The ordering period for the fifth and final twomedal unit in the U.S. Mint's 10piece America's First Medals series is under way. The Revolutionary War heroes commemorated in this last issue (see accompanying illustrations) are Gen. Nathanael Greene for his leadership in the signal victory achieved by American forces in the Battle of Eutaw Springs, S.C., in 1781; and Capt. John Paul Jones for his brilliant command of French and American ships off the British coast in 1779. Both medals were engraved by the noted French artist, Augustin Dupr.

title: Yanks Win, 43Alexander Victor
description: CHICAGO, June 19  As last night, Vida Blue did not pitch for the Yankees against the Chicago White Sox tonight. Ken Holtzman was Vida Blue last night. Doyle Alexander was Vida Blue tonight.

title: Sheryl Diane Backst Wed to Stuart Meddin
description: Sheryl Diane Backst, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Backst of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday evening at the St. Regis Roof to Stuart Levkoff Meddin of Atlanta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman J. Meddin of Charleston, S. C. Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Temple BethEl in Great Neck performed the ceremony.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: New Soviet Weapon Puts Muscle in Athletic Affairs
description: MOSCOWHot tea in a glass and cremefilled pastries were waiting on the table for Olga Morozova. But first the Soviet Union's No. 1 woman tennis player had to undergo the last of 20 electrical muscle stimulation treatments she received in preparation for next week's Wimbledon championships.

title: Education
description: It is a quirk of the American educational system, which grows increasingly competitive as children get older, that lauds kindergarteners for cooperating to solve a problem, but condemns West Point cadets for cheating when they collaborate on a takehome examination.

title: YankOriole Rosters Hazy After Trade
description: CHICAGO, June 19The machine gunlike developments that engulfed the Yankees this week were stunning enough. Consider, then, the bizarre scene that was played out in the lobby of the Executive House Hotel here early Thursday morning. The Yankees, arriving from Minneapolis for a series with the White Sox, collided with the Baltimore Orioles, staying overnight after a series with the White Sox before moving on to Texas.

title: Painting Contractor Arrested on Charge Of Defrauding City
description: A paint contractor who had done business with New York City was arrested Friday on charges of defrauding city agencies with forged documents in a $62,000 scheme.

title: Rehiring Ordered For 233 Firemen In New York City
description: The Fire Department plans to rehire 233 dismissed city firemen next month under an overtimereducing plan approved on Friday by the Beame administration, Fire Department officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Physicians (and Lawyers), Heal Thyselves
description: MEDICAL MALPRACTICE claims and suits are increasing at an alarming rate. Doctors lay the blame at the feet of lawyers and insurance companies. Lawyers blame doctors and insurance companies. Among the causes of the malpractice dilemma are the following:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Major Federal and state beaches in Suffolk County that had reopened yesterday morning after a fourday ban on swimming were closed again later in the day due to new pollution problems.

title: Caryl J. Snapperman Married to Surgeon
description: Caryl Jane Snapperman, daughter of Joan Snapperman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Herman Snapperman, was married last evening in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., to Dr. G. Tames Avery 2d. He is the son of Mrs. Henry T. Field of Ridgefield, Conn., and Gaylord J. Avery of New York.

title: Eunice Mallory Jennings Bride of John Gambrill
description: Eunice Mallory Jennings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Jennings of Byram, Conn., was married yesterday to John Larner Gambrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamer M. Gambrill of McLean, Va.

title: Life With Seven Fathers
description: DIGNITY, courage and compassion are the qualities that Richard J. Hughes, Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, recalls most vividly when he thinks about his father, whose portrait hangs in his chambers.

title: Miss Relihan Bride Of Edward T. Porter
description: Elizabeth Allen Relihan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Relihan Jr. of Delmar, N.Y., was married in Saratoga Springs. N.Y., yesterday afternoon to Edward Thomas Porter, son of Mrs. William J. Spears Jr. of Winchester, Mass.

title: McClure Resigns Post
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 19 (AP)Bill McClure, the University of South Carolina head track coach, resigned his post today with the Gamecocks to take a similar position with Louisiana State University.

title: Mixed Outlook for the Bugs of Summer
description: WHERE'S the bug spray? Haven't you fixed the hole in the front door screen yet? When are they going to do something about those insects?

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Essex Probation Officers Critical of Dean Irving

title: Book Ends
description: Kearns. After all the publicity surrounding her attempt to change publishers in midwriting of Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream, how does Doris Kearns feel now that her book is actually out? Relieved, she said recently at a luncheon held by Harper & Row, the publisher she ended up with after the dust settled (Basic Books, a subsidiary of Harper & Row was the original claimant of the MS.; Simon & Schuster was the disappointed suitor to whom Miss Kearns and Richard Goodwin brought a proposition for a supposedly new book; Mr. Goodwin has since married Miss Kearns, even though their literary collaboration was torpedoed by the lawyers and so did not emerge from the affair emptyhanded; read on). The reviews have been good and Miss Reams is gratified that they concentrated on the book rather than her personal life. She also gave the back of her hand in advance to any speculations about her relationship with Lyndon Johnson (this was before Wayne Hays made relationship a double entendre), mentioning that she had sent a copy of the book to Mrs. Johnson and receivea a wellwishing letter in return.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS' CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe American Dream and The Lesson. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Decade of Rhythms Exemplified in Jazz By New Ramblers
description: A band called the New California Ramblers might be expected to follow the path of other dance bands of the past, such as the Glenn Miller and Tommy Dorsey orchestras, and devote itself to the arrangements of its sourcethe California Ramblers, a band of the 1920's whose personnel included Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey and Red Nichols.

title: 143 Die in Bangladesh Flood
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 19 (Reuters)Bangladesh has reported that at least 143 persons died in floods and landslides after torrential monsoon rains.

title: New & Novel
description: One of the countless corpses in this lovely book is dropped into a pool of giant eels in Rabat, hence the zingy title. Other cadavers turn up in various conditions in Britain, France, Germany, Kenyaall the work of one fantastic superkiller, whose weapons range from a razor blade to a buzz saw. What this character wants is to launch a billion dollar Ponzitype scheme, world wide, to finance his antipollution crusade. (Irony is part of Ivor Drummond's formidable equipment.) Nothing is going to stand in the of Fritz von Cernogratzexcept Lady Jennifer (Jenny) Norrington, Count Allessandro (Sandro) di Ganzarelio, and Coleridge (Coity) Tucker III. Jenny, Sandro and Colly are a trio of enforcers whom Mr. Drummond has concocted out of moonbeams and a terrific sense of action. After thwarting a gigantic heroin deal, they are on the tail of the incredible Cernogratz without taking a deep breath. But breathless is what you will be as you follow this neoBondian chase from one pipe dream into another. A great trip.

title: CHESS
description: There is a tendency to letup when you are winning, but you have to fight it or the victory can slip through your fingers. This complacency is most likely to arise after you have come through a sharp struggle with a decisive advantage that you wrongly feel should win.

title: Reds Halt Phils, 43, on Perez's Sacrifice
description: PHILADELPHIA. June 19 (UPI)Dave Concepcion got three hits, scored a run and drove in one today to help the Cincinnati Reds and Gary Nolan post a 4.3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in a nationally televised game between the National League division leaders.

title: Coffee and Carnations
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaThe world coffee boom, which has raised Colombia's foreign reserves to record levels, is stimulating bold changes in economic policy here.

title: Rock Goes SouthBack to Where It All Began
description: ATLANTA They call themselves The Little Ol' Band from Texas but that's only Lone Star modesty. Little, no; Texas, yes.

title: For City Slickers Who Seek Farmer Chic
description: DENVER, June 8Call it farmer chic. The new youthfashion fad fanning out across the country these days is the baseballstyle farmer cap adorned with the logo of a tractor, seed, dairy or beer company right above the bill.

title: Carter Bids Men of Faith Take Greater Public Role
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 19In a sermonic speech today, Jimmy Carter said that a separation of church and state should not dictate a separation of public and private morality.

title: The World Is Their Campus
description: AT many schools, last Sunday was a day for caps and gowns and folding chairs under a relentless sun, for phrases about the promise of youth and the hope of the future. But in Lloyd Harbor the talk was of mindscapes, ecosystems and planet stewardship.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: H. Ripley Ross and Anthony H. Drury were married yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Richard F. Kuenkler of the United Ministry of Aurora (N. Y.) Church performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Mark C. Sullivan, assistant rector of St. Paul's.

title: FourMaster From Chile Is Called Torture Ship
description: The fourmasted barquentine Esmeralda, Chile's envoy to Operation Sail, has become the object of protests here by groups charging that political prisoners were tortured aboard the ship after a military coup. overthrew President Salvador Allende in 1973.

title: Dance: Sophie Maslow
description: Isolated atypical photographs can give the impression that all sports contests are really ballets manques, and nothing could be further from the truth. Sophie Maslow, a choreographer with a keen eye, decided to extract scores of such moments from a variety of sports and really turn them into a dance, which she did quite successdully in Decathalon Etude.

title: SCHOOL HEADS GIVE FORD BUSING VIEWS
description: WASHINGTON. June 19 (UPI) President Ford heard views for and against busing as a remedy for school desegregation from school superintendents and principals today.

title: Rising Out of the Rubble, Green Things Are Growing Among the City's. Canyons
description: Just a year ago, it was a scene from a nightmare of decaying cities: a vacant lot on the Lower East Side, filled with the debris of the life going on around it. Broken bottles, bedsprings, rubber tiresand bricks, lots of bricks.

title: Cabinet School Post Backed
description: ATLANTA, June 19 (UPI) Jimmy Carter said today that there should be a separate Cabinet department for education to focus the attention of the nation on the need for increased emphasis on education.

title: STAMPS
description: Canada has issued a dramatic set of three commemoratives to usher in the 1976 Olympic Games, the first ever held in that country and only the fourth ever held in North America.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: TRENTON AFTER a good bit of effort over the last several years, the Legislature has passed a bill what will allow motorists to make right turns against red lights.

title: New York City Council Gives Week's Schedule
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Findings Scanty on Impact Of Busing on School Work
description: The future of busing as an instrument of school desegregation has come under political challenge at a time when experts agree that there is still a glaring lack of information against which to assess the educational impact of busing.

title: A Farewell to New York's 470Pound Trash Cans
description: It had taken two years of search and research, so the hopes were high in the summer of '72 when New York City announced it was replacing its wire mesh litter containers with a new modela 470pound concrete hexagonal chunk of pop sculpture.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Section 8 Program

title: A Lag in School Desegregation Is Shown by Federal Statistics
description: WASHINGTON, June 19There has been little change in the high levels of school segregation of black children in the 1970's, and pupils from Spanishspeaking backgrounds have become increasingly segregated across the nation. according to Government figurea released here today.

title: 1976 Summer Theater Straw Hat Directory
description: New York City

title: Jumper Title to Landau
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 19It was just three years ago that Doug Landau nervously climbed on a horse for the first time. Winning championships was an idea that hadn't struck him yet. He merely wanted to stay on the horse.

title: Somber Warning
description: Rioting in black communities around Johannesburg, and harsh governmental countermeasures which the United Nations Security Council by unanimous consensus vigorously condemned yesterday, should dispel whatever doubts may have remained about the practical as well as the moral impossibility of maintaining African enclaves founded on apartheid.

title: Nina Elisabeth Rothschild Engaged
description: Nina Elisabeth Rothschild, who graduated last week from Harvard College, and John David Larkin of Washington, producer and director of Martin Agronsky's Evening Edition on the Public Broadcasting System, plan to be married July 24.

title: Connors, Nastase Split Prize in Rain
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 19 (AP)Jimmy Connors and Ilie Nastase clowned and slid on a wet grass tennis court in the rain for more than an hour today before the Nottingham tournament final was abandoned. It was the last tuneup for Wimbledon, which starts tomorrow.

title: Financing Candidates
description: AS a recent but unsuccessful candidate for public officeChosen FreeholderI observed firsthand just how countywide political campaigns in Bergen County work and how funds are raised and spent to elect candidates.

title: Woman On the Edge Of Time
description: Marge Piercy writes polemics. She also writes novels, and her latest, Woman on the Edge of Time, is a long novel. It is hard to write good polemical fiction, and a good long polemical novel is almost impossible. Polemics usually reduce themselves to stances and arguments, and fiction thus reduced tends to be nagging, repetitive, clogged, staged. It does not help Piercy's new novel, either, that the major instruments of her polemic are terribly familiar pieces of apparatus, the mental hospital and a utopian community of the future. For all these reasons, Woman on the Edge of Time is not really a successful novel. But despite these drawbacks, it is far from being a bad book, and, once it gets under way, it is both absorbing and exciting.

title: Police Likely to Toughen Congress Arrest Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The police here are expected to abandon soon their 100yearold departmental policy that allows members of Congress involved in certain alleged criminal violations to be released under a socalled Congressional immunity clause of the Constitution.

title: Births
description: Auerbach

title: The author: A daring Soviet satirist
description: When I last saw Vladimir Voinovich in Moscow, he was a man tormented by a ludicrous struggle over an apartmentthe kind of imbroglio that he uses so deftly in his writing. Voinovich is probably the most popular dissident writer still active in Moscow. To meet him, or to read his prose in the comfort of a Western living room, is to underestimate his daring. He projects a calm air of independence, a sturdy comewhatmay stoicism in the face of official pressures to silence him. He is a humorist whose essential dissidence is irreverent candor and mocking exposure of official foibles and hypocrisy. If we really had a free press, one Russian remarked to me, Voinovich would he a best seller, more popular than Solzhenitsyn. His early plays, songs and stories demonstrated popular appeal before he ran afoul of the System.

title: Rare Harmony . . .
description: After its feverish internal confrontations in 1968 and 1972and the defeats that ensuedthe Democratic Party now seems bent on victory through consensus. Not only have Governor Carter's opponents all but unanimously closed ranks to concede his nomination, but the party has produced a platform with a lack of friction that has no recent precedent.

title: GARDENING
description: POISON IVY may fool you. It likes to grow along fence rows and rock walls, often mixing with other shrubby or vining plans in such a way that it is not noticeable.

title: Parking Lot Speed Law
description: ALBANY, June 19 (UPI)Governor Carey signed bills yesterday giving cities, towns and villages power to set speed limits for shopping center parking lots. The amendment to the vehicle and traffic law gives (towns even wider authority, allowing them to set speed limits in hospital and apartment complex parking lots as well. The slowest limit allowed would be 15 miles an hour, the law says. and property owners would have to request it.

George Conway, chaplain at the Hotchkiss School there. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. William Conway of WilkeaBarre, Pa., and the late Mr. Conway.

title: Revolution in Silicon Valley
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.The low, rectangular factories and laboratories proliferate on what used to be orchard land around here. It seems like an unlikely place to start a revolution.

title: ...On Platform Goals
description: More important than specifics In the document are the goalsand these are clear. Without endorsing particular legislation like the HawkinsHumphrey fullemployment bill, the platform fully accepts the objective of reducing the adult employment rate to 3 percent within the next four years and otherwise revitalizing the economy.

title: Julia Caldwell Plans July Nuptials
description: Julia Whayne Caldwell, who received a master's degree last month from the University of Kentucky School of Nursing, and John Albert Morris Jr., a member of the class of at the university's medical school, plan to be married in Louisville, Ky., on July 10. The ceremony will take place in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

description: Wendy Paige Bernhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Bernhard of Chappaqua, NLY., and Michael David Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Edwards Of St. Louis, were married last evening by the Rev. Jack Miller in the Mount Kisco (N.Y.) Presbyterian

title: Miss Almy Bride of Rev. J. C. Ransom
description: In the chapel of St. John Baptist School in Mendham, N.J., yesterday morning, Deborah Almy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Almy of Mendham, became the bride of the Rev. James C. Ransom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Ransom of Norfolk. Neb.

title: Atlantic Is Bulging With Racing Ships
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 19The expected congestion of ships in the Atlantic Ocean between here and Newport sometime in the next two clays is a onceonly coincidence. Three different yacht races, each with distinctive sponsors, purposes and participants, happened to be scheduled for the same time, and two of the fleets seem certain to touch, the ocean racers coming down from Newport and the Tall Ships heading northeast to that Rhode Island port.

title: Ripley Ross Bride Of Anthony Drury
TV VIEW
description: The New Consciousness gets an hour of primetime TV on NBC this Tuesday night from 10 to 11 P.M. What is the New Consciousness? Well, the producers of The Search for Something Else, Joan Konner and Bill Turque, have had to be rather arbitrary about defining it. It consists, they have decided, of various techniques and disciplines, many of them new to Western culture, by which millions of disappointed Americans are seeking beyond the American Dream to find the power within themselves to lead happier, healthier lives, a blend of old and new, east and west, science and psychology, philosophy and physics.

title: Miss Lincoln Is Bride of W.H. Seidman
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Carroll Lincoln, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dix Lincoln Jr. of Highland Park, N. J., to William Henry Seidman wok place yesterday at the Helen Hills Chapelon the Smith College campus in Northampton, Mass. The bridegroom is the son of Richard L. Seidman of South Norwalk. Conn., and the late Mrs. Seidman.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: I am not an expert on nuclear fission, and I know experts who are optimistic about it. Yet I am not sure at all that scientific expertise can fully answer the fission dilemma.

title: Bowie on a Long Limb
description: It would be a pleasure to picture Bowie Kuhn as a knight in shining armor riding up on a white swivel chair to save baseball from dishonor but the pastperformance charts discourage this view. The pastperformance charts indicate that the baseball commissioner says and does what his employers tell him to say and do, and it follows from this that when he padlocked Charley Finley's flesh emporium he was acting under orders. It is 17 to 5 that some of the more influential club owners such as Walter O'Malley had to lean on him before he declared the sale of Vida Blue, Joe Rudi and Rollie Fingers null, void and nux vomica.

title: Ratner's Star
description: Don DeLillo's first three books had the feel of novels straining to be something else, of energies out of their element, tadpoles in a cocoon. If what novelists did was to round characters, set scenes and plot consequences, DeLillo was willing, but he did not seem happy doing it. He seemed happiest when careening off into a detour.

title: GOLDIN FORESEES AN OPSAIL DEFICIT
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that Operation Sail on July 4 would cost the city at least $1.4 million for extra police, sanitation and other services without any return from concessionaires, who stood to reap hundreds of thousands in profit.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: For years now the Gillette Company and its competitors in the shaving gear game have been operating on a very simple marketing principle: practically give away razors at comparatively low prices in the hope you can hook the customer into coming back year after year with repeat business for high priced blades.

title: TavernontheGreen, Closed for 2 Years, to Reopen in August
description: The Tavern ontheGreen, which for 42 years has stood in Central Park just off West 67th Street, most recently as a fading monument to a tradition of expensive dining, dancing and romancing, is scheduled to reopen in August at the completion of a $2.5 million reconstruction program.

title: Konrad Perlman to Wed Miss Davidoff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Davidoff of Freeport, L,I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Norma Tila Davidoff, to Konrad J. Perlman of Washington. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander K. Perlman of Pine Plains. N.Y. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: Notes: Is the Zany Newscast A Threat to the Real Thing?
description: Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, the syndicated satirical soap opera conceived by Norman Lear, has borne a bouncy offspring on KTTV, Los Angeles, named MetroNews, MetroNews. The new arrival may be a bundle of joy to some Southern California viewers, but it has professional journalists on edge because it threatens to spawn a new breed of newscasts in local television.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: To halt an identification crisis that Federal and state governments say costs them at least $20 billion a year in illegalimmigration fraud and other abuses, a Justice Department study group has proposed the coordination of birth and death certificates on an interstate basis.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Notes: Hightway Sculpture
description: A 455mile sculpture garden stretchtog practically all the way across Nebraska will be unveiled as the state's salute to the Bicentennial on July fourth.

title: STATE BAR VOTES A FEELISTING BAN
description: The New York State Bar Association, in a surprise move, voted yesterday not to accept its committee's recommendation that lawyers be allowed to publish their fees for an initial consultation.

title: Messengers Of God
description: Elie Wiesel's claim on everyone's attention was absolute for a time. He had two subjects only, the martyrdom of the European Jews and its effect on one Jew who survived, arrested perpetually in adolescence by his sudden overpowering vision of evil. Esthetic considerations, wrongly but understandably. seemed out of place in responding to Wiesel's work. Framed in a parable but grounded in the wellknown facts, his retelling of the story of that young boy's peaceful village, wiped from the face of the earth, demanded an effort to be taken on its own terms in order that its value of pure pain could be received.

title: Viking Orbits Mars
description: The Viking 1 spacecraft went into orbit around Mars about 7 P.M. yesterday after a 10month journey from Earth, thus setting the stage for a landing attempt July 4, [Page 24.]

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Many commercial photographers admit that the number of wedding bookings they have been receiving has been falling off in recent yearsprimarily because today's youth often prefer less formal ceremonies and receptions and, as part of this informality, are often willing to take their chances with having a friend take the desired pictures. Some do this because they thus hope for a less formalized approach, but others like the savings that obviously result from having a photographerfriend (who will normally only charge for the actual materials used) serve as the official photographer for the affair.

title: Arielle A. Wolflisberg Married At Yale to Emerson Miller Jr.
description: Arielle Amalie Wolflisberg and Emerson Huxley Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Cincinnati, were married at noon yesterday in the Dwight Hall Chapel of Yale University.

title: Main Road to America
description: THE land is filled with talk of suburbia, the Negro, the conservation of water, the pollution of air and streams, the need for colleges, the alarm over expanding populations, the need to reapportion legislatures, the perplexing question of taxes, the nagging worries over deteriorating cities. These are problems or challenges, depending on point of view. Naturally, New Jersey is much involved, for its position as the most urban state in the land makes all of these matters agonizingly acute.

title: Newport Festival Comes to Sussex
description: STANHOPE THE Newport Jazz Festival will cross the Hudson River for the first time next weekend, when it will present three programs at Waterloo Village, the recreated Colonial settlement in this Sussex County community. And if the expectations of George Wein, producer of the festival, and of the New Jersey Jazz Society, which introduced Mr. Wein to the setting provided by Waterloo, are realized, the stale will have a regular place in the festival in the ahead.

title: PRETORIA REGIME ASSAILED AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19The Security Council adopted unanimously today a resolution that strongly condemns the Smith African Government for its use of massive violence against black Africans.

title: U.S. Military Aid to Zaire Is Expected to Increase Because of Soviet and Cuban Roles in Other Countries.
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 19 Zaire, uneasy about Soviet and Cuban assistance in neighboring Angola, is due to receive a substantial increase of American arms, according to Western diplomats here.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The least known but in some ways the most interesting photographs in the large exhibition of Edward Steichen's work now at the Helios Gallery are a group of family portraits taken in the years just before the United States entered World War I. Steichen's 1916 portraits of his 12yearold daughter Marylater to become Dr. Mary S. Calderone, the authority on birth controlare curiously modern, both in their straightforward style and in their penetrating analysis of character.

title: No F.B.I. Needed to Pick Veep
description: Jimmy Carter says he won't ask the F.B.I. to run background checks on his potential running mates, and here's hoping Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan won't either. This country needs less, not more, F.B.I. snooping and interference in its politics.

title: David Is Sidelined By Slumping Toros
description: Steve David, the North American Soccer League's most valuable player last year, has been placed on the reserve squad by the Miami Toros. David, who also led the league in scoring with 23 goals last season, has a total output of one goal this year on a team that is doing just as badly.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a paragraph in a story in last Sunday's Week in Review, by Francis X. Clines, appeared incorrectly. The paragraph should have read: A comparable remark last week in the Carey inner circle related to the purity of Mr. Beame's austerity motives. It came from an aide who said, I still suspect Beams talks to Cavanagh regularly. He referred to former First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh, the Mayor's longtime aide and confidant who was purged into private life last winter as a symbol of alleged loose budgeting. The remark, coming in the midst of the austerity drive, was tantamount to suggesting that the hero in a temperance play was still into demon rum.

title: Devereux Powell of Y.W.C.A. Married to John Temple Swing
description: Devereux Loy Powell, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Wilbur F. Powell of Ojai, Calif., was married yesterday afternoon in Easton, Conn., to John Temple Swing. He is the son of the late Raymond Gram Swing of Washington, a widely known radio news commentator of the 1930's and 40's, and of the late Betty Gram Swing, a suffagist and feminist leader.

title: Unauthorized Aircraft Banned During OpSail
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has announced a ban on all unauthorized aircraft flights over the city's harbor area during Operation Sail on July 3 and July 4.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayStaten Island K.C. allbreed and obedience. Parade Grounds, Fort Wadsworth; 1,429 doss; 9 A.M.

title: Bomb Blast in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, June 19 (AP) A small bomb exploded in the Old City of Jerusalem today, seriously wounding an Arab resident, the Israeli police said. They said the bomb had been placed in a public restroom on David Street, one of Jerusalem's main thoroughfares.

title: The Rule on Teaching of Afrikaans Was a Kind of Last Straw
description: An American trying to puzzle out the reasons for the bloodiest riots in South Africa's recent history wondered why the Pretoria Government bothered with the regulation that sparked the trouble: a rule that schools for blacks teach partly in Afrikaans, the Dutchdescended language of the dominant white group. When the situation is sensitive anyway, it Was asked, why do they do something so provocativeand so unnecessary?

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed In order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, June 20, 1976

title: Last Week's Tax Package Is a Necessary Beginning
description: Can money insure a quality public school education? New Jersey cleared one major hurdle last week toward providing an education, quality or otherwise, when the state Senate, under the severe pressure of a courtordered closing of the state's 2,500 public schools on July 1 unless they were constitutionally funded, ended its long resistance to an income tax.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: DURING the building boom in the decade after World War II, when housing developments mushroomed throughout the urban and suburban counties within easy commuting distance of New York and Philadelphia, many of the moderately priced homes of that day were built with asbestos shingle siding on the outside.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on foreign militaryaid authorization oill, which passed, 62 to 18, June 14.

title: New Burlington
description: According to John Baskin, the author or editor of this work, his book, is a history of the distance between two points. One assumes those points to be the founding, in the 17th century, of New Burlington, Ohio, a farming village whose population never exceeded a few hundred, and the present day, when nothing but streets and sidewalks remain of the village, and water backs up in its direction from a dam built by the Army Corps of Engineers. Anybody looking for moral indignation at progress, as it is called, vilification of the Corps of Engineers, or any other form of easy modern protest, may as well look elsewhere. There are no more villains, Baskin says in his introduction, as there were in the days the villagers have come to revere, when people lived by the Bible, when hard work was a virtue, and a day of it measured by available sun; when articles, made mostly by hand, were made to last, and pride was taken in craftsmanship.

title: Buddhist Group to Help Spark the 4th
description: A Buddhist organization tha had its origins in Japan will play a major part in New York City's Bicentennial program on the Fourth of July weekend.

title: The Time Had Come and Gehrig, Unable to Help, Benched Himself
description: Long before his teammates and the public notice an athlete detects signals that he is beginning to slip. It begins ever so slightly in the legs: He still gets the hits, but he knows. And Lou, despite his curt words, despite his rationalizing, began to detect that something was slipping from his control. His arms were weakening and his coordination was off, too.

title: Unveilings
description: BRATMAN David Sunday, 27 June. 1976, at 10 A.M., Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N. J. Block 14, lot 74, section A. Grave 2.

title: The Autobiography Of My Mother
description: In her ingenious book of short stories, Street Games, Rosellen Brown explored the anxieties of the residents of a Brooklyn block. It was an impressive work, containing several O. Henry Awardwinning stories. Brown's characters are refugees from other places: Puerto Rico, Eastern Europe, or earthquaked San Francisco. They are people familiar with assault, the victims and perpetrators of burglaries, the welfare workers and welfare recipients, the fast talkers and marks into which Brown's urban population is divided. She writes the way neurotics talk, and in a wide range of ethnic dialects.

title: Menton Trophy To Towson State
description: BALTIMORE, June 19 (AP) Towson State College has won the Menton Trophy, symbolic of the allsports championship of the MasonDixon Intercollegate Conference, for the 197576 year.

title: PEOPLE
description: E. Merle Hitldreth, a Milltown resident who has been aspociated with the Boy Scout movement for 50 years, has received the Silver Acorn Award of the Scout Association of Great Britain. The award was presented by Sir William Gladstone, Chief Scout of Great Britain, at Windsor Castle in England. Mr. Hildreth, who served in scouting posts in several Eastern states, has been a staff member of the Boy Scouts of America

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: A COUPLE of the canoe trails through the reeds of the Hacken!sack Meadowlands already have been opened, construction of nature trails will soon begin and the ecological uplift of some of the tiny tidal basins within the preserve continues apace.

title: U.S. HELP SOUGHT FOR LATIN EXILES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19The leading organizations in the United States concerned with helping refugees have appealed to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to initiate a campaign to rescue thousands of refugees in Argentina.

title: BRIDGE
description: Alan Truscott and Dorothy Hayden Truscott have each enjoyed distinguished careers as writers about contract bridge ar_d as tcurnament players of high international rank.

title: Constance B. Murphy Wed to Oliver Mading
description: Constance Boyer Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wilson Murphy Jr. of Madison, N.J., and Oliver Mading, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldemar L. Mading of Short Hills, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Donald S. Bachtell performed the ceremony at the Madison Presbyterian Church.

title: Conflict of Interest, Clear Yet Fuzzy
description: WASHINGTONThe Federal law on conflict of interest in Government is complex, but the underlying principles are of Biblical simplicity: No man can serve two masters (Matthew 6:24) and Abstain from all appearance of evil (I Thessalonians 5:22).

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: REPRESENTAT I V E Jerome A. Ambro, Democrat of East Northport, surrenders his chairmanship of he New Members Caucus this week, ending a sixmonth tour in which the freshmen settled into traditional legislative roles and lost some of their reputation as wildeyed reformers. Most are concentrating these days on reelection.

title: How to Make a New County
description: Before a new county can be brought into being in New York, two steps must be taken and one population requirement must be met.

title: Future of State Agency Weighed
description: TRENTON ALEGISLATIVE committee that is preparing to consider measures designed to break up the state government's biggest department has received a detailed report that outlines all the pros and cons of the proposals.

title: Letters: On Losing A Passport Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: For Both Parties, A Summer Of Discontent
description: FACTIONALIZATION, a state of disarray on which Democrats once had an apparent monopoly, has increasingly become a bipartisan characteristic of Suffolk County politics.

title: 13 MERCENARIES OFFER APOLOGIES
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 19Thirteen mercenaries told the Angolan Peoples Revolutionary Court today that they were sorry.

title: Shipping /Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Conservative Intellectual Movement in America
description: The Second World War effectively pulled the plug on American conservatisma mercy killing if ever there was one, for the patient hadn't shown any vital signs since before the Great Depression. Through the 1930's and up to Pearl Harbor it was kept artificially alive on a thin diet of isolationism and reactionary economics, both of which vanished as suddenly as the Pacific Fleet. This is not to say that Harry Hopkins, who affected the American right like a shot of adrenalin straight to the heart, couldn't still provoke an occasional spasm. But that was just about all.

title: Heading for
description: A floodtide of visitorsestimates run as high as 5 millionwill engulf New York City over the July 4th weekend, drawn by the Bicentennial extravaganza called Salute 76. The lure is hard to resist: an international procession of warships and sailing vessels . . a fireworks display ... a giant fair ... parades. The challenge for the visitor will be how to chart a smooth course through the crowds.

title: Ballots And Bullets
description: The voters of Italy will take part in an election today and tomorrow that could produce a profound change in the course of postWorld War II European history. For the first time since the war's end, a Communist Party in a major Western European nation stands a good chance of becoming a governing party through victory at the ballot box.

title: Jailing of 2 Americans in Nigeria Sets Off New AntiU.S. Suspicion
description: LAGOS. Nigeria, June 19A bizarre case in which two Americans have been charged with illegally importing arms into Nigeria is reaping big headlines here and touching of another round of antiAmerican suspicion.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE United States Labor Department recently announced that the national unemployment rate in May was the lowest for any month since December 1974. I read this announcement as I vaited on ate to apply for unempleyment insurance for the first time in my life.

title: CanadianPilots Call Strike for 3 A.M. Today
description: MONTREAL, June 19 (UPI) The Canadian Airline Pilots Association has directed its 2,800 pilots across the country to cease all operations at 3 A.M. tomorrow because of rapidly deteriorating air traffic control brought on by a dispute over the use of French in flight communications.

title: ART
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR TEN years ago Long Island artists, like artists everywhere in the country were riding high on the bandwagon of nonobjective art, churning out abstract canvases and sculptures ??s if they would never go out of style. They were the Good Guys of the period and the Bad Guys were the objective or realist artists. Many Bad Guys were forced into hiding, some went into exile and others became extinct, like the eohippus.

title: The Garden of the World
description: THE writer of what may have been intended as a tongueincheek commentary March 7 proposed that New Jersey abandon its traditional nickname of Garden State in favor of others he thinks would be more appropriate. Lack of information about New Jersey's status in plant and animal agricultureincluding horticulture, floriculture, silviculture, aquaculture and livestock and poultry husbandry probably led the writer into an erroneous opinion.

title: Educator Weds Paula Gibney
description: Paula Ann Gibney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson J. Gibney of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday in Holy Family Roman Catholic Church to Christopher John Tennyson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Tennyson of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Richard Armstrong performed the ceremony. Pamela Ellen Gibney was her sister's maid of honor. Stephen Tennyson was best man for his brother.

title: U.S NARROWS GAP ON ATTACK SUBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The United States has built more nuclearpowered attack submarines than the Soviet Union in the last 10 years, although Defense Department testimony earlier this year left a contrary implication on the public record.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Food
description: In a strictly technical or classic sense, the word vinaigrette is one of the most abused in the entire gastronomic lexicon. What is commonly referred to in this country as a vinaigrette sauce  a combination of three parts oil to one part vinegar plus salt and pepper to taste  is quite simply known in France as a sauce salade. A classic vinaigrette (also called ravigote) consists of oil and vinegar plus capers, chopped herbs such as parsley, tarragon, chives and chervil, a touch of onion and salt and pepper. On this page, we ask Auguste Escoffier to forgive us our sins, for we employ the word vinaigrette loosely and as a matter of convenience. In any event, here are a few favorite vinaigrette recipes, some of which even call for lemon juice in lieu of vinega.

title: Cynthia Wellin To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Keith Sears Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Wellin's daughter, Cynthia Elizabeth Wellin, to Samuel Andrews Plum, son of Matthias Plum of Chatham, Mass, and Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Ann Rainey Plum. The prospective bride also is a daughter of the late Carol Woodhouse Wellin.

title: A Market'sEye View of Carter: Positive
description: Uncertainty about the political outcomeand particularly the possibility of a Carter Presidency in 1977may be one reason for the recent lackluster performance of the stock market. We believe, however, that the investment community will have little difficulty in reconciling itself to either a Democratic or Republican victory in November.

title: How to Hire a Writer
description: Dear Mr. Kaska:

title: FISHING
description: SHARKS made a big splash off Sandy Hook last week and are bound to provide the Island's fishermen with interesting catches for the rest of the summer. Mako and blue sharks arrived a few weeks early in the vicinity of the Mud Hole, Ambrose Lake and the HA buoy, drawn northward by warming waters and migratory patterns.

title: DINING OUT
description: MOTEL dining has never been a particularly glorious chapter in the history of American gastronomy. In fact, it seems at times as if there is a national conspiracy to fashion plastic food to match the plastic furniture. All that is forgotten at the Apollo.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRATASANDavid. . . . Love knows not its own depth until the hour of seoaration.

title: Court Rules Widow Can't Lose OldAge Benefit
description: The Federal Court of Appeals has reversed a ruling in an unusual case involving a widow's benefits, saying that the Social Security Act should he liberally construed and applied.

title: The public event named Jackie; Better than any other famous woman in history (including Garbo), she has mastered the art of managing her celebrity.
description: Jacqueline Onassis has boarded a plane for Australia, where she will begin negotiations with the Earl of Snowdon for the publication rights to his memoirs. If he decides to tell all, Snowdon has indicated, his story will blow the lid off the British royal family. These facts were announced on NBC's 11 o'clock news not long ago.

title: But Events in Lebanon Make It Difficult; Assad Visiting Paris
description: PARISFrance's policy of all azimuth friendship with the Arab world, trying to be on the best of terms with everyone, is being severely tested by events in Lebanon.

title: Friday's Fight
description: West BerlinEckard Dagge, West Germany, knocked out Elisha Obed, the Bahamas, 10 rounds to retain the world junior middleweight title.

title: How safe is safe; enough?; Despite rings of safety, all the risks of nuclear power cannot be eliminated. Are they justified by the need for energy?
description: In the last 20 years, the rounded dome of a nuclearpowered electric generating plant has become one of the most distinctive symbols of modern times, a useful device for cartoonists and illustrators. And yet these days, the dome might more properly be made to look like a medieval castle. Set behind walls and a moat, it would be crowned with a parapet and watchtowers, its keep crowded with officials from public utilities, the nuclear industry and Federal regulatory agencies.

title: PEOPLE
description: I had very little opposition to being a woman, said Valerie L Reed of Brightwaters. A few naturally. But I was running strictly on my record. And, running strictly on that record, Mrs. Reed became the first woman to be elected commander of the Suffolk County chapter of the American Legion, encompasing 53 posts with roughly 7,000 members. Mrs. Reed, who served as an Xray specialist in the Army during World War II, served five terms as a post commander and held a variety of other offices before winning last week's election. Her husband, Charles, the senior engineer on the Long Island Rail Road, is a former Army sergeant who is a vice commander of the Legion. And their son, Charles Jr., who is with the Long Island State Parkway police and is a Vietnamera veteran of the Coast Guard, is also a member of the organization.

title: Sewers Mean a Suburb Is of Age
description: Once again, sewers. They are a suburb's mark of maturity, a sure sign that times of relatively free space and everyhomeforitself are coming to an end.

title: Sicilians Abroad Return for Election
description: EN ROUTE TO SOUTHERN ITALY, June 19The fields and farms of the Italian countryside swept past the train window. Mauro Catalano was going home to Sicily, home to vote in the national elections tomorrow. For the first time, his ballot will go to the Communists.

title: Homeowner's Guide To Choosing and Using Chain Saws
description: There will be about two million chain saws sold in this country during 1976, and well over half of these will be bought by homeowners and other nonprofessional woodcutters.

title: A Poet's Past in the Dooryard Looms
description: WALT WHITMAN celebrated all America, it cities and plains, its artisans and workers en masse. But he also sang a local part of itan island that he liked to call by its Indian name, Paumanok.

title: Nicklaus and Jones
description: DULUTH, Ga., June 19In the gleaming elegance of the Bob Jones Trophy Room, a voice drawled reverentially, as if in church, Look at those silver cups. Another whispered, as if examining relics, Look at those clubs, every one's got a wooden shaft. The pilgrims were visiting the shrine that the Atlanta Athletic Club has erected to honor its most famous golfer. Bob Jones never played the holes where the United States Open is being conducted. He was crippled by a spinal disease before they were constructed. But he was a member of the A.A.C. when it owned the East Lake course several miles away before moving into the suburbs. And now, in a Bicentennial tribute to a fourtime winner, the U.S. Open is here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In The New York Times last Sunday the pictures accompanying the accounts of the weddings of Eleuthera Smith to Temple Grassi and of Kathleen Burpo to Christopher Kager were transposed.

title: Mrs. Tompkins Wed to M. L. Lyons
description: Nancy Callaway Tompkins of Darien, Conn., and Martin Lowell Lyons, a vice president in the investment banking division of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.. were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien. The Rev. Charles P. Henderson Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Jean Lawrence Wed to Peter Petri
description: The marriage of Jean Hathaway Lawrence to Peter Alexander Petri took place at noon yesterday in Bronxville, N.Y., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ruddick C. Lawrence, father and stepmother of the bride.

title: National Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) A drug company has been quietly replacing stocks of a widely used oral diabetes treatment because the drug contains minute amounts of a cancercausing chemical, Federal officials said today.

title: Iris Gordon Is Fiancee of Mark Collins
description: Mrs. Philip Newbold Gordon of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter. Iris Fitzhugh Gordon to Mark Lafort. Collins son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Evert Collins of Fullerton, Calif.

title: Connors Favored For Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 19 (AP)Arthur Ashe, the defending champion, is topseeded for the Wimbledon tennis championships starting Monday, but British bookies make Jimmy Connors a 138 favorite to win back the title he lost to Ashe last year.

title: Sugar Plum Time Is First
description: Happenings that included a dropped whip in the stretch, a victory by a nose and claim of interference against the secondplace horse produced an exciting close yesterday to the 33d running of the New York Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: State Racing, Radio Sports, Olympic Dropouts
description: Let me express to you on behalf of myself and all of the members of my division sincere congratulations for the fine article that appeared in the June 6 New York Times entitled Gambling With Future of New York Horse Racing.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TODAY is Father's Day, and so what else is new? Father's Day seems to have sprung from some equaltime compulsion years back, but it has never really measured up to Mother's Day.

title: Daniel B.C. Cote Becomes Fiance Of Miss Upham
description: The engagement of Sherrard Douglas Upham to Daniel Becket Conklin Ct has been announced by Mrs. E. Wajker Upham of Southport, Conn., mother of the future bride. Miss Upham's fianc is the son of Mrs. David F. Peck of Dayton, Ohio, and Northport, Mich., and John J. Ct of Santa Ana, Calif.

title: The Text Of Statement
description: PRETORIA, South Africa. June 19 (AP)Following is the text of a joint statement issued today by the participants in a meeting here between M. C. Botha, the Minister of Bantu Adminstration and Development, and black leaders from Soweto Township:

title: He Did It His Way
description: BEHOLD the American Dream. It is folded carefully inside Peter Lemongello's wallet, one thin line of type that used to be folded inside a fortune cookie. It says: You Are Almost There. And late at night he can hear it talking to him. Lemongello took the high road, going on television like the VegOMatic man, interrupting everything from the morning news to the midnight movie in New York, Los Angeles and Las Vegas to pitch his tworecord album set that no uptight, awright, outasight love lady could do without. Four color seperational whimwham called Mood Rock.

title: Helpful Tugs to Precede Tall Ships Up the Hudson
description: When the long line of tall ships heads up the Hudson River on the morning of July 4, not the Coast Guard training ship Eagle, but a phalanx of a dozen commercial tugs will

title: SixWheelers Convince the Skeptics
description: For the sixwheel Grand Prix race cars designed and built by Ken Tyrrell to be in the victory lane already is little short of miraculous.

title: Miss Schager R. A. Anderson Have Nuptials
description: Francesca Florence Waring Schager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schager of Oyster Say, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon in Locust Valley, L. L. to Robert Alexander Anderson of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Anderson of Grosse Ile, Mich.

title: Hollywood Is A Four Letter Town
description: Charles Laughton was a homosexual. Clara Bow was sexually insatiable. Milton Berle and Forrest Tucker (Forrest Tucker?) are the most sexually endowed men in show business. Rin Tin Tin was probably a pederast. So what else is new? Clearly, sexual revelations titillate publishersif not readers.

title: Currency Swings Blur Profits
description: Big multinational corporations that draw a large portion of their profit from overseas have always been vulnerable to the quicksilver shifts of values in foreign currencies.

title: The sickness of the city
description: It is too soon, perhaps, for a cool, rational, detached book about what has happened to New York. Those of us who choose to live here are too choked with rage. Rage at the knowledge that the South Bronx is burning to the ground, and we do not have enough firemen. Rage at the plague of crime and violence, knowing that we have too few policemen. Rage because so many of our schools and hospitals have been permanently awarded to the rats, our parks left strangled on weed and neglect, our libraries reduced to parttime outposts of civilization. Rage at the scabrous conditions of our streets, the potholes and trenches that might never again be filled, the sewers clogged with a winter's dismal refuse. Rage at the businessmen fleeing to their suburban arcadias. Rage at the loss of our local democracy. Rage at Washington. Rage at our own impotence.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: You must have noticed, in your favorite London newspaper, that Tchaikovsky returned there the other day and performed his own piano concerto. Some attention was paid to the event, though not as much as you might expect. Because, you see, this pianist and composer was not Peter Ilyitch, the Russian who was made famous by the Ken Russell film, but a Pole named Andre. Probably that made a difference. Young Tchaikovsky, elder observers may recall. first appeared on the concert scene about 15 years ago, spelling his name Tchaikowsky, possibly to avoid just such confusion. He was pretty good, but after a short period of success he faded.

title: Finley Finds Kuhn In His Way Again
description: CHICAGO, June 19Charles O. Finley woke up in his downtown Chicago apartment today, still $3.5 million poorer and still in a rage over the man he considers responsible for the financial loss.

title: A Dream Meets Reality
description: IT was as election to pick the next mayor and board of trustees but for Asharoken residents last week it was also a referendum on future growth, and on a developer's plan that had attracted national attention.

title: The Painter Of Signs
description: A comedy about birth control in India . . . ? An unlikely prospect, perhaps, but R. K. Narayan has achieved it, with an observation that is always acute, a humor that is never condescending, and a delicate sympathy that never becomes whimsical. Malgudi, the South Indian city of Narayan's imagination, is a setting he has used before. It teems with life, with a babble of gossip and argument, and no writer is better than Narayan at transcribing the Indian love of talk. Yet his special subtlety is shown in The Painter of Signs through his choice, in his two central characters, of people who are more naturally solitaries than conversationalists.

title: Miss Campbell Bride of Peter Edwards
description: Caroline Cary Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Campbell of Sewickley, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Bartlett Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Edwards of Montclair, N. J.

title: Tax Gold in Timberland
description: MANSFIELD TOWNSHIP THE buzz of chain saws is being heard more frequently these days in the quiet woodlands or this Warren County township, and in other rural areas throughout the state, as property owners discover the tax benefits of logging New Jersey forests.

title: New York Traffic Deaths Decline for 13th Month
description: ALBANY (UPI)April marked the 13th consecutive month of declining traffic deaths in the state, the Motor Vehicle Department announced.

title: The West's View of Rome Is Clearly Disturbing
description: PARISAs Italians go to the polls, possibly to give the Communist Party a voice in government, the rest of Western Europe has been left with nothing it could do but watch and worry. European government leaders share Washington's belief that Communists in the Italian Government will pose grave and discomfiting difficulties for the allies, despite all the recent assurances from the Communist Party chief, Enrico Berlinguer, about the Atlantic alliance, the Common Market and the EastWest balance.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Lincoln Inn serves tastefully prepared food tasteless surroundings. A large white Victorian house has been effectively hidden behind a whiteshingled, picturewindowed facade. Inside, merciless redecoration has erased every hint of the house's former character. Walls are brickfaced papered with colonial prints and treated to homecenter paneling. Captain's chairs wagonwheel lights sporting orange bulbs and Spanish turnedwood dividers complete the picture.

title: Cathey Mayer Has Nuptials
description: Cathey Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Mayer Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Reed Kennedy of Dobbs Ferry. N. Y., son of Mrs. Alfred William Fleer of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and George Danner Kennedy of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: EVENTS TODAY
description: Americana '76: Street Fair, with anfiques, crafts, food, entertainment; 11 A.M. to cus??, 52d Street from the East River to Ni?? Avenue.

title: When the Living Is Easy and the Traveling Is Light
description: Whether or not one takes a summer vacation, the advent of warm weather almost always means more traveling. For some, it's just getting out of the city to admire the trees and eat country food for a few days. For others, it's a weekend here and a weekend there, visiting friends or resorts.

title: Francis Attains Golf Final
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I. June 19 Gene Francis and Johnny Humm have met in so many amateur tournament golf matches is the last 20 years that they don't know the exact count or who is ahead. But Francis added a 3and2. victory over Human to his record today when the friendly rivals met in the semifinal round of the 53d annual Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at Middle Bay Country Club.

title: VIKING 1 BEGINS ORBITING MARS
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 19 The Viking 1 spacecraft, designed to conduct man's first search for life on another planet, flew into orbit around Mars tonight, completing a 420millionmile, 10month journey from earth.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: The charge: A bribe of less than $10,000 for an undisclosed purpose was given by the South Korean Government to two United States Congressmen in the fall of 1975.

title: FRANCHISE OFFICE CANCELS BUS LINE
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 19A proposed YonkerstoManhattan express bus service was canceled yesterday after Morris. Tarshis, the director of the New York City Bureau of Franchises, told the operator that Board of Estimate approval was required. Service was to have begun tomorrow.

title: No More Chile Sauce Today
description: PARISUntil the collapse of Chilean President Salvador Allende's Popular Front in 1973 followed by his own death in a struggle against the military putsch that displaced him, the massive Communist Party in Italy always seemed to be working to gain power through a purely leftwing coalition. It favored a political dish of spaghetti with Chile sauce.

title: ADM. VON HEIMBURG, TWOWAR VETERAN
description: Vice Adm. Ernest H. Von Heimburg, United States Navy, retired, a veteran of two world, wars, died Friday at the Mount Vernon Nursing Home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: 2 Medical Malpractice Insurers Ask Vastly Different Rate Rises
description: The two companies that provide malpractice insurance to physicians in New York State have digested the same actuarial data and come up with different requests for rate increasesin one case, a 90 percent increase and in the other, a 20 percent increase.

title: EXCONVICT SAYS H SPIED ON VESCO
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 19  A former convict with five felony convictions has said he was flown to Costa Rica by thel United States Attorney's office in New York to spy on Robert L. Vesco, the financier who sought refuge in Costa Rica in 1972 just before he was indicted in connection with an investigation of a stock fraud.

title: Lolich Loses 9th, 50, As Giants End Skid
description: Mickey Lolich started for the Mets yesterday and left after four innings with what was described by Manager Joe Frazier as a headache. Undoubtedly, it was brought on by the hitting of San Francisco's shortstop, Marty Perez, who singled and hornered off the Mets' lefthander in leading the Giants to a 50 victory.

title: ART
description: IT used to be ?? the art season had a precise timetable. Like the school year, it opened with a splash in September and closed in early June.

title: ScrimshawThe Art Of the Whalers
description: Scrimshaw, the art of scribing designs onto ivory or bone to produce decorative household or personal items, is one of the oldest American folk arts. It originated in the early years of this country when sailors aboard New England whaling vessels started the craft as a means of relieving the boredom on sea voyages that often lasted as long as three years.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: If you are a weekend speleologist and you also happen to have got most of the way up Mount Everest on your own two feet, you are just the person to get the most out of Project Studios One, the new art center which is now open to visitors in Long Island City, Queens.

title: East Is East, West Isn't
description: FOR more than a decade, many people in eastern Suffolk County have been unhappy at being compelled to share county government with western Suffolk. Their reasons are obvious enough. Western Suffolk now consists of a number of densely populated suburban communities, dormitory adjuncts of the New York megalopolis. Their problems are those of rapid growth and the consequent expansion in public services, schools and so forth that this growth compels, along with the mounting taxes.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien. Conn. Junior working hunter classic, 10:45 A.M., regular working hunting classic, 12:30 P.M., grand prix for jumpers, 2:45 PM.

title: Fashion
description: Neither of us wears a watch. From our office we can see two of the three digital clocks on the Newsweek Building. They often disagree. Even so, we think that the Newsweek Building is better than a watch. You can't lose it, you don't have to worry about getting it wet and its strap doesn't break.

title: Engagements
description: LilianCardlin

title: The Budget Crunch and City U. Sports
description: The City University of New York has been forced to close because of the impact of New York City's financial crisis. The university comprises 20 colleges with 270,000 students. It has had free tuition for 129 years and has accepted all local high school graduates since 1970.

title: Hanoi and Saigon Merge Their Two News Agencies
description: HONG KONG, June 19 (Agence FrancePress)  The Vietnam News Agency of North Vietnam and Giai Phong, or Liberation agency of South Vietnam, have merged, the Saigon radio has reported.

title: Suez Swings Back Into World Shipping
description: It's been an uphill struggle, but the Suez Canal is finally coming alive. The Canal reopened for business a year ago as shipping plunged through the worst slump in decades, doubly handicapped by the fact that it was too small to handle the large tankers that could still find work in the Persian Gulf. But now transit figures are beginning to look heartily and revenues are starting to move up. It is still too early to judge what Suez means to today's shipping markets, but there are signs that it is again shaping shipping patterns.

title: POLITICS
description: MAYBE I am bull in a china shop, but I'm not going to shut up about it said 30 yearsold Robert J. Mrazek, who has broken some china and rocked some boats in the mere five months he has been in the Suffolk County Legislature. The Centerport Democrat has been a key figure in focusing public and governmental attention on the county's Southwest Sewer District. At least partly because of Mr. Mrazek's outcries about cost overruns and possible corruption in the project, the office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District and the Suffolk District Attorney are investigating the project along with a halfdozen Federal, state and county agencies and committees.

title: Mahaffey's 69207 Leads Open by 2 Shots; Pate 2d
description: DULUTH, Ga., June 19The runaway lead of six strokes that John Mahaffey held midway through the third round of the United States Open disappeared late this afternoon, and suddenly the Open became a competitive event again.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: June 25Triumph Sports Car Club rally school at Great Notch Firehouse, Long Hill Road, Little Falls, N.J. at 7:30 P.M. Short rally follows lecture. All interested persons welcome. Information: Jim Wotton, phone (201)6279342 or Anna Andrews (201) 2564397.

title: Test for Vitamin C
description: VITAMIN C, or ascorbic acid, for years has been the fulcrum of a continuing controversy in the scientific and medical worlds because of claims and counterclaims regarding its effectiveness as a possible treatment for diseases ranging from colds to cancer. Now it may be the key to curing atherosclerosis, a form of arteriosclerosis, according to a young biochemist at Cook College of Rutgers University.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Change at Jamaica:
description: IT took 87 years to do it, but last Thursday the Long Island Rail Road gave passengers a ride directly from Oyster Bay to Penn Station in Manhattan without having to change trains or locomotives at Jamaica.

title: Athletes Want Chiropractor On U.S. Olympic Team Staff
description: Of the hundreds of young men and women who hope to earn places on the American Olympic team at this week's track and field trials, all but one will try to win trips to Montreal by running, walking, jumping and throwing faster, higher and farther than the rest. The sole exception is Dr. Leroy R. Perry, a 30yearold Los Angeles chiropractor, who is eager to be added to the list of Olympic team doctors.
