His ambitions are supported by his patients, among whom are some of the nation's leading athletes.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Ken Holtzman, asked how he will like playing for the Yankees: I enjoy playing any place I'm well paid.

title: Chloroform, Linked to Cancer, Fading Out
description: Chloroform, that standard ingredient of movie kidnappings, has joined the ranks of suspected carcinogens. banned by the Federal Drug Administration along with cyclamates and Red Dye No. 2.

title: French Magazine Is Sold
description: PARIS, June 18 (Reuters)A popular French weekly magazine, ParisMatch, was sold today to the Librairie Hachette group by its publisher Jean Prouvost. Mr. Prouvost, 91, who sold the conservative daily, Le Figaro, a year ago, also sold two other smaller magazines to Hatchette in the same deal. No sum was disclosed. Hachette publishes a popular Paris daily, FranceSoir.

title: Mexico Awaits New President, New Policies
description: MEXICO CITYDespite the predictability of the Mexican elections July 4there is only one candidatetension and uncertainty are accompanying the transfer from an unusually strong President to a relatively unknown successor. The tensions apply not only to Mexico's chronic domestic social and economic troubles, but perhaps as much to its dealings with the rest of the Western Hemisphere and the underdeveloped nations of the world.

title: Italian Vote, Most Crucial In 28 Years, Opens Today
description: ROME, June 19With formal campaigning now over, some 40 million Italians will cast their ballots tomorrow and Monday in the most crucial elections here in nearly 30 years.

title: Service Clubs Fight Attrition
description: ROTARLANS own the town, Lions have all the fun and Kiwanians do all the work. This wvellknown saying, while apocryphal, is familiar to New Jersey's three leading service organizations, whose combined membership of business and professional men exceeds 26,000.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 20, 1976

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Late last month, the California Air Resources Board announced that, beginning this fall, Volvo will be marketing several cars in California which not only meet but exceed the statutory standards for automobile emissions mandated by the Clean Air Act. This breakthrough greatly strengthens my argument that there is no justifiable reason why an extended freeze of the current automobile emission standards should be granted.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: What's Doing Around the FINGER LAKES
description: SCENERYThe continental glacier carved with a fine touch when it crested 11 fingergraped lakes south of Rochester and Syracuse. The longest40 milesis Cayuga Lake, with Ithaca at its southern. end. Seneca Lake, almost a twin of Cayuga, is 630 feet deep, one of the deepest inland waterways in the world. The nine other lakes are smaller but all are adornments of the 9,000squaremile, 14county westcentral New York area called the Finger Lakes Region.

title: Trials Spark Hopes Of U.S. Yachtsmen
description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N.Y., June 19Off what they have shown this week in their Olympic sailing trials on Lake Ontario, American yachtsmen are considered threats for a medal in all six classes.

title: Colorado, a State Known for Glitter, Lends Luster to the DogShow World
description: DENVER, June 19Colorado long has been known for its gold and silver. Central City once was called the richest square mile on earth and alone produced more than $85 million in gold. When President Ulysses S. Grant stepped from his stagecoach at the Teller House in Central City. a walk of silver bullion had been laid for him.

title: Voice of Ox Ridge Heads for Pasture
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 19Jack Gingrich sat in the public address system trailer at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today with three microphones in front of him, a squawk box alongside chattering and a telephone ringing. To make matters even more complicated, an exhibitor would appear at the door periodically and ask Gingrich to make an announcement of a lost dog, a blocked car or any of a hundred of life's little frustrations.

title: U.S. Open Scores
description: Tour Earnings

title: Long Island/This Week
description: AMAGANSETTPaintings by Ann Stanwell, through June 27, daily except Tuesday and Wednesday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., Gallery East Hampton, Amagansett Square, Main St.

title: Washington Bridal For Rose G. Davis
description: Rose Grosvenor Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fellowes Davis of Hamilton, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon in Washington to Fernando Mendoza Sanz, son of Carmen Sanz de Mendoza and Jos Louis Mendoza Gimeno of Madrid,

title: TEAMSTERS FACE A SENATE INQUIRY
description: A Senate committee will hold hearings within the next 10 days into the Ford Administration's investigation of the Central States Pelision. Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and present the first public look at what the Labor and Justice Department have uncovered.

title: Memorial Services
description: JAFFEBeryl. A meeting in his memory will be held by his family and friends on Wednesday, June 23, 1976, at 8 P.M., at the Society for the Advancement on Judaism, 15 West 86th St., New York, N.Y.

title: ATTICA HOSTAGES PRESSING LAW SUITS
description: BUFFALO, June 19 (UPI)A Buffalo lawyer said yesterday he would move forward with civil suits seeking more than $15 million filed by hostages and relatives of hostages held during the 1971 Attica prison rebellion.

title: Jerseyans on the Move
description: CAN the Federal Census Bureau. with all its long experience and expertise, be wrong about its Iatest view of New Jersey population trends? Yes, without a doubt, gays Henry Watson, the state government's chief demographer, who has a batch of his own estimates.

title: Dance: Miss Morishita
description: When the Japanese ballerina Yoko Morishita first danced in this country, she did not unduly impress me. She was seen in classic excerpts, such as the Rose Adagio, from The Sleeping Beauty, or the Black Swan pas de deux from Swan Lake, and she was clearly good, but less clearly interesting. She seemed a copy rather than an original.

title: Katherine O'Brien Is Bride in Jersey
description: The Central Presbyterian Church in Montclair, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Katherine O'Brien and Robert Winston ReesJones. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. Scott Morton.

title: 20 More Delegates for Carter
description: HOUSTON, June 19An additional 20 delegates were added to Jimmy Carter's tally today as Texas Democrats completed their delegate selection for the national convention.

title: Baryshnikov Reviews The Adventures of Baryshnikov
description: I felt like a cow on ice, says Mikhail Baryshnikovthat paragon of classical perfection and ballet's current sensation  when speaking about his appearance last month in Alvin Ailey's jazzstyled choreography. It is also obvious that the Russiantrained dancer relished the experience.

title: W. R. Kincaide Weds Gail Griffin
description: In the Congregational Church of New. Canaan, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Gail Georgia Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wortham Griffin Jr. of New Canaan, became the bride of William Mark Kincaide of Washington.

title: Headliners
description: Cost of Really Living

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES STEADY FOR YEAR
description: The country's independent colleges and universities appear to have held their own this year in the face of rising costs and increasing competition from public institutions for students, according to a study released yesterday by the Association of American Colleges.

title: Dissension Splits Rubin Carter Group
description: An accusation that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter attacked Carolyn Kelley, his former defense chairman has unveiled a smoldering controversy within the group that raised $600,000 to help Mr. Carter and his codefendant, John Artis, win a new trial on triplemurder charges.

title: Preservation, Renovation, Consternation
description: OAKDALE THE people who live in what used to be the chicken coop, the pony stables, the duck shed, the cheese house and the pigsty of the William K. Vanderbilt estate were enthusiastic last year when the Town of Islip designated their neighborhood as the town's first historic district. To them, it meant that the architecture and character of what is known as the Artists' Colony would be protected and that further development be controlled.

title: The Region
description: After much ado, four prominent New York Democrats have been given sanction by the state's Democratic party to seek the Democratic nomination to run for the United States Senate seat now held by James L. Buckley, a ConservativeRepublican.

title: A New Life Of Anton Chekhov
description: Reading the biographies of great writers, one gets the impression that literature is mainly the occupation of mistreated childrenthose preoccupied with being unloved or being unable to return love. These deficiencies branch out into all sorts of tributaries: anger, shyness, aggression, despair. We admire and analyze the products of these disorders as if unhappiness were an oyster exuding pearl after pearl. And we should feel guilty  we probably do  once we know this secret of art. For aren't we in the uncomfortable position of welcoming bad news? Where would we be if Proust's mother had kissed him goodnight? If Beethoven's nephew had been a little nicer? If Chekhovin this casehad been treated with the affection he claims he missed during a childhood of enforced churchgoing, shopkeeping (his father was a grocer), and schoolwork? We are given enigmasthe artist's way of handling the impossibleand the biographer, confronted with enigmas, becomes obsessed by fact. This explains that, he keeps telling us, with a certain amount of rueful

title: Shore Hotels: Past Glory No Help Now
description: AVONBYTHESEA, N.J.  Slowly, the grand old hotels on the Jersey shore, links to another era, are disappearing. Time has caught up with them; they are too costly to maintain.

title: Gov. Brown Moves to Save Coast Preservation Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19 The continuation of California's radical threeyearold program for controlling development along its 1,000mile coast, suddenly blocked by the State Legislature, has received a new lease on life with the help of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: The View of Rome From Moscow Is Ambiguous
description: MOSCOWIf the Communists win a role in an Italian coalition Government, the Soviet Union will be presented with a tangle of advantages and disadvantages thoroughly intertwined, and no outsider can be sure whether the Kremlin will see it as a victory or a threat.

title: ...The Red Scare
description: Either formation would be sharply circumscribed carrying out essential economic recovery and antiinflation programs by the necessity to bid for Communist support or neutrality on key measures, as Italian Governments have had to do informally for several years. The price for such Communist, help is likely go up in proportion to any Communist gains in the election.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: LETTERS
description: Concorde

title: In This Issue
description: GENERAL

title: Meadowlands Opens on Sept. 1
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 19Meadowlands Race Track, opening with a 102night harness meeting on Wednesday, Sept. 1, will offer $640,000 in stakes for its first 60 nights. Highlighting the program for the new mile trackthe East's firstwill be a $50,000 freeforall invitation pace on the opening night and a pair of $100,000 races for 3yearolds  a pace on Sept. 6 and a trot on Sept. 24.

title: Metropolitan Museum Concerts
description: Five Concerts

title: A Hardy Perennial That Looks Good With or Without Its Flowers
description: A perennial flower can be very endearing to a gardener when he discovers that it will bloom for weeks, look great when not blooming, shrug off plant pests, and thrive on neglect. Herbaceous potentillas meet all those qualifications while adding cheerful beauty to the flower garden.

title: The bitter truth about sugar
description: Sugar is one of mankind's new foods. The ancient Greeks and Romans knew nothing about cane or beet sugar (except for those of Alexander's soldiers who reached the Indus Valley and met with sugar cane). The Promised Land flowed with milk and honey, the latter apparently a fairly scarce commodity. The Egyptian pyramid builders, Socrates, Jesus and the Roman legions never tasted sugar  and certainly their brains and sinews worked as well as ours do. Sugar from cane did not become available to Europeansand then only to the rich ones  until the 16th century; beet sugar was not developed as a food until the beginning of the 19th century (in France, when the British blockade after the destruction of the French fleet at Trafalgar cut off sources of sugar in Brazil and the West Indies).

title: Mussolini's Roman Empire
description: The legacy of Rome has been a heavy burden for the Italian state to bear ever since its unification in the 19th century. When Rome became the capital of Italy in 1870, a German observer asked an Italian friend, What do you intend to do in Rome? You cannot be in Rome without having cosmopolitan projects. Certainly Mussolini's cosmopolitan projects in what he conceived to be the grand manner of Imperial Rome turned out to be the most disastrous of his enterprises: It was in his foreign and colonial policy that he revealed all his weaknesses, and it was his ambition to demonstrate Italy's status as a great power that more than anything else led to his downfall.

title: ARCHITECTURAL VIEW
description: The first response of a taxiriding New Yorker to the Museum of Modern Art show called The Taxi Project: Realistic Solutions for Today is that it couldn't possibly lose. There was nowhere to go but up. Anyone who has endured the purgatory of most New York cab rides knows that this is not transportation; it is sadomasochism.

title: FORD KEEPS VIGIL ON BEIRUT EVENTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19President Ford, increasingly concerned about Lebanon after lastminute postponement of a convoy intended to carry American and other civilians out of the fighting zone, kept close watch last night and today at the White House.

title: Summaries of Olympic Trials
description: MEN'S EVENTS

title: Monmouth Rsults
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.

title: CALM REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA AS LEADERS TALK
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 19Riot squads, acting under Prime Minister John Vorster's order to restore peace at all costs, apparently succeeded today in bringing calm to 11 black townships around Johannesburg, but the casualty figures after the toughest police action of the three days' rioting remained secret.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONE tenet of Wall Street's conventional wisdom seemed to be thoroughly discredited last week when the stock market displayed impressive strength immediately following a huge new piece of public financing by the dominant darling of the investment world, American Telephone & Telegraph.

title: Cody Dalton Has Nuptials
description: Cody Dalton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Schneider of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Stephen Charles Grill, son of Dr. Robert Grill of Piscataway, N.J., and Maria Peizler Turr of Budapest.

title: Letters
description: Poetic ripoff?

title: Pat Bradley Leads Plymouth Golf by 2
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., June 19 (UPI)Pat Bradley broke out of a sevenway tie today to take the lead by two strokes over JoAnne Carver, ending the second windy round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hoosier classic tournament with a 69, 71140.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The return last weekend of Alicia Alonso was, oddly enough, a matter for both joy and sadness. Since the early days of American Ballet Theater, Miss Alonso has been identified with American, ballet. Although she was born in Cuba and had her first dance lessons there, it was really America that formed her, gave her her particular style, her Initial repertory and her first taste of international fame.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The formula is simple as well as simpleminded and reactionary if you bother to think about it: a young man and a young woman, who is as faithful to the young man as Tonto was to the Lone Ranger, are being pursued by the law. They race down the road in a soupedup automobile following a macadam trail that is eventually revealed to be a large figure eight. Speed, not space, is the medium. The kids land back where they started. The game of flight and pursuit must end badly, a fiery carcrash, perhaps, in which the couple is killed or, at least, a shootout in which the young man is killedit still being a man's world as far as shootout deaths are concerned.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Senator Eugenio Reale, former Communist treasurer, says half the party's budget comes from kickbacks on trade with proSoviet East Europe.

title: A fan's notes about sex
description: One hopes that Lawrence Edwards is a pseudonym, for then an essential selfaggrandizementa flirtation with the publicwill be reduced to a minimum in this disturbing confession. And anonymity has another advantage: A certain abstraction in this pursuit of women, halfway from a Casanova's blandly conniving Johnny JumpUp reflex toward the philosophic melancholia of Don Juan, suits a host of urban men, troubled about marriage, troubled about women, troubled about feminism, troubled in their own masculinity. One reads itand this is tributeas a story moving from the particular out there to the particular in here. It fits very close to home.

title: Mary Fargo Rousseau Bride In Southport of Carl Roessler
description: Mary Fargo Rousseau and Carl Chard Roessler were married yesterday afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., by the Rev. Ray H. Averett Jr.

title: Miniature Ships on a Miniature Sea
description: Water rolled across the deck as the yacht America righted itself after a knockdown. Undaunted, the skipper, John Steffen, stood onshore in a yellow jump suit, flicked a dial and brought the 50inchlong schooner onto another tack. With final preparations under way for the arrival of the tall ships in Operation Sail, captains of the little ships met in a minisail last weekend on a miniature sea, Oakland Lake in Bayside, Queens. Some 30 radiocontrolled vessels, eight to 60 inches long, were on hand: ketches, sloops and cruisers; a fourfoot tug; a 60inch Vietnam patrol boat capable of doing 40 miles per hour; Spanish galleon.

title: Weddings
description: AdlerApplebaum

title: Beirut Evacuation Convoy Put Off After New Gunfire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 19A Britishorganized evacuation convoy to Damascus for Europeans and Americans was canceled this morning when sporadic shelling and machinegun duels broke out near the seaside route for the first stage of its journey.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Use watersoluble fertilizer to boost bloom on seedlings set out earlier this month. . . . Remove flowers from first year strawberry plants so strength goes toward developing plants. . . . Resow more rows of corn for late season crop. . . . Clean out and repair greenhouses this month. . . . Watch lawns for chinch bugs and control them with diazinon.

title: ECCENTRIC ROCK BY GENTLE GIANT
description: Like Yes, and unlike most of the current crop of English progressive rock bands, Gentle Giant shuns elaborate theatricality and relies on music alone. The music that the fiveman group performed during its twohour set at the Schaefer Music Festival on Friday was eccentric in content, intricately put together, and flawlessly executed, and, unlike the music of Yes, it was often bracingly dissonant.

title: 19 DELEGATES WON BY FORD IN IOWA; REAGAN TAKES 17
description: DES MOINES, June 19President Ford escaped from the Iowa Republican convention today with the narrowest possible victory over Ronald Reagan, capturing 19 of the state's delegates to the Califomian's 17.

title: John Marr Weds Helm Hubbard Of Met Museum
description: Helen Keep Hubbard of the Metropolitari Museum of Art's musical instrument department was married yesterday to Dr. John S. Marr, director and principal epidemiologist of the New York City Department of Health's Bureau of Preventable Diseases.

title: Leg Ailment Jeopardizes His Olympic Berth
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 19The United States Olympic track trials began today, and with them Steve Williams's Olympic chances all hut ended.

title: OAS. MAKES GAINS ON RIGHTS ISSUE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 19For the first time, a general assembly of the Organization of American States has established effective monitoring of humanrights violations as a, major concern in interAmerican relations.

title: Gourmet Camper: Cods' Tongues & Other Delights
description: Camping is not generally considered a gourmet pastime, nor are the operators of recreational vehicles thought to be epicures. And certainly it is fair comment that the informality of camping does not lend itself to the preparation of elaborate sauces and garnishes. Yet my family and I have enjoyed a host of new taste sensations on our travels, regional delicacies that may be old stuff to the locals but have produced dinnertime delights for us. Cod tongues, for example, or beaver or skate wingcooked over the campfirehave taught us to look for the native foods and forget our squeamishness over the unfamiliar.

title: Miss Lidstone Wed to A. Swain
description: Rosalind Grace Lidstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herrick K. Lidstone of Pelham, N. Y., and Slater, Colo., was married in Pelham yesterday afternoon to Alan Swain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Swain of London. The Rev. Donald R. Kocher per formed the ceremony in the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church. A reception was held at the BartowPell Mansion Museum in the Bronx, headquarters of the International Garden Club.

title: A New Incarnation for Old City Houses
description: A year ago, those nine Federalstyle architectural relics on Harrison Street in Lower Manhattan were raw shells in search of owners who would transform them into homes.

title: Deaths
description: AHERNDaniel P., of Hillside, N.J. on June 19, 1976, husband of Inge B., brother of most Rev. Patrick V. Ahern, Auxiliary Bishop of N.Y. Funeral from the Halsey Funeral Home, 199 Center Ave., Westwood, N.J., Tuesday at 9 A.M. Funeral mass at St. John tire Baptist R.C. Church. Hillsdale, at 10 A.M. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visiting hours Sundae 7 to 9 P.M. and Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M.

title: Neil Is Different From Noel, Says Tammy
description: Tammy Grimes and Neil Simon used to be acrossthestreet neighbors on Manhattan's East Side. During the years they shared the same block, the actress kept saying to the playwright, Gee, I'd love to be in one of your plays, Doc. To which Doc Simon kept replying, Someday. Tammy, someday. Well, someday has finally arrived, to general jubilation. Simon, who recently moved from the East Side to Beverly Hills, has returned to Broadway with a laugh  laced comedy called California Suite, and one of its acclaimed stars is the neighbor who used to shoo passing vagrants from her stoop to his.

title: Prosecutors Harden StreetCrime Fight
description: TRENTON FOR the last three months, New Jersey's criminal  prosecution system has been quietly undergoing significant changes. The revisions call for stricter prosecution of violent street crimes, with less emphasis being given to marijuana smoking, social gambling and sexual offenses between consenting adults.

title: Oh, for a room of my own!
description: MOSCOW. Before all this happened, I was peacefully writing my novel, The Life and Extraordinary Adventures of Pvt. Ivan Chonkin, intending to finish it this year (as I have been intending for almost 12 years now). By some miracle, my two earlier hooks had come out at the same time, there was a little money left over after paying my debts, and I knew that in this respite from nervous strain I would have to write Chonkin as quickly as possible and not be distracted by extraneous matters. But the extraneous crept in. Unexpectedly, I became involved in a long and absurd struggle over the expansion of my living space.

title: Hope for Medal Spurs Dressage Riders
description: Picking up his hoofs as though for an Irish jig, Keen, a chestnut thoroughbred gelding, carried his prim and proper rider laterally six steps. Then he changed direction and crossed six steps to the other side, precisely, with hind legs following one track and forelegs another.

title: Design
description: Rejuvenating old houses and apartments requires greater soulsearching today than in the crusading decades of the Modem Movement. Now that clients and designers alike are conditioned Ito respect the architectural past again, there is often a conflict between wanting to preserve and having to discard in order to bring a place up to date.

title: The Lag Is in Tankers
description: LONDONMashour Ahmed Mashour, chairman of the Suez. Canal Authority, was in an ebullient mood when he addressed the Posidonla Exhibition Forum in Athens last Saturday, on the performance of the canal In its first year since reopening.

title: Rain Cancels Auto Heats
description: TORONTO, CANADA, June 19 (UPI)Rain and fog cancealed qualifying heats today for tomorrow's Formula 5000 race at Mosport Park. The heats may be run prior to tomorrow's scheduled 100mile race.

title: Misguided Concern
description: IT was surprising and sad to read such an illthoughtout appraisal of the Walkaway Mental Patients problem (June 6) by students in the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. The students, Paul Mogin and Robert Lack, contended that several recent encounters between walkaway mental patients and the publicsome violenthave triggered a statewide controversy over security at state mental hospitals and that the danger actually posed by such patients has been vastly exaggerated.

title: Decision in Italy . . .
description: Italy's long election campaign, scarred by scandal, assassination and a catastrophic earthquake, ended as it began: Not one of the major participants has offered any fresh approaches to the staggering political and economic problems that beset the country. The most likely prospect after the votes have been counted in the balloting today and tomorrow is for a continuation of muddle and compromise.

title: Inoki, Ali To Meet Friday
description: Muhammnd Ali is in Tokyo where he is talking and training for his upcoming bout on Friday with Antonio Inoki, a Japanese wrestler.

title: Linda Ottenant, John Colin Ball Planning Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene X. Ottenant of Glen Head, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Joan Ottenant, to John Colin Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Ball of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: One Big Plan for the Arts
description: THE arts in America are dangling at the end of a thin thread attached to the temperament of our present political and economic system. The arts exist at all levels of government on the basis of one yearly budget vote in Washington, which places them in the precarious position of never quite knowing whether this will be the year all arts efforts will end. It is difficult to plan and be creative with this thought in the back of one's mind.

title: South African Press, in Editorials on Riots in Townships, Calls for Dialogue Between Blacks and Whites
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 19South African newspapers have reacted in different ways to the township riots of the past, week that has left more than 100 dead and 1,000 injured. A selection of excerpts follows:

title: Redd Foxx, Is That You Starring In a BigTime Movie?
description: LOS ANGELES At first glance, the set for the new movie Norman, Is That You? looks as though it belongs at the studios of NBC or CBS instead of MGM. Glowing monitor screens are everywhere; TVstyle cuecards are stacked in a corner. Director George Schlatter, innovative producer of the fondlyremembered Laugh In and other homescreen shows, is using video cameras, as well as the conventional movie cameras, and computerized TV editing systems to make his first feature film. It's the first time these television techniques have been used so extensively for a major Hollywood film.

title: D. A. Moore Jr., Suzanne Rinfret Have Wedding
description: Suzanne Chartrand Rinfret, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Andre Rinfret of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church to Donald Ashton Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of San Marino and Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. Rene Fontaine performed the ceremony.

title: Persons of the Drama
description: The most interesting theater criticism is that which is based not on discrete moments of isolated experience but on cuItural foundations that provide a continuity of attitude and a reference for judgment that the ordinary theater reviewer generally lacks. To possess an intellectual background more varied and extensive than the memory of a dozen or so theater seasons means, at the very least, that one is fortified against the assaults of spurious novelty that, in our time, have been the most frequent threat to critical sanity.

title: The Trading Stamp Tries for a Comeback
description: Remember trading stamps?

title: Mr. Clements Conducts What Amount to Sales Meetings
description: WASHINGTONEarlier this year, Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr., who is emerging as the executive manager of the Defense Department, held his first foreign military sales breakfast meeting in his Pentagon office. It turned into a kind of pep meeting, the kind that business executives give to a sales team that is not producing.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: David and the titans. As you read this, coveys of trucks are leaving a Chicago printing plant to distribute two million copies of a book that, even in the freewheeling world of paperbacks, is a rara avis. It's an original novel called The Titans, latest in John Jakes's saga of the progress of one family the Kents  through 200 years of United States history. Oldtimers can recall few paperbacksoriginals or reprints that have been so eagerly awaited by as large and vociferous a legion. In the last 20 months, fans of the series have bought an average of 1,750,000, copies of each ofthe preceding four volumes.

title: Miss Meserole Marries in Jersey
description: Barbara Ann Meserole, daughter of Mrs. Clinton Vanderbilt Meserole Jr. of Englewood. N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Jay Worth Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Siegfried of Boston.

title: British Housing Officials End 2Week Tour of 6 U.S. Cities
description: Twenty British housing officials and urban affairs experts conclude a twoweek visit to the United States this weekend with vivid impressions of a nation fighting an uphill battle against massive urban ills.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The golden age of Wagner singing at the Metropolitan Opera spanned about six years, from 1935 to 1941. Take the season of 193637, for examples All of the composer's 10 mature operas, from Flying Dutchman to Persifal, were in the repertory, sung by an extraordinary group of Wagnerians: Karin Branzell, Kirsten Flagstad, Marjorie Lawrence, Lotte Lehmann, Elisabeth Rethberg, Oertrud Klinger, Kerstin Thorborg, Helen Traubel, Paul Althouse, Eduard Habich, Ludwig Hofmann Julius Huehn, Charles Kullman, Emanuel List, Rend Maison, Lauritx Meichior and Friedrich Schorr. The Met has never since had such a wealth of vocal talent to draw upon for Wagner.

title: 6TH GRADE RAISES FRESH AIR FUNDS
description: These sentiments of Hillary Weiss and Howard Menkes, both 12yearold students at Public School 232, in Howard Beach, Queens, were penned as a part of the promotion of the hectic, twoweek long effort by classes 6302 and 6309 to raise money for the Fresh Air Fund.

title: 300 in City March To Protest Killings By South Africans
description: About 300 Africans and American blacks and whites marched from Times square yesterday to the Second Avenue offices of the South. African mission to the United Nation in a demonstration against what they termed the genocide of blacks in South Africa.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Murder Scene in Bryant Park Is a Place to Drink and Gamble
description: Near the spot in busy Bryant Park where a Bronx man was murdered Friday afternoon about 15 young men were lounging yesterday, several rolling dice, others swigging from a whisky bottle and one offering to sell marijuana cigarettes to passersby.

title: For Subs, It's a Struggle To Stay Alive Amid Slump
description: New York City's subcontractors, who install the plumbing, the heating and the lighting and perform dozens of other tasks in new buildings, are among the hardest hit of all the companies affected by the city's sagging economy.

title: Geren Watson, Editor, Is Bride of J. J. Fauth;
description: Geren Jean Watson, former fashion editor of Mademoiselle magazine, was married yesterday afternoon in the Weekapaug (R.I.) Chapel to John Joseph Fauth 4th, an assistant vice president of Citicorp Commercial Inc. in Minneapolis a subsidiary of Citicorp in New York. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold Flynn.

title: Catherine Jean Wiss Married To Walter Schumann, Lawyer
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Catherine Jean Wiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Frederick Wiss Jr. of Short Hills, became the bride of Walter Christian Schumann, son of Dr. and Mrs. Detlev W. Schumann of Providence, R. I., and Pln, West Germany.

title: Margaret Maniatty, Student, Wed
description: Margaret Ellen Maniatty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Connie Steven Maniatty of Westport. Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Brian Paul Fullington, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norbert L. Fullington of Auburndale, Mass.

title: A Special Commitment to the Uncommitted
description: DES MOINES, IowaIowa's Republican chairman, Tom Stoner, shook his head in amazement Who would ever have thought, he asked a visitor, that this state with only 36 delegates, would turn into a major national battleground?

title: He's Good to Hair; Hair's Good to Him
description: CHICAGO  If your hair doesn't look right, it doesn't matter how good your figure is, or how good your clothes are. If you can't get your hair together, forget about it. the young black woman explained.

title: Foyt PaceSetter At Pocono Track
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 19 Mario Andretti put on a cowboy hat and quickdrew, firing a twoindexfinger salvo at an imaginary target in the Roger Penske garage.

title: Ford Bids Congress Back Turks' Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 19With little publicity and scant hopes of success, President Ford has formally asked Congress to approve a controversial agreement with Turkey that would allow the reopening of American military installations in return for a billion dollars in American aid.

title: HOME CL
description: DURING the building boom of the 1950's and 60's, when housing developments were springing up on the Island like weeds on a vacant lot, many of the moderately priced houses were built with asbestosshingle siding on the outside.

title: Judith McCorkle Is Bride of Peyton Cole
description: Judith Clay McCorkle of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Peyton. Magruder Cole of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Robert Nelson Back performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: Laura Hylwa Wed To Collin McNeil
description: In the First Congregational Church of Meriden, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Laura Jeanne Hytwat, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Walter Hylwa of Meriden, became the bride of Collin Farquhar McNeil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The Rev. Robert Daggett performed the ceremony.

title: The World
description: Syrian officials have made clear that they have no intention of withdrawing their forces from Lebanon in the near future. Instead, the Syrians have been consolidating and extending their positions in Lebanon, while still trying to achieve an elusive ceasefire.

title: Howe Wins Confidence Vote in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 19Representative Allan T. Howe won a vote of confidence today from delegates to the Utah State Democratic Convention.

title: GARDENING
description: AFEW weeks after the glory of New Jersey's white and pink flowering dogwood fades, several other attractive native dogwood shrubs and one very choice species from Japan begin to bloom.

title: FISHING
description: SHARKS made a big splash off the New Jersey coast last week and are bound to provide interesting fishing now through the summer, Hefty makos and some blue sharks were taken around the Mudhole, Ambrose Light and the HA Buoy, which is 34 miles off Sandy Hook.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Will Art at Sea Be Trash Ashore?

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Horned Pout
description: CROYDON, N.H.A fine rain and mist shrouded the shores of Spectacle Pond, dimming the glow of lanterns and flashlights on the shore, but, all through the early evening, teenagers, single anglers and family fishing parties  complete even to wailing babiescontinued to haul grunting, squirming horned pout from the water.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices moved higher along a broad front last week in the kind of expanded trading volume that had some analysts talking hopefully of the start of a summer rally.

title: Reporter's Notebook: O'Brien Skillful Navigator of Merger
description: It is a timehonored preaching that Larry O'Brien practiceskeep the ranks tight.

title: HOUSE SEEKS INQUIRY INTO MOON AND BANK
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) A Congressional subcommittee plans to ask Federal agents to investigate reports that the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has secretly gained control of newly chartered national bank in Washington, according to investigators for the House of Representatives.

title: Pekingese Best At MidHudson
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y., June 19 A Pekingese, Ch. Yang Kee Bernard, was judged best in show today at the 34th MidHudson Kennel Club show, on the Dutchess County fairgrounds. Mrs. Susan Rowe selected the Pekingese over 1,019 dogs.

title: An Answer to the Question of What Albany Legislators Do With Their Time
description: ALBANY, June 19Of the thousands of bills that will pass one house or both houses of the Legislature this year, only a few dozen will be bills of major statewide significance. Fewer still will strike the public as worthy of attention. So anyone who ever stops to think about the Legislature has probably wondered: What do all those other bills accomplish, and what do they do up there anyway?

title: Another Forgotten Problem
description: WASHINGTON, June 19In the last few days, the United States has begun formal negotiations with the Marcos regime of the Philippines about the future use of the critical United States military bases at Clark Field and Subic Bay. These negotiations have scarcely been noted in the press, but they raise fundamental strategic and even moral questions.

title: Bilingual Education Stirs Debate in New York City
description: It was born at a traumatic time, is now in its postnatal stage, and no one is sure whether it will survive, said Awilda Orta.

title: This Delegate Leans to Ford AND Reagan
description: ST. PAUL, June 18When Republican politicans meet here to compare battle reports on President Ford's and Ronald Reagan's struggle, for delegates, they end up discoursing on Robert Barry's state of mind.

title: Bicentenial Opens Up New Interest in Time Capsules
description: SEWARD, Neb.When the late Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect and critic, pondered what would remain of 20th century civilization in the event of a nuclear holocaust, he concluded that the identifiable artifact most likely to be excavated in largest numbers from our ruins would be the vitreous China toilet howl.

title: White House Is Stressing New U.S Aims in Africa
description: WASHINGTON, June 20New directions have been set in Administration policy toward Africaa firm commitment to achieving black majority rule in southern Africa and deeper involvement in maintaining the military balance of power in central Africa.

title: GIRL DIES IN CRASH AFTER SCHOOL PROM
description: WOODRIDGE, June 20 (UPI) An Essex County girl was killed in an auto accident yesterday while returning from a trip to the shore after a high school prom.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Thousands of visitors to yesterday's Americana '76 bazaar made 52d Streetknown as Swing Street, west of Fifth Avenue, during its jazz heyday 40 years agoswing again, but this time the action went straight across Manhattan.

title: Ellen Burstyn Will Star In Aimee on Broadway
description: Ellen Burstyn, winner last year of both an Oscar and a Tony respectively as best actress for her roles in Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore and Same Time, Next Year. has agreed to star in Aimee, a play with music scheduled for Broadway next season. The actress will also appear in the subsequent film version of the play, which is based on the life of Aimee Semple McPherson, the evangelist who was one of America's more flamboyant personalities after World War I.

title: The Chief Awards
description: VARIETY GROUPS

title: RHODESIANS FEAR A STEPUP IN WAR
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 20  A series of rocket and mortar attacks into Rhodesia from Mozambique has stirred a wave of uneasiness in Salisbury about an expansion of the, guerrilla war here.

title: Lebanese and Syrian Festival Raises Funds for Antiochian Christian Parish
description: LITTLE FALLS, June 20Lebanese and Syrian Orthodox Christians gathered here today for three days of festivities this weekend as part of an International Summer Festival held at St. George Antiochian Christian Church.

title: The Layoff Route
description: City negotiators and the municipal unions are reported to be near agreement on new contracts that would tie costofliving increases to citywide productivity gains. That is a proposition that ought to he scrutinized with skepticism by the Emergency Financial Control Board even though it may appear to conform with guidelines laid down in the transit settlement.

title: Cornell Offers Russian, In a Labor Camp, a Post
description: ITHACA, N.Y., June 20 (UPI), Cornell University has disclosed that it has offered a dissidentSoviet Biologist, currently serving a sevenyear sentence at a corrective labor colony in the Soviet Union an appointment as a visiting scholar.

title: Judith Silver Wed To David Barrett
description: The marriage of Judith Silver to David Barrett took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. George A. Silver, in New Haven. Rabbi Edward Klein of the Stephen W?? Free Synagogue performed the ceremony.

title: LATINS PLANNING MULTINATIONALS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 20The Latin American Economic System, an organization made up of 25 nations from Central and South America and the Caribbean, has approved plans for the eventual establishment of Latinowned multinational companies.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Francis Wins L.I. Amateur
description: OCEANSIDE. L.I. June 20 A few minutes after Gene Francis won the Long Island amateur golf championship for the fourth time today, the stocky 38  year  old player said, I haven't played better than this since I was in colIege. Come to think of it. I don't think I ever hit the ball better than I am hitting it now.

title: BANKS PREPARED TO PRESS FOR END TO USURY CEILING
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.The New York State Banking Department and the banking industry are planning to press for legislation that would abolish the present 8 percent interestrate ceiling on mortgages and certain other loans.

title: 14th St. Market Owner Wounded by Gunmen
description: When 63yearold Benjamin Moskowitz flicked on the light switch as he started to open the Universal Meat Market on 14th Street, just west of Ninth Avenue, at about 7 A.M. yesterday, a man with a gun stood just in front of him.

title: Lou Klein, 57, Former Coach And Scout for Chicago Cubs
description: CHICAGO, June 20 (UPI)Lou Klein, a longtime member of the Chicago Cubs' baseball organization, died today at East Jefferson Hospital in Metarie, La., after suffering a stroke last week. He was 57 years old.

title: Robert W. Watt Dies at 83; Headed Seaboard Surety
description: Robert W. Watt, the former chairman and president of Seaboard Surety Company, died Saturday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 20 Cromwell Drive in Morristown.

title: 2,800YearOld Fortress Is Discovered in Sinai
description: KUNTILLET AJRUD, IsraeliOccupied Sinai  On this lonely, isolated hill overlooking a vast and empty desert plain, an Israeli archeological team has discovered an ancient Judean fortress containing a rare collection of Hebrew and Phoenician inscriptions dating to about 800 B.C.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bus drivers and mechanics in Hartford unanimously authorized a strike against staterun commuter lines. Drivers and mechanics in New Haven held similar votes, but union officials there refused to disclose the results until the balloting was completed by drivers in Stamford. about 85,000 persons a day ride buses in the three cities.

title: Anthony Re Marries Arlene Unneland
description: Arlene Unneland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Audun Unneland of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday yesterday evening, to Anthony John Re, son of Judge Edward D. Re of the United States Customs Court, and Mrs. Re of Neponsit, Queens.

title: New York State's A .F .L .C.I.O. Fights TrustFund Reallocation
description: The head of the state A.F.L.C.I.O. yesterday called upon Governor Carey and the Legislature to repeal a bill passed June 10 that allocates to the state $75 million in trust funds for disabled workers and the survivors of those killed at work.

description: GENERAL

title: Americana '76 Bazaar Delights One Million Visitors
description: They picked through, antique jewelry, peered through old binoculars and posed for pictures in Revolutionary War garb  all while feasting on such New York specialties as knishes, calznnes, egg rolls and quiche Lorraine.

title: 2 Killed in Korean Clash
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 20 (AP)A South Korean soldier and a North Korean infiltrator were killed in a gun battle last night just south of the demilitarized zone, military authorities announced here today. They said the clash started after the North Korean was spotted in a mountain hideout and refused repeated calls to surrender.

title: Viking 1 Continues Orbit of Mars; Path Closer to Planet Is Planned
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 20 (AP)Hhe Viking 1 spacecraft continued on its first wide sweep around Mars today as lits controllers on earth devised a lower orbit, suitable for studlying the Martian valley picked out for a July 4 landing.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JUNE CHILLS HenriGorges Clouzot, the French director, has been called the greatest French specialist in thrillers and compared to Alfred Hitchcock for his ability to combine violence and neurotic tension with technical expertise. Today and next Monday the Carnegie Hall Cinema (7572131) is reviving four major Clouzot features.

title: No Visitors
description: Photographs of Mao Tsetung, taken this past year, have clearly shown the ravages of age and debility. The fact mat the Peking regime allowed these pictures to be published was implicit evidence that Mao's associates wanted to prepare the worldand the Chinese peoplefor the Chairman's passing. Now Peking has taken a further step by announcing that Mao will meet no more foreign visitors.

title: Royals Scare Indians but Lose, 118
description: Coasting along with a 90 lead over the Kansas City Royals after the first three innings, the Indians seemed headed for an easy triumph yesterday in Cleveland.

title: GREENSPAN SCORES EMPLOYMENT BILL; Simon Joins Him in Deriding HumphreyHawkins Plan
description: WASHINGTON. June 20Alan Greenspan, President Ford's chief economic adviser, said today that the HumphreyHawkins bill, rather than leading to full employment, would make full employment impossible because it would create an extraordinary large amount of inflation.

title: Lady Mirka Wins After 2 Jumpoffs
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 20Lady Mirka, who never had been outside of Mexico until a week ago, astonished her rivals and her rider by winning the $10,000added Grand Prix today at the closing session of the fiveday Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

description: Details of a series of events that erroneously made it appear that 440 pounds of uranium 235 were missing from the pipeline feeding uranium to the French atomic bomb project have recently become known through a series of interviews with French physicists.

description: People get stuck in patternmaking techniques, Scott Barrie observed. They don't try anything new.

title: U.S. Military Units Quietly Shut Last 2 Major Bases in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 20 (AP)The United States military quietly closed its last two major installations in Thailand today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS REGAIN STABILITY IN MONEY DECLINE; Drop in Commercial Loans Seen as Steadying Factor on Fed Interest Rates
description: The credit markets, after floundering in midweek, regained their sense of direction last Thursday afternoon after the Federal Reserve reported a decline in the nation's basic money supply and a drop in New York City bank commercial loans. The money supply surprised the bond market because analysts had expected an increase, and the loan decline was impressive because it was the first decrease over a June 15 tax payment in at least 18 years.

title: ISRAEL CUTS BUDGET FOR DEFENSE BY 1.6%
description: JERUSALEM, June 20 (AP) The Israeli Government cut its defense budget by 1.6 percant today, overriding opposition from Defense Minister Shimon Peres, who warned that the reduction would harm Israel's security.

title: Balloonist Taking Off Soon

Mr. Thomas has been waiting for the sky to clear since last Wednesday, when he was originally scheduled to launch his craft.

Brown Jr. of California has bought a halfhour of television network time next Friday night to put a personal postscript on his 1976 Presidential campaign. The taped and edited discourse, for which the 38yearold Gover nor is paying NBC $80,188, will be part sermon, part celebration, part thankyou but mainly seeyoulater according to the men around him. title: Goldin's New Op Sail Assertions On Profit to City Are Disputed
description: One Operation Sail concessionaire has agreed to cut back a special high parking rate and another will be asked to share some of its income with New York City. Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: San Juan Fiesta Draws Crowd to Central Park
description: Plump pieces of banana fresh from a boiling vat of oil and ice shaved from a block to make a tasty snowcone were a few of the treats offered at the 24th annual San Juan Fiesta. Thousands jammed the area near the Central Park Bandshell at 72d Street to join In honoring San Juan de Bautista, the patron saint of Puerto Rico.

title: Diversity in Politics A Baptist Trademark
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 18 A group of Southern Baptists here for their church's annual meeting were talking elatedly the other day around a luncheon table about possibly being able to invite a President Jimmy Carter to speak to next year's gathering.

title: Fifth Marine Takes Belmont Race
description: A young throughbred, making his fourth appearance in a month, and an old one, competing for the first time in almost a year, entertained a family crowd of 26,292 with impressive victories yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ... Alternative Remedies
description: The other means of putting greater pressure on OPEC would be to increase United States conservation of oil products; breaking up the big oil companies would be an irrelevant or counterproductive solution to that problem. A Congress that has been unwilling either to tax fuel more heavily or let higher prices cut hack demand will find no deus ex machina in the splitting up of the big oil companies. If divestiture should have the effect of chopping down United States profits and investment, the impact on domestic supplies would be negative. Oil imports into the United States have risen above 6 million barrels a day and now approach 40 percent of our daily oil consumption. That trend should be reversed.

title: New York City Schools Weather Fiscal Crisis; But a Study Notes That Impact Was Felt By Entire System in the Academic Year
description: The New York City school system is limping to the end of an academic year of great trauma, battered by the city's financial crisis but showing a resiliency and a strength on the part of the staff that has enabled it to make the best of a bad situation.

title: Retailers Are Pushing Early Summer Clearance Sales
description: A disappointing sales tempo in May and sluggish business in the early weeks of June have led to an early start on summer clearance sales at most New York stores.

title: Calm and Very Happy, Caril Fugate Is Freed
description: YORK, Neb., June 20 (UPI)  After spending 18 of her 32 years in prison for a firstdegree murder conviction, Caril Ann Fugate finally gained her freedom today.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS MEET IN GERMANY; A Rousing U.S.Style Rally Winds Up an Uneventful Party Convention
description: DORTMUND, West Germany, June 20The governing Social Democratic Party opened its campaign for the national elections Oct. 3 with a twoday convention this weekend, winding up with a rousing rally last night.

title: PAIN SUPPRESSOR IS FOUND IN BLOOD
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A natural substance has been found in human blood that seems to have profound and longlasting painrelieving qualities.

title: Fishermen Compete in Shark Hunt Off L.I.

title: The Screen: Roman Polanski's 'The Tenant' Arrives
description: Trelkovsky (Roman Polanski) is a French citizen and he has a carte d'identit to prove it, but he has a foreign accent that puts off Parisian bartenders, concierges, policemen and landlords. Small boned and shortphysically vulnerable  Trelkovsky seems to be aware of having put off people all his life. Thus he goes to great lengths to avoid giving offense. He dresses with carea too-bright necktie might attract the attention of a small talkative child or of a friendly drunk. He answers the unaccountable rudeness of strangers with infinite patience.Trelkovsky exists. He inhabits his own body, but it's as if he had no lease on it, as if at any moment he could be dispossessed for having listened to the radio in his head after 10 P.M. People are always knocking on his walls.Trelkovsky, the hero of Mr. Polanski's striking new horror film, "The Tenant," is a character who might have been invented by an Edgar Allan Poe who'd had the opportunity to read about Raskolnikov and Josef K. He's a particularly Eastern European kind of late 19th-century outsider set down in contemporary Paris. He is alsoby the end of the moviesomething of a joke, but an entirely intentional one."The Tenant," which opened yesterday at Loews Tower East, is the most successful and most consistently authentic Polanski film in years, and in saying that I realize that a lot of people prefer the Polanski who turns out films more or less tailored to popular tastes, like "Chinatown" and "Rosemary's Baby.""The Tenant" displays the clear-eyed narative discipline of his early "Knife in the Water" and "Repulsion," but without the self-indulgent gimmickry that have made a lot of his later "personal" films, including "The Fearless Vampire Killers" and "What?", almost impossible to sit through even when the idiosyncratic talent behind them was visible."The Tenant," adapted by Gerard Brach and Mr. Polanski from a novel by Roland Topor, tells the story of the strange series of occupations that take place when Trelkovsky, a filing clerk in what appears to be a library, moves into a two-room Paris apartment made vacant by the attempted suicide of the previous tenant.The previous tenant, a young woman not yet dead, was unknown to Trelkovsky, but he makes it a point to visit her in the hospital. He is fascinated by what he sees, a body swathed in bandages, one leg in a cast, only one blackened eye and the mouth visible. He has thoughtfully brought her some oranges to suck.During this visit he also meets one of the young woman's friends, an apparently sweet but enigmatic girl named Stella (Isabelle Adjani). Leaving the hospital together, they have a drink in a bar and go to a movie where, as best as one can in a theater balcony, they make love, then part.Little by little Trelkovsky becomes convinced that the other tenants in the building have somehow been responsible for the earlier tenant's suicide attempt. The concierge (Shelley Winters) either ignores him or insults him. The landlord (Melvyn Douglas) monitors his arrivals and departures. The tenants spy on him. One night a mysterious woman (Lila Kedrova) appears at his door with her crippled daughter to report that there's a conspiracy afoot to have her kicked out of the building.Little by little, too, the other tenants force Trelkovsky, against his will, to assume the identity of the now-dead earlier tenant. One morning he wakes up in full drag, missing the tooth that the dead girl was missing. At a party Trelkovsky says to a friend with a good deal of understatement, "These days relationships with neighbors can get very complicated."Movies about madness tend to lose me after a certain point. The tension vanishes when one realizes that any absurdity, any trick, is available to the film maker. The director and his audience must share a set of rules for what passes for ordinary behavior if suspense is to be maintained. These rules do not exist in "The Tenant."That "The Tenant" works so well is because it's not strictly about madness, though that is its narrative form. It's about emotional isolation that has become physical. The forces that occupy Trelkovsky's mind were invited in by him, the outsider.The film is superbly acted by Mr. Polanski, Mr. Douglas and Miss Winters, who might not be entirely convincing as a Parisian concierge in a realistic film, but who fits into this nightmare perfectly. The French actors, including Miss Adjani, sound as if their English dialogue had been dubbed by othersnot very intelligentlythe result being that the performances no longer seem to be strictly their own.Mr. Polanski also has a gifted collaborator in Sven Nykvist, the cinematographer whose camera plays the role of narrator, directing our attention to curious details, offering humble asides, as 19th-century authors once felt free to do without embarrassment or excuse.

title: Holding Up
description: DULUTH, Ga., June 20Up on the TV screen in the Atlanta Athletic Club today, 22yearold Jerry Pate appeared as cool as his Alabama red shirt and pink plaid slacks. His own round completed, Jack Nicklaus was watching the final holes of the United States Open golf championship. Jerry Pate would hit a 5iron shot 190 yards over the lake on the 18th hole to within two feet of the cup for a birdie 3 that would win the tournament after John Mahaffey. desperate for a birdie there, had splashed a wood shot into the water. But now, as Jack Nicklaus was watching. Jerry Pate hadn't vet overtaken taken John Mahaffey, the leader. But the blond former United States Amateu chumpion was displaying the poise that many young touring pros find as elusive as a putting touch.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today

description: ASSOCIATION ISLAND, N. Y., June 20Reflecting the broadbased strength of American yachting, skippers from Texas, New York, California, Florida, New Jersey and Hawaii qualified today for next month's Olympic sailing competition.

title: Music
description: The Caramoor Festival got under way Saturday night, slightly dampened by a persistent misty rain that drizzled throughout the concert. Most of the audience gamely took shelter under the awnings that line the sides of the Venetian Theater on the Walter and Lucie Rosen estate in Katonah. N. Y., where the festival has been held annually for 31 seasons.

description: REXBURG, Idaho, June 20 (UPI)  The first loan checks from the Small Business Administration have been given to 11 victims of the Teton Dam disaster in Rexburg and Blackfoot. The agency had given out a total of 2,049 loan applications by last Thursday.

This has become the routine background music to the larger themes.

title: How Life Imitates A Stoppard Farce
description: LONDON  The thing is about 90 percent romp and maybe 2 percent serious, the playwright was saying at lunch the other day. My director thinks he's got a profound comment on British society. What he really has is a knickers farce. Tom Stoppard, who shook up the theater world with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead and Travesties, used these and other selfeffacing words to describe his newest comedy, a delightful exploration of antic hay called Dirty Linen. The 90minute exercise, which opened last week at the Arts Theater, could not have appeared at a more fortuitous momentboth for him and his audiences.

However, the subsequent death of Premier Chou Enlai and the toppling of his initial successor, the then Vice Premier, Teng Hsiaoping, did not prevent New Delhi from improving relations with its northern neighbor.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Recently we carried an article that focused on challah but mentioned in passing, with a recipe, a pastry that we referred to as ruggalah. We received numerous letters from readers telling us that, while the pastry we printed delivered excellent results, it most certainly was not the pastry known as rugelach or rogalach. Almost every letter spelled the word differently.

title: Newport Jazz Festival Opens Season on Friday
description: The Newport Jazz Festival's fifth season in New York, which will begin on Friday, will be longer than previous Newport Festivals  11 days instead of the customary 10  and will reach into hitherto untouched areas, both geographic (New Jersey) and musical (a children's program, a musical play and a blend of jazz and flamenco dancing).

description: ROME, June 20Millions of Italians voted today in a crucial election that could give the Communist Party a share of power in this Atlantic alliance nation.

description: A Shetland sheepdog made history at historic Fort Wadsworth yesterday when he Marched across the parade grounds and took best in show at the 36th annual show of the Staten Island Kennel Club. The Sheltie was Ch. Chenterra Thunderation, a tricolor owned by Thomas Coen and Steve Barger of Samonsvile, N.Y.

title: Donald E. Hagaman, Head Of FundRaising Consultant
description: Donald E. Hagaman, president of Tamblyn & Brown Atlantic Inc., a fundraising and public relations counseling concern with headquarters in the Empire State Building, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 60 years old.

title: ARABS EXPEDITING FORCE TO LEBANON
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 20 Mahmoud Riad, the Arab League's secretary general, said today that he expected the first contingent of an Arab peacekeeping force to enter Lebanon by land and air this week.

title: McTear 2d Runner Hurt, Gains Berth
description: EUGENE. Ore., June 20America's sprint fortunes, which went down yesterday with a thigh injury to Steve Williams, went up and down today in the same race at the United States Olympic trials. Within seconds, Houston McTear made the Olympic team and suffered a pulled hamstring muscle.

title: 2 Collisions Mar Tall Ships Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20A collision between two of the largest sailing ships in the world maned the spectacular start of the Tall Ships race to Newport, R. L. today. In the accident, one mile off the east end of Bermuda, Juan Sebastian de Elcano lost 60 feet off the top of her 180foot foremast and had to withdraw. She is the Spanish naval training vessel and, at 370 feet in length and 2,400 tons, the second largest of the 18 giant ships in the Class A Division.

title: Commodities
description: Commodity speculators have long scoffed at investors as being merely gamblers laboring under the illusion of permanency. Now however, it is the commodity speculators who are behaving like investors, believing that the recent rise in futures prices is a permanent condition.

title: Books of The Times
description: At the 1947 convention of the United Automobile Workers in Atlantic City, Walter P. Reuther overwhelmed his opposition and consolidated his position as head of the big union. description: The New York City school system is limping to the end of an academic year of great trauma, battered by the city's financial crisis but showing a resiliency and a strength on the part of the staff that has enabled it to make the best of a bad situation.
