description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 20Five executives of staterun banks have been dismissed and 10 others demoted or disciplined as a result of an investigation into loan irregularities by a special Government board of inquiry.

title: Bicentennial Opens Up New Interest in Time Capsules
description: SEWARD, Neb.When the late Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect and critic, pondered what would remain of 20th century civilization in the event of a nuclear holocaust, he concluded that the identifiable artifact most likely to be excavated in largest numbers from our ruins would be the vitreous China toilet bowl.

title: What to Call a Lawyer
description: COLUMBUS, OhioThe word may not have reached Cambridge, Mass., yet, but there can be no doubt that lawyers are on the way out. The evidence is irrefutable.

title: Democratic Panel Refuses Equality Pledge to Women
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Democratic Rules Committee refused today to guarantee women an equal share of the seats at the party's national conventions starting in 1980, provoking what may be the only controversy to reach the floor of next month's convention in New York City.

title: FORD BELIEVED SEA WAS SAFEST ROUTE; Overland Convoy to Syria Rejected as Too Risky
description: WASHINGTON, June 20President Ford relaxed today after completion of a naval operation he had ordered last evening to remove Americans and other foreign civilians from Lebanon.

title: New York City to Press Labor Pacts; Simon Stresses a Freeze on Wages
description: New York City officials, under heavy pressure from the United States Treasury Department, will make a major effort in the next few days to work out an agreement in principle with the municipal unions to insure peace on the labor front and Federal approval for further loans.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meatings for week follows:

title: Fire Island Beaches Are Closed Again As Sludge Returns
description: Beaches on Fire Island remained closed yesterday because globules of sewagelike material continued to wash ashore.

title: Susan A. Koppel, Nurse, Is Married
description: Suan Alyce Koppel, a registered nurse on the staff of Doctors Hospital, was married in Scarsdale. N.Y., yester day to Charles Andrew Meyer, executive vice president of CitiSport Inc., a recreation management company. Rabbi Bernard Schachtel performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cohen, uncle and aunt of the bride.

title: Insurers Cite Risks in Flu Vaccine Plan
description: Insurance executives, explaining why they have cut back sharply in coverage they would give pharmaceutical companies against swine flu vaccine liability suits, are contending that a crash inoculation program planned by the Government presents far too many risks.

title: Defective Machines Delay Uzbekistan Grain Harvest
description: MOSCOW. June 20 (Reuters) Mechanical trouble with combine harvesters is hampering this year's first grain harvest in the Soviet Union, Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, said today.

title: The Wild Trial
description: WASHINGTONIn the interval between the Democratic and Republican Conventions, a political time bomb is set to explode: the trial of Gulf Oil lobbyist Claude C. Wild Jr. on charges of felonious campaign contributions brought by the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Sarah Duncan Wed At Suburban Home
description: Sarah L. Duncan and Peter Finn, who graduated from Brown University on June 7, were married at noon yesterday. Rabbis Seymour Fox and Ezra Finkelstein officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Finn. parents of the bridegroom, in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Intercosmos 15 in Orbit
description: MOSCOW, June 20 (Reuters) The Soviet Union announced today the successful launching of the 15th automatic satellite in Eastern Europe's Intercosmos program of joint space research. The Tass press agency said Intercosmos 15 was launched yesterday and was orbiting the earthearth every 94.6 minutes.

title: 4 POLITICIANS SEIZED BY JAMAICAN FORCES
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 20 (Reuters)Three members of the opposition Jamaica Labor Party and one from the ruling People's National Party have been taken into custody by security forces, the first persons to he detained under the present state of emergency here.

title: Deaths
description: AHERNDaniel P., of Hillside, it.J. on June 19, 1976, husband of Inge B., brother of most Rev. Patrick V. Ahern, Auxiliary Bishop of N.Y. Funeral from the Halsey Funeral Home, 199 Center Ave., Westwood, N.J., Tuesday at 9 A.M. Funeral mass at St. John the Baptist LC. Church, Hillsdale, at 10 A.M. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visiting hours Sunday 7 to 9 P.M. and Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M.

title: Wrong Way on Oil ...
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has sent to the floor of the Senate a bill that would break up the 18 biggest oil companies. A company would have to decide whether to produce crude oil, transport it, or refine and market petroleum products. It no longer could perform all three functions.

title: BOX Scores and Standing
description: ERose. DPCincinnati 1, Philadelphia 1. LOBCincinati 2, Philadelphia 14. 2BG.Maddox 2, Armerister, Rose, Conception, Schmidt. SFO.Brown.

title: Tennis Players Urged to Use Eye Shield
description: When a 38yearold doctor ??ushed the net to return his opponent's shot, the tennis ball traveling at high speed struck him in the left eye. The ball scratched his cornea, the transparent part of the front of the eye that admits light. The ball also set off an inflammatory reaction and caused bleeding within the eyeball.

title: India Achieves the Impossible: It Has Food to Spare
description: NEW DELHI, June 20With an estimated output of 116 million tons of grain this year, India has achieved what had been considered impossible.

title: Personal Finance
description: The New York Stock Exchange fined a trading floor specialist $18,000 the other day for violating its regulations. The violation dealt with a littleknown transaction called a sellstop order, which presents problems for the small investor.

title: Final Captured By Miss Evert
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 20Chris Evert found the touch on an errant backhand and defeated Virginia Wade of England, 86, 63, today to take the Colgate women's invitation tournament and the $6,000 that went with it on the eve of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: REPORTERS' GROUP PLANS DATA CENTER
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 20 Investigative Reporters and Editors, a new journalism organization, ended a threeday conference today with an agreement to establish a national service center at Ohio State University next year.

title: Disney Water Rides Open
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., June 20 (UPI)  President Ford's daughter Susan plummeted down a 260foot water flume today to open River Country, a new attraction at Walt Disney World. River Country covers five acres and features water slides, flumes, swings and raft rides.

title: O'Reilly Leaves W.R.G. to Consult
description: Richard T. O'Reilly, a wellknown and respected adman and vice chairman and director of Wells, Rich. Greene, is getting out of the agency business and into the consulting business. W. R. G. is his first client.

title: Arizona Nine Wins Title, 71
description: OMAHA. June 20 (UPI)Arizona's baseball team defeated Eastern Michigan, 71, last night to win the College world series championship. It was the first National Collegiate sports title in the school's history.

title: Advertising
description: Although it is one of the more popular words in advertising circles, upscale isn't in the dictionary. It is used to describe people and households with well above average income and education, a group loved by a goodly number of advertisers.

title: The Last Republican
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The prolonged competition between President Ford and former Governor Reagan has the quality of a death struggle.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WNCNIFM. Concerto for Two Violins, Harpsichord and Strings, Vivaldi; Jota Aragonesa, Glinka; Oboe Concerto, Albinoni; Overture to La Forza de Destino, Verdi; Concerto Grosso in D Minor, Handel; Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring, Bach; Credo in un dio crudel from Otello, Verdi; Danse des Pretresses de Gagon; Bacchanals, from Samson and Dalila, SaintSaens; Greensleaves, Anon; Dance for Harpsichord, Delius; Polka from the Age of Gold, Shostakovich:

title: Miss Weiss Bride Of Steven Schram
description: Suzanne Weiss and Steven H. Schram, 1975 graduates of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday evening at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman, who was assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich.

title: Yankees Win, 63, for Sixth Straight; Angry Matlack Beaten by Giants, 92
description: CHICAGO, June 20The Yankees, a better road team than the Harlem Globetrotters, wrapped up a perfect tour of the midwest today, defeating the Chicago White Sox, 6.3.

title: Gelsey Kirkland, Seen as Aurora, Is Emerging as a Great Ballerina
description: There is a very special pleasure in watching the gradual growth and slow emergence of a great ballerina. Gelsey Kirkland, with her precise technique, innate musicality and waiflike presence, has been almost chosen for stardom from the beginning. First with the School of American Ballet, then with New York City Ballet and now with American Ballet Theater, her career has blossomed, with only an occasional injury to set her back.

title: HOUSE UNIT RELEASES MY LAI TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON. June 20 (AP)Previously secret testimony on the My Lai massacre released today by the House Armed Services Committee shows a contradiction among witnesses over whether the atrocity was reported to a United States Army division headquarters.

title: Talbert Keeps a Hand in Tennis By Helping Junior League Drive
description: Billy Talbert was in a wry mood the other day, saying. I got involved in this when I found I had a little spare time this summer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and members of the Police Department's major case squad who staked out a branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Bank at 210 Flushing Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn rounded up three armed men apparently planning a robbery. The police, it was learned, had been tipped off by a fourth man, Eugene Welcome, 28 years old, who had been arraigned on Friday and ordered held in $250,000 bail in connection with the armed robbery on March 1 of a branch of the Chemical Bank at 395 Flatbush Avenue, in which he got more than $50,000. Arraigned yesterday in Federal District Court were Robert Jackson, 26; William Scott, 25, and Martin Allen, 26. Two of the threeMr. Jackson and Mr. Allenwere in a latemodel battered rustcolored Lincoln, in which the authorities said they found two sawedoff shotguns, a toy pistol, handcuffs and masks. Magistrate Vincent A. Catoggio ordered each of the three held $100,000 bail.

title: Pay TV: Gone With the Wind and Bette Midler
description: Commercial television intensely dislikes the concept of pay television, a system in which a cable subscriber pays an extra fee for special programming such as new or classic movies (uninterrupted and unedited), sports events or newly commissioned and uncensored shows featuring material not likely to get past the barriers of traditional standards and practices departments. The payTV market is still relatively tiny. Home Box Office, for example, claims 450,000 to 500,000 subscribers nationally, with 200,000 in the New York metropolitan area.

title: White House Extends Hours
description: WASHINGTON, June 21. (UPI)  President and Mrs. Ford have extended White. House visiting hours over the Fourth of July weekend. The White House will be open to the public from 10 A.M. until 5 P.M. on Saturday, July 3. ?? is normally open until 1 P.M. on Saturdays. It will also he open to visitors on Monday, July 5. Monday is traditionally housecleaning day and the White House is closed to tourists.

title: Hay Barn Fire Fells 95
description: KINSMAN. Ohio, June 21 (UPI)Ninetyfive firemen and volunteers were treated for inhalation of toxic gas yesterday during a fire at a hay storage barn that produced a gas when the burning hay, which had been treated with a chemical preservative, was doused with water.

title: HARRISES JUDGE WON'T STEP DOWN
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21The defense in the trial of William and Emily Harris charged today at the opening of the case that security measures ordered by Superior Court Judge Mark Brandler indicated he was afraid for his safety and thus would not preside fairly over the trial of the two selfstyled revolutionaries.

title: Federal Judge Chosen For Hearst Sentence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (AP)William H. Orrick Jr. was selected today as the Federal judge who will pass final sentence on Patricia Hearst.

title: Peace Force in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21About 1,000 Syrian and Libyan troops, described as the vanguard of an Arab League peacekeeping force, arrived overland from Damascus today and took up positions around Beirut's airport as a new ceasefire went into effect.

title: EDWARD G. GARDNER
description: Edward G. Gardner, a vice president in the personal incurance department of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died on Sunday of a heart attack. He was 60 years old. Mr. Gardner, who lived in Neptune, N.J., is survived by his wife, the former Margaret. Kunty, and three sons, Edward H., Allan J. and Bruce D. Gardner.

title: WEST POINT STUDY OF TESTING BEGUN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Lieut. Gen. Sidney Berry, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, disclosed today that West Point was examining the validity of all its academic procedures in the wake of a major cheating scandal.

title: De Laurentiis Dismisses Altman From Ragtime
description: Robert Altman, one of Hollywood's top  flight directors, whose credits includeM*A*S*H, Nashville and Buffalo Bill and the Indians, which is scheduled to open in New York on Thursday, has been dismissed as the director of Ragtime, the movie to be based on E. L. Doctorow's novel.

title: City Marathon, Oct. 24, Will Span 5 Boroughs
description: In its sixyear history, the New York City Marathon has never ventured outside Central Park, preferring to remain a Manhattan event with a metropolitan name. But this year, the 26mile385yard marathon course will wind through all five boroughs, making it a spectacle for the entire city, a happening that, according to Manhattan Borough President Percy Sutton, will draw together and unite common purpose many of the different neighborhoods and communities that make up the York.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 22, 1976

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Consolidated Gas Supply Corporation and the Dravo Corporation, both of Pittsburgh, yesterday proposed to build a coal gasification demonstration plant in northeastern Ohio at a cost of 5100 million. The plan would be part of an effort by the Federal Energy Research and Development Administration to prove the feasibilty of converting coal into gas for industrial.

title: FinleyKuhn Case In Search of Court
description: Neil Papiano, the Los Angeles attorney who is handling Charley Finley's projected $10 million damage suit against Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, spent most of yesterday deciding which court would be the best forum for the case. The possibilities included a state court in Oakland or federal courts in San Francisco, Chicago (where Finley lives) or New York (where the commissioner's office is). Papiano said he expected the action to be filed today or tomorrow.

title: Brian Taylor Suit Dismissed by Jury
description: NEWARK, June 21 (AP)A Federal jury threw out today a $1 million damage suit filed by Brian Taylor, the New York Nets basketball star, against the Penn Central Railroad and Newark Police Department.

title: Girl, 15, Killed in Crash
description: LUMBERTON. N.J., June 21 (AP)A Willingboro teenager was killed today when the car in which she was riding hit a utility pole on Fostertown Road and burst into flames, the police said. She was identified as Linda Geiger, 15 years old. The driver, David Bruno, 19, of Willingboro, suffered a fractured leg.

title: HOSPITAL LAYOFFS REMAIN AT ISSUE
description: Mayor Beame and the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday accepted the recommendations of a factfinding panel to reduce the number of municipal hospital workers to be laid off in the current fiscal crisis.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Hundreds of Hudson County employees walked out for an hour and a half, returning to work after both sides agreed to resume negotiating a new contract.

title: Damaged Ships Out of Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21 (AP)Two vessels damaged in collisions at the start of the tall ships race to Newport will not rejoin the fleet, a race spokesman said today.

title: Turkish Cypriots' Leader Wins a Presidential Race
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 21 (AP)Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, won a landslide victory in yesterday's Presidential election in the selfproclaimed Turkish Federated State of Cyprus.

title: Radio
description: 7:308:55 A.M., WNYCFM. La Belle Helene Overture, Offenbach; Oboe Concerto, Leclair; Waltzes No. 1 and 4. Dvorak; Piano Concerto No. 4, Mozart; Quartet for Violin, Flute, Cello and Continuo, Telemann; Ballet Music from Otello, Verdi.

title: City U. Tuition Decision Courageous, Javits Says
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday called the establishment of tuition for the City University a courageous act by New York City and the state government and he said that his colleagues in Congress had been favorably impressed by it.

title: Board Reaffirms San Francisco Workers' Pay Cuts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21Pay cuts of up to 25 percent for 1,800 bluecollar city workers effective July 1 were reaffirmed today by the city's Board of Supervisors.

title: Three Arrested in Slaying
description: NIAGARA FALLS, June 21 (AP)Three men were arrested early today and charged with murder In he shooting of a taxi driver Andrew Coffie 59 years old, whose body was found outside his apartment Saturday. The three were identified as Willie D. Johnson, 27; Sylvester; Scott, 27, and Samuel Haslip. 20, all of Niagara Falls. Police Lieut. John Zaccarella said that Mr. Coffie was believed to have won money gambling and that somebody tried to take it from him.

title: Lineup Is Drawn at Pocono; Miss Guthrie Gains 22d Berth
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 21 A second straight day of rain washed out today's time trials for the Schaefer 500 at Pocono International Raceway and sparked a controvery among the entrants for the June 27 auto race.

title: Jazzmobile Slated To Open on July 1
description: Jazzmobile, New York's summer jazz series on wheels, will begin its 12th year on July 1, with a concert at City Hall at 12:30 P.M. The opening bill features Clark Terry and his Big Bad band. The Jazzmobile takes groups of jazz musicians to perform in streets, parks, playgrounds and housing projects in the metropolitan area.

title: Clergyman Criticizes ReligionTied TV Ads
description: The cute Xerox commercial about the monk whose productivity on a copier is deemed miraculous by his superior might have been judged best in show at last week's Andy Awards, but it got no votes from the friars at Gravmoor Monastery.

title: HOUSEVOTES 8% RISE IN AID FOR VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)  The House of Representatives voted today to give 2.5 million American war veterans, survivors and dependents an 8 percent increase in disability compensations and pensions.

title: State Farm Action Today Key to Rescue of GEICO
description: A decision this afternoon by the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company may determine the future of the financially shattered Government Employees Insurance Company.

title: MAY ORDERS ROSE 1.4% IN DURABLES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21New orders for durable goods rose strongly in May, and the rate of capacity utilization in manufacturing increased significantly in the first quarter, separate Commerce Department reports disclosed today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Iran to Pay $125 Million For Occidental Oil Stake
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 21Iran intends to purchase a $125 million share in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation as part of a joint deal to develop Caspian Sea oil, the Government announced today.

title: Money and Drugs
description: As the precariously balanced state budget is already threatened with numerous unforeseen strains, the Governor and lawmakers must exercise unaccustomed discipline in dividing up the $20 million that is available for supplemental. One claimant for supplemental funds which we believe merits special consideration is the therapeutic drug program in New York City.

title: Wimbledon Tennis Results
description: Tom Okker, Netherlands, defeated Sandy Maver, Mendharn, N.J., 63, 67, 64; John Newcombe, Australia, defeated Chico Hagev, La Jolla, Calif., 89, 98, 64, 61; Sashi Menon, India, defeated Roger Taylor, Britain, 57, 62, 98, 26, 102; Stephen Warbays, Britain, defeated John Marks, Autralia, 57, 75, 36, 64. 63; John Feaver, Britain, defeated Henry Bunis, Cincinnati, 61, 16, 62, 75; Steve Krulevitz, Baltimore, defeated Colin Dowdeswell, Rhodesia, 36, 63, 63, 66; Hernie Milton, South Africa, defeated Eric Devlicker, France, 75, 62, 16, 64; Teimuraz Kakulia, Soviet Union, seat Balazs Taroczy, Hungary, 61, 92, 62; Adriano Panetta, Italy, defeated Jorge Andrew, Venezuela, 46, 64, 75, 64.

title: Guild Ends Time Strike; Pact Is Like June 2 Offer
description: The strike by editorial and other employees against Time magazine and its sister publications ended yesterday, with the union settling for virtually the same contract that management offered when the employees walked out June 2.

title: Levitz Consents to Settle F.T.C. Sales Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission settled today a number of charges of false and misleading sales representations against the Levitz Furniture Corporation, one of the nation's largest furniture retailers.

title: A.C.L.U. Reverses Ouster Of Elizabeth Gurley Flynn
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has decided 12 years, after the death of Elizabeth Gurley Flynn that it was wrong in expelling her from its board of directors in 1940 and has repealed the expulsion.

title: SENATE THWARTS NEW BUDGET PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Advocates of strict adherence to the letter and spirit of the new Congressional budget procedures lost their fight in the Senate today to forces led by Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: VIOLENCE SHAKES GUATEMALA AGAIN
description: GUATEMALAFour months after an earthquake killed almost 23,000 Guatemalans and briefly united this embittered nation, an upsurge of violence is offering macabre evidence that politics here is back to normal.

title: Realty Executiveto Head Joint Jewish Fund Drive
description: Robert H. Arnow, a real estate man, has been appointed general chairman of the 1977 United Jewish AppealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign in behalf of Jews here and throughout the world.

title: Lichtenstein Chief Of Music Academy
description: Harvey Lichtenstein has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Inc., as part of a revision of the academy's corporate structure, it has been announced by Paul A. Lepercq, board chairman. The changes, designed to make the structure of the corporation reflect more closely the operational responsibility of its officers, also include the appointment of Judith Daykin as executive vice president and general manager; Sharon Rupert as vice president, and Charles Ziff as vice president for promotion.

title: ATenting We'll Go, Ever So Beautifully
description: The Eave Force XV looks like an insect cocoon. The Wing Tent resembles a mosquito poised for flight. Trillium could be the shell of nesting ants. All three are tents the creation of an artistturnedtentmaker, C. William Moss.

title: Progress Erodes Customs of Ancient Nigerian City
description: KANO, Nigeria  Though fewer in number and smaller in size, camel caravans still trek here from across the Sahara to a final watering hole inside the walled city. The drivers unload dates and salts and potash, spread them on a blanket and barter them for richly embroidered cloth.

title: SAHARA GROUP SAYS LEADER DIED IN RAID
description: ALGIERS, June 21 (Reuters) The Algerianbacked Sahara independence movement Polisario confirmed today the death of its secretary general, Sayed elWali, but left the circumstances of his death unclear.

title: Stamford's Mayor Urges Purchase of Glacial Rock
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 21The Mayor of Stamford wants the city to buy a rock that its owner has offered to sell for $45,000.

title: 60.8Cent Rise Expected In New York Realty Tax
description: The New York City Council is expected to approve a 60.8cent increase in real estate taxes today, bringing the rate to the highest in city history$8.795 for each $100 of assessed valuation.

title: WEST POINT STUDY OF TESTING BEGUN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Lieut. Gen. Sidney Berry, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, disclosed today that West Point was examining the validity of all its academic procedures in the wake of a major cheating scandal.

title: Haldeman Asserts He Thought Tapes Would Absolve Him
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 21 H. R. Haldeman, former chief of staff to President Nixon, says he cautioned on several occasions against destroying the White House tapes because he felt they could absolve the President and himself of any wrongdoing in the Watergate affair.

title: Bomb Explodes at Bank
description: A small bomb exploded at a branch of Citibank at 116th Street and First Avenue at 1:33 this morning, causing minor damage to the building, the police reported. There were no injuries. The police said they had not yet determined what type of explosive device was used, and that no one had yet claimed responsibility for the explosion.

title: Ervin Says A.F.L.C.I.O. Acted To Block Vote on Scenic River
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. accused the A.F.L.C.I.O. leadership today of forming an unholy alliance with the American Electric Power Company to prevent Congress from voting on a bill designating a 26.5mile stretch of the New River as part of the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Yields mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Afghan Leader to Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The State Department said today that Mohammed Naim, brother of President Mohammed Daud of Afghenistan, will visit the United States from June 29 to July 1 at the invitation of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Suspect Is Linked to Death of Reporter
description: PHOENIX, June 21  The business partner of John H. Adamson, who is accused of murdering Don Bolles, an investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic, testified at a hearing tonight that Mr. Adamson had urged him to join in a plot to blow up a car shortly before the attack on Mr. Bolles.

title: F.B.I. Investigated Hong Kong Woman Friend of Nixon in'60's to Determine if She Was Foreign Agent
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Federal Bureau of Investigation investigated a Hong Kong woman friend of Richard M. Nixon for two years in the late 1960's to determine whether she was a foreign intelligence agent.

title: Bridge:
description: Most experts are prepared to open the bidding in the third seat with one or two highcard points below their normal standards. But some caution is advisable when vulnerable.

title: 'Children of Paradise' Is Still Enchanting
description: In the 1950's it seemed wonderfully complex; strange, and with a most liberating poetical ambiguity to it. I, for example, have never talked quite straight ever since."Children of Paradise" was the quintessential Foreign Film. Europe wasn't that close then, anyway; no cheap air faresan occasional freighter was the nearest equivalentand young people didn't travel so much. They worked for master's degrees.And there, already into its career of perpetual revival, came "Children." It was a "Gone With the Wind" of cobwebs. Its epic romance, instead of sweeping over miles of landscape was squeezed, Europelike, into the framework of a stage, the landscape all inward.These days some people are discovering, others rediscovering Marcel Carn's masterpiece. It is going through still another revival, this time at the Paris Theater. It looks to be as perennial as the Perseids.Expected and UnexpectedIt is in fact, both as expected as seeing a star fall and as unexpected. There is the scene where Jean-Louis Barrault, as the mime Baptiste in his white Pierrot costume, tries to hang himself, and surrenders his rope successively to a child wanting it for a skip rope and a woman wanting it for a wash line.Now that is a famous scene, quoted and recounted endlessly. Like some of the "Magic Flute's" arias it has a life of its own; and still it is impossible to watch without the small hairs' trying to walk off the back of the neck.After a quarter-century or so, a revisit to "Children" is cheerful and encouraging. Some things have grown fusty and cramped in it, but in general the damage of time is like the gilt flaking off a picture frame. It dates the picture within, but doesn't harm it.Some scenesthe opening street carnival, the drinkers and dancers in a smoky cafeare cluttered and overcharged. There is a certain slow and mechanical contrivance in setting out some of the characters.Not Garance, though, the fatal woman played by Arletty. We meet her protruding from a barrel filled with dark liquid. She is indeed bathing naked, as the sideshow barker has promised, but all the customers get to see is her head and shoulders, comical and stately.It is part of the film's lovely alternation of humanity and fantasy. Arletty is comic and of a practical sensuality; she is also a haunting beauty; at the end, as her carriage melts into the crowd, she has acquired some of Baptiste's elusive transparency.Baptiste goes the other way. At the start, as the drooping Pierrot on the balustrade, he is pure air. His rival, Lacenaire, says that to kill him "would be like killing a ray of moonlight." Gradually, passion subjects him to the laws of gravity. At the end he runs futilely after Garance's carriage like any stumbling lover with a churning gut.Even the cheerful, earthbound Fredericanother rivalhas his moment of rebellious genius. And Lacenaire, the murderer, thinks of himself as a literary figure.The main characters are both clear and shimmering. They have their particular attributes, as in any normal movie, but they also contain the possibility of being their own opposites. Reality in this film is never a matter of "nothing but."It is this that makes any memory of "Children" so complex. Complexity of this kind could fall into pretentiousness and incoherence, but it doesn'tand for a very simple reason.Mimes at the Top"Children" is a perfectly classical and conventional story. Garance leaves her criminal protector to take up with Baptiste and work at his mime theater. His love at this point is tangled in fantasy and he loses her to Frederic, the talking actor. (A fascinating motif in the film is its theatrical hierarchy that places mimes at the top and speaking actors lower downand yet it is the mimes who are applauded by the workers in the cheap seats high up; the "paradise" of the title.)Garance, pressed by the police for her past associations, marries an aristocratic suitor for protection. Years pass, they all prosper, there is a brief reunion of Garance and Baptisteconsummated this timeand Garance leaves.There are side embellishments, of course, small mysteries and bits of fog. But they are scrollwork on a perfectly recognizable object. It is a big stagecoach of a movie  more than three hours along  that rumbles serviceably and creakily on a perfectly recognizable road.It is the passengers who are magic.

title: 2 Young Brothers Drown
description: MARLTON, N.J., June 21 (AP) Two young brothers drowned in a Burlington County lake yesterday, the authorities said. James Clause, 6 years old, and John Clause, 4, of Maple Shade, were pronounced dead at Garden State Community Hospital. They had accompanied their mother on a visit to relatives near the King's Grant section here, according to the authorities.

title: Tests Find Swine Flu Vaccines Satisfactory for Majority of Adults but Less Acceptable for Children
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The new vaccines against swinetype influenza appear satisfactory for the majority of adult Americans, according to data released today from nationwide studies.

title: Market Place
description: When the Chicago Board Options Exchange set up operations almost three years ago, there was concern in some circles that the advent of a listed option market would be the undoing of many individual investors.

title: Waller Rate Increasing
description: HARTFORD, June 21 (AP)The Public Utilities Control Authority has granted the Greenwich Wate Company $212,493 in rate increases, about onefourth of what the company requested. The company serves 13,900 metered customers in Greenwich and 9,900 in nearby Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 21Richard McGlynn, the newest member of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners, last week challenged the State Public Advocates office to give details of its complaints that the board had an inadequate system for handling consumer cornplaints.

title: Other U.S. and Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: Monday, June 21, 1976

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: Worst Drought Since 1921 Threatens All Sectors of the French Economy
description: PARIS, June 21  France is facing its worst drought since 1921 and it affects not only the agriculture industry but now threatens the economy at large, just as it was seen to be picking up again.

title: Last NursingSchool Class
description: HARTFORD, June 21 (AP)A class of 124 graduated yesterday at the last commencement exercise for the 99yearold diploma school program at Hartford Hospital's School for Nursing. In 1973 the hospital decided to close the school, which it had operated since 1877, in favor of communitybased collegiate nursing programs.

title: Chess:
description: The passed pawn is the stumbling block of the average player. If he follows the edict, Passed pawns must be pushed, he all too often finds the pawn surrounded by a mass of enemy pieces and gobbled up. Wiser and more cautious the next time, he may give up the idea of obtaining a new queen and leave the pawn at home, only to discover that there is then no advantage in having it.

title: U.S. Loses in Attempt to Delay Angola Application to Join U.N
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21The Ford Administration today lost an intensive behindthescenes drive for postponement of Angola's application for membership in the United Nations until after the Republican National Convention in August.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: On Ship From Beirut, Sailors BabySit
description: ABOARD U.S.S. SPIEGEL GROVE, in the Mediterranean, June 21 (AP)Sailors became baby sitters, fetched powdered baby formula and throwaway diapers from the storeroom and gave up their own bunks to accommodate the evacuees from wartorn Lebanon.

title: Electronic Editing at Paper
description: OLATHE, Kan., June 21 (UPI)The Olathe Daily News announced today it will install an electronic editing system Aug. 1, which will be linked with United Press International computers in New York. Richand Buzbee, publisher of the morning newspaper of 8,000 circulation, said he had signed an agreement with the Newspaper Electronics Corporation of Kansas City to supply its newspaper editing wire system.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN NAME AMBASSADORS
description: NEW DELHI, June 21India and Pakistan named ambassadors to each other today as a preliminary to the reopening of their embassies after nearly five years.

title: VIKING 1 SWITCHES TO A LOWER ORBIT
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 21 (UPI)Viking 1 switched to a lower orbital track around Mars today so its two telescopic cameras can inspect the July 4 landing area at the same time every afternoon.

title: Jersey Assembly Rejects Senate's Income Tax Bill
description: TRENTON. June 21With 10 days remaining before a courtordered closing of the state's public schools unless they are constitutionally financed. the Assembly rejected today by 77 to 2 a Senatepassed version of a state income tax.

title: Big Board Short Interest Off in Month
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended June 15 fell 1,309,640 shares to 23,527,818 shares, it was reported yesterday.

title: Jones Beach Park Closed to Bathers
description: Jones Beach State Park was closed for swimming yesterday because of the debris that has closed other beaches on Long Island in the past week.

title: Congress, Sex and The Press
description: A great deal of cant, hypocrisy and sensationalism is being heard about the socalled Washington sex scandal, and the principal victim so far is the unfortunate Representative Allan T. Howe of Utah.

title: Republican Platform Unit Opens 2 Days of Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Republican Platform Committee is sitting on a political time bomb, but the committee's chairman, Gov, Robert D. Ray of Iowa, hopes it may never go off.

title: New Zealand Architect Flouts Rules
description: When the International Architectural Foundation, a New Yorkbased organization formed by Architectural Record magazine, announced a competition two years ago for the design of a prototype project for slum housing in underdeveloped countries, it looked like the sort of thing that might attract a few major architectural firms and a few designers who were pushing technology and other panaceas.

title: Pension Reform
description: Foremost among these unattended problems is a disparate collection of state and local pension systems which lavish on public employees retirement benefits substantially in excess of those enjoyed by workers in most other states and municipalities or in private industry. To support these excessive benefits at levels that are perilously below sound actuarial standards, New York taxpayers are assessed $3.5 billion each year$1 billion more than the cost of operating all state agencies.

title: Deaths
description: ADAM Clarence S., beloved husband of Lil?? devoted ?? of Jules ?? law of Rosalind, ?? grandfather of Mark and ?? Services were ?? ?? June 21, 19??6.

title: 500 From 45 States and Abroad At Rutgers Alcoholism Course
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 21 More than 500 professionals and others working in the field, of alcoholism began an intensive threeweek course today at the Center for Alcohol Studies at Rutgers University.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: An Opposition Party Official In Jamaica Is Released
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 21 (Reuters)  Security forces today released an official of the opposition political party who was among nine persons dctaind under the state of emergency imposed on Jamaica over the weekend.

title: New York Crisis Forcing Schools to Stress the 3 R's
description: New York City's community school boards, already up against the frustrations inherent in educating large numbers of disadvantaged children, are fighting an uphill  and many fear a losingbattle to maintain academic quality in the wake of this year's massive budget cuts.

title: ETHEL R. COVINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Ethel R. Covington, widow of J. Harry Covington, a founder of Covington & Burling, the largest law firm in the nation's capital, died Saturday after a long illness at her home here. She was 97 years old.

title: M.A.C. EXTENDS EXCHANGE OFFER FOR CITY'S NOTES
description: The Municipal Assistance; Corporation extended its latest; debtexchange offer yesterday, reporting that it had generally failed thus far to persuade more investors to take M.A.C. bonds in place of New York City's troublesome notes.

title: BATHING BANNED AT JONES BEACH
description: Jones Beach State Park was closed for swimming yesterday because of the floating debris that has closed other beaches on Long Island in the past week.

title: CHARLES L. CLEAVES, A REALTY EXECUTIVE
description: Charles L. Gleaves, a lawyer and real estate executive, died yesterday at his home at 220 East 61st Street, New York. He was 72 years old.

title: RATE DROP AN AID TO U.S. STEEL, U.S
description: In two widely different financing efforts the United states Government and the United states Steel Corporation benefited yesterday from the general decline in interest rates this month. The Treasury sold $7.7 billion of shortterm securities at, lower interest rates and the nation's largest steel company arranged to get $400 million of capital funds on more advantageous terms.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Budget Cuts at City U. Assigned; No College Closing Seen in Year
description: The City University will cut $50 million from its spending for next year, to comply with the level authorized by the Si ate Legislature, by requiring each of the 20 colleges to take bildgct cuts ranging from 8 to 13 percent, a university spokesman said yesterday.

title: Hays's Resignation Of Chairmanship Accepted by House
description: Washington, June 21The House accepted today the resignation of Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, as chairman of the House Administration Committee.

title: Brezhnev and Kekkonen Pledge Wider Political Ties
description: MOSCOW, June 21 (Reuters) The Soviet Communist party cheif, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and President Urho Kekkonen of Finland pledged today to broaden political and economic cooperation between their two countries.

title: Stein Sues to Force Authorities To Seek Restitution by Bergman
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein filed suit yesterday to require authorities to halt Medicaid payments to Bernard Bergman, to move to recover $2.5 million in alleged overpayments to him and to take over his Park Crescent Nursing Home in New York City.

title: Marines Warn Recruiters Not to Restrict Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  Marine headquarters has stressed to its recruiters that corps policy bars any restrictions on enlistment of blacks.

title: Fiscal Crises Keep Official Lobbyists Busy
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Two dozen lobbyists clustered in the marble corridor outside the entrance to the House of Representatives, hawking their wares like competing fishmongers seeking to be heard above the din they had created, as the Congressmen ran the gantlet to enter the House chamber and cast their votes.

title: Iranian Oil Deal Stirs Wariness
description: Both the oil industry and Wall Street seemed to be adopting a waitandsee attitude yesterday regarding the announcement of Iran's intention to purchase $125 million of the cumulative voting preferred stock of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the largest single purchase of an interest in an United States company by a Middle Eastern oil producer.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in 15Month Trial of the San Quentin
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 21 Closing arguments began today in the trial of the socalled San Quentin Six, five inmates and a former inmate accused of murder, conspiracy and assault in connection with an alleged escape attempt at San Quentin Prison by George Jackson.

title: Andy Devine Gravely I
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., June 21 (AP)  Andy Devine, the television character actor, was listed in serious condition today after suffering setbacks at a hospital where he was undergoing dialysis. Dr. David J. Shapiro, his attending physician, did not elaborate on the problems facing the 70yearold actor. When Mr. Devine entered Sonoma County Community Hospital last Wednesday, he was reportedly suffering from kidney failure.

title: How Property Taxes Have Risen Since '67
description: Since 1967 the real estate tax has jumped from $4.957 per $100 of assessed valuation to $8.187 for 1976. The following table shows the tax rate and increases since 1967:

title: No.Amer.SoccerLeague
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: O.AS. CHIEF IRKS CHILE PRISONERS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 20The political prisoners at the Tres Alamos detention center were reported by visitors to be outraged by the public version given by Alejandro Orfila, secretary general of the Organization of American States, of his interviews with them.

title: SENATE THWARTS NEW BUDGET PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Advocates of strict adherence to the letter and spirit of the new Congressional budget procedures lost their fight in the Senate today to forces led by Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: PRICE RISE FORECAST ON HOME HEATING OIL
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The price of home heating oil will rise by 4 cents a gallon over the next 30 months, with or without Federal price controls, Congress was told today. But the Federal Energy Administration said it saw no basis for fears that prices would rise sharply if controls were ended.

title: Savings Units to Fight EqualRate Plan
description: The efforts of the commercial banking industry and of state banking commissioners in the Northeast to abolish savings rate differentials in the region will be strenuously opposed, officials of the thrift industry said yesterday.

title: Public Workers Strike in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, June 21  Thousands of state employees in Massachusetts went on strike today in defiance of state law and, as the day wore on, of a state court order.

title: CONVICTION UPSET IN SEXABUSE CASE
description: Dr. William Abruzzi, the physician who gained public notice as the Rock Doc of the Woodstock Festival, won a reversal yesterday of his conviction last year on charges of sexual misconduct with patients seeking gynecological treatment.

title: Court Order Stops Yanks From Ending FreeTicket Arrangement for Children
description: Citing problems of crowd behavior, the Yankees yesterday suspended a longstanding arrangement with the Consolidated Edison Company to admit thousands of underprivileged children free to games at Yankee Stadium.

title: Mets Are Defeated By Cardinals, 72
description: ST. LOUIS, June 21 The New York Mets offered another display of their losing ways tonight, bowing to the Cardinals 72 and sinking deeper than ever into third place.

title: Amex and Counter Show Slight Rises As Trading Slows
description: Stocks on the American Stock, Exchange and in the overthecounter market inched ahead yesterday. This was the fourth session in a row that the indexes moved up but the pace of trading was noticeably slowed.

title: Soviet Pianists Win in Montreal
description: Pianists from the Soviet Union took top honors in the 11th Montreal International Competition, which ended Sunday night. The first prize of $10,000 went to Eteri Andjaparidze. Nikolai Demidenko and Naum Grubert, her countrymen, were named secondplace winners together with Gerhard Oppitz of West Germany. The sum of the second, third and fourth prizes was shared by them, $3.000 going to each.

title: Economic Summitry
description: WASHINGTONWe have learned after destructive wars that world peace is indivisible, but we must have a better appreciation of the fact that the world economy, too, has become indivisible, West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told Americans last fall.

title: The Flu Bug Cuts Fields At Belmont
description: A flu epidemic has ininvaded the barns at Belmont Park and Aqueduct and it's preventing the Racing Secretary, Tommy Trotter, from filling the daily racing programs at Belmont. Trotter estimates that more than onethird of Tracks the 2,000 horses stabled at the two tracks have the disease.

title: Ashe Is Extended But Wins
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 21The last time Arthur Ashe was on the center court at Wimbledon, a year ago, he won the title from Jimmy Connors in a tennis classic. On that court today, at the start of the 1976 tournament, he lost more games to Ferdi Taygan, a 19yearold who ranks only 57th in the United States, then he had to Connors.

title: Gynecologist's Guilty Plea to Sex Abuse Reversed
description: Dr. William Abruzzi, the physician who gain public norice as the Rock Doc of the Woodstock Festival, won a reversal yesterday of his conviction last year on charges of sexual misconduct with patients seeking ynecological treatment.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 22, 1976

title: Tax Reform
description: If New York is to reverse the flight of industry from the state and stabilize its revenue base, tax reform must also be high on Albany's priority list. A special task force of the Municipal Assistance Corporation has identified a number of taxes that appear especially onerous to business and highincome individuals.

title: New York Senate Votes Curb on Education Chief
description: ALBANY, June 21The New York State Senate today passed a bill, widely viewed as an antibusing measure, that would for the first time give the State Board of Regents the power to overturn a decision of the State Education Commissioner.

title: I.B.M. LEADS LIST AS STOCKS CLIMI
description: International Business Ma chines, the nation's bestknow glamour issue, led the stoc market higher yesterday in a extension of last week's rigo?? ous advance.

title: Bribe Investigation Faced by ExAide Of Pallottine Order
description: BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP) Maryland's attorney general said today that he was looking into the possibility that the former fundraising director of the Pallottine Fathers received bribes from companies in which the order invested.

title: CAREY PRESSING BROKER TAX HELP
description: ALBANY, June 21Governor Carey is pressing the Legislature to agree to a plan providing $43 million in state and city tax relief this year to certain types of brokerage firms threatening to leave Wall Street.

title: PARKS SPRUCEUP BEGUN BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame announced the start yesterday of an ambitious program to give citizens a greater role in keeping city parks clean and green.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES MAKE ADVANCES
description: Soybeans, which have been Iretreating in price recently, moved up yesterday, with a result that most contracts closed up the 20centsabushel daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade. The July delivery ended at $6.36 a bushel, up from $6.17

title: It Can Ruin Your Whole Day
description: ABOARD THE BARQUE EAGLE, June 21A collision at sea. They didn't ruin the majestic spectacle because can ruin your whole day. When the last of the world's great squareriggers helping the United States celebrate its 200th birthday started the BermudatoNewport leg of the race across the Atlantic there were at least three collisions at sea. They didn't ruin the majestic spectacle because nothing could, but they made a hairy mess of the start and almost surely eliminated three ships from the fleet that will parade up the Hudson River July 4. They also demonstrated that in certain circumstances the broad Atlantic can take on a striking resemblance to the Times Square subway at 5 P.M. I have seen some exciting kickoffs in football, said Capt. James R. Kelly after he had maneuvered the Eagle through a needle's eye and had the Coast Guard Academy's training ship off and racing, but never one like this.

title: The Courts
description: The art of the possible is being applied to what a few weeks ago looked like an impossible attempt to achieve legislative change in the state judicial system. As a result of the legislative leadership's bipartisan agreement on the need for constitutional amendments, what now seems possible includes appointment of judges to the highest appellate court, the Court of Appeals in Albany; creation of a permanent statewide court administrator; and a new method of disciplining judges without the delays caused by the present involved procedures. Regrettably, other important contents of the reform package remain sidetracked.

title: O'Neill Said to Have Intervened in Case Of Rent Subsidies for Campaign Donor
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Carla M. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that the House majority leader, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., had called her last July in an effort to speed a decision on $2.2 million in Federal rent subsidies sought by a campaign contributor for an upstate New York housing project.

title: Vanessa Redgrave Signed for Julia, A Film Based on Hellman Memoir
description: Vanessa Redgrave has been signed for the title role in Julia, a film based on a chapter of Lillian Hellman's memoir, Pentimento. Miss Redgrave will he seen as a woman persecuted by the Nazis, with Jane Fonda as Miss Hellman, who tried to come to her aid.

title: Van Peebles Plans RaceDriver Film
description: Melvin Van Peebles, author and director of the controversial film, Sweet Sweetback's Sadasssss Song, will return to moviemaking with a drama based on the life of Wendell Scott, first black champion racingcar driver. The film will he produced for Warner Bros. by Hannah Weinstein's Third World Cinema, which was responsible for the 1974 Claudine.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Books of The Times
description: TISHA, The Story of a Young Teacher In the Alaska Wilderness. As Told to Robert Specht. 358 pages. St. Martin's Press. $8.95.

title: Legislative Priorities
description: As an exhausted State Legislature stumbles toward adjournment this week, the lawmakers must recognize that the state and local fiscal crises that have dominated their deliberations are far from resolved. A series of emergency measures has succeeded in forestalling disaster, but New York City and a number of other localities and the state itself still face the threat of ultimate bankruptcy unless Governor and Legislature begin at once to attack some fundamental problems.

title: Volares and Aspens Recalled
description: DETROIT, June 21 (UPI) The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was recalling 42,348 early production 1976model Plymouth Volare and Dodge Aspen cars because front seat safety belts may not he fully effective in an accident.

title: CONTROLLERS BACK IN CANADIAN STRIKE
description: TORONTO, June 20 (AP)Air traffic controllers returned to work this evening, following walkouts that closed at least eight major Canadian airports in a dispute over the use of the French language by Quebec air traffic controllers, authorities said.

title: 5 Slain in Thai Clash
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 21 (Reuters)Fifty Thai Communist guerrillas shot five militiamen and border police officer to death in an attack on a remote village defense post in northeast Thailand over the weekend, the police said today. At least five persons were wounded in the attack, about 30 miles from the Laotian border.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NORTH BY SOUTH Latin American Presence in New York is the title of a new exhibition mounted In the hall of the Museum Building at the New York Botanical Garden and running through Sept. 13. Some 42 artists, most of them residents of the metropolitan area, are represented in what amounts to a Who's Who of Latin American art, although 10 contributors have never before had their works displayed in the United States.

title: Unpledged G.O.P. Slates Show Little Shift Thus Far
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The uncommitted delegates to the Republican National Convention, who will apparently decide whether President Ford or Ronald Reagan is nominated, have not yet begun to move in significant numbers to either of the two rivals, a New York Times survey shows.

title: Public Workers Strike in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, June 21  Thousands of state employees in Massachusetts went on strike today in defiance of state law and, as the day wore on, of a state court order.

title: Notes on People
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden and his bride had hoped to honeymoon in Hawaii Just like any married couple, but sich was not to be. They were so engulfed in security, so tight that the Swedish Consul in Hawaii almost missed their arrival, that any thought of a quiet arrival was shattered. The Consul, Rick Larsen, managed to fight his way to the couple and place about the neck of Sweden's 24th Queen, the former Silvia Sommerlath, a West German, the traditional lei. The couple will try to find some seclusion at the home of Lurline Roth, heress to a shipping fortune.

title: U.S. BARS TROOPS FOR PHILADELPHIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  Philadelphia was turned down today on its request for Federal troops for the July 4 celebration.

title: 10 Reported Slain in Riots In Townships of Pretoria
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 21Rioting spread this morning to the back townships around this city, and bands of young people overturned buses, set fire to schools and government offices and pelted passing cars with stones.

title: Spoiled or Not, Amy Carter, 8, Is Village Darling in Plains, Ga.
description: PLAINS, Ga., June 21Her father thinks she's spoiled, but her mother disagrees.

title: Tally of G.O.P. Delegates
description: Following is the latest statebystate delegate tally for the Republican Presidential nomination, based on primary elections, state conventions and interviews by The New York Times with elected delegates listed as uncommitted. The tally reflects changes resulting from the interviews.

title: Midshipman Fights Marijuana Charge, Kings Point Ouster
description: Yesterday was graduation day for 220 members of the senior class at the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I.but not for Kenneth O. Ekelund 2d, an honor student with a family tradition in the military.

title: People and Business
description: The two officials most prominently involved in trying to untangle the confusion surrounding last month's massive default on potato futures explained to a Senate subcommittee yesterday what they are doing.

title: Families Hope $10 Houses Will Be Their Homes
description: Orazio and Marianna Iaboni, who have been married five years and have a 3yearold daughter, want to get a house of their own at reasonable cost, rather than to continue renting an apartment from Mr. Iaboni's father.

title: O.E.C.D. Approves Rules of Conduct For Multinationals
description: PARIS, June 21 (Reuters)The 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed today on a voluntary code of conduct for multinational companies, the O.E.C.D. said.

title: Atomic Unit, in Split Vote, Backs Reactor for Spain
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The export of a nuclear power reactor to Spain was approved today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission over the strong dissent of one of the four commissioners.

title: Budget Cuts Hurt Special Education
description: The efforts of the New York City school system to accommodate a rapidly increasing enrollment of handicapped pupils in specialeducation programs have been significantly hampered by the fiscal crisis.

title: Yanks Defeat Indians For 7th Straight, 60
description: Reluctantly, the Yankees returned home last night for the start of an eightgame stay at Yankee Stadium. They quickly learned that coming home wasn't so bad after all.

title: COURT LETS STAND PAYMENTS ON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the constitutionality of a program that has required major oil companies to pay $1.5 billion to independent refiners to help keep the refiners competitive.

title: Argentine Flu Kills 19
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21 (AP) A monthold outbreak influenza has caused at least 19 deaths in Argentina, Government officials said today. Seventeen deaths occurred in Salta province.

title: Academy Forces Woman to Resign
description: A female plebe at the United States Merchant Marine A?? emy has resigned under pressure after she was allegedly seen lying in bed with a m?? midshipman a dormitory roo?? on the academy's campus a Kings Point L.I. academy offcials confirmed last night.

title: Rockefeller Sees Benefit In Right's Opposing Ford
description: WEST ORANGE, NJ.. June 21Vice President Rockefeller said today that if the extreme right wing of the Republican Party opposed President Ford it would help him get elected in November.

title: Wohlhuter Wins 800Meter Run at Trials
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 21Rick Wohlhuter, Edwin Moses, Mac Wilkins and Brenda Morehead won finals today in the United States Olympic trials, all with surprising ease and all with superior performances.

title: June Gable, in Cabaret Debut, Puts Act Together With Skill
description: June Gable, who has sung Jacques Brel's songs in the longrunning Alive and Well show and played the easily assimilated old lady with one buttock in Candide and the Hispanicaccented Googie Gomez in The Ritz, is doing all that and a bit more in herd cabaret debut at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street.

title: Boy, 17, Accused of Murder
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP)A teenage boy has been charged with murder after he allegedly ran over a 3yearold boy who had spilled milk on his car. The police said that Paul Turchi, 17, came out of his apartment yesterday and scolded Ronald Meyers, who had spilled the milk. Young Turchi drove his car from its parking place and allegedly reversed it and struck the child as he crossed the street. The boy died two hours later in a hospital.

title: 10 Reported Slain in Riots In Townships of Pretoria
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 21Rioting spread this morning to the black townships around this city, and bands of young people overturned buses, set fire to schools and government offices and pelted passing cars with stones.

title: SADAT, SAUDI KING AND ARAFAT MEET
description: CAIRO, June 21 (UPI)Leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the Palestine Liberation Organization held talks in Riyadh today. The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, later flew to Cairo to press for the speedy, dispatch of a joint Arab peacekeeping force to Lebanon.

title: Citizens Group Suggests M.T .A. Deficit Solutions
description: The Citizens Budget Commission warned yesterday that politicians would have to take the bull by the horns in meeting Metropolitan Transit Au thority deficits, which are projected to exceed $100 million in each of the next two years.

title: Iran to Pay $125 Million For Occidental Oil Stake
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 21Iran intends to purchase a $125 million share in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation as part of a joint deal to develop Caspian Sea oil, the Government announced today.

title: 3 More Seized in Japan On Lockheed Charges
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, June 22 (UP)Three executive of allNippon Airways, a leading Japanese domestic airline, were arrested today on suspicion of illegally receiving roughly $166,666 from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Jersey Democratic Delegates Delay Endorsement of Carter
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 21The New Jersey delegates to the Democratic National Convention put off any endorsement of Jimmy Carter tonight after electing Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. as their convention leader.

title: Jersey's Assembly Rejects Income Tax
description: TRENTON, June 21With 10 days remaining before a courtordered closing of the state's public schools unless they are constitutionally financed, the Assembly rejected today by 77 to 2 a Senatepassed version of a state income tax.

title: Luzinski Slugs 100th Homer As Phillies Subdue Expos, 83
description: Around Philadelphia, where many of the nation's Bicentennial festivities are planned this year, 200 is the operative number. But last night for Greg Luzinski of the Phillies the number 100 worked just as well. Luzinski hit the 100th home run of his career and led the Phillies to an 83 victory over the visiting Montreal Expos.

title: Dance:
description: One of the most interesting things about the New York City Ballet is its sudden flexibility. It has the capacity to fly into the unexpected. At the momentand indeed, apparently for all timeit rigorously maintains a nostar policy. Yet it is a policy flexible enough for it to invite guest artists (dare one say guest stars?) from the Paris Opra Ballet.

title: De Camp Plans Bus Runs Tomorrow, But State Opposes Dropping of 2 Lines
description: NEWARK, June 21An official of De Camp Bus Lines said today that partial service would be restored Wednesday following a monthlong strike, but the company appeared headed for a clash with the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners over plans to abandon two of its nine routes.

title: Belmont Charts
description: 1976, by Triagie Pubilcanons. Inc. (The Delly Racing Form) Monday, June 21. 44th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Wilderness Area Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  Members of a HouseSenate conference committee agreed today to a compromise Eagles Nest wilderness area bill with provisions for some development of its water for use in the Denver metropolitan area. Essentially, the conferees I agreed to set aside land for a (canal of the east side of the central Colorado wilderness preserve, and room near Frisco for a water collection tunnel portal.

title: Keaser Gains In Wrestling
description: BROCKPORT, N.Y., June 21 (AP)  Marine Lieut. Lloyd Keaser gained a final shot at winning a starting berth on the United States Olympic wrestling team tonight while Stan Dziedzic set up a showdown with Wade Schalles.

title: Snug Harbor
description: There is no guarantee of salvation, for life or landmarks. One battle leads to another. Sailors Snug Harbor on Staten Island, one of the country's finest Greek Revival groups, is still fighting for survival in spite of its landmark status and the city's purchase of the land and buildings for a cultural center a few years ago.

title: Beame to Discuss Problems Of City With Businessmen
description: Mayor Beame has decided to initiate a series of breakfast meetings at Gracie Mansion with chairmen and presidents of the shrinking number of major corporations that have headquarters in New York City.

title: William Dinsmore, Pianist, Composer and Teacher, 73
description: William B. Dinsmore Jr., a pianist and composer who taught harmony and counterpoint in New York for several years, died in the Martha's Vineyard Hospital on June 17. He was 74 years old.

title: GENERAL FAVORED IN LISBON CONTEST
description: LISBON, June 21Violence that has claimed one life has begun to mark arr otherwise desultory presidential campaign in which the four candidates have not yet come to grips with the central issue in Portugalhow to revive an almost prostrate economy.

title: Dividends Announced
description: IRREGULAR

title: M.A.C. EXTENDS EXCHANGE OFFER FOR CITY'S NOTES
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation extended its latest debtexchange offer yesterday, reporting that it had generally failed thus far to persuade more investors to take M.A.C. bonds in place of New York City's troublesome notes.

title: State Spurs Effort, Too
description: ALBANY. June 21Governor. Carey today named Richard E. Drucker, former vice chairman of the Liberal Party in Queens, as a $31,000ayear assistant deputy commissioner in the Commerce Department, with the mission of seeking to keep corporate headquarters in the state.

title: VOTE ON LAYOFFS ASKED IN PETITION
description: A petition campaign designed to force the rehiring of all laidoff policemen and firemen by means of a voter referendum was begun yesterday by municipal union officials.

title: CHRISTIAN DEMOCRATS TOP ITALIAN VOTE BUT RED GAIN LEAVES CRISIS UNRESOLVED
description: ROME, June 21The Christian Democrats today maintained their place as Italy's largest party, but the Communist Party scored impressive tains in the national elections.

title: Helping New York
description: There is a group of children in the city who receive little, or no schooling. For the most part, they are children of the poor who have been judged too mentally retarded to attend public school and who spend their days with their parents or guardians. They have little hope for improvement without dependence on others.

title: A Canal Project in South Caps 200Year Dream
description: COLUMBUS, Miss., June 17For more than two centuries entrepreneurs and engineers have dreamed of cutting a canal through this corner of Mississippi to link the Tennessee River to the north with the Tombigbee River to the south, as a passage from the Gulf port of Mobile to the cities and towns of the Tennessee Valley.

title: King Kong Plunges as Thousands Gasp
description: Drawn by 1930's nostalgia and 1976 excitement, a horrified crowd of more than 5,000 New Yorkers surged past police lines at the World Trade Center last night on cue and fought its way to the spot where a giant gorilla lay dead after a 110story fall from the North Tower.

title: PHILLIP J. CRUISE, EXHOUSING CHIEF
description: Phillip J. Cruise, who retired in 1958 as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, died Sunday night in Booth Memorial Medical Center, Flushing, Queens, where he had been admitted early this month with a heart ailment. He was 78 years old.

title: Arabs Pay $15.9 Million For London's Dorchester
description: LONDON, June 21The Dorchester on Park Lane, one of London's best known and most luxurious hotels, has been sold to Arab interests for cash, it was announced today.

title: The Outlook for Italy
description: ROME, June 21  If the trends established in incomplete results of Italy's election, hold firm, the country's political future could be more precarious. Although the political arithmetic was not yet clear, the chance of renewed government by a center or center eft coalition was undermined. The prospects were bewildering even to politicians, and they were hard put to speculate how a future government might be formed with even the minimum solidity needed to haul the country out of its economic quagmire.

title: Summaries of U.S. Track Trials
description: MEN'S EVENTS

title: The Sahel Is Not a Wasteland
description: WASHINGTONAn American visiting the Sahelthe subSaharan region of West Africafor the first time carries the mental images of the great drought: barren land and emaciated children. It comes as a shock when reality does not match the image.

title: VORSTER ADDRESSES ENVOYS ON RIOTING
description: BONN, June 21 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa addressed a score of his country's ambassadors today on rising world criticism of his Government's apartheid policy, diplomatic sources said.

title: Argentine Executive Slain
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21 (UPI)Leftist terrorists killed Osvaldo Trinidad, industrial relations manager for the Swift meat packing company, with bursts of machinegun fire as he left his home early today in the city of La Plata, police sources said.

title: COURT EASES WAY FOR STATES TO AID CHURCH COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that states may provide funds for nonsectarian purposes to churchaffiliated colleges and universitieseven when prayers are said at the start of some classes in those schools and religion and theology are mandatory courses.

title: FrankDonoghue, 77, A Former Newsman And Official of City
description: Frank Lee Donoghue, a former newspaperman and pubiicrelations consultant who was director of New York City's Department of Commerce from 1947 to 1951, died Sunday in Vern Beach. Fla., where he had lived in retirement. He was 77 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Peace Force in Beirut
description: About 1,000 Syrian and Libyan troops, described as the vanguard of an Arab League peacekeeping force, arrived in Beirut today as a new ceasefire went into effect. Page 3.

title: Reprieve in Italy
description: Italy's Christian Democratic Party has survived the most critical test of its 30 years in office. But the most powerful Communist Party in the Western world has collected its biggest share ever of the votes for both houses of Parliament and remains in position to influence the course of Italian politics in a major way.

title: Jazz Trumpeters Play a Memorial To Four Colleagues
description: Jazz trumpet players took part in A Tribute to Courage at CAMI Hall over the weekend. The two concerts were devoted to the memories of four dead trumpet artists, Fats Navarro, Clifford Brown, Kenny Dorham and Lee Morgan, and most of the musicians involved planned their sets accordingly, mixing original compositions with tunes written by or in tribute to the four men being honored.

title: Ford's Busing Stance: Little Change Discerned From His Voting Record and LongHeld Convictions
description: WASHINGTON, June 21When school busing suddenly emerged as a focus of public debate during the recent primary campaigns, many critics of the Ford Administration assumed that the President was attempting to exploit the racial issue to rescue his faltering quest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Mobile Units Resume Collections of Aluminum Cans
description: It was collection time once again yesterday in New Jersey as vans from the Reynolds Metals Company swept through the state seeking aluminum to recycle.

title: Unpledged G. O . P. Slates Show Little Shift Thus Far
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The uncommitted delegates to the Republican National Convention, who will apparently decide whether President Ford or Ronald Reagan is nominated, have not yet begun to move in significant numbers to either of the two rivals, a New York Times survey shows.

title: TeenAge Abortions Without Family Consent Hang in the Balance
description: She is 16 years old and she had an abortion at the Eastern Women's Center the other day, perhaps one of the last days that the pregnancy of a minor could be legally terminated in this state without a parent's consent.

title: People in Sports
description: Ali is in fantastic condition, said Angelo Dundee, the trainer of the heavyweight boxing champion, Muhammad Ali. He's doing a lot of training every day, roadwork in the early morning and workouts in his hotel suite.
