description: BASEBALL

title: Fiscal Crises Keep Official Lobbyists Busy
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Two dozen lobbyists clustered in the marble corridor outside the entrance to the House of Representatives, hawking their wares like competing fishmongers seeking to be heard above the din they had created, as the Congressmen ran the gantlet to enter the House chamber and cast their votes.

title: 2 World Records In Swim
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 21 (AP)America's swimming queen, Shirley Babashoff, shattered the world record in the women's 800meter freestyle and a high school junior, Brian Goodell, broke a second world mark, winning the men's 1,500meter freestyle tonight at the United States Olympic swimming trials.

title: Blix Donnelly, 62, a Pitcher For 2 World Series Teams
description: OLIVIA, Minn., June 21 (UPI) Sylvester (Blix) Donnelly, a former baseball pitcher for two World Series teams, the St. Louis Cardinals of 1944 and the Philadelphia Phillies of 1950, died in Renville County Hospital yesterday after a long illness. His age was 62.

title: Strike Four
description: As a baseball fan, I realize I am supposed to be dumb, and I try hard. Half the sports writers assume I am an idiot, the players hold me in contempt, those company finks who describe games on television assume I am too stupid to tell a real reporter from a shill, and the club ownerswell, the club owners deserve a book on the subject of how to get rich by never underestimating the stupidity of the fans.

title: Corning Net Sets Record
description: The Corning Glass Works reported yesterday record earnings for the second quarter, reflecting a sharp recovery from depressed levels a year ago.

title: Mrs. Ford to Seek Votes In Minnesota for Husband
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) For the second straight week, Betty Ford will represent her husband at a Republican state convention  this one in Minnesota  and more such appearances are likely.

title: COURT EASES WAY FOR STATES TO AID CHURCH COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that states may provide funds for norrsectarian purposes to churchaffiliated colleges and universitieseven when prayers are said at the start of some classes in those schools and religion and theology are mandatory courses.

title: Champion Agrees in Principle To Sell Roberts Consolidated
description: The Champion International Corporation announced in Stamford, Conn., yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell Roberts Consolidated Industries, a wholly owned subsidiary for $29 million. The buyers include a group of employees and Carl Marks & Company, investment bankers. Under terms of the transaction, $21 million in cash will be paid at the closing, scheduled for Aug. 31, and the remaining $8 million over a fiveyear period.

title: VOTERS' APPROVAL IN ZONING UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that it is constitutional for a city to require property owners who want their land rezoned to first get the approval of the city's voters in a referendum.

title: In Memoriam
description: FIELDPauline D. Dear sister you are always in my heart. Love, Cecelia.

title: William Flanders, A Mortgage Expert And F.H.A. Aide
description: William D. Flanders, a former president of the Fred F. French Investing Company, 551 Fifth Avenue, died Sunday in the Princeton Medical Center, Princeton, N. J. He was 85 years old.

title: Comptroller Resigns In a Surprise Move
description: President Ford announced yesterday that he had accepted the resignation of James E. Smith as Comptroller of the Currency, one of the nation's key bankregulatory positions.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, June 21 1976

title: Parochial School Aid Law tin New York State Stricken
description: A Federal court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that it was unconstitutional for New York State to reimburse religious schools for the costs of statemandated testing and record keeping because it had the primary effect of advancing religion.

title: Bicentennial Jewelry Made To Last Another 200 Years
description: The Bicentennial theme has penetrated fashion in a number of ways, producing a rash of flag colors and a tendency to look to work clothes, such as lumbermen's jackets, and hunter's and fishermen's gear, as the source of styles for less strenuous activities.

title: HAROLD DINERMAN
description: Harold Dinerman, director of regional services for the National Jewish Welfare Board, died Sunday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived in Maplewood, N. J.

title: Advertising
description: Frequency is the key to memory. Frequency is the key to learning and retention, said Gene DeWitt, executive vice president and media director of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson.

title: Despite Alarm Over Racial Violence, Most White South Africans Seem to Support the Status Quo
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 21Out on the dusty veld a few miles away, bursts of police gunfire signaled the renewal of black rioting that has cost at least 140 lives. But inside the Voortrekker monument, an Afrikaner shrine high on a hill overlooking this capital city, Esther Maty seemed relaxed and feeling fine.

title: KISSINGER WARNS WEST ON ECONOMY
description: PARIS, June 21Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger urged the Western industrial powers today to meet the world's new and demanding challenges by cooperating more closely in dealing with Communist and thirdworld nations.

title: LYKES PASCO CUTS ORANGE JUICE PRICE
description: The Lykes Pasco Packing Company, a major Florida orange juice concntrate. packer said it had reduced prices by 80 cents a case on cases of 48 sixounce cans and two dozen 12ounce cans and $1.07 a case on cases of two dozen 16ounce cans and a dozen 32ounce cans.

title: New York Crisis Forcing Schools to Stress the 3 R's
description: New York City's community school boards, already up against the frustrations inherent in educating large numbers of disadvantaged children, are fighting an uphill  and many fear a losingbattle to maintain academic quality in the wake of this year's massive budget cuts.

title: NBC Head Urges Set Political Spots
description: Herbert S. Schlosser, president of NBC, yesterday proposed that the three television networks act in concert in advance of the 1980 Presidential primaries to prevent the chaos that occurred this year in the scramble to purchase political time.

title: P.P.C. Cites Lag in Reporting Natural Gas Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A Federal Power Commission staff report said today that producers of natural gas and the American Gas Association sometimes makes generous estimates of newly discovered gas reserves.

title: Card of Thanks
description: VERNICKMrs. Sonia Vernirk and family cincorely thank their friends and ralatives for their kind expressions of sympathy their recent bereavement.

title: TOUCHE ROSS BACKS ACCOUNTING BOARD
description: Touche Ross & Company, one of the nation's Big Eight accounting firms, quickly jumped to the defense yesterday of the Financial Accounting Standards Board as the only opportunity to preserve accounting rulemaking in the private sector where it belongs.

title: Ford Coming to Connecticut
description: WATERBURY, Conn., June 22 (AP)President Ford plans to speak at the Connecticut Republican convention July 17, the party state chairman, Frederick Biebel, said tonight.

title: Carey Signs Union Bill For Household Workers
description: ALBANY, June 22 Domestic and household workers employed by contract cleaning concerns will he able to bargain collectively and eventually unionize like other workers in the state under a bill signed into law today byl Governor Carey.

title: GAP IN LAYOFFS AND SAVINGS SEEN
description: The massive layoffs of e nicipal employees in New York City last summer and fall failed to produce commensurate re; ductions in the city's payroll, the state's deputy comptroller,. Sidney Schwartz, said yesterday.

title: Amstar Sugar Prices Cut
description: The Amstar Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its prices for industrial sugar in bag and bulk lots by 50 cents a hundred pounds, effective today. The new price for 100pound bags will be $20.05 and for hulk shipments, $19.25 per  undred pounds.

title: Dow Declines 9.82 To Close at 997.63
description: Stock prices weakened in late trading yesterday and once again failed to move into new high ground for 1976.

title: Ford Urges Busing Curbs In Fighton Big Government
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 22President Ford declared here today that his efforts to minimize the extent of busing to desegregate public schools were a prelude to the nation's search for freedom from intrusive, overbearing government.

title: Valve Closing Blamed in Fire
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)  The fire that killed one man and destroyed the MidValley Pipeline Company terminal near Lima, Ohio, last Jan. 17 occurred because pressure in the pipe built up when a valve was inadvertedly closed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: CONSUMER NOTES; Salt Substitutes? Ask Your Doctor
description: WASHINGTON, June 22Those comparatively expensive little containers of salt substitute commonly sold in the supermarket diet section are generally useless unless a doctor has recommended the use of a salt substitute as part of a strict medical diet, according to a Federal Trade Commission consumer specialist.

title: Fromm Gains Net Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI.. June 22Eric Fromm gained the final of the New York State junior tennis championship today with a 75, 63 victory over John Galbraith at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. He plays Bob Rosello for the title tomorrow.

title: Stock Prices Drop OnAmexandOTC; Volume Shows Rise
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market retreated yesterday after Monday's advance. The Amex market value index closed at 104.70, down 0.35. The NASDAQ industrial index ended at 95.12. off 0.81. maker of mobile homes and equipment for them, led the most active list on the Amex on volume of 95,400 shares. It closed at 5, up %. Second on the list was Brascan, a holding company whose principal investments are in electric utilities. In volume of 62,300 shares it closed at 107/8, unchanged

title: A NEW U.S. ENVOY TO BEIRUT NAMED
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 22 (AP) President Ford announced here today that Talcott W. Seelye, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, would temporarily take charge of the United States Embassy in Lebanon following the killing of Ambassador Francis E. Meloy Jr.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on Jimmy Carter that appeared in The Times last Friday. it was erroneously reported that Attorney General Edward H. Levi had offered the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to Presidentiil candidates to check the backgrounds of potential VicePresidential choices. Mr. Levi has never made such an offer.

title: Algeria to Vote on Charter
description: ALGIERS, June 22 (Reuters) A new Constitution for Algeria was published today, affirming Islam as the state religion, putting the army under civilian control and stressing the emancipation of women and the role of the press. The document will be put to a referendum on Sunday.

title: The Now York Times/Robert Walker
description: REENACT SWEDISH IMMIGRATION: Anders Wettergren of Sweden, his wife, Carin, and their two children, Anna 7, and Lisa, 5, wore 19th century clothes yesterday after they left'Ellis Island, background, where they simulated the processing of immigrants. the journey was an official U.S. Bicentennial observance of the Swedish Government.

title: Only Narrow Movements Shown in Credit Markets
description: Prices and interest rates in the credit markets yesterday moved within only a very narrow range, although investment bankers nevertheless handled substantial volume of newissue activity at yields

title: Senate in Albany Passes Reform of Public Access
description: ALBANY, June 22The State Senate today unanimously passed a bill that its sponsors describe as strengthening the state's twoyearold Freedom of Information Law by sharply limiting the circumstances under which government agencies can refuse to grant citizens requests for access to records.

title: Market Place
description: Shareholders of Pickwick International Inc.. merchandiser of music on records and tapes, were alarmed and pleased in turn yesterday.

title: Cultivated Marijuana Seized
description: LEXINGTON. N. C., June (UPI) Davidson County sheriffs authorities waited week for the owner of 184 marijuana plants to harvest his welltended crop Out when lie did not show up, they confiscated the weed yesterday. We left a note to whom it may concern that the owner of the crop could file a complaint with the sheriff's department if unhappy over the seizure, said Capt. Von E. Everhart, chief deputy.

title: Four. Held in Japan In Initial Arrests Of Lockheed Case
description: TOKYO, June 22Japanese !authorities arrested the former ;managing director of a major !trading corporation and three iniriine officials today in the !first such legal steps stemming from the Lockheed Aircraft I bribery scandal here.

title: Sohio Gasoline Up 1d
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday that it was raising the price of its gasoline by 1 cent a galIon. Sohio's move is another in a succession of gasoline price advances that began in April.

title: INJUNCTION DENIED IN PETROFUNDS CASE
description: A Federal judge, noting a record that fairly bristles with disputed facts, denied yester1 day a request by the Securities. and Exchange Commission for; an injunction against. Petro; funds Inc. and other defendants in an alleged $76 million oildrilling fraud.

title: A Mississippi Crisis
description: A run on deposits at some savings and loan associations in Mississippi has caused the Legislature to ban withdraw als, tying up 120,000 accounts involving $450 million. Details on page 23.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1976

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1976

title: Firehouse Bicentennial Art Snarls Newark Traffic
description: NEWARK, June 22Firemen from Engine Company and Truck Company 9 inadvertently caused a traffic tieup today near their firehouse at the busy intersection of West Market and Hudson Streets here.

title: Coffee Price Exceeds $2
description: Though the overall cost of feeding a family of four New York City dropped slightly last week, the average price of a pound of coffee broke the $2 level, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported.

title: WINE TALK
description: MARLBORO, N. Y.Would you like to own your own grapevines in a producing vineyard? Would you like to assist in the development of the Hudson Valley as an important wine region, the way it was early in the country's history? And would you like to be entitled to a case of wine each year produced from the vineyards of which you are a part owner?

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS. June 22 (UPI)The Italian lira dominated early trading on European money markets today, while the dollar was mixed, rising to preweekend levels in Zurich. A firmer Italian lira dominated early trading on foreign exchanges as dealers expressed relief that the Communist Party had not gained power in Italy's general election. The lira opened at 844 in active trading, then settled back close at a twoweek high of 847.75 to the dollar, up from yesterday's 854.

title: Roberts Vaults 18 81/4, Breaks World Record
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 22Earl Bell is a good sport. He allowed Dave Roberts to use his pole today and Roberts used it to regain the world polevault record from Bell.

title: LARRY H. ROBINSON
description: PAY E. Idaho. June 22 (UPI)Larry H. Robinson, publishereditor of The Independent Enterprise in Payette for 10 years, died yesterday. He was 01 years old. He majored in journalism at the University of Idaho, and his first employment as a journalist was at The Daily Idahonian in Moscow. He married Florence Larson June 2. 1938. She died in March of this year.

title: Evacuees From Beirut Land Safely in Greece
description: ATHENS, June 22 (AP)Weary but relieved, 276 Americans and other foreigners reached Athens today 45 hours after evacuation from Lebanon by the United States Navy. Some of them criticized United States Presidential politics as responsible for the evacuation.

title: 15 Given Half a Vote In Democratic Move
description: Fifteen New York Democratic delegates at large have agreed to give up half their vote at the Democratic National Convention to allow the appointment of 15 women and young Persons as halfvote delegues.

title: KIDDE SHIP PACT UPHELD BY COURT
description: A 1Vr0 supplemental agree, ment between Walter Kidde & Company and the R. J. Rey nolds Tcbacco Company for the sale of Kidde's United States Lines subsidiary was ruled lawful and not in violation of antitrust laws by a Federal District Court judge yesterday.

title: Woman Fights to Save Noble Title That Queen Says She Cannot Hold
description: BOSWORTH PARK, England  A pub in this pastoral Leichestershire village is named for the Dixie family. Nearby is the nowdefunct Dixie Grammar School, which gave Samuel Johnson his first teaching job. The Dixies ancestral home still stands, although now it is the local infirmary.

title: Spanish Tall Ship Protests
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22Among sailors who have gone yacht racing, and Bermuda has hundreds of them, the discussion was still raging today about who was right and v, ho was wrong In the spectacular collisions amcng, four vessels at the start of the Tall Ships race here Sunday.

title: Energy Agency Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) The House voted today to let the Federal Energy Administration die on June 30 if HouseSenate conferees fail to work out compromise legislation before then. Representative John D. Dingell. Democrat of Michigan, one of the leaders of the conference set to begin tomorrow, said that there was little chance conferees could finish in time. An aide said the conference would probably continue into late July.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Scattered showers and thundershowers may develop today across the Eastern Seaboard, Appalachians and Ohio Valley. It will be unseasonably hot in northern New England, and warm and humid across the rest of the Northeast. Mild weather will prevail from the Ohio Valley to the middle and lower MisSiSSini Valley, and also along the coast of the Pacific Northwest; temperatures will be below normal in northern portions of the Rockies and plateau region; warm or hot conditions will occur throughout the rest of the country. Scattered or widely scattered thunderstorms will develop across the southern halves of the Mississippi Valley and the Plains States, western portions of the Northern Plains States and the Rockies. It will be mostly sunny elsewhere.

title: Boston Council Votes To Require Residency
description: BOSTON, June 22 (AP)All new city employees, and those promoted after July 1, must live in Boston, under an ordinance approved by City Council.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Penn Central Railroad conductor and five Newark police officers have been cleared of false arrest and assault charges filed by Brian Taylor, the New York Nets basketball player. A United States District Court jury ruled late Monday that Mr. Taylor had not been falsely arrested, assaulted or maliciously prosecuted after a railroad conductor had told him to take his feet off a seat. The jury said that it found no basis for the $1 million suit or for claims by Mr. Taylor that the incident had violated his civil rights and damaged his bargaining power as an athlete in contract negotiations.

title: Vote in Council On Realty Taxes
description: Following is the rollcall vote by which the City Council approved an increase in the real estate tax:

title: Morton Sees Early Victory for Ford
description: WASHINGTON. June 22President Ford's campaign chairman said today that when the formal delegate selection process was completed, Mr. Ford would be likely to need only 13 of 103 delegates who will be uncommitted at that juncture to win the Republican nomination in Kansas City.

title: Rev. Justin J. McCarthy. 68, Fordham Student Adviser,
description: The. Rev: Justin .1. McCarthy, student adviser and professor of theology at Fordham University, died Monday at. Union Hospital in the Bronx. He vat GB years old.

title: WHYTE, HUDSON SINGING AT CLUB
description: It may be that the onagain, offagain relationship of Travis Hudson and Ronny Whyte as a performing team works to their advantage. Miss Hudson is so frequently involved in musicalsas she now is with Very Good Eddie at the Booththat Mr. Whyte works as a solo performer, singing and playing the piano, almost as much as he does in joint ventures with Miss Hudson. And yet every time they come together, they appear to have grown, both individually and as

title: ATTACK ON NEWSMEN RENEWED IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 23 (Reuters)A Soviet literary journal today renewed its attack against three American correspondents stationed in Moscow who, it charged a month ago were associated with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: U.S. to Study Iran Deal
description: A Ford Administration committee plans to examine the proposed 5125 million investment by Iran in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. Page 55.

title: Lipscomb Will head Quadrangle
description: Thomas H. Lipscomb has been named president of Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company, it was announced yesterday by Sydney Gruson, an executiife vice president of The New York Times Company.

title: CARTER, IN BOSTON, GOES FUNDHUNTING
description: BOSTON, June 22With the Democratic Presidential nomination in hand but with a campaign debt of more than $500,000, Jimmy Carter came to this city today searching more for money than delegates.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Argentine Town Avoids Recession And Austerity Through Smuggling,
description: CLORINDA, Argentina  In Buenos Aires, 600 miles to the south, shopkeepers nod listlessly behind counters or stand] with arms folded at doorways waiting in vain for customers, who can no longer afford more than basic necessities.

title: Officer on Belknap Guilty of Negligence In Collision at Sea
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 22 (AP) Lieut. (j.g.) Kenneth M. Knull, 26, officer of the deck of the cruiser Belknap when she collided with the carrier Jahn F. Kennedy last year, was convicted today of responsibility for the accident in which ainht sailors were killed.

title: Nassau County Closes Its Beaches Because of Sewage
description: MINEOLA, L. I. June 22All oceanfront beaches in Nassau County were ordered closed for bathing today as the mysterious incursion of sewage that has been washing up on the beachfronts of Long Island since last Tuesday moved westward toward New York City.

title: Gun Duels Resume In Beirut as Syria Begins a Pullback
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22Some Syrian troops began with drawing from positions around the Beirut airport today, but a calm that had baen settling over this embattled city was shattered by heavy shelling duels between Lebanese leftist and rightist factions.

title: Vote in Council On Realty Taxes
ROLAND C. BERGH
description: Roland C. Bergh. a retired aeronautical engineer, died Friday at a Princeton, N. J., hospital. He was 71 years old and a resident of Rumson, N. J.

title: Books of The Times
description: Raman, the sign painter of Malgudi, thinks of himself as independent, but his a romantic independence based on an image of someone who heroically transcends India's cluttered and rather suffocating social customs. It pleases him to pose as modern and rational and he is incessantly on guard against what he regards as retrogressive sexual obsession. Sitting on the steps by the river, he catches a glimpse of a woman's thigh and finds himself haunted by itand humiliated too, for he realizes that he has isolated this thigh from its owner, that he never even saw her face. He considers such dehumanized passion to be better than animal's.

title: Two Prominent Malaysian journalists Are Arrested as Communist Plotters
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Nlaiaysia, June 22Two of Malaysia's most prominent journalists were seized before dawn today under the Internal Security Act and named as the key figures in what was described as an intricate Communist conspii.acy.

title: Palomino Stops Stracey in 12th
description: WEMBLEY, England, June 22 (AP)Carlos Palomino, a MexicanAmerican based in Los Angeles, stopped John Stracey of Britain in the 12th round tonight to win the world welterweight boxing title.

title: House Bill on I.M.F. Pact Is Set Back Temporarily
description: WASHINGTON; June 22 (Reuters)A bill giving United States approval to amendments of the International Monetary Fund's articles of agreement affecting exchange rates and gold suffered a temporary setback today in Congress.

title: A Lingering Bugaboo.
description: The jump in the consumer price index for May by sixtenths of I percent7.2 percent at an annual rate is bound to stir fears that inflaItion is back from its holiday.

title: Jefferson, an American in Paris With a Taste for French Food...
description: Is connoisseurship in the world of fine food intuitive, or is it learned? Or both? How does it come about that two men, each endowed with uncommon sensibilities, can be exposed for an extended period to the great dining salons of France and return to native soil, one to be immortalized as perhaps America's greatest gastronome, the other far better remembered for going out and flying a kite?

title: U.S. to. Examine Iran's Occidental Deal
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The ?? Administration's investment review committee expects: to take an initial look next weck at the proposed $125 mil. lion investment by Iran in the ??dental Petroleum Corporation.

title: O'Neill Defends His Intercession In Campaign Contributor's Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 22Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the House majority leader, acknowledged today that he had interceded with Cabinet officer to speed a decision on $2.2 million in annual rent subsidies sought by a campaign contributor. But he said he would do the same for any other businessman ensnarled in the Federal bureaucracy.

title: Gun Duels Resume In Beirut as Syria Begins a Pullback
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon June 22Some Syrian troops began.withdrawing from positions around the Beirut airport today, but a calm that had been settling over this embattled city was shattered by heavy shelling duels between Lebanese leftist and rightist factions.

title: Tempest Finishes Sail First
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22Tempest, Eric Ridder's classically impressive 79foot ketch from Oyster Bay, L.I., was the first yacht to finish the 635mile Bermuda Race today.

title: Massachusetts Strike

title: BEAME IS PARING $50 MILLION MORE
description: ALBANY, June 22  New York City officials preoared to day to make up to $50 million in additional budget economies next month, acceding to state. pressure for greater austerity even as Mayor Beame made one lint display of asking Governor Carey for state court aid for the city.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
COMMUNISTS GAIN 49 CRUCIAL SEATS IN ITALY CONTEST
description: ROME, June 22  Final returns in Italy's national elections showed today that while the Christian Democrats had won a substantial victory in the popular vote, the Communists had captured a crucial number of scats in Parliament.

title: Car Kills Princeton Woman
description: MIAMI, June 22 (UPI)A woman struck by a car as she stood behind her damaged car on Interstate 95 north of Miami Sunday was identified today as Alexandra Bush, 20 years old, of Princeton, N.J. The car in which Miss Bush had been riding was damaged in a minor accident a few minutes before she was struck by the auto of Roberto Mejuto. 28, of Miami. He was charged with reckless driving and driving while intoxicated.

title: Ballet: A Night of Joys
description: Monday night was one of the nights that made American Ballet Theater famous. It glittered, it exulted, it cheered. At the Metropolitan Opera House, the company gave the American premiere of Glen Tetley's fascinating new version of Le Sacre du Printemps, together with the debuts of Mikhail Baryshnikov in Petrushka and March. Haydee and Richard Cragun in Pillar of Fire. It was, in total, a sort of depth charge of energy.

description: If there is one rule of thumb the welltraveled gastronome abides by, it is to avoid all restaurants on the tops of tall buildings. For no matter how high the building, nor how wide and handsome the view, food in such lofty environs invariably turns out to be much like that in nightclubshideous at worst, innocuous at best, and, generally, outrageously expensive.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD ACQUAINTANCE With a roundup of vintage Disney movies blanketing the metropolitan area this weekend, other wellknown cartoon figures are not being overlooked. Last Thursday, Leonard Maltin, the young film buff and scholar who is also one of the coordinators of the classic American comedy series at the Museum of Modern Art, resumed his sixweek cartoon series at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Maltin calls his programs Cartoons Unlimited: A Summer Animation Festival, and things began festively last week with a parade of such favorites as Bugs Bunny, Woody Woodpecker, Popeye and Farmer Alfalfa.

description: The Philadelphia Phillies are not awed by the world champion Cincinnati Reds. That was apparent last night in Riverfront Stadium when the National League's Eastern Division leaders beat the Western Division leaders, 42.

Walter Thompson Company and head of broadcast production for IJWT New York, was killed Tuesday in a helicopter crash while scouting locations to film cornimercials near Bishop. Calif. Mr. Fragasso, who lived in Rye. N.Y., was 42 years old.

description: BERNSTEINMollie C. Who shares the eternal SIM of our beloved son, Albion. Peace to von. Mollie.

title: Fire Damages Landmark

Y., June 23 (UPI)A twoalarm fire early today heavily damaged a wood frame building described as a landmark and forced the evacuation of 14 elderly tenants, the police reported. One resident was slightly injured in the fire at the former Martha Wilson Nursing Home, 434 Franklin Avenue. The blaze was apparently touched off by a television set explosion.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley. ConservativeRepublican of New York, was in satisfactory condition today at. Bethesda Naval Hospital after contracting viral pneumonia, his office reported. The 53yearold Sentor was admitted yesterday. Aides said that the was not serious.

He said this would help take away some of the edge an informed bookmaker had over the uninformed bettor who places an illegal wager on college football and basketball games.

However, ours is as different from yours as day from night, East from West, or, to be perfectly blunt, liberty from enslavement.

title: F.B.I. BURGLARIES SAID TO BE FOCUS OF MAJOR INQUIRY

description: GUATEMALAFor the 20,000 inhabitants of the February 4 Colony, the sprawling slum is not the only grim reminder of the earthquake that devastated Guatemala over four months ago.

title: New Jersey Man Accused Of Threats to Rockefeller
description: NEWARK, June 23 (UPI) A Camden County man who made an unsuccessful bid to run for Congress on the Republican ticket was indicted today for threatening to kill Vice President Rockefeller.

title: Reynolds Patents Use Of Cereals in Tobacco
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company received five patents yesterday covering the use of five different cereal grains as tobacco extenders. Under the patents, the grains may he mixed with cigarette or pipe tobacco or used as substitutes.

title: Albany Bill Ties Tax Rises In New York and Nassau
description: ALBANY, June 23In a classic legislative squeeze play. Republicans in the Senate moved today to try to force Democrats here to accept a onecent increase in the Nassau County sales tax by tying the increase to a tax measure vital to New York City.

title: MORE BEAME COTS ADOPTED BY BOARD
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday adopted an intensified austerity plan for New York City that would require Mayor Beame to in!crease his cuts by at least $50 millionand probably much morein the coming year, according to the board's execufive director

title: Teamster Pension Funds Found Unaccounted For
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 23Labor Department investigators have found that hundreds of millions of dollars in the teamsters union's Central States Pension Fund is unaccounted for, and the department is considering putting Federal trustees in charge of the fund, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: BEACH POLLUTION ONLLLAID TO CITY
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., June 23A number of public officials today began pointing to New York City as the major source of raw sewage that has washed up on Long Island shores in recent weeks.

title: Arms Negotiators Meet Again
description: GENEVA, June 23 (Reuters) United States and Soviet negotiators met here today in the 160th session of the strategic arms limitation talks on a new agreement to curb nuclear arsenals. The negotiators are trying to complete details of a new pact limiting each side to 2,400 intercontinental missiles and bombers, including 1,320 missiles to be fitted with multiple warheads.

title: Issue and Debate
description: One of the most trequently mentioned and least understood issues in the running debate on a new international economic order is the transfer of technology from the rich countries to the poor. Increasingly the lessdeveloped countries see improved access to new technology as the key to their economic growth, and increasingly they arc complaining that the technology received from industrialized countries has been insufficient, too expensive or not really suitable to their particular needs.

title: West Bank Is Calm Again After Riots But Arabs Still Protest the Occupation
description: NABLUS, Israeli  Occupied West Bank, June 22An Israeli armored personnel carrier was parked outside a restaurant here today, its machine gun untended and its heavy steel door open to the sun. On the restaurant terrace, three Israeli soldiers in combat gear were eating roasted corn on the cob and bantering cheerfully with an Arab waiter about the price of a small bottle of arak.

title: Guidelines Issued to Curb Genetic Research Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Guidelines to govern revolutionary and potentially hazardous genetics research were issued today by the National Institutes of Health for distribution to American scientists and to scientific societies and governments throughout the world.

title: NEWCAR SALES UP 28% FOR MIDJUNE
description: DETROIT, June 23 (AP)Sales of domestic new cars in midJune rose 28 percent over yearearlier levels, with continued gains by the big three automakers offsetting a steep decline by the American Motors Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a chart in The Times yesterday, an incorrect figure was given for the nation's inflation rate over the last three months as measured by the Consumer Price Index. The figure should have been 4.9 percent.

title: House Reforms Approved By Democrats After Fight
description: WASHINGTON, June 23House Democrats passed tonight the bulk of the package of reform proposals that would substantially change the chamber's administrative operations, but only after more than seven hours of bitter infighting between opposing factions.

title: 'Big Bus' Is Inexhaustible Film Comedy
description: Movie comedies nowadays are like large airplanes with every conceivable flying feature except aerodynamics. They roar around the runways making the right noises, the jet engines go like a dream, the seat belts and ashtrays are flawless. And none of it lifts as much as an inch from the ground.For the first few minutes, "The Big Bus" gives every forced sign of being one more gag-stuffed, landbound contraption. Then there is a lurch, a bump and an almost forgotten lifting sensation. For at least three-quarters of an hour it is soaringly, achingly funny.Then it settles back down on the runway and bumps along more or less predictably. But the glow of startled gratitude lasts for quite a while.It seems evident from the start that we are in the presence of yet another genre parody or put-on. Not a mock-western or mock-detective movie this time, but a mock-Airport-Hindenberg-Grand Disaster Hotel movie.The parody involves the creation of a nuclear-powered giant bus that makes the first nonstop run from New York to Denver. Archfiends try to sabotage it, mechanisms fail, the crew is racked with personal and professional problems, the passengers are a menagerie of odd and problematical types.The conventional parody things start the movie off: the mock portentous announcements of the new invention, the heavy satire on Cape Kennedy-style launching preparations. A bomb goes off, disabling the crew and flooring the scientist in charge. Then comes the fist bump.The scientist (Harold Gould) lies there attended by a maniacally incompetent doctor. His daughter (Stockard Channing) runs up. "He can't hear you," the doctor says, covering the scientist's face with a sheet. "Of course I can hear you" says a voice from under the sheet. "Oh, I thought he was resting," the doctor says.A new driver must be found. The scene shifts to a bus drivers' bar. In comes Dan Torrance (Joseph Bologna). "Hello, Whitey," he says to one colleague. "Hello, Blackie," he says to another. "Hello, Reddy, Hello Bluie, Hello, Greenie," he raves on. No one answers; Torrance, the best driver in the business, is ostracized. He is suspected of having eaten 110 passengers when his bus broke down in the desert.He denies it. "I ate the seats. I boiled the floor mats like they taught us to," he pleads. At most, he insists, he might have eaten one foot by mistake.He is hired, in any case. The passengers assemble. They include Ruth Gordon as a housewife who has run away from home after "50 years of cooking and cleaning and fixing the TV antenna," a couple celebrating their divorce, a disbarred veterinarian, a failed priest and so on.The busa successfully and comically inflated vehiclerolls off and the disasters begin. The disasters are of a more or less predictable humor. It is the characters, played with fine lunacy by such actors as Sally Kellerman, Lynn Redgrave and Ren Auberjonois, that provide the lift.In their lead roles, both Mr. Bologna and Miss Channing are fine. Miss Channing, who specializes in kooky roles, has the difficult part of straight woman, more or less. Even so, she manages to be funny just standing still and impersonating Elizabeth Taylor.The main credit for the picture, though, must go to the writers, Fred Freeman and Lawrence J. Cohen, and the director, James Frawley. They have unearthed a buried truth: Comedies can, in fact, be funny."The Big Bus" is playing at the Loews State I and the Sutton Theaters. It is rated PG for parental guidance. Parents should take all their children by the shoulders and march them off to see it.

title: Running Tide Is Victor in Sail
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda. June 23Running Tide, a famous 60foot sloop from Annapolis. Md., was declared the winner of the Bermuda ocean race today. Al Van Metre's black beauty had finished the 635mile passage from Newport, R. I., yesterday at 1 P.M., and when handicaps were figured, he had posted the best corrected time. 86 hours.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 2.3Dr. James M. Shuart, who has served as Hofstra University's vice president for administrative services since last year. was elected today to be the university's sixth president.

title: Its Lush Interior Is Stylish, Too
description: The design of the club and restaurant atop the World Trade Center would probably send Mies van der Rohe whirling in his grave. Gone is the austerity, the tightness, the discipline of purist modern architecture, but instead of seeking refuge in any historical style, the architect for the project, Warren Platner, has taken elements of modern design and loosened them, manipulated them, contorted them into a style that can only be called sensuous modernism.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23The superintendent of the United States Air Force Academy said today that an honor code clause allowing for punishment other than expulsion had strengthened the code his academy had inherited from West Point.

Nitcher, 47 years old, and his wife, Helen, also 47, of El Sobrante, Calif., escriped with minor injuries.

Now it is 1976 and, while there were initial weak attempts to change those disposal practices, officials agree nothing has been done. And now the beaches have been closed.

title: Possessed Infant Turns Into Killer In British 'Devil'
description: The week's not yet over but as of yesterday "The Devil Within Her," which opened at the Penthouse and other theaters, stands a good chance of being the week's worst movie about demonic possession.The British import, directed by Peter Sasdy, stars Joan Collins as a nightclub stripper who is cursed by a fellow worker, an amorous dwarf (George Claydon) whose advances she has spurned, to bear a devil-child.One might rightfully hope that all hell would break loose. It doesn't; it just mopes around, although the possessed baby does dispatch his nanny, his mummy, his daddy and his kindly old pediatrician, played by Donald Pleasence.The film is a smear to dwarfs everywhere.

The Pacific Telephone securities are rated a little lower, however.

title: Books of The Times
description: You can find advice to the troubled of mind in every subway car and on every lamppost. And books explaining how to solve your emotional problems come out at the rate of 365 a year. Why then is Dr. Joel Kovel's A Complete Guide to Therapy: From Psychoanalysis to Behavior Modification worth singling out from the thousands of others like it and paying close attention to? First, because Dr. Kovel is a serious mana practicing psychoanalyst, an associate professor of psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and the author of an original and provocative study, White Racism: A Psychohistory, which was nominated for a 1970 National Book Award in the category of phiand religion. description: The time has come for us to seek a partnership between North America, Western Europe and Japan. Our three regions share economic, political and security concerns that make it logical that we should seek everincreasing unity and understanding.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities said in report today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency had failed to fulfill their obligations in investigating the assassination in 1963 of President Kennedy.

title: Simon's Breezy 'Murder by Death'
description: The dinner party takes place far from any point of reliable reference, on a foggy night, inside a vast, gloomy old house where one shouldn't trust the wine, the chandeliers, the thunder outside, or the oil portraits, whose eyes tend to follow the action below. The butler is blind and the cook is not only deaf and unable to speak, she also cannot read, which makes the food scarce and communication with and between the domestic help impossible.What's worse is that the host, an eccentric millionaire named Lionel Twain, is some kind of fiend. In the 1930's he was arrested for attempting to smuggle a truckload of rich white Americans into Mexico to pick melons.The guests look familiar, Strangely. They include Sidney Wang, the famous Chinese detective and a member of the Catalina police, who starts sentences saying something on the order of "Treacherous fog, like mushrooms. . . ." There are also Sam Diamond, the tough Frisco private eye and his secretary-mistress, Tess; the famous Belgian detective, Milo Perrier, and his chauffeur-companion, Marcel; the tweedy English amateur sleuth, Miss Marbles, and Dick and Nora Charleston, who are elegant, tall and very thin, and who act as if they invented the dry martini.The occasion is a murder, and the movie, "Murder by Death," is for people who never quite remember who killed Roger Ackroyd. Neil Simon remembers enough to have written one of his nicest, breeziest screenplays, a parody murder mystery that appears to be the cheerful confession of a man who, more often than he should, has sat up until all hours of the night reading to find out who did it, and who has then promptly forgotten."Murder by Death," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and other theaters, is Mr. Simon's fond send-up of the work of Agatha Christie, Dashiell Hammett and Earl Derr Biggers. By bringing Sam Spade into the comparatively genteel worlds of Hercule Poirot, Charlie Chan, Miss Marple and Nick and Nora Charles, Mr. Simon might appear to have mixed his genres with unforgivable lack of respect. Yet his creation, Sam Diamond, hilariously mugged by Peter Falk, is one of the principal joys of the film; he's the rude noise that shakes up the drawing room.All of the performances are good, and if some seem better than others, it may simply be the material. James Coco is very, very funny as the somewhat prissy take-off on Hercule Poirot, his toupee and his eating habits. David Niven and Maggie Smith are marvelous as Dick and Dora Charleston, though they haven't enough to do, and Eileen Brennan is an inspired hybrid of Joan Blondell and Lauren Bacall as Sam Diamond's secretary-mistress. If Peter Sellers is not quite as funny as we expect, it may be because we've seen him do his Oriental bit before. It no longer surprises.Alec Guinness is most welcome as the blind butler, but Nancy Walker isn't around long enough as the disadvantaged maid, though she almost brings down the house with one magnificent absolutely silent scream. Which leaves Truman Capote, which I suppose I can't because he plays the diabolical Lionel Twain. Mr. Capote possibly is acting, but it looks more as if he's giving us an over-rehearsed impersonation of himself as people see him on unrehearsed TV talk shows.Considering the tone and manner of "Murder by Death," it would seem to be very much a Neil Simon work, but that may be to underestimate the contributions of Robert Moore, a talented theater director ("The Boys in the Band," "Promises, Promises") who is making his debut as a film director here. Whoever should get the credit, "Murder by Death" is as light and insubstantial as one could wish.The film has been rated PG. Naughty language did it.

title: Columbia Pictures in Pact To Sell Music Unit to EMI
description: Columbia Pictures Industries announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its music publishing division, including the operating assets of Screen GemsColumbia Music Inc. and the Colgems Music Corporation, to EMI Ltd. of London, for $23.5 million in cash. Sir Bernard Delfont, director of the EMI Film and Theatre Corporation, announced a related agreement in principle that provides for EMI to make a multimilliondollar investment in four of Columbia's upcoming major film releases.

title: Film: 'The Great Scout':Prospecting Trio Adds Fun to Western With Harmless Dirty Tricks
description: "The Great Scout and Cathouse Thursday" begins well enough, with Lee Marvin winning barroom bet by picking up a rattlesnake and kissing it. It's not exactly Gable and Lombard, but the faces have the same mutual suitability.It ends well enough with a showdown punch-up between Marvin and the smoothie villain. Robert Cuip: lots of harmless dirty tricks and rolling around in the mud.Mr. Marvin is good at physical adversity. His features are shaped by a sandstorm, and it is in other moments, when the wind has blown out and it is time to register more subtle emotions that he seems excessive and out of place, like foul-weather gear slung over a drawing-room couch.The problem with "Great Scout," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and other theaters, is the long corrugated road between its beginning and end. So many clumsy examples of the funny western have gouged their way, square-wheeled, along it that we set our teeth anticipating each joke as if it were a pothole.There were once three partners who prospected a gold claim. The first, Jack Colby  played with likable deviousness by Mr. Culp  absconded with the proceeds, made a fortune and went into politics. The other two bumped along, scavenging a living.One is Sam Longwood (Mr. Marvin). The other. Joe Knox, is a loud-mouthed Indian half-breed whose idea of revenge on the white race is to infect it with syphilis. Knox, is not so much played as pillaged by Oliver Reed. He makes him winsome.The plot has these two trying in various ways to steal their money back from Colby: one of their schemes being to kidnap his wife. The wife has a foul tongue and low sexual habits, but, such is the power of graceful acting, Elizabeth Ashley makes her the movie's closest approach to civil comedy. Kay Lenz who plays Cathouse Thursday, a young camp-follower of Longwood's tries hard for the same thing but misses.Rough language, and feet sticking out of beds at non-missionary angels, earn this movie its PG rating.

Mr. Morgenstein, who was 17 years old at the time of the murder, was tried as an adult and convicted March 5 of fatally shooting Kimberly McIntosh, 22, a fashion model, after she.reportedly spurned him.

title: Personal Finance: Vacation Homes

title: The Screen: 'Logan's Run,' a Science-Fiction Fantasy
description: It is the dubious premise of "Logan's Run," the science-fiction fantasy that opened yesterday, that by the middle of the 23d century overpopulation and air pollution will have rendered life on the surface of this planet impossible and that the strictly controlled, drastically reduced number of survivors will live near Washington in a city that sort cf looks like the Houston Astrodome on the outside but inside is a Hollywood special-effects expert's dream.Within this huge bubble life is simple, automatic and perfect. Everything is ruled by a computer, including the weather. Babies are born from machines. Pleasure is the principle. At age 30 each citizen goes through "the ritual of the carousel," thus to be reborn in a spectacular display of levitation and laser beams, though it's just a fancy way of executing the old-timers and getting rid of the ashes.If you know your science fiction at all, you know that no perfect world of the future is perfect. This one has a major flaw. A lot of people aren't convinced that the carousel actually renews them, and they try to run away to escape execution. "Logan's Run," written by David Zelag Goodman and directed by Michael Anderson, is the story of one of the city's policemen, a man named Logan (Michael York), who himself becomes one of the "runners" who had earlier been his quarry.Just why and for what particular purpose Logan makes his run is anything but clear after you've sat through nearly two hours of this stuff. "Logan's Run" is less interested in logic than in gadgets and spectacle, but these are sometimes jazzily effective and even poetic. Had more attention been paid to the screenplay, the movie might have been a stunner.This "Logan's Run," which is quite different from the novel by William F. Nolan and George Clayton, is harmless fun enlivened by a couple of sequences that are as good as the entire film should have been.One, early in the movie, shows us the the carousel ceremony, which is a kind of aerial ballet, fireworks display and skeet shoot. The other is a sequence in which Logan and his girl, played by Jenny Agutter, explore the ruins of Washington, which, though overgrown by vines, could easily be restored to its ancient splendor with the help of a pair of pruning shears, a lawn mower and a little plaster and paint. Peter Ustinov shows up in this sequence giving a benignly fussy performance as a sweet old hermit whose dearest wish is to meet people.The film's PG rating apparently has reference to some nudity and a very blurry sequence in which Mr. York and Miss Agutter pass in slow-motion through a dimly lit pleasure palace whose patrons try to persuade the couple to join in. They emerge untampered with.

Neither Dave Wolf's steak and seafood house at 1240 Avenue of the America's, nor G. Lombardi's, down in Little Italy at 53 Spring Street, is yet crowded that you can't get a reservation, but both Mr. Wolf, a senior citizen, and Mr. Lombardi, definitely a junior, were full of smiles on our recent visits to their establishments. title: Discard's Visit to Britain Ends With Specific Issues Unresolved
description: LONDON, June 24The first visit to this country in 16 years by a French President ended today with expressions of mutual good will but without agreement: on the specific issues that clividz, Britain and France.

title: Bay State Strike Ends
description: State services returned to normal in Massachusetts as 20,000 public employees ended their threeday strike. Page A15.

title: Kissinger Expresses Hope After Talks With Vorster
description: LONDON, June 24Secretary 4f State Henry A. Kissinger said today that after two days of talks with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, a process is in motion to droduce a negotiated solution And avoid a racial war in southern Africa.

title: Light Opera Troupe Is Heavy on Nostalgia
description: Eight years ago. William MountBurke staged and conducted his first light opera here. It was Gilbert and Sullivan's The Pirates of Penzance. which was performed in the living room of Mr. MountBurke's West Side apartment. There were 12 people in the audience, fewer than in the cast. From that .developed the Light Opera of Manhattan, of which Mr. MountBurke is producerdirector. It is probably the only lightopera repertory company in America that functions year round, giving six performances a week. Its latest production, Sigmund Romberg's The Student Prince. has been such a nostalgic success that it is being held over until Aug. 1 at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street. It can be seen tonight and tomorrow evening at 8:30, tomorrow and Sunday 4.

title: Ashe, Miss Evert Gain at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24Topseeded. Chris Evert and Arthur Ashe reached the round of 16 at the AllEngland Club today, Miss Evert granting a lone game to Lesley Hunt, who took her to three sets in 1974, and Ashe blunting the heavy serves and strokes of Mark Edmundson, the Australian champion, 75, 62, 8.6, with his best showing at Wimbledon so far.

title: A PENSION ACTION SURPRISES ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 24  The Democratic members of the Assembly, believing themselves under severe electionyear pressure to reduce public employee pension benefits, today rejected as too prounion a pension proposal by their own leadership. They sent the leaders back to the drawing board to come up with a bill like the one passed by the Senate two days ago.

title: The Gray Area
description: LONDONFord Administration officials, led by Henry A. Kissinger, have reiterated their belief that the strategic arms limitation talks must continue to serve as the foundation for a less antagonistic superpower relationship. For more than a year, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and his colleagues have voiced a similar view. After signing the United StatesSoviet agreement on peaceful nuclear tests recently in Moscow, Mr. Breziniev stressed that the Soviet Union was doing all that it could do to achieve an accord limiting strategic weapons.

title: A New Rival for Zeferetti's Seat Wants Explanation of Staff Pay
description: Robert Chira, a 35yearold lawyer, announced yesterday he was opposing Representative Leo C. Zeferetti for the Democratic nomination for Congress in Brooklyn's 15th District and he challenged Mr. Zeferetti to explain how some of those on his Congressional payroll had earned their. Day.

title: Waldheim Expresses His Regret At Veto Barring Angola U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim expressed regrets today that Angola's request for United Nations membership had been blocked yesterday in the Security Council.

description: ROME, June 247Pope Paul VI, in an addressto the Roman Catholic hierarchy released here today, hailed Catholic education in the United States as the strength of the church in America.

But food buffs will be heading there aso because Buster Holmes will be making his own kind of music from noon t 5 P.M. each day.

title: Ford Found Strong. In Reagan Territory
description: President Ford would be at least as strong a Republican Presidential nominee in the South and West as would Ronald Reagan, according to the latest national survey of voter attitudes by The New York Times and CBS News, but the survey also showed that if the election were held today Jimmy Carter, the apparent Democratic nominee, would swamp either man by about 2 to 1.

title: Red Smith
description: ABOARD THE BARQUE EAGLE, June 24Now it can be told. Here, somewhere north of the fabled expanse the Bermuda Triangle, where ships and planes and people have been known to vanish without reason and without trace, the mystery is solved. The ships don't sink, the planes don't crash, the people don't drown. They just hang in suspension like chicken in aspic, as the great sailing ships of many nations have been hanging here between cloudless sky and motionless sea, inanimate blobs in a vast emptiness. The men on tnese snips LEIOUWIL Sports they were racing from Bermuda to Newport, R.I., and they believed that when the race of was done they would sail down to New The Times York to celebrate the 200th birthday of the United States with a parade up the Hudson. And they were right. This evening, after two days of no wind, captains of the squareriggers, the Tall Ships, agreed to move the race deadline forward by two days and the race for the Class A vessels came to an end. The parade will go on.

title: How to Get Tickets
description: Tickets may be obtained from the Newport Jazz Festival headquarters in the New York Sheraton Hotel on Seventh Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets (7578650), or from Ticketron outlets (5417290) from Chargit (2397177).

title: ENDING ALL CURBS ON DRUG ADS URGED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 24 A publicinterest advocate told the Board of Pharmacy, at a hearing here today on proposals for regulating prescriptiondrug advertisement that complete and unrestricted advertising was essential for comparisonshopping.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The 17yearold arrived for her interview one morning in June. Her lightbrown hair was neatly braided. She smiled, braces twinkling behind lips that knew no artificial color. She wore a crisp plaid blouse tucked into a blue denim skirt in the mode of the day. She could swim, she said. She had a driver's license and, Oh yes, sne added, I love children.

title: Movies, An ExTrio, Plays Club
description: JUST a few months ago, the Movies was a charming if rather eccentric trio that skittered back and forth between the underground rock circuit and the cabarets. They were too cute for the rockers and be properly cabaret cool, but they madde friends on both scenes, nonetheless. So many friends that they were signed to a bigtime maybe even bigmoney record contract: And Wednesnight they opened a fivenight showcase run at the Other End, as a prelude to their assault on the national market.

title: Ban on Advertising of Eyeglass Prics: Ends in New York State After Protests:
description: The New York State Education Department said yesterday it now considered the advertising of the prices of lenses and frames to be legal in the state. thus reversing a previous stand that had been the object of longstanding consumer pro tests.

description: Planetariums in the metropolitan area are reporting a steady increase in attendance as interest in science fiction, television shows such as Star Trek and the Viking space probe this summer stimulate interest in astronomy.

description: From the very beginning the outing was not supposed to be logical. It was intended to be democratic.

title: AIRPORT PLAN HAILED AFTER PLANE CRASH
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UPI)A seldomused ermrgency operation involving city policemen, firemen and four hospitals has been credited with averting a major disaster in the crash of an Allegheny Airlines DC9 at Philadelphia International Airport.

description: New York City was held liable yesterday for a $2 million award to Fire Department firefighters for violation of a labor union contract.

title: GEORGE D. EMMONS, RACING YACHTSMAN
description: George D. Emmons, a navigator on the 12meter yacht Weatherly when she defeated the Australian yacht Gretel in 1962 off Newport, Rd., in the America's Cup races, died Tuesday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. His age was 79.

title: Market Place A StockMarket Blow for Purolator
description: When officials of Purolator Inc., the oil filter maker and courier service company, announced that earnings in the first half of 1976 would be 3 to 6 percent below those for the similar period of 1975, they did nit expect the news to result in a stork market disaster.

title: Courageous Veto
description: Governor Carey has acted with courage and compassion, as well as due respect for the Constitution, in vetoing a highly questionable bill that would have required al: women under 18 to obtain parental consent for legal abortion. in rejecting the action of a politically obsequious Legislature, the Governor spared New York the tragic consequences of a measure that could have driven thousands of desperate young women back the bloody hands of illegal abortion mills.

title: CURBS ON BUSING SPECIFIED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 24President Ford, declaring that our domestic tranquillity and the future of American education were at stake, today proposed legislation to restrict the power of the courts to order busing as a remedy for segregated schools.

description: Barbara Ann Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Stein of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Scott Andre Wright, son of Warren E. Wright of Clinton, N. Y., and Nanette Wright of Chesterfield, Mass.

title: Ford or Reagan?
description: The nearcertainty of Jimmy Carter's nomination by the Democrats, and the fact that in the general election Mr. Carter will have a regional claim on most of the Southern and border states, poses the central question in the continuing Republican fight: Would Gerald Ford or Ronald Reagan be more likely to defeat Jimmy Carter?

title: $80 Million Set in Loan To Koreans
description: The London subsidiary of the Bankers Trust Company of New York has arranged an SSG millin, fiveyear Eurodollar loan for the Korean Development B'r.k. South Korea's leading financial institution and the prime lender to its major industries

title: U.S. Withdraws Military Advisers From Islands of Quemoy and Matsu
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The Administration said today that the United States had withdrawn its small military advisory teams from the Chinese, Nationalist islands of Quemoy and Matsu but that no further, withdrawal of American forces from Taiwan was planned now.

title: American Gift Helps the British Buy Site of Battle of Hastings
description: LONDON, June 24 (AP)An anonymous American academic institution gave Britain a Bicentennial gift todaythe bulk of the money to buy the site of the Battle of Hastings.

title: Beanie Honors Budget Aide
description: At a City Hall ceremony, Mayor Beanie presented the city's Distinguished Performance Medal to First Deputy Budget Director John J. Lanigan, who will retire ortt July 2 after a 40year career in city government. The Mayor said that Mr. Lanigan's contributions during the city fiscal crisis was unsurpassed.

title: Notes on People
description: Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Commerce, who was the United States Attorney General dismissed by Richard M. Nixon, the former President, in the Watergate crisis, received last night the second annual Louis Dembitz Brandeis medal for distinguished legal service. Mr. Richardson was honored at a Brandeis University dinner in New York's Plaza Hotel, at which Maxwell M. Raab, a Wall Street lawyer and former aide to President Dwight D. Eisenhower, was inducted as a fellow of the university. Mr. Richardson previously had served as Secretary of Defense, and before taking over at the Commerce merce Department, he was Ambassador to Great Britain. The first winner of the medal was Lson Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor.

title: ... Under Scrutiny
description: Between word and deed stretches a broad gulf, and voters have learned to their sorrow how different President's decisions in office may be from his rhetoric in the campaign. The tone of public statements may sometimes strike more sensitive chords than the actual words spoken.

title: Ashoka Ray In Raga Bill At Carnegie
description: Indian classical music is an ancient and complex art, and so it is difficult for a sympathetic but untutored Western enthusiast to judge how closely to a given tradition an artist may adhere, or how free he is with the ragas (basic note sequences) and talas (extended rhythmic cycles) that underlie the improvisation.

title: Dickson Leads With a 67
description: OAK BROOK, III., June 24 (UPI)Bob Dickson, who hasn't won a golf tournament in three years, capitalized on a few good breaks today to shoot a fourunderpar 67 and take a twostroke lead after the first round of the $200.000 Western poen.

description: Thursday, June 24, 1976

title: Business in New York Stemming the Flood of Companies Leaving
description: The news that City Hall once again is seeking a new approach and a new leader for its economic development programs raises the hope that New York at last may find the right formula for slowing its massive job losses in the private sector.

title: Records: Mozart and Hindemith
description: The Mass in C minor and the Requiem are Mozart's two greatest choral works, even if neither was completed. The two versions of the mass here both choose to perform only the music Mozart wrote, as opposed to the various versions available that flesh out the complete liturgical form with repetitions and borrowings from other works by the composer. Neither performance eliminates the older Colin Davis and Farnc Fricsav versions from the competition. The Somary is buoyantly, conducted, but his women singersthe women dominate the solo materialsimply are not up to those of the rival versions.

title: Buster Holmes's Red Beans And Rice: A Recipe for Eaters
description: I don't like thyme and bay leaves in red beans. said Buster in describing the following recipe. That's for gumbo. Smoked ham and hot sausage are nice, and I like a little garlic. But be careful about adding too much salt too early on, especially with the salt in the meat. Pickled pork is good, too, if you can get it.

title: About Real Estate
description: Ronald Keenan is 37 years old and his wife, Melanie, is 29. They live with their 4monthold on in a brownstone walkup on Ninth Street in Greenwich Village that they bought at. the time of their marriage two years ago. They have six tenants in efficiency apartments.

title: Music: Dorothy Collins Sings
description: If Dorothy Collins's program at Grand Finale, 210 West 70th Street, leans toward the work of Stephen Sondheim, it is understandable and certainly justifiable. Miss Collins got her first Broadway starring role in Mr. Sondheim's Follies, in which she sang the showstopping Losing My Mind. Her husband, Ronald Holgate, sang his first Broadway lead in Mr. Sondheim's SomeThing Happened On the Way to the Forum. They met while performing in the SondheimRichard Rodgers musical, Do I Hear A Waltz? And Miss Collins has also appeared in Mr. Sondheim's A Little Night Music.

title: Murder Suspect, Free on Bail, Held in Attempt to Kill Witness
description: A murder suspect free on $7,500 bail in a Chinatown gang; slaying earlier this month was arrested again and charged with attempted murder yesterday after he allegedly shot a teenage witness to the slaying in an ambush early yesterdays morning outside an East Side discotheque.

Mrs. Wallace's fat farm is called The Fountains and is run by the saturninely handsome Dr. Bertini, who is actually a dedicated man wistfully longing to touch spiritual fountains within his clients, as well as touching up their figures.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, June 24 (UPI)The pound fell below $1.77 for the first time in more than two weeks today, prompting moderate support from the Bank of England. The pound opened weaker at 81.7715, then light speculative selling pressure forced it to $1.7635 for the first time in more than two weeks. It recovered later to close at $1.7725.

description: New Yorkers and Long Islanders may be reluctant to swim at their favorite South Shore beaches, but will the current crisis brought about by oceanborne sewage also affect their eating of fish?

Walker, former Deputy Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, told a group of New Jersey businessmen yesterday in Wayne that we are falling away behind the rest of the world in per capita gross national product, because they've got their heads screwed on right on tax structures, particularly in Japan, Western Europe and the United Kingdom.

description: WELLESLEY ISLAND, N.Y. June 24More than 300.000 gallons of tarlike fuel oil that spilled from an oil barge grounded yesterday in the St. Lawrence Seaway spread slowly today through the Thousand Islands resort area, but cleanup crews were beginning to contain the spill.

title: Wind Shift Blamed in Crash Of Jet in Denver Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) A wind shift so severe that it cut an aircraft's speed by 47 miles an hour in less than five seconds caused the nonfatal crash of a Continental Airlines jet at Denver last August, according to a Federal accident report.

title: Queen Elizabeth's Rather Pricey

title: Reagan, in Mississippi, Rejects Plea That He Accept No. 2 Spot
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 24Ronald Reagan replied with an emphatic no way today to a prominent Mississippi Republican's plea that he, take the VicePresidential nomination this year and lay down the sword with President Ford.

title: Lollipops Are Recalled
description: WASHINGTON. June 24 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of two types of children's lollipops distributed in Arksnsas and Louisiana because the banned food coloring Red Dye No. 2 was used in their manufacture. The two types were Big Apple Suckers and Big RedHot Suckers, both manufactured by the Dumas Candy Company of E1 Dorado, Ark.

title: Management Alice in Corporationland
description: The game of Alice in Corporation land is played eery couple of months or so by a dozen women at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. One of the most significant aspects about it is the number of players who choose not to win.

title: Carey Accepts an Increase In Supplemental Budget
description: ALBANY, June 24  Bowing to bipartisan pressure from legislative leaders, Governor Carey agreed tonight to a supplemental budget of roughly $30 million  half again as much as the maximum he had insisted on  in an accord the leaders said later would permit the Legislature to adjourn this weekend.

title: Sailing Ships Give Up Race, Go to Engines
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 24The tall ships surrendered to modern times today, giving up their sailing race from Bermuda to Newport because of a dead calm and turning on their engines to assure an arrival here by Saturday.

title: Sidewalk Cafes Get Hearing at City Hall
description: Sidewalk cafesan ornament of the city state to some New Yorkers and to others an intrusion on pedestrian rightsdominated a lengthy meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

description: President Ford would be at least as strong a Republican Presidential nominee in the South and West as would Ronald Reagan, according to the latest national survey of voter attitudes by The New YorK Times and CBS News, but the survey also showed that if the election were held today Jimmy Carter, the apparent Democratic nominee, swamp either man by about 2 to 1.

title: A Taste of India Comes to Central Park
description: Sitars, saris and hot samosasmusic and dance, a fashion show and Indian snacksare all part of an India Festival that will begin at 2:30 tomorrow al the mall in Central Park.

description: Donald Braider, an author of books on artists and other subl jects, died Tuesday at his home; in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 53 years old.
