description: Morning

title: Custer's Defeat Remembered In Entreaties On Peace
description: CUSTER BATTLEFIELD, Mont., June 24 With little pomp, unobtrusive but heavy security and an impromptu Indian victory dance, the Federal Government today commemorated the 100th anniversary of the battle of Little Bighorn.

title: DR. MOREY L. APPELL, 59, A PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Morey L. Appell, a psychologist and associate professor of educational psychology. at Hunter College, died yesterday in his Greenwich, Conn., home. He was 59 years old.

title: Stocks On Amex And Counter Gain In Bargain Buying
description: After two days of declines, stocks on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market moved ahead yesterday In slow trading. Some brokers thought bargain hunters were at work, picking up some quality issues.

title: HIGH COURT FREES STATES AND CITIES FROM U.S. PAY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, June 24In a lantmark ruling that strengthens states rights and limits the power of the Federal Government, the Supreme Court struck down on a 5to4 vote today the laws that extended Federal minimum wage and maximum hour provisions to state and municipal employees.

title: Dance: Balanchine Dream
description: GFORGE Balanchine has the right and proper inconsistency of genius. Most of his ballets are spare and sparse, yet once in a while he will produce a work that is pure and classical operahouse stuf.

title: Gotbaum Issues Warning On Strike in New York
description: Victor Gotbaum, the leader of the city's municipal workers, warned yesterday that if there was no substantive ageement on a new labor contract by next Thursday, he wonld recommend a strike by all City workers.

title: Music: Goldman Sreirit of 76
description: With the Goldman Band back for its 59th season of free concerts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, sponsored by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, thousands of New Yorkers will again have the opportunity to hear the famous ensemble's inimitable Programs of band music.

title: Summary of Court Rulings
description: Ruled, 7 to 2, that if the police see a person whom they have probable cause to arrest standing in the doorway of a home, they may follow that person into the home in an attempt to make an arrest, even if they have no warrant.

title: 15,000 in Coliseum Witness Installation Of Bishop on L. I.
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., June 24John R. McGann was installed today as the second bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre in a ceermony marked by solemnity, sacrament and pageantry.

title: ALLAN F. HUBBELL, 61, DIALECT SPECIALIST
description: Allan F. Hubbell, professor of English at New York University and a specialist in the dialects of New York, died Tuesday in Worcester Memorial Hospital, Worcester, Mass. He was 61 years old and lived at 4 Washington Square Village.

title: Publishing: Georgia O'Keeffe
description: GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, a classic figure in American painting who is now 88 years old, is putting aside palette and pigment to complete her first bookan account of how her career started and evolved, her relationships with other artists and the esthetic values she cherishes. The book will cover a time span from 1916 to the present and although not intended as an autobiography, it will surely provide a biographical outline of her life.

title: The Pop Life
description: BORDERLINE GUSH is the way Warren Zevon, the latest challenger in the promising young singersong writer lists, describes his response to his first Asylum album and current tour. It's been very, very rewarding, Mr. Zevon said the other day from Boston. We've opened for some wonderful artists, Jackson [Browne] has been great, my management's been great, Asylum's been great, the reviews have been great. Is that gush enough?

title: Weekend Gardening:Orchid Bargains
description: Sales have become part of the American way of life, and they are not an unusual merchandising device even in plant stores. Rarely, however, will you see an orchid plant on sale. Even more rarely will you see a grower who specializes in orchids marking down prices. Yet if you are an inveterate salegoer as well as a plant lover thinking about expanding your collection to include an orchid or two, this is going to be your weekend. And there's a lovely drive in the country into the bargain.

title: 5 IN CROATIA JAILED 20 YEARS FOR BOMB
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. June 24 (AP)The District Court of Zagreb today sentenced five Croatian separatists to death for planting a time bomb in 1975, then commuted the punishment to 20 years imprisonment for each, the official Yugoslav press agency Tanyug reported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark said that former Representative Joseph J. Maraziti had not committed a crime when he put a woman friend on his Congressional payroll, even though she was working full time at another job.

title: The Confederacy Rocks Again
description: Two of the Souths most experienced rock bands, both enjoying an upsurge in popularity, performed at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park on Wednesday, and if the familiar outlines of the Gulf and Western building hadn't been visible towering above the trees, the scene could have been mistaken for a rock festival in Atlanta or Memphis. Confederate flags were waving and although there were few rebel yells, there was n new wrinklesquare dancing in the aisles.

title: Times Club Presents Awards
description: The New York Times Thirty Year Club yesterday presented its annual Arthur Hays Sulzberger awards of $50 United States Government bonds to two sixthgraders of Public School 111, the Adolph S. Ochs School, 440 West 53d Street. The winners, selected by the principal, Jerome Green, were Georgina Corbo and John Stefanidis. The awards are made for scholastic achievement and good citizenship. The presentation was made by the club's new president, John McCue.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Browse thru 5 acres of relics & nostalgia. More then 30,000 sq. ft. of buildings loaded with furniture, relics from old houses, marine salvage, stalfired glass, farm & country store Items, lighting fixtures, antiques, fabulous reproducVans and just plain junk. Conn. Turnpike, Exit 6. Closed Sundays & Mondays. Write for free literature.

title: D.C. Jury Sets $640,000 As Damages in Rape Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The District of Columbia has been ordered to pay $640,000 to a 10yearold girl who was allegedly raped on three occasions in 1974 by a janitor at the public elementary school she attended.

title: Levi Strauss 2d Quarter Net Is Up 43.8%
description: Levi Strauss & Company, manufacturer:4 of jeans, slacks and other apparel, reported yesterday profit increases of 43.8 percent for the second fiscal quarter, ended May 30, and 105.9 percent for the half year.

title: Reforms in the House . .
description: It is clear from the reform proposals now emerging from the Democratic majority in the House that no matter what else may be said of Elizabeth Ray, she made an unwitting contribution to good government. Under the prod of unsavory headlines coupled with the imminence of elections, the House leadership has produced a package of reforms which, though not designed to do much about sexual mores on Capitol Hill, will curb some of the more obvious and tempting opportunities for misfeasance in office.

title: Most L.I. Beaches Reopen; Jones Beach Remains Shut
description: OCEAN BEACH, L. I., June 24Almost all Long Island beaches were declared fit for swimming today after sewage debris had closed them for as much as a week.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 24All 10 Federal district judges in the state have been asked to join ahearing here next Wednesday to decide if Federal courts can reopen the public schools if they are closed July 1.

title: Red Smith
description: ABOARD THE BARQUE EAGLE, June 24Now it can be told. Here, somewhere north of the fabled expanse the Bermuda Triangle, where ships and planes and people have been known to vanish without reason and without trace, the mystery is solved. The ships don't sink, the planes don't crash, the people don't drown. They just hang in suspension like chicken in aspic, as the great sailing ships of many nations have been hanging here between cloudless sky and motionless sea, inanimate blobs in a vast emptiness. The men on these ships thought Sports they were racing from Bermuda to Newport, R.I., and they believed that when the race of was done they would sail down to New The Times York to celebrate the 200th birthday of the United States with a parade up the Hudson. And they were right. This evening, after two days of wind, captains of the squareriggers, the Tall Ships, agreed to move the race deadline forward by two days and the race for the Class A vessels came to an end. The parade will go on.

title: Carter Loses Two Delegates In Federal Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)  Delegate totals from the District of Columbia's Democratic Presidential primary are being reshuffled because of a United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruling that about 8.600 ballots previously ruled invalid should be counted.

title: U.S. Attorney Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) David W. Marston, legislative counsel to Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, was nominated byt President Ford yesterday to succeed Robert E.J. Curran as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

title: $516.2. Billion Bill For H.E.W., Labor Backed by House
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The House of Representatives approved tonight a $56.2 billion appropriation bill that includes funds for a variety of employment and social programs, raising the possibility of a veto by President Ford.

title: it.&P. Achieves a Profit For First Fiscal Quarter
description: KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., June 24The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company told its shareholders here today that the giant food chain had a profit in the first fiscal quarter on a 22 percent sales rise.

title: Kissinger Expresses Hope After Talks With Vorster
description: LONDON, June 24Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said. today that after two days of talks with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, a process is in motion to produce a negotiated solution and avoid a racial war in south. ern Africa.

title: HIGH COURT FREES STATES AND CITIES FROM U.S. PAY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, June 24In a landmark ruling that strengthens states rights and limits the power of the Federal Government, the Supreme Court struck down on a 5to4 vote today the laws that extended Federal minimum wage and maximum hour provisions to state and municipal employees.

title: A THREAT DELAYS HARRISES
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24A prospective juror whose wife received an anonymous threatening telephone call was discharged today from the jury being selected to hear the state's kidnapping, armed robbery and assault case against William and Emily Harris.

title: Killings Condemned at O.A.U.
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, June 24 (Reuters)Africans killed in the South African riots were the victims of oppression, the Prime Minister of Mauritius said today in opening a meeting of the Organization of African Unity:on this Indian Ocean island nation.

title: Campbell Quits Ministry At the Riverside Church
description: Ernest T. Campbell has resigned unexpectedly as senior Minister of Riverside one of the nation's leading religious centers.

title: Syria and Egypt. in Move. To Settle Policy Dispute
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 24Egypt and Syria took relatively cautious steps today toward political and military cooperation.

title: Chiropractor Indicted as Medicaid Cheat
description: A chiropractor with offices in Brooklyn and Manhattan was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of fraudulently obtaining nearly $28,000 from Medicaid over threeyear period starting in 1973.

title: Perfect Game by Alexander Lost in 8th
description: To pitch a perfect game, a pitcher has to face 27 batters and retire them all. Don Larsen did it for the Yankees in the 1956 World Series. Catfish Hunter did it in 1968. Harvey Haddix did it in 1959, then added nine more batters, but lost. Eight other pitchers have done it in major league history.

title: Doing Time in Hollywood
description: Tom Dardis has a good ideaalthough, after all the huffing and puffing, it just sits there, like Howard Hughes's Spruce Goose, not doing much. What, he wonders, did Scott Fitzgerald, William Faulkner, Nathanael West, Aldous Huxley and James Agee do to Hollywood, When they had to work there? We are more accustomed to hearing about what Hollywood did to them, a morality tale in which Hollywood usually plays the part of venereal disease.

title: ...Starring a Concentration of Light.
description: The 10:30 P.M. showing of Laserium at the Hayden Planetarium is a hot ticket because that's the time of the weekend when the Pepsi Generation is looking for a cure for its ennui, and Laserium is said to be psychedelic. In fact, it may be one of the most consciousnessdisplacing shows in town.

title: At Roosevelt
description: Savoir, last season's horse of the year in harness racing, returns to action on Long Island tonight in the 825,000 Su Mac Lad Trot. Bill Haughton will drive the 8yearold gelding from the No. 5 post in the onemile event. Savoir, owned by Allwood Stable of Far Hills, N. J., was listed as a 31 favorite on the overnight line.

title: De Hart Hubbard, 72, Is Dead.; Won Olympic Broad Jump Title
description: CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) De Hart Hubbard, a track star during the 1920's who became the first black American to win an Olympic gold medal, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: Debentures of Pacific Phone Sell Slowly
description: In the key corporate bond financing this week, the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company sold 8300 million of longterm debentures that underwriters priced to yield 8.85 percent, and the securities sold Credit slowly. At the end Markets of the afternoon, the winning underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley & Company, reported that no more than third of the issue had been sold investors.

description: The New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, yesterday abandoned his effort Ito work out a compromise that would have let Maurice H. NaIdjari retain substantial power as a special state prosecutor, (thus ending, any chance that Mr. Nadjari would survive in that post.

title: Wepner in Match At Shea Stadium
description: Not since the Jets surfaced from football's lower depths to challenge the Giants have New York's sports fans been as argumentative.

title: Screen: Altman's Buffalo Bill
description: WHAT are we going to do about Robert Altman? He simply won't: stand still so that the movie industdy, movie critics and the movie going public ;can get a comfortable hold on him. He is praised for doing one thing right and he takes another direction to try something completely different.

title: If It Flies Without Feathers, New Space Museum Has It
description: WASHINGTON, June 24There's one thing missing in the new National Air and Space Museum: a feather from Icarus's wings:

description: WASHINGTON, June 24Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation kidnapped a radical political figure within the last five years in an attempt to frighten the man and deter his political activity, a wellplaced bureau source disclosed today.

description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 24 (Reuters)The deputy leader of Jamaica's opposition Labor Party, Senator Pearnel Charles, has been detained under the country's emergency regulations, it was announced today.

description: BOUND BROOK, N.J., June 23A large sign outside James Shea's Citgo gasoline station here announces: Citgo credit Cards accepted.

description: BUENOS AIRES, June. 24 Argentina's armed forces, three months after having overthrown President Isabel Martinez de Pern, are in a bitter struggle with leftwing extremists, many of whom Dave been killed.

title: Pilot Attributes Airline Discharge To Homosexuality
description: MINNEAPOLIS. June 24 (AP) Guy Hunt says he lost al pilot's job with Northwest Airlines because he is a homosexual. He has filed a discrimination complaint to regain his job.

description: WARSAW, June 24Poland today announced a big package of food price increases, ending a fiveyear experiment in pricefreezine.

title: Some Bolivian Miners Reportedli End Strike
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 24 (Ap)About .30 percent of Bolivia's striking tin miners mimed work today, the Government said. Others vowed to continue the .15day stoppage that has crippled the industry providing Bolivia with most of its export revenue.

title: The Tragedy of Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 24Both the rioting in the black townships here and the police; actions that appear to have quashed them bear marked; similarities to the racial dis orders that swept through the black ghettos of American cities in the sixties. The roving bands of black youths in Soweto threw rocks, raised fists and chanted Black power just as young people did in Watts, Newark and Detroit. The questions raised in newspapers here ahout whether police overreacted were like the questions asked after riots in BedfordStuyvesant and Jersey City. And the questions asked by whites who wondered what exactly sparked the fury of Soweto and what led blacks to burn their own communities had familiar ring to them.

title: Bill Offers Racing a Tax Break
description: Faced with the ultimate prospect of default, the New York Racing Association hopes to get back on the right financial track with some help from Albany. Under a proposed bill worked out by the state's Budget Division, the tax structure under which the N.Y.R.A. operates would be revised in an effort to keep the association intact and increase its borrowing capacity. Apparently, many legislators are ready to concede that maybe the N.Y.R.A. really does have the shorts. At the Race Tracks

description: LOS ANGELES (NL.)Optioned Joe Simpson, outfielder, to Albuquerque of the Pa. rifle Coast League.

title: Art People
description: ALITTLE BIT of SoHo will go to West Berlin this fall, opening Sept. 5 at the 26th annual Berlin Festival. The plans announced last month for a show called SoHoDowntown Manhattan, to be presented in Berlin's Academy of Arts, are now jelling. At least, that's the word from Steve Reichard, a consultant for art shows and publications, who's doing the organizing along with Rend Block, a dealer with one foot in West Berlin, the other in SoHo, and H. Lutze, Berlin Festival coordinator for New York.

title: Custer's Defeat Commemorated By Entreaties On Peace
description: CUSTER BATTLEFIELD, Mont., June 24 With little pomp, unobtrusive but heavy security and an impromptu Indian victory dance, the Federal Government today commemorated the 100th anniversary of the battle of Little Bighorn.

title: Advertising
description: In planning for the future. Mary Wells Lawrence, chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene, is giving serious consideration to moving part or most of her agency out of the city and state. She isn't the only one in the advertising business with thoughts like this.

title: Old Warner Films To Play at Regency
description: A collection of 34 movies made by Warner Brothers between 1927 and 1949 will be shown at the Regency Theater, on Broadway at 68th Street starting tomorrow night and ending Sept. 4. The oldest movie will be The Jazz Singer'; the newest will be White Heat. Al Jolson sang in the first, and James Cagney died in the second, and tomorrow night Errol Flynn will shoot arrows. This will be in The Adventures of Robin Hood.

description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn ordered the Oakland A's last night to remove any restraints against the use of Joe Rudi, Vida Blue and Rollie Fingers, who have been benched by the team during the legal dispute gathering round their sale on June 15.

description: Edward Birdwell, horn player and for the last five years assistant to the dean of the Aspen Music Festival and Music School, will become deputy director of Carneale hall on Sept. 1.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOR MODERNS. says Dean :MacCannel!, reality and authenticity are thought to be elsewhere: in other historical periods and other cultures. in purer, simpler life styles. The tourist, then, becomes a traveler in modernity, an importer of ideas, and tourism itself serves as the ethnography of modernity.

title: Inoki Is Opponent in Tokyo Tonight
description: TOKYO, June 24  Both Muhammad Ali, the boxer, and Antonio Inoki, the wrestler, are serious about their World Heavyweight Martial Arts Championship Bout.

title: Police Find Youths Are Good Troopers
description: SEA GIRT, June 24It has not been an ordinary week for 80 teenagers assembled here at the State Police Training Center.

description: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The first session of the National Assembly of reunified Vietnam opened here today after 30 years of war and sepa ration.

description: There was no trading yesterday on the stock exchanges in Montreal and Toronto. They were closed in observance of the St. John the Baptist holiday.

title: U.S. MOVES CLOUD OUTLOOK FOR AID TO POOR NATIONS;
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The World Bank announced today, that its softloan affiliate, the International Development As sociation, had reached the $10 billion mark in aid to the poor. est of the less developed coun, tries.

title: ...and the White House
description: In a small but significant way, two members of the House attempted last week to impose rational limits on the personnel operations in the White House. Representatives Herbert E. Harris of Virginia and John Dingell of Michigan knocked $22 million out of the appropriation for running the White House next yearincluding $16.5 million for staffon the ground that the appropriation was being moved through the House without the required legal foundation.

title: Big Crafts Fair Gives Rhinebeck a Carnival Air
description: The biggest and most renowned crafts fair in the Northeast opens this morning at the Dutchess County fairgrounds in Rhinebeck, N.Y. It will ruafthrough Sunday, from.10 A.M. to .6 2:1%.daily.

description: WASHNGTON, June 24The tax bill currently before the Senate contains two separate provisions that appear likely to confer benefits of thousand's of dollars, possibly millions, on relatives of Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana.

title: Defendant Rights Curbed In Two 72 Court Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The Supreme Court ruled today that when the police have probable cause to make an arrest and they sight a suspect in the doorway of his home, they may pursue him into the house even if they have no arrest warrant.

title: Art: The Tale of Kimono
description: When Raoul Dufy was young, he designed fabrics for Paul Poiret at the time when Poiret had no serious rival as a dress designer. It's funny, Dufy said later. Women wouldn't buy my paintings at any price, but they'd stand in line to carry me around on their backs.

title: A Walk Down Ghostly Aisles
description: All it takes to see the ghosts of New York City's first dramatic actorshidden in lower Manhattan's steel and glass and concrete canyonsare a good pair of walking shoes and a willing imagination. Mary C. Henderson will do the rest.

title: Hospital NonSolutions
description: In attempts to head off threatened hospital strikes that could inflict immeasurable suffering on the city's sick and infirm, two separate panels have recommended concessions that would reduce the number of planned layoffs in municipal hospitals and grant costofliving increases to employees in voluntary hospitals.

title: Sentencing of Mercenaries In Angola Off Until Monday
description: LUANDA, Angola. June 24, (UPI)Sentencing of 13 American and British mercenaries was put off today until Monday, to allow the trial judges more time to decide whether to order the death penalty. There were indications in the Angolan press that the Government, which ordered the postponement, might be leaning away from capital punishment.

title: Foster Gets Berth On Hurdles Victory
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 24For weeks there has been talk that Charles Foster, the world's best high hurdler in 1974 and the second best in 1975, would be an injured alsoran in 1976, the victim of a tender thigh. Today in the United States Olympic track trials, Foster ran like the healthiest man in the world and won the 110meter high hurdles final.

title: 3 Amendments on Court Reform Passed by New York Assembly
description: ALBANY, June 24The New York State Assembly tonight passed three proposed constitutional amendments designed to have Court of Appeals judges appointed instead of elected, to streamline judicial discipline and to centralize court administration.

title: Hi Ho, Silver!
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Jimmy Carter, who is not usually a frivolous man, poked fun at Henry Kissinger the other day as the Lone Ranger of American foreign policy. Hi Ho, Silverly Carter said in effect. But the important thing about the Governor's latest speech is not that he differed with so many of Mr. Kissinger's policies but agreed with so many of them.

title: EUROPEAN REDS SET TALKS FOR TUESDAY
description: EAST BERLIN, June 24 (Reuters)  The longawaited conference of 28 European Communist parties wil be held in East Berlin on Tuesday and Wednesday, it was announced today.

title: JUVENILES FACING STIFFER PENALTY
description: ALBANY, June 25Bipartisan agreement on a bill that allows Family Court judges to mandate a minimum confinement of two years for juveniles who commit the most serious (crimes of violence was announced here today. The bill has the support of Governor Carey, and quick passage is now expected in both houses of the Legislature.

title: G.O.P. PANEL ACTS TO IN DELEGATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Republican National Committee voted today to makes state laws binding on delegates pledged to support President Ford or Ronald Reagan at the party's nominating convention in Kansas City.

title: Prolific and Versatile
description: Mr. Mercer was an unusually prolific and versatile songwriter, who was as successful in turning out breezy, vernacular lyrics for Jeepers Creepers, Goody Goody or G.I. Jive as he was in the romantic vein of Dearly Beloved, Skylark and Moon River, the moodsettings of Blues in the Night, Laura and That Old Black Magic, or in modernizing an old song such as The Glow Worm.

title: Panatta Is Upset by Pasarell
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25The sun shone brightly, the women players asked officially for money equal to the men's and were turned down and most of the seeded players came through to their appointed placeswith one major exception. That exception was the defeat of the fifth  seeded Adriano Panatta, the hottest player in the world during the past few weeks.

title: FMC PLANS SALE OF FIBER DIVISION
description: The FMC Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its fiber division to Avtex Fibers Inc. Avtex was recently formed by several FMC executives led by John N. Gregg, vice president of the fiber division. Merger Robert H. Malott, News FMC's chairman and president, in issuing the announcement did not disclose what price would be received for the fiber division. Its book value has been estimated by trade sources at $120 million, but fiber executives said yesterday it probably would not sell for more than $60 million.

title: Economic Talks: Dialogue Is Stressed
description: I WASHINGTON, June 25In a gathering that a highranking American expects to be somewhat of an international encounter group, the leaders of seven industrialized nations will meet in Puerto Rico, starting tomorrow night, to talk again about mutual economic problems and goals.

title: Palmer Trails by 5 Shots
description: MOOR PARK, England, June 25 (AP)Arnold Palmer, with a thirdround 71 for a 54hole total of 212, was five strokes behind the leader after the third round today in an international golf tournament. Palmer trailed Martin Foster, a former England amateur international player, who had a thirdround 89 for 207.

title: WOR SALUTE TO CITY TO BENEFIT LIBRARY
description: New York: A Portrait in Sound, a salute to the city coupled .with an appeal for funds to aid the New York Public Library, will be broadcast for two weeks on WokAM on Monday through Friday at 0 P.M. beginning Monday. .

title: The Opera: Tasteful Pique Dame
description: SPOLETO, ItalyAThe IDth Festival of Two Worlds, better known as the Spoleto Festival, opened this week at the Teatro Nuovo,'with a performance of TchaikOvsky's opera.. La Dama Picche. In The original Russian, this would be Pikova Dama, better known to aficionados as Pique Dame or The Queen of Spades.

title: PUPIL RULING HELD A SETBACK TO FORD
description: The general counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that the Supreme Court decision declaring it unconstitutional for private schools to bar children because of their race was a vindication of morality and a moral and political setback for President Ford.

title: Debris
description: Because they wanted to know more about the ocean's current, students in the Science Club at Mark Twain Junior High School on Coney Island give 10 bOttles with returnaddress cards inside to crewmen of one of New York City's sludge barges.

title: New Jersey Girl Wins N.Y. Tennis
description: PURCHASE, N. Y.. June 25Donna Lies of Springfield, N.J., defeated Lisa Levins of Massapequa, L. I., 63, 63, to win t1 KodelNew York State hard court tennis champiOnship for girls to 18 years old at Manhattanville College today. Miss Lies, 16, a junior at Springfield High School, was seeded third and Miss Levins, 15, a junior at Massapequa High School was seeded fourth.

title: Tito, Ending Boycott, Will Join Parley of European Communists
description: BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, June 25. (Reuters)  President Tito will attend a highlevel meeting of European Communists in East Berlin next week, ending a 19year Yugoslav boycott of international Communist conferences, it was announced here today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the NoblePrize winning. Russian author, visited Yale University on June 16 and met privately for eight hours with Prof. Alexis Rannit, curator of Slavic and Eastern European literature at the university. The professor, whose wife made the photograph, said the atithor studied rare documents in preparation for a work on Russian history.

title: Ali, Inoki Fight to Draw in Dull Bout
description: TOKYO. Saturday. June 26 Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion and Antonio Inoki, the jutjawed Japanese wrestler fought to a draw in a 15round bout that turned into a kicking contest here today.

Yeo 3d, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, a statement predicting closer management of currency exchange rates. Mr. Yeo says the Treasury remains opposed to any sort of management.

title: Excerpts From Opinions in Private School Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision written by Justice Potter Stewart, outlawing racial discrimination in private, commercially operated schools, and from the dissenting opinion written by Justice Byron R. White.

title: Belmont Racing charis
description: Friday, June 25. 47th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: LET MY PEOPLE COME TO GO TO BROADWAY
description: The longrun sexual musical, Let My People Come, by Earl Wilson Jr., will be transferred from the Off Broadway Village Gate Theater to the Morosco Theater, 217 West 45th Street, on July 7, it was announced yesterday by Phil Osterman, producer.

title: POLAND CANCELS FOOD PRICE RISES AFTER DISORDERS
description: WARSAW, June 25The Polish Government tonight withdrew its plan to raise food prices sharply. It acted after striking workers protesting the increases had torn up railroad tracks outside the capital and struck in other parts of the country.

title: HotDog Vendor Is Loser In Case in Supreme Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 25The Supreme Court ruled today that the City of New Orleans could grant an exclusive hotdog franchise to one company of street  corner vendors and thus preserve the appearance of the city's French Quarter and attract tourists.

title: BuiltIn Inflation?
description: News of the rise of the consumer price index last month at an annual rate of 7.2 percent was perhaps most remarkable for the composure with which it was accepted by the Ford Administration, by conservative bankers and businessmen, by most economists and by the stock market.

Their crews had suffered enough having been becalmed under a hot sun on the ocean for most of the week.

While most of her contemporaries have been attracted to pure movement and nondramatic dances, she was determinedly expressionist. Her inspiration usually came from painters and writers, and sometimes touched also upon social commentary.

description: SAN DIEGO, June 25 (UPI)A medical expert testified today that he did not think a young Texas Marine recruit died of an overdose of antibiotics in a Houston hospital.

title: Adirondack Compromise
description: Republicans in the Senate have very little time in which to reverse a mischievous decision to bury legislation concerning the Adirondack Park Agency. In a surprise move a party conference voted not even to take up a compromise package of bills already passed by the Assembly. The purpose of these bills was to improve the operations of the agency and to ease tensions between that hardpressed office and some of the park's residents and local governments.

title: Moscow Narodny Bank Stirs Singapore Trouble
description: SINGAPOREThe Moscow Narodny Bank, the stateowned Russian bank that does a big commercial business from its London base, is causing problems for the Soviet Union as a result of its operations in Singapore.

title: Books of The Times
description: Many Americans, thinking about Benito Mussolini, perceive him somehow as less malevolent than Adolf Hitler on the ground that there was no holocaust in Italy. Readers of Mr. Mack Smith's splendid book will be shown that 11 Duce was fully as genocidal as Der Fiihrer, a Caesar (and not made of sawdust) who blithely consigned hundreds of thousands of Italians to their deaths in a vain search for imperial glory. Not only did Mussolini use the bloom of Italian youth as cannon fodder in Spain. Albania, North Africa and Ethiopia, but he also impoverished the peoples of Italy in his foreign ventures by lowering their living standards front 1930 through World war II.

title: South African, Citing Arson, Hints Rioting Was Organized
description: PRETORIA, South AfriEa, June 25James T. Kruger, the South African Minister of Justice, Police and Prisons, said today that there was evidence that the rioting in black townships last week was organized. He said that the use of blackpower salutes by young people in the townships made it quite clear that black consciousness and the black movement are somewhere behind the riots.

I., seeded No. 3. gained a decisive singles victory today over Lisa Rosenblum of Farmington, Conn., for the New England women's open championship. title: The Screen: 'Omen' Is Nobody's Baby
description: The best thing that can be said about "The Omen" is that very few viewers will want to walk out. They will stay, but they will feel foolish.A member of the "Exorcist" family, it is a dreadfully silly film, which is not to say that it is totally bad. Its horrors are not horrible, its terrors are not terrifying, its violence is ludicrouswhich may be an advantagebut it does move along.Movies about Satanic possession do not depend for their effectiveness on making their central device convincing. They should, however, make all the details surrounding this device so plausible that when the Thing appears the audience's skepticism has gone to sleep. It was this peripheral credibility that gave "Rosemary's Baby" its strength."The Omen," which opened yesterday at the National, Loews Cine and other theaters, takes its details with no seriousness at all. It is not a put-onit is terribly solemn, in factbut it often seems like one.There are miles of plot. It deals with the problems of a rich and privileged Americanhe happens to be Ambassador to Great Britain, which is the source of a great deal of the movie's incredibility  whose wife gives birth to a dead baby. A devil-possessed priest slips them another baby who is destined to grow up to rule the world in the name of Satan.The baby becomes a lovely little boy, but when he is 4 years old or so, a mysterious black dog turns up. In quick order the boy's nursemaid hangs herself and a mysterious new nursemaid, a malevolent Mary Poppins, arrives to replace her.Things begin to go badly wrong and the Ambassador, played by Gregory Peck, can't figure out why. A mad-looking priest arrivesnot the one who supplied the baby and warns him that the child is the Antichrist. Soon the priest is impaled by a spire falling off a church.The Ambassador begins to be convinced. Joined by a photographer, played by David Warner, he goes to Italy to try to find the origins of his adopted child, and from that point the disasters begin to mount.From the moment Mr. Peck comes home after a hard day and tells his wife, played by Lee Remick, that they're off to be Ambassadors, the film's working-level reality is hopelessly scratched. This must be the most unattended American emissary to Great Britain since John Jay. Scenes in which he and his wife look for a housethe United States Ambassador in London has an official residenceor in which he runs around London by himself are quite impossible.Yet the movie is reasonably well-paced. We don't have time to brood about the sillinesses of any particular scene before we are on to the next. There is not a great deal of excitement, but we manage to sustain some curiosity as to how things will work out. "The Omen" is the kind of movie to take along on a long airplane trip.

description: ST. PAUL, June 25President Ford headed tonight toward the capture of all or nearly all of Minnesota's 18 atlarge delegates, striking to within fewer than 100 votes of the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, June 25 (UPI}The dollar recouped midweek lossks on most European money markets today, while the pound remained stable. In London the pound closed for the fourth consecutive day at $1.7725, and made slight gains against the Swiss franc and the German mark. Dealers..said the pound drooped slightly in early trading but they attributed the easing to the dollar's advance against west major currencies.

title: U.S. Five Beats Stars
description: MOUNT PROSPECT. Ill., June 25 (AP)The United States Olympic basketball team gained a lastminute victory last night against the Midwest AllStars, 9490, in another tuneup for Montreal's Summer Games. The Olympic squad took the lead for good at 9290 with only 15 seconds remaining on a driving layup by Walt Davis, a North Carolina forward.

title: SEOUL WEIGHING TIES WITH PEKING
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25 Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin of South Korea said today that his Government was looking for ways to open what he called effective communications with China. His remarks to the National Assembly's Foreign Affairs Committee did not indicate whether this meant full diplomatic relationships.

description: President Tito will attend a highlevel meeting of European Communists in East Berlin next week, ending a 19year Yugoslav boycott of international Communist conferences. Page 5.

description: LAKEHURST, N.J. June 25 (UPI)  A Michigan ballonist, who had been forced to postpone his attempt to make a transAtlantic solo flight five times because of the bad weather, took off from Lakehurst Naval Air Station for Paris tonight.

title: 5th Victim of Coast Accident
description: CULVLR CITY, Calif., June 25 (UPI)Ernest Drowne, 65 years old, whose wife and sisterinlaw died in last week's gasoline line explosion and fire, became yesterday the fifth victim of the accident. Mr. Drowne died at a hospital of burns and other injuries he received in the June 16 accident at a road construction site in west Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Steel Reported Planning Ohio Plant
description: The United States Steel Corporation has apparently settled on Conneaut, Ohio, as the site for a $3 billion steel plant.

description: Small bombs exploded early yesterday outside the Pail Am Building and two banks in Manhattan and behind a police station in the South Bronx. the police reported. There were no injuries and damage was slight.

title: Bush Says C.I.A. Is Ending Use Of PartTime Agency Newsmen
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is ending its association with all parttime correspondents affiliated with American news agencies abroad and will no longer hire them as agents, George Bush, Director of Central Intelligence, has told representatives of the National News Council.

title: U.S. NEWSMAN SUES A SOVIET JOURNAL
description: MOSCOW, June 25 Alfred Friendly Jr., Newsweek magazine's Moscow correspondent, filed a lawsuit in a Soviet court today seeking to force a Soviet literary weekly to retract its allegation that he works for the Central Intelligence Agency. The judge accepted the complaint and scheduled a preliminary hearing for July 2.

title: System to Produce Hydrogen From Waste Invented
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A new energy system for the production of hydrogen by the incineration of waste has been invented by Gerald J. Harvey, president of New York Testing Laboratories Inc., Westbury, L. I. Mr. Harvey was granted Patent 3,965,362 this week, assigning it to his company, which since 1919 has been engaged in such activities as pollution analysis and testing services for industrial concerns. A subsidiary manufactures test equipment.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the People and Business column of June 16 incorrectly attributed to Edwin H. Yeo 3d, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, a statement predicting closer management of currency exchange rates. Mr. Yeo says the Treasury remains opposed to any sort of management.

title: Prisoners Denied Right to a Hearing On Transfers, 63
description: WASHINGTON. June 25 (UN) The Supreme Court ruled, .6 to 3 today that a prison inmate does not have a constiutiotial right to a hearing before he is transferred to a maximum security penitentiary.

He was 67 years old.

title: A POLITICAL DONOR CONVICTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 (UPI)Dr. Louis Cella Jr.. California's largest individual political campaign contributor irr 1974, was found guilty yesterday of conspiracy, income tax evasion, tax fraud and Medicare fraud in the embezzlement from two Orange County hospitals of more than $600,000 used primarily for political contributions.

description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Two members of the House' Appropriations Committee said today that President Ford had agreed to accept a compromise on supplemental military assistance for Israel that would provide a total of $275 million for the neriod June 30 to Oct. 1.

title: The Small Dried Black Beans of Hanoi
description: HANOIShe sat behind her staples all spread out tidily in baskets on the sidewalk. A thin canvas protected her and the foodstuffs from the morning drizzle. I paused before the small driedup Vietnamese woman,.and said, Bonjour, grandmaman. She replied with a wide smile on her full red lips, revealing betelstained. black teeth. Around her head she wore a black Tonkinese velvet coil. I asked if I could take her picture and she assented.

title: What's Doing in ALSACE
description: TWO CULTURESAlsace is the northeastern corner of France, and the Alsatians have been both French and German in the course of their history. The region is gentle and rolling, with wellordered vineyards, medieval church towers and barley and wheat fields. Lying between the Rhine and the 3,000to4,000foot peaks of the Vosges Mountains, which cut the province off from the rest of France, Alsace is a marriage of two cultures. There is no more delicate cuisine in all France; the white Riesling and spicy Gewiirztraminer wines are subtler and less sweet than their counterparts across the river in West Germany; the cities and villages have preserved halftimbered houses as if immune from time, and the winding country roads and stately firs of the Vosges bind the region

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE by 0.6 percent in May, mainly because of a jump in food prices, the Labor Department reported. This was the largest since November 1975 and pushed the Consumer Price Index to 169.2 (1967=100)  New car sales in the second 10 days of June at 243,371 units were 28 percent over the 1975 period. This year to date 4,127,847 new cars have been retailed, up 37 percent from the year earlier.  New orders for durable goods rose in May by $2 billion, or 4.1 percent, to $49.82 billion. The backlog of new orders in May rose by $1.4 billion to $138.4 billion.

title: Surprise! Surprise!

title: Essay: What I Think, What I Am
description: Our loneliness makes us avid column readers these days. The personalities in The New York Post, Chicago Daily News, San Francisco Chronicle constitute our neighbors now, some of them local characters but also the opinionated national stars. And movie reviewers thrive on our need for somebody emotional who is willing to pay attention to us and return week after week, year after year, through all the toandfro of other friends to flatter us by pouring out his (her) heart. They are essayists, as Elizabeth Hardwick is, James Baldwin was. We sometimes hear that essays are an oldfashioned form, that soandso is the last essayist, but the facts of the marketplace argue quite otherwise. Essays of almost any kind are so much easier for a writer to sell now than short stories, so many more see print, it's odd that though two fine anthologies remain which publish the year's best stories, no comparable collection exists for essays. Such changes in the reading public's taste aren't always to the good, needless to say. The art of telling stories predated even cavepainting, surely; and if we ever find ourselves living in caves again, it (with painting) will be the only art left, after movies, novels, essays, photography, biography and all the rest have gone down the drain

title: Guinness CUD to East Germans

title: The High Court's Mixed Record on Religion
description: WASHINGTONht 1947, in the first of the modernday Supreme Court decisions on the First Amendment's religious establishment clause, the Court was considering New Jersey's system of paying for transportation to and from parochial schools. Clearly, the payments helped the children get religious training. Justice Hugo Black wrote in ringing words for the majority: The First Amendment has erected a wall between church and State. That wall must be kept high and impregnable. We could not approve the slightest breach.

title: JOHN WALTER PLUMB
description: John Walter Plumb, former secretarytreasurer of the American branch of Phs Van Ommeren Shipping Inc., a Dutch firm, and a lineal descendant of Cornelius Melyn, one of the first patroons of mid15th century New Amsterdam, died Friday at his home, 6836 Amboy Road, Staten Island. He was 77 years old. Mr. Plumb leaves his wife, the former Ida Clarius; a daughter, Carol; two sisters, and three grandchildren.

title: Spy
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 26 (UPI)The Air Force launched a Titan 3C, its most powerful rocket, with possibly one or more spy satellites aboard last night. The Air Force said that the rocket was carrying a classified payload. No other details were available.

The weepie classic will be paired with The Petrified Forest at the Regency, July 2830, as part of the theater's retrospective of vintage Warner Brothers fare, beginning next Sunday and running through Sept. 4.

But conservationists and public officials who monitor nature's ways are convinced that only perpetual care will assure preservation of the 100milelong strand that both protects the Island and serves as its principal playground.

description: ALBANY, June 26With each house trying to portray itself as the one most dedicated to holding down the cost of government, both the Assembly and the Senate were expected today to pass a newly revised bill that substantially reduces pension benefits for future public employees.

description: CUSTER BATTLEFIELD, Morrt.Nearly forgotten amid the Bicentennial celebrations, this rolling stretch of grassland, edged by the Little Bighorn River, dented here and there by coulees (dry gulches) and dotted with unobtrusive white stone markers, reached a memorable anniversary last week. It was on June 25 and 26, 1876, that an army of In'dians won one of the last armed efforts . . . to preserve their ancestral way of life, as the National Park Service brochure states.

title: Site Hazards Force Delay In Viking I's Mars Landing

He shuffled them over and over, then ran through the deck card by card, muttering to himself. Plus two, minus one, even, plus two, even. . . . As the sun fell over the desert and the city put on its neon makeup, Uston went to his room in the hotel, a chamber of crimson and purple, the decor in apparent homage to Polly Adler. There he dressed in slacks, an opencollar shirt and

title: Volunteer Recalls Jimmy Who?
description: DENVER,  The Jimmy Carter bandwagon was just gleam in the candidate's eye when Larry St. Pierre Aot aboard last November. In Mr. St. Pierre's own mind, he was walking away from a defeat, not headed for a victory.

title: Education
description: For the nation's service academies, impregnable to criticism for decades, the West Point cheating scandal couldn't have come at a worse time. Even before public attention was focused on cheating, critics had already been wonderingquite vocally in some caseswhether the taxpayer was getting his money's worth from the academies, and proposals to drastically modify the institutions were being put forward with increasing frequency. Now a Senate armed services subcommittee is examining proposed changes in the honor code as at least 415 cases of alleged cheating at the Military Academy are being investigated.

title: PEOPLE
description: Deeply involved in the Mystery of the Missing Turtle in the Vatican is Helen Boehm, board chairman of Edward Marshall Boehm Inc. in Trenton. At a private audience with Pope Paul VI, Mrs. Boehm, widow of the noted porcelain sculptor, presented the third and last of a grouping of two swans of peace to the Pontiff, and it was only then that she noticed that a porcelain turtle about four inches across was missing from the group. There was much consternation among Vatican officials, who had received the porcelain gift two days prey iously and locked it all away, for in Italy turtles are considered good luck omens.

title: The Coach With the Couch
description: I met a man the other day who gave me the creeps. His name is Arnold Mandell, and he's a wellknown psychiatrist in San Diego. Four years ago he was asked by Eugene Klein, the owner of the San Diego Chargers, to help that football team win. Dr. Mandell's assignment was to hang around the players, observe them, and try to gauge their moodswere they up for the game or down.

title: Big, Bold, Bright and Colorful
description: An increasingly popular method of dressing up or accenting interior walls and ceilings of homes and apartments is by the application of large graphic designs which consist basically of bold swirls, lines and curves of geometrically laid out swaths of color. First used by professional interior designers on the walls of showrooms, offices, theaters and customdecorated luxury homes, this idea, often referred to as supergraphics, can now also be used by doityourself homeowners and apartment dwellers who purchase the components of a professionally designed system called, appropriately enough, the Supergraphics System.

title: EXCAIRO OFFICIAL IS GIVEN 10 YEARS
description: CAIRO, June 26Salah Nasr, who was chief of Egyptian intelligence in the early 1960's was sentenced to 10 years hard labor in prison here today for having ordered the torture of a prominent journalist, Mustapha Amin, 11 years ago.

To go out was meaningless. There was no out, merely a mist of cinders, a smog of the cerebellum. And so we watched television, as cats watch flies, making little clicking noises.

Such knowledge won't feed the world's hungry, solve the Near East problems or get inflation in hand, but it might help us to understand more about life and time.

Some pale blue lights over the entrance are your only clue. You enter a deep burgundy bar area, and to the right, the dining rooms explode with silver. Glittering, corrugated silver and mirrors blanket every inch the high walls and serpentine silver covers the tables set with glass.

description: FISHERMEN can look forward to some super fluke catches along the New Jersey beaches this week, especially if the water temperatures don't dip. The prospects for bluefishing are more uncertain; bluefishing has been good on some days and bad on others.

But euphemism is no veil for the fact that the city's political life, closely related to its budget problems, has been turned upside down by the fiscal crisis with shibboleths scattered like tenpins.

title: Despite Ruling, Blacks Are Not Likely to Apply
description: ATLANTAThere is a long tradition of private schooling in the South, particularly at the secondary level. But until the mid1950's, Dixie's private day academies and boarding schools were the exclusive educational retreat of handful of upperclass white youngsters whose parents were dissatisfied with the region's povertystricken state schools. The education issue in the Old South was social and academic quality, not equality, since the region had dual black and white systems.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Hope Springs Eternal in Hunt for Loch Ness Monster

title: ARNOLD H. SPARROW, RADIO BIOLOGIST, 61
description: Dr. Arnold H. Sparrow, geneticist who was senior radiobiologist in the biology department of Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L.I., died of a heart attack Thursday in the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, Patchogue, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: THE bells will start ringing across the state and the nation at 2 P.M. next Sunday, a clarion to the solemn moment 200 years ago that changed the history of America and the world. For two minutes, the pealing will fill the air and forge, in a nation of 200 million people, a singularity of thought recalling the day when 13 colonies broke from the British Crown and embarked on the road to mankind's most enduring democracy. Then, the bells silent again, there will ne resumption of the diverse celebrations of the Fourth of July. Some people will celebrate at the seashore. Others will head to hometown parades, fairs and picnics and, after dark, gasp it the brilliance of exploding fireworks. And there will be private expressions of thanks, prayers of gratitude and appeals for the fulfillment of freedom promised long ago.

title: The Return of the Oyster
description: 60 YEARS or so ago, the abundance of nature, in the form of Long Island Sound oysters, supported more than two hundred companies. Today, there are four. But the industry, once menaced by pollution and storms of such severity that the oysters were washed out to sea, is thriving again. The oyster boats, plying the waters with their specialized equipment, are once again reaping harvests that are hauled ashore by straining crewmen and sped to market for the delectation of aficionados.

title: Tips for the Youthful Job Hunter
description: If your son or daughter is Job hunting in Manhattan this summer, some knowledge of terrain and native customs may ease the pavement pounding. They will find that searching for work is hard work, but they might as well make the search as comfortable as possible. Desks shielded by soundproof stalls, for example, can be used for paperwork for as long as needed at the MidManhattan library, 8 East 40th Street. Rows of desks are available first come, first served, on the library's fourth floor and job hunters are welcome. Classified job advertisement sections from area newspapers are posted daily and ad sections from the Sunday editions are also posted. At the fifth floor job opportunity center civil service test manuals and past tests and books on job hunting and careers are available.

title: FORD WARNS CUBA OVER PUERTO RICO
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 26President Ford, upon arrival here today to convene an economic summit meeting of seven nations, warned Cuba sharply against meddling in relations between the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: Space Saved Is Energy Earned
description: THE rising prices of energy and the need to reduce our dependence on foreign oil present Long Islanders with basic issue regarding the future development of our regicm. We must consider whether we can afford to continue to pursue landuse policies that do not encourage the economical use of energy.

title: Parent and Child
description: A great many children today are being raised by the book. Child rearing manuals aren't brand new, of course. Dr. Speck's Baby and Child Care has been around since 1946, and various publications of the Yale Child Development Clinic when it was nun by Dr. Arnold Gesell had considerable influence during the 30's and 40's. For that matter, before Gesell there was Maria Montessori; before Montessori there was Rousseau; before Rousseau there was John Locke. For parents inclined to study the subject, there has probably never been a lack of written advice about raising children.

title: Mint Cuts Off First
description: Last Friday, June 25, was the ordering cutoff date decreed by the U.S. Mint for its 10piece America's First Medals seriesthe special pewter reproductions of the first battle hero medals authorized by the Continental Congress. The Mint's announcement of the opening the ordering period for the final pair of medals in the series, as well as the reopening of a backordering period for the entire series, was reported in this column last Sunday. The unexpectedly and unnecessarily short span of time between that June 20 opening announcement and the June 25 cutoff was reportedly due to a mailroom mixup or communications breakdown at the Mint. The final ordering period was to have startedand actually did start for collectors on the Mint's mailing list in early April, but the news of that decision intended for the general public did not go out to the press until early June. An apologetic Mint official reports that the communications system is now being unsnarled prevent a recurrence.

title: Warsaw Surrender
description: The unprecedented speed with which the Polish Government abandoned its price increase program testifies eloquently to the terror that worker protests create among the Warsaw rulers. Edward Gierek, today's top Polish Communist, came to power five and a half years ago because of massive worker revolt against price increases instituted by his predecessor, Wladyslaw Gomulka. Mr, Gierek clearly has no intention of following Mr. Gomulka in walking the economic gangplank to oblivion. The real mystery, in fact, is why Mr. Gierek tried last week's gamble that ended so ingloriously and so quickly.

title: A Busing Fraud
description: President Ford's recently unveiled antibusing legislation is every bit as mischievous and disingenuous as had been expected. The name seems to promise something constructive while the proposal actually seeks to dismantle a good portion of the legal groundwork supporting the constitutional effort to desegregate the nation's schools.

title: Red Smith
description: Frying under a merciless sun on the deck of a lifeless sailing ship drifting in the horse latitudes is not necessarily the ultimate in gracious living. Yet it has its compensations. While the stately queens in Operation Snail 76 lay becalmed last week in their race from Bermuda to Newport, R. I., the men aboard were spared watching Muhammad All and Antonio Inoki on closedcircuit television. That was a privilege not accorded to everyone. Moreover, due to a distinct shortage of printing presses in the emptiness of the Bermuda Triangle, not one word was published there about the historic lover's quarrel between Charlie Finley the Oakland A's and Bowie Ktihn, the earthly vicar of Abner Doubleday hi short, though the pace of the sailboat race left something to be desired, the peace was blessed.

The flamenco dancers with whom he shared the program urged him on, and he executed a few more jaunty steps before disappearing beaming into the wings.

description: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL, A??? ??? ??? Center, 8.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford, at a summit meeting of seven major industrial nations in Puerto Rico, yesterday said that Governments had overcommitted themselves economically in order to improve social conditions and raise their citizens standard of living. He told the other leaders in a private session that the industrialized nations must set more realistic social and economic goals that would be acceptable to tie people of their countries. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: The Young Lawbreaker
description: A bipartisan proposal in Albany to deal with serious crimes committed by 14 and 15yearolds eschews the destructive gettough approach of throwing youngsters into the criminal maelstrom. Instead, youthful offenders would remain within the present juvenile justice system, to be judged by the Family Court and supervised by the Division of Youth. Although the bill is by no means soft on the young lawbreakers, it at least considers rehabilitation possible and desirable.

title: Exceller Longchamp Victor
description: PARIS, June 27 (Reuters)Nelson Bunker Hunt's Exceller, ridden by Yves SaintMartin, easily won the $345,000 Grand Prix de Paris today at Longchamp race course. Second in the twomile race for 3yearolds was J. Lagardere's Secret Man, ridden by Philippe Paquet. Mrs. R. Ades Caron, ridden by Marcel Philipperon, was third.

title: Jazz Today
description: Noon to 2 P.M., free outdoor event: Equitable Life Assurance Plaza, 51st Street and Avenue of the Americas. Sy Oliver Orchestra.

description: Article 7  No Title

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 27Joel R.Jacobson, the president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, has asked Congress to investigate naturalgas rates.

title: Milton A. Conner, Retired As Chemical Company Aide
description: Milton A. Conner, a retired vice president of the National Aniline Division of Allied Chemical Corporation, died Friday at St. Barnabas Hospital Center, Livingston, N. J. He was 80 years old and lived at 377 South Harrison Street, East Orange, N. J.

title: Big Communist Party Rallies
description: WARSAW, June 27 (Reuters) Poland's Communist Party, Irecovering from the shock of demonstrations by workers that forced the withdrawal of proposed foodprice increases, staged big rallies throughout the nation today backing party leader Edward Gierek.

title: Witnesses Tell What They Saw When Riots Came to Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 27Sometime between 7:30 and 9 A.M. on Wednesday, June 16, a march of schoolchildren in the black township of Soweto turned into one of the worst racial riots in South African history.

title: Commodities
description: Ever since the Soviet Union bought a record 19 million metric tons of grains and soybeans here in 1972, Moscow's crop reports have tended to dominate the actions of the lesssophisticated speculators in the commodity futures markets for these basic foodstuffs.

title: Miss Yergan Bride Of W. J. Harvey 4th
description: Donna Yergan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Yergan of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there last evening to William J. Harvey 4th, son of the Rev. and Mrs. William J. Harvey 3d of Philadelphia.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Entries

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
description: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings

title: Professor Asserts F.B.I. Covered Up Typewriter Evidence Helpful to Hiss
description: John Lowenthal. Rutgers University law professor who has acted at times as Alger Hiss's lawyer, asserts that newly released F.B.I. documents show that the agency covered up evidence helpful to Mr. Hiss concerning the date of the manufacture of the Woodstock typewriter in the case.

title: Caren Friedberg Wed To H. S. Hammerman
description: The marriage of Caren Suzanne Friedberg, a magna cum laude graduate of Mount Holyoke College, class of 76, to Hillel Sander Hammerman, a student at the Cornell Medical College, took place yesterday at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston. Rabbis Hitel Rudaysky and Israel Mowshowitz officiated.

title: DANNY KALB IS BACK WITH 4PIECE BAND
description: Danny Kalb, making what he only halfjokingly described as my 15th annual comeback, performed two shows Friday evening at CAMI Hall with a fourpiece electric band. Mr. Kalb, a guitarist, singer, and songwriter, was a founder of the Blues Project, a pioneering folkrock band of the 1960's. The CAMI Hall concerts were his first appearance with band backing in several years.

title: Washington and Business
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Prodded by Congress, the United States Employment Service is making a searching reexamination of how it can best help employers fill vacant jobs and help the unemployed find fobs that they can hold.

title: Blanchard to Head U.S. Open Tourney
description: WIMBLEDON. England, June 27 Mike Blanchard, for several years referee at the United States Open at Forest Hills will take over as director of the tournament, succeeding Billy Talbert.

title: Algerians Vote on a Charter For Islamic Socialist State
description: ALGIERS, June 27 (Reuters) Algerians voted today in a referendum on a new national charter, a vote expected to amount to an expression of national support for President Houari Boumediene and his Government.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
11 Passengers Killed, 29 Hurt As Express Derails in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, June 27 (AP)Six cars of an express train carrying Dutch and British vacationers from Amsterdam to Paris derailed in Belgium today killing 11 passengers and injuring 29, railway officials said.

title: Tool Orders Climb As Shipments Fall
description: Machine tool orders in May rose and shipments declined, which produced the first increase in the industry backlog since August 1974, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

title: Newport Jazz Festival
description: WATERLOO VILLAGE, N. J. June 27Governor Byrne proclaimed yesterday as Count Basie Day in New Jersey in honor of the jazz pianist and hand leader who was born in Red Bank and whose band played here as part of the Newport Jazz Festival last night.

title: New Yorkers Reclaim Their Beaches
description: New Yorkers reclaimed their beaches yesterday from the mysterious tide of pollution that had befouled them for a week.

title: O.A.U. Denies Soweto Riot Was Tied to Kissinger Visit
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius. June 27 (Reuters)A spokesman for the Organization of African Unity, Peter Onu, today clarified a statement that he made yesterday saying foreign ministers of the organization had linked Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's recent visit to Africa with race riots in South Africa.

title: Thousands Join in March For Homosexuals Rights
description: Thousands of homosexuals yesterday paraded along the Avenue of the Americas, from Greenwich Village to Central Park, in the seventh annual march for homosexuals rights.

title: Dog Show Results
description: HOUND (Mrs. Mary Nelson Stephenson, tudge)1, Margaret Hodge's whippet, Ch. Highlight's Legacy; 2, Gayle Bontecou And Janelle Rosen's Scottish deerhound, Ch. Salutary's Alfred; 3. Debra Groshan's Borzoi, Ch. Laba's Arimskv; 4, Jean P. Dill's 15Inch beagle, Pickadilly Petticoat Chaser.

title: Airlines Using Buses For Canada Traffic
description: With United States pilots refusing to fly into Canada because of support for a strike by Canadian pilots, United States airlines are offering combined plane and bus transportation from New York to Canadian cities.

title: Judith A. Fields Married to Jeffrey Saper
description: Judith Ann Fields, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Fields of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey David Saper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Saper, also of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony in Temple EmanuEl.

title: A Party Office Was Attacked by Poles
description: RADOM, Poland, June 27 (UPI)Demonstrators set fire to Communist Party headquarters here and looted food and liquor stores during strikes Friday protesting Government food price increases, it was learned here today.

title: CANADA'S DECISION ON LOCKHEED PLAN IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The Canadian Cabinet is ex pected to hold what could be a decisive meeting tomorrow on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's effort to reinstate a Canadian plan to buy IS Lockheed antisubmarine patrol planes.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error in editing a dispatch from Santiago, Chile, in The Times last Tuesday, the meaning of a statement by Alejandro Orfila, the secretary general of the Organization of American States, was altered. A corrective ar, tide appears on Page 9.

title: Advertising
description: What could be more endearing in this highly charged legalistic and consumerist atmosphere than a meaningful, meaningless advertising theme that seems to be saying something while saying nothing?

title: JACKSON A. SEWARD
description: Dr. Jackson Anderson Seward, a specialist in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, died of a heart attack Friday while visiting relatives in Conroe, Tex. He was 80 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Commuter operating Agency, whicn pays state subsidies to bus and rail lines to keep essential commuter services, will discontinue aid to the Blue and White Bus Company of Fairview when the fiscal year ends on Wednesday because of the company's alleged fail. ure to maintain proper financial records. Alan Signer. chairman of the agency and Commissioner of the State Department of Transportation, said that auditors also had found that the bus line, which operates principally in Bergen County, had had recurring problems with the Internal Revenue Service, which had obtained tax liens against the company. The line was said to have re eived $176,000 in operating subsidies over the last 18 months.

title: Mrs. Grasso Holds Up Plans for Hidden Mikes
description: HARTFORD, June 27 (AP) (AP)  Worried about possible invasions of privacy, Gov. Ella T. Grasso has temporarily halted plans for an electronic burglardetection system that would use hidden microphones in 11 state buildings, including the Governor's mansion.

title: Ford's Jersey Leader Warns on Reagan
description: The chairman of President ??? nomination campaign in New Jersey said yesterday that a victory at the National Republican Convention for former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California would be a disaster for the Republican Party in the state.

title: Bridge:
description: A book that is unusual in the literature of the game but also excessively dull and expensive is now available. It is the record of 720 deals played in the World Team Olympiad in Monte Carlo, Monaco last month by 45 teams, together with 31,520 results and the names of the players.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Viking 1 Team Seeks New Site For Delayed Landing on Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 27 (AP)Scientists in control of the Viking 1 spacecraft began directing it in search of alternative landing sites on Mars today after delaying the scheduled July 4 Bicentennial landing of the craft's landing module, possibly for several weeks.

title: Getting Smart
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.  Senator Roman L. Hruska's remarks, some years ago, about providing suitable representation on the United States Supreme Court for mediocre peoplemediocre justicesstill evokes the knowing snigger of the American intellectual. Of course it should.

title: Mrs. King Set for Singles In Federation Cup Play
description: LONDON, June 27Thirteen years ago, the United States won the first Federation Cup of tennis at Queens Club here, with Billie Jean Moffitt and Darlene Hard defeating Leslie Turner and Margaret Smith of Australia. 36, 1311. 63. in the longest doubles match ever played by a United States women's team.

title: Cosmos Lose to Diplomats,32
description: FAIRFAX, Va., June 27 The Washington Diplomats scored three goals in the second half to defeat the New York Cosmos, 32, before a capacity crowd of 11,000 here today at Woodson Stadium.

title: Korshak's Power Rooted In Ties to Labor Leaders
description: In October 1961, a Chicago labor lawyer named Sidney R. Korshak unexpectedly checked into the Riviera Hotel in Las Vegas. The hotel was the site of a conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the nation's largest union, and it was jammed.

title: Strategies Are Pragmatic In Two Republican Camps
description: HELENA, Mont., June 27Consistency, that hobgoblin of little minds, scarcely gives pause to the deep thinkers who devise strategies for the Republican Presidential contenders, President Ford and Ronald Reagan.

title: MARINE ABUSE CASES UP DESPITE REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27, (UPI)Despite reforms in the United States Marines basic] training that were aimed at reducing maltreatment of recruits, the number of courtsmartial for serious maltreatment by drill instructors has tripled since the new rules went into effect last November.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The Federal Government's current action against a group of New York City school principals to compel them to fill out questionnaires about the racial and ethnic characteristics of their staffs and pupils has focused new attention on a controversy that has long been developing here over such inquiries.

title: Race Discrimination Found Pervasive In Rental of Manhattan Apartments
description: Racial discrimination in the rental of apartments is still widespread in New York's prime real estate marketManhattanand works to deny many choice apartments to blacks and other minority group members despite their ability to afford them, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

description: Horses listed In Circler of post positions Letter desionates OTB listing

title: Cash for Losers in Italy
description: ROME, June 27 (AP)About 400 incumbents who were defeated for reelection to the Italian Parliament got some good news today. They will receive what amounts to severance pay ranging from $6,000 to $12,000. The money conies from a fund set up by legislators, who contribute $48 a month.

title: ARMY CHIEF LEADS IN PORTUGAL VOTE FOR A PRESIDENT
description: LISBON, Monday, June 28The Portuguese voted heavily for the lawandorder candidate, Gen. Antnio Bernatho Eanes, in presidential elections yesterday and struck a severe blow to the Communist Party, according to a trend apparent in substantial returns.

title: TREASURYREFINES ITS MANAGEMENT OF FEDERAL DEBT
description: The Treasury is beginning to make some headway in its effort to keep the nation's debt from getting progressively shorter and less easily managed. This week it will sell $8.2 billion of bills and notes that will help offset a decadelong decline that shrunk the average life of the debt from five years and four months in June 1966 to two years and five months in March 1976.
