description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
description: Wednesday, June 30, 1976

title: Tigers Defeat Yanks
description: DETROIT, June 29 A game that started with great promise for the Yankees ended in a 75 defeat to the Tigers tonight as Sparky Lyle suffered one of his rare off nights. Working for the 12th time in the last 15 games, Lyle was shelled for five hits in less than two innings and absorbed his fifth defeat against five victories at Tiger Stadium.

title: Shares of A. & P. Offered
description: An offering of 1,750,000 common shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Cornpally, at $12.50 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Leading Connecticut Judge Convicted In Odd Case of LiquorLaw Violation
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 29 Judge Samuel J. Tedesco of Superior Court, in a curious case still clouded by puzzling questions, was convicted by a jury here this afternoon of a minor liquorlaw violation that could send the former Bridgeport Mayor and Lieutenant Governor to jail for a mandated minimum of three years.

title: AMEX VALUE INDEX INCREASES BY 0.17
description: Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange and in they overthecounter market inched upward yesterday partly reacting to some better economic news.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of superior court reversed the conviction of a Baltimore man for the murder of a groom at Monmouth Park race track three years ago. The court ruled that the only evidence against Mark Butcher in the alleged robberymurder of the groom, Thomas McAvey, 44 years old, of Chester, W. Va., was a confession that should not have been admitted as evidence.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on April 2, 1976, stated that according to former C.I.A. agents a recipient of C.I.A. favors in the early postwar period was Matsutaro Shoriki, a deceased Japanese communications executive and government official. While the information did come from former C.I.A. agents, further Investigation by The Times has led it to conclude that none of its sources are able to supply sufficient elaborating details to justify, in the view of the editors of The New York Times, the impression left by the article.

title: W. H. A.'s Club in Toronto Transferred to Alabama
description: TORONTO, June 20 (AP)The World Hockey Association today approved transfer of the Toronto Toros franchise to Birmingham; Ala. It also realigned the league into two divisionsEast and West for next season.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTS payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Business Papers' Seizure For Use in Trials Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court ruled today that the constitutional protection against selfincrimination does not prohibit the seizure of private business papers and their use as evidence against the owner in a criminal trial.

title: No More Family Cannibals?
description: PARISThe twoday Communist summit conference that terminates today in East Berlin is noteworthy because it was held at all. For months Leonid Brezhnev has been privately arguing for the meeting with the doubting Thomases of the Marxist world, led by their old believer Tito.

title: Marine Brutality
description: The acquittal of a Marine Corps drill instructor of all charges stemming from the fatal beating of a recruit at the San Diego Training Depot leaves totally unresolved the serious issues of Marine recruiting policies and brutal boot camp training practices.

title: Woman Takes Stand at Hearing On Charge A gainst Rubincarter
description: A woman who said she had been attacked by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter testified yesterday at a closed court hearing in Paterson, N.J., to determine if more stringent bail conditions should be imposed on the forsecond boxer, who is awaiting a second trial on murder charges.

title: A Sociologist Doubts Rich Will Do Enough To Abolish Hunger
description: AMES, Iowa, June 29 (UPI)Resistance by the world's affluent to economic and social changes will ultimately stand in the way of abolishing hunger and malnutrition, a leading Filipino sociologist said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Westchester County RentGuidelines Board yesterday announced new limits on rent increases that will affect about 48,000 rentregulated apartments in 11 communities in the county. According to the board's chairman, Willa Good, increases of 3 percent will be allowed for a oneyear lease expiring before July 1, 1978, 4 percent for a twoyear lease and 6 percent for a threeyear lease. The allowable increases for leases that have been adjusted under previous guidelines are 4 percent for a oneyear lease, 5 percent for a twoyear lease and 7 percent for a threeyear lease. This year's limits are substantially lower than last year's, which allowed a maximum increase of 17 percent. The new figures reflect economic changes and increased unemployment, Mrs. Good said.

title: Last 2 Seamen at Snug Harbor Vow to Stay
description: By ambulance, jet plane bus and an Army convoy, 107 residents of Sailors Snug Harbor, the 143  year  old home for reitred seamen in Staten Island, have been taken to a new home in Sea Level, N. C. But two of the residents, 76yearold Johan C. Bugel and 60yearold Antony O'Connor Pujol, refuse to leave.

title: About New York
description: These the only gloves they got? asked Pete Muller. They feel too small.

title: Price Soviet Has Paid for East Bloc Conference
description: EAST BERLIN, June 29The Soviet Union has paid a certain price to get the leaders of 29 European Communist parties together in one room, ready to put their signatures to a single document.

title: U.S. TIES TO CHINA ARE REPORTED SET
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, June 30 (UPI)The Japanese newspaper Mainichi Shimbun reported today that the United States and China had secretly reached agreement on establishing diplomatic relations, which it said would become effected after the United States Presidential election in November.

title: DENVER RAIL PLAN REJECTED BY U.S.
description: The Urban Mass Transportation Administration yesterday rejected Denver's application for Federal funds to build $733 million 22mile light rail system connecting the city's downtown area to the foothills of the Rockies.

title: Marinaro Hoping To Fill Jet Vacuum
description: The main reason Ed Marinaro decided to play out his option with the Minnesota Vikings last season was that he considered himself a running back, with the emphasis on running. That was why he was glad to sign a oneyear contract with the New York Jets yesterday and why the Jets were glad to have him.

title: Manning PublicRelations Merger
description: It's turning out to be a big week for mergers in the world of public relations. Yesterday's activity was the announcement that the boards of Manning, Selvage & Lee (with estimated 1975 fee income of $2.7 million) and Bell & Stanton (with $892,000) had agreed to merge.

title: Bill on Alcoholism Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate passed and sent) to the White House today a bill authorizing the expenditure of $510.5 million over three years for the treatment and research lof alcoholism.

title: COOP CITY STRIKE OWED BY ACCORD
description: Governor Carey and leaders of Coop City residents reached a compromise agreement yesterday to end the bitter 13month strike during which most residents in the mammoth development in the northeast Bronx had refused to pay a 25 percent increase in maintenance charges.

title: SHERWOOD PROTHERO
description: NORWALK, Conn. June 29Sherwood H. Prothero of 18 Nursery Street, executive vice president of the Norwalk Chamber if Commerce, died Monday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Congress is Urged by Zarb to Permit Suspension of FuelOil Price Controls
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Administration moved today to dispel Congressional opposition to suspension of price and allocation controls for heating oil and diesel fuel.

title: Stevens Unit's Head Leaves
description: TRENTON, June 29 (AP)Richard J. Sullivan former State Environmental Protection Commissioner, has stepped down as director of the Center for Municipal Studies and Services at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. He was the center's first director and served one year. He will be succeeded by Dr. N. Peter Jurkat, who has been with the Davidson Laboratory at Stevens.

title: Television
description: 8:30 Daytime

title: Q.A.U. Worried Over French Territoryi
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, June 29.African guarantees for the lindependence of the French Territory of the Mars and Issas appears to be potentially the most divisive issue confronting African foreign ministers who are preparing an agenda for the Organization of African Unity meeting that begins here Friday.

title: IRE LOAN HELD WAY TO AID ITALY
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The potential help for a new Italian Government discussed at the Puerto Rico economic summit conference this week would be a huge supertranche drawing from the International Monetary Fund, it was disclosed here today by United States Treasury officials.

title: Strike Over, Air Service In Canada is Resuming
description: OTTAWA, June 29 (AP)Commercial airline service was being resumed in Canada today after pilots and airtraffic controllers submitted the disputeover the use of French as well as English in control centers in Quebec Provinceto a Government panel.

title: Riis Park is Closed To Water Activities Because of Sewage
description: Jacob Riis Park on the Rockaway, Queens, peninsula was closed to swimming and fishing at 4 P.M. yesterday after raw sewage and other debris were discovered in the water near the shore.

description: (In bushels, 000 omitted) Open

title: G.A.O. Assails Army's Plans for New Battle Tank
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The General Accounting Office has criticized the Defense Department for rushing into developent of a costly new main bat tank in the face of major uncertainties about the future of armored warfare.

title: Maine Pupils Spread America's Spirit
description: It played one night on Broadway and received a standing ovation. Costumes ranged from blue jeans to colonial knee breeches and were, for the most part, made by the actors who wore them. The cost consisted of 160 parents, teenaged students and teachers. America's Spirit had come to New York.

title: Aqueduct Softens Its Image
description: Unable to match Belmont Park in trees or flowers, Aqueduct will at least close the gap slightly today when it begins a 28day meeting.

title: About Real Estate
description: Miner Industries loves the Bronx. Eugene Swee was explaining why the other day.

Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, took conciliatory stand in his keynote address toward those seeking independence from Moscow's tutelage. The Communist leaders including Enrico Berlinguer of Italy and President Tito of Yugoslavia, attending his first international meeting since 1948. assembled to ratify a new declaration of principles as the basis of solidarity. title: Texas Judicial Nominee Found Guilty
description: HOUSTON, June 29 A nominee for a seat on the Texas Supreme Court, who apparently won the Democratic primary last month because voters mistook him for another politician, was found guilty of fraud by the state Civil Court today in a $117,500 bank stock transaction and of having been grossly negligent in his legal practice.

title: Albany Bill to Halt TuitionAid Abuse Passes Senate
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 30The Senate yesterday passed a bill to end what state officials have described as an abuse of the state's tuitionassistance programthe growing number of claims by college students that they are emancipated from their parents and therefore eligible for maximum scholarship aid.

title: But U.S. Official Says Some Abuse is Continuing
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Conditions for Americans prisoned in Mexican jails have, improved markedly in some respects since January, the Ford Administration told Congress today.

title: Notes on People
description: James G. Veneris, on of the last two of the 21 American turncoat prisoners of war who chose to go to China rather than be repatriated after the 1953 armistice ending the Korean War, has asked to return home for a family visit, and the State Department said yesterday he was free to do so.

title: Arab Drive to Arrange a CeaseFire Collapses Amid Rightist Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29Arab efforts to arrange a ceasefire and find a political solution that would end the civil war here have reached a deadlock.

title: Preparing an English Mixed Grill for Six
description: Six lamb chops, preferably rib chops or cut from a rack of lamb. The chops may be grilled as taken from a meat counter. Preferably, however, it is best to have the top bone cut away, leaving only the rib bone. It is also preferable if the ribs are prepared Frenchstyle, which is to say with the bottom of the rib bones neatly scraped. Brush lightly with oil, sprinkle with salt and pepper and set aside. When ready to cook, place on a hot grill, preferably charcoalfired, and grill, turning once, about three to five minutes or to the desired degree of doneness. Brush with butter before serving.

title: Bridge and Tunnel Tokens Sold to Cope With Strike
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority began selling 50cent, 75cent and $1 tokens at its facilities last night for use at automated booths, in response to the strike by its 650 toll collectors that began Monday.

title: GOODIIIMPS STAMP MARKS NEW OCTEI
description: The octet that Benny Goodman brought to Carnegie Hall for his Newport Jazz Festival appearance on Monday evening was almost completely different from the group with which he had been playing for the last couple of years. Yet the customary Goodman stamp was on everything it didthe ensemble flair on such old Goodman favorites as Avalon and Don't Be That Way. strong contributory solo work by Budcly Tate on tenor saxophone by Eddie Duran, a guitarist from San Francisco; by Mike Moore, a bassist, and briefly, the sound of the original Goodman Trio was heard when Teddy Wilson joined Mr. Goodman on piano for a few numbers.

title: Prices of Soybeans For July Decline; Other Months Gain
description: Soybeans for July delivery, dropped five cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but the more distant months showed gains of a few cents a bushel.

title: AsbestosLinked Diseases Protested at JohnsManville
description: CARSON, Calif., June 29An unusual memorial service and demonstration were held outside the JohnsManville plant here today for 12 employees of the factory who died of asbestosrelated diseases in the last 14 months.

title: Litton Tells Navy It Must Pay Costs Or Ship Work Ends
description: Litton Inclustnes iormauy notified the Navy yesterday that it would stop work Aug. 1 on four assault ships costing a total of more than $1 billion un less the Navy agreed to pay of further costs.

title: Books of The Times
description: I've never really understood before why subsequent generations ever felt it necessary to bowdlerize William Shakespeare why, for example, the 17thcentury English poet and playwright Nahum Tate saw fit to neaten up King Lear and supply with a happy ending, and why his adaptation became the standard acting version until almost the middle of the 19th century. I've always thought with the typical short  sightedness with which the present regards the pastthat this impulse to prettify arose from hypocritical piety or disdain for his audience on the part of the bowdlerizer. But now, after reading Herbert Lieberman's latest novel, City of the Dead, I understand little better that under certain circumstances it may prove necessary to draw the veil over particular developments in a story. For there are possibilities in Mr. Lieberman's plot that I regarded with a fear surpassing esthetic terrorthat is, while reading City of the Dead I became nervous not so much about the story he was shapingthough I was nervous enough about thatas about the kind of book he might be writing and the limits to which he would confine himself. Moreover, when all was said and done, I wasn't at all sure wouldn't have preferred a prettier ending.

title: POTASH CONCERNS INDICTED IN PLOT
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)I Eight major producers of potash, a principal component of most fertilizers, were indicted today on charges that they illegally restricted production and controlled prices of the chemical.

title: Wilderness Area Approved
description: WASHINGTON. June 29 (AP) The Senate today passed a bill creating a 392,000acre wilderness area in the state of Washington. The measure was passed on a voice vote and sent to the President for his signature.

title: Mystic Work Raises Image of a Tall Ship
description: MYSTIC, Conn., June 29The shipwrights at Mystic Seaport here finished hurriedly chiseling out a new 38footlong top mainmast for the crippled Gaeta Primeiro early this morning, an exercise in an ancient and dying craft completed just in time to allow the 93yearold barkentine to take her place in the tall ships parade on July 4 without the embarrassment of looking undressed. Later this morning the shipwrights, Willets. Ansel and Steven Watrous, and their crew fitted the mast on the Primeiro by hand in the harbor at Newport, R. I., using the same ropeandpulley system a ship's carpenter might have used for emergency repairs at sea 100 years ago.

title: People and Business
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, the city's Deputy Mayor for Finance since September 1975, will return to the J. C. Penney Company, from which he has been on leave, on Sept. 16 to resume his post as senior vice prey dent and director of finance and administration. Penney, the nation's second largest retail chain after Sears Roebuck and Company, moved yesterday to prepare for his return and to lighten his task.

title: Residential Values Up 29% in Month, Dodge Reports
description: With residential building contract value rising sharply, construction contracts in May totaled $9.83 billion, 2 percent below the level of May 1975, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems said yesterday.

title: No Word on Balloonist
description: No word was received yesterday on the fate of Karl Thomas, a balloonist seeking to make a sole flight across the Atlantic to Paris. But Wallace Clayton, spokesman for Mr. Thomas who started out from New Jersey on Friday, expressed a belief that he was moving safely eastward, veiled by a cloud cover that may be extending all the way to Europe.

title: N.C.A.A., Japan Slate Golf Event

title: Biggest Gain Since Last July Augurs Well for Business
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Commerce Department said today that the composite index of leading indicators rose 1.4 percent in May, compared with a seventenths of 1 percent rise in April. It was the biggest increase since last July's 2.8 percent and signaled steady expansion of economic activity in the months ahead.

description: Tenneco Inc., announced yeserday that it had raised its vholesale price for gasoline by cent a eallnn.

title: Breaking Up the Bulk of a Brick Box
description: It started off last spring as Miami Beach on top of a brick box. Now the design for the proposed apartment house at 800 Fifth Avenue at 61st Street, site of the Dodge mansion, has been altered drastically, and the new version will be presented before the New York City Planning Commission today. The project has been one of the most closely watched in recent memory, in part because there is so little else going on on New York's construction front now, but also because the building's site, between the Pierre Hotel and the Knickerbocker Club, is of crucial symbolic and visual importance to the entire city.

title: Miami Oil Spill Dissipates
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 29 (AP)The Coast. Guard said today that an oil spill discovered off the Miami area was dissipating and was not considered a serious threat to the area's beaches.

title: zzzZZZBOOMMM
description: As every fireworks buff knows, it was in a letter to Abigail Adams in 1776 that John Adams prophesied the anniversary of the signing of the Declararation of Independence would be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bells, and illuminations from one end of the continent to the other.

title: Bah Humbug
description: BRANFORD, Conn1976. Ah, yes. The Bicentennial of our nation's birth. In vainglorious reflections, we celebrate the freedoms that redblooded American colonists won for us in a confrontation with the vast British Empire. Americans were brave in those days. We fought for our rights. We earned world respect because we took no guff from the British or any one else.

title: Business Papers Seizure For Use in Trials Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court ruled today that the constitutional protection against selfincrimination does not prohibit the seizure of private business papers and their use as evidence against the owner in a criminal trial.

title: VOTE SPLIT ENDED BY PUERTO RICANS
description: WASHINGTON. June 29A dispute between two Democratic factions in Puerto Rico that could have erupted both inside and outside the forthcoming national convention was settled by compromise today in the party's credentials committee.

title: Film:'Old Gun' Misfires:French Doctor Turns Into Nazi Executioner
description: In "The Old Gun," a simple and possibly effective story has been ruined by mass of directional and acting self-indulgence.A French film, which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater. It is set in the last months of the German occupation of France. A doctor in a provincial hospital, a comfortable family man whose aid to the Resistance is a matter of careful balancing, turns into a one-man death squad after a group of drunken and demoralized German soldiers murders his wife and daughter.Prowling through the cellars and back halls of his chateau, where the Germans are bivouacked, the doctor exterminates them messily, one by one. His anguish and desperation are set in a framework of ironic futility: Even while he is going about his mission the Resistance has taken over the village.The movie has a cast, but for all practical purposes it seems to have only one actor in it: Philippe Noiret. Mr. Noiret is a decent actor; his performance as the soft, plump, comfortable doctor whose fire is betrayed only by tiny sparks until it bursts into conflagration is sometimes funny, sometimes moving. It is overdone at times.It is not, however, as horribly, crushingly overdone as the use of the camera by the director, Robert Enrico, makes it seem. The camera virtually never leaves Mr. Noiret's round; puffing face; when it does, it is only to take in a slightly larger view of his round, puffing figure. We are smothered by him.Mr. Enrico's major mistake, however, is in using what must be at least a dozen flashbacks to tell his story. Almost at the beginning, we meet Romy Schneider, as the doctor's wife, burned to a cinder. The flashbacks are a way of seeing more of her, but they are no way to make a movie.Once he has come upon his dead family, the doctor can hardly take a few steps or make a move without everything shifting back to scenes that range from a childhood hunt, to the courting of his wife, to a confusing moment during a village festival in which she takes refuge, for no apparent reason, in a cellar.Whatever coherence or interest the main action might have is shattered by the technique. The intention may be to render even more dreamlike and unreal the doctor's unaccustomed essay into violence; it becomes unreal, all right, and enormously irritating.

title: GlassyEyed Legislators Rush Slowly To a Garrison Finish of 1976 Session
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 30Fitful as it is, the rush to end the 1976 legislative session here at least has the benefit of dress rehearsals.

title: Leonard Kogan, 57, Psychologist, Dies
description: Dr. Leonard S. Kogan, a professor of psychology at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and director of the school's Center for Social Research died Monday. He was 57 years old and lived in New York City.

description: Government analysts said unofficially yesterday that the, labor contract promising General Electric workers a 33, percent wage and costofliving increase over the next three years appeared to be a little high, but they said they were just beginning to analyze the terms.

The young men drowned Saturday in the Hudson River north of here when two rafts they and three others were riding capsizd in strong currents.

title: CORRECTION

While the information did come from former C.I.A. agents, further investigation by The Times has led it to conclude that none of its sources are able to supply sufficient elaborating details to Justify, in the view of the editors of The New York Times, the impression left by till article.

title: Grandstand Seats for Op Sail
description: When some visitor from Conshohocken, Pa., climbs to a bleachers seat in Battery Park City to watch the modern world's greatest fleet of squareriggers in a parade of sail up the Hudson next Sunday, he may or may not care know that the last person whose bottom warmed that segment of planking was watching John Mahaffey hit into the water on the 18th hole and lose the United States Open era championship, whereupon Jerry Pate hit a 5iron over the water and won. That happened about sundown on Sunday. June 20. The next morning Gabe Rispoli's men were dismantling the 5,400 grandstand seats flanking the final hole on Atlanta Athletic Club's highlands course The Tinter and the 2,600 others overlooking the fourth, seventh, ninth and 12th holes. Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, seven trucks were hauling these stands to New York while other trucks brought in 6,500 seats from the lacrosse field at Johns Hopkins University Baltimore and 3,500 more from a Staten Island warehouse.

The Chicago Bulls, who finished with the worst wonlost record in the N.B.A. last season, will get the first chance at Gilmore.

Brown for a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, despite renewed criticism over his repetition of a remark he first made in 1974 that Jewish Americans have too much influence over Congress.

The program was Swan Lake headed by Natalia Makarova and Ivan Nagy.
